Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 16:27:48 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: H4 headlights ARE street-legal.

>The H4"s are a one bulb light. Cost apprx $65 a set.
>
>Both are halogen and illegal at least in calif. I think they are illegal 
>in all states because they are not DOT certified.

Hella recently have their H4 conversion kit DOT-approved - probably 
just by sticking on the three teats that are on the US headlights. 
Nowhere does the box say H4, it calls them HB2s. The kit is called Hella 
Vision Plus, and it's in a yellow and purple box. The bulbs ARE H4s... 
Philips, to be exact. It comes with 55/60s, which I assume are the max 
allowed by law.

I wouldn't be surprised to see them available in the parts store designed 
for the "unwashed masses", ie Nat'l Auto and Pep Boys. ;)

I just put a set in my 914, haven't really driven it at night yet, but they 
seem super-bright. (I plan on putting in some 55/100 watters soon.)

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 19:34:54 -0500
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: Re: Speedometer/Odometer Error

My 9171 911E spedeomter/odometer behaves exactly the same way!

I have 14" E Fuchs and 195/65 Yoko AVSi tires.

Most spedometer repair shops that specialize in VDO will recalibrate your
unit. I'm told thay ask you to disconnect the cable at the dash and carefully
roll the car for a small but exact number of tire revolutions and carefully
count the cable shaft revolutions. Armed ith this data they change the gears
in your spedo unit.



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 16:38:42 PST
From: calzia@mojave.wr.usgs.gov
Subject: Suspension travel

Hello

        Anybody know how to measure suspension travel on a 911?  After
removing wheels, shocks, and disconnecting anti-roll bars, it's easy to
measure full droop (=max rebound); the trick is to get an accurate (and
precise) measure of rebound (=max compression).  I have the car on jack
stands and started jacking up the front suspension until I started lifting
the car off the stands.  Seemed like the right thing to do until I realized
that I couldn't get the same reading twice and my measurements varied 3-5
cm from side-to-side (should be within a couple mm!).  Same results with
the rear suspension.  The problem is the subjective call on when all of the
suspension travel is used up and you start lifting the car.  Short of
putting the tub on the garage floor, I haven't a clue what to do next.  Any
suggestions?

Much thanks in advance

Jim
73 911S

used, but I can find out from the previous owner. I've got One Grand polish
and wax (carnauba). Should I use that? Is there something you're supposed to
do differently with a fresh paint job? I'd like as glossy a finish as
possible. As you can probably tell, I know next to nothing about paint,
polish and wax, so please don't hesitate to mention anything that may seem
obvious to you. (I'm not even sure what the difference in function is between
polish and wax.) But, hey, I'm learning! Thanks.

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 19:48:55 -0500
From: JonesWFla@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911: Adjustable spring pl...

I must agree with ehab, I have not had any trouble with my spring plates. I
also used the white greese he spoke of and had excellent results. He is also
correct in his statement about them not realy being designed for hight
adjustment. Make sure you know what you are doing when it comes to setting up
the rear suspension. I have seen a lot of people screw the alignment up. Make
sure your local alignment shop has the knowhow to properly set up your car.
If you ever plan to take your 911/930 to top speed, you better have some
confidence in your alignment tech. By the way, I bought mine from Sway-Away.
                                                          
                    William Jones
                                                                             
 1977 930 EURO

respond!

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 19:20:20 CST
From: "David Kelly" <dkelly@iquest.com>
Subject: Re: Try this with your fiche manuals...

>On Thu, 30 Mar 1995, David Kelly wrote:
>
>> Ahh. But its easy to Xerox the the expensive paper manual in the 3 ring
>> binders, make notes all over, get greasy, and file away for future reference
>> with working notes of just what was done.
>
>Ahhh, but its just as easy to Xerox the fiche at your local public 
>library on printing fiche viewers. If you're going to copy them anyways, 
>why not buy the cheaper source at $15 for fiche, $200+ for paper. The 
>fiche viewer was $10.
> 
>Worst case scenario you copy all the fiche onto paper at 25 cents a page. 
>$200/0.25=800 pages. I think there are far fewer than 800 pages in the 
>manual. The result is you get fiche + paper at a much lower cost.
>
>Joe '86 944

Ahhh, but the large size parts fiche does not fit in the viewers at my
public library. Doesn't even fit in the local microfiche shop's viewers.
None the less they managed to print the 928 parts fiche for only $43. 
The quality sucks, its barely readable. But at least its not on the curly 
paper the library uses.

Maybe its not readable as I purchased a 1985 reverse gear set for my 1983 
by mistake. Found out too late for refund. Nice $500 paper weights.
Anyone interested in a new set of reverse gears for a 928 5-speed? Exact
part number available on request.

My 928 manual set (8 volumes) cost $250 and is easily my best purchase
to-date.

Have you checked out the Euroselect catalog? Its got exploded diagrams of 
probably at least 95% of all the parts you would ever want to replace on 
a 944/928 up to '88 model year. Its also got all the factory part numbers 
listed. This will easily be one of my most valuable references.

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 17:46:47 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: NOT Removing 944 camshaft sprocket

On Fri, 31 Mar 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:

   I wrote: 
> > I've got an oil leak where the camshaft sprocket cover meets the cylinder 
> > head. The factory manuals and Haynes lack detail intructions on replacing 
> > the seal.
> >  
> > 1. How difficult is it to remove the camshaft sprocket? Is the allen bolt 
> > a pain to get off usually? Will I need a puller?
> 
> The allen bolt (actually a 12-point triple square) is one of the most
> difficult bolts on the engine to remove.


I now have reservations about removing the sprocket. I guess my question 
now is what are the drawbacks if I don't get this leak fixed? Will 
anything be starved of lube or is it simply a case of a little harmless 
oil leak (as long as it doesn't fall on hot or rubber parts).
 
Right now, I've wrapped a rag around the leak and this seems to control 
it fine. I don't  have to replace the rag more than once a year after it 
becomes soaked. I'd like to continue this practice if there's no harm to 
the engine.
 
Joe '86 944

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 23:13:58 -0500
From: StreakN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porsche stock

>Anyone out there know the symbol for Porsche stock?
 
Bill O'Connell - Riesentoter Region, PCA
 81 SC Pacific Blue - Der Luft-Klub fur Manner

The symbol varies from data system to data system, but on the Bloomberg
system, which is utilized in most buy and sell side firms, the symbol is
POR3. So to get a quote for the last trade plus the bid/offer, you'd punch up
    POR3 (equity) Q    

------------------------------

Date: 31 Mar 95 23:13:47 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Help for my mechanic

 
1. Oil isn't supposed to get on timing belts.
2. Oil degrades some types of rubber.
3. Timing belts are made of rubber.
4. If timing belt breaks, engine is likely to suffer extensive damage.
5. Have mechanic offer to put old timing belt back in for free. He may be
able to recover the cost, and then some, when the belt does let go.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 31 Mar 95 23:13:49 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Another miracle liquid

 
Herb suggests that perhaps I contributed to the Ventil Sauber stocks in the
Weissach cans.
 
Hate to say this, folks, but I was well aware of this insidious plot and
studiously avoided letting Them have any of my precious bodily fluids.
 
Pete

supposed to

>polish and wax, so please don't hesitate to mention anything that may 
seem
>obvious to you. (I'm not even sure what the difference in function is 
between

>

If paint is less than 3 months old do not use any on it yet. And only 
was with clean cool water. I use zymol on all my cars. More exp to start 
with but not in the long run as wax goes farther. You use a lot less.

Meguires makes excell products and are avail at all auto parts stores. 
Stay away from the pertrolium distillants use carnuba.


						mike

Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 01:52:22 -0500
From: HHeath3@aol.com
Subject: Porsche life in Salt Lake City

George Shea asked about Life After Chicago re: proposed move to Salt Lake
City.  I'm considered a newbie, having moved here in Nov. '90 (to be
considered rooted here, your ancestors have to have arrived by oxcart in 1847
with Brigham Young).  My comments, FWTW:

1. After 17 years in Minnesota, winter here is a cakewalk, and it's actually
warm enough to permit skiing at the 8 or 9 major downhill ski areas near the
city.

2. While there is less auto rust here than in MN, they do put *prodigious*
amounts of salt on the streets, sidewalks, parking lots, barrom floors, cats,
etc.

3. THEREFORE if you drive your car in the winter, it needs meticulous
attention to prevent cancer.

4. The combination of winter freeze/thaw cycles and blazing summer desert sun
beats the asphalt to S--T, so watch your alloys.  My 944 has cost me a few
fillings, but fortunately no wheels yet.

5. The mountain and high valley roads east of SLC are heavenly for the
Porsche driver (and the Porsche)-- highly recommended.  And in the southern
part of the state are some of the most highly-rated driving and sightseeing
roads on the planet, less than 4-5 hrs away.

6. The straight desert roads west of the city cry out for license-lifting
pedal-pushing.  In Nevada, not too far off, is the biannual open (legal)
high-speed solo race-- classes up to 140 mph or more, I read.

7. The PCA is very active in the unsalted months, with several slaloms,
tours, and parties.  I've only been to a few things, but folks seem friendly
and accepting.  As usual, I think the more you invest w/ them, the more
you'll get back.

8. Come take a look, and you won't leave the land of Saints (and Sinners,
possibly the more interesting inhabitants).

Ciao,

Hunter Heath

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 02:07:04 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Help for my mechanic

Greetings:

One of the first things I try to do with  new 944 owners is educate them in
the importance of belt maintenance.  I do this with a display of previously
removed valves.  (The "S" shaped ones have the best impact.)  Along with
these I have a cllection of belts.  Some with missing teeth, some oil soaked,
some broken.  Also have a variety of pulleys in varying stages of failure.
 With this and the mention of "$1500 to $2000"  the point is usually made.

The customer brought the car in for oil leak repair and when they were
repaired, felt he had been ripped off?  The cost of the cam belt is so
insignificant in the context of the repairs made it's laughable.  If the
customer maintained this attitude after a careful, detailed explanation of
the potential repurcussions of not replacing a belt in this condition,  your
mechanic would probably be better off without him.  I wonder what the
customers response would have been if your mechanic had *not* replaced the
oil soaked belt and it had failed.

A *good* customer, one who's truly interested in the health and well being of
his p-car, would have been grateful the mechanic saved him from a much more
serious problem.  Of course if he hadn't spent that $15.00 or $20.00 on the
belt he probably could have bought a set of curb feelers or perhaps something
really important like a couple of new 8-track tapes.

On a more serious note, no repair shop owner likes to think a customer is
unsalvagable, but it seems this one might take a bit of work.  Perhaps your
mechanic should put this customer in touch with a previous victim of "belt
neglect".  Usually conversation with someone who's "been there, done that"
get's the point across.

Pat Moyle

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 00:12:44 -0800
From: uo14@freenet.victoria.bc.ca (Eric R. Cherneff)
Subject: Fiche printing



A friend gave me an old set of 914 fiches that he "liberated" from a
dealer. I don't have a reader and don't plan to get one so here's what I did:

	-the fiche is printed in columns. If you cut it into strips 2
columns wide, can read them on a standard microfiche strip reader.

	-our local college has the latest type of microfiche reader which 
rotate the image and zoom in/out.

	-I set up the pages the way I wanted, which was 2 diagrams/2 parts
list per letter sized page and printed them at 10 cents a copy. The result
was quite readable, except for the scratches on the fiche itself. If you
have new fiche, this wouldn't be a problem.

As far as cutting up the fiche goes, I sure wasn't going to use it as is,
and they are hardly collectible (although I could be wrong here...) so I
didn't feel too bad cutting them up.

Eric
'60 356B
'75 914 2.0

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 15:23:15 +0200 (GMT)
From: Jarkko Antero Elonen <jelonen@vipunen.hut.fi>
Subject: Too low idle of 944?

My question concerns too low idle of my '83 944. When the car is
cold the idle is around 400 rpms and the motor dies quite 
frequently. When the motor gets to it operating temperature the
idle raises to about 600 but is still very rough. I have new
plugs, air and fuel filter, and I have inspected the wires,
rotor and distribitor cup, but these seem to be OK (or have I
missed something). I know there is a idle controller somewhere
there, but how could I inspect if its defective? Also other
points I should take into consideration?

Thanks in advance!

Jarkko

'83 944 black from California to Finland...

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 08:14:59 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Polishes/Waxes

OK, though my mechanical expertise is limited, (but expanding every
week........for 25 years! When do I become knowledgeable?) I do know
something about maintaining a paint finish - any paint finish.  My 914 has
won over 35 concours 1st places, including 2 Parades, primarily because of
its finish and luster.  There is not a treatment I haven't tried over the
years, unless it's under 6 months old.

My experience indicates that (get this), usually, the easiest is the best!  I
have a preference for Meguiars products, but others work just as well- if,
you wash you're car frequently.  No wax stands up to frequent washing (notice
the word WAX).  So, wax it frequently with a reputable wax.  Never, ever,
POLISH your car unless you have dead paint.  If,you'd like to discuss dead
paint, e-mail me.  In fact, if you can avoid it, never POLISH your car.
 Treat it properly when washing, wax it frequently, remove dead wax every
couple of years, and your finish will last 20 years or more!

Moreover, I never touch my concours car with a power buffer!  I do use one on
my other car, but my 914 gets waxed with bare hands (i.e., wax applicator is
my bare hand - no rags).  I'm an Aaccountant, so my hand are soft; my 911
keeps them dirty! I do not waste money on expensive trade names - they wash
off as quickly as J-Wax.  The key is taking care of your Porsche when you
wash it ( another topic).

Please, do not waste your $$$ on Zymole(sp intentional) or other cash crows
(sp intentional).  Not necessary - wash your Porsche properly, WAX it
frequently, polish it infrequently, and drive it.  Don't let it become the
museum pice that I have!

Pat Garvey

'72 914 museum piece
'73 911 pleasure car
'88 Audi pleasure car
'92 VW Passat - piece of absolute sh_t!

Date: 01 Apr 95 09:02:24 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Speedometer/odometer error

 
>Most speedometer repair shops... ask you to disconnect the cable at the
>dash and carefully roll the car for a small but exact number of tire
>revolutions and carefully count the cable shaft revolutions.
 
Palo Alto Speedometer asked that cars be rolled for a distance of 52 feet 9
1/2 inches or so, which is 1/100 mile (5280/100 = 52.8 ft = 52 ft 9.6 in).
 
I suppose you could estimate fractions of a turn well enough, but I did mine
a different way. I have test equipment that measures true road speed. I can
also clip an inductive pickup to the coil wire to get engine rpm. From the
engine rpm and known gear ratios, I can get tire revs per minute in top
gear. From the observed speed, I can get miles per minute. Dividing
one by the other gives tire revs per mile. I programmed the equipment to
calculate this internally and print it out every time a button was pushed. So
I just went out onto the freeway, drove along for a few miles, pushing the
button maybe half a dozen times at 60, 70, 80 indicated, and averaged the
results. They were all surprisingly close to each other, +/- 1 rev
per mile. I reported that back to Palo Alto Speedometer, they redid my
speedo, I checked it on the road and it's within 1 mph all across the range.
 
Doing this by rolling the car would have required me to be able to read
tenths of a turn of the speedo cable. I suppose that's doable. Maybe make a
round card marked off in degrees or 1/10 turn (36 degree) segments, tape it
to the speedo cable housing, make a pointer out of a paper clip or such, and
roll the car 1/100 mile.
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 01 Apr 95 09:46:31 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Too low idle of 944?

> My question concerns too low idle of my '83 944. When the car is
> cold the idle is around 400 rpms and the motor dies quite 
> frequently. When the motor gets to it operating temperature the
> idle raises to about 600 but is still very rough. I have new
> plugs, air and fuel filter, and I have inspected the wires,
> rotor and distribitor cup, but these seem to be OK (or have I
> missed something). I know there is a idle controller somewhere
> there, but how could I inspect if its defective? Also other
> points I should take into consideration?
> 
> Thanks in advance!
> 
> Jarkko
> 
> '83 944 black from California to Finland...

Sounds like a vacuum leak.  The idle controller on a 1983 944 is merely 
an auxiliary air valve, similar to those used on Bosch CIS cars.  Probably
not the problem.

Good luck

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 07:17:21 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: NOT Removing 944 camshaft sprocket

On Sat, 1 Apr 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:

> > I now have reservations about removing the sprocket. I guess my question 
> > now is what are the drawbacks if I don't get this leak fixed? Will 
> > anything be starved of lube or is it simply a case of a little harmless 
> > oil leak (as long as it doesn't fall on hot or rubber parts).
> > Right now, I've wrapped a rag around the leak and this seems to control 
> > it fine. 
> 
> Having an oil soaked rag that close to an exhaust manifold sounds a little
> bit dangerous to me...
> 
> I would fix it...

The rag isn't as bad as it sounds. It is tightly wound around the 
junction between the rear sprocket cover and cylinder head. It is made of 
surgical gauze and there are no loose ends.
 
BTW, I insulated my manifold by wrapping fiberglass insulation sandwiched 
by aluminum foil around each pipe. This has REALLY reduced the heat in 
that area and so far I haven't noticed any ill effects. The manifold is 
the steel-pipe header type, not cast. Any reson why this might be bad for 
the car?
 
Joe '86 944

Date: Sun, 02 Apr 1995 00:06:02 +0600
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: repost: questions re polish & wax (urgent)

David,

Mike Willis is correct in his precaution to NOT wax your car.  Wait at least 
three months (sometimes more) before using any product called WAX on your 
car (unless you know *specifically* that your car has a laquer job which is 
unlikely).  Although a new paint job feels "dry" to the touch it takes many 
weeks for the finish to "cure" and fully complete the chemical reaction 
which causes the paint to "harden".  You can use polish (those not 
containing any wax or "space age" polymers) and/or rubbing compounds on the 
finish during this curing period without harming the finish, but you should 
not need to as long as the car was properly painted (once again, assuming it 
is not laquer).  I strongly caution anyone using a machine buffer (on any 
car)  who does not have adequate experience.   When the time comes to wax 
your car, stick with a good quality carnauba wax and avoid the "space age" 
products.  I like Meguire's, but there are many high-quality brands.

Good Luck
Andy




>I was hoping I might get some other responses to my post about polish and
>wax, as I'm planning to do it this weekend (taking the 914 to AZ next
>weekend!). Anyone care to help? Thanks!

>and wax (carnauba). Should I use that? Is there something you're supposed to
>do differently with a fresh paint job? I'd like as glossy a finish as
>possible. As you can probably tell, I know next to nothing about paint,
>polish and wax, so please don't hesitate to mention anything that may seem
>obvious to you. (I'm not even sure what the difference in function is between
>polish and wax.) But, hey, I'm learning! Thanks.

Date: Sat, 01 Apr 1995 14:11:20 -0500 (EST)
From: "Dr. Jan Ringnalda" <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: Re: help your mechanic

Hi,
	Well although I didn't qualify on your list, I have done a lot of work on 
all types of cars.  Your mechanic's customer should sell his Porsche and by a 
bicycle.  I would state categorically that anyone who is too cheap to replace his 
timing belt (a less than $20 item) when the belt is removed for repair work 
anyway, does not deserve a Porsche.
	Oil impregnation will affect the belt, and your mechanic was absolutely 
right to replace it even if it had been renewed a week before the repair.
	Regarding the seals, They come in the form of kits usually, so Tim would 
have another problem if he had not replaced all the seals that came in the kit - 
undoubtedly another reason for cries of "rip-off" from the customer.  Sounds like 
this customer will never be pleased, no matter what Tim does...
	Suggest that Tim could have replaced one seal at a time until the leaks 
stop, but made sure the labor is charged every time, AND make the customer pick 
the seals that he wants replaced. THAT should shut him up.  On the other hand... 
Maybe not.  A total waste of time, this customer sounds like a complete **&hole.  
Hope this will help Tim, show it to the customer if you like, and give him my 
email address if he wants a follow up discussion.  Having been in this situation 
myself, it really winds me up.  Guess what would have happened if Tim hadn't 
changed the belt and it snapped in 5000 miles?
Good luck,   Jan

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 17:33:02 -0500
From: TimK913781@aol.com
Subject: Tire wear

Could you guys give me a hand with this?

My dad put Yoko A008Ps on his '87 911.  12K miles later, the rear tires are
shot.  Interestingly enough, the center of the tires are bald, while the
outside portions are fine.  Naturally, this leads us to believe that the
tires are overinflated.  Dad says that he keeps them at the factory
recommended pressure (36 psi) and has tried the old chalk trick, but can't
discern a difference in chalk wear with different pressures.  The car is a
daily driver and is not used in autocross or track events.

My questions are these:  Is 15K miles a reasonable life expectancy for the
rear tires?  Does anyone have a suggestion regarding the proper inflation of
these particular tires?  I don't think he's too disappointed in the mileage,
but the wear pattern is a little distressing.
 
Thanks in advance,
Tim Krone
timk913781@aol.com
'78 911SC, tires wearing nicely, thank you.

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 18:56:14 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Mail on flywheels and balancing

> I understand one of the easier ways to 
> improve performance is to use a lightened flywheel and pressure
> plate.  

Ummmm. You gotta define "performance" here. The car will accelerate and
decelerate *much* more quickly as the rotational mass will be reduced.
This will make *EXACTLY* **ZERO** more horsepower. It will just *feel*
more usable.

> Are there O.E.M. parts available?  

No. There are reproducations of things the factory used to make, and
there are odd bits of New Old Stock (NOS) that are suitable for particular
restoration applications, like factory specials. But nothing for the
"modern" street cars.

> Where would I get
> them from?  

You make them. Or rather, you pay someone to do this for you, or you buy 
from someone that has already made them under the assumption that someone
like you would wander by...

> What are the disadvantages with respect to cost
> and/or longevity.  

The car becomes significantly more difficult to drive in traffic. It won't
"maintain" as well, since when you let off the gas, the revs just drop
straight to low idle, no waiting. You have to adopt a very different
driving style as a result.

You can also get it too light, and have the flywheel go "boom", which can
be simply catastrophic. Remember, it's storing a huge amount of 
rotational energy...

> Is there any potential to damage anything?

See above. Not to mention damage from ham-handed machinists...

> 	Also, I've heard the list talk about getting these parts
> balanced.  Is this done staticly as individual parts, dynamically
> as individual parts, or dynamically as an assembly?  

The *BEST* thing to do is get all of the "moving parts" that go on 
the crankshaft balanced at one time. Everything gets staticly and
dynamically balanced then. Final test is assembly as a unit and dynamic
balnance as a unit.

> Where could
> I get this done in the Denver area?

No clue. Look in the Yellow Pages under "machine shops". It's helpful if
they've done this before. It's *VERY* helpful if they've done this for
either air-cooled VWs or Porsches -- a lot.

Stan

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 22:26:06 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Roadside Help

Many years ago,  when I joined the 356 Registry (which I have since left), a
movement was made to gather a listing of similarly-bent members from around
the country for area assistance when trouble reared its ugly head.  It was a
good idea, since these folks were diehards and would help anyone.

Just a thought - why not create such a group within P-philes?  It doesn't
matter what type of Porsche one drives, it's still the Marque.  Gather a list
of those who are willing to lend moral, technical, or directional support to
those who have problems while traveling in the repective area(s) with a
Porsche.  Publish the list each month, with the rest of the FAQ's and such.

I'm willing to head up the list, and upload each month.  The last thing I
want is to be stranded with a '73 911 or '72 914 in some area where Porsches
are unique, at best.  Would be nice to be able to call a friend, even if 100
miles away, for assisatnce in finding the right shop or tools to make an
emergency fix.

What about it - any takers?  Stan, Bart, etc., what do you guys think?

Pat Garvey

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 20:49:49 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Using P9201 tool on 944 timing belt


I found that there was no way of fitting the paddle of the P9201 between
the belt and the plastic rear belt cover without deflecting the belt
downwards thus causing an inaccurate reading. 

However, after I removed the timing belt idler and the chrome guard rail, 
I was able to position the tool farther down the belt for a better 
reading so nothing else was touching the tool and belt. The sliding 
paddle was directly above the water pump pulley.

Is this the correct procedure? In all the pictures I've seen of the tool 
in use, it was positioned higher. But there's no way of inserting the 
paddle without affecting the belt tension at this position.

Joe '86 944

Date: Sat, 1 Apr 1995 21:56:07 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: Help for my mechanic

>He replaced the balance and cam shaft seals and because the timing
>belt was oil soaked, replaced that also.  His customer is irrate
>because the timing belt only had 20k on it and thought he was being
>ripped off.  He also thought it was unneccessary to replace all the
>seals.

With the problem as described, the mechanic clearly made the correct
call in replacing the oil-soaked belt. Also, considering the amount of
labor required to get to the engine seals, replacing all of them if
only one failed is certainly justifiable.  If it were me, I would have
definitely resealed the whole front of a 96 Kmile 944 engine.

However, what we really have here is a failure to communicate.  Here is
how I think the mechanic/customer interaction should go:

1) Customer brings car in with report of a problem.  

2) Mechanic diagnoses problem and formulates proper repair
recommendation.

3) Mechanic calls customer on the telephone to inform him/her of
problem cause.  Mechanic recommends proper repair procedure, which, if
accepted and authorized by customer, is warranted for some period of
time (at least 6 months).

4) If customer declines the mechanic's recommended repair procedure,
the car is returned as closely as possible to its original condition.
The problem and recommended repair procedure are written on the work
order, together with the fact that the customer declined the
recommended repair.  The customer signs the work order, pays for the
time spent diagnosing the problem, and is handed his/her keys, free
to get a second opinion elsewhere or grenade his/her engine with an
oil-soaked timing belt.

It shouldn't be any more complicated than this, should it?.

 -Milo

Date:          Sun, 2 Apr 1995 08:47:43 -0600
From: "Terry Ferentinos" <Terry.Ferentinos@is.net>
Subject:       3.2 L Twin Plug Conversion Question

I have converted my 3.2 L ,87 enging to twin plugs and am using a 
distributor from the 3.6 L engine to distribute the spark to all the 
plugs (yes I am aware of the mod to the distributor to prevent 
premature belt failure)

My question has to do with how to set this system up with only one 
signal from the brain to fire the coil.
I am aware of the hybrid that Andial offers, but think that it is 
entirely out of my budget and want to explore alternatives. 

One of the concepts that we are exploring is to have the brain signal 
go to the stock 3.2 coil (as it does normally) and then take a 1 meg 
ohm resistor from that signal on the coil and send it to a CD box 
(already have one) to fire tanother coil. The theory is that the resistor 
will help to isolate the second coil from the first. 

I'm not sure that this is the best solution because of the number of 
parts involved (more prone to failures). What I would prefer is a 
single CD box or coiless system that can accept a single signal from 
the brain and send spark to both distributors. Does anyone know of 
such a beast or have any suggestions??

Regards,

Terry
