------------------------------

Date: Mon,  3 Apr 95 09:26:32 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; twin plug conversion question

From: "Terry Ferentinos" <Terry.Ferentinos@is.net>

>I have converted my 3.2 L ,87 enging to twin plugs and am using a
>distributor from the 3.6 L engine to distribute the spark...

>My question has to do with how to set this system up with only one
>signal from the brain to fire the coil.
I am aware of the hybrid that Andial offers, but think that it is 
entirely out of my budget and want to explore alternatives. 

>One of the concepts that we are exploring is to have the brain signal
>go to the stock 3.2 coil (as it does normally) and then take a 1 meg
>ohm resistor from that signal on the coil and send it to a CD box
>(already have one) to fire tanother coil. The theory is that the resistor
>will help to isolate the second coil from the first.

>Terry

     Terry, I have not familiar with exactly this setup...your idea may
   work but my concerns would be;
     1. IF the 3.2 coil is a "CD" type, then the primary is at 300-450
        volts, not 12 (I think they are, as my brothers 84 928 would throw
        a 3" spark across the distributor cap with a plug wire removed).
        Your 1 meg resistor might lower the voltage, but...
     2. ...a 1 megohm resistor and whatever stray capacitance is around could
        give you an "RC" time constant that is pretty slow, and would throw
        off your accuracy (the second spark would be late). This combined
        with the serial delay of the CD box itself -may- be a problem.
     3.  You have to change the DME prom to lower your advance, otherwise
        I don't see much benefit in twin-plugs and very possibly you'll
        reduce your power by combusting too soon.

     For the electricals, what might work is to;
      a. Find the "logic" signal that makes the spark (between the computer
         and the CD circuitry (if Motronic is CD-type).
      b. Go to 2, parallel ignition boxes (don't do the serial route). The
          GM/HEI module, Ford Duraspark or Chrysler box are cheap and good
          (though not CD).
      c. Find some way to modify your PROM for lower overall advance.

    The aftermarket Electromotive (HPV-3b) ignition does what you want, and
   is user configurable, but will cost about $1200 (they gouge on the price
   of the extra coils/drivers for a twin plug) and truly isn't as 
   sophisticated or refined as Motronic.

          Have fun--Lee

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 07:50:31 -0700
From: "jim gregory" <jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: 951 coolant system overflow

Tracy-

The same thing happened to me on my car. We replaced the secondary water pump
on the car (check this), bled the air out of the coolant system (definitely do
this) and the probelm persisted. We decided to pull the head and what it was
was the initial system of head gasket failure. Although this is not good news
to hear, there is a bright side--> it may be in the early stages of going bad
(mine was slightly starting to leak, only if "pushed", ie higher rpms) instead
of blowing out in a big way, dumping coolant all over the track and leaving you
to hitch hike home.

Brace yourself for a new head gasket (have it O ringed when you get the new one
put on) and cross your fingers that it one of the simple problems. If you
haven't had a head gasket blow yet, and if you have done a lot of drivers
schools and spirited driving, you may just want to save the "guesswork" expense
and just go for a new head gasket.

good luck

 -jim gregory

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 08:33:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: 89 C4 Oil Leaks Revisited

Yes - again with the oil leaks.  Hopefully Stan H. and Kevin G. and 
everyone else can provide some helpful insight.

Previously I wrote that I was getting an 89 C4 w/ 20k miles checked out 
when my mechanic (who hasn't seen many 89-newer cars) noticed oil leaking
from the cylinder-to-cylinder head joint.  He also noticed leaks from the 
cam towers (or cam covers - don't remember which).

The current owner was mad that his perfect car had these leaks so he 
called PCNA and had a Porsche Rep (Tim Quinn) look at the car.

This morning Tim, the current owner, and the car met at Jim Ellis 
(Atlanta Porscher Dealer).  Here's what the owner said Tim said:

1. The will fix the problem with the cam towers (covers?).
2. The say another leak in power steering and will fix that.
3. But that the cylinder leak is considered "normal" and they recommend 
NOT fixing it - even if you got a million bucks.  Tim says that the leak 
is caused by oil leaking through the gap when the engine cools.

Help !!!

Who do I believe?  Why is oil (that much) above the cylinder and 
"available" to squeeze through the crack left when the engine cools?  
Porsche Rep says it will not get worse - will it?

My plan is to digest whatever you guys say and if I feel still Ok with 
the car - get Franz Blam (Atlanta mechanic who's seen more newer cars) 
check the thing out.  The owner says he is going to get Tim's stuff in 
writing - even though I don't think it will carry much weight down the road.

Let me know what you think.

Scott Kelly (scokelly@netcom.com)

Date: 03 Apr 95 12:21:01 EDT
From: "Raymond M. Owen" <74223.2534@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 Suspension Tuning Perspectives

I understand that the best investment of my Porsche $'s is in making me a better
driver.  I have taken steps (primarily driver training schools and autocross
events) to hone these skills.  Having stated that, I would appreciate some
perspective from the masters on the appropriate steps to set-up my 1988 911
coupe up for better handling.  I have already invested in great tires with Fuch
7's on the front and 8's on the back.

My approach is in three phases, (naturally, driven by the ever dwindling balance
in my checking account).  The phases are shocks, followed by sway bars, followed
by torsion bars.  My questions are as follows:

1)  Is this the right order for suspension upgrades?  Does is matter if I
upgrade one sub-system prior to another?

2) Shocks - My understanding is that the 1988 911's use Bilstien's in the front.
I am unsure of the proper shock selection.  Bilstein's, Koni - Red, or Koni -
Yellow's?  My driving style and application is aggressive street driving and
autocross/time trials.

3) Sway Bars - I am considering Weltmeister 22mm front and 22mm rear.  Is this a
proper application?  I've heard of "Charlie Bars", is there any difference?
What is the stock sway bar setting on an 88 Carrera Coupe?

4) Torsion Bars - I am considering 23mm front and 28mm rear.  Is this an
appropriate application?  What are the stock torsion bar settings?

5) Am I completely nuts for wanting to do this?  Can anyone out there recommend
a shrink who would cure me of this insaitable obsession to pour all my money
into a peice of steel?

Date: 3 Apr 1995 09:59:40 -0500
From: "Arthur H. Kay" <ahkay@docserv.com>
Subject: Re: EMERGENCY: NEED HELP WITH BROKEN CONVERTIBLE!

Carlin,

There is a way to manually raise the top.  This should be detailed in you
owner's manual.  I believe it involves removing the two round trim covers
behind your rear speakers and then manually turning the crank with your lug
nut wrench (I hesitate to call it a tire iron because it is a two piece
assembly.

Good Luck!

 -Arthur

'90 944 S2 Cab

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 09:54:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Son Nguyen <snguyen@hydra.acs.uci.edu>
Subject: stripped spark plug hole in my 914...

Arrgghh!

I spend most of yesterday cursing at anything that was
in sight.  Generally in a real crappy mood.  

I haven't done anything yet since I've acquired the 914
about a month ago.  I've been spending all my time fixing up 
our pickup truck so we can take our dog along with us wherever
we go.  

So yesterday, feeling a bit guilty, went out and bought a 
set of Bosch Platinum plugs (should I use something else?).  

Anyway, the old plugs were Bosch Super.  The first plug
exchanged normally.  When I removed the 2nd, it didn't 
come out nicely.  I inspected the thread on the plug 
and it showed some shavings.  Then I spent the next
2 hours trying to thread the new plug in.  It wouldn't
no matter what.  It would go in 1/2 way and then get
REALLY stuck.  Every time I removed it, I found more
shavings so after a while, I just put it in and
left it there.  The car starts but all I did was drove
it up the driveway into the garage.  I was afraid to
even take it out for a test drive.

Please help, what should I do?  I'm afraid to take out
the other 2 plugs.  Should I "work" it in and out until
it seats all the way in?  I don't think it'll come flying
out since it takes some effort to get it in...

I've forgotten how much fun it is to do little things
on a 914 with that tiny engine lid...:-)

- --
Son Nguyen
snguyen@uci.edu

sig = P226


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 95 11:05:43 MDT
From: wendy@gita.lanl.gov (Wendy Schaffer)
Subject: 1988 924s


Hi,
        We are on the verge of buying a used 1988 924s with about 68,000 miles.
We haven't found any reviews of the car in the used car books, so we are desperate
for information. Can anyone tell us about the reliability/maintenance cost and what
would be a reasonable price for such a car (in good shape)? Also, what should we
look for when checking the car out, test driving it? And does anyone have any
recommendations for mechanics to check it out (in the Albuquerque area) or even
general suggestions, like whether we should have it checked out by a mechanic at
a Porsche dealer? Thanks!!
                                                Wendy Schaffer

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 10:17:20 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ for April


+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              +
+                   (last revised March 6, 1995)                      +
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It is posted regularly,
once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are undoubtedly
additions, changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited in improving
the FAQ.  Send any comments to the address at the end of the FAQ.

Changes this month include corrections submitted by several people.

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives?
  Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
  What about other Porsche-related WWW links?
  What about splitting the list?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  What is the Porschephiles Fund?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references are available for information about Porsches?
  Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

=======================================================================

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

     To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other 
administrative issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

     If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you
feel moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all
of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow
mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want to
convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

=======================================================================

Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          Principal, 
          Technology Tranfer Associates
          P.O. Box 2087
          Bellaire TX 77402-2087

          e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
          voice:  (713) 661-2084 

     His Porsches currently include:  
          '64 356 SC (daily driver)

=======================================================================

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

=======================================================================

Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?

     Beyond using normal good sense and discretion, you can submit
whatever you like that is relevant to Porsches.  You might want to use
descriptive "Subject" lines, including the model number when it is
relevant (e.g., "944 S2 Fuel leak query").  Your submissions would be 
easier for others to read if you make sure that your mailer wraps 
lines of text at 80 characters or less.

=======================================================================

How do I submit administrative requests?

     Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  

=======================================================================

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/archives.
Archives in six subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94, 95) each of which 
has the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or Stan
may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to mail you
archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY
mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program,
or equivalent, to restore to textual format.  Mac and Windows versions
of "uncompress" are available via FTP from /pub/porschephiles/programs.

=======================================================================

What else is available in the tta.com archives?

     FAQs: In the FAQs directory there is this FAQ and there are FAQs 
for specific Porsche models (so far there's one for 914s and one for 
the Carrera models -- feel free to contribute one on YOUR favorite 
Porsche).  These are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/FAQs.
 
     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where 
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If 
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>", 
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if possible.

     PCA racing info: The PCA Club Racing Newsletter is now on-line,
thanks to the tireless efforts of the editor.  This is available by FTP 
in the directory tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/ClubRacing.  The 
newsletters are available both in PostScript and in Windows Write 
format.  If this is useful to you, send your thanks to the editor, Tom,
at "tt911@ibm.net".
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     Logo contest: Several Porschephiles logos have been submitted;
check them out and choose one you like, or develop your own candidate.
Someday maybe we'll decide on a winner, and then we can have T-shirts,
coffee mugs, stationery, etc., made up.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

=======================================================================
 
Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
 
     Yes, WWW access is through http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html.
The FTP restriction above applies to major downloading of stuff from the
archives, not WWW access.  Suggestions for improving the WWW pages
would be welcomed, as well as experienced help in doing so.

=======================================================================

What about other Porsche-related WWW links?

     There are several WWW home pages related to Porsches, and more will
undoubtedly appear (if you know of any others, please submit them):  

     http://192.253.114.31/Stuttgart/Porsche/Porsche_contents.html -- 
     Porsche Museum (courtesy of an American High School in Stuttgart)

     http://warthog.cns.udel.edu/porsches.html -- "Delaware PCA Mosaic 
     Home Page"

     http://www.research.digital.com/CRL/personal/hawe/pca-ner.html --
     PCA Northeast Region home page

     http://tta.com/PCA/Carolinas/homepage.html -- PCA Carolinas Region
     home page

     http://www.vpm.com/pca-svr/ -- PCA Sacramento Valley Region home
     page

=======================================================================

What about splitting the list? 

     Various proposals surface now and then about splitting the list 
into components based on car model, activity types, or other divisions?  
Stan's reply to these suggestions is as follows:  

     "I just want all you Faithful Readers to understand: there are only 
two votes that count. Mine, and anyone who's willing to pay me to change 
my mind or operation or whatever.
 
     "Posted rates around here are $75/hr for automotive engineering 
projects, $125/hr for information technology consulting, and $2k/day for 
expert witness engagements.  Just so you know where the bidding starts..."

     In other words, the list *WILL* **NOT** be split.

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state/country of residence, their car's year and model, and
their net address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the
information, and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out
on a monthly basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't
send your Alfa Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send
submissions or changes to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Fund?

     From Bart Chambers, the custodian of the fund: "Here, gentle 
reader and Porschephile, is *The Problem*!  Porschephiles has over 1200
members and generates so much traffic and creates such a demand for
computer and bandwidth resources, that its future is in jeopardy if it
remains dependent upon the *ability* and willingness of any individual
to *donate* them.  In order to ensure the continued survival of
'Philes, we, like PBS, are asking members to donate to a non-profit
fund to be used to acquire the required resources, to be *owned* by
Porschephiles.  This will reduce the load on our beloved Listmeister to
merely backbreaking.  We are asking everyone for a *VOLUNTARY* Donation
for the survival of Porschephiles.  Send your check, made out to
`Porschephiles Acct# 3933150532' to Porschephiles Custodian, c/o Bart
Chambers, 1270 Lavall Drive, Davidsonville, MD 21035.  We suggest $50
for members, $15 for Students and $100 for Patrons.  Thanks."

=======================================================================

Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club of America.
          P.O. Box 10402
          Alexandria VA 22310
          Telephone: +1 703 922-9300

The main US Porsche club; see below for more information.

          Porsche Club Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End
          Northleach
          Gloucestershire
          England GL54 3HG
          Telephone: +44 451 860792
          FAX: +44 451 860011

The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          Porsche Owners Club
          P.O. Box 9000-277
          Seal Beach, CA  90740
          +1 310 784-5653.

Based in Southern California, the focus of POC is time trialing and 
racing.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone +1 313 558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $20 per year and cheap at twice
the price (The 356 Registry Magazine with Vic Skirmants' racing column 
is worth that, as are the classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be 
wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: +1 619 325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: +1 215 652-701 (day), +1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

=======================================================================

I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?

     The Club affiliates you with a local region based on where your
ZIP code falls on their territory map.  You *CAN* request to join a
specific region, and you can specify an affilate region or dual
membership in another region.  The local regions put on many different
events, some social, some educational, some driving or compeition
oriented.  The annual gathering of the whole membership, the Porsche
Parade, features competition for the national championships in many
events, seminars, a GREAT goodie store, and one of the most fun weeks
you'll experience.

     To join, you need to have a Porsche VIN number and be able to claim 
you're an owner, a co-owner, or hold a lease on a Porsche.  That may
seem restrictive, particularly if you want to join the club to get
access to Panorama, the club magazine, for purposes of FINDING a car...
In such case, it's suggested that you purchase a modest fraction of a
friend's car for say $5 or so, hence becoming a co-owner.  Just don't
tell them you did that or where you got the idea...

     Once you have a VIN number, there are four ways to join:

     1) Send a letter to the national office saying that you want to 
join, with your name, address, car info and a check for $36 to:

	Porsche Club of Americia.
	P.O. Box 10402
	Alexandria VA 22310

     2) Call them up at +1 703 922-9300, roughly between 9:00 to 5:00
EST (GMT - 6).  If you have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number
handy, you can do it over the phone.  (Otherwise, they'll send you an
application which you can mail in with your check.)  This is the FASTEST
way, and if you need to be a member *RIGHT NOW* to go to an event that
is members only, this is your best bet.  Don't count on using this
method the week of or before Parade...

     3) find someone active in your local region.  *MANY* of the regions
are represented on the Porschephiles list, so that's a good place to
start.  Once you have found someone, get them to put you in touch with
the local region membership chair, they can give you the form, and off 
you go.

     4) National membership chair Nann Weissenberger is also on the
list, and is reachable via e-mail at "nannw@aol.com".  She'd be more 
than happy to help you out.

=======================================================================

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     If you own a North American Porsche, Porsche Cars North America 
will, for a fee of $20, research the original bill of sale for your car
and give you a Certificate of Authenticity stating the facts and 
figures for the car as it was delivered to the dealer.  If you're 
interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  A similar service is
available in Great Britain from Porsche Cars Great Britain, for about
30 pounds Sterling.  Porsche AG can also perform a similar search.

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

=======================================================================

What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?

     The following list was extracted from _Illustrated_Porsche_Buyers_
Guide_, _Porsche_Specials_, _Cars_Are_My_Life_, _We_At_Porsche_, and
the article "Project Porsche, The Early Years" in the June '83 issue of
_Thoroughbred_&_Classic_Car_.  It includes only more or less complete 
automobiles designed by Ferdinand Porsche or by the Porsche factory.  
Components (engines, transmissions, etc.) have not been included.  
The list is incomplete, in part because there has apparently been 
imperfect record keeping at the factory.  In addition, the nature of the
list has changed over the years from an in-house listing of project 
numbers to a market-driven listing.  Additions and corrections are 
welcomed:

      "1" - Lohner-Porsche electric car, 1900; Ferdinand's first design,
            but not part of the "official" model sequence.
       7  - Wanderer passenger car, 1.7-liter, 6-cylinder engine, 1930; 
            the first official model, chosen to convey impression of 
            prior experience.
       8  - Wanderer 8-cylinder saloon design, 3.5-liter engine, 1931.
       9  - Second Wanderer 8-cylinder prototype, supercharged, 1931.
      12  - Zundapp small car, 5-cylinder radial rear-engined, 3 built.
      22  - Auto Union P-Wagen Grand Prix car, 4.3-liter, V16 engine, 
            1932-1937.
      24  - Zundapp three-wheel vehicle.
      27  - Mathis-Ford Saloon.
      32  - NSU prototype (Volkswagen forerunner).
      52  - Auto Union sports car based on P-Wagen GP car, 1934.
      60  - Original Volkswagen prototype, renamed KdF (Kraft durch 
            Freude, or strength through joy, by Adolf Hitler), basis 
            for the postwar Volkswagen, 1934-1941; the 60K10, a variation 
            of the 60, was a sports coupe built for the later cancelled 
            Berlin-Rome race, 1939. 
      61  - Another Volkswagen prototype, a narrower version of the 60.
      62  - Volkswagen-Kubelwagen (bucket car) cross-country prototype.
      64  - KdF-based sports car, 3 built, 1937-1938.
      65  - Volkswagen for driving schools.
      66  - Volkswagen for export, right-hand drive.
      67  - Volkswagen for invalids with steering column gear change.
      68  - Volkswagen Post office delivery van, model A, 1939.
      80  - Mercedes-Benz land speed record car, 44.7-liter V12
            Daimler-Benz engine, 1938-1939.
      81  - Volkswagen Medium Van, 1939.
      82  - KdF-based military Kubelwagen, 1939-1940.
      86  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen with 4wd, 6 built.
      87  - 4-wheel-drive version of Kubelwagen, 1939-1941.
      88  - Volkswagen delivery van on Kubelwagen chassis, model B, 1939.
      90 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      94 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      97  - Daimler-Benz heavy lorry.
      98  - Volkswagen amphibious car.
     100  - Panzer Leopard tank, 2 prototypes, 1939.
     110  - Volkspflug Small Tractor.
     111  - Small Tractor (2-cylinder engine).
     112  - Further development of 111 above.
     113  - Further development of 111 above.
     114  - F-wagen, 1.5-liter sports car prototype, 1.5-liter V10
            twin-ohc water cooled mid-engined coupe, 1938-9.
     115 -  1.1-liter supercharged Volkswagen mid-engined coupe, 1938.
     116 -  1.5-liter Volkswagen mid-engined coupe.
     128  - KdF-based amphibian Schwimmwagen, 1940-1941.
     130  - Tiger Tank (Jagpanzer) "Ferdinand".
     138  - Volkswagen Amphibious Car (version 2).
     155  - Half Track version of Kubelwagen.
     164  - Six-wheel lorry.
     166  - Volkswagen amphibious car (production version).
     182  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen (production version).
     187  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen 4wd (production version).
     205  - 180-ton Maus tank, 1942; two built, never saw action.
     245  - 18-ton multipurpose tank, 1942.
     293  - Caterpillar tractor.
     312  - Tractor with petrol engine.
     323  - 11-hp diesel tractor, 1946.
     328  - Tractor, 28 hp. engine.
     340  - Wheelbarrow.
     355  - Volkswagen delivery van.
     356  - The original Porsche sports car, the first to wear the
            Porsche name, 1948-1965; various engine and drivetrain 
            components and numerous styling variations existed.
     360  - Cisitalia 4-wheel-drive Grand Prix car, 1947-1948.
     370  - Cisitalia 1.5-liter sports/touring car, 1947.
     425  - 20 bhp diesel tractor.
     514  - LeMans car, also called 356SL, 1951.
     524  - Improved 356 prototype with mechanical injection, 1951;
            not economically feasible to take to production.
     530  - Experimental 4-passenger Porsche, 1951-1952.
     534  - Volkswagen Small sports car.
     540  - Porsche America Roadster.
     541  - Special sports version of 356.
     542  - Studebaker Saloon 1952-1954.
     550  - Mid-engine, 2-seat sports/racing car, the car that James 
            Dean died in, 1954; the 550A was a redesigned 550 with a
            tubular space frame, 1956.
     597  - Jagdwagen (Hunter) 4-wheel-drive vehicle, 1954-1955.
     621  - Porsche single-cylinder tractor (allgaier).
     622  - 2-cylinder tractor.
     623  - 3-cylinder tractor.
     624  - 4-cylinder tractor.
     633  - Studebaker saloon prototype.
     645  - Sports/racing car, "Mickey Mouse," 1956.
     675  - Small Volkswagen 1955-1959.
     691  - Porsche 550 RS (1956)
     695  - Porsche predevelopment (T7) for 911.
     702  - One man Helicopter.
     718  - Bergspyder sports/racing car (RSK), 1957; the 718/2 was a 
            1.5-liter single-seat racing car (F-2), 1959.
     726  - Volkswagen Saloon 1958.
     728  - Small Volkswagen 1957-1961.
     737  - Porsche outboard motor.
     753  - Porsche 1.5-liter 8-cylinder Formula 1.
     764  - Volkswagen 6-cylinder saloon.
     787  - Grand Prix car, 1961.
     804  - Grand Prix car, 1962.
     806  - Leopard Tank.
     814  - Leopard Tank.
     901  - Prototype 6-cylinder sports car, basis for 911, 1963; 
            changed to 911 for production because of conflict with 
            Peugeot numbering scheme.  6 prototypes built.
     904  - Mid-engine competition GT coupe, with various engines in 
            1963-1964, 100+ built, some for street use. 
     906  - Competition sports coupe (space frame), 1966-1967.
     907  - Sports/racing coupe, various iterations, 1967-1968.
     908  - 3-liter, 8-cylinder competition car, various bodies,
            1968-1970.
     909  - 2-liter hill climb spyder, 1968.
     910  - Sports racing coupe, different configurations, 1966-1968.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the 993.  
            Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Many engine variations have existed through its long life, 
            from the original 2-liter car to the 3.8-liter RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1966 through
            1969; 912E in '76 was a revival with engine from the 914.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6
            was a Porsche-built variant with a two-liter 911 engine
            inserted in place of the four-cylinder engine and other
            refinements.
     916  - Projected 2.4-liter version of 914/6, 1971.  Was apparently
            used in competition by the factory.  Also, a few examples 
            of an 8-cylinder (908-based) version supposedly exist.
     917  - 12-cylinder competition car, famous for Le Mans and CanAm
            victories; various iterations, 1969-1973.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine; updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain;
            has the best aerodynamic shape of any street Porsche.
     928  - The high-end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5-liter
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     934  - Group 4 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1975-1976.
     935  - Group 5 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1976.
     936  - Group 6 turbocharged spyder, 1976.
     937  - 924 Carrera GT.
     939  - 924 Carrera GT Le Mans.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four-cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5-liter displacement, except for a 2.7-liter
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3-liter 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     956  - GT racing car, loosely based on 911; 1982-1983.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative; 2.85-liter, four-valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive; not street-legal in US.
     961  - Racing version of the 959.
     962  - GT racing car based loosely on 911; used in endurance racing 
            and IMSA GTP; 1984.
     964  - The 911 Carrera 2 and Carrera 4, introduced in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992 with revised styling.  A 
            noteworthy feature is variable valve timing.
     986  - The Boxster, due in Sept. '96, the newest hope for Porsche's 
            future.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, introduced in 1994.

    1764  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1834  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1866  - Volkswagen successor.
    1906  - Leopard tank.
    1966  - Volkswagen small car prototype.
    2539  - "Save" ambulance.
    2567  - "Orbit" fire fighting system.
    2708  - Cart.

=======================================================================

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

=======================================================================

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

=======================================================================

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     BTDT = Been there, done that
      BTW = By the way
      EFI = Electronic fuel injection
      FAQ = Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
      FTP = File transfer program
     FWIW = For what it's worth
     IMHO = In my humble opinion
      IMO = In my opinion
      IOW = In other words
      LWB = Long wheelbase
      MFI = Mechanical fuel injection
      PAG = Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     PANO = Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
      PCA = Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     PCGB = Porsche Club Great Britain OR Porsche Cars, Great Britain
     PCNA = Porsche Cars North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PMJI = Pardon me for jumping in
      POC = Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     ROFL = Rolling on the floor laughing
  ROFL,PP = Rolling on the floor laughing, peeing in my pants (!)
     RTFM = Read the f**king manual (for some, "read the Ford manual")
      SWB = Short wheelbase
      TIA = Thanks in advance
     TTFN = Tata for now
     TTYL = Talk to you later
      WWW = World Wide Web
     YMMV = Your mileage may vary
      <g> = Grin
     <bg> = Big grin
    <vbg> = Very big grin
      :-) = Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to 
            "read" it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
=======================================================================

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     telephone: 714-957-3900
     FAX:       714-957-9332

     Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in 
     the US.  Catalog $6.00.


     Automobile Atlanta
     505A South Marietta Highway
     Marietta, GA 30060
     telephone: 404-427-2844
 
     The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
     prices.  Catalog $5.00.  (Also a 924 catalog?)

     telephone: 800-777-8881

     sister company to Weltmeister, whose suspension kits they carry.
     Free catalog.

=======================================================================

What references are available for information about Porsches?

     There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for 
you depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

     The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the 
technical articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of 
their Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's 
executive office.

     What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  If 
you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note: there's 
not much information about water-cooled cars; those with favorites 
should submit them to the name at the end of this FAQ.)

     Aichele, Tobias
     Porsche 911, Forever Young
     (translated by Pete Albrecht)
       ISBN 0-92975811-0
     Beeman Jorgensen, Inc.

     Anderson, Bruce
     Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
       ISBN 0-87938-269-4
     Motorbooks International

     Automobile Quarterly, Volume 9, Number 2 (Porsche is featured 
     marque, with 58 pages devoted to the man, the car, and racing)
       Library of Congress Card Catalog No. 62-4005
     Automobile Quarterly, Inc.
 
     Automobile Year, Number 41

     Barrett, Frank (ed.)
     Porsche Panorama, The First 25 Years
       ISBN ?
     Porsche Club of America, Inc.

     Batchelor, Dean
     Illustrated Porsche Buyer's Guide
       ISBN 0-87938-239-2
     Motorbooks International

     Boschen, Lothar & Barth, Jurgen

     Arco Publishing, Inc.

     (translated by Pete Albrecht)

       ISBN 0-929758-00-5

       ISBN 0-929758-01-3

     HCP Research (408) 727-1864
     (The "Maestro" has several other books available as well)

     HP Books

       ISBN 1879301032
     Top Ten Publications

     Porsche 356 Performance Handbook  
       ISBN 0-87938-417-4

     356 Porsche Technical and Restoration Guide
       ISBN 0-929758-10-2
     Beeman Jorgensen, Inc. 

     There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While 
the Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

=======================================================================

Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?

     This is Stan's response:  "Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE 
THAT ISN'T JUST PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil.  Or as Bruce 
Anderson commented about something else, "a cash flow device."  Slick-50
is *evil* if you have an engine with an aluminium case.  Guess what we 
all have, eh?  There is a bit of info on it via anonymous FTP in tta.com
in /pub/porschephiles/MiscInfo.  Additionally, many of these additives 
use teflon.  DuPont (the inventors of Teflon) have stated categorically 
that teflon is useless in such applications."
 
=======================================================================

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
 
     Yes. There are many luminaries in the Porsche world on this list.
If something is relevant to them, they'll typically respond to you
privately.  Their participation is greatly valued, so respect their
privacy and don't try to draw them out in the open.  If they want to
say something to the list as a whole, they'll do so.

=======================================================================

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

=======================================================================

Who maintains this FAQ?

     The FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil).  I have
a 1972 911T as my daily driver.  Anyone who wants to contribute should 
do so.  Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items are 
always welcomed.  I peruse the list for potential additions, but I don't
promise to find everything you might want in the FAQ.  Don't be shy 
about sending suggestions directly to me.

=======================================================================

Porschephiles #1297                         Mon Apr 3 16:01:07 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 10:26:01 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Good Bye friends....

I just want to comment on the situation Lou Nicotra describes, as it's
always sad to lose someone from the list:  

Lou wrote:"Well, the bean counters are after me.... Just been notified that
there
are going to start charging for mail that comes over the Internet. I have
been asked to remove my name from the list. I'm sure most of you know that
live in a corporate world know how it is."

I guess a lot of people on the list have Internet access through work, and
feel that they couldn't possibly afford it if they had to pay for it
themselves.  Depending on your situation, this may be way off the mark, so
long as you know where to look. I'm not an Intenet expert (see Stan for
that), but I can shed some light on the home Internet setup:

What you need:

1) a phone line
2) a computer
3) a modem
4) a (good) piece of software
5) an Internet provider
6) discipline to avoid spending all your time on the net

What it costs:

1: you already have one, I presume
2: if you already have one, great! O/wise $1-2k
3: no more than $150 for 9600/14.4k
4: $0-$100
5: As little as $18/month (unlimited use)
6: $0

Admittedly, if you  don't have a computer at home it's hard to justify
getting set up.  But if you do, or you've been thinking of buying one, the
prices are really quite reasonable, especially if you live in a large
metroploitan area where your Internet access provider is only a local phone
call away.

As an example, I use a Mac, a high-speed modem, Eudora (great software!)
and I pay $17.50/month for unlimited Internet access in the SF Bay Area. 
Plus, it isn't a distraction at work. It sure beats cable! :)

So for those of you who may be losing their list access through work due to
corporate purse-string tightening, or those who might like to use that
computer that's lying around idly at home, consult your nearest computer /
Internet guru (not me, please!) and enjoy the list from the comfort of your
home!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 10:26:08 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Antifreeze and racing (long)

David asks:

>Is it suggested to use the Red Line *only* for racing, or is it *better* than
>'regular' anti-freeze for every day driver?

Let me answer with some personal experience.

WaterWetter improves the ability of your engine's cooling system to shed
heat.  It's a rather complicated subject (a recent issue of MBCA's STAR
magazine had good coverage), and I won't go in to how it works. Just think
of it as something that helps transfer more heat from the combustion
chambers to the coolant. It also (now, in liquid form, NOT the "salmon
eggs" of yore) has corrosion inhibitors.

As an example of how good this stuff is, consider my experience with a 3.6
liter "big-block" BMW motor putting out (dyno'd) 275hp:

I used to run very high concentrations of anti-freeze (I know, I know) in
my motors because of my fear of corrosion (I've since stuck to 50-50 mix).
Anyway, at the time this motor was running about 90% anti-freeze
(Shellzone) and 10% distilled water, and it was running a wee bit hotter
than I liked (let's say at 5/8 of full-scale; sorry, I don't have a
calibrated gauge).  So I put a dose of WatterWetter in it, and went for a
test drive.  The engine overheated almost at once! The effect was dramatic
and unambiguous.

I wondered what was going on, as I limped home.  After some conversations
with RedLine I was able to confirm the (in hindsight) obvious - since
Antifreeze is a poor heat conductor (much worse than water), the
WatterWetter in the coolant was enabling more heat to get out of the
combustion chamber walls than the antifreeze could carry to the radiator
and get rid of.

The solution was to dump the whole mixture and start over, this time with
100% distilled water.  That gave a running temp of 1/2 of full-scale.
Adding WaterWetter brought it down to 1/4 (!). Then getting back up to
50-50 mix Antifreeze and distilled water keeps it at 5/16.

For about 5 years I've used a mix of 50% Shellzone, 50% distilled water,
plus a bottle of WaterWetter on all my water-cooled motors. Some are
all-aluminum (Alfa, Jag), and the others are iron-block, aluminum-head
(BMW, Mercedes).  In 150,000 miles I have seen absolutely no evidence of
corrosion - just the lightest white film on some water passageways.  I
don't see how the phosphate-free stuff would be better, but I may switch to
it for environmental reasons.  The WaterWetter definitely works for me, and
if I didn't have to worry at all about freezing temperatures I would run
just distilled  water and WaterWetter.

When I start racing (getting closer) my race car (an Alfa, sorry!) will run
distilled water and WaterWetter.

 ____________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman   aek@netcom.com  | 
|____________________________________         
| "The hour of noon has passed,"     |
|   said Judge Fang. "Let us go and  |  
|   get some Kentucky Fried Chicken."|
| Neal Stephenson,                   |
|  "The Diamond Age"                 |

580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 10:50:54 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ted Rodgers <rodgers@indigo01.akctr.noaa.gov>
Subject: RE: Wash, Polish, etc.


The articles you copied were originally published in the "Zundfolge", the 
monthly magazine of the Puget Sound Region, BMWACA.  The author, Thomas 
Nast is an attorney and would be extremely displeased that someone 
published his copyrighted article, unless of course you have permission, 
which I didn't see.  

Stan and others have discussed intellectual property rights on this forum 
several times.  I suggest you find them in the archives and read them.

Sorry to put a damper on what I'm sure was offered as a service, but it 
had to be said.  

Ted Rodgers



------------------------------

Date: Mon,  3 Apr 1995 13:54:18 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: stripped spark plug hole in my 914...

    Sounds like you get to have the fun job of fixing a 914....  I
personally would try to get a helicoil or something in there.  Hopefully
it's one of those plugs where you can actually reach the hole through
the sheetmetal (not one of those ones that's angled like a bitch..)  I
have heard several tricks for trying to get a helicoil in without
disassembling the negine... the one I liked the best was filling up the
cylinder with shaving cream through the spark plug hole - the idea is
that you crank the engine over before you put the new plug in and all
the shavings come back out.
    Never had to do this, though, so I can't give a full Nate's
TechReport.  I think this experience of yours is a pretty good
advertisement for that aluminum anti-seize stuff... that was one of the
first things I did when I got my car (remove plugs and put on goo.)  I
may sound like I'm selling the stuff, but I'm not.. just after too much
engine work and too many brake jobs I have realized that the stuff is
indispensible.

later,

Nate

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 11:34:37 -0800
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Tires

>While prepping my car for drivers ed this weekend I determined
>that my current tires are not up to snuff.
>
>I have to order this afternoon to get the tires to the shop by
>thurs am since that is the only time I can get in the shop
>before the event.
>
>I'm trying to pick between (listed in current preferential order)
>yoko AVS-I, Dunflop SP8000, yoko A008P
>
>I have an '82 911 targa which will see 2 track events and 2 autox's
>a year *TOPS*.  I want a good high performance street tire which
>will give me a good agressive but smooth ride and stick well, I'm
>not interested in shaving off 1/10ths of a second off my lap time
>(another 911 is on the boards for that maybe), and I don't want
>to have to buy two sets of tires and year.
>
>soliting input on my picks - esp diffs between the two yoko's
>
>I have eagle-gt's right now which I hate.  they're a real "hard"
>feeling tire but I don't feel they stick too well esp when the
>road is a little bumpy (all roads are bumpy in cinti.).

Martin,

I have had the Dunlop SP 8000s and Yoko A008P on my car and I like
the Dunlops much better. They are quiet and stick better than the
Yokos in the dry. In the wet they are much. much better than the
Yokos.

I friend of mine that has had the Dunlops and the Yoko AVS says the
Dunlop is better in the wet and much better in the dry.

The Dunlops wear at about the same rate as the Yoko A008P and a
little faster than the Yoko AVS.

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 15:48:36 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: stripped spark plug hole in my 914...

>>  I think this experience of yours is a pretty good
>>advertisement for that aluminum anti-seize stuff... that was one of the
>>first things I did when I got my car (remove plugs and put on goo.)  I
>>
Unfortunately, that recommendation is at odds with Porsche's that spark
plug threads should be clean and dry when installed. Using a lubricant
means that more of the tightening torque goes toward stressing the
threads, less toward overcoming friction. The obvious answer is to use
less torque, but then you have the problem of plugs loosening if a lower
number is used without lubricant, etc, etc.

Liked the shaving cream idea, though.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 15:19:52 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Break Squeal

Jeff,

>Does anyone have any recommendations on how I can get
>the dam brake squeal noise to stop on my 89 951 turbo.
>It is down right emabarrasing comming to a stop and
>here these things scream. I am willing to change pads
>so if there are some recommended pads to use I would
>appreciate some input. I am also going to try some of 
>the anti-squeal lube to see if that helps, does the
>anti-squeal lube get applied to the back of the brake
>pad?

What kind of brake pads do you currently have?  If they
are metalic they will tend to squeal on the street.
Several dealers advertised specials on Euroselect brake
pads in the latest Excellence.  You may want to try
some of these.  Officially, you can't get Euroselect parts
for your car, but your brakes are identical to the '88 951S.
I've had decent luck with the Repco pads for street use.

Yes, the anti-squeal goes on the back of the pad between it
and the caliper.  Never put anything between the front of the
pad and the rotor!  

Ross Stites
'87 951


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 95 16:21:09 EDT
From: weltyc@cs.vassar.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: April Porsching Column


Permission is given to use this material in any publication as long
as my name and affiliation are left intact.  If you can, send me the
issue.  Previous Porsching columns are available at
http://www.cs.vassar.edu/faculty/welty/porsching

PORSCHING  by Chris Welty
Hudson-Champlain Region

When You Wish Upon A Star - Part IV

Perhaps it was the sounds of Steve's rather psychotic girlfriend
(Jeez, I hope he isn't reading this) checking if the stove had
caught fire, perhaps it was Steve's foot in the small of my back, or
perhaps it was this magical force which had been trailing us, but
whatever the cause, John, Karl, and I were awake unusually early.
After showering and regaining full conciousness, I realized that a
nights sleep had wiped away our apprehension, and we were once again
filled with excitement.  We were not, however, filled with food.
After an initial look of horror from Steve's girlfriend at the
suggestion of breakfast, I ran around the corner to the police station
for some donuts. 

We spent much of the morning calling numbers on the lists we'd made
the previous evening, and making appointments.  Since Steve had left,
and his girlfriend had retreated to the bedroom to watch game shows
(after almost losing her hand reaching for a donut amidst the feeding
frenzy), we decided to make a few calls to Japan and Taiwan,
too. Actually, practical jokes were far from our minds at the time, we
were all focused most intently on the task before us. 

We each had our price range, and were naturally looking a little
beyond them as well.  Karl was hoping for a 78 or later SC, and I was
looking for a 73 or earlier S or T.  I didn't think I'd be able to
afford an S, and I was right.  Still, it didn't hurt to try.  By about
10AM, we had tried every number on both our lists, and headed out to
the now open used car lots.  These places were, almost without
exception, stereotype used car dealerships.  Counselor Troi from Star
Trek would have been screaming, "I sense deception!!" and
clutching her head in pain if she'd been with us.  In most cases, when
we politely pointed out falsehoods in such statements as, "never
been hit," and "totally original," the salesmen would back down.
One place, right out on Santa Monica, had such a high pressure sales
technique that we had to laugh in the guy's face.  He insisted that
Karl leave a deposit on a car, and we'd never seen it, in fact,
neither had the salesman.  We should have guessed this guy was a loser
after our exchange over an 80 SC in the lot. 

"How much for this car?" asked Karl.

"Eighteen thousand, but there may be some flexiblity in that.  The
car is, as you can see, mint." 

The three of us drew our breath in shock.  "Eighteen thousand?
Mint? It's been hit!" Karl said in amazement.  

"Hit?  Never.  Where do you think it's been hit?" said the
salesman with annoyance. 

"Right front and rear fender," muttered John.

"And what makes you say that?" the tone had turned condescending,
which for you novice salesmen out there is a real good sales
technique. 

"This is an aftermarket front fender, the paint isn't rippled
properly - there is no orange peel," said Karl, running his fingers
under the wheel well. I tried not to looked as confused as I was, it
seemed to me that if the paint wasn't peeling that should be good. 

"And there is a weld line right here where the rear fender was put
on," said John. Weld line, sure, I knew what that was, but I moved
over to check and make sure I could see it, too.   

The salesman inspected the weld and riposted, "It comes that way
from the factory."   

Now it seemed to me, as an outside observer, that if two guys were to
know enough to point out weld lines and paint rippling, that they
probably can't be bluffed.  At this point, a simple, "I never
realized it had been hit," or other clever lie could have easily
covered up the initial attempt at dishonesty, and make it seem as if
the dealer himself had been duped.  This had been the pervasive
strategy we encountered.  Sometimes the salesman would carry it as far
as thanking us for pointing these things out.  But here we had a
rather pathetic attempt at a bluff, which resulted in amused gapes
from the three of us.  Well, two of us, I was still trying to find the
peeling paint. 

"Well," he huffed.  "If you don't want this one, tell me what you want
and I'll find it for you." 

It was downhill from there.  After actually requesting a deposit on
this phantom car he promised to "find" (we later conjectured that
in dealer-speak this is slang for "steal"), he became so insistant
that we give him money that my ninja-type sixth sense began to tingle,
as it was getting pretty close to a stickup.  Our outright laughter at
his preposterous proposal finally wore him down, however, and he threw
up his hands in frustration and walked away - as if WE were at fault.

I shook my head and remarked, "What an idiot.  He probably didn't even
know what orange peel was!"  John and Karl nodded in dumbfounded
agreement.  It took us a few deep breaths to recompose ourselves
before we proceeded on. 

The excitement was now building again, and I was changing my pants at
almost hourly intervals.  After spending a disappointing morning in
the dealerships, we were on the road for our first appointment.  To
our surprise it turned out to be another used-car dealership.  In this
case we had expected it to be a private individual, and in fact the
guy Karl had spoken to on the phone had given this impression.  In
response to my rather accusatory tone, I was politely explained the
process of "consignments."  I learned a lot on this trip. 

The car we looked at was nice, it was an SC but there were numerous
mysteries about it.  John was quick to point out the lack of a true
Porsche VIN.  I was overjoyed at this moment, because I felt I was
starting to understand the process. The format of the Porsche VIN had
been the subject of one of the things I had read on the plane, and I
immediately recognized and corroborated John's analysis.  I was
quickly lost again when Karl pointed out the lack of a gamma device or
something that was supposed to come on an 1980 911.  I was still
trying to get the firing order straight (162435 had become my mantra.
I figured I needed some sort of mantra while I was in LA) and this guy
is noticing missing parts in the engine.  Finally we were able to
determine that it was a 2.7 litre engine that had been installed in
this 80 chassis. 

"Ah yes," I said, still completely mystified as to how anyone could
know an engine was 2.7 and not 3 litres.  "The 2.7 engines have a
tendency to overheat and warp. 162435"  

The dealer eyed me suspiciously, but John was nodding and I was
floating once again in the realm of the knowledgeable.  We drove away
from this lot proud that we were still on top of these bozos trying to
sell cars for what they weren't.   

Our next stop was our first dealing with a human being.  It was too
bad, though, because we had dismissed the car before we even met him.
We got out of the car, and I went to the door while John and Karl
attacked the car.  It was a red 911T, a 73, parked on the street.  It
was one of my prospects.  By the time the owner and I arrived at the
scene, Karl was sliding his head out from under the car, and giving me
the secret signal for a bad car (our secret signal was a complex
combination of semaphore and verbal signals which involved violent
shaking of the head, a disappointed clucking, and the words, "No
way"). 

Our host, clearly some cryptography expert for the NSA, cracked our
code in no time.  He was taken aback.  "What's wrong?  This car is
great!  Is there something wrong with it?  Tell me." 

Karl pointed at a round hole in the underside of the car. "The torsion
bar caps have somehow come off.  Your torsion bars could just slide
right out, not to mention rust.  I've never seen anything like it."

The owner looked confused and I saw my chance at showing off some of
my newfound knowledge.  "The 911, unlike most cars, uses torsion bars
instead of coilover springs.  162435." 

The owner glared at me like I was some sort of idiot, but he
coudln't bring me down.  We moved on. 

We finally found Orange county, which had been the location of many of
the appointments we had for the later afternoon and early evening.  We
had been having a lot of trouble finding it, but it turned out to be
the same color as the rest of LA, and this is what had been throwing
us off. 

We found a nice sized mall, which proved to us once and for all that
we weren't in another country.  The mall was centrally located to
all our appointments, not to mention an abundance teenagers.  These
kids were at that obnoxious age where they think that everything in
the world is sooooooo stupid except for their pathetic little social
circles.  We had fun laughing at their trivial little lives, after
all, we were buying Porsches;  Clearly everything else was stupid.
So, like, nya, nya, or whateverrrrr. 

The mall had everything we needed: payphones, fast food, and tables on
which we could spread out our maps and notes.   We established a base
of operations here, made a few more phone calls, and planned an
optimal travel schedule.  With luck we would see many cars that
afternoon.  I sank my teeth into a Big Mac and envisioned my new car.
I felt sure I would see it today.  Faint strains of music were
drifting over from a "film your own music video" shop.  Listening
carefully I realized it was Suzanne Vega. 



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 15:26:34 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: stripped spark plug hole in my 914...

> Please help, what should I do?  I'm afraid to take out
> the other 2 plugs.  Should I "work" it in and out until
> it seats all the way in?  I don't think it'll come flying
> out since it takes some effort to get it in...

This can become a serious problem. You need to timesert or helicoil the
head, and the only way you can get access to do that is to drop the engine
and usually you also have to take off the sheet metal. If you do that,
this is also a great oportunity to clean the engine up a bit, replace
the oil cooler seals ($0.75 parts with $300 labor charge attached if you
have to pay someone to do them with the engine still in the car), etc.

Also be very careful on this. The tiny metal shavings can stick to the pistons
and cause hot spots which can cause preignition or possibly burn the 
pistons. Not to mention the trouble you can get into if they stick 
between the valve and valve seat... Be *VERY* careful with this proceedure.

Stan

Date: 03 Apr 1995 16:27:00 -0700 (PDT)

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 15:39:55 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911 Suspension Tuning Perspectives

> I have already invested in great tires with Fuch
> 7's on the front and 8's on the back.

That's a good start.

> The phases are shocks, followed by sway bars, followed
> by torsion bars.  

> 1)  Is this the right order for suspension upgrades?  Does is matter if I
> upgrade one sub-system prior to another?

This is approximately correct. You'll get a synergistic effect if you do it
in this order, i.e. better shocks are needd for the better sway bars to 
matter, etc. Doing it out-of-order is not recommended.

> 2) Shocks - My understanding is that the 1988 911's use Bilstien's in the front.
> I am unsure of the proper shock selection.  Bilstein's, Koni - Red, or Koni -
> Yellow's?  My driving style and application is aggressive street driving and
> autocross/time trials.

Well, this is where it's time to insert the "so what do you *REALLY* want to
do" message. If you're going to drive the car on the track and at autocrosses,
there is the concept of "classification". Certain changes move you from one
class to another. Before you make *ANY* changes, be **CERTAIN** that you
understand the classification impact of the change, and that you can live
with it. For instance, you'd run in A Stock in SCCA. IF you change the
sway bars, you'll pop to A Street Prepared where you'll pretty much look 
like meat to the Scott Jessen's of the world. In PCA, your classification
varies by region. Most places, that would at least bump you up into Improved
and a few more points would have you running with the purpose-built cars...

Shocks are typically "free". You can use whatever you like. I personally
like Bilstein or Koni Yellow for full race cars, Koni Red for most
street applications, and (oddly enough) KYBs for 914s that are mainly
street with some autox. For grins, I ran KYBs on my 911 autox car for
a while. They're OK, but you need a new set once a year...

> 4) Torsion Bars - I am considering 23mm front and 28mm rear.  Is this an
> appropriate application?  What are the stock torsion bar settings?

That seems to me to be *AWFULLY* stiff for a street car.

> 5) Am I completely nuts for wanting to do this?  Can anyone out there recommend
> a shrink who would cure me of this insaitable obsession to pour all my money
> into a peice of steel?  


You might be. Here's the deal: it sounds like you've been reading too
many of the slick aftermarket catalogs and the slick magazines. You really
don't have to do all this stuff to be FAST; you don't even have to be
FAST to have fun. There's *NO WAY* that Joe Average can "buy" his way
into the winner's circle. I've watched some of the old timers lap the
field in race cars that I wouldn't have bought as parts cars. The main
thing is SEAT TIME. I'd spend every nickle I could on two things: make
sure the car is safe and mechanically sound to or exceeding factory spec;
then go to every event in driving distance. You ought to be able to hit
at least 3 autox events a month between PCA and SCCA unless you live like
in Pandale, TX, or something (look it up on a map and you'll see what I
mean...).

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 16:13:21 -0500 (EDT)

Porschephiles #1298                         Tue Apr 4 01:35:33 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 3 Apr 95 16:57:31 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Drivers' Ed & Insurance Problems...

>A friend of mine is having a problem with his insurance company & has asked me 
> for any info I can find. His message to me reads:
> "Our insurance company added a clause to our policy that excludes racing. 
> Despite the wording used, which refers to "pre-arranged competions," they say 
> that Driver's Ed is also excluded. I'm going to fight their interpretation, 
> but don't know how it will turn out. Do you know of any insurance companies 
> that will provide single event insurance for collision, etc? Could you check 
> with your "Internet buddies" in the interest group."

Contrary to what agents might say, the policy actually says what it covers.
Failure to pay valid claims is actionable, in much the same way that
attempts to file fraudulent claims is actionable, but you should realize
that the insurance company has lawyers (and perhaps judges) on retainer.
You would be far better off dealing with an insurance company that is 
familiar with the actual meaning of the language in their policies - these 
can be hard to find, but it's better than having to depend on a court 
to understand and correctly interpret the policy... Good luck!


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 16:48:29 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Rent a Porsche for the track!

Hi,

I do not have any connection to this business (except friendship)
and am providing this info as a public service.

    Lots of people would like to drive a Porsche at a race track, or
actually run in PCA or SCCA racing, but do not want to use their own
Porsche because of several reasons (paint chips, tires, wrong model, race
preparation, etc). There is an alternative to driving your own car - you
can rent a Porsche!

    Customer Driven Motorsports in Connecticut has a 911 Carrera
which can be driven at PCA driver's education, and a 944 Turbo which
is race-prepared and can be driven in any event including PCA club
racing and SCCA road racing (and the 944 Turbo is really fast this year!).
Both of these cars are safe and well prepared.

    Any of the Northeast tracks are available. Ralph has a new HUGE
motorhome which you have full access to, and will instruct you himself if
you desire. He has an SCCA and PCA racing license and is a PCA instructor.

   You can call Ralph evenings (before 9:00PM eastern time) at (203)
828-5930.
I think this is a relatively inexpensive way to find out if you really want
to get into track driving, or to do more serious driving if you are already
experienced. EMAIL me your snail mail address and Ralph will mail you
more information.

Regards, Mike Piera  AnalogMike@aol.com  '72 911S  '73 914/2.0

just fine although my special tool alarm was sounding...

Anyway, is there anyone in IL or willing to let me pay the shipping
that has this "special tool?"  Is it *worth* it or should I just
use my pipe wrench again?  I've been holding off on the struts long
enough and now the time has come...

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 14:48:53 -0700
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: RE: H4 headlights ARE street-legal.

>     You might compare the actual patterns, too.  Even though the bulb may 
>be the same the pattern might not.  The Hella H4 pattern on my 944 are flat 
>and ramp up on the right side with all the useful light being below this 
>line.  The HB2's may be some compromise for DOT approval, but I don't know. 
> I've seen some Hella lights advertised in various magazines, etc. and the 
>lens pattern does not look the same.    

Well, I can't compare, per se, since I have nothing to compare against, but they 
do quite a job lighting up the roadway. The lowbeams have a noticable gradient - 
bright light down low, and a very distinct, narrow lighter beam above it. The 
high-beams seem to be pure light. The faces of the lenses are almost flat, very 
unlike the standard sealed-beam curvature.

The box does have pictures showing the light patterns, but I'm not sure if I have 
anything showing the euro pattern. I'll have to check.


- --

| jeffk914@ix.netcom.com                        Do the dumb things        |
| Scottsville, NY, USA                                  I gotta do."      |

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 17:00:38 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: AOL Users - Searching FTP - HELP

> How do I uncompress?  (IBM PC / Windows)

You need the uncompress program which can be found in 
ftp://tta.com/pub/porschphiles/programs/uncompre.exe

> How do I search the archives? Can this be done without downloading them?

Nope. Not at this time. I'm working on it, but it takes time, more
disk space, faster processor...

Stan

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 95 15:18:25 PDT
From: Ehab Aljandali <ehab@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: 911 Suspension Tuning Perspectives




	Hi;


> 1)  Is this the right order for suspension upgrades?  Does is matter if I
> upgrade one sub-system prior to another?
>
	I think so.

 
> 2) Shocks - My understanding is that the 1988 911's use Bilstien's in the front.
> I am unsure of the proper shock selection.  Bilstein's, Koni - Red, or Koni -
> Yellow's?  My driving style and application is aggressive street driving and
> autocross/time trials.
>
	
	If your shock are bad, then replace with OEM or any quality shocks.

 
> 3) Sway Bars - I am considering Weltmeister 22mm front and 22mm rear.  Is this a
> proper application?  I've heard of "Charlie Bars", is there any difference?
> What is the stock sway bar setting on an 88 Carrera Coupe?
>

	Welt front transmit a lot of road noise, I recommend 21-23 mm for FR. I
believe you can get OEM ones. I recommend adjustable rear sway bars. This gives
you the best dollar value. Your stock sway bars are 18mm FR and 21mm RR I think.
Don not know about Charlie bars!
 
> 4) Torsion Bars - I am considering 23mm front and 28mm rear.  Is this an
> appropriate application?  What are the stock torsion bar settings?
>

	I think your ok here, may be 21 mm FR?
Your stock torsion bars are 18.8mm FR and 25mm RR.
 
> 5) Am I completely nuts for wanting to do this?  Can anyone out there recommend
> a shrink who would cure me of this insaitable obsession to pour all my money
> into a peice of steel?  
>

	Your are a certified P-nut. I recommend NO shrink at all. You are very
sane and wise to buy a 911 and dump monye into it. Better than drugs or Alcohol!
This is the most fun per dollar for any pleasure IMHO.

	Ehab.

 
>
