Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 19:16:38 -0400
From: DMoore356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Good Bye friends....

It should be remembered that there many of us out here  post and clear
messages at our own expense and on our own time already.  This means, of
course, that messages (many) are posted at no cost to the poster but cost
those, like me, to clear those messages.  If it were costing everyone,
brevity and restraint might be more in evidence.
It seems perfectly reasonable to me that institutions who pay for the service
have the right to ask that users reinburse or refrain from using the service
at work and during working hours.
I know this will not be a popular view but it is  logical.

Denis Moore

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 16:24:25 -0700 (PDT)
From: Dan Brown <danb@acme.csusb.edu>
Subject: Re: Correct way to say ....

On Mon, 3 Apr 1995, April Lambert wrote:

> 	What is the correct way to say Porsche?
> 
> 	Is it with an "ah" sound on the end or not.

	German, unlike English, doesn't have silent trailing "e"s.  Thus, 
the ending "e" in "Porsche" is pronounced--the "ah" sound.

 --
 Dan Brown, KE6MKS
 danb@acme.csusb.edu -- finger for PGP 2.6.1 public key
 Don't Tread on Me

The use of rear tail without an appropriate front spoiler will cause the 
front wheels to get light. This happens at over 120 as with my carrera. 
Turbo tail no front lip type spoiler.

You also need addtional downforce in front.

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 20:06:50 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 oil cooler question

Hi,
I've got an '83 944.   It had the familiar milkshake in the  H2O.  I knew it
was the seals but kept on driving...just couldn't stop myself.  Long story
short,  replacing the seals is very easy and would've saved me countless
hours filling and flushing to get all the oil out (including the heater
core).  Everythings fine now.

JUST DO IT!

Phil Carr
Austin, TX
'83 944
'65 MG Midget
'70 BMW R60/5

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 17:31:46 -0800 (PDT)
From: sham@acsc.com (Carlos Sham)
Subject: Re: ?Honest Mechanic in O.C.

>

>  have a reputable mechanic look at it for me.  Can anyone recommend one
>  in the Orange County, CA area?
> 
>  =->Roger

Roger,

I took my car once to Automotive Pit Stop in Sherman Oaks. Hans and
Dieter took care of car very well. Knowledgable, patient, yet reasonably
priced. Their number is 818-784-5197.

Since you will be driving a Carrera, it won't take you too long to
get to LA anyway. :-) I've asked about recommened mechanics in LA a 
while back, here is the kind responses from the group:

(note: info referenced/copied without permission)

	"I don't know if this is close enough to you or not, but I have used 
	Larry Brown at Autobahn West (28236 Dorothy Drive, Agoura Hills, CA 
	91301, (818) 889-1245, at the Chesebro exit from the Ventura Freeway) 
	for the last 5 years or so."


	"AL HAFNER TUNING(Meticulous Porsche Care) 1711 LaCienega Blvd.
	(LaCienega & Airdome) 310-652-6178, ask for Bob, it's his place.  
	I frequently stop by with any little problem that comes up and he 
	will take the time to check it out, sometimes even putting it up 
	on the rack just to take a look.  If you love your car this is 
	the place. Good luck!"


	"Have had previous experience with PorscheShop (or is it Factory?) 
	in Marina Del Rey area - it has been a few years tho'.  Now using 
	Scientifc Automotive in Pasadena with no complaints."


	"The garage I take my car to is Lomita 911 Services.  Owned by 
	Dieter Shoepflin in Harbor City 310-534-3631.  Dieter is excellent 
	technically and he is the MOST honost business man I've delt with.  
	I've used him for the past 8 years.  Some other friends I know have 
	been using him for the past 20 years."

You may want to check-out the January 94 archive too.

Carlos

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 20:38:01 -0400
From: Russ930@aol.com
Subject: Re: Drivers' Ed & Insurance P...

John, in MA all ins. co. have to play by the exact same rules, so with this
in mind let me tell you what happen to me last year and how I handled my
mishap.
     While driving in a drivers ed event I got a little loose and as the car
came around the car behind me clip the rear bumper and exhaust pipe.  The
force was enough to cause the left rear qt to buckle, plus the damage to my
muffler and rear bumper.  The damage to the car that clip me was a lot worse.
 Starting at the drivers door and back including his left rear wheel and
quarter.  (Note:  At the same event a 944 went into the wall broadside)  I
made a point of getting all the event papers including insurance papers from
the organizers that detail this event as a Drivers Ed. Event and submitted
them along with my accident report.  Apox. 10 days later I call the Ins.
Co.(Arbella) to see when they are going to send a check.  The claims adjuster
tells me that they have to look into this in more detail since I was on a
race track they fell that I may have been racing.  I tell her that this is
fine and I will check back with her in 2 days.  When I call back I am told
that the claim is being denied because this type of accident is not covered.
 When I ask her to what exclusion she is refering to, she tells me that the
policy does not cover racing. When I asked her how she came to the conclusion
that I was racing she said that since I was wearing a safety belt and a
helmet that it was racing.  I asked her if she had read the mat'l that I had
supplied, and she said that she had but because it said that the word racing
was not to be used then I must have been racing.  After some debate I told
her that I knew of a claim that they had paid under the exact same
cirumstance last year and that if she would review that claim then maybe she
would reverse her decision.  The alterative would be a 93A law suit filed by
me. (93A in MA allows you to collect 3 times your damages plus atty fees.)
 She said she would look up the claim and for me to call her back in a couple
of days.  I should note here that the claim I am referring to did require a 93
A action to resolve.       When I did get back to her, expecting her to now
reverse her decision she told me that she was still rejecting my claim
because that were not the same.  When I asked her what was different about the
 2 claims she said that in the other claim the driver was alone.  I told her
that he was not alone (Bridgehampton) and that the circumstances were exactly
the same, she claims that had they know that they never would have paid the
claim.  I asked her what other drivers on the course had to do with it, and
she said that since it was suppose to be a drivers ed event there should not
have been any other car on the course.  I asked her if she had gone to
drivers school when she was getting her license and she repled yes.  I then
ask her if they had closed down the local roads and highways while she was
being taught, she said no, but she still didn't get the point.
     I told her that if she didn't reverse herself that once I filed the
court action that I would not accept just the face value of the claim.  She
said that she had already talked to the company atty. and that she was holding
 her ground.  I filed the claim and the day after they recieved notice they
settled saying that I still wasn't covered but that they were making a
business decision.  I settled for double the claim without going to court. 
This whole action took from Sept. 94 to Feb. 95.  There were a lot of
conversions that I left out, but would be glad to relay if anyone would like
to call me.

Russell
617-269-9551 EDT till 4PM

P.S. Remember that 944 that went into the wall at the same event that I had
my mishap at.  The same Ins. Co. insured him. He had his check within 15 days
without any hassle.

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 22:27:38 -0400
From: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com (Lou Krieg)
Subject: Re: 944 oil cooler question

>Phil writes:
>>> Hi,
>>> I've got an '83 944.   It had the familiar milkshake in the  H2O.  I knew it
>>> was the seals but kept on driving...just couldn't stop myself.  Long story
>>> short,  replacing the seals is very easy and would've saved me countless
>>> hours filling and flushing to get all the oil out (including the heater
>>> core).  Everythings fine now.
>>>
>>> JUST DO IT!
>
>So, my question for the wisdom of the porschephiles is this:
>
>Should any 944 owners be thinking about changing these seals as a
>preventative measure (so it doesn't happen, say on the way to the
>Parade), or ???
>
>Pat
>pat@ixi.saic.com
>'86 944 rally car (with lots of miles and lots of original stuff)


Funny you should suggest this...since my water pump seized at last year's
Parade on the way from the hotel to the Autocross site....sounds good in
theory. I wished at the time the courteous NY state policeman was radio-ing
for a flatbed that I had just changed my water pump!

(Hot tip...if you do not have a "towing eye" for you pride and joy, get
thee to a Porsche dealer and order one to keep in your tool kit in the car
when travelling (just in case). Plus, I find I almost never need the piece
of emergency equipment I have, and always need the one I don't have! They
are the ONLY way to safely tow a p-car onto a flatbed).

Also reminds me of a (serious) proposal I read about: during WWII there
were a few imprompty appendectomies on US submarines performed by
pharmacist mates (read people trained in basic first aid--not surgeons!)
because of appendicitis striking during a war patrol (usually about 60 days
long). So the proposal was to remove all submarine force crews' appendixes
to eliminate the chance of appendicitis! Needless to say, this was never
implemented...

My sense is that the cooler seal failures are not predictable, and you
might as well wait until the failure to replace them. I have not heard of
anyone replacing them as a prophylactic measure, but it is a novel
idea...any other opinions among our more mechanically experienced 'philes?

Hope to see you at the Parade..

  --Lou


____________________________________________________________________
Lou Krieg                         '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
PCA Green Mountain Region         '90 VW Corrado G60 Tornado Red
Internet: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com      '95 Grand Cherokee V-8 Moss Green

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 22:28:48 -0400
From: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com (Lou Krieg)
Subject: Re: 944 oil cooler question

>Phil writes:
>>> Hi,
>>> I've got an '83 944.   It had the familiar milkshake in the  H2O.  I knew it
>>> was the seals but kept on driving...just couldn't stop myself.  Long story
>>> short,  replacing the seals is very easy and would've saved me countless
>>> hours filling and flushing to get all the oil out (including the heater
>>> core).  Everythings fine now.
>>>
>>> JUST DO IT!
>
>So, my question for the wisdom of the porschephiles is this:
>
>Should any 944 owners be thinking about changing these seals as a
>preventative measure (so it doesn't happen, say on the way to the
>Parade), or ???
>
>Pat
>pat@ixi.saic.com
>'86 944 rally car (with lots of miles and lots of original stuff)


Funny you should suggest this...since my water pump seized at last year's
Parade on the way from the hotel to the Autocross site....sounds good in
theory. I wished at the time the courteous NY state policeman was radio-ing
for a flatbed that I had just changed my water pump!

(Hot tip...if you do not have a "towing eye" for you pride and joy, get
thee to a Porsche dealer and order one to keep in your tool kit in the car
when travelling (just in case). Plus, I find I almost never need the piece
of emergency equipment I have, and always need the one I don't have! They
are the ONLY way to safely tow a p-car onto a flatbed).

Also reminds me of a (serious) proposal I read about: during WWII there
were a few imprompty appendectomies on US submarines performed by
pharmacist mates (read people trained in basic first aid--not surgeons!)
because of appendicitis striking during a war patrol (usually about 60 days
long). So the proposal was to remove all submarine force crews' appendixes
to eliminate the chance of appendicitis! Needless to say, this was never
implemented...

My sense is that the cooler seal failures are not predictable, and you
might as well wait until the failure to replace them. I have not heard of
anyone replacing them as a prophylactic measure, but it is a novel
idea...any other opinions among our more mechanically experienced 'philes?

Hope to see you at the Parade..

  --Lou


____________________________________________________________________
Lou Krieg                         '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
PCA Green Mountain Region         '90 VW Corrado G60 Tornado Red
Internet: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com      '95 Grand Cherokee V-8 Moss Green

Date: Mon, 03 Apr 95 23:13:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Help for my mechanic


Hi Clint,

I concur with what the others have written regaring oil on the timing belt. 
 I
would add, in case no one else has already, that it is very common for
the cam and balance shaft radial oil seals to leak, and that when they do
so, they really ought to be replaced.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 21:15:38 -0700
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: Using P9201 tool on 944 timing belt

Joe writes:
>However, after I removed the timing belt idler and the chrome guard rail,
>I was able to position the tool farther down the belt for a better
>reading so nothing else was touching the tool and belt. The sliding
>paddle was directly above the water pump pulley.
>
>Is this the correct procedure? In all the pictures I've seen of the tool

I remove the idler pulley, for exactly the reason you describe.  I
have not found it necessary to remove the pump rail though.  Are you
working from above (by removing the air filter box and air flow
meter), or trying to do it from underneath?  The former approach is
much easier, at least on the turbos.

 -Milo
'86 951


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 21:37:06 -0700
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: 944 Camshaft Seal & Gasket Replacement

John writes:
>2.  Can the seal replacement be done in situ or must the camshaft housing
>be removed?  How about for the rear gasket?

I was able to replace the rear cam housing gasket on my '951 without
pulling the entire housing.  It is basically just a matter of removing
the three bolts (probably 10mm) that hold the cap (and engine
transport hook) on.  The clearance is pretty tight, but patience and
lots of wrench repositioning will do the trick.

Although it was a few years ago that I made this repair, I still
remember being thrilled by the fact the replacement gasket only cost 87
cents, which was the least expensive part I had ever purchased for the
car.

 -Milo 
'86 951

Porschephiles #1299                         Tue Apr 4 12:08:28 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 4 Apr 95 10:24:05 +0200
From: kevinh@hasler.ascom.ch (Kevin Holden)
Subject: Re: K-Mart Quality

> Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 22:45:08 -0600 (CST)
> From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
> Subject: Re: K-Mart Quality
> 
> > I concluded that Kenmore may have been made abroad (Mexico, or some such).
> > Could a similar situation be the case for auto parts as well?
> 
> Geeze. OK, guys, this is Business 301 -- Private Label Merchandise.
> 
> Vendor X has manufacturing capability for 100,000 units of Item Y per
> month. They have retail capacity for moving 65,000 units per month.
> Cost per unit is relative tothe total number made. Margin per unit is 
> thus higher if they can make that extra 25,000 units a month.

[snip]

> 
> And so it goes with any generic product, any store-label product, or for
> that matter, any high-demand product that a vendor might want to make sure
> they have a second source readily available for.
> 
> No "seconds" bins that go to K-Mart. No "Made in the People Republic
> of Vergaak" mystery parts. Just good, simple business practices.

It's not quite like that everywhere... Companies I knew of in the UK
particularly made oil for a certain vendor totally dependent on price, additive
pack, viscosity additives etc. Agreed they probably used the same base but 
the characteristics of the oil were not the same as their standard product. 

On the other hand, Halfords (major chain of parts/accessories shops) is owned by 
Castrol and they certainly use GTX and re-package it under the Halfords name.

So what's the conclusion, there is none IMO. Generally, you pays yer money!
(unless you have insider info :-).

 > P.S. How the hell did any of you people get to the point where you 
> could afford these cars anyway??? 8{)

Overtime :-)

Kevin.

Date:      Mon, 03 Apr 1995 18:05:48 -0500
From: "Chris Alexander" <chris@smaug.synapse.net>
Subject:   Photos of Porsches

Corel has a photo CD available that has some really good shots 
of Porsches in racing livery at speed.   I think rumour has it 
that Copeland is a big Porsche-fan. 

Cool pictures of a 904 and a also a 917 coming down the "esses" 
at Laguna.   _Lots_ of 911s.   Kewel!

If anyone cares about such things it is well worth the $20 or so 
that they are asking for it.

Couldn't get the chessy Win16 binaries to install on NT properly 
but the images are in .PCD format anyway so it doesn't matter 
what OS your running provided you can read .PCD files.   The CD 
is also usable with Mac (w/ binaries?), at least the manual says 
so.

These are not pro quality .pcd files, it's only consumer grade 
(3072x2048? res) images.

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 06:56:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: 944 balance shaft seals - How?


I'd like clarification on what is meant by 'replacing the balance shaft 
seals'. Correct me if I'm wrong but here is my understanding of how the 
seals work:

  Front   ----..   .. 
         |----||   ||   ____||    |
         |----||   ||  |    ||    |
         |----||   ||  |    ||    |    ---> Balance shaft
         |----||   ||  |____||    |   
         |----||   ||       ||    |
         |----||   ||
          ----'' 
           A       B      C       D
 
A = Bal. shaft sprocket   B = shaft seal    C = spacer   D = polyester seal
 
1. To replace the seals, is it just a matter of replacing B, C, and D?
  
2. The manual mentions using a speacial tool (P9202) to drive in seal B? Is
   it really necessary? Is it easy to remove the seals once the sprocket is
   off?
 
3. Are there any special procedures for assembly? Haynes mentions putting
   assembly lube on the spacer and the manual mentions putting special oil
   on before inserting the sprocket. It also recommends the use of Loctite
   574 for the bolt. Are these all really necessary?
 
4. Can the seals and spacer be bought separately? I choked when I heard 
   the price of the seal kit was $150 - $190 cdn. I believe the kit 
   includes seals for cam, 2 balance shafts, crank, plus 3 metal spaces, 
   and 1 infamous camshaft bolt (I guess they expect you to strip the old 
   one). Can anyone confirm?

Any help would be appreciated.
 
BTW, I'll probably document all my experiences when this is all done.
 
Thanks.
 
Joe '86 944

------------------------------

Date: Tue,  4 Apr 95 09:07:07 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; efficacy of tails on 911

>From: gt2bfree@postoffice.ptd.net (LG Schwartz)

>I'm certain that this subject has been dicussed a million times but...bought
>a '88 Carrera Coupe last fall and noticed that over 100mph the vehicle
>becomes somewhat, uh, airborn...exactly how effective are the "tails",
>either the regular "carrera-style" or the turbo version in countering this
>aero-tendency...

>Later
>'88 Carrera

    The statistic I remember is that a tail adds about 400 pounds of
  downforce at 150mph (that was for the early turbo tail, not for the
  3.3 "tray" tail). A tail probably looks better than 7 sacks of mortar
  mix on the rear end...

     Probably for most speeds, the tail is purely cosmetic. IMO on a targa
  they look bad (with the wraparound glass, a tail makes the back look
  awkward) but on a coupe they look good. I also prefer the early turbo or
  carrera tail over a the tray type on a non-flared car...but I like Yellow
  too (and beauty -is- in the eye of the beerholder....).

        -Lee A

Date:         Tue, 04 Apr 95 11:02:43 EDT
From: Archie <SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU>
Subject:      914-4 Normal Operating Temp

I recently put an oil temp gauge in my '72 914-4.  The temp gauge reads from
about 10 o'clock to 2 o'clock with the red portion of the dial at the 2
o'clock position.  I have taken the 914 out for drives in the country and
at about 60 mph, it takes about 15 miles for the oil temp gauge to reach
a stabilized position with the needle pointing at approximately 1:00 on the
gauge face.

Questions please:
  1.  Is it normal to take this many miles at this speed to reach normal
      operating temperature?
  2.  Is the (approximately) 1:00 position correct for normal operating
      temperature on a 914-4 using oem gauges from a 1974 914?

Thanks in advance for your response.

Archie T. Smith
East Carolina University
Department of Sociology, Brewster A-412
Greenville, NC 27858 (919) 328-6147
Bitnet: SOASMITH@ECUVM1 Internet: SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 10:47:09 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: Should I sell ?

>A few years back I bought my first car, a 1970 911t.  Since that day I 
>eat, breath, and well you know, Porsche.  However, I am only 22 years old 
>and it has come time for me to go back to school ( Queen's Arts '94, Cha Gheil 
>fellow alumnus ).  I think that I can survive the upcoming financial 
>crunch and still keep my precious.  But my monetary situation would be 
>eased with an extra several K in my pocket.
>
>For a 70 911t my car is in really good shape and all original.  Obviously 
>I have many years to make my mark and plan to drive only 911s until the 
>day I die.
>
>My question is, should I go for the financial security now and get 
>another 911 later, or should I live in squalor and keep the 70 ?

This is something that you'll have to decide for yourself in the
end.  But, I can tell you what I'm doing in a similar situation.
I'm quiting my job at the end of the summer and heading off to 
school to pursue my final graduate degree.  I managed to pay of
my Porsche a couple of weeks ago.  At one time I thought it would
be best to sell the car when I head off to school, but now I've
decided I'd rather not live without it.  

The logical arguement for keeping your Porsche is that your Porsche 
shouldn't loose value over the next few years, assuming you keep 
it in good shape.  If things get tight enough you should be able 
to sell it fairly quickly, though you may have to take less than you
think it's worth.  The biggest question in this case is can you afford 
to maintain it.  (This is what student loans are for, right:)

>p.s. I've been eyeing a 83 911sc as a possible replacement.

If you can use the SC as a daily driver this isn't a bad plan, but 
I would think it would take a bit of $$$ along with the value of
your 911T to get a decent SC.

>Any help would be very much appreciated.

Like I said above, in the end only you know your financial ability.

Good luck,

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 11:53:47 -0400
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: PCA Driver's Education (Long)

All-

Okay, up front, if you think it is a waste of your time reading about the=

virtues of PCA driver=92s education, or you somehow think it is not worth=
 the
time/money/effort and slight risk, stop here.  Because what I have to say=
 has
had to wait three days for me to wipe this giant =93Silly Grin=94 off my =
face. It
just won=92t go away after spending a day at my *first* driver=92s ed eve=
nt at
Bridge Hampton Race Track in NY.

First off, let me thank all the people on the list who have me advice goi=
ng
into the event.  Several things stuck with me, and if anyone is heading t=
o

y, a
thermal shirt, T-shirt, Turtle Neck, Sweat Shirt, Wind Breaker, Jacket, H=
at &

aster,

next.  Your car can do it, it=92s just finding out how to let it happen. =

amateurs

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 11:31:19 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Fuel Hoses

        My 74 2.0 has two different kind of fuel hoses.  One kind is
grey plastic (?) and has a large-ish ID.  These lines go from the hard
lines in the center tunnel to the fuel pump, from the fuel pump to the
RHS fuel rail.  The other is black rubber (again, ?) and has a smaller
ID.  It connects the two fuel rails, and connects the LHS rail to the
cold-start valve.  I forget which kind goes to the guel pressure regu-
lator.
        I'm replacing all the fuel hoses ("shipwright's disease").  Is
the grey hose the "good stuff"?  Should I replace it with the same
thing, or with the black hose?  Or with some third alternative?  I want
to avoid the engine fires the 914 was infamous for.

- --DD

Date: 4 Apr 95 12:48:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: 944 CV Joint FAQ Entry (Preliminary)

Greetings fellow Porschephiles

Finished cleaning, repacking, and swapping my 944's CV joints last weekend, a project 
that I had started the weekend before but ran out of time.

In response to several requests I have written up a FAQ entry on CV joints, and
hereby submit it for consideration.  Criticism, suggestions, and erratta would be 
appreciated.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine, nice clean, greasy CV joints

Preliminary 944 Constant (CV) Velocity Joint Maintenance FAQ Entry

Q:	What are CV joints and where are they located?

A:	CV Joints are similar to the universal joints used on some cars.  
	They connect the transaxle to the axles and the axles to the drive 
	wheels, transferring power while allowing for up and down motion
	of the suspension.  If you look under the rear of your 944 you will
	see black rubber boots on the either end of both axles.  These boots 
	enclose the CV joints, and keep the grease that lubricates them from
	running out.

Q:	What maintenace do CV joints require?

	The rubber boots protecting the CV joints should be inspected at each oil 
	change, and replaced if any cuts, tears, or damage is noted.  A leaking boot
	will allow the grease to run out, resulting in very rapid failure of the CV 
	joint.  Replacement of the boot requires removal of the boot, but is well 
	worth the effort.

	The joints should be periodically removed, cleaned, inspected, repacked
	with grease, and reinstalled.  In addition, some people recommend switching
	the joints from left to right and vice versa on a periodic basis.  This is
	due to the fact that wear on the joints tends to be directional, based upon
	the loading imposed during forward travel.  By swapping the joints to even 
	the wear their life can be extended.  Since new CV joints from Porsche cost
	approx. $150 each and there are four CV joints this seems like a worthwhile 
	idea.

A:	How do I know if my CV joints are bad?

	The most common sympthom is a clicking noise heard from the rear of the car,
	especially during cornering.  The noise will usually come from one side only,
	usually the side opposite the direction of the turn.  If you have any doubt, 
	take them apart and check them out yourself.

Q:	How long does it take to remove, clean, repack, and reinstall all four joints?

A:	First time, budget 7-8 hours, barring too many problems.  Will take considerably
	less time with practice.  The process is not difficult, provided the proper tools 
	are available (see below) but patience is required, especially in the cleaning 
	stage.

Q:	What is the CV Joint Removal/Cleaning/Inspection/Replacement procedure

A:	The Haynes 944 book has a very good description of the process, and it should be 
	consulted first.  If you don't have it, get it!  

	Tools required:

	8mm 12 point Allen head socket
		Note:	This tool is available from Performance Products, Automotion 
			and other sources for about $20.  Your local auto parts store 
			may carry a cheaper version for about $6.50.  The cheap 
			version requires you to use your own 8 mm socket, but is nice
			because it is about three inches long, to help clear the 
			rubber boot when removing the CV joint bolts.
	Breaker bar
	Torque wrench capable of measuring 30 ft/lbs
	Slip joint pliers or large vise grips
	Various sized sockets
	Hammer
	Punch or screwdriver
	Scribe (carbide-tipped)
	Parts cleaning tray
	Parts cleaning brushes
	External snap ring pliers (Snap-On part number PR-40, $22.95 or equivalent).  
		NOTE:  	External Circlip pliers (for clips with holes) may work, but 
			only with extreme difficulty and much cussing.  The correct type
			of pliers has two undercut metal tabs facing outward that hook
			under the ends of the ring and expand it like this:

				 *		 *
				  **	       **
				   **         **    <-----Tabs - rectangular   
				   ***       ***		 cross-section, not round! 
				********* *********
				********* ********* <-----Plier jaws
				********* *********
				********* *********

	Consumables:

	Solvent (mineral spirits)
	Spray brake cleaner
	Rags/paper towels (lots!)
	CV Joint grease (moly based grease, available at auto parts stores)

Procedure:

1.	Raise the rear of the car and support it securely with jack stands or ramps.
	Disconnect the battery and chock the front wheels.  

2.	Put car in neutral with	parking brake off.

3.	Clean all dirt, oil, and mung from center recesses on the 12 point allen head
	bolts holding the CV joints to the transaxle and wheels on one side of vehicle
	using spray brake cleaner and a pick or nail.  Mark axle with scribe to indicate 
	which end is inboard.

4.	Hold wheel from rotating with foot while using 8mm 12 point allen head socket 
	and breaker bar to just loosen all six bolts holding CV joint to transaxle, 
	rotating wheel as necessary to bring each bolt into position.
		NOTE:	If bolts are very tight, apply parking brake or put car in gear
			to hold wheel, loosen bolt, then release brake and put in neutral 
			to rotate wheel for each bolt.

5.	Repeat step 4 for bolts holding CV joint to wheel hub.

6.	Back 5 of six bolts on each CV joint out completely.  While supporting CV joints
	back out remaining bolts and carefully remove CV joints/axle assembly from 
	vehicle.

7.	Place assembly on newspapers on a clean, flat surface.

8.	Work around metal collars holding boots to joints with hammer and punch or 
	screwdriver to gently separate collars from joints.

9.	Wipe grease from ends of joints, and mark across axle, inner, and outer races
	with scribe to mark orientation of parts (IMPORTANT!)  Make one mark on inner
	joint, two on outer, to identify parts if they become separated.

10.	Use snap ring pliers to remove snap ring on end of axle.  Or, use circlip pliers
	to spread ring, small screwdriver to pry ring up, mouth to curse, and eyes to
	watch where ring lands if you are lucky enough to get it off.

11.	Push axle out of joint with thumbs, or if necessary drive out using a hammer
	and a small socket.

12.	Work concave washer off axle using slip joint pliers or vise grips (see illus.
	in Haynes book).

13.	Carefully pull boot off axle.

14.	Disassemble joint by tilting inner race until inner race, ball bearings, and 
	retaining ring come out.  Keep parts together and label inner or outer and pass.
	or driver side.

15.	Clean all parts with solvent and brushes, including boots (if being resued) and 
	axles.  Take your time and do a good job.  Some greases are incompatible.  Unless
	you KNOW that you are using the same formulation of grease as was in your joint
	previously, try to get rid of ALL the old grease.  Save solvent for proper 
	disposal.

16.	Dry all parts thoroughly, removing ALL traces of solvent.  Inspect carefully
	for wear, burned areas, scoring, etc.  If in doubt, replace joint.  Inspect
	boots carefully for cracking, cut, rips, etc.  If in doubt, replace.

17.	Apply a small amount of CV joint grease to the inside of the boots.  Work into 
	the folds of the boots with your fingers.

18	Apply a small amount of CV joint grease to the ends of the axles, and carefully
	work the boots down over the axles.  The boots should go over the ribs machined
	into the axle to hold them in place.

19.	Reinstall the concave washers, using a deep socket to drive them on.  Or, use a 
	pair of vise grips, opened enough to sit on the washer without touching the axle,
	and hammer on the vise grips.  Washer must go all the way to the bottom of the 
	splined area.
		NOTE:	Washer goes on like this: \|AXLE|/, not like this: /|AXLE|\.

20.	Reassemble joints by putting inner races inside retaining rings, and snapping
	ball bearings into slots on retaining ring.  Insert inner race assembly into
	outer race by tilting in, ensuring that marks made during disassembly line up.

21.	Test operation:  Inner race should freely rock back and forth, while retaining
	ring remains locked to outer race.  If inner race is locked to outer race and
	retaining ring tilts freely, then joint is assembled improperly.  Correct before
	use!

22.	Lightly grease splines on axle and center holes on joints.  Reassemble joints
	onto axles, keeping same joint on same end of axle and same sides of joints
	facing out.  Observe orientation marks made during disassembly.

23.	Reinstall snap rings with snap ring pliers, or use small screwdriver and much
	cussing.

24.	Tap on end of joint with hammer and deep socket (or partially opened vise grips)
	to ensure snap ring is fully seated in groove.

25.	Thoroughly pack CV joints with CV joint grease, working inbetween races and
	ball bearings.  Use plenty - grease is cheap, CV joints aren't!

26.	Repeat steps 1-25 on other side of vehicle.

NOTE:	If swapping joints from side to side, keep the same end pointing in.  In other 
	words, the joint that was connected to the transaxle on the driver's side will
	end up connected to the transaxle on the passenger side, and vice versa.

27.	Clean any old grease out of flanges on wheel hub and transaxle. Fill with fresh 
	CV joint grease to provide extra grease for joint.

28.	Reinstall joint/axle assemblies and tighten bolts finger tight.

29.	Torque bolts to 30 ft/lbs using 8mm 12 point Allen head socket and torque wrench.

30.	Rotate wheels and check for unusual noises, binding, etc.

31.	Apply parking brake and put vehicle in gear.  Reconnect the battery.

32.	Lower vehicle.

33.	Road test vehicle carefully, checking for unusual sounds.

Date: Tue, Apr 4, 1995 1:00 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: What's this Fund business

You 112 payed-up Patrons and Members can delete this...

To you Old and New Porschephile-subscribers (who are wondering
what all this talk of money for a *free* list is all about...)
Greetings!

Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER* 1200 members,
generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per *day*, which is more
traffic than MCI handles!

This volume of traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1
service.  In addition, it now requires that a machine be dedicated to
handle this traffic.  This machine is old, nearing the end of its service
life, and should be replaced.

Not to put too fine a point of this, this eats into the Listmeister's
livelihood, and, amigos, that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable
debt of gratitude for freely providing this service at no cost for the
past 5.5 years.  The very least we can do to show our gratitude is to
take as much of the capital burden upon ourselves as possible.

We have established a Not-for-profit bank account with my bank in
Crofton, Maryland, to accumulate the funds, and are asking that each
member who is concerned for the survival of Porschephiles, to contribute
what they can.  I have suggest appropriate donations would be $15 for
Students, $50 for Employed people, and $100 for those who wish to be
considered Patrons.

*Nobody* has to contribute anything.  We are trying to acquire the funds
to build the infastructure to ensure the survival of Porschephiles
independent of any member.

I don't have firm figures for the costs we are facing, and that doesn't
bother me a bit. I do know that Stan has made the service available to
the group, using the capital resources that he depends upon to earn his
daily bread, and is begining to feel the strain.

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say
"Rectal Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford
$15.  If a poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of
line for a Working person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and
access to the 'net, to be able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more,
then $100 seemed like a nice, tidy round number.

I don't think it's anal-retentive to recognize those who dig deeper.  I
have assured all that no one's name or contribution level will be
published *unless* they instruct me to do so.  NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE
ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  Last week's InfoWorld has a
comparison of two package servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  Whatever
organization we form to shelter the funding under, this number will be
your membership number.  You get to be a *charter* member of whatever it
becomes.  Impress your Friends!  Be *attractive* to Members of your
favorite Gender!  Be known as a *True* Porschephile...

And, how about *Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great*
happenings on the 'net?

Finally, the "membership" issue.  By 3/18/95, we must apply to the IRS
for Non-Profit Organization status. (tick...tick...tick) I'm the guy in
the barrel here.  We need to decide what kind of an organiztion we will
be.  Here, again, you can be a PORSCHEPHILE and not join any more
organizations.  Many of us would like to be the Electronic Frontier
Region of PCA, but this is not universal. Most of the Non-US folks are
not interested in affiliating with PCA, and that's no problem either.

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!  Everybody can Join
(whatever orgainzation we decide); again, *NOBODY* has to...there is
enough interest in the EFR business that we *can* go that route if
required to keep my butt out of the [deleted] grasp of the IRS.

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute:  The bank folks would
rather that you send the checks to me, made out to

for deposit to "Porschephiles" Acct #3933150532

My address is:

Custodian "Porschephiles" 
c/o Bart Chambers 
1270 Lavall Drive
Davidsonville, MD  21035 
(410) 721-2989

If you wish to call me, please do so prior 8:30 PM EST.

***Please send me an Email with your address, ck number and amt.*** This
will be private unless you wish to send it to 'philes yourself:

Here is the name, address and Phone number of the bank officer so anyone 
who whishes, may verify that this is on the up-and-up.

     Cathy Laster,
         re:  Porschephiles acct.# 3933150532
     NationsBank, Crofton Office
     2227 Defense Highway
     Crofton, MD  21114
     (410) 793-0770

We are grateful any and all donations.


Cheers, <vbg>

Bart,
Frau, Dora

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 12:36:24 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Fuel Hoses

>         My 74 2.0 has two different kind of fuel hoses.  One kind is
> grey plastic (?) and has a large-ish ID.  These lines go from the hard
> lines in the center tunnel to the fuel pump, from the fuel pump to the
> RHS fuel rail.  The other is black rubber (again, ?) and has a smaller
> ID.  It connects the two fuel rails, and connects the LHS rail to the
> cold-start valve.  I forget which kind goes to the guel pressure regu-
> lator.
>         I'm replacing all the fuel hoses ("shipwright's disease").  Is
> the grey hose the "good stuff"?  Should I replace it with the same
> thing, or with the black hose?  Or with some third alternative?  I want
> to avoid the engine fires the 914 was infamous for.

Since I have *NO* idea what this "grey hose" stuff is, let me just tell
you what you *should* have.

You should have four kinds of fuel line in the car. I'll describe the
2.0 version. 1.7 is almost the same, 1.8 is similar but the exact fuel
line plumbing is a bit different...

1) hard plastic lines, two each. Run from the front of the car near
   the tank to the rear of the car under the battery, roughly. If
   they're in bad shape, you'll get gas in the center tunnel, and
   other Bad Things may happen... You *CAN* buy replacements for these
   things from Porsche, or you can run -06 or -08 Aeroquip...

2) metal fuel distribution lines, two each. These are the things attached
   directly to the injectors, with two connections and a center tap. One
   connection is "in", one is "out". On the battery side, the front is
   "in", the middle tap goes to the cold start, and the rear connection
   is "out", which goes to the rear connection on the relay board side,
   which is "in", and its forward connection goes to the fuel pressure 
   regulator.

3) 7mm hose. Black rubber, some kind of braided covering. From Wurth. 
   *ONLY* -- no "smooth rubber" hose, no substitutes. Can get it at any 
   VW,Porsche,Audi,etc. dealer, most Bosch distributors, most of the 
   aftermarket suppliers, and of course, Wurth direct. *MOST* of the 
   fuel line in the car is 7mm.

4) 9mm hose. See above for specs. This is used only in going from the 
   fuel pump to the tank, with the fuel filter acting as a "diameter
   converter". If I recall, it's used from the tank to the hard line
   on the supply side, with 7mm on the return. And it's used again
   from the hard line to the fuel filter, then everything else is 7mm.
   Could be wrong, though -- it's been a while since I've replaced 
   hoses on a stock 2.0...

Anyway, that's it. Key feature is that you *MUST* use lines rated for
fuel injection pressures, and gasline. *LOTS* of the stuff labled
"gas line" for American cars is very low pressure only, and will fail
in most entertaining ways....

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 13:33:31 -0400
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Driver's Ed/Insurance

The Northern New Jersey Region of PCA was involved in litigation against an
insurance company that refused to pay on a claim.  The member was a
participant in an NNJR Driver Ed Event and was involved in a single car incide
nt.  He submitted a claim to his insurance company who promply claimed it was
"racing" and refused to honor the claim.  

This person then sued the insurance company.  The Driver's Ed Chairman,
President and Event Chief Instructor from NNJR testified on behalf of the
driver and also presented all the NNJR literature concerning Driver's Ed.
 The result was the court forced the insurance company to pay all claims.

The key areas of the defense were:

1. NNJR Drivers Ed is a non-timed event.  All timing devices of any kind,
either in or outside the car are strictly prohibited.

2. The sole purpose is to educate the entrant as to proper driving techniques
and improve driving ability.  We do not teach "speed" but teach "proper
driving techniques" at speed.

3. All entrants are grouped into "run groups" that are of similar skill level
and experience.  Thus novices are on the track with other novices, etc.

4. Passing is allowed only in designated areas of the track and the passee
informs the passer where and when to pass through the use of clearly defined
hand signals.  Any pass without a signal results in a black flag and
reprimand from the chief instructor.  Two such incidents in one event results
in ejection from the event.

5. An instructor must be with the novice driver at all times.  Only when a
driver has sufficient seat time (at this and previous events) and  has
demonstrated to the instructor an adequate skill level, is the student
"signed off" and allowed to solo. This "sign off" is only for the duration of
this particular event.

6. All entrants in the intermediate run groups are strongly urged (sometimes
forced) to utilize an instructor to hone their driving skills. 

7. Safety is the primary concern from rigid automobile pre-event and daily
safety inspections, required SA rated helmets, required on board fire
extinguishers,  to a strictly enforced "two spin rule" ( A spin is defined as
breaking a 90 degree angle to the direction of travel or dropping two wheels
off the track surface- Do this twice and you go home - even instructors)

8. All instructors must meet rigid training and skill level requirements. 

These were the main points of the defense.  Thus there is a precedent in New
Jersey. (This and $1.50 will buy you a cup of coffee.)  

Many insurance companies will not cover "off road" activities.  Driver's 
Ed may be considered such and thus fall into the crack.  I would suggest that
all entrants in driver education programs check with their insurance agent
prior to participating in any such event. 

There is a rumor that an insurance company is offering "single event"
coverage for either Drivers Education or PCA Racing.  I am trying to get more
information on the costs and extent of such coverage.  I will post my
findings.

If anyone has any additional questions, or I may of further service, please
give me a shout.

Thank you,

 Larry Reynolds
 Car Care Specialties, Inc.
 Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
 Post Office Box 535
 Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663-0535
 Phone (201) 796-8300
 Fax (201) 791-9743
 E-mail carcaresp@aol.com
 Old enough to remember when sex was safe and race cars were dangerous

Date: 4 Apr 1995 10:37:53 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: My first auto-x

                       Subject:                               Time:10:15 AM
  OFFICE MEMO          My first auto-x                        Date:4/4/95

Hi All,

I designed my first auto-x course last weekend (actually I 
designed it 2 weeks ago, it just got run last weekend).

It was *really fun* (designing the course that is, *I* drove like
shit... - I now believe the theory that one never does well on a 
course one designs).

The Redwood Region is splitting up the workload this year and our
auto-x chairman has recruited people to each run one event.

I had some hesitation about running the event at first and agreed 
mostly because I felt "that I should."

I'm posting this because if anyone else is ever in this situation, 
just run the event!  You'll love it.

All you really need you to know you learned in kindergarten:

1)   Loud voice is good at recess (and driver's meeting!)

2)   Aimless crayon drawings (i) impress parents *and* (ii) make 
      killer auto-x courses.

3)   Share with your friends; some of them are closet course designers:
      "This cone's in the wrong place" (really means "I can't possibly make 
      this turn").  Okay, okay, the course was safer after I moved the cone.

4)  Don't forget your nap the night before - I was *beat* by the end of the
     day.


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 10:44:20 -0700
From: "jim gregory" <jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: Advice on buying '86 944T

james-

Some things to quickly qualify the car as a good prospect:

	1. When was the last water pump installed (they go bad ~2-3 years)
	2. Does it have the new style exhaust manifolds (willhave an obvious
	    bellows type shape in the manifold)
	3. When was the clutch last replaced (944T clutch life is ~30,000
miles)
	4. Have both motor mounts been replaced, when?
	   (they dry out, lose all their fluid and need replaced periodically)
	5. When was the last set of timing & balance shaft belts replaced?

		(should be done every two years or 30,000 miles whichever comes
		 first)
	6. WHen was the timing belts & balance shaft belts last adjusted?
	(should be annually or every 15,000 miles whichever is sooner)
	7. Turbos DO wear out. Depends on how they are taken care of.
	8. What type of oil was used & how frequently was it changed?
		(right answer: synthetic oil, every 2500-3000 miles )
	9. Have the wheel bearings been replaced yet (especially the rears-
	   they can get to be expensive)
	10. When were the rod bearings last replaced? (tend to last for about
	    50 hours of track use, suffer oil starvation problems, I do mine
	    every two years)
	11. CHeck ball joints (are integral part of lower control arms-- cost
	     about $1600 just for the parts)
	12. Transaxle- any problems shifting? Has the transaxle ever been
	    rebuilt?
	13. Head gaskets-- known weakness. Look for it in the records, maybe
have a leakdown test run on the car.


Maintenance records are worth a LOT. Proof of maintenance activity is worth
paying a premium for vs. a car with an unknown history. Check with the service
shop that did the work on the car-- they will know best what is right and wrong
about the car. A little effort and expense before you buy the car can save you
thousands after you have bought it. SPend a $100 or $200 and have a porsche
repair center you trust check the car out for you. Maintenance for these cars
can get painful.

good luck-

jim gregory
87 944turbo

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 14:07:27 -0400
From: WA8MSF@aol.com
Subject: 993/New Turbo for TALL GUYS?

We of the headroom challenged sort (6'4") find the thought of new Porsches a
sore subject on our pointy little heads.   All the hair is gone off the top
of my head because I own a '90 C4 with a sunroof and the standard
semi-electric seats.  I tried to hunch down in the seat with my helmet on for
track events but gave that up as I have now reached middle-age and value
pain-free days.  I absolutely love driving various P-cars and have many racy
types in the garage that require less contortions with a helmet on than the
sunroof C4 in civilian clothes.  Of course none of the racy cars have
sunroofs.  They're also old and you have to truck them to intermediate or
distant track events.  A combo track/cruising setup that could be driven, to
say Mid-Ohio or Watkins Glen, tracked around, then driven home would be the
point of the exercise.

Somebody famous (can't remeber who) told me that sunroof-delete on newer
P-cars didn't buy much headroom since the sunroof tracks/framework had been
engineered within an inch of its life for improved roll-over protection and
was installed as an integral part of the roof on ALL 911s, sunroof or not.
 Is this essentially true?

I would dearly love to find a pleasing solution to the headroom dilemma so's
that I can realistically lust after a 993/C4 or a new Turbo.  I was able to
get a sunroof-delete on a '92 Audi S4 that converted it from undrivable in
any position to plenty of room for a helmet in one box on the order blank, so
maybe there is a way with Porsches too.  Maybe as a "special wish" for tall
guys.

Any and all tips would be appreciated.  The PAG-PCNA-Dealer chain is not
helpfully informative so far.  And since I am not in daily conversation with
the factory, you all are my only hope.

Thanks in advance,

Mike 
Cincinnati, Ohio

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 17:10:54 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Mid-Ohio - need tire shop...

John writes:
>I'll be attending the Potomac regions drivers Ed event at Mid-Ohio in the 
>middle of May - a 3 day event! Does anyone know of a reputable shop near the

>track that will change tires for me?
>I only have one set of wheels & don't want to drive from Wash D.C. & back on

>R-1s.
John,
Don't worry about the drive. I routinely drive my R1's to and from the track
or race events. I went from Philadelphia to Mid Ohio two years ago (500miles)
and the tires still had the mold feathers on them when I reached the track.
The only thing is make sure they are inflated to factory pressures and be set
for a bumpy ride.They certainly are not as smooth as the P700's I use for the
street. BTW they are great in the rain as I had that experience a few times.
(Look out for large standing puddles however).
The ride home is usually less pleasant because you will sometimes get the
tires a bit lumpy from track rubber that you pick up. Also there is always
the chance of a flat spot. You can think of all the fun you had on the way
home and that really helps the time fly.
Have fun, don't worry!!

Date: Tue, 04 Apr 95 17:29:38 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re:      944 : Limp mirror

> One of my mirrors went limp. It appears that a screw that holds the mirror
> to the mount on the door has come loose. I can't get to it unless I remove
> the mirror.  How is the mirror attached? With glue?  I don't want to break
> it.  What's the preferred way of doing this?
> 
> Darren
> '87 944S Indischrot

Hi, Darren,

There are a couple of things that hold the mirror parts in place (on all
cars with electric mirrors).

1) The base of the mirror is attached to the door with a single bolt that
can be accessed by rotating the stem of the mirror towards the front. It may
be hidden by a small plastic plug.

2) The stem of the mirror is attached to the base by a hollow bolt in the
stem itself. It is accessed from the bottom of the base and requires a large
(12mm?) triple square 12-point internal wrench.  Of course, there are a few
wires running through this bolt, so you may have to remove the wires first.

3) The mirror motor is attached to the stem by three small bolts. To access
these bolts, you have to remove the mirror glass.

4) The mirror glass is attached to the mirror motor in one of two ways:

a) On older mirrors, there are three spring-loaded pins that simply friction
fit into corresponding holes on the motor.

b) On newer mirrors (for 944, 1985/2 and newer), there is a ring that locks
the mirror glass into place. The ring has a couple of notches at the bottom
of the glass. To release the mirror glass, tilt the glass up as high as it
will go without breaking, then use a small screwdriver to rotate the locking
ring from the bottom. 

That's all that I know about, based on my exhaustive analysis of 944
electric mirrors.

Good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Tue Apr 04 14:09 EDT 1995
From: ncrhub4!ncrgw1!atlantic.nos.noaa.gov!bchambers@dayhub.daytonoh.NCR.COM
Subject: What's this Fund business

You 112 payed-up Patrons and Members can delete this...

To you Old and New Porschephile-subscribers (who are wondering
what all this talk of money for a *free* list is all about...)
Greetings!

Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER* 1200 members,
generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per *day*, which is more
traffic than MCI handles!

This volume of traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1
service.  In addition, it now requires that a machine be dedicated to
handle this traffic.  This machine is old, nearing the end of its service
life, and should be replaced.

Not to put too fine a point of this, this eats into the Listmeister's
livelihood, and, amigos, that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable
debt of gratitude for freely providing this service at no cost for the
past 5.5 years.  The very least we can do to show our gratitude is to
take as much of the capital burden upon ourselves as possible.

We have established a Not-for-profit bank account with my bank in
Crofton, Maryland, to accumulate the funds, and are asking that each
member who is concerned for the survival of Porschephiles, to contribute
what they can.  I have suggest appropriate donations would be $15 for
Students, $50 for Employed people, and $100 for those who wish to be
considered Patrons.

*Nobody* has to contribute anything.  We are trying to acquire the funds
to build the infastructure to ensure the survival of Porschephiles
independent of any member.

I don't have firm figures for the costs we are facing, and that doesn't
bother me a bit. I do know that Stan has made the service available to
the group, using the capital resources that he depends upon to earn his
daily bread, and is begining to feel the strain.

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say
"Rectal Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford
$15.  If a poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of
line for a Working person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and
access to the 'net, to be able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more,
then $100 seemed like a nice, tidy round number.

I don't think it's anal-retentive to recognize those who dig deeper.  I
have assured all that no one's name or contribution level will be
published *unless* they instruct me to do so.  NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE
ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  Last week's InfoWorld has a
comparison of two package servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  Whatever
organization we form to shelter the funding under, this number will be
your membership number.  You get to be a *charter* member of whatever it
becomes.  Impress your Friends!  Be *attractive* to Members of your
favorite Gender!  Be known as a *True* Porschephile...

And, how about *Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great*
happenings on the 'net?

Finally, the "membership" issue.  By 3/18/95, we must apply to the IRS
for Non-Profit Organization status. (tick...tick...tick) I'm the guy in
the barrel here.  We need to decide what kind of an organiztion we will
be.  Here, again, you can be a PORSCHEPHILE and not join any more
organizations.  Many of us would like to be the Electronic Frontier
Region of PCA, but this is not universal. Most of the Non-US folks are
not interested in affiliating with PCA, and that's no problem either.

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!  Everybody can Join
(whatever orgainzation we decide); again, *NOBODY* has to...there is
enough interest in the EFR business that we *can* go that route if
required to keep my butt out of the [deleted] grasp of the IRS.

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute:  The bank folks would
rather that you send the checks to me, made out to

for deposit to "Porschephiles" Acct #3933150532

My address is:

Custodian "Porschephiles" 
c/o Bart Chambers 
1270 Lavall Drive
Davidsonville, MD  21035 
(410) 721-2989

If you wish to call me, please do so prior 8:30 PM EST.

***Please send me an Email with your address, ck number and amt.*** This
will be private unless you wish to send it to 'philes yourself:

Here is the name, address and Phone number of the bank officer so anyone 
who whishes, may verify that this is on the up-and-up.

     Cathy Laster,
         re:  Porschephiles acct.# 3933150532
     NationsBank, Crofton Office
     2227 Defense Highway
     Crofton, MD  21114
     (410) 793-0770

We are grateful any and all donations.


Cheers, <vbg>

Bart,
Frau, Dora
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

Date: Tue Apr 04 14:43 EDT 1995
From: ncrhub4!ncrgw1!jdola.lanl.gov!hsu_a@dayhub.daytonoh.NCR.COM
Subject: 1990 Porsche C2 for sale

Found on Net earlier today.

Date: Tue Apr 04 15:05 EDT 1995
From: ncrhub4!ncrgw1!porsche.trevose.sgi.com!jimg@dayhub.daytonoh.NCR.COM
Subject: Re: Advice on buying '86 944T

james-

Some things to quickly qualify the car as a good prospect:

        1. When was the last water pump installed (they go bad ~2-3 years)
        2. Does it have the new style exhaust manifolds (willhave an obvious
            bellows type shape in the manifold)
        3. When was the clutch last replaced (944T clutch life is ~30,000
miles)
        4. Have both motor mounts been replaced, when?
           (they dry out, lose all their fluid and need replaced periodically)
        5. When was the last set of timing & balance shaft belts replaced?

                (should be done every two years or 30,000 miles whichever comes
                 first)
        6. WHen was the timing belts & balance shaft belts last adjusted?
        (should be annually or every 15,000 miles whichever is sooner)
        7. Turbos DO wear out. Depends on how they are taken care of.
        8. What type of oil was used & how frequently was it changed?
                (right answer: synthetic oil, every 2500-3000 miles )
        9. Have the wheel bearings been replaced yet (especially the rears-
           they can get to be expensive)
        10. When were the rod bearings last replaced? (tend to last for about
            50 hours of track use, suffer oil starvation problems, I do mine
            every two years)
        11. CHeck ball joints (are integral part of lower control arms-- cost
             about $1600 just for the parts)
        12. Transaxle- any problems shifting? Has the transaxle ever been
            rebuilt?
        13. Head gaskets-- known weakness. Look for it in the records, maybe
have a leakdown test run on the car.


Maintenance records are worth a LOT. Proof of maintenance activity is worth
paying a premium for vs. a car with an unknown history. Check with the service
shop that did the work on the car-- they will know best what is right and wrong
about the car. A little effort and expense before you buy the car can save you
thousands after you have bought it. SPend a $100 or $200 and have a porsche
repair center you trust check the car out for you. Maintenance for these cars
can get painful.

good luck-

jim gregory
87 944turbo

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1301                         Wed Apr 5 02:00:06 CDT 1995
Date: 4 Apr 1995 17:41:46 -0500
From: "Arthur H. Kay" <ahkay@docserv.com>
Subject: 944 S2 Various Items

I just purchased this car less than a week ago.  Everything is absolutely
perfect except for this one small problem.  After driving for more than
fifteen minutes, when down to idle, the low oil light comes on (even though
the oil pressure seems to be pegged on 1) and the "!" light comes on.  At
first the light flickers but then, after a few more minutes, it comes on
pretty strong and stays on while at idle.  Depressing the accelerator just a
tad turns it off.  The strange thing is, even though this is my first Porsche
and I have only owned it for less than a week, my gut tells me that it is
idling OK.   No stalling, at least.  So, what gives? 

This problem didn't show itself during the "test drive" and the owner didn't
say anything about it.  He probably didn't know the problem existed because
he wasn't driving it very frequently or for extended periods of time.  I have
all of the records as well and there is no indication of this problem.

Thanks in advance for any responses!

BTW, thanks to everyone who responded to my earlier queries in searching for
this car.  It took six months, but I held out for the most perfect specimen
at the best price.  Other than my *very silly grin*, I have no driving
impressions other than last weekend being perfect topdown weather and people
staring at a very red convertible Porsche with my 18 month old son in the
front passenger seat (in his car seat).  This actually leads me to another
question.  Anyone out there with any luck fitting a child seat into the back
seat of a 944?  Seems almost impossible as the back seats are half as long as
the bottom of a child's seat.  Maybe there is a particular brand of seat that
will fit?  We have a Renolux.

Also, BTW, I seem to be without or in need of the following items (not in any
particular order):

Porsche Electric Air Pump (for spare tire and ?)
Boot Case (did Porsche provide these with the car or is this an extra?)
Locking lug nuts (Every other one I looked at had these)
Heavy rubber backed carpet mats, front & back, black

If anyone has any of these items for sale (new or used) or knows where to
find them, please let me know, directly if you prefer.  I am planning on
going to Don McGill sometime this week to check prices.

 -Arthur

'90 944 S2 Cab - Indischrot/Linen/Black

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 19:43:37 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Driving Handbook by Vic Elford

>Has anybody out there read "Porsche High-Performance Driving Handbook" by
>Vic Elford?

>What did you think?   Is it a good book?

I bought the book when it first came out.  It is an entertaining book,
but I don't think I really *learned* a heck of a lot about "High-
Performance Driving".  Having read alot of  books on *how* to drive,
I've found that there is **no substitute** for seat time.  Period.

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 17:58:41 -0600 (MDT)
From: David Claussen <claussen@rintintin.Colorado.EDU>
Subject: 901 Questions


Hello Everyone,

	I had spent a good portion trying to get the 914 in good tune over
the spring break. I have had the car parked over the snowy months and when
I got under the car to adjust the valves, I noticed a rather large pool of
yellowy-green oil on the concrete. If you guessed gear oil, you win a
cigar. (This is a side-shifter, BTW) I removed the shift-shaft cover and
another cup or two of oil dumped on the floor. After examining the
shift-assembly, I noticed a rather large large amount of lateral "play" 
in the shift shaft, as if it wobbles in the support.

Given the lack of a seal on the shift-shaft, and the seeming lack of 
precision in the bushings, I would like to remove and rebuild this 
portion of the transmission, as the rest of the unit works 
beautifully(No clashing downshifting into 1st, even). I have looked at 
the Haynes manual about removing this portion of the transmission, but it 
is unclear if this piece can be removed separately without further 
disassembly of the transmission. Has anyone done this? Any advice? Or do 
I just live with the leak until graduation? How difficult is this piece 
to rebuild?

Which brings me to my next question:

Upon discovering the leak, I attempted to remove the fill plug to top it 
off. It seemed rather resistant to moving. Before I get nuts with a 
breaker bar, is there anything that I can do to minimize the chances of 
stripping out the case. I know someone else has had this very trouble 
lately, what were your experiences? I tried to find something of this in 
the archives but I must not have looked hard enough as I have not found 
anything specific to the transmission on seized? hardware.



Thank you very much in advance

David Claussen(claussen@rintintin.colorado.edu)

Date: 4 Apr 1995 16:58:20 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re-911 battery

Derek writes:



>     
>Hi Howard, I would recommend a Porsche battery.  I have a Sears in mine and
the 
>disadvantage is that it is *not* the correct size.  You'll have to home-brew
a 
>new battery clamp to secure the battery.  Mine tends to float all over the
place
>right now, cause I have'nt found the time to fix it!

I have a sears die-hard in my 911.

I do not recommend this battery.  It works great but leaks slightly.  I assume

that if I did not auto-x, the battery would be okay.

By the by, this sucker is 5 years old and will still crank the engine for 
at least 30 seconds w/o slowing down.

Next time I think I'll try one of the Optima batteies.  No leaking...

As far as size goes, sears does (did 5 years ago) make a group 24 battery.
This is the correct size for a 1980 911.

My girlfriend bought a different non-factory battery for her 1981 911.  It's 
not a group 24; it's shorter.  The 1981 911 has a second bolt hole for this 
size battery.  I did have to fab a bracket out of a piece of aluminum 
angle.  It took about 10 minutes.


 
     _______________
     |     |  |     |
     |_____|__|__   |
            ^    |  |
            |    |__|
            |
           hole



soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

I haven't read it, but I'll take this opportunity to plug Hank's book:

   Secrets of Solo Driving

This is a *great* book for the beginning auto-x / time-trial driver.
It is required reading for the Zone 7 auto-x school.


Automotion carries it.  Around $15.

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 17:36:43 -0700
From: lherman1@ix.netcom.com (Len Herman)
Subject: 911 Cold Start Problem

I just had the 2.7 engine in my '76 911 replaced with a 3.0 from an '81 
SC.  The following components were also upgraded during the swap:
Fuel pump, CD, Fuel accumulator, distributor, tach, brain box installed 
under passenger seat.

The PROBLEM:  Car will not run right for about the first minute when 
cold.  It sputters, coughs and backfires through the airbox (thankfully 
it has a pop valve).  The engine will not go above 1,000 RPM.  After 
about 1 minute it is fine.  It runs much better than the 2.7 ever did.

I am looking for suggestions.

Thanks,

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 20:39:51 -0400
From: L8Apexer@aol.com
Subject: Re: 951 Brake Squeal

I have  89 951 and have had no brake squeal with stock or Repco semi
metallics.  Cool Carbons ssqueal like h!!!!  You may be getting glazing on
the pads if you do mostly city driving.  This can be buffed out or you can
try several hard stops from speed.  I haven't had much luck with anti squeal
juices!

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 19:40:21 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Targa Top Repair question

Hi ya'Jeff,

I do not claim to be an expert in automotive vinyl repairs, but I have 
worked in a auto interior and trim shop for a talented craftsman.  Here 
is my 2 cents worth, I would never advise attempting vinyl repair.  When 
we had vinyl to be repaired, we called in the experts.  Guys who 
specialize in vinyl and leather repair can cover a rather large hole that 
is hard to see with the naked eye, while non-experts usually turn out less 
than adequate work.

In regard to recovering the entire top, here is the name, #, and address
of a company in Kansas City that can fix you up.  They will give you prices 
on German Vinyl and Lavant Vinyl, of course the "CHERMAN" version is more 
expensive.  The german vinyl is "hand rolled", 	I know that will make you 
feel better ! :-)

Here is your info: J.R. Veteran Company
                   2912 Cherry
                   Kansas City, MO  64108
                   1-800-342-5578
Prices may vary from $160.00 up to $240.00, headliner material not included.

Hope this helps, sorry about your tear !  :-(

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 20:46:43 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Sporto Conversion

You said:

>However I have a question to ask: On the left side of the engine at the
>head
>>there is an oil pump that is used to pump oil from the oil tank to the
>torque converter that will now be useless. How do I remove this? Can I >just
>slip out the gear that is inside and replace the cover and plug the in/out
>lines or is there some other way?

Unbolt the pump and gear drive.  You get a cam tower plug for the hole (same
as the other side of the engine), and tap it in. Presto, no pump, no hole!

Jon Lowe

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 14:20:18 -0400
From: JOHNM@icac.org (John Mulligan)
Subject: Re: Drivers' Ed & Insurance P...


<---- Begin Included Message ---->
Cc: Porschephiles@tta.com
Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 20:38:01 -0400
From: Russ930@aol.com
Subject: Re: Drivers' Ed & Insurance P...
To: JOHNM@icac.org

John, in MA all ins. co. have to play by the exact same rules, so with this
in mind let me tell you what happen to me last year and how I handled my
mishap.
     While driving in a drivers ed event I got a little loose and as the car
came around the car behind me clip the rear bumper and exhaust pipe.  The
force was enough to cause the left rear qt to buckle, plus the damage to my
muffler and rear bumper.  The damage to the car that clip me was a lot worse.
 Starting at the drivers door and back including his left rear wheel and
quarter.  (Note:  At the same event a 944 went into the wall broadside)  I
made a point of getting all the event papers including insurance papers from
the organizers that detail this event as a Drivers Ed. Event and submitted
them along with my accident report.  Apox. 10 days later I call the Ins.
Co.(Arbella) to see when they are going to send a check.  The claims adjuster
tells me that they have to look into this in more detail since I was on a
race track they fell that I may have been racing.  I tell her that this is
fine and I will check back with her in 2 days.  When I call back I am told
that the claim is being denied because this type of accident is not covered.
 When I ask her to what exclusion she is refering to, she tells me that the
policy does not cover racing. When I asked her how she came to the conclusion
that I was racing she said that since I was wearing a safety belt and a
helmet that it was racing.  I asked her if she had read the mat'l that I had
supplied, and she said that she had but because it said that the word racing
was not to be used then I must have been racing.  After some debate I told
her that I knew of a claim that they had paid under the exact same
cirumstance last year and that if she would review that claim then maybe she
would reverse her decision.  The alterative would be a 93A law suit filed by
me. (93A in MA allows you to collect 3 times your damages plus atty fees.)
 She said she would look up the claim and for me to call her back in a couple
of days.  I should note here that the claim I am referring to did require a 93
A action to resolve.       When I did get back to her, expecting her to now
reverse her decision she told me that she was still rejecting my claim
because that were not the same.  When I asked her what was different about the
 2 claims she said that in the other claim the driver was alone.  I told her
that he was not alone (Bridgehampton) and that the circumstances were exactly
the same, she claims that had they know that they never would have paid the
claim.  I asked her what other drivers on the course had to do with it, and
she said that since it was suppose to be a drivers ed event there should not
have been any other car on the course.  I asked her if she had gone to
drivers school when she was getting her license and she repled yes.  I then
ask her if they had closed down the local roads and highways while she was
being taught, she said no, but she still didn't get the point.
     I told her that if she didn't reverse herself that once I filed the
court action that I would not accept just the face value of the claim.  She
said that she had already talked to the company atty. and that she was holding
 her ground.  I filed the claim and the day after they recieved notice they
settled saying that I still wasn't covered but that they were making a
business decision.  I settled for double the claim without going to court. 
This whole action took from Sept. 94 to Feb. 95.  There were a lot of
conversions that I left out, but would be glad to relay if anyone would like
to call me.

Russell
617-269-9551 EDT till 4PM

P.S. Remember that 944 that went into the wall at the same event that I had
my mishap at.  The same Ins. Co. insured him. He had his check within 15 days
without any hassle.


<---- End Included Message ---->

Date: Tue, 4 Apr 95 18:24:35 PDT
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: early 911 fuel level sender

My gas gauge needle started jumping rapidly between full and empty and I'd
been relying on the reserve warning light for a few weeks.

So I replaced my 69T fuel tank sender. 

It's an easy job.

But I made the job longer by taking the opportunity to pull apart the old 
sender.

Here's a description:

The sender is a long vertical aluminum tube containing a float that is free 
to move in a vertical direction only.

One small nut + lock washer at the bottom of the sending unit holds the 
assembly together.

Here is a rough picture of what you see with the aluminum tube off.


   W       G                     ground
   |       |
   |       |           _____________
   |       |           |       |   |
   |       !           !       |   V
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !|--ccccc--|!       |
   |       ! | float | !       |
   |       ! __wwwww__ !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       !           !       |
   |       |           |       |
   |___________^   ^___________|
           |___________|

         
      G        = gauge terminal
      W        = reserve indicator light

             !
             !
             ! = bare resistance wire  

   |--ccccc--| = sliding contact short on the float.

    __wwwww__  = brass washer on the bottom of the float.
       

The float has two spring loaded sliding contacts that short the 
resistance wire at the point of the float level.

The resistance is lowest when the float is at the full tank position.

On a new sender it measured 2.3 ohms with the float at the top. 

At the bottom it measured 67 ohms.

When the float bottoms out on the __^  ^___ (contacts), the brass washer shorts
the two contacts together and the "reserve" light comes on.

So the gauge and reserve lights are two independent circuits.

The sender failed when one of the float's two spring loaded sliding brass
contacts fatigued and broke off.  

I won't be making a warranty claim on this part.

It had a datecode 11 68 so it was likely original on my 1969 911T.  


John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com
