Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 21:38:19 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Roadside Assistance

For those who may have thought the idea was dead - the CRAP list lives!
 That's Cyberspace Roadside Assistance Plan.  Stan and I are working out some
final details before "going public" with the thing, so bear with me.  To the
9 who have already signed up, thanks.  I'll contact each of you shortly with
more info.  To those who forget what this thing is going to be........

It's a plan to provide a list of P-philers from around the country, to aid in
roadside emergencies.  You don't need to turn a wrench if you don't want to,
just be willing to help a friend out in an emergency, or just talk Porsches
when they stop in town.  More info coming this week.

Pat Garvey
CRAPMeister

Date: Tue,  4 Apr 95 12:01:48 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Archive searching and your $$$ (was: Re: AOL Users - Searching FTP)

| From: Stan Hanks  <stan@tta.com>
|
| > How do I search the archives? Can this be done without downloading them?
|
| Nope. Not at this time. I'm working on it, but it takes time, more
| disk space, faster processor...

And this, folks, is one of the reasons why Bart is soliciting contributions.
It would be a real convenience for the archives to be uncompressed and
indexed so that one could do a true full-text search in genuine client-
server fashion. It would also be nice if the ftp time restrictions could be
lifted. But these and other enhancements take disk, processor, and net
resources that Stan cannot spare. So, if you haven't already, send your
contribution to Bart Chambers, the Porschephiles fund custodian, so that
the Porshephiles computer hardware and software can be upgraded.

I also want to take a moment to say thanks to all of the helpful folks who
have responded to my inquiries. It is always appreciated.

    Eric

Date: Tue, 04 Apr 1995 20:16 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Re: 911 Cold Start Problem


  Hey Len,

  I've had the same problem with the '83 SC engine in my
  '73T. I've researched FI, checked/had checked various
   components of the fuel injection (if you don't have Probst's
  book on Bosch fuel injection, I recommend it, if for nothing other
  than to have a first rate reference on FI). Adjusting the CO
  seemed to ameliorate the situation, but it hasn't completely
  gone away. I would recommend as a start getting/borrowing
  Probst's book. Understanding the beast is the best way to
  start.

  Hope this helps a little,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

Porschephiles #1302                         Wed Apr 5 11:46:37 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 04 Apr 95 23:04:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: 911 SC HELP!!!!


Help me please!!!!

I need a kind soul with a 911 SC to do me a huge
favor.....I need to identify the pair of wires running
from your distributor to the Bosch CD box.

Open your engine lid and look at the distributor.
You will see a black wire running from the side
of it for a couple of inches then there will be a
plug connector.  The other side of the connector
runs to the CD box.  This plug should have a raised
black #7 and #31 on it - and I need to know which
side they are on.

Separate the plug and hold the CD side towards
your face so you can see the socket and that the
square groove (to ensure a one-way connection)
is facing up to the sky.  Is #7 on the left or right?

Thank you VERY much!!!!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date:      Tue, 04 Apr 1995 08:21:50 -0500
From: "Chris Alexander" <chris@smaug.synapse.net>
Subject:   Efficiency of Tails

According to Figure 15.5 on pp 498 of "Race Car Vehicle Dynamics" by 
Milliken and Milliken (SAE Press - available through ewa), the rear 
spoiler reduces rear axle lift by approx. 125 lbs while the front chin 
spoiler reduces front axle lift by approx 70 lbs (at 100 mi/h for both 
figures).

You definately want both devices.

Hope this helps.

(the original reference for this data is "Aerodynamics of Road Vehicles" 
edited by Hucho - forget who did the translation from German)

Later
- -- 
Chris Alexander @   email:

Gloucester, ON      voice: 613.834.0696

Date: Tue Apr 04 15:54 EDT 1995
From: ncrhub4!ncrgw1!atlantic.nos.noaa.gov!bchambers@dayhub.daytonoh.NCR.COM
Subject: What's this Fund business

You 112 payed-up Patrons and Members can delete this...

To you Old and New Porschephile-subscribers (who are wondering
what all this talk of money for a *free* list is all about...)
Greetings!

Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER* 1200 members,
generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per *day*, which is more
traffic than MCI handles!

This volume of traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1
service.  In addition, it now requires that a machine be dedicated to
handle this traffic.  This machine is old, nearing the end of its service
life, and should be replaced.

Not to put too fine a point of this, this eats into the Listmeister's
livelihood, and, amigos, that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable
debt of gratitude for freely providing this service at no cost for the
past 5.5 years.  The very least we can do to show our gratitude is to
take as much of the capital burden upon ourselves as possible.

We have established a Not-for-profit bank account with my bank in
Crofton, Maryland, to accumulate the funds, and are asking that each
member who is concerned for the survival of Porschephiles, to contribute
what they can.  I have suggest appropriate donations would be $15 for
Students, $50 for Employed people, and $100 for those who wish to be
considered Patrons.

*Nobody* has to contribute anything.  We are trying to acquire the funds
to build the infastructure to ensure the survival of Porschephiles
independent of any member.

I don't have firm figures for the costs we are facing, and that doesn't
bother me a bit. I do know that Stan has made the service available to
the group, using the capital resources that he depends upon to earn his
daily bread, and is begining to feel the strain.

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say
"Rectal Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford
$15.  If a poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of
line for a Working person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and
access to the 'net, to be able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more,
then $100 seemed like a nice, tidy round number.

I don't think it's anal-retentive to recognize those who dig deeper.  I
have assured all that no one's name or contribution level will be
published *unless* they instruct me to do so.  NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE
ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  Last week's InfoWorld has a
comparison of two package servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  Whatever
organization we form to shelter the funding under, this number will be
your membership number.  You get to be a *charter* member of whatever it
becomes.  Impress your Friends!  Be *attractive* to Members of your
favorite Gender!  Be known as a *True* Porschephile...

And, how about *Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great*
happenings on the 'net?

Finally, the "membership" issue.  By 3/18/95, we must apply to the IRS
for Non-Profit Organization status. (tick...tick...tick) I'm the guy in
the barrel here.  We need to decide what kind of an organiztion we will
be.  Here, again, you can be a PORSCHEPHILE and not join any more
organizations.  Many of us would like to be the Electronic Frontier
Region of PCA, but this is not universal. Most of the Non-US folks are
not interested in affiliating with PCA, and that's no problem either.

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!  Everybody can Join
(whatever orgainzation we decide); again, *NOBODY* has to...there is
enough interest in the EFR business that we *can* go that route if
required to keep my butt out of the [deleted] grasp of the IRS.

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute:  The bank folks would
rather that you send the checks to me, made out to

for deposit to "Porschephiles" Acct #3933150532

My address is:

Davidsonville, MD  21035

will be private unless you wish to send it to 'philes yourself:

who whishes, may verify that this is on the up-and-up.

Date: Tue Apr 04 19:08 EDT 1995
From: ncrhub4!ncrgw1!bbs.mhv.net!George.Beuselinck@dayhub.daytonoh.NCR.COM
Subject: Re:      944 : Limp mirror

> One of my mirrors went limp. It appears that a screw that holds the mirror
> to the mount on the door has come loose. I can't get to it unless I remove
> the mirror.  How is the mirror attached? With glue?  I don't want to break
> it.  What's the preferred way of doing this?
> 
> Darren
> '87 944S Indischrot

Hi, Darren,

There are a couple of things that hold the mirror parts in place (on all
cars with electric mirrors).

1) The base of the mirror is attached to the door with a single bolt that
can be accessed by rotating the stem of the mirror towards the front. It may
be hidden by a small plastic plug.

2) The stem of the mirror is attached to the base by a hollow bolt in the
stem itself. It is accessed from the bottom of the base and requires a large
(12mm?) triple square 12-point internal wrench.  Of course, there are a few
wires running through this bolt, so you may have to remove the wires first.

3) The mirror motor is attached to the stem by three small bolts. To access
these bolts, you have to remove the mirror glass.

4) The mirror glass is attached to the mirror motor in one of two ways:

a) On older mirrors, there are three spring-loaded pins that simply friction
fit into corresponding holes on the motor.

b) On newer mirrors (for 944, 1985/2 and newer), there is a ring that locks
the mirror glass into place. The ring has a couple of notches at the bottom
of the glass. To release the mirror glass, tilt the glass up as high as it
will go without breaking, then use a small screwdriver to rotate the locking
ring from the bottom. 

That's all that I know about, based on my exhaustive analysis of 944
electric mirrors.

Good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Tue Apr 04 21:21 EDT 1995
From: ncrhub4!ncrgw1!dayhub.daytonoh.NCR.COM!ncrhub4!ncrgw1!porsche.trevose.sgi.com!jimg@dayhub.daytonoh.NCR.COM
Subject: Re: Advice on buying '86 944T

james-

Some things to quickly qualify the car as a good prospect:

        1. When was the last water pump installed (they go bad ~2-3 years)
        2. Does it have the new style exhaust manifolds (willhave an obvious
            bellows type shape in the manifold)
        3. When was the clutch last replaced (944T clutch life is ~30,000
miles)
        4. Have both motor mounts been replaced, when?
           (they dry out, lose all their fluid and need replaced periodically)
        5. When was the last set of timing & balance shaft belts replaced?

                (should be done every two years or 30,000 miles whichever comes
                 first)
        6. WHen was the timing belts & balance shaft belts last adjusted?
        (should be annually or every 15,000 miles whichever is sooner)
        7. Turbos DO wear out. Depends on how they are taken care of.
        8. What type of oil was used & how frequently was it changed?
                (right answer: synthetic oil, every 2500-3000 miles )
        9. Have the wheel bearings been replaced yet (especially the rears-
           they can get to be expensive)
        10. When were the rod bearings last replaced? (tend to last for about
            50 hours of track use, suffer oil starvation problems, I do mine
            every two years)
        11. CHeck ball joints (are integral part of lower control arms-- cost
             about $1600 just for the parts)
        12. Transaxle- any problems shifting? Has the transaxle ever been
            rebuilt?
        13. Head gaskets-- known weakness. Look for it in the records, maybe
have a leakdown test run on the car.


Maintenance records are worth a LOT. Proof of maintenance activity is worth
paying a premium for vs. a car with an unknown history. Check with the service
shop that did the work on the car-- they will know best what is right and wrong
about the car. A little effort and expense before you buy the car can save you
thousands after you have bought it. SPend a $100 or $200 and have a porsche
repair center you trust check the car out for you. Maintenance for these cars
can get painful.

good luck-

jim gregory
87 944turbo

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 10:07:24 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Efficiency of Tails

On Tue, 4 Apr 1995, Chris Alexander wrote:
> 
> According to Figure 15.5 on pp 498 of "Race Car Vehicle Dynamics" by 
> Milliken and Milliken (SAE Press - available through ewa), the rear 
> spoiler reduces rear axle lift by approx. 125 lbs while the front chin 
> spoiler reduces front axle lift by approx 70 lbs (at 100 mi/h for both 
> figures).
> 
> You definately want both devices.

Interesting -

If the rear spoiler provides 125 Lb of down force, presumably the rear 
spoiler must be capable of accepting a load of 125 lb evenly distributed 
 - or the weight of the average 22 year old woman I cannot imagine that 
the lifting 993 style spoilers can take this sort of punishment.

like wise if the chin spoiler imparts a down force of 70, when it's 
centre of pressure is perhaps only 6 inches below the centre of gravity 
and 2 feet in front of the front axle, I quickly calculate that the force 
on the chin spoiler must be around 280 lb evenly distributed. All this 
force is carried by some trivial bolts and self tappers

Chris I am not flaming you, I wonder about these Milliken figures though

I admit I know very little about aero-dynamics, but I do know about 
something for nothing theories, none of them work

As a matter of interest do M&M make plastic bolt ons

Are there any tame experts out there who may car to comment

Your as sarcastic as ever

Pete

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 07:57:20 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: Efficiency of Tails

>>
>>On Tue, 4 Apr 1995, Chris Alexander wrote:
>>> 
>>> According to Figure 15.5 on pp 498 of "Race Car Vehicle Dynamics" by 
>>> Milliken and Milliken (SAE Press - available through ewa), the rear 
>>> spoiler reduces rear axle lift by approx. 125 lbs while the front chin 
>>> spoiler reduces front axle lift by approx 70 lbs (at 100 mi/h for both 
>>> figures).
>>> 
>>> You definately want both devices.
>>
>>Interesting -
>>
>>If the rear spoiler provides 125 Lb of down force, presumably the rear 
>>spoiler must be capable of accepting a load of 125 lb evenly distributed 
>>- or the weight of the average 22 year old woman I cannot imagine that 
>>the lifting 993 style spoilers can take this sort of punishment.
>>
>>+-------------------------------+
>>| From   : Peter Diffey         |
>>+-------------------------------+
>>
But reducing lift is not really the same as providing downforce. You
can reduce lift by making airflow turbulent, or by redirecting it, using
a device which doesn't have to take very much pressure itself. The
weight on the tires isn't greater at speed than when stationary; it
just isn't reduced by as much with the spoilers in place.

Of course the numbers may still be totally bogus, but I don't think
you can judge that by the strength of the spoilers themselves.

 -John White-

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 08:41:26 -0400
From: WA8MSF@aol.com
Subject: Re: Efficiency of Tails

Peter Diffey questioned whether the Millikens had their data right about
front and rear "de-lift" figures in their new book.

I can personally attest that the Millikens are REAL smart guys when it comes
to anything regarding vehicle dynamics and aerodynamics.  Bill told me about
making and test flying his own airplane as a much younger man.  His son Doug
is an architect as well as a smart car guy.  I would trust anything they say
implicitly.

The stress analysis you perform might not take into account the way in which
the "de-lifting" acts on the car.  The front chin spoiler, IMHO, would not
take all the loads (70#) on its own structure.  It causes a low pressure area
under the front of the car which acts on the underside spread out across the
entire area of maybe the front quarter of the chassis.  This only requires a
few pounds per square foot of force to make happen.  The strength to resist
100 mph wind is found from about 40 pounds per square foot wind pressure as
applied to the 6 inch lever arm of the spoiler.  Since the spoiler can be
driven in excess of 150 mph without failure, it must be strong enough to keep
itself intact  at 100 and let the negative pressure differential across the
hood to bottomside separation do the tough stuff.

I assume the tail must work in a similar fashion by acting on pressure balance
 top of car to bottom of car for "de-lifting".

Think about it.  We are not trying to "push" down on the car with air, we are
trying to queer the lift that the body shape produces.  The car is a huge
airfoil, an upside-down version of ground effects.  These "spoiling" devices
try to cancel out the mechanisms of  the  shape induced lift.    The 962
generates a minus 1500 kg of lift at top speed.  Hans Stuck reports that it
was physically impossible for him to apply enough pedal pressure to test some
race car ABS (lock the wheels) at Nardo until the car slowed down enough to
undo the downforce induced traction.  I can tell you that 962 bodywork is so
flimsy that a girl friend's backside can crack a door panel (mine is cracked
from same at a "concours", not my girl friend, mine was home with the kids).
 Yet the aerodynamic effect  causes the car to "weigh" 2.5 times its normal
self at speed.

My $0.02

Flame sheilds on.

Mike
Cincinnati, Ohio

only a 2.5-3  hour drive.

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 10:19:07 -0400

Date: Tue,  4 Apr 95 16:02:10 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: track/auto-x/street tires

I am planning on doing about 10 auto-xes and perhaps 6 track events in
my 944 this year. I am trying to decide what type of tires to get. I have a
second set of wheels but am wondering if I can get just one set of tires
and use them for everything, including commuting to work.

First I should state that I am just learning how to drive in these types of
events, so I am not really interested in shaving the last few tenths of a
second off of my times through tire choice. Rather, I want a tire that is
predictable at the limit. I am considering R compound tires because I
do want to push the limit a little farther than what I have already
experienced (I have attended 4 auto-xes and 1 track event using my
Dunlop D60 tires).

I am considering the BFG R1 and the Yokohama A008RS II. I understand
that the R1 is probably a faster tire, but that it won't last as long for daily
driving, it won't be as predictable at the limit, nor will it be much fun to
drive on the street. The latter is due to its stiff, asymmetrical sidewall
construction which causes serious wander problems. On the other hand,
I have been told that the RS II, while being an auto-x compound, works
fine at the track and is more predictable at the limit than either the R1 or
the track RS. The only drawback to the RS II for my purposes is a greater
tendency to harden from track heat cycling. I do know of quite a few guys
who put RS IIs on their cars at the beginning of the season and just leave
them on until the end (at which point they are pretty well worn). However,
since the RS and RS II tires are not asymmetrical, they can be turned
around on the wheel and a few more events can be coaxed out of them.

So, I am, at this point, leaning towards the Yoko RS IIs.

Anyone have any comments?

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

and White tent set up in front of it.  Larrys display is Care Care Specialties.

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 11:56:51 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 944 S2 low oil pressure

Arthur H. Kay <ahkay@docserv.com> asked :

> After driving for more than fifteen minutes, when down to idle, 
> the low oil light comes on (even though the oil pressure seems to be 
> pegged on 1) and the "!" light comes on... Depressing the accelerator 
> just a tad turns it off.  

I had the same problem with a Mistubishi without an oil pressure
guage. I added a mechanical guage to double-check the idiot light
and found that the oil pressure was fine (thank God). A new idiot
light sender was all I needed. I bet this is your problem too. 
The low oil sender I had was way out of spec and acted more like 
a temperature switch than a pressure switch!

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S  '73 914/2.0


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 12:39:57 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Targa Top vinyl suppliers / Rebuild

Hi,

Here are some hints on Targa Top Vinyl and restoration:

I just completed a total rebuild of my targa top myself.  A total
rebuild meant tearing all the old vinyl off, and the foam topped
canvas, and the webbing that keep the plates together.  I bought
the new German vinyl, not for $100, but for something like $65 from
a place in CA, mail order, that advertises in the back of excellence
magazine called World Upholstery and Trim.  They have an 800 number.
It is 1-800-222-9577.  The vinyl they sent me was perfect, looks
exactly like the original, and is identical to the factory piece in
shape, size, and quality.  I looked around at a bunch of adds and
catalogs from places like tweeks, performance products, etc.  These
places do not deal in Upholstery, so anything they sell they got
via some supopolier, and tacked on a nice profit to it.  To pay
more than $100 for a piece of vinyl is stupid.  Try calling the 2
or 3 adds in the back of excellence for the various shops that just
do upholstery work, and you will be getting a much better price for
the identical product.  They even gave me some advice on how to go
about repairing the top, and sent me diagrams and samples of all of
the types of vinyl, foam, and headliner material that they sell.
They also told me that they supply dealers, and shops, and stores
with their product.  

The headliner was something like $35 or so, I can`t remember.  
I got both items (vinyl, and headlinder) for well under $100.  And
the vinyl does have the beading that runs along the front and back 
edge already sewn in place.  And the headliner is perfect too.  So
if you are going to buy these things, go to one of these upholstery
shop places, not a parts supplier house.

The other materials I used to recover it were some very think and
heavy canvas - which I bought at a large artist supply house.  They
sell it to poaint on - I bought the thick stuff that was last 
a long time - it was $6 for the piece.  I also bought 1/4 inch foam
to put between the canvas, and the vinyl, to simulate the factory
foam backed canvas that porsche uses.  But I ended up not using
it becuase it made the fit to tight of the vinyl, so I just used the
canvas alone.  I used nylon webbing - 2 inch wide - across both long
sides of the top, to hold the aluminum plates in place.  I bought
Marine Goop adhesive (comes in a tube), and 1/8 inch rivets, and 
gludes and riveted this band of nylon across the top of these plates,
running along the edge of the long sides of the top.  When this dried,
the next day, I bought a quart of contact cement to glue the canvas
in place onto the plates, over the webbing, and wrapped it around the
edges of the top, with an overhang of about 4inches on the ong ends, 
and 2 inches on the short sides of the top.  The contact cement worked
well to secure the canvas in place.  When this was all done, I used
the contact cement again to secure the vinyl in place on the canvas.
Note that you do not glue the entire vinyl to the entire canvas, 
just the edges that wrap under the top get glued.  The whole process
took quite a while - maybe 12 hours of labor.

See the post a while back for more defined details about this whole
process - such as duct taping the nuts in place that are used for 
the hook-like attachements, etc.  

A warning though - When you have the top totally apart, and all 
the aluminun plates (3 free floating plates) are unattached, take
the frame to your car, put it on the car, and aling the plates on
top of the frame - as if the top were attached to the car while
driving.  Lay the plates in placeaaaaaaa (this is without any vinyl 
on the frame.  Then lay the webbing in place along the edges near the
windsheidl frame, and the targa bar.  Carefuly note the position of
the front and rear edges of each floating plate in relation to the 
2 side plates - which do not float.  Then while the webbing is laying
in place, as if it were glued and riveted down, use a marker to mark
the position of the plates.  

Why do I say this above - becuase I reconstructed my entire top without
ever going back to the car after each step to make sure it still fit
into place smoothly and correctly. This is a BIG MISTAKE.  After each
major step in the Targa Top rebuild process: #1 install webbing, #2
install canvas, and #3 install vinyl - go back to the car each time
and make sure the plates are centered between the top edge of the 
windsheild frame, and the top edge of the targa bar.  Not centered
left to right - this matters too, but less so.  What matters is that they 
are centered from to back.  The most important thing is that the gap, maybe
3/8 inch, between the alluminiun plate, and each edge (targa bar, 
windshiled) is the SAME!!.  I did not do this, and when I put the top 
on the car, after the plates were glued to the canvas, I found that
they were about 1/8 inch to far forward.  So when my top was on the
car, I had the porblem of a little tiny gap bnetween the vinyl beaded
edge and the rear targa bar.  Result: it can leak.  I fixed this, but
I was lucky I could, since it was a small error.  It was a pain in
the ass to fix.  I had to adjust the hooks on the plates so that when
the rear frame bar was snapped tight, it would engaged these hooks
and pull the 3 plates towards the rear targa bar, thus closing the gap.
It would have been much much easier to get it right the first time.

Other hints - Drill out the old rivets for the webbing, use the same
factory holes.  Buy rivet heads for the rivets - these are washers
that go over the end of the rivet that gets smushed, and get pulled
against the opposing rivet head, thus sandwiching the material you
are riveting.  Also, wrap the nylon material over the edge of the
aluminum, and rivet both parts of the same piece of webbing, the 
top section, and the part wrapped under.  Use lots of marine goop
on the webbing, all around the rivets, and along the top and 
underside edge.  When this stuff is fianlly dry, that webbing will 
go nowhere.  Get marine goop since it is resistant to moisture.

I also need now to replace the plastic cones that cover the pins
which extend into the windsheild frame and the targa bar.  Mine
are old, borken, worn, and let the top rattle and squeek.  Where
can I get these?

Sorry for such a long post, and the typos, but I followed the other
post and came into the snags mentioned above - not the posters
fault - but clarifications will help the next person.  All in all,
I would do it again if I had to - some places wanted $500-600 to
rebuild it!  Chaaa - as if!  I enjoyed the satisfaction of staying
up until 4am, 2 nights in a row, working away at it.  And my
roomates enjoyed the satisfaction of the fumes from the contact
cement filling the entire house.  Now if my engine was just as
mechanically simple as this top...

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com
1981 911SC Targa

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1303                         Wed Apr 5 16:49:36 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 10:03:55 -0800
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: track/auto-x/street tires

>I am planning on doing about 10 auto-xes and perhaps 6 track events in
>my 944 this year. I am trying to decide what type of tires to get. I have a
>second set of wheels but am wondering if I can get just one set of tires
>and use them for everything, including commuting to work.
>
>First I should state that I am just learning how to drive in these types of
>events, so I am not really interested in shaving the last few tenths of a
>second off of my times through tire choice. Rather, I want a tire that is
>predictable at the limit. I am considering R compound tires because I
>do want to push the limit a little farther than what I have already
>experienced (I have attended 4 auto-xes and 1 track event using my
>Dunlop D60 tires).
>
>I am considering the BFG R1 and the Yokohama A008RS II. I understand
>that the R1 is probably a faster tire, but that it won't last as long for daily
>driving, it won't be as predictable at the limit, nor will it be much fun to
>drive on the street. The latter is due to its stiff, asymmetrical sidewall
>construction which causes serious wander problems. On the other hand,
>I have been told that the RS II, while being an auto-x compound, works
>fine at the track and is more predictable at the limit than either the R1 or
>the track RS. The only drawback to the RS II for my purposes is a greater
>tendency to harden from track heat cycling. I do know of quite a few guys
>who put RS IIs on their cars at the beginning of the season and just leave
>them on until the end (at which point they are pretty well worn). However,
>since the RS and RS II tires are not asymmetrical, they can be turned
>around on the wheel and a few more events can be coaxed out of them.
>
>So, I am, at this point, leaning towards the Yoko RS IIs.
>
>Anyone have any comments?

Eric,

I have used both the Yoko RS II and the BFG R1 230 for autox on my 911
within the last 6 months.

First of all, the RS II has a tread pattern similar to the BFG R1 and
has the same "this side out" requirements of the R1. So there is no
advantage here. The tire has to be mounted on the wheel in a particular
way.

Since you have an extra set of wheels, I would use them instead of
trying to us the R compound tires all the time. Since you are going
to do track events, you will want to order the BFG R1's shaved or
have the Yoko RS II shaved once you get them. This will actually
extend tire life and improve performance. Whichever tire you choose
will last a lot longer if you do not drive it on the street.

I don' about track events, but the BFG R1 is just as predictable at
the limit as the Yoko RS II. The key is that tire feels different
than the Yoko and takes a while to get in tune with the tire. After
switching from the Yoko RS II to the BFG R1 it took me about 5 runs
to get comfortable with the tires.

The BFG R1 is a great tire and I heartily recommend it over the
Yoko RS II. It is a fster tire for both autox and time trial
useage.

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

<---- Begin Included Message ---->
Cc: Porschephiles@tta.com
Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 20:38:01 -0400
From: Russ930@aol.com
Subject: Re: Drivers' Ed & Insurance P...
To: JOHNM@icac.org

John, in MA all ins. co. have to play by the exact same rules, so with this
in mind let me tell you what happen to me last year and how I handled my
mishap.
     While driving in a drivers ed event I got a little loose and as the car
came around the car behind me clip the rear bumper and exhaust pipe.  The
force was enough to cause the left rear qt to buckle, plus the damage to my
muffler and rear bumper.  The damage to the car that clip me was a lot worse.
 Starting at the drivers door and back including his left rear wheel and
quarter.  (Note:  At the same event a 944 went into the wall broadside)  I
made a point of getting all the event papers including insurance papers from
the organizers that detail this event as a Drivers Ed. Event and submitted
them along with my accident report.  Apox. 10 days later I call the Ins.
Co.(Arbella) to see when they are going to send a check.  The claims adjuster
tells me that they have to look into this in more detail since I was on a
race track they fell that I may have been racing.  I tell her that this is
fine and I will check back with her in 2 days.  When I call back I am told
that the claim is being denied because this type of accident is not covered.
 When I ask her to what exclusion she is refering to, she tells me that the
policy does not cover racing. When I asked her how she came to the conclusion
that I was racing she said that since I was wearing a safety belt and a
helmet that it was racing.  I asked her if she had read the mat'l that I had
supplied, and she said that she had but because it said that the word racing
was not to be used then I must have been racing.  After some debate I told
her that I knew of a claim that they had paid under the exact same
cirumstance last year and that if she would review that claim then maybe she
would reverse her decision.  The alterative would be a 93A law suit filed by
me. (93A in MA allows you to collect 3 times your damages plus atty fees.)
 She said she would look up the claim and for me to call her back in a couple
of days.  I should note here that the claim I am referring to did require a 93
A action to resolve.       When I did get back to her, expecting her to now
reverse her decision she told me that she was still rejecting my claim
because that were not the same.  When I asked her what was different about the
 2 claims she said that in the other claim the driver was alone.  I told her
that he was not alone (Bridgehampton) and that the circumstances were exactly
the same, she claims that had they know that they never would have paid the
claim.  I asked her what other drivers on the course had to do with it, and
she said that since it was suppose to be a drivers ed event there should not
have been any other car on the course.  I asked her if she had gone to
drivers school when she was getting her license and she repled yes.  I then
ask her if they had closed down the local roads and highways while she was
being taught, she said no, but she still didn't get the point.
     I told her that if she didn't reverse herself that once I filed the
court action that I would not accept just the face value of the claim.  She
said that she had already talked to the company atty. and that she was holding
 her ground.  I filed the claim and the day after they recieved notice they
settled saying that I still wasn't covered but that they were making a
business decision.  I settled for double the claim without going to court. 
This whole action took from Sept. 94 to Feb. 95.  There were a lot of
conversions that I left out, but would be glad to relay if anyone would like
to call me.

Russell
617-269-9551 EDT till 4PM

P.S. Remember that 944 that went into the wall at the same event that I had
my mishap at.  The same Ins. Co. insured him. He had his check within 15 days
without any hassle.

<---- End Included Message ---->




------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 14:45:13 -0400
From: WA8MSF@aol.com
Subject: Weird Sparkplug Story (long)

I own a '92 Audi S4 (4-valves x 5 zyl) turbo sedan and had a weird thing
happen one cold morning.   The car is kept in a heated garage.  I know this
because the outside-temp reading on the instrument cluster said 65 F when I
staterd up.  The Cincinnati outdoor temperature was about 2 or maybe 3 F when
I backed out of the garage.  After snaking my way to the interstate and
boosting up the rush-hour raceway for 10 minutes the temp guage read 7 F.
 Car is running fine.  I get off the interstate at my exit and after a few
stop lights, I attempt to suck the head-lights out of a Mustang by using alot
of boost.  This proves difficult since the Mustang says "5.0" on the fender
where I hadn't seen it.  OK, we'll use alot of boost for more time.  Not a
good move, now I have to trail-brake to make the next turn-off.  Oh well, no
harm no foul, it was a 4-lane boulevard anyway.  I pull in to an intermediate
destination (no, not a bathroom) and turn off the motor.  After I come back
and re-start, I pull back out onto the street and I immediatly think there is
something wrong with wheel balance or maybe I have "D"-shaped tires.  Lots of
wubba-wubba-wubba related to car speed.  I push in the clutch and it quits.
 Oh-oh, engine!

I limp it to the office and call the dealer (warranty still going) and then
drive it over to them.  They say givem a day or so and they'll call.  They
drive me back to the office.  They call a day later and say that the fault
code in the engine computer says the injector on the front cylinder is bad
and they have put in a whole new set of injectors.  This seems to have helped
and they will drop off the car.
I get it back and the driver says he doen't think that it is completly right,
but I should drive it over the weekend and see.  I drive it home and it is
still bad but different.  It doesn't idle smoothly and it misses at full
boost ( 1.7+ bar), but it runs great at part throttle and low boost ( 0.8 to
1.3 bar ).  I take it back and relay all this to the service manager and he
assembles a coven of mechanics, the service advisor, the owner, and me.  The
spark coil trough comes off and everything seems OK except the insulator tube
for the front cylinder seems dirty with a faint chalky film.  I look down the
sparkplug well and its ID is coated with a sooty film.  I announce to the
throng that I want to see the sparkplug real bad.  

When the mechanic pulls out the plug, it looks weird.  Normally, one would
expect to see a hooked ground electrode, a conical insulator ceramic, and a
coaxially located center electrode.  Not on this one!  It had the hook ground
electrode like normal, but seemed to have a roller shaped thing in the
center.  It was the insulator cone.... busted off and replaced sideways,
jammed in the threaded housing like it had been made that way (it hadn't been
made that way).   They leaked it down and finding nothing out of the ordinary,
 put in a new set of plugs and the car has been perfect ever since.

I can only speculate that the high boost maneuver followed by a frigid-air
restart stressed the insulator ceramic and it, at some point, broke off,
bounced around the chamber a million times, and stuffed itself back in the
hole.  The tip electrode was never found.
The one-coil per cylinder high-energy ignition could fire past the bum plug
elements at modest pressure and non-lean (idle) mixtures.

Weird, huh?

Mike 
Cincinnati, Ohio
wa8msf@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 14:09:06 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Convert Bosch 009 to 050?

> I am wondering if anyone out there has had any experience with the 009 
> distributor on a 912/356.  It only has about 20 degrees of advance and I either 
> lose power at real low rpm or lose it up top.  Will I notice much of a change 
> going to 050 distributor?  Is it worth the $75?  Thanx!

Don't do either. There are plenty of perfectly good 022s and 031s out there,
not to mention the VJ4 BR9's, and the parts to put them back in perfect 
working order are readily available at Stoddard. 

If you don't believe me, ask Vic Skirmants, Brett Johnson or most of the
other Registry tech crowd. Harry Pellow will say sure, use the 050 because
it's *almost* the same but it's really not even close. You have to have
too much initial advance to make it work well to make good power at
low RPMs. It *IS* however significantly cheaper than a new 031, but if
cheap is what motivates you, you've got the wrong car to begin with...

I've wondered if there might not be an aftermarket for taking 050s or 009s
and re-curving them to be *EXACTLY* right. But after doing that on my
Sun distributor machine, I figure that if you have to pay yourself
*ANYTHING* for your time, that there's no way you can compete with the
price of rebuilding a cheap used VJ4...

Stan

wording is:
 
"We do not provide liability coverage for ownership, maintenance, or use of 
any vehicle, located inside a facility designed for racing, for the purpose 
of:
 
(a) competing in; or
(b) practicing or preparing for;
 
any prearranged or organized racing or speed contest."

"We do not provide medical payments coverage for any insured for bodily injury 
sustained while occupying any vehicle, located inside... (etc., same as 
above)"
 
"We will not pay for loss to your covered auto or any non-owned auto, located 
inside... (etc., same as above)"
 
The underwriters insist that Drivers' Ed is not covered because of the speeds 
involved. They say that it doesn't matter that it is not a race, that it is a 
"contest with myself" to go faster, not to improve general driving skills. I 
have not received their response in writing, so I am just paraphrasing the 
discussions. The definitions section of the policy DOES NOT define any of the 
terms used in the clause (i.e., "facility designed for racing", "competing

"speed contest").

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 15:15:44 -0400
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 hunting


Dear Dennis,
You wrote:
<A question about rust:  How much is too much?  Reading the 914 FAQ,
<the battery tray is a very common rust point.  In my $3K price range,
<I expect I may be seeing a bit more of this.  Is there a point
<where the rust can be amputated fairly easily?  Obviously if the
<battery tray is rusted there is going to be some on on the chassis
<there too.  Or should I hold out for an utterly rust free car?

<The transmission was also pretty much shot.  1st, 2nd, and 3rd
<gear synchro's were non-existant.  How much does a tranny rebuild
<run on the 73 or later 914's?  This car also had the Euro gear
<shift pattern.  How common was this?

<The gas pedal seemed to require far more pressure than seems
<correct (as much or more than the clutch).  I assume this isn't
<normal?

<Am I expecting too much from a car marked "Excellent!" for
<$3600?  I'd like a car that's reliable, rust free, and well
<maintained and preferably stock.  It doesn't have to be beautiful,
<I even wouldn't mind "dogged" and "ugly", as long as it isn't 
<rusty.  Doesn't have to be a 2.0 either.  I'd prefer a 73 or later,
<but again, not a requirement.


$3600 for a 1976 914 2.0 that is rust-free except for some battery area rust
is a bargain to the point of being too good to be true.

Good '76 models easily sell for $8,500 and up with pristine examples worth
$14,000. Since the '76 model was the last year for the 914 and the second
rarest production year to the '70 914-6 (only about 4200 1976 models were
manufactured), the '76 models fetch a premium price.

All 914 transmissions shift the same with first over to the left and back.
Transmission rebuilds are fairly costly because of parts prices ($895 parts
and labor with warranty) and one cannot trust used gear boxes because of the
first gear problem due to the gizmo 914 clutch cable roller assembly and
constant adjustment problem.

Accelerator linkage problems are caused by several things:
     1. bad pedal cluster accelerator pivot bushings
     2. a stiff or wobbly pedal
     3. an old non-greased cable or one being used as an electrical ground
due to a poorly connected transmission ground strap
     4. An improperly connected throttle return spring or the wrong spring
     5. a sticking throttel body (especially on 1.8 models!)

The conclusion is that if you can find a rust free '76 914 (and they were all
2.0 models) for $3600, buy it!

George Hussey 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 15:15:47 -0400
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 starter


Dear Mike,
You wrote:
<My '74 914 suddenly began engaging the starter when I put the

<started, the starter keeps grinding.  I changed the ignition 
<switch electrical unit, but no dice.

<Any suggestions?  The starter coil, perhaps?


If the starter is engaging in the keyswitch "on" position and you have
replaced the ignition switch, the wiring has to be melted together! Sorry.

George Hussey

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 12:36:50 +0800
From: craigs@amgen.com (Craig Smith)
Subject: Re: Correct way to say...

I didn't want to tie up the lines, but I thought I'd try to settle this:

Yes, you're all right. It's por'-shuh (the uh would technically be a schwa --
upside down e -- but I can't do that here so uh is my approximation).
In German the e is pronounced. There are dialect variations, but they are not
correct, as Porsche is a name. I have heard people from Berlin say porshee.

What do I know? I speak German, lived in Germany for two years, worked at
Porsche in Stuttgart, and met Dr. Ferry Porsche.

I didn't know the correct way until then, as I had also heard porsh at Porsche
dealers. Sometimes it takes a while to get used to the right way.

Either way, the cars are still the best!

Craig Smith -- craigs@amgen.com

Date: Wed, 05 Apr 95 14:16:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>

Hi Scott,

If I remember correctly, the tech bulletin describes PCNA's criterion
repair vs. leaving it alone.  It is probably something like this: if the oil
is just seeping and cruding up on the barrell/head, no repair.  If it
is dripping onto the floor, repair.

Kind of disappointing.  Then again, I hang with the owner of probably
the only daily-driven Ferrari engine in the world which doesn't leak
anything, and that sets the bar pretty high!

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 05 Apr 95 14:56:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944T Coil-overs


Hi Doug,

Sorry for not replying sooner.  I am not sure how good an answer I
can give you.  I don't know anyone running 10" rears.

If you're happy with the springing and just want the tires and wheels
to clear, I'd try to modify the bodywork.  I don't know whether the inner
rear fender wells can be moved in, but I would find out and try to make
that change.

I think you have  too little springing in the car, too much of it in the 
sway
bars, and should, at a minimum, upgrade to later factory specs.  Your
front springs are about 130# and you can drop in 210# or 250# springs
with a minimum of fuss.  For higher rates, I do not know of a source of
springs in Porsche's ID (like about 3.75").  Call Eibach or Truechoice.
The rest of the world uses 2-1/4" or 2-1/2" springs for competition, and
they are cheap and plentiful.  Converting your suspension to use then
is not cheap, though, per the quotes you got from VCI.

The rears are more of a problem, if that weren't enough.  You ought to
upgrade to larger later torsion bars.  However, labor exclusive of
alignment is at least six hours.  Torsion bar springing goes as the
fourth power of their diameter, and a change of a few mm. will have a
big effect.

Your problem is going to be knowing beforehand exactly what you
need.  If you know how much rear travel you have today, and can
set a goal for how much you can get away with, then you know roughly
what change in wheel rate you need.  You also have to build in some
head room on the assumption that you'll eventually push harder and
faster...

Sorry to be so vague.  I guess that's why they call it "suspension
tuning."  Doug Arnao at VCI is very knowledgeable when it comes to
suspension design -- chat with him.

Kevin Gross



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 05 Apr 95 15:07:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Racing and Rebuilding Brakes


>Because of
>the age of the car, would it not be cheap insurance to rebuild
>the calipers?  The calipers are not leaking right now, but I would
>hate to have one blow out at 100+mph because of their age.

No, leave well enough alone.  They will not "blow out," the seals
are kept in a way which makes that impossible.

If you have a leaking or stuck piston, that's another matter.  Absent
any symptoms, I would not rebuild the callipers.

Kevin

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 16:22:31 -0400
From: StreakN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Drivers' Ed & Insurance Problems...


>I asked the list a question about insurance & drivers ed on >behalf of a

>restrictions don't start appearing in other companies policies!

>By the way, my friend is still looking for a company that will >cover his
car 
>for individual drivers ed events. Does anyone know of a >company that would 
>consider this?

>Sorry for the long message...

- ---------------------------------------------
>John (and, I hope, Bill),

(Snip...much deleted)
I hope your experience with AMICA wasn't one that would sour you on the
company forever. My familry has been insuring vehicles and businesses with
AMICA and its predecessor company (Factory Mutual) for over 50 years, and I
can say without reservation that they have been the best business dealings I
have had. Extremely reasonable, willing to listen to  your side, and claims
paid in a timely manner. When I lost a car in the California fires in October
1993, I had a check in the bank the day following my claim. My vehicles
aren't exactly ordinary, either; AMICA  has never refused coverage on any of
my four-wheeled vehicles, and that includes Porsches (both new and vintage)
and a Lamborghini. 
I must also say that I'm surprised that you want an insurance company to bail
you out of a track event's damage. As a person who has spent a great deal of
time on the track, I can't imagine  expecting an insurance company to pay for
a mistake I made at speed. Isn't there a point where responsibility for your
actions becomes your own? Of course, insurance is there for a reason--to
cover the costs of repair when mistakes are made.  However, even at PCA
events some groups approach the intensity seen at races, and it doesn't take
a great leap of faith to see that the pitfalls of racing, such as oil on the
track, mechanical failure, tire failure, etc. can have a much greater impact
(so to speak) on potential damage a car is likely to incur. I'm a big
believer in racing, and also strongly believe that PCA driver's events are
beneficial to most Porsche drivers, but I have a hard time thinking that
someone should bail me out if I make a mistake. 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 95 13:27:27 PDT
From: "David O. Blanchard" <blanch@capella.cup.hp.com>
Subject: Re: track/auto-x/street tires

I would recommend the Yokos in this situation.  If you were
fighting for the world championship, the R1s might be a better
choice.  The Yokos will give good wear and will not harden up
to the point of being unpleasantly slow.  Dwight Mitchell gave
me a set of Yokos once that he had used and discarded.  They had
sat in the sun next to his house for over a year (Sacarmento, CA).
I used them for practice tires for almost a year before I finally
corded one of them.  The felt good up to the end.

I would recommend getting an extra set of wheels.  The 7" cookie
cutters can be had at reasonable prices at a swap meet and will
work fine.  Make sure you go with 15" wheels and use the 225/50
tires.  Reason for the extra wheels is that the chances that
you will end up flat spotting the tires is pretty good.  Makes
street driving unpleasant.

Have fun.

DavidOB --- blanch@cup.hp.com    81 924 Turbo (931, Toy car) 
Golden Gate Region PCA           
SF Region SCCA                   88 Toyota turbo All Trac

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 95 13:59:03 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 944 oil pan baffle


There may be a cure for part of the oil pickup problem for 944s used
on the track. THIS APPLIES to cars with extensive suspension mods 
which allow very high cornering rates.

The 1989 944 Turbo and 944S2 has an additional pan baffle which is 
to counteract the high-G oil travel problem. It works with normal 
944 pans. The part number is: 944.107.389.03, Oil Pan Baffle, 
$65.97 ea.

Not a complete cure, but I am advised that it helps a great deal. 
Consider this if you are tracking your car on a continuous basis.


Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 05 Apr 95 15:17:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: track/auto-x/street tires


Scott,

>Since you are going to do track events, you will want to order the
>BFG R1's shaved or have the Yoko RS II shaved once you get them.
>This will actually extend tire life and improve performance.

How does it extend life?  I don't think someone with 10 days at the track
is going to be able to tell the difference between a shaved and a "full"
(6/32") depth tire.  Nor do I think he will chunk them.

>Whichever tire you choose will last a lot longer if you do not drive it
>on the street.

Depends on a lot of things.  I think street driving takes away very little
if any tread depth by comparison with the wear tires see at the track.
Say, for example, you get 1,000 track-only miles vs. 15,000 street-only
miles from a set of RSII's or R1's -- is it really worth all the pain of 
constantly
swapping them?  I put mine on in April and take them (well, the current
set) off in November.  Not to mention the rotaries and ramps...

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 05 Apr 95 15:10:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 ignition wires


Mitch,

There is an impedence stamped onto the plug ends.  Each wire should
meter out at between 3K and 5K ohms, end to end.  I think Jim Pasha
probably covered this in an Excellence article.

Inspect the wires in the dark, with the engine running.  Look for blue
arcing, indicating failed wire insulation.

At 140K, your wires are probably quite ready for replacement.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 05 Apr 95 17:23:59 EST
From: Bob_M_Pachman_at_HRC-Mail@ccmail.howmet.com
Subject: 66 912wood wheel

Scott,
    A friend of my sanded the wheel from his '66 912 and it did not remove the 
dark streak. The finished project looked beautiful! Make sure that you use a 
good grease remover before you repaint the steel ribs. Also, the leather hub had 
pulled away from the ring and he was able to restore it by soaking it down in 
armour all for several days.BTW-under the crome ring is brass! If your chrome is 
pitted, polish it down to the brass- it looks great!

Bob Pachman

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 17:17:24 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 hunting

>$3600 for a 1976 914 2.0 that is rust-free except for some battery area rust
>is a bargain to the point of being too good to be true.
>
>Good '76 models easily sell for $8,500 and up with pristine examples worth
>$14,000. Since the '76 model was the last year for the 914 and the second
>rarest production year to the '70 914-6 (only about 4200 1976 models were
>manufactured), the '76 models fetch a premium price.

        My first reaction was to blurt out, "Oh, no way!"  Upon reconsider-
ing that, I think I'll just say that it depends on a lot of factors.  Here
in the Bay Area, it is not at all uncommon to find good 73-74 2.0's for
$3K-$4K.  76'es are about the same (depends on the buyer and seller, may be
a bit less), and 75s are also a bit less.  Not too many around here seem to
be interested in the rarity of the 76.
        One of the racers, Bert Del Villano (sp?) bought his 73 2.0 for $6K.
It was pretty much perfect, slightly non-original, and everybody thinks he
paid too much.  $5K for a great one seems to be the asking rate.
        You know, maybe I should truck my rusty 1.8 out to Atlanta!  It
sounds as if I could make a decent profit from it out there!   ;)

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 18:17:06 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: US "legal" 959, Porsche pronunciation

Hi,

I went over to my mechanics' shop today and for the first time noticed that
he had a picture of a red 959 near one of his tool boxes. I asked him if that
was a real one and he answered Yes. The next queston was " Hey, I thought
they were illegal here?" to which he replied "Not if you got a lot of money."
I guess that doesn't apply to Bill Gates. To make a long story short he says
that there are two in Florida. One is owned by some Austrian/African- don't
know which country- guy who has diplomatic plates (i.e. immunity) and the
other is owned by a dealer who puts his dealer plates whenever he wants to
drive it around. I imagine that the dealer must be Champion Porsche.  I have
yet to see them.

On another note, does it really matter how one pronounces "Porsche"? I know
that it should be pronounced "Porscha", but I think it sounds a little
pretentious to pronounce it the German way when speaking English. You
wouldn't say "After picking up my "Porscha" in Stuttgart, I went to Koeln and
Paree (Paris)," would you? 

Nomex suit on, fire extinguisher ready.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  5 Apr 95 17:16:58 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; paint gun advice

From: Paul Moruzzi <pmoruzzi@hpwarhw.an.hp.com>
Subject: Wanted Paint gun info.

>I have a Snap-On BF500 paint spray gun that I got used.  I bought a seal
 kit from Snap-On and replaced everything I could (couldn't undo the
 front where it would slide vertically).  Anyway it now blows air
 nicely:-)  My question is anyone have any advice on pressure settings or
 starting points for the two knobs? ...

>TIA
>PVM

     Paul, the last thing you need is an air pressure regulator. These are
  available with a moisture trap for about $40 at Sears, etc. Read the
  directions for the paint you are spraying, you'll usually set it to about
  50-60psi. Mount it a couple feet from the gun, don't rely on a pressure
  regulator separated from the gun (i.e., at the compressor).

     The 2 knobs on the gun are for Air mixture and Fan size.  You have to
  adjust these to taste....Most glossy painting goes on heavy, it takes
  a while to geet the feel for this...

               -Lee A.   '79 Binks model 7...


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 18:30:36 -0400 (EDT)
From: Klasse 356 <356parts@cais.cais.com>
Subject: 050 vs 031 ditributors

Stan pointed out the differences between the advance curves of the 
various distributors that an owner might choose between for their 356. 

Stan - I have seen the differences on paper, and on the bench, but 
experimenting with a street motor and an assortment of used distributors 
one day I could not detect any difference. Can you feel it in the seat of 
your pants? It seemed to me that the advance curve came on so quick, that 
if you set the timing at the point of full advance, the distributors 
behaved just the same. I suppose the response to different curves could vary 
with the engine recipe.

BTW, I have offered remanufactured distributors for some time, at a very 
reasonable price, with no real luck. They were re-curved by Nelson of 
Nelson's specialties (AKA Captain Lightning Bolt in NASCAR circles), yet 
people felt more comfortable with new, less precise units. Oh well. Don't 
stock 'em any more

- --------
Walter Piescik, 356parts@cais.com, 703/528-2661
"Klasse 356" New & used parts for your Porsche 356
Visit our web site: http://www.cais.com/356parts/


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 15:37:58 -0800
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: track/auto-x/street tires

>Scott,
>
>>Since you are going to do track events, you will want to order the
>>BFG R1's shaved or have the Yoko RS II shaved once you get them.
>>This will actually extend tire life and improve performance.
>
>How does it extend life?  I don't think someone with 10 days at the track
>is going to be able to tell the difference between a shaved and a "full"
>(6/32") depth tire.  Nor do I think he will chunk them.
>
>>Whichever tire you choose will last a lot longer if you do not drive it
>>on the street.
>
>Depends on a lot of things.  I think street driving takes away very little
>if any tread depth by comparison with the wear tires see at the track.
>Say, for example, you get 1,000 track-only miles vs. 15,000 street-only
>miles from a set of RSII's or R1's -- is it really worth all the pain of
>constantly
>swapping them?  I put mine on in April and take them (well, the current
>set) off in November.  Not to mention the rotaries and ramps...
>
>Kevin


Kevin,

Jim Fogarty, one of the designers of BFG R1, told me that if you are
going to run the R1's on the track, you should shave them. He said
the tires will last longer and will run cooler (more likely to stay
in the optimum temp. range). This prevents excessive tire wear.

Now, maybe you know more about the tires than Jim does, but I think
not. He also said that if you are autocrossing only, you probably do not
need to shave the tires because they will not get too hot in all
likelyhood. I did not make the recommendation just for the performance
improvement, but for tire life as well.

Of course tires wear faster at the race track tha on the street. Let's
not state the obvious. I don't get 15,000 street miles from street tires.
Why would I expect to get that for Yoko RS II's or BFG R1's. I've
heard 5000 miles is about right for BFG R1's on the rear of a 911.

If you are using your daily driver as a autocross and track car I
think it is a very good idea to go through the "pain" of swapping
them! Especially if you are hitting the track every weekend.

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 19:05:08 -0400
From: Telemed@aol.com
Subject: Praise-Porsche Customer Service

An anecdote:

I bought a 1992 911 TurboS2 in Feburary from Brumos Porsche with the factory
one year warranty. Two days ago the bracket that holds the air conditioner
wheel sheared off, trashing the fan belt.

Porsche roadside assistance conveyed the vehicle to the dealership for free,
although they had no record of my purchase in their database. The dealer
called and said that the repairs would cost $690, and were not covered by the
used car warranty.

I called Porsche Customer service, and told them that I was a bit
disappointed at having to shell out so soon after purchasing the car. They
were extremely nice, and said that they would "look into the matter, but
could not promise anything". Today the regional manager called to say that
Porsche will cover the cost of repairs, because I shouldn't be stung with
such a large bill so soon after buying the car.

I was amazed at the cordiality and consideration shown by Porsche customer
service. This stands in stark contrast to other car companies that I've had
to deal with in the past (especially Chrysler).

Thought some of you might be interested.

 -Gerry

1980 911SC Targa, Brown
1992 911 TurboS2, Black

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 19:30:03 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: track/auto-x/street tires

Scot,
FYI the criteria for shaving, and this is according to Jim Fogerty, is the
temps at which you run the tires. They are designed for max grip at about
210-225 degrees. If you are developing greater than that then there is too
much heat due to squirming and you need them shaved.
I ran my new BFG R1's at Sebring  and never got above 160 degrees, according
to my pyrometer. 
This is not to say that on a mid-summer day at an asphalt track such as
Summit Point they won't get hotter. I am sure they will but by that time I
will have worn enough off so that it doesn't matter.
BTW the guys in the BFG support truck at Sebring gave me the same advice.
One other point is that it is fine to run these tires on the street. I agree
with Kevin. The amount you scrub off and one track event is of a far greater
magnitude then you will loose by street driving. I routinely drive 500 miles
to a track event with no discernable wear.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:26 pm

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 19:44:32 -0400
From: StreakN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Drivers' Ed & Insurance Problems...

Thanks for your reply. I understand that others may disagree with the
track/insurance issue, and I suspect a lot of that originates from the
different goals that track participants have. If some are there to learn the
"proper" techniques of approaching what a Porsche can do for one re:
capabilities, I can understand those individuals wanting to retain coverage.
On the other hand, other folks at track events are consistently closer to the
edge of their personal performance envelopes than they realize. This
group--not PCA racers but at drivers ed. events--is the bunch that creates
headaches for insurance agents.  At any rate, I'm not advocating any position
other than my own personal view, which is--if you're at the track and you
break it, you fix it. If others have a different view, well that's what makes
the world go 'round. Everybody's entitled to their own opinion.

speeds, though).

it wasn't a methodical or scientific experiment.

seals are breaking down.

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 20:09:30 -0400 (EDT)
From: Armagan Ozkaya <ozkaya@seas.gwu.edu>
Subject: Softening 944 ride?

Hi everybody,

I have an 85.5 944 which I bought about 5 months ago. 
I drive the car almost daily, commuting from No. VA to DC.
Those of you who also have to drive in DC know that most
parts of DC roads are not admirable. 

The previous owner had all shocks/struts replaced with KYB's.
I have a feeling that the car rides rather harsher (though I
do not have experience with any other Porsche!). Every time I
drive through even a small hole/bump, the car shakes/rattles
and I feel like a piece of my heart gets ripped off.

Is this kind of ride typical for 944s? How do the KYBs compare
with stock shocks/struts? Is it possible to soften the ride,
I am willing to compromise the handling with comfort (a bit),
since I do not race/track?

Any feedback, opinions, suggestions are appreciated.

Thanks a lot.
Armagan.

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 00:35:56 GMT
From: spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov (Steve Elkins)
Subject: 944S ball joints?


944 folks,

What do you recommend for replacing ball joints?
        - using expensive OEM control arms
        - using remanufactured control arms
        - or something else.

My car has 100k miles and the ball joints are a little
loose.  This is a hard driven street car.       
 
There are several places listed in Panorama for remanufactured
control arms.  Does anyone have any experience with them?
 
I have a limited budget and if I use remanufactured control 
arms I could also get some new shocks, since they are about 
$300 less per arm than new OEM arms.  My car seems to be a
little under dampened, it gets a little floaty over about 60 mph.
 
Thanks for any recomendations.

Steve

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 95 17:52:55 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: redoing wood steering wheel


- --Boundary-7965556-0-0

Hi:  I redid the wheel on my 68 912.  Go to a marine supply store and get the 
scraper and blades used to strip and finish teak on boats.  Get marine varnish 
and some basic instructions on revarnishing teak that covers sandpaper grits, 
sealing, and thinning varnish.  The blades and a pint of varnish and some 
thinner shouldn't set you back more than $30 and get a good brush.  The blades 
come in various shapes.  Y ou should be able to find curves that will fit the 
curvature of the wheel and the finger grips.  If you have a heat gun to warm 
up the old finish it will come off easier. 
 
The black inlay is very durable.  I put on 6 coats of varnish, high gloss. If 
you don't want a very shiny effect get semi gloss.  It's three years old and 
shows no sign of wear or deterioation.  Had the chrome ring around the padded 
horn button rechromed.  The effect is great and the wood on the wheel bears 
some scars from the years so it looks very original rather than like an add on. 
 
Good luck, 
 
Ted Smith


- --Boundary-7965556-0-0
X-Orcl-Content-Type: message/rfc822

Subject: redoing wood steering wheel

try to sand it down I will sand out the black inlay that is in the wheel.  
Anyone out there done this before?  Are there any nasty chemicals that take off 
all the old crud?  Any info would be appreciated!

proudly brought to you by falling snow, without which I would be out 
driving right now... grrr !

For those not familiar with UCR, we are the PCA chapter located out of 
Toronto, Canada ( home of the we're-not-sure-if-it-counts three-peat World 
Series Champion Blue Jays ).  But for those more intimate with UCR, April 
is the signal that with warm, sunny days just around the corner, it is 
time to dust of the dash, crank up the carbs, and finish polishing the fuchs 
 in time to immerse yourself in this months events.

APRIL		9	Shift into Spring/Swap Meet

			Thomson Miracle Mile )

			STOPP will be the guest

like more information about UCR and future activities, please do not 
hesitate to contact me at the Internet address below.

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 18:33:33 +0800
From: craigs@amgen.com (Craig Smith)
Subject: mail vol and $

I'm new to porschephiles and had hoped to catch up on the archives and FAQs
before sending too much mail, but I've barely had time to read through the
subjects of new mail. I would very much like to continue participating and
would be glad to pay my share, but will soon drop like many others if I can't
find a better way to manage it. The general FAQ says dividing the list will
not happen, but could it happen if someone else were to help maintain it?
Are there other options? Maybe technology isn't where I'd like it to be,
but it seems there could be a better way. Less unwanted mail would free up
resources on everyone's end. I could say more but I'd like to hear some
more experienced opinions!

Date: Wed, 5 Apr 1995 22:12:07 -0400
From: L8Apexer@aol.com
Subject: Re: 89 951

Congrats on your "new car"!  A water pump at 44k is not that unusual.  I'm
told that the labor is about 8 hours book rate and a pump can  be had in the
$200 range.  Because of the labor already involved, it makes sense to go
ahead and replace the belts at the same time.  Clutches depend on how  you
 drive but most I know will go 60-70k.  Head gaskets-I'm no expert there but
if the car is chipped(how many aren't?) that puts more stress on it
especially if you do a lot of track events.  Also if you do a lot of track
events ie. sustained high rpms it is recommeended to change rod bearings
aboout every 50 hours-now we're talking real money!  I'd try to get the car's
maintenance history and also use a synthetic oil.  Enjoy!
L8Apexer:John Lochner
89 951
95 993

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 05 Apr 1995 22:49:49 EDT
From: MDJS51A@prodigy.com ( KARL E HAUG)
Subject: Brake Fluid

Richard Hocking asked if, in fact, ATE Super Blue Racing was now amber.

We got this story last summer here in Michigan and several folks switched
to the amber stuff with no problem.  ATE Super Blue's specs are as follows:

 -Meets DOT 3 & 4 specs, except for blue color

 -Dry boiling point 536 deg F

 -Wet boiling point 392 deg F

If the amber stuff meets these specs (it'll say on the can), I'd use it.
If you must have the blue stuff, contact Paul at Weston Motor Sports, (610)558-0361.

Karl Haug, MotorStadt Region

> Are there other options? Maybe technology isn't where I'd like it to be,
> but it seems there could be a better way. Less unwanted mail would free up
> resources on everyone's end. I could say more but I'd like to hear some
> more experienced opinions!

This is a very frequently asked question. Please don't take this as a personal
attack. It's just the truth. Here are the answers:

1) NO. Period. No splits until I figure out how to deal with certain 
   issues of making sure that messages are dropped, mis-"filed", or otherwise
   don't go where they need to go. Period. If by "help" you mean
   "come to work for me full time at no pay to read and redistribute
   all of the messages where each meassage goes out within 15 minutes of
   coming in" then *THAT* might work.

2) Less unwanted mail is in fact a good thing. To better manage your
   mail load, select a service provider that allows you to run a 
   POP based mail program that lets you see the subjects and authors
   before downloading the mail. That way, if you're like me, you can 
   *VERY* quickly divide your incoming mail into "not interesting" -- 
   for me, anything about a water pumper that did not come from someone
   on a very short list of names, "interesting" -- for me, anything about
   racing issues, 356/914/911s, fuel injection issues, and general tech
   like tires and oil, "not sure" -- where the subject isn't sufficiently
   informative and the author is not someone that I already know I want
   to read whatever it is they've written. Everything that's in the 
   "not interesting" camp, I don't even bother. I just delete it. If
   I discover that I missed something, I can always fish it out of the
   archives later.

3) you can *JUST* use the archives. FTP over the previous month's mail near
   the first of the month. Read it at your leisure.

4) Read Uncle Bart's missive on the hows and whys of the list. This is a
   *SIDELINE*. It *COSTS* me money. Lots of it, as it turns out, over
   the five years the list has been on-line. So, as it turns out, I *do*
   get to make the rules...

   By the way -- my "real job" is about 85% done via e-mail. I get over
   150 messages a day *PLUS* the 100-150 from this list. *PLUS* another
   roughly 4500 failed mail/admin/etc messages to the "porschephiles-request"
   address. *PLUS* whatever sort of notes my friends around the world send
   me (btw, guys -- don't take this as me saying I'm too busy for you to send
   me mail!!!) So I don't care how strapped for time you think you are, or
   how much of a hardship you think it is to read all this crap. I've got
   *YOUR* mail load covered by at least 100% if not more.

5) if you *REALLY* want a lower traffic list, I'm sure that someone can
   provide you with the T*d's 911 list address. Low volume, and I'm told
   low content as well. Just the thing...

Stan

Date: Wed,  5 Apr 95 12:06:13 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: '88 944 options

| From: "Glen P. Pilvre"  <GLEN@microlnk.ml.ee>
|
| Does anybody happen to know the engine options of an '88 944?
| If I'm not sure of the year, is there anything the car could be
| identified by? (excl. docs) The problem is I'm trying to buy one, but
| I've got  serious doubts about the year-number...
| Also, what should be the first things to check on this model?

In 88 there was a normal 944 (8 valve), an S (16 valve), a turbo,
and a limited edition turbo S (both 8 valve).

If it is not a turbo, the easiest way to tell if it is a 16 valve car is to
look at the engine. The 8 valve has the plugs between the intake
runners off to one side of the head. The 16 valve has a wide head
(to accommodate both cams) with the spark plugs running down
the middle.

The easiest way to identify the year is with the VIN number.
For an '88 8-valve, non-turbo US car, the VIN numbers ranged from
WPO ABO 94 - JN4 70001-79999
or with ABS
WPO ABS 94 - JN4 80001-89999
This is from the 944 spec book. I don't have the VIN ranges
for the S or the turbo. A dealer could provide that info.

BTW, the first thing to check is the service records. If there are
none, it is worth far less as there are a number of things that need
periodic maintenance (motor mounts, water pump, clutch, and
especially timing belts). If you don't have proof of these things
being serviced recently, then you could be faced with doing them
soon after you buy it. The presence of records also attests to the
care given by the prior owner. If there are no records, then a
pre-purchase inspection by a reputable mechanic is highly
recommended.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 00:51:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 050 vs 031 ditributors

> Stan - I have seen the differences on paper, and on the bench, but 
> experimenting with a street motor and an assortment of used distributors 
> one day I could not detect any difference. Can you feel it in the seat of 
> your pants? It seemed to me that the advance curve came on so quick, that 
> if you set the timing at the point of full advance, the distributors 
> behaved just the same. I suppose the response to different curves could vary 
> with the engine recipe.

Well, the simple answer is "yes". It's a question of balance. The original
distributors have a total advance of about 27 degrees, and you start off
with a 3-5 degrees of initial static advance. That works pretty well. The
low initial advance improves power *SIGNIFICANTLY* at low RPM, but as
the R's go up, the advance comes on *quickly* in a manner that facilitates
rapid accelleration, until it's "all in" at a total of about 30 degrees
advance. 

The 031 has 30 degrees of advance, so if you start at 3 degrees, you'll
get to 33 degrees total, which is still OK (factory says that 35 degrees
total advance is about as far as you want to push it. They're right. You
can melt pistons, and break other stuff, if you have too much advance)

The 009 has 20 degrees of advance, so to get that 30-35 total advance,
you have to set the initial advance *WAY* up. That will not be good
for the engine and you can actually feel the poor response off-idle and
at low RPMs. Plus, the 009 has a slight offset in the #3 lobe, to
compensate for the overheating problems in the Type Is without doghouse
coolers. Well, guess what: that's *JUST*  exactly the same case as the
356s!! Problem is, the rest of the curve is just *SO* wrong...

The 050 has about 30 degrees, just like the original VJ4s and 022s, and
the later 031s, *but the curve is different*. As a result, acceleration
is somewhat impeded. You want more advance as you accellerate, and the
curve of the 050 is relatively flat compared to the 031, etc. You get
the same total advance, but you don't get it as quickly.

Bottom line: best bet is the original cast iron distributor, or an 031.
I've also started using the Crane breakerless in a friend's car that
I'm sort of acting as chief engineer for. It's very nice. Next stop, the
Permatune 6V CD system. If it all works well for him, I'll have to
consider it for myself. Of course, I *COULD* design a 6v crankfire
system....

Stan

------------------------------
