Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 02:39:15 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: #1(2) Porschephiles #1303

Re: .050 vs. .009

     Yes, Stan, I like (and use) the .050's. Testing them on my Sun
Distributor Testing Machine, I've found the .050 to have 27-28 deg total
advance. With 3-5 degrees static advance, one can get 30-33 degrees  Total
high speed advance out of them, which with the gas these days is just fine,
thank you. (The .050's were used with alcohol-running VW's which could
tolerate more advance than gasoline-running VW's. That's why the .050's work
on Porsche 356/912's, which need more advance than the "normal" VW
distributors can provide. The ".009", ".010" and ".019" VW Distributors test
out at 20 degrees mechanical advance which is not  enough for Porsches.
      Original distributors have, from my experience and the  Sun's testing
results, only a 1 in 3 chance of being "usable". Some have 35+ degrees
advance, some have 15 degrees advance, and  some have NO advance! Even if
they do have the 30 degrees, the average original has a lot of "slop" in the
timing at steady-state- much more so than a new .050. Originals are also
"sticky" sometimes, coming down from 30 degrees many will "stick" at 15
degrees (or  so), and then sloooowly come down to 0. All this  while you're
adjusting the carbs and think that you're affecting the engine, but in fact
it's the distributor, not you! 
    Frankly, for my money I'd much rather put in  a new distributor that has
a  known, smooooth, continuous  27 degree advance than gamble on a sticky,
sloppy "original".
    Just MHO.
KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro

>>Hi,
>>   I needed some help on a wierd problem.  I was driving my 944S to a
>>client's office, excited the highway and slowed down to about 40 mph when
                   ^^^^^^^

I do this all the time, myself.  Sometimes I positively thrill the highway!


>>The battery is new (about 2 weeks old), the starter recently rebuilt (about
>>3 months ago).  There seems to be power (radio, lights, etc. work).  Any
>>clues what I should go after next?  

I'd start with that rebuilt starter.  Also check that you got your battery cables
good and tight when you replaced the battery.  Generally the first things to check
on any problem are the last things you messed with (one of Murphy's rules).

Date: Thu,  6 Apr 95 07:09:37 -0500
From: Mike Selner <mike@is.com>
Subject: Re: 944 balance shaft seals - How?


>  I'd like clarification on what is meant by 'replacing the balance
>  shaft seals'. Correct me if I'm wrong but here is my understanding
>  of how the seals work:
>
>  Front   ----..   ..
>         |----||   ||   ____||    |
>         |----||   ||  |    ||    |
>         |----||   ||  |    ||    |    ---> Balance shaft
>         |----||   ||  |____||    |
>         |----||   ||       ||    |
>         |----||   ||
>          ----''
>           A       B      C       D
>
>A = Bal. shaft sprocket   B = shaft seal    C = spacer   D = polyester
> seal
>
>  1. To replace the seals, is it just a matter of replacing B, C,
>  and D?
>

I replaced mine last year when doing the water pump.  I replaced B and D.

>  2. The manual mentions using a speacial tool (P9202) to drive in
>  seal B? Is
>     it really necessary? Is it easy to remove the seals once the
>     sprocket is off?

I removed the housing which holds the seal "B" and then removed the
seal on the bench.  I replaced it (carefully) using the socket and hammer
technique.  The seals are different for the upper and lower balance shaft.

>
>  3. Are there any special procedures for assembly? Haynes mentions
>  putting
>     assembly lube on the spacer and the manual mentions putting
>     special oil on before inserting the sprocket. It also recommends
>     the use of Loctite 574 for the bolt. Are these all really
>     necessary?
>

I used engine oil on the inside surfaces and no loctite.
I think the Haynes manual is useless for serious work.
Spring for the factory manuals.  You will learn more than the
$300 (or less if you have microfiche) worth.
I think Jim Pasha did an article for Excellence last year which
covered balance shafts.  I don't remember the issue. (Jim?).

>  4. Can the seals and spacer be bought separately? I choked when I
>  heard
>     the price of the seal kit was $150 - $190 cdn. I believe the
>     kit includes seals for cam, 2 balance shafts, crank, plus 3
>     metal spaces, and 1 infamous camshaft bolt (I guess they expect
>     you to strip the old one). Can anyone confirm?
>

I recall you might need to remove the plastic cover to access these parts.
If that is true, you will need to remove the crank sprockets for the
belts.  You will need the flywheel holder to do that and you will
need a pin spanner wrench to remove the balance shaft sprockets.
You will need the belt tensioning tool to reinstall the belts.
If you need to remove the cam sprocket (Can't recall if you need to
right now)  You will need the 12pt triple square tool for the cam bolt.
I know it hurts - but my experience is that using the wrong tool
will lead to an even more expensive repair.

You may be able to replace seal "B" without pulling the plastic
cover by removing the spacer and pulling the seal.

I bought the parts separately.


>  Any help would be appreciated.
>
>  BTW, I'll probably document all my experiences when this is all
>  done.
>
>  Thanks.
>
>  Joe '86 944
>

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 08:51:06 -0400

Hmmmmmmmm...Well, not to flame the unidentified originator of this
"participant in the Porsche pronunciation parade" (Hey!  C'mon, would *I*
do such a thing?  Why, Heaven *forfend*!), but I do believe that the word
with which Mike ended this message, should have been, "ignorant."

The correct pronunciation of foreign words, especially proper nouns and
names, is but a sign of erudition and, dare I say it, sophistication.
Mispronunciation, on the other hand, unless clearly for ironic impact,
demonstrates either ignorance or, er... (how can I say this delicately)
those qualities most often associated with an abundance of gold neck
chains (and usually, both qualities).

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 09:31:00 -0400
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: 944 console 'hinge'


I want to confirm the recent postings about a part to replace the hinge
on the 944 console (aka cassette holder.)

You NO LONGER must buy the entire unit for approx $150.

You can buy only the 'hinge'; PN 944 552 553 01 010. It now costs $19.
(When introduced about 6 months ago the cost was $13.)

The reason I keep calling it the 'hinge' is that this part is actually the
entire plastic bottom and hingable top frame. It lacks only the upper padded
leatherette top, which you re-use from your existing broken console.

Tools needed for installation: 1 phillips head screwdriver.
Time for installation: about 10 minutes.



Fred Pack					fhp@unipress.com
UniPress Software				phone: (908) 287-2100
2025 Lincoln Highway				fax:   (908) 287-4929
Edison NJ 08817					http://www.unipress.com/

'89 944S2
'72 914 2.0L

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 14:46:29 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Dead 944S


Sanjay

If your car suddenly slows ie dead engine, then it is unlikely to be 
because of your starter.

If it slowed without making a horrible crunching sound, then don't worry 
about cam belts

You have lost your ignition or your fuel pump or your fuel supply

If you loose the ignition you will also loose the fuel pump, because the 
fuel pump will not run unless the engine is turning.

So check for a spark - by placing a sparc plug on top of the engine, 
connecting it to no 1 wire and turning the engine over

If you have a spark, then it must be fuel related if you don't, then 
climb under the dash and waggle the wires in the fues box area - it is a 
birds nest of red wires - my car had a problem like yours and it was a 
loose wire feeding the electronic control box

good luck

Pete

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 06 Apr 95 10:02:50 est
From: "Walczak, Lee" <lwalc@mh.com>
Subject: B&B muffler for 993

     P-folk:
        Are any of you with stout heart, fat wallet, and excellent hearing 
     interested in B&B stainless-steel track mufflers for your 993? I 
     realize there are about 5 people on the planet who would be, but if 
     you're one of them, read on...
        The unit in question is brand new; just came off the dyno at B&B. I 
     had it installed a couple of days ago. It's gorgeous, with welded-in 
     4" end pipes.
        I bought the mufflers for dual street/track use. But they're a bit 
     loud for the former application. There's a pronounced boom between 
     2-3,000 rpm (a range you hotshoes never drive in, I'm sure). After 
     that, things gets quieter, resonance-wise, building to a nice snarly 
     shriek. The mufflers totally eliminate exhaust back-pressure, and you 
     find yourself revving very freely, with more bottom-end torque. The 
     change is quite dramatic. But then, so is the expression on my 
     neighbors' faces as I go rumpa-rumpa up the street.
        I'm going to run the units at an upcoming Driver's Ed, then they 
     come off and either go back to the factory or get sold to another 
     P-phreak. Price: $500. If anybody wants 'em, holler. (Holler extra 
     loudly, so I can hear you over the din...).
        Lee / Wash., D.C.  (Older, but apparently no wiser).    


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 09:21:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: #1(2) Porschephiles #1303 (Really 356 distributors)

> results, only a 1 in 3 chance of being "usable". Some have 35+ degrees
> advance, some have 15 degrees advance, and  some have NO advance! 

Ah.... So *THAT'S* why they have rebuild parts available! 8{)

>     Frankly, for my money I'd much rather put in  a new distributor that has
> a  known, smooooth, continuous  27 degree advance than gamble on a sticky,
> sloppy "original".

Agreed. If that were the only choice. However, an hour with basic hand
tools and an NLA.602.101.50 (shim and washer kit), NLA.602.650.04 (advance
spring, two required), NLA.602.102.00 (sliding surface for advance weights),
NLA.602.301.02 (drive shaft bushing), and you should be set. Shoot, most
of the time you don't even *need* all of that... BTW, you can get these
and other fine parts for your original distributor from Stoddard.

Stan

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 07:53:49 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: Dumb Qestion

You wrote: 

>
>Please forgive the dumb question:
>
>What is auto-x?
>
>Jeff Sussna
>
>
An atuox (autocross)  is a timed  event like  race usually run on a 
large parking lot. The "course" is usually outlined with traffic cones.

Classes are arranged by car type model. The porsche club, Sport Car Club 
of America sponser these events. 

These events are a perfect place and safe place to learn how to dirve 
the porsche at speed. The courses are designed for safety and for the 
challenge of getting through the corners quickly and smoothly.

Autox and salom are used interchangeably both are pretty much the same.

For additional informaiton take a look at the Sacramento VAlley Porsche 
club web page at: http://www.vpm.com/pca-svr/

There is an article on Autoxing as one of the pages.


- -- 
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

This subject may have been beaten to death previously, but being a new member

 Here in southwest Wisconsin there has been quite a furor about the stuff

articles in Pano by Bruce Anderson and Allan Caldwell, but would like some
first-hand information by anyone who has had problems with the stuff.  As I'm

a top end job done) I sure as hell don't want to ruin my engine for the 3rd
time.  Caveat:  If you are ever in Green Bay and need work done on a 914, Ill
tell you where *NOT* to go.

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 08:46:10 -0700
From: dthompsn@ix.netcom.com (William D. Thompson)
Subject: Re: CD unit gone bad on a 911T

You wrote: 

>
>Is it possible to destroy a CD unit by charging batteries IN the car.
>The factory manual says not to do this (I read this after the fact!)
>My car does not have voltage/amperage  at the coil (#15)  and through 
the test
>ing procedure in the factory manual, my unit
>has gone south.  The unit still whines and worked before winter
>hiberation.  I did hook up my charger before trying to wake the car up.
>
>Any thoughts, suggestions or alternative testing procedures would be
>appreciated.
>
>Bill
>72 911T that I want to drive bad!!!!!
>ps Does anybody know who can fix one of these CD units cheap?
>
>
>
Bill:
The CD unit could be fried, but it could be some other things to.  Check 
out the fuses on the relay panel right behind the CD unit and check out 
the relays.  Like all electrical problems, it probably will take a while 
to chase down.  The early 911s with the dual batteries are 
particularly finicky.  The Bosch CD units ain't cheap.  Performance 
Products sells reconditioned units for about $700.  A lot of people 
replace the CD units with Permatunes when they go bad (undeer $200).  
I've used both Bosch and Permatunes on my '72 911T and couldn't tell the 
difference between the two.

Doug

'72 911T Targa (daily driver)
'71 914 (restoration project that may never end)
'74 TR6 (significant other's daily driver)
'74 Mustang (when there's salt on the road)

John:
The '76 914 should be able to hande the reformulated crap better than 
most because of its FI, but that doesn't change the fact that the gas 
is crap and doesn't help any engines.  It's the early models in the days 
before oxygen sensors and electronic systems that have the real problem. 
 Here in the D.C. area, I have to readjust the mechanical fuel injection 
pump on my '72 911 to handle the stuff.

Doug

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 95 9:16:01 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Zimmermann Brake Rotors

Hi Folks -

Anyone have experience with Zimmermann brake rotors on their P-car?  For
an upcoming brake overhaul on my '83 SC, I ordered "OEM" rotors from a
usually-reliable aftermarket supplier (of p-philes FAQ fame).  They're
here, and they look like brake rotors... but some of the details are,
um, less than inspiring.  Let's just say that I hope that the guys doing
the casting and heat treating were paying more attention than the guys
doing the countersinking and number-stamping.  I see this brand
advertised elsewhere as well... has anyone else here tried them?  I only
ask because I recall a thread last winter where the 951 folks had to be
real careful of the pedigree of their rotors since many "OEM Quality"
parts warped...

TIA,
Ed Mellinger

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 13:58:21 -0400
From: PJZabo@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porsche pronunciation

"Nile Koopeers" writes:

On another note, does it really matter how one pronounces "Porsche"? I know
that it should be pronounced "Porscha", but I think it sounds a little
pretentious to pronounce it the German way when speaking English. 

You wouldn't say "After picking up my "Porscha" in Stuttgart, I went to Koeln
and Paree (Paris)," would you? 


Neil, oh did I mispronounce your name, gee I'm sorry, I thought that's how
you're supposed to say it in the US!

Mike's right.  The point is, Porsche is the surname of a man that designed a
car and built a company around it, that is still owned to a great extent by
that family.  His name was Porsche (a soft "ah" at the end please).

It's really not pretentious, I just would want my name to be pronounced
properly regardless of where I happen to be.  That is a thing called courtesy
that Americans are often accused of having very little of when traveling in
other countries.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 13:58:15 -0400
From: PJZabo@aol.com
Subject: Re: Should I Sell? 1970 911T

Ross writes:

>My question is, should I go for the financial security now and get 
>another 911 later, or should I live in squalor and keep the 70 ?

I feel I'm uniquely qualified to consult you on this.  I purchased my first
Porsche, a 1970 911T with S guages, Chrome Steel wheels, Silver with Black
interior, for $5000 in 1980, as a senior in high school.  I can tell you that
I worked my ass off for that car, and loved it more than life at the time
(witnessed by my intense driving and loss of license for 6 mos back then).  I
also did everything myself (replaced chain tensioners with mech ones, shocks,
paint, rust repair,etc.)

One year into college I parked my 911.  THe cost to replace the heat
exchangers conflicted with other trivial costs such as food, heat, etc (this
while going to a State College in NY that was relatively inexpensive at the
time).

I didn't have the heart to sell and kept the car garaged at my folk's house
while I drove a clapped out 1971 Toyota Corona that I purchased for $20 (NO
LIE!!) - the floorboards were held together by plywood!  In the end run, I
sold the car after I graduated to pay off student loans after correcting the
inevitable problems that surfaced with storage (frozen brake calipers, etc.)

When you're young you vote with your heart, and I don't want to take that
right from anyone.  But if you want advice - sell the car now, cut your
potential losses and disconnect yourself emotionally for a little while.  A
911 car is not a practical college driver, unless your folks can support your
habit - mine couldn't.  Get a nice VW 16V GTI if your folks can insure it, or
find the newest, low insurance, 4 door sedan that offers some driving
pleasure.

All us Pphiles, be here waiting for you when you get out, to give you lots of
advice on how to spend you Porsche money!!

A fellow 70' 911T driver who's been there.

                                                      Pete


77' Carrera 3.0 - Complete Resto underway
Wife, son, 2 jobs, and yes - 2 college diplomas on the wall

I realize this subject is a couple weeks old, but I have just got around to
catching up on my mail and cannot let this pass without comment.

The notion that the 911 is "goofy" and outdated is totally absurd. My wife
and I both consider our 993 to be the best looking car made. Period!
(Apparently many others agree, as  people constantly stop us to say how
gorgeous they think the car is.)

While some other "newer" styles (e.g. Supra-bleh, Acura) may be more eye
catching, they tend to look worse each time I see them, while the Porsche
just keeps looking better and better.

Just my 2 cents, thanks for listening

David K.

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 15:33:25 -0400

Subject: replacing 944 ball joints

>What do you recommend for replacing 944 ball joints? 
 - using expensive OEM control arms
 - using remanufactured control arms
 - or something else.

I used reconditioned ball joints/control arms from German XXXX XXXXXX in
Houston, Texas (I can't remember their full name, but they regularly
advertise in Excellence, near the back) I no longer have the car but I do
know that I/the new owner have had no problems after 10,000 miles. As I
recall they cost about $500 for the pair. I think Automotion is also
selling reconditioned ball joints/control arms now but are a bit more
expensive (big surprise !!).

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 11:35:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: Wayne Joerding - Economics <joerd@wsunix.wsu.edu>
Subject: 911SC tire question

I sent the following questions to Bruce Anderson for possible inclusion in 
the Tech Q&A section of Panorama.  Bruce very kindly answered the 
question very promptly, which I take to mean that it wasn't of enough 
general interest to include in Panorama.  I'm passing the question on to 
the net since Bruce's answer left me with some outstanding questions.

March's article on tires like all good articles enabled me to ask more 
questions than I could have before.  In particular toward the end the 
article mentions yearly recommendations by Porsche for tire sizes on 
older cars.  The article even mentioned 195/65-15 for the older 15 inch 
wheels  Would you be able to publish Porsche's current recommendations for 
older cars?

Also, I am particularly interested in recommendations for 911SC's with 15 
inch wheels.  Stock for my year was 185/70-15 and 215/60-15.  Your (Bruce 
Anderson) book recommends 205/60-15 and 215/60-15 and Porsche's customer 
service recommends 195/60-15 and 225/60-15.  I thought that the 
difference in width was important for the over/under steer problems with the 
911, reasoning which suggests the 195 and 225 widths would leave the car 
closer to the factory configuration than your recommendation.  However, I 
believe that when Porsche went to 16 inch wheels they moved to 205/55-16 and 
225/50-16.  Also, I note that all Porsche stock specifications produce tire 
with the same un-loaded diameter front and back.

This reasoning has led me to think in terms of 205/60-15 and 225/55-15 
(yes, they make such a V or Z rated tire) for my car as a way to slightly 
improve performance but still retain factory compromises on handling and 
comfort.  These tires generate the same 24.7 inch diameter front and back; 
and match the width choices for 911SC's with 16 in wheels.

Finally, do you think the 225/60-15 tires will fit inside my 911SC rear 
fenders?

Can you clarify any of these issues for me?  Thanks in advance.


Bruce's answer helped me a little but didn't answer the crucial question 
of whether the 225/60x15 tires will fit inside the rear of my 911SC.

Also, Mr. Anderson mentioned that the only Fuchs wheels that worked 
well in the front are the 7x15" wheels for the 911R.  My wheels are 
7x15 in the front and 8x15 in the rear, while I believ stock was 6x15 and 
7x15 in 1980.  I suppose the reason for my 7's and 8's is that the 911 I 
bought is a "Weissach Edition".

Any advice on any questions raised above would be appreciated.

Wayne Joerding
1980 911SC Weissach

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 13:51:30 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: replacing 944 ball joints

>I used reconditioned ball joints/control arms from German XXXX XXXXXX in
>Houston, Texas (I can't remember their full name, but they regularly
>advertise in Excellence, near the back) I no longer have the car but I do
>know that I/the new owner have had no problems after 10,000 miles. As I
>recall they cost about $500 for the pair. I think Automotion is also
>selling reconditioned ball joints/control arms now but are a bit more
>expensive (big surprise !!). 

I just got a control arm from Dynamic European Technologies in Houston,
Texas.  They advertise in Pano.  I've just replaced the arm and have
no miles on the car yet, but everything seems ok so far.  The rebuilt
arms were $225 a piece.  

Just another data point,

Ross Stites
'87 951

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 06 Apr 95 21:02:22 +0200
From: Chris Berry <chris@vbo.dec.com>
Subject: Re: 944 balance shaft seals - How? 

In message <9504061209.AA08933@is.com> you write:
>
>>  I'd like clarification on what is meant by 'replacing the balance
>>  shaft seals'. Correct me if I'm wrong but here is my understanding
>>  of how the seals work:
>>
>>  Front   ----..   ..
>>         |----||   ||   ____||    |
>>         |----||   ||  |    ||    |
>>         |----||   ||  |    ||    |    ---> Balance shaft
>>         |----||   ||  |____||    |
>>         |----||   ||       ||    |
>>         |----||   ||
>>          ----''
>>           A       B      C       D
>>
>>A = Bal. shaft sprocket   B = shaft seal    C = spacer   D = polyester
>> seal
>>
>>  1. To replace the seals, is it just a matter of replacing B, C,
>>  and D?
>>
>
>I replaced mine last year when doing the water pump.  I replaced B and D.

Well, from what I have learnt from both experience, and from digging
through the archives I would say that 'C' should be replaced also. If
you take the 'spacer' out and clean it up, you will probably notice that
it has a wear line from the seal. This is why it was manufactured as
a separate replaceable item. It only costs a few $$'s , it's just not
worth not replacing


>
>>  2. The manual mentions using a speacial tool (P9202) to drive in
>>  seal B? Is
>>     it really necessary? Is it easy to remove the seals once the
>>     sprocket is off?
>
>I removed the housing which holds the seal "B" and then removed the
>seal on the bench.  I replaced it (carefully) using the socket and hammer
>technique.  The seals are different for the upper and lower balance shaft.

I think it's fairly safe to gently tap the seal into place with a socket and
soft hammer. All the seals  I recently replaced pushed in with hard finger
pressure (with a tap on a socket for good feeling/luck ).
>
>>
>>  3. Are there any special procedures for assembly? Haynes mentions
>>  putting
>>     assembly lube on the spacer and the manual mentions putting
>>     special oil on before inserting the sprocket. It also recommends
>>     the use of Loctite 574 for the bolt. Are these all really
>>     necessary?
>>
>
>I used engine oil on the inside surfaces and no loctite.
>I think the Haynes manual is useless for serious work.
>Spring for the factory manuals.  You will learn more than the
>$300 (or less if you have microfiche) worth.
>I think Jim Pasha did an article for Excellence last year which
>covered balance shafts.  I don't remember the issue. (Jim?).

I would go with the light greasing that the (spit spit) haynes manual
suggests. Make sure all the other surfaced a well oiled before assembley

>
>>  4. Can the seals and spacer be bought separately? I choked when I
>>  heard
>>     the price of the seal kit was $150 - $190 cdn. I believe the
>>     kit includes seals for cam, 2 balance shafts, crank, plus 3
>>     metal spaces, and 1 infamous camshaft bolt (I guess they expect
>>     you to strip the old one). Can anyone confirm?
>>
>
>I recall you might need to remove the plastic cover to access these parts.

Yes the OUTER plastic cover needs to be off, but not the inner one.
	
>If that is true, you will need to remove the crank sprockets for the
>belts.  You will need the flywheel holder to do that and you will
>need a pin spanner wrench to remove the balance shaft sprockets.
>You will need the belt tensioning tool to reinstall the belts.
>If you need to remove the cam sprocket (Can't recall if you need to
>right now)  You will need the 12pt triple square tool for the cam bolt.
>I know it hurts - but my experience is that using the wrong tool
>will lead to an even more expensive repair.

Couldn't agree more .. But if you are ONLY doing the balance shaft
seals (see previous posts for disbelief), you won't need to attack
the imfamous and nasty 'cam sprocket bolt' ......


>
>You may be able to replace seal "B" without pulling the plastic
>cover by removing the spacer and pulling the seal.
>
>I bought the parts separately.
>
>
>>  Any help would be appreciated.
>>
>>  BTW, I'll probably document all my experiences when this is all
>>  done.
>>
>>  Thanks.
>>
>>  Joe '86 944
>>

I'm glad someone responed to the original poster . I was kind of waiting 
for a reply myself. I'm not an 'expert' in this particular field, it's the
first time I've 'sorted' the front of a {{second class porsche a.k.a 
'water pumper' }} , but I'm glad to share any experience/ knowledge in this
area. 

By the way, I would also recommend pulling the front housing off the camshaft
if you are doing the camshaft seals, and replacing the o-ring that seals this
to the housing. It's well worth the five minutes spent to eliminate another
potential source of 944-oil-leak.


All the best,


Chris.

so I will look there, too.

From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: Re: 944 Control Arm/Ball Joint Assemblies

The outfit in Houston that reconditions the alloy control arms is
Eurocar-Werk, 5103 Gulfton Dr., Houston, TX 77081.  Their phone
number is 713-661-6428.  They advertise $299 per side (installed).
I don't know what they charge for the assemblies alone.  Zim's
sells the arms (alone) for $279 each.

Date: Thu,  6 Apr 95 14:51:51 -0500

Subject: Re: mail vol and $

I wrote:

>  which can be set up to filter mail.  I get the digest and then
>  filter out the articles which are not interesting to me (based on
>  a ".interesting" file). This may help you.
>
Craig Smith wrote:

>  Thanks for the info.  I was actually thinking of writing
>  something like that.  But where can I get it?
>

Procmail README Excerpt Reply:

Procmail & formail mail processing package.
Copyright (c) 1990-1994, S.R. van den Berg, The Netherlands.

The procmail mail processing program. (v3.10 1994/10/31)

Can be used to create mail-servers, mailing lists, sort your
incoming mail into separate folders/files (real convenient when
subscribing to one or more mailing lists or for prioritising your
mail), preprocess your mail, start any programs upon mail arrival
(e.g.  to generate different chimes on your workstation for
different types of mail) or selectively forward certain incoming
mail automatically to someone.

Internet E-mail:		berg@pool.informatik.rwth-aachen.de

Snail-Mail:	P.O.Box 21074
		6369 ZG Simpelveld
		The Netherlands

Procmail mailinglist:	procmail-request@informatik.rwth-aachen.de
SmartList mailinglist:	SmartList-request@informatik.rwth-aachen.de

- ----------------------
A recent version can be picked up at various comp.sources.misc archives.
The latest version can be obtained directly from the ftp-archive at:

	ftp.informatik.rwth-aachen.de (137.226.225.3)

as (g)zipped tar file:	   /pub/packages/procmail/procmail.tar.gz	<160KB
as compressed tar file:	   /pub/packages/procmail/procmail.tar.Z	<224KB
- ----------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 16:52:44 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: new rubber !

Well I just picked up my 911 from Performance Alignment here in Cinti.

It's a beautiful day with clear blue skies and temps in the 60's - perfect
day for top off crusing in a car which now handles like a dream !

I decided to go for the Dunlop SP8000's (205/55ZR16 and 225/50ZR16) rather
than the Yoko's because I wanted rain performance and longevity for
these street tires.

Compared to the Eagle GT's on before it's night and day.  I also had the
positive 2 deg camber taken out of the rear and one front (the other front
was about vertical) and went to -1.75 and -.75 on the rear and front
(I think - I left the damn paper in the car).  Wow - I'd thought that
the discomfort and noise were all part of owning a handling car.  The
car is now smooth, quiet, and turns like *NOW* !  I'm gonna have to
learn to drive it again before I do something stupid !  It's like my
brain is connected directly to the wheels !!

With apologies to Queen:

ooooooo I'm in love with my car...

Told my wife I'd have to forget her,
Rather buy me a new set of rubber,
So she made tracks saying
"This is the end now!"
Cars don't talk back,
They're just four wheeled friends now.

(She didn't really leave because of the Porsche - but it's poetic license)
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 13:25:44 +0800
From: craigs@amgen.com (Craig Smith)
Subject: 944 clutch work reply

A late response to some discussion about how much work it is to do a 944
clutch (sorry this is so long):

Agreeing with the previous responses, it takes awhile--mostly because the
Haynes manual skips important points. Is the factory manual really not that
much better? I've been thinking about breaking down and buying one. I haven't
read it yet, but I think a huge thanks should go out to Michael Kehr for
writing the procedure on the porschephiles server. What would it take to get
Bentley to do a manual? If PCNA would license the factory manual for a
small(!) fee maybe it could be edited and slightly enhanced at a reasonable
cost. Or has someone out there done enough already that they want to publish
it?

Anyway, when I finally completed the job I earned a new level of respect from
my wife that I haven't lost yet. (And I saved around $800.)

If you think the rubber center is breaking up, replace it ASAP. Mine went out
in the middle of an LA freeway in heavy traffic and I had to force it out of
gear. I was able to get over to the side before I lost all speed; after 
about 10 minutes it dislodged itself and didn't give me further problems until
I replaced it.

I advise replacing the crankshaft pilot bearing and rear main seal at the same
time. Maybe this is common knowledge. The only hassle is the seal: it's only
$20, but the tool is $120. Does anyone make a cheaper one? I just used a large-
diameter plastic pipe, but I ruined one seal in the process.

I've only done it once, but feel free to call me anytime. I don't want to see
people go through what I went through. 805-447-2579 days

Craig Smith - craigs@amgen.com

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 17:51:50 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Upfixen'

>I've seen mention of the UpFixin' Der Porsche materials on several
>occasions, but I've not been able to find out what these are.  There are no
>references to UpFixin in the FAQ and my bookseller stares at me blankly when
>I mention it as a title.  Can anyone provide a pointer to how to obtain these?

        Sounds like an Update the FAQ item--Walt, are ya there?
        Upfixen' der Porsche is not a title available at most bookstores.
It is a collection of all the Technical Q&A articles from Panorama.  The
articles are gathered together (once per year?  every two or three years?)
and put in a book.  There are at least seven volumes right now.
        Upfixen's are available through PCA or your local region.  You
can buy all of 'em, or just selected volumes.  BTW, if you want to get
all the volumes including 914 info, the cost is just a *little* bit less
than the "buy 'em all" price.

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

Ross writes:

>another 911 later, or should I live in squalor and keep the 70 ?

If you're going to sell it, I'd recommend as a low cost reliable sports car and 
84-85ish Rx7. They're a blast. Mind was going very strong at 175k miles before I
took it over an embankment @60mph (and drove away). They're cheap (2-3k), fun 
and they friggin' *last* (at least mine did).

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 21:13:31 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: She Lives!


If you don't like non-technical P-car stuff, please delete.  This may get 
lengthy! :-)

Well, she's out.  After a long, lonely winter in the OmniBag (if you 
store your baby, get one - more later) my 911 has re-emerged as 
splendidly "goofy" as she went in last December 8.  Remember that post a 
bit ago about the "silly grin" - well, it's back and firmly in place for 
another eight months or so!

Some info some may be interested in from the storage results:

1.  No "flat spots" on the Dunlops (overinflated by 10 - 15 lbs before 
stored; rolled a foot or two twice during storage).

2.  Not a DROP - not even a HINT of any fluids whatsoever in the bag when 
she came out.  Four months of gravity at work and perfection.  No oil, no 
tranny fluid - nothing.  Clean as a whistle!  I love Carrera engines!

3.  Stored the battery in the basement on wood blocks.  Never got around 
to buying a charger.  First crank with the battery hooked up and the 
sweet purr filled the garage again!  No prob!

4.  Car was stored in second bay of a two car garage beside the daily 
driven (in salt, slush etc., much of which was brought into the garage) 
mini-van (now "track support vehicle").  However, it was stored in the 
OmniBag (sold locally, but I know they ship around the country (world?).  
Brake rotors, rubber seals you name it - clean and sweet as I left them 
when I stored the car.  Not a speck of rust or dust.  The outside of the 
Bag showed me what it saved me from - dust, lint, some salt marks 
(evidently from evaporation and condensation in the garage).  But the Bag 
kept it beautiful!  I'm a believer!

And finally, as we head into our first full season together, she has a 
name - Katarina.  Yes, German for my daughter's name - Catherine.  Is she 
goofy looking?  Not half as goofy as this grin I have on my face!  Let 
the Summer begin!

Thanks for your tolerance!

Jerry Mac
84 911 Carrera Targa (Cognac Brown)("Katarina")
Motorstadt Region PCA

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 21:52:05 -0400
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Track/street tires

In reference to your choices on tires for your 944, let me relate my
experiences with BFG's over a 5 year span on an '84 and '90 944. First the
R1's are tremendous autocross and track tires, the life is about 6-8000 miles
of combined street and competition driving, they work extremely well in wet
weather, even with minimal tread, provided it is warm outside.  Cold weather
performance is simply terrible, this is by design.  The only drawback other
than short tire life is a tendency to "nibble" on the road, in other words
follow any imperfections in the surface like cracks, trolley tracks or even
depressions in the highway caused by heavy trucks, this is easily
controllable but may be disconcerting at first. For advice on Yoko's you will
have to speak to someone else, sorry.


                             Steve

                             90 944S2

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 22:37:39 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: re-strangulated gas!

 JUtter914@aol.com said.......about reformulated gas
> would like somefirst-hand information by anyone who has had 
>problems with the stuff.  As I'mabout ready to bring my '76 914 out 
>of hibernation....

We're stuck with that junk here in Ky, too!  My daily drivers mileage was
reduced almost 15% - both cars on fresh tunes.  Have terrible cold starting
problems, as in 30 seconds of cranking prior to 3 minutes of sputtering(I
know, they sound like Porsches, don't they - but not).  I will say that I've
not notice any change in performance once the cars are plenty warmed up, but
they stuff is really obnoxious smelling - doesn't smell like gasoline at all.
 My neighbor told me last week that, while he was pumping gas, the lady next
to him complained loudly of its smell - a proceeded to puke all over the lot!

I'm like you - scared sh__less to pull the P-cars out of hibernation and try
to feed this stuff to them.  My 911's cranky enough on real gas.

Pat Garvey

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 02:29:21 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 050 vs 031 ditributors

> Thanks for all the information you provided it will be very helpful in my 
> selection of a replacement for the 050 in my 69-912.  My question is this: I 
> had acquired a new 'Mallory' distributor, should I install it?  The unit has 
> an *adjustable* total crancase advance of between 16 and 32 degrees.  Before 
> I install the unit I would like to know if anyone has already done this and 
> if the advance curve is what I need to optimize my 4 cyl boxer. Also if set 
> to 30 advance then should I set the timming at 950 rpm 3BTC or only consider 
> the total advance ?

Ummm. You said some telling things in here: like "'69 912"...

Here's what I know: I have zero experience with this particular Mallory, but
used to use their high-RPM dual point setup on big-block Ford sprint cars
Back When. In general they make good products. I *HAVE* experimented with
the MSD "VW Billet Distributor" that also has an adjustable advance. I
find it to be a very useful item indeed for racing applications, but 
find it to be just another useless way to spend money for the street.
I'm a *REAL* big opponent of the "if it's good for racing, it's good for
the street" school of thought. There are very few things that are as
COMPLETELY false as that....

Anyway, your car came with originally with a Bosch 061 distributor that 
has a mechanical *AND* a "vaccuum advance". This "vaccuum advance" was
really a high-pressure vaccuum retard that pulled the advance "in" (i.e.
lower numerically) at idle. This let those particular cars pass emissions
tests. The "vaccuum advance" had no impact on the performance of the
mechanical advance part of the distributor once the car went off idle.
I forget the absolute pressure that it cut off at, but it wasn't too high;
just enough to get you in the 1-1.2K RPM range.

Now, if you live in an area under EPA interdiction, or an area that has
adopted CARB regulations on emissions testing, or for that matter, the
People's Republic of California, you *NEED TO FIND AN 061*. If you don't
you should consider it for completeness anyway. It's just the right
thing to do.

Since there's a significantly high probability that you'll ignore that,
I'll also tell you about the advance curve on the 022/031/061 series.
With the 022, there's zero advance until about 450 RPM, then a sharp slope 
up to about 15 degrees at about 650 RPM, then another linear slope up
from there to about 1600 RPM where the advance is "all in" at about 27
degrees. With the 031, the advance starts up from zero at about 650 RPM,
with the knee at about 15 degrees at about 900 RPM, then it's all in
at 27 degrees at about 1600 RPM. For those of you that care about these
things, this is crank degrees, "uninstalled"; the installed values are 
a little higher (same curve, shifted "up" for 3-5 degrees more advance 
at the same...

Anyway, bottom line is that if you can duplicate the curve, you can use
the distributor. It's just that I hate to see the elegance of the original
destroyed by aftermarket stuff that serves no purpose except to make you
feel good because you "had to" spend all this extra money on the car...

Stan
points...

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 00:24:14 -0700
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Rotten Eggs



According to my wizard son, if your Porsche smells like rotten eggs, it's
running too fat dumping raw fuel containing sulphur through the exhaust
system which burns up in the cat creating the rotten egg smell. This
condition is quite common in Japanese cars, especially brand new
econo-boxes. The Porsche fuel management system is supposed to prevent that.
Have it fixed before attempting a smog check.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 02:45:59 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Zimmermann Brake Rotors

> Anyone have experience with Zimmermann brake rotors on their P-car?  

Well, that's what I used on my 914 racer, 914 street cars, and currently
have on my 356SC... So far, no problems. Word is that Zimmermann
really does make the stuff that came on many of the cars originally.

> ps  I sure wish that Euro-Select would get around to doing the
> air-cooled cars... any of you insiders heard anything about the chances
> of that happening in our lifetime?

Not that I know of. It's not seen as being so critical, with nearly
50 years of 356 "market development" and nearly 30 years of 911 "market
development" people have found or created sources for the parts that make
them affordable. 

Stan

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 95 09:03:35 +0200
From: kevinh@hasler.ascom.ch (Kevin Holden)
Subject: Re[2]: Should I Sell? 1970 911T

Ross writes:

>My question is, should I go for the financial security now and get 
>another 911 later, or should I live in squalor and keep the 70 ?


Sell it. As much as you (and I) love Porsches you're going to college
for something that will, hopefully, set you up for a life of Porsche
buying experiences  and you need as few distractions as possible - working
at some burger place or something just to keep the Porsche going is
not a sensible choice, IMO. 

Whilst not in the same league as a 911, I had a small collection of cars when I was 
at college (errm, 2 spitfires, 2 mini's, a Vauxhall Chevette, Chrysler Avenger) and 
it was the biggest waste of time and money! I ended up working on weekends and an 
evening or two at a supermarket just to survive and the amount of sweating & lost 
nights I did coming up to exams (and assignments) just wasn't worth it!! Doncha
love hindsight... :-)

That '70 will always be around in the future if you want to get another, and you
could get an 'S' next time.

Kevin.

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 08:26:39 -0600 (MDT)
From: Chris Landt <clandt@lib.nmsu.edu>
Subject: Pronunciation of Porsche... a responce!

This is in responce to the articles:

"US "legal" 959, Porsche pronunciation

One article stated that it does not matter how we pronunciate the name of 
the car we drive.
	
Okay, so I was born in America and not Germany. I speek a language that 
Americans believes to  be the language of world commerce. I feel it 
"aint" a problem to go around makin' fun of people I don't know. And as an 
American I obviously take a lot for granted.

Come on... 

I, and many people like me drive a "Porsch(a)" all day. Other people own a 
house and sit on our "porch" at night.

On weekends we enjoy autocrossing our "Porsch(a)s" Other people get to sit 
on their "porch."

Every now and then I like to clean my "Porsch(a)" Other people get to 
hose down their "porch."

Ya get the picture?

When I was in Europe I was smacked in the face with the reality that 
other people speek other languages and pronunciations vary. In England, to 
my surprise, they love to drive their "Jag-you-ares." In Italy there is 
nothing finer than blasting along the countryside in a finnely tuned 
"Ferrari." Nothing decent ever came out of France so who cares how you 
pronounce "Pairs"... (just joking...) Parie! Oh la la....

If you want to remain a stuck up American, go for it. Keep buying those 
"Christlr" "Vipprs" (as the Europeans would say) and quit buying 
the front end of everyones house and expecting it to take you anywhere.

Just a though from the peanut galery...

Christopher A. Landt        PRONUNCIATION: "Laundt"
1986 Porsch(a) 944 Turbo.

P.S. no one can pronounce my last name either, The Germans do every time, 
but not one American. Boy that makes me so mad... Be proud of who you are 
and respect others for who they are!

Subject: Porsche shrunk 944 Repair Manual Fiche to 4"x6"

I decided to go ahead and get the 944 Repair Manual on fiche,
figuring I could pick up a large format viewer pretty cheap.
So, I ordered the fiche (PNA 000 127) from the local dealer.

When it came in, I was surprised that it was a 10 fiche set
in the more convenient 4"x6" size, not the larger 8"x10" size
I was expecting.  Either I had misunderstood, or Porsche
has taken a small step forward on their manuals.

Ron Olson (olson_r@cho.ge.com)

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 10:32:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: I need a new 944 repair-man

> I just had an argument over the price of the 
> clutch on my 944 '86 and I do not want to go 
> to my regular garagist anymore. 

Welcome to the world of owning a 944. Depending on the model, you
could have gotten a quote between about $1600 and about $4000.
These are *REAL* numbers. It really does take that kind of time
to do the job. If you're expecting $300-500 like a "normal" clutch,
buddy, you own the wrong car...

Stan

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 12:03:37 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porsche pronunciation

Jesus, you guys are really uptight on the "proper" way to pronounce Porsche.
 What I meant was that in some languages you pronounce proper names
differently from the original languages, e.g.  Muenchen, Deutschland, la Tour
Eiffel, and Kuempers.  My last name is German and when I'm in Germany it's
pronounced with the umlaut, in France it is prounced slightly differently and
lastly in English the U is pronounced without the Umlaut.  Do I care? No, if
it is easier for others to pronounce it that way and they pronounce the way
it is written then that's fine. As long as we don't pronounce Porsche like
Porch.  BTW, the French also pronounce Porsche without the e.  

Now can we all just forget about it. I'm sorry I got this started and have
wasted everybody's time. If somebody has a problem, then for the sake of
others, address me personally. 

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 12:03:50 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: '73 911S oil cooler update

Hi,

I'd like to thank Jeff Shorey, Jim Calzia, Mike Piera and Steve Watson as
well as those who answered my question last week for their help. Here is a
quote that answers my original question:

Bruce Anderson (911 Performance Handbook, p. 56-57) and Porsche
workshop manual (V.III, sec. 1, model 72 on) indicate that an external
radiator-type oil cooler in RF fender was standard equipment on '69-72
911S.  Anderson adds that "the '73 S had optional loop-type oil cooler in
RF fender unless ordered with air conditioner". 

So '73 S with A/C couldn't get the loop oil cooler, which is nice to know. I
thought that mine was missing and was worried that I needed to get one.
Afterall, the owners manual did say that I should have one. 

Thanks again for your help,

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 09:12:37 +0800
From: craigs@amgen.com (Craig Smith)
Subject: Parking at P factory reply

I would not park in downtown Stuttgart and take the subway/commuter train
(unless you want to shop downtown). It's a hassle and quite expensive.
Instead you can park easily and cheaply at one of the suburb train stations
and go from there.

I think the following still applies, but don't know absolutely:
On Friday afternoon parts of the factory close a couple hours early. You can
then often park right outside the gates. Even during regular hours I never
had trouble parking, though sometimes it's a little bit of a walk.

Craig Smith - craigs@amgen.com

Date: Fri, 07 Apr 95 12:51:41 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: 944 Turbo head gasket questions

Hello Phellow Philes

Earlier in the week I asked about a problem I had with my 89 951 venting about a 
gallon of coolant when I turned my car off after some spirited driving.  The 
answer from a fellow porschephile (thanks Jim) was possible head gasket failure 
(oh, no $$$).  After refilling and bleeding the system there have been no 
further incidents of displaced coolant.  No water in the oil or vice versa.  No 
overheating.

My question is...Is it possible for a head gaasket to leak 'just a little' and 
only under high stress applications?  Or is it usually a catastrophic failure?  
Will a leak down or compression test help diagnos the problem?  I am trying to 
determine if I am chasing a red herring before spending  many $$$ to fix a 
problem which may not exist.  Any comments greatly appreciated.  I have driver's 
Ed at Summit Point on the 4/14 and 4/15.  I do not want to go there with a leaky 
head gasket.  TIA.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov

parts.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 12:41:48 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: Re: mail vol and $

> 
> Glad someone finally brings it up. I too have been laboriously 
> sifting through the 150-some messages I find in my E-mail every two days. 
> While I really enjoy the forum and subject matter, it is too 
> time-consuming. I would be elated if a way could be found to read only 
> about technical matters that affect my particular Porsche model. It 
> seems, without being an expert of any kind on listservers, that model 
> specificity would be a logical way to go. Can it be done?
> 
> Geert Pallemans
> 
> 
There have been a few notes on this subject this week already.  Cruise the 
archives.  

Meanwhile, here is a brief summary of what I know:

Depends on your system, mailer, etc.  I use a unix OS, so have access to
LOTS of goodies.  With the elm mail reader, you can set up a .forward file
to send all incoming mail to the filter program.  The filter program has
easy to understand syntax, and I do things like:

if (subject contains "subscribe") then save /dev/null
if (to contains "porsche" and subject contains "924") then save "Mail/924"
if (sender contains "porsche" and subject contains "924") then save "Mail/924"
if (from contains "porsche" and subject contains "924") then save "Mail/924"
.
.
.

anything falling through ALL the rules gets dropped into my mail box.  I have
94 rules currently, so I get about 10 messages a day into my general mail, and
everything else gets filed by subject matter.

You run the risk of not noticing something if it has a filtered word in the
wrong place, but you also get to view messages by subject without plowing
through them when you don't want to.

Another program called procmail does something very similar, with harder to
understand syntax.  It will allow you to search the entire body of a message,
not just from, sender, to, etc. header records.  It is more robust in that
respect, but does require a lot more effort to install and set up.

Outside of unix I know NOTHING, so don't ask <g>.

 -chuck

- --
'83 911 Cabriolet (Guards Red)

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 15:10:00 -0600 (CST)
From: "thak chaloemtiarana" <tc17@cornell.edu>
Subject: shaving tires

If shaving Comp TA R1 tires improve handling and in fact prolong the life of
the tires (less rubber lasts longer), why does'nt BFG just sell those tires
at the correct depth or pre-shaved?  Why do we have to pay extra to get them
shaved to get better wear?  All this seems contradictory, but I am sure that
there must be some scientific explanation to do with heat cycles and
dissipation, and surely, the government must have had a say about tread
depth.

I just bought replacement R1's and they are yet to be shaved.  If I shave
them, there would be no gooves left on the outside surface and I will be
running "semi-slicks."

Can I shave seconds off by shaving the tires?  I did not shave my last set
and noticed that lots of rubber came off the first few autox and track
events.
Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu

around a bit on the highway.  The steering is very tight, I feel no slop what so 
ever.  The front struts do need to be replaced and are on my "list of things to

totally flat and smooth highway?  I am correct in believing this?  Would an

alignment what numbers are best for a street car that is driven fairly hard?

Scott 

66 912


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 15:27:36 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 Carb Problem

You probably don't have a carb problem.  Rather, the most likely cause is a
clogged fuel line filter.  Especially the one located under the fuel tank in
the front of the car.  It is common, as the tank corrodes, for the filter to
become jambed causing the problem you describe.

 -Allen Henderson-

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 15:27:40 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: '73 911S oil cooler update

So just when you really needed the external cooler the most, it was
unavailable.

 -Allen Henderson-

Date: 07 Apr 95 18:52:01 EDT
From: Kim Knapp <73477.1132@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: Pronunciation of Porsche

I think this is getting blown all out of proportion. I asked my German friend,
who has owned Porsches most of his adult life and has talked to the staff of
Porsche many times, how he feels about it. He thinks that anyone that is making
a big deal out of the pronunciation of Porsche is being silly. He even
pronounces it Porsch in the USA. I find that I pronounce it Porscha when I am
talking to Germans or owners who know how to pronounce it and Porsch when I talk
to owners of Cadillacs and others who have no idea what a sports car is. BTW,
when I am in Germany they all pronounce my last name Kanopp, and it certainly
does not bother me. Why should it, after all that is the way they pronounce
Knapp (pronounced nap in USA) there.
			Kim

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 95 16:26:30 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924 wheel sizes



For the 924 with 5-bolt wheels and four-wheel disc brakes the following 
wheel sizes will work:

	Front:			Rear:
	6J x 15			6J X 15  Spider-web OEM wheels 1979-82

	6J x 16			6J x 16  OEM 928-style wheels
					 used in 1980-82 and 1986-88
					 optional

	6J X 15			6J x 15  Phone dials, 928 offset
					 OEM on 1986-88 924S


Here's what else fits:

				7J x 16  928 wheels, requires a 1"
					 spacer at rear for inside 
					 clearance
				7J x 15  phone dial, 928 offset or 1987
					 or later 944 std. wheel

If you play with the spacing on the front, you can use a 7 x 16 on the 
front with a 205/50 x 16 tire. Watch for strut interference. 

I have stuffed 7" x 16 fronts and 8" x 16 rears with 205/50 and 225/50
tires under my own car with custom, three piece wheels. They do clear.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 19:29:18 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: Parking at the Factory

Pierre asked about parking at the factory:

You should have no problem parking if you don't mind a modest 5-10 minute
walk.  When you follow the Porsche signs to Werk II in Zuffenhausen, turn
left (Museum sign) on what I believe is called (cleverly) Porschestrasse.
 You'll see an entry gate and museum as the street makes a sharp turn to the
right.  Keep going until you find a space (I've always found one at least up
by the Opel dealer, about 1 1/2 blocks straight on).

When you walk back, try the employee office building entrance rather than
going through the guard gate.  (It's on the right just before you make the
sharp turn with the guard gate straight ahead).  If you can get in (sometimes
it's locked), take a quick left down the hall and you'll be in the customer
delivery lounge.  Good place to get some coffee or orange juice and a armful
of the latest quality brochures.  They can also give you a "besucher"
(visitor)  sticker badge or you can get one at the gate if you go in that way.
  After the museum, try (they'll tell you that you can't if you ask!) and
walk up to the upper level where the new cars awaiting delivery or shipment
are located.  The color array of 200 or so new 911s is gorgeous.  

Enjoy yourself!

Perry

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 17:55:41 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Timothy A. Budd" <budd@rohan.sdsu.edu>
Subject: Model age or Mileage

Ok, I'm the toyota guy (hopefully I can live down this monicker).

Anyway, as most of you know I am in the middle of a search for the 
perfect (for me) 911SC.  Firstly, I want to ask a general question.  What 
is more important on the SC, the age of the car or the mileage.  For 
example, if there was a 1979 911SC with 100,000 miles and a 1983 911SC 
with 127,000 miles, what would be the better choice, all things being 
prety much equal?  

Specifically, I have a quasi problem.  I have a really good friend, whose 
friend is an owner of a very respected Porsche garage here in San Diego.  
They also run a small dealership.  Yesterday in the auto-trader there was 
listed a 1983 911SC Targa with 127,000 miles.  I called the dealer and as 
it turns out, it was my friends' buddy's shop.  The car was serviced 
there and he said it was in great shape.

If I were to look at any other cars, I would without hesitation take it 
to this guy.  But when he is selling a car, there is a conflict of 
interest, that gives me pause.  Once I get a SC I will take it to this 
guy for any work on it.  I think I can trust him, but...

Thanks for your time,

Tim

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 22:13:50 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: Re: I need a new 944 repairman

Join the club. 
 
OK. About $500 for the clutch plus another $100 for overnight shipping and
$100 for pure profit on the part. Don't assume that your mechanic spends
much time shopping around. It's tough to bill for that time. I normally
double the lowest price that I can find, so that the sticker shock doesn't
kill me when I finally see the bill. Think about things like $25 window
wipers and $5 quarts (liters?) of oil. You've probably paid those prices.
Why sweat it now. Your mechanic could just hit you on labor instead. If
he's a good mechanic who spots the cheap fixes early in the game, it
probably worth it. 
 
Porsche's are expensive toys. In the last 14 months, I have spent far more
than the original cost of the car on parking (NYC, where having a reserved
parking space runs $500/month), insurance, paintwork and service for my
$7500 944 Turbo. Really makes no financial sense. In that context, $700 for
clutch parts shouldn't make you flinch. 
 
BTW, the 29 year old mechanic owns an Aston Martin POW-spec Vantage, Range
Rover, 911 street car, 911 track car, etc. and collects Rolex Daytonas. I
believe that he is currently shopping Ferraris (he is starting to service
them, so it makes sense to have one for the track). Makes me wonder how the
guys with the full page Pano ads do. 
 
Stan - So which model 944 gets the $4,000 clutch job?

Date: Fri,  7 Apr 95 12:16:46 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Turbo head gasket questions

| From:  <Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov>
|
| Earlier in the week I asked about a problem I had with my 89 951 
venting about a
| gallon of coolant when I turned my car off after some spirited driving.  The
| answer from a fellow porschephile (thanks Jim) was possible head 
gasket failure
| (oh, no $$$).  After refilling and bleeding the system there have been no
| further incidents of displaced coolant.  No water in the oil or vice 
versa.  No
| overheating.
|
| My question is...Is it possible for a head gaasket to leak 'just a 
little' and
| only under high stress applications?  Or is it usually a catastrophic 
failure?
| Will a leak down or compression test help diagnos the problem?

The head gasket on my '84 944 failed gradually over about a 3 month period.
The first symptom was a small burp of water out ot the expansion tank overflow.
This happened a couple of times over a several week period. Then it started
overheating and losing water. I never did get any water in the oil 
(luckily, didn't
have to change the rod bearings) or vice versa. On teardown, the failure was
clearly in just one small area between the #1 cylinder and a water passage.
I put a straight edge accros the head which appeared slighly warped in the
vicinity of the leak, so I had the head milled. I also had a valve job 
done while
the head was in the machine shop (130K miles on the car).

I didn't run any track events or otherwise stress the engine during 
this period.
Also this is a normally aspirated car. A turbo will have much higher combustion
chamber pressures and the gasket would probably fail faster.

It only showed about a 10 pound loss of compression just before the repair.
A month earlier there was no noticable loss of compression from that cylinder.
I don't know if a leakdown would have shown more.

I understand that there is a dye that you can put into the water system 
that will
change color if exposed to combustion products. That sounds like the best
test to try. Perhaps someone else knows the details of it.

I suppose it is also possible that your thermostat had stuck closed. I 
don't know
if this is very likely or not.

Good Luck!

    Eric

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 21:21:51 +0000 (GMT)
From: DAUN WILLIAM P <DAUN_WILLIAM_P@Lilly.com>
Subject: 81 911SC- Puzzling electronics

81 911SC- Puzzling electronics

A week or so ago someone requested info on how/where to wire the heater fan.
This reminded me that my blower didn't work either.  Can someone please help
diagnose from the following info:

1) Heater relay tests OK
2) Fan runs w/ jumper to 12v source
3) Relay fuse not blown and checked for continuity across holder
4) Heater fuse not blown and checked for continuity across holder
5) Relay socket info (I'm sure there's a std convention but I don't know it 8^(
      There are pins at 12,3,5,7, and 9 O'clock
      Pin 12: Never hot
      Pin  3: Hot when HtEx levers pulled up (12v)
      Pin  5: Never hot
      Pin  7: Never hot (this pin is connected to the fan, continuity checks OK
      Pin  9: Always hot (12v)

I will, of course, claim complete stupidity to electrical type stuff but it
seems to me that energizing pin3 is supposed to connect power from pin9 to pin7

Getting on with the question(s):
1) Is there some secret fuse or relay I'm not aware of that could cause the
   heater relay not to work?
2) I'm lost as to what to try next.  Everything checks for continuity.  Seems
   like the power and lever switch are OK.  What can I try next????

Thanks for any help.
BDaun@Lilly.com

'81 911SC
'85 944
'89 Mixed pure breed canine (a mixture of many pure breeds)
One wife
Multiple children

Date: Sat, 8 Apr 1995 00:39:06 -0600
From: Bdale Garbee <bdale@gag.com>
Subject: (fwd) RE: 944 Turbo head gasket questions

> I suppose it is also possible that your thermostat had stuck closed. I 
> don't know if this is very likely or not.

I stopped to get gas in my 924 one fine day in 1989, and when I got back
up to speed on the interstate I noticed the temp gauge climbing.  I backed off
the speed, pulled over to the side of the road, shut down the engine, and
poked around.  I couldn't find anything obviously wrong, so I re-started the
car and drove a couple of miles to the next exit where I got off and headed for
a service station with a phone to call for a tow.  I gathered after the fact
that the engine overheated badly during this process.  I thought maybe I just
had a bad temp sensor driving the gauge.  After I got it hauled home and 
started tearing in became clear that the thermostat had failed closed.  I 
swapped it out, and was able with some difficulty to get the car started again.

There had clearly been some head gasket failure and/or warpage as a result of
the overheating, as I averaged about 1-2qt/day of coolant loss on a cross-
country trip a week or so later.  Nothing in the oil, and water on at
least one plug when the engine was cold.  Made it a real bear to start, but
it ran fine once I got it going.  Seemed pretty obvious to me that I
was leaking coolant into at least two cylinders, before the end.  I had 
scheduled a teardown to get it fixed, but a young lady "solved the problem" 
for me before I could get it done by running a light and totalling the 924 
on my way to work...

So, a thermostat *can* fail closed, and the resulting overheating if not
noticed and understood fairly quickly can cause real damage.

Bdale
'87 944 S
'90 Isuzu Trooper (my snowmobile)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Apr 95 11:01:26 EDT
From: RON OLSON  07-Apr-1995 1100 <olson_r@cho000.dnet.ge.com>
Subject: Porsche shrunk 944 Repair Manual Fiche to 4"x6"

I decided to go ahead and get the 944 Repair Manual on fiche,
figuring I could pick up a large format viewer pretty cheap.
So, I ordered the fiche (PNA 000 127) from the local dealer.

When it came in, I was surprised that it was a 10 fiche set
in the more convenient 4"x6" size, not the larger 8"x10" size
I was expecting.  Either I had misunderstood, or Porsche
has taken a small step forward on their manuals.

Ron Olson (olson_r@cho.ge.com)

Date: 7 Apr 95 13:27:43 -0400
From: mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Subject: Re: wheels and offsets

>> Folks, 
>>    Having recently expanded my horizons from air- to water-cooled
>> by getting an '88 924S, I'm interested in understanding what types of
>> (original porsche) wheels I can get, for winter use (i.e. cheap, not
>> beautiful, but straight).
>> 
>> The phone dials I have, it says "6Jx15ET52.3" on the inside.  I can
>> parse most of that, but is 52.3 the offset in millimeters, and can
>> I use any 6x15 with that offset?
>

much unnecessary stuff being plastered.

continuing headache because a solution was offered to my problem within 1 day by 
one of the best on-line diagnostics on the net: Yes you George.  It is people like 
you, and Peter, and even Stan can be tempted into replying to water pumper 
questions when they appear sensibly.  
	Being a what I would call poor Porsche owner (which is why I have a 944 
and not a 911) this list is proving invaluable for questions relating to specific 
problems and or parts availabilities.  I am a 'home mechanic' and work on German 
cars for fun (sometimes) but with prices for parts and service in the 'States' the 
fun can be short-lived; this list makes the fun last longer.  I am of the opinion 
that you *can* maintain these cars yourself, the technicalities in these motors is 
nothing special (yet).  You do make stupid mistakes when you start; that's where 
this list is proving invaluable; there are lots of us, some of us have been there.  
The days of the home mechanic are numbered with the advent of new engine 
management systems and more complex sensors, we can extend our own days by keeping 
up with some of this development on the net and by sharing our 
experiences/solutions.  Volney Spalding (proud patron) has contributed in a way 
that he can (and selling SG equipment at the prices they charge he should be able 
to!  Sorry Vol...)  I hope to be able to give unka Bart some dough after my next 
paycheck, and have been saying the same thing for the last two months. Now I need 
to save that same dough for a knee operation coming up. So in order to feel that I 
am contributing something I have been trying to respond to questions on technical 
issues whenever possible (but George usually beats me to it).  Just wait George, 
as I'm having to repair more things on this 944 I'll get quicker on the draw...
	Just my $0.02...

Date: Sat, 8 Apr 1995 10:33:08 -0400
From: WA8MSF@aol.com
Subject: F/R Stagger 964 C4 - Handling???

Hello allrad mavens!  I am about to re-tire the '90 C4 for the summer and
have the following technical question:

Will dissimilar tire diameter cause any bad or maybe even good effects as far
as the differential-locking computer is concerned?

It seems like if one uses front tires that are larger diameter than the rears
(as in 205/55-16F on 7" and 245/45-16R on 9"), the rear will be turning
slightly faster and maybe cause the front to be given more torque or some
such.

How does this work in practice?  What would be good tire sizes for 7x16 front
rims and 9x16 rears (this is what I have from factory race department in
1991)?

My sap is rising here in sunny Ohio.

Mike 
Cincinnati
wa8msf@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 08 Apr 95 10:57:11 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: F/R Stagger 964 C4 - Handling???

Hi, Mike

> Hello allrad mavens!  I am about to re-tire the '90 C4 for the summer and
> have the following technical question:
> 
> Will dissimilar tire diameter cause any bad or maybe even good effects as far
> as the differential-locking computer is concerned?
> 
> It seems like if one uses front tires that are larger diameter than the rears
> (as in 205/55-16F on 7" and 245/45-16R on 9"), the rear will be turning
> slightly faster and maybe cause the front to be given more torque or some
> such.
> 
> How does this work in practice?  What would be good tire sizes for 7x16 front
> rims and 9x16 rears (this is what I have from factory race department in
> 1991)?
> 

The effect on the computer will not be noticeable, as long as the
differential in circumference front to rear is negligible. 

Your ABS may give you an indication that it is not working properly, but
check your owner's manual for specifics.

My guess is that Porsche will have similar restrictions to those that Audi
has for their Quattro cars...

Of course, I could be dead wrong. :-)
- --

Date: Sat, 8 Apr 1995 17:11:41 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: 356 carb problem

Could be several things. Dirt in the carbs. Carbs are fairly easy to clean,
just get a good manual with a good exploded view so all the jets go back in
the right place. If you don't have compressed air, one of those little
bottles used to clean lenses and cameras and such, available at the art
store, will work fine. Use carb cleaner, wear safety glasses to keep from
getting carb cleaner in your face (you never know which opening it will come
out of when you put air through it).

Second possibility, needle valve for admitting fuel to the float bowl is
hanging up. If you are sure that this problem is confined to one carburetor,
maybe try swapping the valve between carbs to see if the problem moves with
it.

Here's a way to check that needle and seat assembly once you have it out of
the car: suck on it (pretend you are the float bowl.) It should hold a
vacuum, that is, stick to your tongue. Also try tapping the assembly on a
surface like a piece of wood (to avoid damage) to dislodge and dirt that may
keep it from seating properly.

Is your fuel filter ahead of (tank side) or behind (between pump and carbs)?
It should be ahead of the pump (I know, most people put it downstream, I
plead guilty). The pump should be pulling through the filter. It is possible
that there is some dirt jamming the pump outlet or filter inlet, and floating
around in there causing intermittent blockage. Pull to pump cover and check
for dirt on the screen.

(Later) Alan Henderson correctly pointed out that you should also check the
filter below the gas tank. Easy to do. Close the valve (inside cabin, below
center of dash), get underneath, unscrew wingnut on filter bowl, take out
screen, check and clean.

Other possibility, but very remote, is that you have some sort of vapor lock
problem. But that wouldn't explain why only one side seems to have this
problem, unless you have somehow misdiagnosed it as being confined to one
carb.

One last word -- don't install Webers to fix this problem. 

Pete

Date: Sat, 8 Apr 1995 21:53:07 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: PCA NNJR Concours Workshop

Went to the Concours Workshop today, hosted by European Performance, and
lectured by fellow Porschephile, Larry Reynolds, aka. CarcareSP@aol.com. I
expected to be bored, as I am not a concoursy kind of guy. 
 
Was very surprised. It was a great lecture and I learned at least as much
about technical details and the quality of German parts as I did about
cleaning the car. Like hard Bosch wipers will wear out soft Porsche
windshields, like Armorall leaches plastic and vinyl, like Larry sells the
original Porsche touchup paints which are unobtainable from dealers, etc.
Also was convinced that cleaning the two dirtiest spots on my car, engine
and wheel wells, was safe and easy, with the right materials. 
 
Larry sells most of the Wurth, Sonax, P21, etc. cleaning and conditioning
products. Hundreds of them. And he details the uses of each one. I don't
know of another one stop source for this type of thing. Definitely hit him
up for a flyer. It should go on the shelf with Pano, Excellence, Imparts
and Eastwood. 
 
Also check out the next PCA Concours workshop in your area, even if the
idea of concours doesn't excite you. It could be far more interesting than
you have imagined. 
 
See, all AOL'rs aren't bad:)

Subject: 944 door handle problem


Howdy P-Philers!
  I've got a question for those of you with intimate knowledge of the door
handle.  The problem is that the outside handle does not travel far
enough to unlatch the door.  The interior handle works perfectly.

  I took off the interior panel and 'played' with the mechanism for
a while and came to the following conclusion.  The problem is that the
metal part connecting the door handle latch to the lever that releases
the door latch doesn't travel far enough.  Where the bototm of the
metal part there are threads that could be unscrewed to "elongate" the
travel enough for the handle to work.  
  I looked in the haynes manual, and it vaguley says to spread apart
the connector and unatach..  It is a small plastic piece, and I don't
want to break it..   Is this the only method?  If so, how hard should
I pry at it?  Could I adjust this metal pieces postion at the top?

Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated!  Thanks!

Regarding the problem Tracy Meyer mentioned on his 951 and it belching
coolant after running hard- Check the head gasket.  When the gasket is
starting to fail it can pressurize the coolant system and cause it to expell
coolant.

Date: Sat, 8 Apr 1995 22:42:08 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Rebuilding Brakes

Corbett Kull writes:

I'm going to be running in some Autocrosses and drivers schools
this year and I'm concerned about my brakes.  I have an 85 911
and the brakes calipers have never been rebuilt.  Because of
the age of the car, would it not be cheap insurance to rebuild
the calipers?  The calipers are not leaking right now, but I would
hate to have one blow out at 100+mph because of their age.
- ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Corbett,

I cannot disagree more with anyone who says "not to rebuild" your brake
calipers.  It would be an excellent time to do this!  After ten years the
brake seals can become quite brittle and can easily be broken.  What can
happen is that a seal will crack, and let fluid leak past, resulting in no
braking pressure.  Chances are that it will happen at a very inopportune
moment, with unhappy results.  I rebuild my calipers every other season (or
after about 10 events).  Even after this short a time, the boots become
brittle, and the seals are much "stiffer" than new ones.  Remember that you
are taking your car onto the track, and components that would last many years
on the street will "age" very quickly under the heat and stress of track
driving.


Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer



------------------------------

Date: Sat, 8 Apr 1995 23:24:07 -0400
From: L8Apexer@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 Turbo head gasket que...

Tracy, as yet I have not encountered this on my car, also an 89.  A friend of
mine wiith an86 had exactly the wsame experience.  At first he thought it was
the the water pump and that was replaced for a tidy sum.  He still had
intermittant decreases in the coolant level but no leaks could be detected
and the exhaust looked clean.  Things continued to deteriorate and it was the
head gasket in the end.  Sorry for the news but better sooner than later.

Porsche being an older design?

After paying closer attention to the oil level guage, it seems
that the dash guage indicates about 3/4 full once the engine
is at operating temp.   Also noticed that it can vary some
with both longitudinal & lateral G loading and engine load.
Of course this makes sense.

so it is quite a novelty still, maybe that's why I'm

engine as well so this just compounds it...
