Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 02:20:56 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 Carb Problem.

Dear Snarkler:
      Re: Zenith carb that "runs out of gas" after 2-3 miles- it probably IS
running of gas! Most likely from a bad new Needle Valve! Replace the needle
valve with  the old one and you'll likely be fine! (We've had a recent rash
of Zenith (And Solex) carb kits whose needle valves stick. If they stick
closed, the carb will run out of gas. If  they stick open,. the carb floods.
Either way, you lose.
      Other possible problems include a weak/bad fuel pump. a dead bug in
your fuel line (rather unlikely),. or your knee hitting the fuel cock lever,
moving it so only a little gas gets through, enough to run the car for a few
miles, then "run out of gas". But I bet the problem's as described in the
first paragraph.
KEEP THE 356 FAITH!!!
The Maestro


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1312                         Sun Apr 9 21:59:54 CDT 1995
Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 07:39:48 -0400
From: Snarkler@aol.com
Subject: 356 Carb Problem (Solution)

My "Thanks" go out to everyone who responded with their "help" on my Zenith
Carb problem.   All of your suggestions were greatly appreciated.   The good
news is that it's running great now....   Problem was that the "new" needle
valve (from the "new" rebuilt kit) wasn't sealing properly?  Never was able
to get it to seal?, even after a very good "flushing" with carb cleaner?.  I
also noticed that the "Old" ones that were removed, appears to be designed a
bit different (square opening at the base of the needle)?; and after
installing one of the "old" valves, the problem is gone. Thanks again for
everybody's help on this one.  "We're back on the road again".

Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 11:07:12 -0600 (CST)
From: "thak chaloemtiarana" <tc17@cornell.edu>
Subject: pronunciations--into the fray

Pronunciations are culture specific.  Once they migrate, all bets are off.

My sister-in-law once asked about my porch and I replied "I need to replace
some rotton boards this spring."  In Siam, Porsche is pronounced (or known
as) "Paw-che" the "P" is unaspirated and the frist syllable is middle tone,
"che" is pronounced as in "Che Guevara" but with a falling tone.

My own name is pronounced anyway you'd like in American English (most people
give up after the first name), but in its original cultural context, it is
pronounced "Tuck" in which the "T" is aspirated, the word is high tone and
ends with a glottal stop.  I can give a lesson on the last name, but I doubt
whether many will remember.  When asked by a store clerk once, I made the
mistake to tell him that (he should not bother writing it down because) it
was "long, very."  The next thing I heard that he had called my office
looking for a "Mr. Long"!

I continue to enjoy driving my "Paw-che" (plural).
Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu

Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 13:31:56 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Matthew A. Dilligan" <diligan@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Mystery 914 air filter

	Well I went home and tried to solve the bucking problem with my 
914 1.7. The pressure sensor seemed fine and disconnecting the throttle 
switch seemed to make the problem go away. So I removed the throttle 
switch, cleaned the contacts and put it back in. Everything seems pretty 
good now, but it still idles rough until warm.
	 When I removed the airbox I realized there didn't seem to be an air 
filter. So I went to a shop to get one and the one they had for a 914 
1.7 didn't fit. What's going on? Do I have a non-stock air filter housing? 
Looking at the drawings in the Automobile Atlanta catalog (haven't 
gotten a manual yet) externally it looks similar and it seems to fit 
right in, and the airfilter I tried to put in looks a lot like the one 
they've got in the catalog but it didn't fit. 
	There seems to be some sort of oiled-foam filter encased in a metal 
housing that fills most of the airbox which didn't seem to be removable (I 
didn't try to force it, though) and a baffle or something that the 
apparently stock airfilter seemed to just fit inside. Could this strange 
setup be causing my rough running problems (different vacuum signal due 
to non-stock intake parts)? 
	
Matt
1970 914 1.7

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 14:35:13 -0400
From: Andre Rotchel <lmcanro@LMC.Ericsson.SE>
Subject: Re: Sunroof on 944 (cant get it out!)



Hi Marc,

basically, you are doing the right thing to remove the 
sunroof but your ignition key is not set 
at the proper position...

To remove the sunroof:

1/ Make sure it is closed:
While the car is on, press the sunroof button 
until it tilts down and it is completely closed.

2/Turn off the car.

3/ The ignition key has 3 levels. Turn the ignition key 
                                  ---------------------
only *ONE* notch to reach the first level.
- -----------------------------------------
At this point, press the sunroof key. You should
hear a faint unwinding noise. Keep pressing until the noise stops.
The hook is now off.

4/ Unhook the front manually. Press upward the back of 
the sunroof. At this point, you should be able to 
slide it out.

Regards,
Andre Roctchel.

Just fill the housing up to the line with engine oil and go.

Date: Fri, 07 Apr 95 07:51:48 PST
From: radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
Subject: 914 CV Joints and other stuff

          Just dropped the burnt-out 1.8 from my '74 914.  Replacing
          it with 2.0 from a '75.  Gonna rebuild it before installing.

          Anywho, I need to rebuild/replace the CV joints.  Original
          plan was to:
          (1) Remove entire half-axles (incl stub axles)
          (2) Replace rear wheel bearings
          (3) Clean CVs, install new boots and pack with Sta-Lube
              CV grease
          (4) Replace the one that was clunking

          Some of you may remember my question last month about how
          to get off the axle nut.  I have long cheater pipe but I
          have been rethinking.  Is it worthwhile to go to the trouble
          of removing stub axle to get to bearings?  Someone said that
          I will need a slide hammer to get out the stub axles --
          where do you attach the slide hammer?  DO you need to remove
          the outer CVs first or can I pull the whole thing as a unit?

          Also, I noticed while replacing the rear rotors that the
          left rear training arm can be moved laterally a few mm.  The
          other one is rock solid.  Is this an adjustment problem or
          does it mean that the trailing arm mount is shot?  From what
          I can tell, the trailing arms mount with a big piece of
          threaded rod that is encased in rubber in the trailing arm.
          Then the trailing arm is mounted to the body.  I have never
          seen where I would need to install bearings or bushings yet
          the catalogs offer urethane bushings for the rear trailing
          arm.  I apologize for being ignorant on this area, but I
          have never seen a 914 rear suspension completely
          disassembled.  I don't want to screw anything up like I did
          when I started hacking away at my Triumph.

          Thanks, Tim Radsick

          P.S: When I removed the engine, I noticed that the front
          engine mounts had both sheared off through the rubber.  Is
          this common?  And one more thing... Is there a better CV
          grease to use than the Sta-Lube.  Perhaps a moly-synthetic?

------------------------------

Date: 09 Apr 95 10:36:52 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: distributors and such

Lately, there has been some discussion about distributors for the 356. Stan
called it right: unless the engine has been significantly modified from stock,
anything but the factory advance curve falls under the heading of "cash
generating device."
 
Stan points out that:
>The original
>distributors have a total advance of about 27 degrees, and you start off
>with a 3-5 degrees of initial static advance. That works pretty well. The
>low initial advance improves power *SIGNIFICANTLY* at low RPM, but as
>the R's go up, the advance comes on *quickly* in a manner that facilitates
>rapid accelleration, until it's "all in" at a total of about 30 degrees
>advance.
>The 031 has 30 degrees of advance, so if you start at 3 degrees, you'll
>get to 33 degrees total, which is still OK (factory says that 35 degrees
>total advance is about as far as you want to push it. They're right. You
>can melt pistons, and break other stuff, if you have too much advance)
>The 009 has 20 degrees of advance, so to get that 30-35 total advance,
>you have to set the initial advance *WAY* up. That will not be good
>for the engine and you can actually feel the poor response off-idle and
>at low RPMs. Plus, the 009 has a slight offset in the #3 lobe, to
>compensate for the overheating problems in the Type Is without doghouse
>coolers. Well, guess what: that's *JUST*  exactly the same case as the
>356s!! Problem is, the rest of the curve is just *SO* wrong...
 
[Right on, Stan!!!]
 
>The 050 has about 30 degrees, just like the original VJ4s and 022s, and
>the later 031s, *but the curve is different*. As a result, acceleration
>is somewhat impeded. You want more advance as you accellerate, and the
>curve of the 050 is relatively flat compared to the 031, etc. You get
>the same total advance, but you don't get it as quickly.
>Bottom line: best bet is the original cast iron distributor, or an 031.
 
To which Pellow replies
>Original distributors have, from my experience and the  Sun's testing
>results, only a 1 in 3 chance of being "usable". Some have 35+ degrees
>advance, some have 15 degrees advance, and  some have NO advance! Even if
>they do have the 30 degrees, the average original has a lot of "slop" in the
>timing at steady-state- much more so than a new .050. Originals are also
>"sticky" sometimes, coming down from 30 degrees many will "stick" at 15
>degrees (or  so), and then sloooowly come down to 0.
>Frankly, for my money I'd much rather put in  a new distributor that has
>a  known, smooooth, continuous  27 degree advance than gamble on a sticky,
>sloppy "original".
 
Sounds like Monty Python, the little old ladies who can't tell the difference
between Whizzo Butter and a dead crab. Comparing correctly functioning
original distributors (which aren't already junk or sorely in need of a
rebuild) with new units would be more appropriate.
 
And Stan comes back with
>Ah.... So *THAT'S* why they have rebuild parts available! 8{)
>an hour with basic hand
>tools and an NLA.602.101.50 (shim and washer kit), NLA.602.650.04 (advance
>spring, two required), NLA.602.102.00 (sliding surface for advance weights),
>NLA.602.301.02 (drive shaft bushing), and you should be set. Shoot, most
>of the time you don't even *need* all of that... BTW, you can get these
>and other fine parts for your original distributor from Stoddard.
 
Pellow:
>Yes, Stan, I like (and use) the .050's. Testing them on my Sun
>Distributor Testing Machine, I've found the .050 to have 27-28 deg total
>advance. With 3-5 degrees static advance, one can get 30-33 degrees  Total
>high speed advance out of them, which with the gas these days is just fine,
>thank you.
Pellow still doesn't get it, the curves are WRONG! And they will stay wrong
even if you set the same total advance as the stock distributors. He just
doesn't grasp the concept that total advance isn't the total story. Midrange
matters too, in terms of advance curve slope and begin/end, as already
described so well by Stan.
 
                                  .....
 
Self-appointed experts, with personal agendas (read: increased sales of
whatever dreck they have sitting on the shelves) notwithstanding, there is a
reason the factory chose a given advance curve. There is a right curve, and
then there are all sorts of wrong curves, for all the wrong reasons, for any
given engine configuration. If you change the configuration, maybe, MAYBE
you need a different advance curve. Maybe you only need to vary the static
timing to allow for different cams/compression/etc. Whatever, the only way
you are ever going to find out for sure what that optimum curve should be is
by spending time and money on a dyno. Most people who recommend some
different-from-stock advance curve for a different-from-stock engine have
never actually gone out and spent the money to determine the optimum curve.
They may recommend a certain distributor and a certain maximum advance using
knowledge (presumably gained at the cost of detonated-to-death engines) that
it won't cause any particular harm, but they don't know (although they may
even believe their own PR) that it's any improvement on stock. Once
you know how a carmaker arrives at a particular advance curve, you can see
why there is ONE correct advance curve for that engine. This is basically the
same argument as the current craze for "chips" to "improve" the factory's
tuning of the Motronic box. (See Hanks, Stan, "Cash Generating Device." Many
previous posts.)
 
While I was at Porsche, we had the following procedure for determining the
curve for an engine with non-adaptive ignition. The engine is mounted on a
dyno and run with individual cylinder knock sensors, a knock sensor on the worst
cylinder, or just the trained human ear. For laboratory purposes, you can use
special water-jacketed spark plug adapters, made by Kistler, AVL, and others,
that permit piggybacking a piezoelectric pressure transducer on any standard
spark plug port. Or machine a laboratory head with ports for piezo pressure
transducers on each combustion chamber. Or use a standard production knock
sensor if the optimum location for that engine has been determined (you can't
just stick them on the block like one of those toilet deodorizer things.)
 
For any given rpm a curve is plotted for horsepower vs. ignition
advance, up to the knock limit. This is done at several different rpms.
We called these "Zuendhaken" ("ignition hooks") due to the shape of the
curve. They might look something like this: (a purely hypothetical curve; if
this doesn't look right on your reader try a Courier font and 80 column page):
 
 
      |
      |
      |
      |
      |
      |
      |
      |
      |                                                 5000
      |                                             *   *  *
Power |                                          *   x  x     *
      |                                       +   +       x <-6000 rpm
      |                                     +  4000   +
      |                                         rpm
      |
      |
      |                         o
      |                      o        o
      |                  o   3000 rpm
      |
      |            .
      |       .       .
      |   .    2000 rpm
      |
      ----------------------------------------------------------------
      0     5     10     15     20     25     30     35     40
                           Timing (crank degrees)
 
 
In this simple example, we would want a distributor advance curve that gives
us the following:
 
rpm               2000      3000      4000       5000      6000
 
advance            10 deg    20       30-34     34-39     35-37
 
If you look at the "ignition hooks" you will see that if you don't run near
the top of each curve, the peak of each hook, you are giving up power. In
other words, there is ONE CORRECT ADVANCE CURVE that will give you maximum
power throughout the rpm range. There are other curves that will allow the
engine to run, work, and avoid detonation in the midrange if the distributor
is installed to give the same total advance as stock, but they will give up
power in the midrange. That means your car will accelerate slower through
the gears.
 
Furthermore, if in your laboratory testing you hit the knock limit before
the curve drops back down, you may want to specify higher octane fuel or
change the mechanical design of the engine. This sort of fine tuning is what
development in the prototype stage is
all about. If I remember correctly, the rule of thumb for laying out non-
adaptive ignition systems was to maintain a 3 degree, or better 5 degree
(crank angle) safety margin from the knock limit. As engines age, they tend to
get progressively lower knock limits, although this is no longer quite as
severe with modern detergent fuels. See farther down, discussion of fuels.
 
So the curve we finally build into the distributor might look like this:
      |
      |
      |
      |
    40|
      |
      |                                                  ............
      |
      |
    30|
      |                                         .
ign   |
advnce|
      |
    20|                               .
      |
      |
      |
    10|                     .
      |
      |..................
      |
    0 ----------------------------------------------------------------
      0        1000        2000      3000      4000      5000      6000
                                 engine rpm
 
 
This is a very simple curve. You can design in breaks in the slope of
the curve by using more than one set of springs. Centrifugal advance
systems can not give a downward slope at higher rpms; the curve can only
be flat or slope up.
 
Vacuum advance (or even vac retard) are added to some (more modern than 356)
distributors to give different ignition timing at part load for economy or
emissions reasons. Vacuum devices can be used to give a downward slope.
For reference, see "Bosch Technical Instruction, Battery Ignition Systems,"
VDT-UBE 120/3B, or "Bosch Automotive Electric/Electronic Systems."
 
I hope this clarifies any misconceptions about finding a "better than stock"
advance curve for stock engines. It ain't gonna happen.
 
As for rebuilding original 356 distributors, Stoddard offers this service at
a nominal cost. No more bearing slop, no erratic timing, no sticking springs,
etc.
 
There has been an associated urban legend about modern gasoline not being as
good as the stuff we used to get 35 years ago. Pure uncut Bullshit. This has
been perpetrated by the same people who have something to sell you, like
distributors which have been magically recurved for "today's reformulated
gasolines" or engines built to have lower compression ratio than stock because
they allegedly won't run on what the perpetrator calls "today's panther piss."
As far as detonation is concerned, the only thing the engine cares
about is octane number. It only takes a moment to glance at the factory recom-
mendations for fuel, as stated in the owner's handbooks, to blow this claim out
of the water. 356 C recommended 94 Research Octane No. (about the same as our
present-day "midgrade" at 89 pump octane, which is typically 4-5 points lower
than a fuel's RON.) The SC called for 96 RON, adequately met by our present
unleaded premium. The 356 Carreras called for 96 RON in their last
versions, while earlier Carreras didn't even call for that high a grade.
(Reference: appendix to "Porsche 356: Driving in its purest Form" by Conradt.)
You have to remember that in the 1950s and early 1960s, when these cars were
designed, we didn't have the rocket fuel leaded Sunoco 260 and the like
which was developed for big high-output American engines of the late 1960s. And
Germans didn't have any sort of monopoly on high grade fuel, if anything their
early postwar economy didn't allow or require high grade fuel. That whole trend
started with the big overhead valve American V8 and the resulting horsepower
race. Bottom line, 356s will run fine on modern fuel. If anything, they will
run better, due to the detergent properties of modern fuel and resulting
avoidance of combustion chamber deposits which in the old days could
eventually lead to detonation.
 
It is true that modern gasoline is different. Its heat value is lower. This
means that unless you rejet the carbs or recalibrate older injection systems
accordingly, the engine will run leaner. Modern systems with oxygen sensors
don't care, they set the correct mixture automatically. But it would
be a mistake to misdiagnose detonation caused by a lean mixture as detonation
caused by lower octane fuel, and fix the non-problem by dialing back the total
advance or installing some magic distributor from a different application. Yes,
modern fuel will give ever so slightly less power, because the little bit of
extra fuel you need to get in the chamber will displace a very small amount of
combustion air, but you would never feel this and you would need to measure it
under controlled conditions or on a dyno to tell for sure. Atmospheric effects
would more than cover up this slight power difference. Also some fuel, such
as the gasohol available or mandated in some parts of the country, plays
holy hell with some older fuel systems. But that's not an octane problem and
a different distributor won't keep your fuel lines from rotting or aluminum
parts from corroding. I run oxygenated fuel here in California (added
ethanol? MTBE?) and have no problems.
 
Pete

Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 20:38:47 -0400
From: PJZabo@aol.com
Subject: 3.0 liter 911 engine mods

OK guys, help me spend some money that I probably don't have!

In pursuit of absolute power, I have conceded to making some minor mods in an
otherwise stock rebuild of a 1977 3.0 liter 911 euro motor (same case, heads,
pistons as a 911SC, but a 2.7 crank).

I am replacing the stock 8.5:1 pistons with 9.3:1s and plan to run the stock
CIS which I believe is the same as other 1977 units (no O2 sensor), only
modified for the added displacement.  Please don't try to talk me into
induction mods, I'm on a budget, the CIS works and I'm gonna keep it!

My question has to do with cam modifications.  This engine uses the same cams
as the SC and Carrera, only with more aggressive timing that sacrifices
torque for horsepower.  Under advice of my most trusted machine shop, I'm cons
idering having the stock cams reground with C2 profiles (cost of $285).  I'm
told that this mod alone should yield a 10-15% power increase.

Can anybody validate the power increase claims from these cam mods? Seems
like a good investment.  The motor is rated 200 HP DIN in stock form and with
SSI heat exchangers, Bursch exhaust, 9.3:1s and the cams, I'd hope for a
minimum 30 HP gain over stock, without any sacrifice in drivability.

Any other low buck improvement suggestions for this project are welcome.

Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 20:38:43 -0400
From: PJZabo@aol.com
Subject: How to clean 911 engine cases?

I'm in the midst of a full rebuild on my 77' 3.0 liter (euro motor).  The
heads, crank and rods are being shipped back to me from the machine shop and
I need advice on cleaning the grime off the aluminum cases before I start to
bolt the thing together.

The previous owner really neglected the car and the motor had more oil leaks
than an early Triumph Bonneville when I got it (not to mention a broken
compression ring in cylinder #6), so the cases are a mess of baked on oil and
grease. My spare time is precious, so I'm thinking of having them hot tanked.
 I could spend a long time getting into the nooks and crannies with Simple
Green or Gunk and a brush.

What do I have to look out for? I understand that aluminum has to be cleaned
in a special tank.  I plan to reuse the #8 main bearings since they
supposedly don't wear out and look perfect, so I'd remove these before
tanking the case.  Also, the head studs have never cracked and the bottom row
is Dilivar (from the factory), so I plan to leave these in place.  Will the
tanking damage these studs in any way?

Lastly, what can I expect to pay for this service?

Thanking the experts out there in advance for their advice!


Pete Zaborowsky

77' Carrera 3.0

I was very interested in Jerry's positive experience with the Omnibag.  Earlier
this spring, it was very damp and humid here.  The cold garage floor caused
moisture to condense on the underside of my Porsche.  It was literally dripping
wet for a week or more.  A loose tire that was standing vertically had about
1/2 inch of water condensed in the bottom of it.  Any steel not painted or well
greased now has surface rust on it.  I wish I had put my car in a sealed bag.
I'll be looking into it for next winter.

Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 21:53:40 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sanjay Nasta <sanjay@bga.com>
Subject: HELP: Update on Dead 944S

I was driving my 87 944S down the road at about 30-35 mph when it suddenly
died.  It didn't make any noise, didn't vibrate, just died quietly.  Since
then, I have checked a number of things including:

1.  Timing Belt, and Balance Shaft Belt.  Both are on and rotating when I
    crank it.
2.  There seems to be pressure @ the fuel rail.  I don't know if it is the
    specified pressure since my meter pegs @ 10 psi (anyone know of a good
    fuel pressure gauge with a range of 29 to 58 psi?  Anyway, there is
    definately fuel there, and the fuel pump is delivering it there.
3.  There is power getting to the injector's solenoids.
4.  I swapped out the relays into a friend's 944S.  His care kept working
    so...
5.  There is a spark on the spark plugs.
6.  The battery voltage is within specs (under load).  

I'm stumped for where else to look.  Any suggestions...before I swallow my
pride and take it to a mechanic?


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 20:52:11 -0700 (PDT)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: 944: Question for timing belt DIYourselfers


After installing my new timing belt, setting the tightness to 4.0 with the
gauge, and installing the balance shaft belt, I now realize that it will
practically require removal of the bal. belt just to check the timing belt
again at 3000 km. It doesn't seem right, but it's impossible to use the
gauge with the balance belt in the way. Therefore, I'm curious as to what
the timing belt usually reads at the end of the first 3000 km. Is it
usually pretty close to the prescribed 2.7 +/- 0.3? 

Also, the 944 Spec. booklet (p.41) specifies for the balance belt:
 
for roller without oblong hole: 4.3 +/- 0.3 (new belt)
for roller with oblong hole:    2.7 +/- 0.3 (new belt) 

 - Jim Pasha's Excellence article specifies 2.7 (no mention of oblong hole)
 - Factory manual mentions nothing of 'oblong hole' and specifies 2.7
 - All balance belt tensioners I've seen have a round hole. Therefore 4.3?
 - Maybe they're referring to the bal. idler roller, and therefore 2.7?
 - My instincts tell me to go with 2.7

Can anyone clear up the confusion?
 
Joe '86 944 (almost done)

Porschephiles #1314                         Mon Apr 10 11:38:04 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 03:25:49 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Original vs.050 Distributors

Dear Peter:
           Once again let me state  again that GOOD Original Distributors
with 30 degrees advance in them that  are NOT sticky or jerky are Good
Distributors. However, despite what you say about the ease  of rebuilding a
bad original, the  success rate is not 100% but some number well below that
figure. Likewise, how many Originals have been touched by the hands of
Turkeys and butchered beyond reasonable repair? Like when the drive mechanism
and locking pin have been "disassembled" with a sledge hammer? 
    Let us take, for example,  Jerry Seinfeld's '58 Speedster that came into
the Maestro's  shop last week. It had what Stan and you would call a Good
Original distributor- 30 degrees advance with little variation of the timing
at constant speed. However, it had a problem all too typical of old
Originals- the "sticky" one wherein, when coming down from high RPM, the
timing would "stick" at 15 degrees advance and take a while  to return to 0.
Meanwhile if you're trying to adjust the carbs you  think what you're doing
with the carbs is affecting the engine  when in fact you're not affecting the
engine- the distributor is! 
     The LA-LA land Porsche Dealer who worked on the car previously had
retarded the timing to three degrees  AFTER  Top Dead Center in an attempt to
overcome this problem. As a result, the  engine idled at near stalling speed,
and any attempt at proper carb adjustment was made difficult since
sensitivity was lost.
     Resetting the timing to proper high speed advance made the carb
adjustment possible (it was way off), and made  the car run much better-
except for the lag in returning to idle.
     A new .050 eliminated the lag in returning to idle, made possible  the
proper carb adjustment and if anything, made  the car run BETTER than  with
the "good" original. 
    The proof of the pudding is in the eating.
    (Oh, and in case you're curious, the engine itself had the main case
halves of a later '58 with the third piece from a mid-1957. Looking up these
components in the Maestro's Data Base of 4000+ engines showed that the Third
Piece is the type that used the  External Oil Booster Line (which was
missing), while the Main Case Halves used the Cast Internal Oil Booster Line
(which didn't  exist in the third piece that was on it!).
    Maybe that's the reason the engine had all of 16 psi at 3000 RPM.
Boy, that Data Base sure has important information!
    And, Peter, despite what you say about how the gas has remained just as
good now as it was years ago- I don't think a lot of people will agree with
you. Yes, the "92" octane gas is the average of RON and MON (Research Octane
Number and Motor Octane Number), and maybe 92 now (RON+MON)/2 is about 96
then, but don't forget there were many gasolines (Sunoco comes to mind), that
had octane ratings over 100!
     These octane ratings allowed one to build engines with significantly
higher compression ratios then (and, correspondingly, more power, higher
Thermal Efficiency and all those goodies), without premature failure from
detonation damage. (And  without MTBE either!)
    These days, I think 9:1 is about  the limit for a street 356/912
(water-cooled engines can be higher since they operate at a much more
constant temperature), and I set most all the street engines to between
8.6-8.9:1. They produce good power, get good gas mileage and go over 100,000
miles. That's not a bad compromise, and part of the reason I like to:
    
KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 09:10 EDT

Subject: Re: Aid in dealing wi

Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca> piped up and said:
    It would sure would be nice if it was mandatory to prefix all mail subject
    titles with the Porsche year and model number. That way you could do a
    quick deletion of all irrelevant mail before actually going in to read the
    notes pertaining to your particular model(s) of interest. 
    
    Non mechanical related notes could have 'AUTOX', 'DRIVING', 'TRACK' etc. 
    as the first keyword of the subject title.
     
    Just an idea...

Alternately, you can stick your own headers in with the "X-" prefix.  This
would permit normal-looking subject lines, while still giving the  indexing
capabilities.  Something like:

X-Porsche-model: 1987 944S
X-mech-prob: clutch

Of course, then you'd wind up declaring all kinds of classes/sections/topics,
probably some kind of hierarchy, eventually you'll wind up needing a custom
mailer just for Porschephiles.  Kinda like the one I'm writing... ;)

Date: 10 Apr 95 09:32:05 -0400
From: mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Subject: re: 914 CV Joints and other stuff

>          Just dropped the burnt-out 1.8 from my '74 914.  Replacing
>          it with 2.0 from a '75.  Gonna rebuild it before installing.
>
>          Anywho, I need to rebuild/replace the CV joints.  Original
>          plan was to:
>          (1) Remove entire half-axles (incl stub axles)
>          (2) Replace rear wheel bearings

I would only replace rear wheel bearings if they are bad.  Mucho work,
they do not just pop out easily.

>          (3) Clean CVs, install new boots and pack with Sta-Lube
>              CV grease
>          (4) Replace the one that was clunking
>
>          Some of you may remember my question last month about how
>          to get off the axle nut.  I have long cheater pipe but I
>          have been rethinking.  Is it worthwhile to go to the trouble
>          of removing stub axle to get to bearings?  Someone said that

Yes, removing axle nut is easiest way.  Once you have the pipe (and a
quality wrench that won't break) use a 1 inch extender and do it with the
wheel still on, but chocked, for safety.  If you choose not to remove the
axle nut, then you have the problem of getting at the outer CV bolts
through the arm, then there's no way to separate from splined end,
then trying to get the silly thing back on later.  Once the axle nut is
off, the whole thing slides right out.  Do yourself a favor and also
remove the starter, it gets in the way.

>          I will need a slide hammer to get out the stub axles --
>          where do you attach the slide hammer?  DO you need to remove
>          the outer CVs first or can I pull the whole thing as a unit?

I can't see anyone needing a slide hammer.  Remove the nut, undo the
inner CV bolts and separate from trans flange (carefully if you don't
have new gaskets), and then it comes right out.

>
>          Also, I noticed while replacing the rear rotors that the
>          left rear training arm can be moved laterally a few mm. ...

Sorry, can't help here.

>
>          Thanks, Tim Radsick
>
>          P.S: When I removed the engine, I noticed that the front
>          engine mounts had both sheared off through the rubber.  Is
>          this common?

yes.  nothing to be worried about.

>                       And one more thing... Is there a better CV
>          grease to use than the Sta-Lube.  Perhaps a moly-synthetic?

Mark Skala            '73 914
mvmas@mvujc.att.com   '88 924S

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 08:02:24 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: RE: Transaxel Noise, NOW WHAT


Sounds like the ring and pinion.  A friend had the same problem in a "88"
944.  A couple of teeth broke off of the pinion gear and were laying at
the bottom of the transaxle housing.  Here's something you can do to diagnose
it:

Jack the rear of the car up and put in neutral:

	-Turn one rear wheel and the other should turn in the opposite directi
	and make no noise.  This is because only the spider gears in the
	 diff are turning at this point which is what the diff is
	 supposed to do.

	-Get some help and turn both wheels at once.  This will turn the ring
	gear and pinion and you should hear the clunking.

	-If you don't hear anything at this point I don't know what is wrong.
 

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 08:13:25 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: RE: Help: Update on Dead 944S

 
> From porschephiles-request@tta.com  Sun Apr  9 23:12:16 1995

> I was driving my 87 944S down the road at about 30-35 mph when it suddenly
> died.  It didn't make any noise, didn't vibrate, just died quietly.  Since
> then, I have checked a number of things including:
> 
> 1.  Timing Belt, and Balance Shaft Belt.  Both are on and rotating when I
>     crank it.
> 2.  There seems to be pressure @ the fuel rail.  I don't know if it is the
>     specified pressure since my meter pegs @ 10 psi (anyone know of a good
>     fuel pressure gauge with a range of 29 to 58 psi?  Anyway, there is
>     definately fuel there, and the fuel pump is delivering it there.
> 3.  There is power getting to the injector's solenoids.
> 4.  I swapped out the relays into a friend's 944S.  His care kept working
>     so...
> 5.  There is a spark on the spark plugs.
> 6.  The battery voltage is within specs (under load).  
> 
> I'm stumped for where else to look.  Any suggestions...before I swallow my
> pride and take it to a mechanic?
> 

I once had a similar problem on a Honda.  It was getting spark and fuel but
not starting.  The problem turned out that the spark was intermittent and 
weak.  Look at the spark closely to see if it is firing everytime it is 
supposed to and a nice blue spark.  If not, check the obvious in the 
ignition system:    
 
	-Coil resistence
	-Plug wires
	-Etc.

The computer could also be the culprit so try swapping computers.

Good luck!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 09:24:12 EDT
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: 944 Timing Belt Self-Tensioner - HELP!


From discussions here on P-files, MY87 and later 944's should
have a spring loaded self-tensioner that should allow
correct tensioning without the P9201 tool($$$).

The microfiche manuals make no mention of the self tensioner
and procedures specific to it.  The consensus on P-files
seemed to be: 1. loosen the lock-nut on the tensioner, the
tensioner will "self-adujst", and then, 2. tighten the lock-nut.

My car does seem to have the self tensioner- there is a 
metal plate that covers a portion of the tensioner sprocket
where the eccentric shaft would be on the older cars.  The lock-nut is 
on top (in front?) of the plate which is held down by two bolts on the 
right side (looking at the engine from the front).

Here's the problem:  When I went to loosen the lock-nut it was
very difficult to turn.  After adding more leverage (with a 
1/2 drive socket wrench) the nut would turn, but it never 
seemed to loosen up, like the other lock-nuts do.  After closer 
inspection, and putting a dot of paint on the end of the bolt, 
I determined that the bolt is turning as well(!).  It seems
the nut is siezed on the bolt, and that whatever is holding the
bolt from behind is slipping.

And the belt is even looser now.

Here are my questions:

1.  Is this a BIG problem?  Is the head of the bolt
    supposed to be imbedded in the engine block somehow, and
    it sheared?  Or is the bolt simply holding the
    tensioner sprocket against the metal plate?  If that's
    the case then it's just a matter of loosening the 
    nut from the bolt.

2.  Should I attempt to remove the self-tensioner assembly
    and loosen everything up on the work bench?  Or will the
    tensioning spring pop out and be impossible to get back
    in correctly?

3.  What is the exact procedure for adjusting tension
    with the self-tensioner?  After the lock-nut is loosened
    should you turn the crank once or twice and back off as 
    for making measurements for the manual tensioner?  Or
    do you just loosen and re-tighten the lock-nut?
    Does anyone have a copy of a factory bulletin on the
    self-tensioner?

4.  Am I doomed to go to a mechanic/dealer?  Argghhh....


Thanks for any advice....

Scott Humphreys
scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com
`87 944 (parked for now)

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 10:25:04 -0400
From: asdunn@nytimes.com (Ashley Dunn)
Subject: 911 alignment

Well folks, despite my skepticism, I went and got Ray Scruggs' book on home
alignment. Amazing! It works. My twitchy, foul-handling beast (untouched for
25 years!) now handles wonderfully (quiet too). I have a few questions: 1) I
changed the camber on the car to negative one degree. Scruggs recommended .5
degrees. I can't adjust it any more. I've got the ride height set at 25.5
inches to the top of the wheel wells and the top of the strut all the way
over to the outside of the car. There just doesn't seem to be any adjustment
left to get to .5 degrees. Any ideas? 2) Any ideas on how to four-corner
balance the car? Scruggs outlined a procedure involving driving around and
tinkering with torsion bar adjustments without using a weight scale. Anybody
found any other cheap do-it-yourself ways of weight balancing the car?
Thanks. Ashley.
Ashley Dunn
Metro reporter
The New York Times
wk. (212) 556-7422
fax (212) 556-7615

Date: 10 Apr 1995 08:50:24 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: 911: "Panting" Engine noise

Another question for you motorheads:

The problem:
My '86 Carrera is idling weird, it sounds like this: rrrump rrump rrump.
The tach indicates the engine speed is dropping to say 800 RPM then
it "catches" itself and gives it some throttle and idle goes up to a little
over
1000 RPM. Once in a while it will idle fine.

The clues:
It started dong this after I put the engine back in the car. In the process
of removing the engine I disconnected a bazillion lines and cables and
while the engine was out I:
 - Replaced clutch, resurfaced flywheel.  I mention this because there
  are sensors in this area.
 - Replaced the head temperature sensor and oil pressure switch.
 - Adjusted valves.
 - To replaced the left cam tensioner oil line I removed the distributor to
  gain access (in case that make a difference).
 - I cleaned the contacts on the rotor  and distributor cap.

This was my 2nd mechanical project _ever_; the 1st was just replacing
some brake pads on my GTI. Don't be afraid to mention stuff that
should be obvious - it probably isn't obvious to me. :-)

  thanx in advance,
    Chris Bennet
 '86 Carrera

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 10:44:26 -0400 (EDT)
From: Joseph Tzougrakis <jtzougra@acad.bryant.edu>
Subject: Re: Sunroof on 944 (cant get it out!)

  The trick is to make sure the key is turned to the first click.  The 
mechanism that lifts the roof has a much greater range when the key is in 
this position and the roof should come right out.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 10:47:26 -0400
From: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com (Lou Krieg)
Subject: Re: Sunroof on 944 (cant get it out!)

>  I'm almost embarresed to ask this question, I've owned many cars but
>this is my first Porsche and I'll swallow my pride and ask. Either I'm a
>complete idiot or mr roof is broken.
>   How the hell do I get ths sunroof out on my 86 944!!!! The book says
>tilt the roof, Unlatch the front and lift! The roof tilts up fine BUt!
>it wont lift out, the back stayed firmly attached. I wont force it.
>
>
>Thanks in advance and dont be to hard on me :)
>Marc
>86 944
>88 GTI 16v

The manual for my '87 944 Turbo says:

- -----------------------------
Clean the roof prior to removal to avoid scratches and soiling your clothes.

1. Turn the ignition switch to position 1 (see ingition/starter switch section).
[i.e. one click to the right of off--Lou]
 Depress rear half of rocker switch until the prop-up linkage mechanism
unlocks the roof [i.e. the "forks" retract down into the fixed roof--Lou].

2. Loosen front holding clamps.

3. Lift up and remove roof.

4. Store roof in the pouch provided in luggage compartment.
- ------------------------------

Seriously, these are somewhat "particular" cars about how they are treated,
and how they work. If you don't have the factory manual (I assume you
don't) the I strongly recommend that you order one from the dealer and read
it cover to cover. Since you subscribe to this list, I infer that you are
an enthusiast, and want to maintain your pride and joy properly. The manual
is an essential part this.

The manual will explain the procedure for re-installing the roof  ;-)

Best of luck,

    --Lou

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 08:51:40 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Fuel gauge sender


John Wright's excellent post on the construction of the
fuel gauge sender mechanism reminds me of the problem I
have, and haven't gotten around to fixing yet.

The float in my sender (and others have told me they
have the same problem) gets stuck every now and then.
Examination of the resistance wire reveals little nicks
or kinks at certain spots, apparently due to having had
the float sit at those spots for extended periods, perhaps
during storage.  It's almost impossible to smooth the
wire enough to allow the float to ride freely without
hanging up.  One needs to replace the wire, which brings
me to the point...

Does anyone know where to get resistance wire?  The stuff
in the sender is about 36 ohms/foot, and you only need
two feet.

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa (with a sticking fuel gauge sender)

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 09:13:59 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Re: Transaxle Noise, NOW WHAT?!!!


Asfar,

The problem, I am 99% sure, lies in the Constant Velocity (CV) joints
in one of your half-shafts (drive axles).

The cost ro repair can be about $250 per side if you replace both CV 
joints. Each axle has two. 

There most like is no damage to the transaxle. If it hasn't been done, 
has the gear oil in the trans axle replaced at the same time the CV
joints are repaired. If only one side is bad, have the other side 
removed and lubricated.

Jim Pasha

Well I am hoping for the worst but that's because I don't have
a CLUE. I would like to hear the diagnostic from the list 944
Experts specially ( but not the least) from those members on 
the Cc list. 

Yesterday, I took my 85/2 944 with 51,000 mile, for a cruise.
Soon after exiting the highway (about 1/2 mile ), while
making a right turn, a loud clunking noise started to come from
the rear axle. I pulled the car to a side street and couldn't
find any thing visible wrong with the transaxle. The clunk
appears to sync with each revolution of the wheel. However, the
clunking noise seems to disappear in the reverse. 

So, I drove the car at a snail speed ( < 2 mph ) to the nearest
phone (1/4 of a mile).  After having it towed to my house following
are the existing symptoms.

1. Loud cluttering/clunking noise in the forward direction.
   ( in gear ). Seems to be comming from inside the transaxle.

2. Slight noise in the reverse. It was not there before I
   drove looking for a phone booth.

3. Slight noise in neutral. It also, was not there before I
   drove looking for a phone booth.

4. When rolling the car in the forward direction there is a point
   where the wheels appeared lock and would not turn. However, a 
   slight push in the reverse direction will unlock the wheels to 
   move forward, for a couple of wheel revolutions.

5. The gears seems to shift normally. A little hard shifting into
   reverse ( again, All together now; "It was not there before I
   drove looking for a phone booth" ).

6. After raising the car and turning the wheel, the noise seems to
   be coming from the transaxle.

The CV joint boots does not show any grease leakage and appears
normal. Since there is some noise when the car is in neutral
so can I assume that it is not the linkage? 
Rear wheel bearing? I thought that it was a problem in the early
944's.

Beside this I don't have any clue as to what is wrong. All I can
tell you is that I replaced the transaxle oil last year with
Redline MTL(80-90??).

Jim Pasha and Kevin Gross I would greatly appreciate your opinion
and comments. Jim , sometime ago, I remember reading your transaxle
article in Excellence. Would you happen to know, what month
was that issue for?

Any comments will be greatly appreciated.

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 18:28:43 +0200
From: Chris Berry <chris@vbo.dec.com>
Subject: Re: HELP: Update on Dead 944S 


I know every failure mode is different, but you could try this.

Ensure that the plugs are dry, and the engine isn't flooded (turn
it over a bit wth the plugs out and the fuel injectors disconnected.
(standard warnings about diconnecting the coil included :-) ).

Then try to start the car normally for a few seconds. Disconnect the
injectors ( power leads),and try again. If the engine fires at all then
you are getting too rich a mixture, by a long way. 

In fact you should get a good idea about fuel delivery by the state of
the plugs ..

The reason I suggect this is that this is my 944's failure mode (albeit
intermittent). If these are your symptoms, and you find a fix, let me know,
as mine has a habit of coming back to life as soon as I get serious with
the diagnostics.

Good luck,

Chris.

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 10:33:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944: Question for timing belt DIYourselfers


On Mon, 10 Apr 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:

(of using the P9201 gauge)

> Not a problem. You just have to find the spot where you can slip the gauge
> in. about halfway between the cam pulley and the crank pulley.
> You must not be trying hard enough. I do it all the time...

Thanks George. I'll take a harder look. The problem is that:

 - the bal. belt is in the way
 - I cannot insert the P9201 paddle at certain places along the belt without
  binding btween the belt and belt cover and seriously affecting the reading.
  Therefore, I'm quite limited as to where on the belt I can use the gauge.
  Maybe the belt covers allowed for different clearance on different years?

As for the tech bulletin on removing the vent hose connecting the belt cover
to the air box, I can see some pros/cons leaving it in:

pros: sucks up loose belt material, cools down belt area
cons: sucks in sand and grit into the belt assembly accelerating wear on 
      belts and rollers.

I haven't decided either way yet, but I'm curious as to Porsche's reasons
for removing it. I suspect many 944s still have the hose connected.

Joe '86 944

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 10:38:29 PDT
From: "JEVERING.US.ORACLE.COM" <JEVERING@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: RE: 911SC Blower moter wanted


- --Boundary-8041012-0-0

Hello again Bill, 
I took your suggestion and rebuilt the blower motor myself.  The most 
difficult part was fabricating those liitle clips which hold the casing on.  
Also, the housing the clips rest on was BROKEN!... I ended up drilling holes 
at 45 degree angles and bolting in on, after a serious lubing and cleaning... 
it now seems to work great... thanks for the suggestion. 
James


- --Boundary-8041012-0-0
X-Orcl-Content-Type: message/rfc822

Received: 07 Apr 1995 10:09:24                    Sent: 07 Apr 1995 12:06:30
From:"krause@mgi.com" <krause@vixvax.mgi.com>
To: JEVERING@us.oracle.com
Subject: RE: 911SC Blower moter wanted
Reply-to: krause@mgi.com
X-Orcl-Application: Sender:  krause@mgi.com


James,

I needed a blower moter also for my 79 911SC and was shocked at the price
for both new and rebuilt, so I thought I'd try and fix mine.  It turned out
to be a very simple problem of the small braided wire that is soldered to 
the brushes breaking at the solder joint.  You probably have already opened
it up, but if not, take a look there.  It was the cheapest and simplest thing
I've ever fixed on my car.

Bill Krause
'79 911SC mostly bronze


- --Boundary-8041012-0-0--

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 10:49:35 -0700

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 13:41:47 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Turbo Oil Consumption

1 quart/ 1000 miles 
 
This is what I get for my chipped 89k miles '86 944 Turbo car in normal
street use, and that is the same as what other drivers that I have spoken
to get. It was more like 1 quart/1500-2000 miles before the chip. If you
drive harder, faster, and stay on the boost longer, expect gas and oil
consumption to increase in multiples, not fractions. 
 
The car occasionally blows a puff of smoke at startup. It emits enough
pollution to discolor the back of the car and the parking spot after a
time. Of course it has a cat pipe. Again, all typical stuff. I have been
told that Porsches are built looser, for racing durability. Probably
another myth. It certainly consumes more oil than my old RX-7's, which
actually are designed to consume oil like a 2-stroke. 
 
I use Mobil 1. Seem to remember that consumption was less on dino-juice.
Sometimes even the brand can make a big difference. 
 
The wisdom is to use an extra .5-1 quart in the engine to cover that
fragile #2 rod bearing, if you run the car hard. Also, keep the coolant
tank at Max when cold.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 10:49:40 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: 930 vs 911SC?


- --Boundary-8041464-0-0

Jonathan:  Interesting timing on your query.  I've owned both 911SC's(2) and a 
78 930.  I'm looking for another 911 and am considering an 86 930 or an 83 
911Cab.  I will probably get the 911 over the 930 and I've had to keep 
reminding myself why I sold the 930 in the first place.  The 930 is a 
fantastic car but doesn't make a lot of sense for me as a regular driver.  
Here's why: 
 
The 930's are four speeds.  This is a great tranny, very durable, smooth 
shifting etc.  The problem is that the car is very hard to drive within the 
speed limits on a highway.  By speed limits I don't mean 55, rather 62-65 
where you're up with the flow of traffic.  The 930 is bareley breathing in 4th 
gear at 60-62mph.  They are so quiet and smooth that unless you're staring at 
the speedo you notice little difference between 62 and 82mph.  It's very easy 
to unintentionally creep up to ticket levels. Got several tickets like this. 
Also noticed that my right foot was heavier in the 930 than in the 911  90mph 
in second gear impressed almost any passenger. 
 
 Also, the police here in California are very aggressive about ticketing these 
cars.  They are easy to spot and the cops seem to view them as major quarry.  
Next is the cost of maintenance. I would spend 2x the amount on 930 
maintenance as 911.  In todays market, a 930 is probably going to cost you 2x 
the amount to buy as a comparable 911.  Insurance will also double on the 930. 
 
The 930 is a very civilized car to drive until you get into the boost.  This 
factor makes race tracks and winding roads real interesting.  The 911 then is 
the car of choice for me.  If you do have an itch to scratch on the 930 side, 
however, scratch it.  You can always sell it and get a 911. Thinking about 
getting another 930 makes my eyes glaze over and induces a trance like state 
for very short periods.  Then I come back to  reality.   Most of my friends 
who bought them came to the same conclusions.    
 
Good luck,  
Ted Smith


- --Boundary-8041464-0-0

FWIW When my rotor arm broke up (not uncommon 944 experience), I found
the remains of the rotor arm, and the plastic 'dust shield' in the
air cleaner box. Now perhaps if there were not reduced pressure in the
cam enclosure they would have stayed in the distributor cap, perhaps
not, but I'm sure glad all those bits weren't flying around the belt
enclosure for too long ..

Just my 10 Centimes worth ,

Chris.

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 14:31:03 -0400 (EDT)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: 930 vs. 911

One thing to consider:
If you're buying a '77 930, the parts are different from the later models 
because of the engine differences. The '77 930 Turbo Carrera has a 
turbocharged engine based on the European Carrera engine- correct me if 
I'm wrong. I've been told parts costs for a '77 are much higher than the 
newer models.

The '77 930 isn't intercooled either, right?

But, if you can afford it, the Turbo is a blast, and IMHO it looks nicer 
than the standard Carrera or SC.
Then again, if you're into looks, you could always get a turbo-look.

- --

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 14:09:33 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: piston source

> Can anyone recommend a source for special size pistons for my 914 ? Thanks.

Depends on the application. You got the "special sized" cylinders already?
What do you mean "special size"?

There's Arias and Venolia for the *REAL* "special" pistons, then you can
get Mahle, TRW, and Cosworth in applications that *fit*, but you may
have to do other things like use different rods, or even have some rods
made up special. Or you can have special cranks made that let you
use off the shelf "unusual" rods -- like some Chevy parts -- with those
"other applications" pistons.

So I guess it gets down to this: what the hell are you trying to DO?

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 15:20:27 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 911 alignment

Hi,

Ashley Dunn asked about aligning his own 911, and used Ray Scruggs' book.

> I changed the camber on the car to negative one degree. 
> There just doesn't seem to be any adjustment left to get to .5 degrees
> (in the front). Any ideas? 

I've got the same problem, but at a very low ride height (24") I can get
no less than 1.8 degrees. I want 1 deg ft and 1.5 rear. I'm going to try to
jack up the front, remove the three strut adjusting bolts, and lower
the strut mount away from the body. Then I'm going to try to remove the
hard black gook that was smeared on the adjusting plate 23 years ago.
This might give us some extra adjustment. And with no weight on the strut,
it should be easier to move. Anyone every try this?

> 2) Any ideas on how to four-corner balance the car? 
> Scruggs outlined a procedure involving driving around and
> tinkering with torsion bar adjustments without using a weight scale.
> Anybody found any other cheap do-it-yourself ways of weight balancing the
car?

I really don't think this is possible without some sort of scales.
I had my car really screwed up last year (80 pounds off on each corner)
because I tried it without scales. I've got a set of scales in Danbury, CT
that I'm borrowing. If you want to come up we can see how far off you are.
If you can get it close enough with only the front adjustments, it is easy.
But if the rears need re-indexing you're out of luck as I've been fiddling
with rear adjustments about 20 times in the last year and am sick of it!
Wish my adjustable spring plates were legal in SCCA stock...

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S Targa

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 15:33:24 -0400
From: asdunn@nytimes.com (Ashley Dunn)
Subject: 911 alignment

I forgot to say that I have a 71 911T. I have my car up to about the max in
ride height, 25.5 at the wheel wells. I did manage to get most of the gunk
off the adjusting plate, still no go. There is no room left in the adjusting
hole to move the strut over any more. I can't believe that Porsche built
these cars to always ride with mega negative camber! 
   One thing I forgot to say that may be important is that I have the caster
set all the way back (toward the rear of the car). I don't think caster
changes the camber situation, but who knows...
   One last thing, Mike I may eventually take you up on the offer to use
your scales. Can you rent scales or buy them from any place?  
Ashley Dunn
Metro reporter
The New York Times
wk. (212) 556-7422
fax (212) 556-7615

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 14:36:33 EDT
From: javier@ascc01.ascc.att.com (Javier Rodriguez - ATT ASCC)
Subject: '88 911 Carrera - starting problems

Hello Porschephiles,

I'm in need of some help in diagnosing a starting problem I am having w/my '88 Carrera.

Sometimes (it has happened twice), the car won't start when cold. The motor
cranks but it won't start, the behavior is similar to that of a cis f.i. system
with a bad control pressure regulator; it seemed like if there was no gas in the
tank or like if the fuel pump was not working.

This never happened before; the first time it happened was on Saturday pm.
When I tried to start the engine, it won't start. it would crank but it won't start.
I ran the starter five or six times, for about 4 seconds each try and about 30-45
seconds between each attempt, and... nothing. I could not believe this, the thing
was just fine the night before. So of course I could not resist trying again.
About 20-30 minutes later, I tried the same sequece, and ... the engine just
started! I let the engine idle for about 5 minutes, stopped the engine, and 
re-started it, it started immediately. Good. 

On Sunday morning, the same thing just happened again; the engine won't start.
Followed the same sequence, and it started. What is going on?

This morning the car started just fine. 

Do you people have any ideas about how to diagnose/resolve this problem?

TIA,

Javier. 
javier@ascc01.ascc.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 13:28:03 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Resistance Wire

Bob Spindel asks:

> 
> Does anyone know where to get resistance wire?  The stuff
> in the sender is about 36 ohms/foot, and you only need
> two feet.
> 

Try MWS Wire Industries (MWS = Magnet Wire Specialties, their old name I
think); Westlake Village CA, 818-991-8553.  Every kind of bare and film
insulated wire you can think of, and some you probably can't (what does
*anyone* do with Niobium wire, anyway?).  They list about twenty
resistance alloys.  Very service oriented, but also a bit pricey...

 -Ed

Andy:

You answered your own question.  Intersport is the place to go.  See 
Ivan Arzola.  He's not only a good Porsche mechanic -- he's a fanatic.  
Won't let a job go until he's satisfied and he's tough to please.  Ivan 
is the Potomac PCA 944/968 expert and knows the cars.  Not sure what he 
charges for a pre-purchase, but Intersport's rates are lower than most 
and their work is better than most.  They're at 302 Mill Street in 
Vienna (right off the main drag near Vienna Inn).  Phone (703) 
242-8680.  Tell him I sent you -- My 911 needs a major tune and I could 
use the chits <g>.  Seriously, Intersport is a good shop and the site 
of an upcoming driving event tech session.  Ivan has kept my '72 911 on 
the road for several years now.

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 16:05:25 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: "87" 944 ball joints

>I have a small amount of play when pushing on the bottom of the front wheel
>when at the same time pulling on the top when the car is jacked up.  Does
>this mean ball joints?  No one was available to push and pull when I looked
>to see where the play was originating.  I repacked the wheel bearings and 
>noticed it when checking the play after some miles.  I'm relatively sure
>it is not bearing play.

Most likely it is ball joints.  Get someone over to move the 
tire while you check the ball joint since these aren't cheap 
for newer 944s.  You get to change the whole control arm, not
just the ball joint.  There are a couple of companies around that
sale rebuilt control arms, and you can also find used ones depending
on how budget-minded you are.  

Ross Stites
'87 951



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 16:07:55 -0500
From: scot@phoenix.phoenix.net (Scot VanAlstine)

OK fellow 914 folks. Here is some intesting news. A 914 rear shift trans
can be converted to a side shift by replacing the side shift mechanism, 2
studs, rear cover and shift forks.  The final drive casings are identical.
The gears are supposedly the same.  Any discussion?  Anyone have any of
these parts laying around?  Thanks to Otto for this information.

Scot

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 16:50:57 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Aviation Gas in a Carrera?

>A Corvette owner suggested that I get some 115 octane aviation gas
>and run it in my '86 Carrera during the next autocross. Is this
>a wise thing to do?

        Depends on what was used to bring it up to 115 octane.  If
it's leaded avgas (do they make that anymore?) then it would be bad
for your catalytic converter.  I'm not sure if other additives will
have bad effects on the FI/emissions equipment.
        That said:  Higher octane *NEVER* hurts.  Unless your car
has a knock sensor or is already pinging, it will not help.  However,
some cars with knock sensors will keep advancing the ignition timing
until the sensor kicks in.  Higher octane can help those cars make
more power.  Someone said on the list a while back that a ride in a
Euro-spec 3.2 with 100-octane gas was a religious experience.  The
US-spec version may not have a high enough compression ratio to make
a big difference, though.

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 14:57:19 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: How to clean 911 engine cases?

| From:  <PJZabo@aol.com>
|
| I'm in the midst of a full rebuild on my 77' 3.0 liter (euro motor).  The
| heads, crank and rods are being shipped back to me from the machine shop and
| I need advice on cleaning the grime off the aluminum cases before I start to
| bolt the thing together.
|
| The previous owner really neglected the car and the motor had more oil leaks
| than an early Triumph Bonneville when I got it (not to mention a broken
| compression ring in cylinder #6), so the cases are a mess of baked on oil and
| grease. My spare time is precious, so I'm thinking of having them hot tanked.
|
| What do I have to look out for? I understand that aluminum has to be cleaned
| in a special tank.  I plan to reuse the #8 main bearings since they
| supposedly don't wear out and look perfect, so I'd remove these before
| tanking the case.  Also, the head studs have never cracked and the bottom row
| is Dilivar (from the factory), so I plan to leave these in place.  Will the
| tanking damage these studs in any way?

Do not hot tank it. Hot tanking is for cast iron blocks. I've never 
done a 911 motor,
but I have rebuilt several VWs. VW machine shops have tanks filled with carb
cleaner which works well for aluminum/magnesium cases. Of course this was
years ago and in the environmentally acute '90s this may no longer apply.
I didn't remove the studs, although it would make the cleaning job 
somewhat easier.

| Lastly, what can I expect to pay for this service?

I forget what I had to pay. It was reasonable enough, though. (Well, these days
with hazardous chemical disposal fees and all, it may no longer be reasonably
inexpensive.)

    Eric

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1316                         Tue Apr 11 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 17:35:39 CDT
From: wpcostel@porsche.aud.alcatel.com (William Costello)
Subject: Re: Aviation Gas in a Carrera?

Jim,

For an 86 911 Carrera, anything above 87 (or maybe 89) octane is a waste of
money. In 1987, the DME program was changed to assume premium unleaded fuel.
Unless an engine requires high-octane fuel to avoid pre-detonation, there is
no benefit to running high-octane fuel. Check out the gas FAQ on the WWW
at address:

  http://ram.chem.tulane.edu:8080/f-body/trivia/gasoline.html

W.P. Costello

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 18:03:48 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Aviation Gas in a Carrera?

> A Corvette owner suggested that I get some 115 octane aviation gas
> and run it in my '86 Carrera during the next autocross. Is this
> a wise thing to do? I have visions of my car being hoisted up onto a
> flatbed truck for the long trip home after depositing engine parts
> in the parking lot...

Two things: 

1) tax issues - you're not supposed to use plane gas in cars, if you
   get caught, it's Bad News for both you and whoever sold it to you.

2) octane is *NOT* octane; the Reid vapor pressure of AvGas is *WAY*
   different from that of Car Gas.  You can, by all means, use racing
   gas. I use Phillips, Sunoco, and Cam2 in octane from 101 to 125,
   mostly in unleaded. Certainly, you can get this stuff in leaded too...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 19:06:03 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Aviation Gas in a Carrera?

Excerpts from mail: 10-Apr-95 Aviation Gas in a Carrera? by J.
jbauman@btr.com@btr.b 
> A Corvette owner suggested that I get some 115 octane aviation gas
> and run it in my '86 Carrera during the next autocross. Is this
> a wise thing to do? I have visions of my car being hoisted up onto a
> flatbed truck for the long trip home after depositing engine parts
> in the parking lot...
> 
> Jim Bauman
> '86 Carrera (92 octane is all I drink, so far)
> 

    I would say that if you have no problems with detonation then stick
with whatever you're using.  Going to a higher octane will only cost you
power (very little, but hey...) because of the slower burning
characteristics.  If you do need more octane, I would still be wary of
using avgas because it may contain lead because that is the cheapest way
to boost octane.  This will f**k up your catalytic converter in a big
way.  I don't know if no-lead avgas is available or not, not having
enough money to futz around with airplanes... but be sure to check.  I
personally would try an octane booster that is labeled as not containing
lead, along with whatever gas you're using now.

later,

Nate

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 15:41:12 PST
From: radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
Subject: 914 rear suspension and drive

          Extremely gracious thanks to all respondants so far!

          I was successful in removing the stub  axle castelated nuts
          over the weekend.  AFter shattering a Craftsman 1/2" drive
          breaker bar (quite non-ideal grain structure in that
          thing....) I bought a similar device from Armstrong and it
          worked well. 

          I then tapped out one driveshaft/stub axle but still can't
          get the other out.  I tapped with a sledge and a wood block.
          I pounded and then assaulted with the same.  No luck.  I
          then tried a brass block as a buffer. Nope.  Then I just
          hammered directly with the sledge (5 pound).  Desperate, I
          tried loosening the nut, lowering the car on the wheel,
          lifting it rotating a bit and repeating.  I don't know if I
          did any serious damage, but it sure didn't help.  Short of
          removing the trailing arm and using a press, does anyone
          have any ideas? I guess I am committed to replacing the
          bearings, now that I probably damaged one.

          As far as CV grease goes:  What kinds are the best?
          Synthetic?

          Thanks,
          Tim Radsick (who just joined PCA this morning!)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 14:57:23 PDT
From: Daryl Savage <daryls@microsoft.com>
Subject: 930 vs 911sc

Jonathan Ross inquires on the merits of 930's vs a 911sc as it seems he
is wanting to replace his ('87) 951.  he mentions looking for a "'77 or 
'78 930"
and wonders which is better (specifically: maintenance, road trips and
speed on track).

Summary:

1) avoid pre '78 930's if you will ever want to go fast or stop fast 
(consistently).
2) bad news: you will hate the four speed.  good news: it can be fixed.
3) 911's are loud road-trip machines.  either you can take it or you can't.
4) maintenance will be merely *ok* if you avoid turning up the boost
   and don't make "improvements".   But if you wanted a safe life you'd
   probably stay in bed (alone).

i've never owned a normally aspirated 911 (i do routinely drive with
(err "against"?) 'em at the track though) so i'll leave experience based
comparisons to others but on the subject of '77 vs '78 930's i think 
you'll find
the following:

pre '78 930's did not have an intercooler.  nor did they have the 
big-time suspension
and brakes that most people associate with 930's.  These cars are not 
concidered
(as) desirable for track use.  Having an intercooler is a very good 
thing for engine
life expectancy and wallet thickness (although, thick wallets and 
owning 930's don't
usually go hand-in-hand :)).  You will want those bigger brakes when 
you enter your
first corner :)  That having been said, i *have* seen pre '78's at the track in
Portland so i know it happens.

my recommendation would be for any track-aware type to get a '78 or later 930.
'78 and '79 are good choices for track types due to their availability and low
emissions requirements (ie: you can modify the hell out of 'em and get away
with it (easier)).  My track'd car is a beautiful '78 Gold-Metalic example that
goes like stink.  but then, i've done a few of those "improvements" to it...

you're primary impression of a pre '89 930 will be frustration with the 
4-speed.
they suck.  they are Evil Incarnate.  the short answer is that you will want to
change the ring-&-pinion or get a five speed.

on the track you will find that the normally aspirated 911's have that annoying
low-end torque stuff (never experienced it myself but i've heard about 
it :):) that
provides certain advantages at the apex and exit of corners (ahem).  Throttle
stearing is more difficult with a 930 due to the added complexities of the
God's Annointed Torque Curve Syndrome (ie: turbo-lag).

You will also find out how irritating those damned 944 turbos are.  too damned
quick...  too easy to drive (neutral in corners, etc.).  can't imagine 
where the
challenge is in that ;):)  However, i note that you have seen the light and are
*upgrading* (now, where is that nomex anti-flame suit) to a challenging car
<big grin>.

Daryl's secret to 930 driving on the track is to DRIVE THE CAR EVERY DAY.
only by logging lots of hours behind the wheel of 930 can you become one with
the torque curve.  else you'll just get into trouble on the track.

Urban legend has it that boost "comes on unexpectedly" in a 930.  this 
is hogwash.
if you get caught with your panties down when the boost comes on then 
you just havn't
driven your car enough.  Boost comes on when it can (ie: when you'v got 
your foot
into it and the rpm's are up, etc.)  not by magic (ask me about the time my
rear-distributor jump forward a tooth though)...

930's are typically heavier and have more weight bias toward the rear.  
expect a
930 to be harder to drive then a normally aspirated 911.  If you're coming from
a 944, though, you's gots a different experiece ahead 'o you anyway :):)

i think road tripping any 911 is gonna be the same.  Either you can take
the noise or you can't.  additional irritations come from lowering the car
and running bigger tires (bump steer and "seeking") which you're gonna
do if you love your 930 and drive it at the track.  Again, the four-speed
is not pleasant for long drives although its better then 'round the city kinda
driving.

i spent a month on the road in my 930 in late '92.  5500 miles.   took it down
to phoenix to have a g50 installed but got lost in the southwest :):).  Yes i
have an awsome sterio in the car (sorry Stan).   Yes it helped.  Yes
there were times when all i wanted to do was listen to the engine...
but there were times when my ears hurt so much i wanted to leave
the car on the side of the road and hitchhike home :):)

Maintenance will be merely *ok* on a 930 if you don't turn the boost
up or make "improvements".  remember that you are buying a 17
year old car, though.  if they've been driven at all chances are they've
not been treated well.  EVERYONE loves to feel that boost come on.
not everyone knows to wait till the car is warm or to let the turbo spool
down while the oil is still flowing.  expect to pay for some initial repairs.

also, a 930 IS a 911 so.. umm... shit happens and you'll love it or get
the hell out :):)

daryls@microsoft.com

'89 930S (velvet red, factory slantnose targa, g50, sc cams, euro injection...)
'88 930S (guards red, factory slantnose coupe, recently sold :(
'78 930  (gold metalic, fire breathing (literally) 450 hp beast)
'93 Jeep Wrangler

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 18:50:28 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 930 vs 911sc

> low-end torque stuff (never experienced it myself but i've heard about 
> it :):) that
> provides certain advantages at the apex and exit of corners (ahem).  Throttle
> stearing is more difficult with a 930 due to the added complexities of the
> God's Annointed Torque Curve Syndrome (ie: turbo-lag).

Ah.... I see, Daryl was asleep the day that they taught Turbo 101 8{)
The real secret here is to never let the R's drop. Run the car in the
boost zone, shift like crazy to keep the R's up. It's just like driving
a race car -- really. No power at all in the low range, pulls like hell
from say 4k up...

> Daryl's secret to 930 driving on the track is to DRIVE THE CAR EVERY DAY.
> only by logging lots of hours behind the wheel of 930 can you become one with
> the torque curve.  else you'll just get into trouble on the track.

Yes! This is, however, true of any of the Porsches. You'll do a lot better
in whatever you spend some quality time with on the street. Moral: don't
just let it sit there, DRIVE IT.

> Urban legend has it that boost "comes on unexpectedly" in a 930.  this 
> is hogwash.
> if you get caught with your panties down when the boost comes on then 
> you just havn't
> driven your car enough.  Boost comes on when it can (ie: when you'v got 
> your foot
> into it and the rpm's are up, etc.)  not by magic (ask me about the time my
> rear-distributor jump forward a tooth though)...

True, true, all true.... The boost comes on a a specific point (varies with
engine and the rest of your modifications) that's fairly consistent. If
it "surprises" you, you're just not paying attention or you don't have 
enough seat time. Plus, as noted above, your REAL objective is to never
ever get off the boost. That way you don't have to worry about this stuff.
You do however learn little tricks like left foot braking so you can keep
your foot on the gas, etc...

> 930's are typically heavier and have more weight bias toward the rear.  
> expect a
> 930 to be harder to drive then a normally aspirated 911.

I think I can sum it up: 930s are like driving 356s with real power.

> and running bigger tires (bump steer and "seeking") which you're gonna
> i spent a month on the road in my 930 in late '92.  5500 miles.   took it down
> to phoenix to have a g50 installed but got lost in the southwest :):).  Yes i
> have an awsome sterio in the car (sorry Stan).   Yes it helped.  Yes

you need all the distractions you can get...

> also, a 930 IS a 911 so.. umm... shit happens and you'll love it or get

Ah! Yes, that, folks sums it all up.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 19:10:31 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 wheels and offsets

> I'm looking into having a set of 7"x15" wheels made for my 914 to fit
> under the "stock" fenders and fit the 4bolt pattern.  What I need to
> know is the backspacing, or offset from a set that already work.  If
> there is anyone out there with a set of Revolutions or other 7x15
> wheels on a 914 that could measure the backspacing for me, I would
> really appreciate the help.  

I don't know about 15x7s, since I'd just buy those. I do know about
15x8s, since you have to have them made.

For 15x8", 5.5" backspacing, 4x130mm pattern, and 66mm center hole -- but 
that's the size for the early front rotors.  The later ones are 78mm, 
I think, but you'd be better of measuring that. These wheels center on
the hub (rotor, actually) by use of the hole so it's important to
get that right.

BTW -- Panosport and ATS already make 15x7s for the 914 that work
great.

Stan

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 18:05:52 MDT
From: kimknapp@vailnet.org (Kim Knapp)
Subject: RE:Aviation gas

Jim,
        I understand that aviation gas may not have the right additives for 
flatlanders. It is made to operate well at high altitudes. If you want to 
try high octane, check around at your local retailers for racing gas. I 
found some at a nearby Phillips 66. If I remember correctly, it was about 
108 octane.
                Kim
