Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 17:23:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: Cherie Woodward <cherie@corp.cirrus.com>
Subject: Re:clean cases



	I've given up on almost all degreasers - Brakleen being
	one of my favs - since I found the citrus-based cleaners.
	When installing the new SS exchangers, I spent very little
	time and $$ degreasing valve covers and bottom case by 
	applying a thin film of a non-pumice citrus hand cleaner
	and wiping everything off. I thought it worked so well on
	my hands that it must do a good job on the motor. It did
	great! I didn't have to scrape, but did do some toothbrush
	application for tight areas. The grease literally melted off.
	I was impressed. There was no dripping either (as I used a
	sparse amount). Give it a try on a small area and let us all
	know how your comparison went.

	cherie - used to be grease monkey

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 18:26:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944: Question for timing belt DIYourselfers

On Mon, 10 Apr 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:

> > On Mon, 10 Apr 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:
> > (of using the P9201 gauge)
> > 
> Make sure that you are placing the flat paddles on the outside (flat part)
> of the timing belt and the round roller on the inside of the belt. I have
> never found this to be difficult or to affect the reading...

I measured the distance between the flat side of the belt and the rear 
belt cover. At the top near the cam sprocket cover, 4 mm. Further on down
just before the belt cover makes a slight curve, 6 mm.

The paddles on the gauge are 10 mm. If I force the paddle into the gap, 
it deflects the belt down and makes the gauge read higher.

The only available space (where the gap is big enough) is further down the 
belt with the idler roller removed and the balance belt out of the way.

> After looking at several different years, there is no difference in the
> clearance of the covers...
> 
I wonder if the thickness of the gauge paddles changed? I've read that at 
least one other netter had the same problem...

Joe '86 944

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 21:52:18 -0400
From: FURNANS7@aol.com
Subject: Re: Easy on the oil...

Chris

More on the oil.... The dash gauge measures level in the tank, the higher the
revs the more oil goes to the engine and the level shows low. Back to idle
for a minute then the gauge is correct again.  From "full" to "empty" on the
gauge is only 1-1.5 liters, so small changes appear  radical. If you have no
other symptoms, relax and enjoy!

Bob
Furnans7.AOL

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 21:01:38 EDT
From: MDJS51A@prodigy.com ( KARL E HAUG)
Subject: 911 Vs. 951

Jonathan Ross asked (paraphrased):  Does anyone have comments on the
relative merits of these cars?

I've owned an '89 944 Turbo S, sold after it broke the second ball joint
and currently own an '88 Carrera coupe.  I'm a reasonably serious track
junkie and instruct for PCA and other groups.

My 944 Turbo was catastrophically unreliable, so my perspective may be a
little distorted, but I have the strong sense that a well-cared-for 911 SC
or later will be far more reliable than an equivalent 951.  Routine
maintenance will be somewhat more expensive on 911s, primarily due to the
fact you replace 11 quarts of oil at each change.  You also will need a
valve adjustment every 15K miles.  On the other hand, you won't need timing
belt adjustments or routine replacements, so the net cost may actually be less.

Nicer to drive?  The 944 is hands down the better cruiser.  911 HVAC and
ergonomics are stone-age, they are noisier and harsher riding.  The 911,
however, is much better endowed with that elusive quality called
"character".  There are few things in this world more pleasurable than
taking a Porsche flat six to the redline, even with the stock exhaust.

Faster on the track?  Depends on the track.  At Mosport, I'd pick a 951
with no hesitation.  At twisty tracks (such as Mid-Ohio) it's a wash.
Stock 951s (are there any left?) are about as fast in a straight line as a
Carrera, somewhat faster than an SC.  More fun on the track?  The 911 is
MUCH more demanding to drive fast on a road course than the 951, but (I
think) more satisfying when you get it figured out.  Proper chassis setup
is MUCH more important on the 911 because of its inherent design problem
(rear engine).  I now have several thousand buck worth of chassis stuff
done to my 911 and it's a nice car to drive fast, though still not as
benign as my Turbo S was.

See you at Mosport 6/10??

 -Karl Haug, MotorStadt Region, Lansing, MI


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 23:50:00 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Aviation gas in Carrera

Jim Bauman asks if it's OK to put Avgas in a Carrera.

Yes, depending. Higher octane will do absolutely no harm to the engine. It
may not do any good except to the gas station's account either, but it will
NOT damage pistons, valves, etc. 

It COULD damage a catalytic converter if car is fitted with same and the
Avgas contains lead, but I think leaded Avgas is a thing of the past just
like leaded mogas.

Higher octane provides added protection against knock, if you have some
reason to think that is a problem. Also some cars (such as some Euro spec
cars) which have adaptive engine management systems will dial back spark or
boost (if turbo) to compensate for poor gas. If your 86 Carrera is supposed
to run fine on 92 octane, anything above that is probably wasted money.

Higher octane fuel does NOT contain more energy, or burn any differently.

(Later) Dave Darling summed it up about the same.

Only one thing, the Euro 86 Carrera called for 98 Research Octane, about
93-94 pump octane. If you read my previous explanation of how carmakers
select ignition timing, then you'll see that a system does not necessarily
have to be advanced to the knock limit to get optimum power. I don't know if
that's the logic employed by the factory Motronic (advance it til it knocks,
then dial it back a bit) but if max power (regardless of octane rating of the
fuel) is achieved at some specific timing, it could be that that timing is
the one the Motronic prefers to use, and using even higher octane fuel won't
help (it will want to run at that optimum timing unless it detects knock). It
would not make sense to design an engine that is knock limited and then
relies on a knock sensor to prevent disaster, because if the sensor fails or
such, the manufacturer is looking at a warranty claim.

Pete


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 22:41:16 -0700
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: Avgas: a pilot's view


Thanks for all your replies on the avgas. Here's
a response from a pilot friend who was following this
with me...

======
The Avgas that was suggested, 100-130 octane (usually abbreviated
115) contains plenty of lead and is a pre-EPA fuel.  It has been
replaced for most high-performance aircraft engines with 100LL
(low lead).  100LL was mandated by the EPA way back to make aviation
conform to requirements for a specific lead content fuel that would
theoretically serve the needs of all aviation internal combustion 
engines. It replaced 80-octane and 100-130 octane aviation fuels
even though 80 octane actually has less lead in it.
 
The experiment did not work, as 80-octane engines could not handle the
additional lead content of 100 LL, and 115 octane engines -- well
shucks ya gotta have octane!  North American Mustangs with V-1650
Packard-built Rolls Royce engines run fine on 100LL, but lowly T-craft
F-19s with 200 CID engines producing 100 HP have to have TCP added
to the mixture to prevent valve fouling.  
 
The result is that 115 octane fuel would undoubtedly cause damage to 
the catalytic converter on your car, due to the high lead content,
but it certainly will not damage your engine.
 
80-octane fuel is available in the western US but is scarce in the
the US east of the Rockie Mountains. 100LL is available everywhere,
and I have never seen 115 east of the Rockies (then again, I don't
fly anything that uses it).  I believe it is used for airplane racing
as they need the additional knock resistance when running at 
a manifold pressure of 115 inches... ;-)
 
=======

I guess I'll try the real racing gas just for fun....

Jim

Porschephiles #1317                         Tue Apr 11 12:22:35 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 02:09:59 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: seeking Speedster

> I have a friend who is seeking a (1950's) Porsche Speedster in need of
> restoration (but substantially complete) with no rust. Please send me e-mail
> if you know of anyone selling.

Near as I can tell, Speedsters fall into two categories at this point:

1) need everything, including lots of rust repair

2) restored, if that word may be used, at some point in the past and
   range from need everthing to be RIGHT on up to 100 point
   concours cars.

There are no cars that fit into the "original, needs restoration, no rust"
category. When you start stripping paint and undercoating and removing
the interior bits, it's there. It's *ALWAYS* there.

Stan

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 07:34:51 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Transaxle Noise, NOW WHAT?!!!

Hi, Afsar,

> Well I am hoping for the worst but that's because I don't have
> a CLUE. I would like to hear the diagnostic from the list 944
> Experts specially ( but not the least) from those members on 
> the Cc list. 
> 
> Yesterday, I took my 85/2 944 with 51,000 mile, for a cruise.
> Soon after exiting the highway (about 1/2 mile ), while
> making a right turn, a loud clunking noise started to come from
> the rear axle. I pulled the car to a side street and couldn't
> find any thing visible wrong with the transaxle. The clunk
> appears to sync with each revolution of the wheel. However, the
> clunking noise seems to disappear in the reverse. 
> 

Sure doesn't sound like a CV joint... more likely a ring and pinion 
getting ready to lock bigtime.

Best way to check is:

1) drain the transaxle fluid. Look for signs of metal in the fluid.

2) drop the passenger side halfshaft.

3) remove the passenger side flange (on the trans).

4) remove the passenger side cover.

You can now look inside at the ring and pinion.  If it is broken, your
options are few:

1) rebuild the trans.

2) buy a used or rebuilt trans.

Sorry, there are no cheap options...

Good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 07:45:59 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944: Question for timing belt DIYourselfers

> 
> After installing my new timing belt, setting the tightness to 4.0 with the
> gauge, and installing the balance shaft belt, I now realize that it will
> practically require removal of the bal. belt just to check the timing belt
> again at 3000 km. It doesn't seem right, but it's impossible to use the
> gauge with the balance belt in the way. Therefore, I'm curious as to what
> the timing belt usually reads at the end of the first 3000 km. Is it
> usually pretty close to the prescribed 2.7 +/- 0.3? 

Not a problem. You just have to find the spot where you can slip the gauge
in. about halfway between the cam pulley and the crank pulley.
You must not be trying hard enough. I do it all the time...

> 
> Also, the 944 Spec. booklet (p.41) specifies for the balance belt:
>  
> for roller without oblong hole: 4.3 +/- 0.3 (new belt)
> for roller with oblong hole:    2.7 +/- 0.3 (new belt) 
> 
> - Jim Pasha's Excellence article specifies 2.7 (no mention of oblong hole)


> - Factory manual mentions nothing of 'oblong hole' and specifies 2.7
> - All balance belt tensioners I've seen have a round hole. Therefore 4.3?
> - Maybe they're referring to the bal. idler roller, and therefore 2.7?
> - My instincts tell me to go with 2.7

I have used 2.7 on my 83 for several years. And yes, they are referring to
the smooth idler roller. (the one on the inside of the belt)...

> 
> Can anyone clear up the confusion?

Probably, but it might not be me...  :-)

Good luck
- --

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 95 02:05:17 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Window fuse blowing on 944

> Hi all
>      I had my 86 944 detailed today and the power window fuse has blown 
> 3 times since, Any input folks??
> Thanks!
> Marc
> 86 944 Black.
> P.S. Thanks to all who responded to my sunroof question.
> 
> 

Hi, Marc,

If you look at the wiring diagram for the power windows, you will discover
that there is very little except 3 switches and two motors.

I would look for a wire that has had the insulation stripped off or chaged
by a chunk of body (read: ground)...

Disconnect all the switches and ring out the circuits with an ohmmeter. Look
for a dead short..... .You can also check the motors for dead shorts, but
probably won't find that to be the case...

good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 18:24:24 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944: Question for timing belt DIYourselfers

> 
> On Mon, 10 Apr 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:
> 
> (of using the P9201 gauge)
> 
> > Not a problem. You just have to find the spot where you can slip the gauge
> > in. about halfway between the cam pulley and the crank pulley.
> > You must not be trying hard enough. I do it all the time...
> 
> Thanks George. I'll take a harder look. The problem is that:
> 
> - the bal. belt is in the way
> - I cannot insert the P9201 paddle at certain places along the belt without
>   binding btween the belt and belt cover and seriously affecting the reading.

>   Therefore, I'm quite limited as to where on the belt I can use the gauge.
>   Maybe the belt covers allowed for different clearance on different years?

Make sure that you are placing the flat paddles on the outside (flat part)
of the timing belt and the round roller on the inside of the belt. I have
never found this to be difficult or to affect the reading...

Also, make sure that you set the engine to TDC on #1 and then back up one
and a half teeth to take the tension off the upper part of the belt...

After looking at several different years, there is no difference in the
clearance of the covers...

good luck,

- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 10:07:38 -0400
From: Yumski@aol.com
Subject: 911 Rookie

Dear Porsche Experts:
I've just begun to look for a 911 Targa recently. I'd like to have one to
tool around Penna. this summer.  Been lurking around the list for awhile.
Figured I might learn a little without appearing like too much of a schmo by
posting a naive message. Well, I learned a little. But I guess there's just
no getting around looking like a schmo when your a rookie. So here goes.
Here's what maybe I learned:
1. New owner's should probably stay away from turbos for a variety of
reasons. They are great once you have some experience driving and maintaining
but giving one to a newbie is like giving a baby dynamite.
2. Pre 79 911's with the 2.7 liter engine probably should be avoided if
possible.
3. 3/4 of all Porsche's are in California and all of them (no matter the
geography) need a lot of attention.
4. All Targa tops leak
5. There is no real "correct" way to pronounce the name, but Porsha is
probably the best choice(this discussion sure went on longer than
anticipated) 
Anyway, here's my questions:
1. As a general rule are the '79 to '83 sc's the best cars for durability or
is a better rule "the newer the better". I'm refering to both durability and
drivability here.
2. Is the swap meet coming up in the Carlisle, Pa. area a good place to see
cars or potentially make a deal to buy one? I noticed it's refered to as a
"Swap Meet" so maybe it's mostly parts and whatnot. Much as I'd like to have
a car, I don't think I'm ready to build one from parts.
Thanks for your patience
The Rookie
(and worse yet, from aol)
Please email Yumski.aol.com

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 10:12:49 -0400
From: asdunn@nytimes.com (Ashley Dunn)
Subject: Re: Ray Scruggs' book

You can order the book  from:
Ray Scruggs
20-A Scenic Ave.
San Rafael, Calif. 94901

$10 for each copy plus $2 shipping and handling
He also has a pamphlet on home alignment of the 914. 944 and C2, C4 is
coming soon!
I heartily recommend his pamphlet. All the adjustment on the front
(toe,caster, camber, hieght) can be done by any fool (hey I did it, although
my wife was embarassed to see the lines of string around my car in the
driveway). One sugestion: instead of measuring the distance between strings
to make sure they are parallel, just get two long pieces of wood or rod and
mark the distance on them and tie string to the mark. A lot easier and you
don't have to get another person to help you measure. Rear adjustment gets a
little trickier, but is doable. The only area that seems weak is the corner
balancing part. 



>I would like to know were you purchase Ray Scruggs' book. This sounds of
>interest to me. There is not a "good" Porsche alignment shop in my area. I do
>all the work on my car except the alignment. Thank you in advance.
>              
>                                         Bill
>
>1977 EURO 930
>
>

Metro reporter
The New York Times
wk. (212) 556-7422
fax (212) 556-7615

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 07:52 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Kicks on Route 66


  Hey P-filers,

  This past (long) weekend I spent back where I got my P-car, in
  Oklahoma City. Circumstances forced me to drive in something
  other than my 911T, but it was an enjoyable drive, nonetheless.
  I thought I might share a few observations that might be helpful/
  interesting/of no value whatsoever to folks travelling to Parade
  by this route this summer, or just on I-40 ("todays route 66")
   in general.

  1. First of all, the road itself was in pretty good shape, and had
  very few work zones. Gendarmes did not seem to be excessively
  zealous, but the Texas panhandle and all Arizona bear (no pun
  intended) due care in forays above 70 MPH.

  2. If you need a  P-car shop in Oklahoma City, call Bob Dumont's. They
  have
  moved from their I-40 downtown location, but I believe it is still close
  to where it used to be. First rate independent shop.

  3. The Owl Cafe in Albuquerque (Owlbuquerque ??!) at Eubank and I-40
  serves up great green-chile cheeseburgers and has a huevos
  rancheros that is will knock your socks off. A mandatory stop for me.

  4. Lots of great sights along the way. Everything from the Grand Canyon
  to the Cadillac Ranch in Amarillo. Plus the traffic on the highway has
  its own
  interesting sights. ( Yesterday, all the Indycar tractor-trailers were
  heading east
  after Long Beach.  Bitchin' rigs...) Plan some extra time to take in what
  you
  can (be like the Porsche engineers in the ad and get some "really neat
  stuff",
  like stuffed armadillos or jackalopes...)

  These are just a couple of things that came to mind. If you have any
  further questions about this route, go ahead and ask as I am reasonably
  well travelled on this stretch of highway.

  Regards,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 10:21:25 -0500
From: martinw@eapi.com

From martinw Tue Apr 11 10:41:19 1995
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: aviation fuel in carrera
X-Mailer: SCO Portfolio 2.0
Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 10:41:14 -0400 (EDT)
Message-ID:  <9504111041.aa04639@eptax.eapi.com>

Forget who asked the question but

100LL or 100 octane low-lead aviation fuel is mis-named.

it is *NOT* low -lead.  it has twenty (20) times the lead contents
of the old leaded pump gas...don't plan on running it in a car with
a cat on it that's for sure.  your also bound to have other problems
like leaded plugs, sticky valves etc

hell I have these problems in an *AIRPLANE* when I run (infrequently)
airplane gas in it.

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 95 11:52 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Formula Motorsports Park

In a recent letter to the list at large, OneGRed930@aol.com said:
    In a recent Autoweek there was a full page ad for Formula Motorsports Park.
     They describe it as a "performance driving country club" with a 3 mile road
    course, autocross park, go-kart track and more.  They describe it as near
    Philadelphia (off Exit 22 of the PA turnpike)  They have a coupon to send in
    with $5 to just get information.  Before I waste $5 and a stamp, does anyone
    on the list know anything about this?

There was a representative from the FMP organization at a recent tech session I
attended.  Basically, they are building a racetrack, skidpad/autocross area and
a clubhouse.  The racetrack will have garages, parking areas for transport
trailers, electronic timers, it will be usable as either one large (2.8 mile?)
track or two smaller tracks.  The clubhouse area will have basketball, tennis,
soccer and baseball facilities, a "pro shop" for racing goodies, a sauna and
swimming pool.  Right now they're just trying to get the track, skidpad and
clubhouse built.  Future plans include a shopping mall with free bus service to
and from the park.  Right now the track is going to be built into a bowl, which
means that the entire track is visible from any one spot.  In the future, the
organization may build bleachers to handle large crowds for F1 or IMSA racing.
Also, they have just signed A. J. Foyt (or was it Mario Andretti?) to the board
of directors, so they've got some good credibility.  If you're serious about
racing, send in your five bucks, as they've got some charter memberships for
sale for about $500 (held in escrow until the park opens, fully refundable at
any time before then).  Once the park opens, memberships jump to something like
US$5K.  Oh, and if you're not a member, I believe the cost is supposed to be
something like $65/day to play there.

More information (with better accurancy ;) will cost you $5....

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 12:19:26 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Avgas in Carrera

Stan's right about distillation curves being different etc. I don't know how
much that would affect operation.

If you put in any kind of octane booster yourself, it is a good idea to wear
serious rubber gloves (not the disposable AIDS thingies). Tetraethyl lead is
toxic, so are some of the substitutes like aniline. I suspect that over the
counter octane remedies are mostly just alcohol though.

Pete

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 17:25:13 +0100
From: P.M.KATZ@CAM3SE.boat.bt.com
Subject: RE: New Porsche C4 Owner Questions

> My boss is a new Porsche C4 owner still familiarizing himself with his new
> car. He has three questions about the car:

>  2. He left the car unused in his garage for about one month while away on
> vacation. When he returned his battery was dead. The car has about 3K on
> its clock and is only about 4 months old. He says he's quite sure he didn't
> leave his interior light or anything else on while away;

	The radio's memory plus the alarm/immobiliser which I assume the car
has are sufficient to drain the battery on most P-cars. Also, if the 
car does very
few miles, it's possible that the battery was far from fully charged 
when it was
stored.

	If it's definitely a problem, put an ammeter in series with the battery
and see what current is being used when the car is not running. Pull 
each fuse in
turn until the current drops to 0 and you'll be able to see what 
circuit the problem
is in. It's not impossible that a wire is chaffing somewhere and is grounding
to earth (happened to a colleague in a new Rover).

> 3. What is the rationale for having to punch in or set or whatever a secret
> code in order to make his radio work following the dead battery incident.
> True, without the code the radio would be useless to a thief. But do all or
> most thieves know this? He found it inconvenient to have to find the code
> in order to reactivate his radio and wonders if this security feature is
> worth the trouble.

	On most radios you can override this feature by setting a null code.
Look in the instruction manual. My 911 has a "coded radio" sticker which would
inform a thief, but I'm not sure that the sort of lowlife who steal car 
radios are
able to read ...

Philip Katz                                     <P.M.Katz@cam3se.boat.bt.com>

1989 911 Carrera 3.2 Sport Coupe (Taubenblau/Baltic Blue Metallic)
Zero cats (but we're thinking of getting 2 kittens ...)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 17:33:15 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: HELP: Update on Dead 944S

On Mon, 10 Apr 1995, Chris Berry wrote:

> Subject: Re: HELP: Update on Dead 944S
> 
> 
> I know every failure mode is different, but you could try this.
> 

This is a stab in the dark - have you checked the air flow sensor, that 
is the quarter circle piece of cake shaped dubery between the air filter 
and the intake manifold.

These are known to stick from time to time

this make the DME think the throttle is wide open and consequently you 
get a rich mixture.

I am told that a sharp tap on the top with your open hand normally 
unsticks them.

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 09:56:25 -0800
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: 911 Vs. 951

>>  The 911,
>>however, is much better endowed with that elusive quality called
>>"character".
>        [snip!]
>>  Proper chassis setup
>>is MUCH more important on the 911 because of its inherent design problem
>>(rear engine).
>
>        What a detractor calls a "problem", the enthusiast says "adds
>character."  You're still crossed up.  Must be that small remnant of
>H2O in your bloodstream.  Don't worry, that will clear up soon--then
>the tail-happy nature of the beast will be a *feature*, not a problem!
>        The rear-engine configuration is right and proper.  It isn't
>God's Ordained Engine Layout--the middle (sound of Nomex being donned)
>--but it will do for some.   ;)

Thank you Dave.....

I for one am real tired of hearing about how 911's have this design
flaw that makes them a bear to drive and how 951's are so much
better.

If this is God's truth, why has the 911 been such a successful race
car? It's competition does not have the design flaw of the 911.
Why does the 911 continue to do well at every level of competition if
it has an "inherent design problem"?

Why, by the same token, has the alleged superior 951 (944) not been as
successful?

Price Cobb in a recent Pano interview noted that he and Mauro Baldi
had never raced a 911 before. After their first time out in the 911
3.6 Turbo they both looked at each other and wondered what the big
deal was. They had anticipated this ill-handling car and did not
experience that at all.

Now, I am no Price Cobb, but I have been asking this same question
since I got my 911 several years ago. I don't see the big deal. Sure,
the handling is different, but not so abnormal that the car is
difficult to drive. It is just different.

I have yet to have any 944 come within 1 second of my time at an
autocross. I drive a '78 911 Targa with a stock '88 3.2 Carrera
motor with headers and a chip. Sure, I have trick suspension and
a 7:31 ring & pinion. But I autocross in the San Francisco area, one
of the autox hotbeds. If the 944 S2 or 951 or 968 are so great,
how come they are not cleaning my and every other 911's clock?

I am not trying to say the 911 is superior to the 944 series. That
is an issue best taken up with one's self. I am just saying that
the 911 "inherent design problem" is not a problem at all!!

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

as 92 octane so what the hell, right?

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 95 13:09:41 EDT
From: BlaineDeLancey <Blaine.Delancey@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: Re: '88 911 Carrera - starting problems

> Sometimes (it has happened twice), the car won't start when cold. The motor
> cranks but it won't start, the behavior is similar to that of a cis f.i. system
> with a bad control pressure regulator; it seemed like if there was no gas in the
> tank or like if the fuel pump was not working.
> 
> This never happened before; the first time it happened was on Saturday pm.
> When I tried to start the engine, it won't start. it would crank but it won't start.
> I ran the starter five or six times, for about 4 seconds each try and about 30-45
> seconds between each attempt, and... nothing. I could not believe this, the thing
> was just fine the night before. So of course I could not resist trying again.
> About 20-30 minutes later, I tried the same sequece, and ... the engine just
> started! I let the engine idle for about 5 minutes, stopped the engine, and 
> re-started it, it started immediately. Good. 

I had the same set of problems with my CIS '80 SC, and after much
confusion, it was discovered that the resistor in the distributor rotor
had burned up.  I kicked myself for not checking it before the garage
spent $90 diagnosing a $8 fix.  I kept checking the fuel system, battery,
etc.  Ah well, hope this is all you have.

Blaine

64, 66, 72, 80, 85, 87, 90, 91, 94, and 97.

version.  Has anyone looked at both?  Can you tell me how many pages ar in the
books?  Are there are any more Groups that are included only in the books?

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 12:53:37 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Avgas in Carrera

> Stan's right about distillation curves being different etc. I don't know how
> much that would affect operation.

It affects heat and rate of combustion, flame front propogation and
a few other things that in general make this a less than desirable
solution. Did a lot of experimenting with this while building VW Type
I powered dragsters...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 13:10:05 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: MFI vs. Carbs

>Which got me to wonder what the consensus is on this comparison?  What are the
>positives and negatives of each?

        Basically the MFI *will* give you more power if you have not
majorly modified your engine.  And if it's in good working condition
and properly adjusted.  Those last two can be a royal pain in the
***.  The carbs are a well-understood quantity that pretty much any
mechanic can deal with.  Not so with MFI.
        MFI *may* also have better cold-start/etc. behavior, probably
better fuel efficiency, lower emissions, and all those other Good
Things that result from fuel-injection systems.  At least the fuel
tends to burn better by being better atomized.

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 95 12:11:37 PDT
From: "David O. Blanchard" <blanch@capella.cup.hp.com>
Subject: Re: 911 vs 951

Scott Winders wonders why his 911 isn't getting beat by 944s, 951, 968s.

The tail happy behavior that makes 911s treacherous road cars makes them 
fun autox cars.  The opposite is true for the waterpumpers.  
Waterpumpers are safe and easy to drive fast on the street, but on an 
autox course, their concentrated front weight means they don't like 
tight corners.  951s are really fun on race tracks, but are a pain at an 
autox.  I have yet to find a turbocharged car of any stripe that is easy 
to autox.  968s and 951s also suffer from an autobaun final drive at 
autoxes.  Normal 944s don't have anything like the weight/HP (18:1 vs 13 
to 15:1) common in later 911s.  The greater weight is supported on tires 
the same (or smaller) size as the later 911s.  I think you can say that 
911s and waterpumpers are different kinds of cars.  Comparing the two on 
the basis of autox times doesn't tell you much.

In Golden Gate region, I have the most highly prepared waterpumper that 
autoxes.  I have tires, Koni shocks and an aftermarket front swaybar on 
a 924Turbo ($931).  Needless to say, Scott's well-prepared 911 (His 
wheels are worth more than my car :-) ) cleans me up.  It would be fun 
to see Byron Short show up in his S2, although the prep level (for SCCA 
Solo II) is about the same as my $931.  An S2 has Weight/HP similar to 
an SC or Carrera, and doesn't suffer from a turbocharger.

Despite my whining, waterpumpers are fun and challenging to drive. I 
lament the fact that there are not many waterpumpers autoxing.  At this 
point in Porsche's progress, they represent a very reasonable entry 
level for newcomers.  We need them to show and play and be part of us.

DavidOB --- blanch@cup.hp.com    81 924 Turbo (931, Toy car) 
Golden Gate Region PCA           
SF Region SCCA                   88 Toyota turbo All Trac

Date: 11 Apr 95 15:20:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: Where the streets have no name.

Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV shook the dust off his boots and wrote:

 >> I thought I might share a few observations that might be helpful/
 >> interesting/of no value whatsoever to folks travelling to Parade
 >> by this route this summer, or just on I-40 ("todays route 66")
 >> in general.

***Interesting local tour guide deleted***

This section of highway (from OKC west to Bakersfield) has to be my absolute 
favorite road.  Especially going through Arizona, New Mexico, and the California 
high dessert.  Incredible country, beautiful vistas, and mile after mile of flat, 
straight, concrete ribbon just begging to be eaten up!

I've done the trip several times, but only once in a P-car.  That was back in '89,
when I drove my '944 from its old home in California to its new one in NJ.  That trip
ranks as the very best road trip I have ever made.

Of course, you've got to watch out for the snow, and particuarly the ice, going
over Flagstaff.  There's a giant whirligig windmill somewhere in West Texas that
always makes me smile, and a solar furnace in the California dessert that's
kinda cool.  My favorite roadside sight has to be the airfield at North Edwards
(or is it Mojave?).  You come out of the barren dessert, into a two stoplight
town with tumbleweed blowing down the main street.  But there, on the outskirts, 
is what looks like Atlanta International Airport.  Hundreds of giant jets - 747s, 
727s, even 707s, all parked in rows on the tarmac.  Of course, they're all just 
being stored there, in the land where nothing rusts, until such time as the 
economics of the airline industry make it profitable to fly them again, but what 
a sight!

By the way - if there is such a thing as a rust free, unrestored 356, this is
where it is hiding.  Keep those eyes open, and peer into every tumbledown shed
that you pass - you never know!

I've rambled long enough and wasted enough bandwidth, but your post brought back
some very good memories.  Maybe someday soon I'll take "baby' back for a visit to
the land of her youth.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, Misses the Dessert!

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 16:00:20 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 vs. 951 (long)


At the risk of not restating the theme, I am going to put in my $.02 worth!
 I enthusiastically agree with Scott Winders and Dave Darling on the
DRIVABILITY of the 911 platform.  It is stable, predictable, and fast!  I
spent three days at Sebring battling with the 951's and I know where I was
faster than they were...in the turns!  And as far as the dreaded TTO
(trailing throttle oversteer), a properly set up 911 has VERY LITTLE.  Turn 17
 is a huge decreasing radius sweeper, that you enter off of a 1/2 mile
straight.  I go in at about 150, stand on the brakes, and then TURN IN, while
still hard on the brakes!  Once the car slows down to about 80, approaching
the first apex, I lift off the brakes, grab 3rd gear, and set off like a bat
out of h*ll, towards the 2nd apex, and down the pit straight.  The quicker
951's used the exact same technique.  So much for the wicked 911 handling.

I will agree that the 944/951 platform (high polar moment & 50/50 weight
distribution) is easier to drive at speed, and much more neutral and
forgiving than a front biased or rear biased car.  The car will resist the ini
tial urge to understeer or oversteer.  What people do not understand is that
this DOES NOT make the car inherently faster at the limit, only easier to
drive at the limit.  Because the average person will feel more comfortable
with it, they can get closer to the limit of the car.  A 911 is much harder
to drive, but well driven it is easily a match for the equivalent HP 944/951.

One final point is that a 911 demands to be driven properly; i.e. obeying all
of the laws of physics, using the weight shift of the car to generate more
cornering power, proper apexing, etc.  It rewards poor technique with
off-road excursions.  A 944, on the other hand will get around quite nicely
(that high polar moment again!) whilst driven all wrong.  I know...I've spent
alot of time trying to re-teach 944 drivers that have picked up bad habits.
 If they drove a 911, they would not have been able to get away with such
behavior.

Sorry for the long-winded discourse, but driving is my favorite subject.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 20:22:13 +0000 (GMT)
From: "Ralph E. Forey III" <FOREY_RALPH_E_III@Lilly.com>
Subject: A/C questions & R-406A

Regarding something that was posted weeks ago ...
 
> Conversion is really a side issue because R-12 is going to be around for
> a long time.  The Bush admin EPA was shilling for big industry as 
> represented by MACS and SAE.  The Clinton EPA is taking a much more
> pragmatic approach (strangely enough), particularly after the industry
> was caught lying about the ease of conversion and the reliability
> of 134a systems.  They have already pushed back the deadline to stop
> production of R-12 by a year and the feeling is it will be pushed back
> further.  Plus there are alternatives.  R-406a, formerly known as 
> GHG-12, developed by George Goble (ghg@ecn.purdue.edu) is an exact
> drop-in for R-12.  Banned at industry request under the Bush admin,
> it was re-examined under the Clinton administration and given approval
> for everything except mobile use.  The exception is strictly a political
> move in that the EPA doesn't want to admit all at once how bad it screwed
> up so the mobile exclusion will go away within the year.
        ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

I corresponded with the source of info. on R-406A (GHG-12) George Goble and he 
responded ...

>I did not say this.. It is currently a $25,000 fine and a $10,000 reward
>(for those you turn you in) to put R-406A in a car.. Unless you owned the
>refrigerant before Feb 14, 1994, and it is legal to still use  pre
>Feb 14, 1994 R-406A in cars. (it wasn't called R-406A back then though).
>
>There are approx 150 million R-12 cars still around.. Assume 1/3 of those
>end up trading in early to get a New car (R-134a).. and the other
>2/3 sweat, etc.. that is $10,000 (for a new car/low) X 50,000,000
>for 1/2 trillion $$$ in new cars sales above and beyond normal..
>These car sales "belong" to Detroit, and nobody (not even the
>president of the US) is going to take it away from them.  Whatever
>means/laws which are necessary to do this will happen.

and also...

>It is mfgr by People's Welding Supply, but they don't do any sales or take
>orders.  Certified technicians (with EPA "green card" for stationary
>refrigeration) can contact Monroe Air Tech, 1-800-424-3836 (Bloomington,
>IN) or McMullen Oil in Clearwater, FL (800 669 5730).  McMullen uses
>"McCool 406A" for a brand name.  Putting it in your car could get you
>a $25,000 EPA fine!!  R-406A is "legal" for transport refrigeration
>and it is allowed to cool the cargo, bit it is not allowed to cool
>the driver.  The A/C parts for the "driver" are made in Detroit
>(same as automotive compressors, etc) .. Go figure..  R-406A is
>legal for cars in most countries outside the USA.

and finally ...

>Back in '85.. I used to work 14 hour days, 7 day weeks.. in 1990
>I burned out on that.. and cut back to more or less 8 hour days
>and 5 day weeks.. so I piddled around for a few weekends (a couple
>in the library, and a couple blending refrigrant), and came up with
>R-406A.  And spent the next 5 years fighting with everybody trying
>to stop it.  Did get 2 patents on it, but I I am still several 
>tens of thosands in the hole over it..
>	
>good to hear from you
>--ghg

Nice to know that our good government is protecting Detroit at the expense of 
the taxpayers and entreprenuers.  BOHICA!! (Bend over, here it comes again!!)

Ralph  --> FOREY_RALPH_E_III@LILLY.COM

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 16:54:35 -0400

Joe writes
>In a recent Autoweek there was a full page ad for Formula Motorsports Park.
>They describe it as a "performance driving country club" with a 3 mile road
>course, autocross park, go-kart track and more.  They describe it as near
>Philadelphia.

I know all about it since one of my friends, Bob Russo, is a VP of the organiz
ation. Bob may be known to some of you as he was head of Holbert's Racing
until Al's untimely death.
Anyway this is going to be one fantastic site for car enthusiasts with a road
corse, AutoX site, Car oriented shops, recreation areas etc, etc,... There
will be professional instructors available  for private lessons , just about
anything you can think of. It was just announced that Mario Andretti is on
the board of directors.
That's the good news. The bad news is that it isn't built yet, with ground
breaking scheduled for later this year. Hopefully at least the track will be
open in late 96.
BTW this is a commercial operation that is supposed to show a profit and
potential investors are invited to contact Bob at 215-732-9376. I am sure he
will be glad to answer any questions personally.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
4:40 pm

------------------------------

Date:         Tue, 11 Apr 95 15:33:27 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      944 Thermostat failure

>> I suppose it is also possible that your thermostat had stuck closed. I
>> don't know if this is very likely or not.
>

I was at a driver ed event in Talladega, AL last month and noticed
my temp climbing at the end of the back straight.  By the time I
entered the pits and shut the engine down, the temp gauge had just
popped into the hot region and the warning light came on.  We noticed
that I didnt have 1 drop of coolant left!  So after letting the engine
cool, we filled with water and started the engine. Temp started to
climb again, we shut it down. Finally figured out what happened.
While running at 6K+ rpm on the back stretch, my thermostat failed
in the closed position.  The sudden closure increased the pressure
so much that it split the input heater hose spewing all my coolant
all over the track.  We temporarily fixed my car by duct taping
the heater hose and ripping the innards out of the thermostat.
We didnt have the magic snap ring pliers.  As long as I kept the
heat off and the engine running to supply vacuum to the heater valve,
the hose didnt leak and I was able to limp home (2 hr drive).

I had been noticing my car running warmer than usual, especially on
cool days.  While sitting at a traffic light, the temp would climb
to the top of the normal range. When the car moved or the fans kicked
on, the temp dropped back to the bottom of the normal range.  This
happened for awhile until eventually my fan switch failed.  I replaced
the switch and noticed the fans came on much earlier than before. But
still the car ran warmer that I thought it should.  What I suspect was
happening, was that my thermostat was never completely opening and
then it failed completely.  So, if you notice your temps running
hotter on days that arent the hot, replace your thermostat and/or
fan switch.  My car now consistently stays on the bottom line of
the normal range, even on 85F degree days in city traffic.

While I was at it, I replaced my coolant with Zerex Extreme 450.
It is phosphate-free and approved by Porsche. (See Panorama March 95)
It's also 1/2 the price of the gray bottle Prestone.

Also, if your car is overheating and you have A/C, with your engine
shut off, turn your key to the ON position and mash (southern term)
the A/C button.  It'll make your fans run.  Mine didn't run because
the coolant was all over the track instead of being in contact with
the fan switch.

Darren
'87 944S Indischrot

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 17:24:37 -0400 (EDT)
From: Joseph Tzougrakis <jtzougra@acad.bryant.edu>
Subject: Re: 911 Vs. 951

> 
> I for one am real tired of hearing about how 911's have this design
> flaw that makes them a bear to drive and how 951's are so much
> better.
> 
> If this is God's truth, why has the 911 been such a successful race
> car? It's competition does not have the design flaw of the 911.
> Why does the 911 continue to do well at every level of competition if
> it has an "inherent design problem"?
> 
> Why, by the same token, has the alleged superior 951 (944) not been as
> successful?

> 
I think its quite puzzling too that everyone always focuses on the 
drawbacks of this layout without seeing the benefits.  A rear-engined 
layout offers the following benefits:

1) Superior traction under acceleration

2) Effecient packaging (just like FWD that everyboby else seems to have 
embraced)

3) Excellent balance while braking

4) Very responsive steering

I'm sure there are many others.  I'm not sure why, but the press is 
always trying to point out the problems with this layout for the nth time, 
but rarely do they write about its inherent advantages.  

Joe Tzougrakis

 -black 86 944

Dag!  That's exactly what my car's doing!  I figured it was some reaction to

I replaced was in a Buick, and it was too easy -- pop the radiator cap and
there it was!  Pull it out (literally -- no tools required!), stick in a new
one, all done.  I assume on a P-car it'll take an hour and some Appropriate

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 15:25:26 -0600
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Mystery plastic in oil screen (912)

This weekend I decided I should attend to the 6000 mile maintenance early 
and as such took out the oil screen and magnet that surrounds the oil pickup 
line. This was the first time I've done this since having the engine rebuilt 
about 5000 miles ago. (More years ago than I'd like to admit).

To my dismay there were small bits of soft blue plastic (looks like gasket 
sealer) all around the wire mesh protecting the oil intake. What did this 
guy do when he rebuilt my engine ? I was not happy with the independent 
shops attitude at the time but got warm fuzzies from the fact that the chief 
mechanic *claimed* to have worked for a local Porsche dealership previously 
(for all I know they may have fired him).

Now to the core of the mystery. I tested the 'oil booster line' by holding 
the 'by-pass valve' in place manually. I got oil flow after cranking for a 
few seconds. Since the car has been running very hot I was afraid of a 
clogged booster line causing oil flow to bypass the oil cooler.

Last weekend I aborted a trip when the oil temp gauge crawled close to the 
red line while driving normally at highway speeds in 80 degree weather. I've 
never seen the car run so hot before. I suspected the guage and sender but 
after stopping I touched the bypass oil filter and could not believe how hot 
it was. (Not very scientific I know.)

When one of the oil cooler 'O' rings failed in cold weather (years before 
the engine rebuild) I had the chance to clean the oil cooler and inspect it. 
I also cleaned the cooling impeller. Yes my weber carburettors need 
rebuilding and tuning. Ignition was checked with a timing light about three 
months ago so I *think* thats OK but I'll check it this weekend. 

I'm going to be very reluctant to drive this car until I can have an idea of 
what is going on inside my engine. Does anyone have any idea what this blue 
plactic (gasket sealer?) is from. Did a seal fail somewhere in my engine ? 
Do I need to tear it apart to find the cause ?









Chris Jungmann                                   jungmann@swcp.com
Software Development                             Voice: 505-275-6566
Northern Systems, Inc.                           Fax:   203-373-0880
                                                 BBS:   203-373-0881

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 23:18:13 -0400
From: David1786@aol.com
Subject: Re: Javier's starting prob.

I have an 82 911SC and recently experienced almost exactly what you have
described.  A non-Porsche mechanic identified it as a problem with the fuel
pump relay (it's on the fuse panel in the trunk).  The car started fine for a
few weeks, and then the problem reappeared.  I took it to my Porsche mechanic
who immediately recognized it as a bad/worn/corroded fuse.  He replaced the
fuse and it has been fine ever since. 

The Porsche mechanic initially believed that the entire fuse panel had begun
to disintegrate and, therefore, connections were not being made.  That was
not the problem with mine (yet!), but it be another possible explanation for
your problem.

David
82 911SC

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 23:26:52 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Mystery plastic in oil screen (912)

> That's been confirmed this afternoon. I took a sample to a mechanic friend 
> and he recognized it as such. Seems it came from the valve covers. I did'nt 
> see any between the crankcase halves. The RTV "FAG" must have found its way 
> into the crankcase via the valve guide tubes.

Hmmm. Well, that's a lot better than what I'd guessed. You don't use
RTV there, you use 3M #8001 "gorilla snot" weatherstrip and trim
adhesive to hold the gaskets to the covers. On the 914's too, for 
that matter.

> Hum yea kinda ... we'll last time the oil filter canister was out of the car 
> I cleaned it completely but during my last oil change I did'nt *suction* the 
> remaining oil ...

Get a turkey baster. No, you *can't* use the one that your wife has. She'll
notice. Trust me. Pop the filter out, suction the oil, wipe it out with a
clean rag/paper shop towel/etc, drop in the new filter (or the old filter
if you're one of those "oil at 3k, filter at 6k" types), fill with oil,
replace the gasket, top, and don't forget to torque down that bolt! Then
proceed with the rest of the engine.

> So in your honest opinion, does it sound like I have a clogged oil tube, 
> perhaps oil cooler ? Does this "Bad News" mean that I need to tear this baby 
> apart and rebuild it to find the cause of the excessive running temperature ?

Possibly a clogged cooler. What I'd recommend is this: buy a case of filters,
a couple of cases of 40 wt. oil. Change the oil with *GREAT* frequency 
(not quite daily, but at least every 1k miles, maybe weekly if you're
not driving it a lot) [sidebar: my SC is seeing about 1500 miles a week
right now, so I have a skewed view on "a lot" of miles...]

If it improves, then you're fine. If it doesn't, then you'll need to think
about dropping the engine, pulling the shroud and cooler for look-see.
I'd also be real tempted to pop off the strainer, and use compressed air
to blow down the pushrod tubes to see if anything interesting pops out
of that big hole in the bottom of the engine.

Good luck!

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 23:43:22 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Engine Rebuild Question

> I've had my 911 for about 8 months and have been enjoying Excellence and
> Panorama magazines for about a year. The ads in those magazines are about as
> interesting to me as the articles. I was looking at the Engine Builders
> Supply ad and had a question. 

Don't get too wound up in the ads -- or the articles, for that matter.
Most of the mags don't let the facts get in the way of blowing an
advertiser...

> What is the difference between a top-end rebuild kit and an engine re-ring
> kit. Rings only cost $120 for a 2.4 911 engine, what else comes with the
> re-ring kit?   

Top-end kits *typically* have just enough to take the heads on and off;
re-ring kits have enough to take the pistons out. That usually includes
rings, and for waterpumpers, rod bearings (you don't have to take the
rods off the crank to get to the pistons on air cooled engines).

> Also, why do 911 performance rebuild kits cost 3-4 times as much as 914 kits
> when they only have 2 more cylinders. Is 911 engineering really that much
> more complex than a 914, or is it more price gouging? Do these kits include
> everything? 

In part, due to the limited market. Lots of Type IV engines out there.
*LOTS*. Count the total number of late model VW Buses, 914s (there's about
120k alone), etc. vs. the total number number of 911s of a particular
engine configuration... It's not even close.

Second, the 911 stuff is of *MUCH* higher quality. 

Couple the two, and you get significantly higher prices.

Stan

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1319                         Wed Apr 12 00:19:18 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 11 Apr 95 22:10:40 PDT
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: re: 914 clutch question

>From: DavidSoCal@aol.com
>Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 02:14:24 -0400
>Subject: what clutch for 914?
>
>My clutch went out on my 914 and my mechanic is suggesting I consider a
>heavier duty clutch. I do drive it pretty hard. But I want something that is
>comfortable for stop-and-go city driving. (I live in LA. :) ) Any suggestions
>or advice?
>
>David Bombardier
>1974 914 2.0

The stock clutch in a 914 lasts about 100K miles.  Everybody I've
talked to has gotten the same results.

If you replace it with a heavier duty clutch, you may get a few more
miles out of it.

But if you do use a heavier clutch, you run the risk of breaking off
the clutch cable tube.  And they aren't cheap to weld back in.

"When in doubt, stick with stock."

Gary.
gary@superior.ucsf.edu.

Subject: Opinion Wanted - Foreign Intrigue

Intrigue of Berwick, Maine?

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 22:20:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: '87 944 cam belt tensioner

On Tue, 11 Apr 1995 Hultgrenho@aol.com wrote:

> This whole proceedure is covered by Technical Bulletin # 8820 "Camshaft Belt
> Adjustment" complete with handy pictures.  Of course the bulletin is dead
> wrong, in that I don't believe you can replace the cam belt without removing
> the dreaded crankshaft pulley which is torqued to about 350 million ft-lbs.

I had no problem inserting the cam belt into the gap between the balance 
gear on the crank and the rear belt cover. Slide one edge in upwards at a 
diagonal in the centre and gradually push the belt in as you work away 
from the centre. But then again, I have an '86 944 so it might be different.
 
Joe '86 944

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Apr 1995 23:36:19 -0700
From: leedsg@halcyon.com (Leeds Gulick)
Subject: re: Oil Change on the 993

>Why is the Oil Change on the 993 so expensive?
>
>          The 993 has two oil filters that need to be changed.  As i
>        understand it, one filter in in the engine compartment while
>        the second filter is a real bear to get at.  Requires removing
>        some stuff that requirs time.  Like an hour to get at it and an
>        hour to put all the suff back into place.
>
>
>          I do not have a 993.  But I did talk with a PORSCHE mechanic
>        about the cost of changing the oil and how to do it.  He
>        did not have a 993 at that time to show me what had to come
>        off to get at the second filter.
>
>          Does anyone know why they put a second oil filter in the
>        car?

The auxiliary oil filter is located in the bodywork just in front of the
right rear wheel and its purpose is to provide extra protection for the new
hydraulic valve lash adjusters against contaminants in the oil. The oil
passes through this secondary filter after it leaves the oil tank and
passes through the oil pump, and just before it enters the engine. The oil
passes through the primary filter just after it is scavenged from the
engine and before it goes to the cooler and oil tank. Oil changes are every
15,000 miles and both oil filters are to be changed at 30,000 miles. I
think the engineers felt that the time between filter changes was so great
that they didn't have to worry about convenience.

Leeds Gulick



------------------------------


Porschephiles #1321                         Wed Apr 12 13:36:02 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 03:25:39 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Mystery Plastic in 912 Sump

Dear Chris:

      Hummh, blue plastic in the 912 sump screen? Was it hard or soft blue
plastic? If hard, it could be  from the blue-green Flywheel Seal that comes
in Reinz Lower End Kits. (These seals aren't nearly as good as the White
Silicone seals which, unfortunately, you can't get anymore.)
    If it's a soft blue plastic, that could be from the blue "O" rings used
under the case Acorn Nut washers. Sometimes a bit of these seals is sheared
off when torquing the case and ends up in the sump.
    Since the Flywheel Seal is some 60mm (2.4") while the Acorn Nut  "O" ring
is about 1/4" diameter, any curvature of the pieces could tell you where it
came from. If it's just blobs or gobs of blue stuff without any definite
curvature  (or round cross section), then it's probably excess Blue RTV.
Unfortunately, Blue RTV is a Trademark of a Turkey. Especially excess RTV of
any color.
     As  to the overheating- check your High Speed Timing just for funsies.
If it's 40 degrees advanced  (or 20 degrees), that's the problem. Check fan
belt for proper tension (not way loose). Check (with engine OFF!) for
rag/paper towel in fan. And check to see if heater boxes flaps are open
rather than shut. 
     New engines tend to run hot, but should be broken in at 6000 miles,
unless your "normal highway speed" was 90+. THEN they do run pretty warm!

KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro
P.S. The hand on the oil filter is a pretty good indicator. If you can hold
your hand on it, its NOT running too hot. If the thermal radiation from the
can tess you it would  be stupid to touch it, it probably IS running too hot.
The  dip stick works the same way.

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 95 10:52:21 +0200
From: Kari Eloranta <eloranta@lammio.hut.fi>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1315 Mon Apr 10 17:03:42 CDT 1995

A while ago I did some automotive reserch i.e. top speed runs on  
Autobahn with my 944 using regular motoring gas available in Germany  
but varying the octane rating. There is a distinct improvement in  
top speed (about 210 -> 245 kph) when the octane rating goes from  
91(2) to 95. The engine runs fine with both. Basic physics seems to  
say that at high speed wind resistance is the main opponent and it  
is top horsepower that counts. So what is it in the higher octane  
gas that makes this happen? Some people in recent discussion on   
Avgas said that higher octane (above the minimum) doesn't really  
contribute to power.

Regards,

Kari

84 944, Red and roaming free after hibernation...

complete replacement ECU system for the 911 developed by Bob Watson Racing.
Sounds very interesting and apparently suitable for retrofit onto 930s with
K-Jetronic.
  They are charging 5500 UK POUNDS for it fully fitted. The tuning is/will be 
done on a dyno and there is/will be an interface to a lap top for tweeking.
Think its realy aimed at racing but probably very good for street. One claim
they have is that they got 25bhp more after converting their RACE RSR on
mechanical injection system. It also gave them a better lap time round Oulton
Park by 1.5 secs.

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 08:40:36 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: RE: Porschephiles #1315 Mon Apr 10 17:03......


The only time I got my "87" 944 to 140mph was with a slight down hill and 
a strong tailwind.  I suspect you're seeing speedometer error as these cars
are not capable of 147mph as you stated (I used 0.6 as the conversion).  I 
have read that a car tuned properly to take advantage of increased octane
can see a performance increase of 1.5% from 87 to 93 octane.  I suspect
your observed variations are due to day to day changes in humidity and 
ambient air temperature which affect an engine's performance.  

It has to do with the rate at which the fuel burns and at what point the 
flame front is initiated.  The key is to develop the flame front so the 
cylinder pressure is peaking when the piston begins the power stroke.  The 
higher octane gases will keep burning as the piston travels to bottom dead
center.  That will keep the pressure in the cylinder higher through more of
the power stroke and more power will result.  This may not be *exactly* corr-
ect but the gist is correct.  

So if the engine is not tuned for high octane gas, the flame front will not
be initated soon enough, take too much time to develop, and the fuel
 will still be burning when the exhaust valves open.  This happened when 
a friend of mine used 110 octane gas in a motorcycle with chrome exhausts.
At the cylinder interface the chrome got discolored from heat and I assumed
it was because the gas was still burning.

A high octane gas burns slower than low octane gas and resists pre-ignition.

Any critiques or additional info is welcome

Jeff
Jpuzas@astro.ge.com


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 95 08:29:35 EDT
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: Re: '87 944 cam belt tensioner


Ok- I think we've sorted out my tensioner problems.
I was working on the wrong nut- the 17mm one that looks like
the locknuts for other tensioners- and not the 13mm one 
that locks down the mechanical "self" tensioner.

I checked again, and yes the fiche manuals DO have the 
information, at the end of section 15 under the title
"Cam Belt Mechanical Tensioner."

Thanks to everyone for the good advice...

Scott Humphreys
scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com
87 944 (RED)

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 06:45:33 -0700
From: dthompsn@ix.netcom.com (William D. Thompson)
Subject: Re: More MFI

>What actions can one take to prevent damage to the engine due to the 
>mixing of the oil and gas?  I guess I should smell my oil every before
>every oil change.
>
When the engine is hot, take off the oil cap and smell.  If the smell 
of gas is strong, you're mixing gas and oil.  By strong, I mean if it 
makes your eyes water.

>I know that all the manuals state that idle speed is set by adjusting 
the
>air correction screws on the stack, but this is not true with my car.
>Ive turned all six out to the maximum number of turns allowed with 
little
>if none change to idle speed.  The only effective way Ive found is to
>adjust the throttle stop screws.  Oh, and the air bypass holes in the 
stacks
>are as clean as whistles.

I'd check your distributor to see if the advance is working properly.  
Adjusting the air correction screws should work.  The fact that they 
aren't affecting idle speed indicates something else if wrong.
 

>
>What do most people experience when the MFI is out of shape?  What are 
the
>key indicators?  Ive noticed that mine is not very smooth when 
accelerating
>from a stop.  I usually have to slip the clutch a little bit in order 
to
>accelerate from a stop smoothly.  Some people have told me that it is 
>because I have a 911S, others say I shouldn't have to slip the clutch.
>I agree with the latter.

Rough idle, lean throttle surge at about 2500-3000 rpm, hesitation, 
"wandering" idle speed and a rich mixture that adjusting the pump won't 
correct are the usual warning signs.  A 911S is a little rough at the 
low end by nature (particularly the pre-'72s).

>Why better cold start and top end than carbs?

The Webers don't have fuel enrichment and MFI responds better under 
temperature and barometric changes.


- --Doug

Date: 12 Apr 95 10:27:33 EDT
From: Mark Doyle <MDOYLE@laitram.mhs.compuserve.com>
Subject: '85 911 Vacuum Leak

Based on reading the archives, I suspected a vacuum leak was causing the 
rough and surging idle.  I sealed off the air flow sensor and pressurized 
the intake system with smoky air at 3 PSI.  A small leak was found at a 
rubber boot which was easily fixed.  A larger source of smoky and hissing 
was coming from behind the cooling fan.  After digging around a little, I 
found the leak.  It seems to be coming from the point where the left 
camshaft endplate mates to the cam housing.  It can be seen by removing 
the #1 spark plug connector.  There is also oil seepage below that point 
on the under side of the engine.  Now some questions for the engine 
experts.

Is there some easy fix for this problem?

Can I fix this without removing the engine?

If I use the same sprocket shims, will I have to check the sprocket 
alignment?

If I am careful to set the engine at TDC and mark which hole the cam 
timing pin is in, do I have to check the cam timing when everything is 
back together?



BTW, the smoky air trick worked great.  Much easier to see than a hissing 
sound.  If anyone is interested, I will tell you how I did it.

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 08:19:12 -0700

Subject: FAQs renamed

I was updating the part of the general Porschephiles FAQ that references
model-specific FAQs, and decided to ask Stan if he could rename them so
that the naming convention is more consistent.  In about 30 seconds,
he'd done it.  Here, for your FTPing pleasure, are the new names for the
FAQs in the tta.com archives:
 
NAME                    LAST UPDATED
911.faq                 Feb 22 1995 
914.faq                 Jan 12 1994 
924.faq                 link to 944.faq
944.faq                 Mar  9 1995 
968.faq                 link to 944.faq
carrera.faq             Dec 18 1994
general.faq             Apr  3 1995 

(Now let's hope no DOS/Windows product appears with a .faq suffix  :-)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 10:45:30 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Autothority Mass Flow for 3.2 Carrera

> How about just the chip?

That's tougher. In general, it's the same sort of deal. Two data points:

1) I used to spend about 65 hours of dyno time developing programming for
   a race engine. That's *TYPICALLY* 3 engines, for a total investment
   on the part of the team owner of about $100k. And we didn't have to
   deal with problems like shitty gas, idling in traffic in the summer
   with the A/C on high, etc. So anyone that says they can just "whup out
   a new chip" is completely full of shit. At least AutoThority *has*
   a dyno...

2) see Pete Albrecht's note about how you build an advance curve for 
   a distributor and multiply that by about 100 for a degree of difficulty.
   The factory has the advantage of they already know *everything* about 
   the engine, so it's easy for them to do, relative speaking. To do on
   the outside, first you either have to "reverse engineer" the factory
   stuff, which strictly speaking is not illegal, but the way most people
   do it (disassembly the microcode in the chip) *IS* illegal. Or you have 
   to reverse engineer everything they know that made it possible for them to 
   write their code. Yeah. right.

The use of "special chips" was made popular originally by two things:

* initial shipment of chips that significantly mis-guessed about the 
  prevailing quality of US gas, so a chip with different assumptions
  performed better

* turning up the boost on 944 Turbos. FOr details, see the archives under
  "Head Gasket, Blown"

Porsche in general doesn't give up anything to anyone. Once it is established
that there is a better way to do something with their cars, it becomes
further researched, documented and part of The Way. Typically with more
improvements, BTW.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 10:53:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: C-88?

> 
> What about the C-88?
> 
> If you don't know about it, look and find out. It is a Porsche concept car
> that is similar to a Geo Metro in every aspect. It is for the newly opened
> Chinese market where cheap cars will be bought in mass quantities,
> supposedly.

Everything I've read indicates that it's not just a "concept" car, but
a fully functional prototype.  It is designed by Porsche with the intent
that it will be manufactured in China, by the Chinese, for sale in the
Chinese market.  Design variations allow for different powerplants,
body styles, and the eventual export of the cars to other countries...

Hmmm, sounds a lot like the Beetle story doesn't it...


> I think that maybe Porsche/VW/Audi splitting up did this... Under the old
> system, Porsche didn't have to make nearly as much, and in fact, could even
> take a loss, so long as VW and Audi covered it (which they could have).
> We're now at a point where Porsche prices have gone out of control (so much
> that Porsche recognizes it even, by lowering the 993 prices) and Porsche is
> losing money. This is certainly why the 986 is coming out, but a C-88?
> Should Porsche make little cars with little power? Maybe a joint venture
> between VW and Porsche like the one that produced the 914 and the 912E?

What split-up?  What old system?  Porsche is, and has always been, an
independent company.  The only association with VW-Audi (other than
design/engineering work which they also do for many other companies)
was the marketing agreement for a shared Porsche+Audi dealer network
here in the U.S.

Porsche (the car manufacturing "division") anticipates breaking even
next fiscal year, with a small profit to be turned the year after.  It's
products include the 911, 928, and soon the Boxster.

Porsche (the engineering consulting "division") turns a tidy profit
every year...  It's "products" include the *design and engineering
services* for the C-88, along with all the other engineering/design/
development *services* they provide to (probably) hundreds of other
companies.

- -- 
mike
mjt@adc.com

I own a `77 911S that has a transmission problem.

transmission to a local PCA`er, who does extensive motor & transmission work,
to repair.  First gear was extremely elusive and 2nd was very notchy and would
grind at higher rpm shifts.  He said he replaced 5 syncro`s, 2nd & 3rd dog
teath, 2nd gear operating sleeve, gaskets and seals.  Parts & Labor $1200.
Now with a totally rebuilt motor and a supposedly rebuilt tranny, I`m ready for
some `next to new` performance.  NO  WAY.  The motor is runs great but the
transmission is EXACTLY the same.  The clutch is new and a new short shifter.
AND, to make a bad situation worse, now I can`t find this guy.
Is there something else in the transmission that could cause the problems or
does it sound like this guy stiffed me and really did nothing but take my money
?

Mike	 `77 911S, Zermat Silver

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 12:13:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sanjay Nasta <sanjay@bga.com>
Subject: Dead 944S Solved

Just wanted to let everyone know that I solved the problem...part of the
timing belt is stripped.  It was difficult to spot since it was against a
pulley usually.  Now, I've been told that there is a high likelihood of the
valves being bent.  How difficult is it to do a valve job?  (I completed a
clutch job pretty successfully...slowly but succesfully to give you an idea
of mechanical skills).  Is there a way to test that valves are bent?

Sanjay@bga.com

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 13:08:25 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911 74 2.7 Starter--Wanted

> Are the upgraded starters worth the extra $$$'s??

If you're running 12:1 race motors, you bet. That extra couple of
HP the starter has makes a WORLD of difference cranking a monster
race engine on a cold test day. For a street car, see my usual
comments on "good race stuff is NOT good street stuff"...

Stan

radiator had a slightly larger core and therefore a different pressure 
rating was required?  i had recently changed the radiator on my '83 to 
the larger core variety (i did not replace the cap with the later type 
though), could this have caused the expansion tank to be put under too 
much pressure?  i think i'll change the tank anyhow (after 145K miles i 
think it has served me well!), but should i use the newer cap also?

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 14:56:18 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Aviation Gas



You all may have already discussed this stuff but I felt it was pertinent.

I have read that a car tuned properly to take advantage of increased octane
can see a performance increase of 1.5% from 87 to 93 octane.  

It has to do with the rate at which the fuel burns and at what point the 
flame front is initiated. The goal is to tune the engine for the specific
octane gas being used to hit Maximum Brake Torque (MBT) for a specific
engine speed and load condition.  The key is to develop the flame front so the 
cylinder pressure is peaking when the piston begins the power stroke.  The 
higher octane gases will keep burning as the piston travels to bottom dead
center.  That will keep the pressure in the cylinder higher through more of
the power stroke and more power will result.


So if the engine is not tuned for high octane gas, the flame front will not
be initated soon enough, take too much time to develop, and the fuel
will still be burning when the exhaust valves open.  This happened when 
a friend of mine used 110 octane gas in a motorcycle with chrome exhausts.
At the cylinder interface the chrome got discolored from heat and I assumed
it was because the gas was still burning.

A high octane gas burns slower than low octane gas and resists pre-ignition.

Any critiques or additional info is welcome

Jeff
Jpuzas@astro.ge.com

p

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 95 11:54:08 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  944 coolant sys question

...
>> rating was required?  i had recently changed the radiator on my '83 to 
>> the larger core variety (i did not replace the cap with the later type 
>> though), could this have caused the expansion tank to be put under too 
>> much pressure?  i think i'll change the tank anyhow (after 145K miles i 
>> think it has served me well!), but should i use the newer cap also?

I don't know about which cap to run, but the expansion tank probably
simply wore out.  I replaced mine a few years back after it simply
started to expand during long drives.  Change the tank before it
springs a leak and causes a problem.

Remember to bleed the cooling system when you're done, just to be
sure.

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 13:03:52 -0600
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: Blue RTV in 912 Sump

>Dear Chris:
>
>came from. If it's just blobs or gobs of blue stuff without any definite
>curvature  (or round cross section), then it's probably excess Blue RTV.
>Unfortunately, Blue RTV is a Trademark of a Turkey. Especially excess RTV 
>of any color.

Well, yes. I looks it would be described as 'blobs' of stuff. I took a 
sample to a friend who identified it as Blue RTV. I took the valve covers 
off and found more. I'm taking Stan's advice and cleaning the covers off to 
replace the RTV with the proper gasket. (there was no gasket under the valve 
covers, just lots of beaded RTV)

>     As  to the overheating- check your High Speed Timing just for funsies.
>If it's 40 degrees advanced  (or 20 degrees), that's the problem. Check fan
>belt for proper tension (not way loose). Check (with engine OFF!) for
>rag/paper towel in fan. And check to see if heater boxes flaps are open
>rather than shut. 

Good ideas there. The rag/paper towel lodged in impeller would work nicely 
to help overheat the Porsche engine. I hope (meekly) to find this as it 
would save having to tear the engine apart.

>KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
>The Maestro
>P.S. The hand on the oil filter is a pretty good indicator. If you can hold
>your hand on it, its NOT running too hot. If the thermal radiation from the
>can tess you it would  be stupid to touch it, it probably IS running too >hot.

We'll no I can barely touch it after I've run it for a while. I'm going to 
check all of the above this evening if my wifey lets me. 

Can you check if I did my math right: 32 degrees max advance would be 
located radially 38.5 mm to the left of the TDC mark ?

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 14:09:13 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Aviation Gas

> You all may have already discussed this stuff but I felt it was pertinent.

Yup.

> I have read that a car tuned properly to take advantage of increased octane
> can see a performance increase of 1.5% from 87 to 93 octane.  
> 
> It has to do with ...

What you just said was "if you use higher octane gas, you can advance
the spark further because it is less likely to knock; if you've built
the rest of the engine to take advantage of that then you can make
more power".

Racing 101. More or less. Actually, Engines 101. Racing 101 is "bring money".

Stan

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 15:18:10 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: Subject: 911 alignment

Hi,

- -----------
Thanks for the advice. I think I'll survive with my neg 1 degree. It seems
like the best solution of all is simply to rebuild the front suspension if
is all that important. The only parts that seem to be involved are the ball
joints at the end of the strut, the strut themselves, and the a-arm
bushings. I'll probably get around to it  in the next decade or so...
- --------

Don't forget the A-Arms themselves. The bushings can't really
be replaced. The best way to do this job is to get a whole
front suspension from a late model car and bolt it in.
This is also cheaper. You will only need to modify the
sway bar mount by cutting off the late model one and
welding on a tab for the old (good) style one.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 95 15:35:49 EST
From: Lee Walczak <lwalc@mcgraw-hill.com>
Subject: Re: Shoes for driver's ed

     Tracy:
       All you need is loose cotton clothing--long-sleeved shirt, long 
     trousers. If the weather is cool, I'd advise a turtleneck--gets drafty 
     with the window open at 120 mph!
       Re shoes: *Don't* wear tennis shoes--the soles are too thick. Sperry 
     Topsiders or other thin-soled deck shoes are ideal. Topsiders tend to 
     get a little sloppy, width-wise, so if you really want to splurge, try 
     a pair of Simpson racing shoes--around $90 bucks. They work best with 
     thin socks, because the Nomex lining makes them hot.
       I pass this one to you as a grizzled veteran of one driving event. 
     Have fun...
       Lee / Wash., D.C.
