Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 15:59:28 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: RE: Aviation Gas


Stan,
Advancing the timing to the point of knock and backing off does not maximize
brake torque.  My point was:  to do it correctly, you need a dyno and a lot
of time for very minor performance gains;  therefore, it is not really 
worth the aggravation.  Furthermore, the chances of getting it right are slim. 


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 95 13:02:43 PDT
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Steel Turbo Flares

P-Netters,
	I am posting this for a friend.  If anyone out there has
access to any or knows of their whereabouts, please e-mail
me directly or my friend (his email address is below).

> 
>       Several years ago I helped a Porsche owner friend of mine 
>       resurrect a badly maintained 911, it was rusted thru at the

Date: 12 Apr 95 16:38:20 EDT
From: Mark Doyle <MDOYLE@laitram.mhs.compuserve.com>
Subject: Finding Vacuum Leaks

Many people have expressed interest in the smoke method I used to find a 
vacuum leak, so here goes.



Equipment needed:

Compressed air source regulated down to 3 PSI

Canister with hose connection (I used a disposable medical type vacuum 
canister that is used to suck out and contain body fluids.)

A few cigarettes.



Seal off the intake system as early in the air flow stream as possible.  
I removed the air flow sensor and put a 3 inch diameter cup in it's 
place.  This isolated everything downstream of the airflow sensor.

Connect one hose connection on the canister to the 3 PSI air source.

Connect the other hose connection on the canister to one of the vacuum 
hoses connections on the throttle body.

Verify that the intake system is pressurized by loosening a boot or 
something else connected to the intake system.  All vacuum connections 
are not connected directly to the intake system.  The oil fill cap works 
fine on a 911.

Now that everything is connected and ready,  take the canister lid off 
and insert a lit cigarette (filter end first) into the canister outlet 
hose connection from the bottom side of the lid.  Replace the lid.  The 
cigarette is now inside the canister and all the airflow is passing thru 
the lit cigarette then into the intake system.  It may take a minute for 
the clean air to be purged before the smoke will appear.  You may have to 
use a mirror to pinpoint the leak if smoke appears from the back side of 
the engine (911 problem only).

It worked for me.



I am still hoping that one of the engine experts will give me some 
advice.  Here are my original questions:

I have a leak at the point where the left camshaft endplate mates to the 
cam housing.  It can be seen by removing the #1 spark plug connector.  
There is also oil seepage below that point on the under side of the 
engine.

Is there some easy fix for this problem?

Can I fix this without removing the engine?

If I use the same sprocket shims, will I have to check the sprocket 
alignment?

If I am careful to set the engine at TDC and mark which hole the cam 
timing pin is in, do I have to check the cam timing when everything is 
back together?



Mark Doyle

'85 911




------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 16:50:03 -0400
From: asdunn@nytimes.com (Ashley Dunn)
Subject: re: 911 alignment

I don't have sway bars on my car (comfort group 71). What year suspension
will fit in my 71 with no modification? What is the difference between old
and new suspensions? Thanks. Ashley.


>Don't forget the A-Arms themselves. The bushings can't really
be replaced. The best way to do this job is to get a whole
front suspension from a late model car and bolt it in.
This is also cheaper. You will only need to modify the
sway bar mount by cutting off the late model one and
welding on a tab for the old (good) style one.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S
Ashley Dunn
Metro reporter
The New York Times
wk. (212) 556-7422
fax (212) 556-7615
e-mail: asdunn@nytimes.com

flag are the only moments of glory most drivers get and many regions have
decided not to do this. Sure it is an extra 5 minutes per seesion, but that
glory was earned by the driver. 

This was one of the big thrills I got when racing one summer in the NEDiv.

The only Aviation fuel I have seen that will work in an internal combustion
engine at my local airport is 100 octane low-lead. Great stuff, makes my
944turbo really happy. BTW- they are not allowed to pump directly into the car
(ok to pump into a can or if the car is on a trailer-- highway tax issue)

Date:         Wed, 12 Apr 95 16:56:06 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re:      944 Thermostat failure


Oh let me TELL you about that Snap Ring!  It don't come out easy
without the proper tool!  If you don't have the proper tool, don't
even try. It took me 4 days working 3 hours each day to get that
thing out. I had bought two different SRPs. The problem was that
the pins were too small.  Working from below, I rotated the snap
ring until the holes were at the top of the water pump. This can
be done with a small phillips screwdriver.  I could manage to
compress the snap ring, but when I tried to pull out, the pliers
would slip off.  Finally after 4 days, I got one edge of the snap
ring out of the groove. I used a screwdriver to slowly work around
the ring and ease it out.  I had trouble catching up to the Snap-On
salesman. He drives around in a van. That's the only way to get
Snap-On tools in this town, track him down.

Make sure you use a thermostat from Porsche!  I bought one at an
auto parts store. It was only $6 and didnt look too robust. So, I
went to Porsche and got one ($35). The gasket is pre-installed on
the Porsche thermostat and it looks MUCH meatier.

Tracy, I would definitely get this fixed before going on the track.
I was fortunate enough to have had the temp select on heat and that
hose rupture.  I feel the damage would have been worse (head gasket)
if that hose didn't rupture.

Darren
'87 944S Indischrot

P.S. - I hope I don't have to replace the output heater core hose
       anytime soon. That thing looks like a PITA to replace!...
       not to mention it cost $35.

Date:         Wed, 12 Apr 95 17:30:57 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: '87 944 cam belt tensioner

On Tue, 11 Apr 1995 22:20:44 -0700 (PDT) you said:
>On Tue, 11 Apr 1995 Hultgrenho@aol.com wrote:
>
>> This whole proceedure is covered by Technical Bulletin # 8820 "Camshaft Belt
>> Adjustment" complete with handy pictures.  Of course the bulletin is dead
>> wrong, in that I don't believe you can replace the cam belt without removing
>> the dreaded crankshaft pulley which is torqued to about 350 million ft-lbs.
>
>I had no problem inserting the cam belt into the gap between the balance
>gear on the crank and the rear belt cover. Slide one edge in upwards at a
>diagonal in the centre and gradually push the belt in as you work away
>from the centre. But then again, I have an '86 944 so it might be different.
>
>Joe '86 944

I also had no problem sliding the new belt in. I did practice several
times with the old belt to get my technique down. I removed the
tensioner too as I replaced that roller along with the others.
THAT was very difficult to get back on.

By the way, my service manual says to just loosen the nut and the bolt
and then retighten. It says nothing about about moving the tensioner
while the nut/bolt is loosened.  Is this procedure something new?

Darren

>another option (let me qualify that: in the sub $150 catagory), I'd

Ignitor on 1/13 and 2/8 this year.  I've e-mailed you those postings
privately. 

I use the Ignitor with a Bosch blue coil and it works great.  I advise you
to stay away from Jacobs products.

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 18:41:21 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sanjay Nasta <sanjay@bga.com>
Subject: Dead 944:  Summary of Possible Problems

 Hi,
    I figured out what was wrong with my 87 944S thanks to the help of some
 people on here (thanks Lee)....it was basically a stripped timing belt (lost
 about 2-3" of teeth).  However, a lot of people have been rather helpful in
 suggesting different causes so....I thought I'd post some of these in a
 summary format.
> 
> 1.  Stripped or broken timing belt (costly as heck..the valves bend...cost
> lotsa $$$'s)  My mechanic is recommending that timing belts be replaced
> religiously on the S/S2 at 30K miles.  
> 
> 2.  Fuel Pressure Regulator.  Zim's was saying that they have been having a
> rash of Fuel Pressure Regulator failure's lately.  This device basically
> keeps a certain pressure (approx 29 psi I believe) in the fuel line.  BTW
> it's rather easy to check since they have a rather nice access point on the
> fuel rail.
> 
> 3.  Fuel Pump Relay (G5 I believe).  This is another common failure point. 
> I did a preliminary check on mine with a meter (for obvious defects) and
> then swapped one out from a friend's car.
> 
> 4.  Numerous sensor failures.  The Haynes manual actually has a decent set
> of tests...didn't get this far so I can't comment.
> 
> 5.  Ignition Coil Failure
> 
> 6.  Fuel Pump Failure--You can test it similar to the Fuel Pressure
> Regulator.
> 
> 7.  Fuse--Couple of fuses do control the injectors, the DEE, etc.  easy to
> check.
> 
> 8.  DEE Failure:  I haven't found a good way to check this.  It's a god
> awful expensive part (btw its the control computer).
> 
> Thanks everyone for your help!
> 
> 
> --SAA29282.797730009/zoom.bga.com--
> 
> 


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 20:06:52 -0400 (EDT)

Following are Porsche cameos:

the Honky Tonk Bar, a black Porsche 911 is pulling in. It's only a 2 second
scene.

In Bad Boys 'Watcha gonna do?', the previews show a black 993 being driven.
Whether it was stolen (in the movie) or what, I dunno...

 -Derek Cahill

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 20:07:37 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: RE: Early 911 License Plate Panel

In message Tue, 11 Apr 1995 11:32:51 -0700 (PDT),
  stevew@tamri.com (Steve Watson)  writes:

> I was wondering how the rear license plate on early 911s was attached from
> the factory.  The rear panel on my car has a couple holes that look like
> they were punched through with a screw driver.  Does this panel normally
> come without holes for the license plate bracket?  If so my panel must
> have been defective.
I believe that there were either 3 or 4 'dimples' where the spots for holes
to be drilled were clearly marked for different countries (the tall thinly
spaced ones being for US models, the short, but wide for German, etc.)
The dealer generally would use a drill or self-tapping screw (ack!) to put
the hole for the license plate in for the first customer. If your car came
from another country, the holes may be there from that country.

Which all reminds me... our license plates are no good now... gr.
 -Derek Cahill

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 18:01:23 -0700
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: re: Bargain Bosch H4's

>I think the name of the company is ZIMS (sp?).  I believe they sell 
H4's for 
>about $60/pair.  I have been thinking about getting a set myself so if 
anyone 
>has ordered H4's through them let me know how it went.

Hella has their H4 conversion kits DOT-approved now, and should be 
available from any decent sports car accessory shop, as well as any 
place that carries Hella foglights, etc. It's called the Hella Vision 
Plus, and they call them HB2 bulbs, but don't let that fool you - 
they're H4s. I have a set in my 914, and they're very nice. They come 
with 55/60, which I believe is the brightest you can use "legally".

So, anyways, stop into your local Pep Boys, or Nat'l Auto, or Wheels, 
or wherever you go to buy your motor oil, and see if they have them...

- -- 
| Jeff Kyle                                    "Memo to myself:           |
| jeffk914@ix.netcom.com                        Do the dumb things        |
| Scottsville, NY, USA                                  I gotta do."      |
| "Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914                       -They Might Be Giants |

Porschephiles #1323                         Thu Apr 13 02:00:24 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 12 Apr 95 18:23:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: 914 conversion


>Do any of you have any experience
>with the 914 small block conversion?  I know, savage insult to Zuffenhausen
>and all that, but it would be interesting....

I rode in one a few weeks ago....and found it to be completely
disgusting.  Fast, yes.....very fast - and not that expensive.

End of pros....now the cons:

You lose the front trunk to a radiator and fans.

You will eventually be like this owner and the only reason
I met him was because he brought his car to my mechanic
friend's place (where I'm working on my 914-6 project),
because his transmission was screwed.  The engine
tore it apart.

CV joints break.

He had also installed the ugly (IMHO) body kit that
Renegade will package with their V8 conversions.  This
body kit involves removing so much of the structural
parts of the 914 that the body creaks and cracks all
the time.  Water leaks into the passenger compartment
and the bodywork is coming away from the remaining
metal bits on the car.

Slightly impaired handling due to engine weight and
placement in the car.

The usual "purist" views.

I got this info from the owner - these are not my assumptions.
He liked the cheap horsepower, but disliked the resulting
"price".

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 21:26:24 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jan Ringnalda <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: Re: '87 944 cam belt tensioner

Guys (& Gals):
	I agree with Joe, the cam belt can be put on with the dreaded crankshaft 
pulley in place, however great care must be taken not to kink the belt as you try 
to feed it gently around the pulley into its place.  When fitting the new belt 
start here!
	Also to help upon removing the old belt, pull it out of this confinement 
last, so that you can remember the reverse procedure.  I would recommend fitting 
the old belt a few times as practice...and remember the old belt is more flexible!
Cheers,  Jan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 21:55:31 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jan Ringnalda <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: Re: Update on dead 944S

Sanjay,
	Yes there is a test you can do to see if the valves are not bent; it 
involves putting on a new timing belt and doing a compression test.  There is no 
easy way to check if the valves are straight or not, however what you can do is 
remove the camshaft housing and do a visual on the height of the valve stems.  
Since the engine is at that point pretty well down to the head, depending on the 
mileage it would be false economy not to lap the valves in and replace the valve 
stem seals anyway.  The whole job is quite straightforward, and if you have done a 
clutch on one of these I'd have thought you will have no major setbacks.
	The replacing belt idea may not be that bad, but make sure you get the 
valve timing correct.
Cheers,  Jan

its worth doing . . .  etc.

Date: Wed, 12 Apr 1995 23:39:52 -0400
From: Mgibson54@aol.com
Subject: Re: 930 vs 911

Jonathan,  I've owned both and found the 930 to be just about the most fun
that can be had in a production car.  Tractable around town, a/c, good
stereo, and with a few easy mods ie susp, carbon pads, adjustable boost(be
careful!), it was the fastest track car I've owned. The 911 is a great car,
but not as much fun.  Maintence costs will be higher for the 930,  but IMHO
well worth it.  I wouldn't hesitate if I were you.  Another downside is that
I"ve been stopped by police just to check license.  Never happened in any
911.  
Just read Daryl's note on 930.  I didn't mind the 4 spd.  I didn"t mind the
boost.  Loved the brakes.  Sold the car.  What can I say?

mark

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 00:32:16 -0400 (EDT)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Re: Autothority Mass Flow for 3.2 Carrera (fwd)


Stan Hanks wrote:
> > How about just the chip?

[lots of good advice from Stan deleted]

> The use of "special chips" was made popular originally by two things:
> 
> * initial shipment of chips that significantly mis-guessed about the 
>   prevailing quality of US gas, so a chip with different assumptions
>   performed better
> 
> * turning up the boost on 944 Turbos. FOr details, see the archives under
>   "Head Gasket, Blown"
> 
> Porsche in general doesn't give up anything to anyone. Once it is established
> that there is a better way to do something with their cars, it becomes
> further researched, documented and part of The Way. Typically with more
> improvements, BTW.

So Stan, how about using the latest Porsche chip and/or engine computer 
in your car? Would that make a difference?

On a related note, I've noticed that many cars have been losing power 
recently due to the tighter emissions standards, e.g. M-B 500E going from 
322hp to 315hp (I think). Has Porsche had a really clean engine to begin 
with, or have they somehow tweaked their engines to perform cleaner _and_ 
better each year? The 911 hp numbers haven't changed from year to year, 
in the 964 and 993 generations.

Tracy,

valuable feeling plus the wide jobbies can hit more pedals then you would
like. I prefer Docksiders, and some folks splurge on the Simpson (or other)
real race shoes.
  Don't forget to take clothing for both warm and cold weather, including
rain gear.  After spending more than one year opening event there we have
had everything from snow to blistering days.  One constant seems to be wind,
and lots of it.  Better a few extra things than a very uncomfortable weekend.

Porschephiles #1324                         Thu Apr 13 12:41:57 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 01:58:23 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Autothority Mass Flow for 3.2 Carrera (fwd)

> So Stan, how about using the latest Porsche chip and/or engine computer 
> in your car? Would that make a difference?

Sure. If you updated the rest of the engine too... It's not like you
walk into the dealer and see "Turbo 95" software release that's coming Real
Soon Now.... they work where it does them the most good and that's the
current platform. On a related note, there *HAVE* been mechanical 
changes in the 3.2 -> 3.6 -> 3.8 progression that are a direct result
of things noted in programming the EFI.

> On a related note, I've noticed that many cars have been losing power 
> recently due to the tighter emissions standards, e.g. M-B 500E going from 
> 322hp to 315hp (I think). Has Porsche had a really clean engine to begin 
> with, or have they somehow tweaked their engines to perform cleaner _and_ 
> better each year? The 911 hp numbers haven't changed from year to year, 
> in the 964 and 993 generations.

Two things there, first, Porsche has done an EXCEPTIONAL job of meeting
tighter emissions standards *and* getting more HP. Second, note that 
there is a 0.2 liter increase in the 993 ffrom the 964...

Finally, Porsche claimed HP is usually *WAY* low from actually measured
if you pop the engine out of a new car and put it on a calibrated dyno.
Specmanship, most likely. Avoiding liability issues by claiming more
performance than the engine delivers, also possible.

Stan

playing tricks on me again?

Date: 13 Apr 95 14:49:00 +0000
From: swellen@intgp1.att.com
Subject: more on tyres

I agree more scientific testing of these tyres may disagree with my
views in which case I bow to science. However if enough other people
express similar views on a tyre then maybe the experts are wrong.

I do no rotation and have only needed tracking once in the last five
years. I have also not needed balancing accept when new tyres are fitted.
Tread depth (visual) and pressures checked every fortnight. Tyre depth 
measured and recorded every couple of months unless visual checks found
anything noticeable. I have stuck to factory recommended pressures within
+ 1psi, never below. All tyres have worn across very evenly for both cars.

Porsche 944 Lux  1985  Tyres 215/60 all round, wheels 7J and 8J forged.

1) Pirelli P600s. Despite Pirelli's reputation a very ordinary
tyre with ok grip in dry, less in wet verging on inadequate.
Average breakaway characteristics. Wear rate was good at approx
30,000 a set. Neither noisy or quiet, same comment for ride.

2) Yokohoma A-008Ps. Much better tyre with fabulous grip in the
dry and reduced but still very good in the wet. Gentle on the
limit allowing panic free drifts (usually all four wheels). Front's
capable of 18,000 miles, rears 11,500. Noise and ride average as 
with the P600s.

3) Dunlop 8000s. Not so much grip as Yoko's in dry but even so
more than adequate. Grip little reduced by the wet and probably
better than the Yokos. However breakaway was a little sudden.
Car sold but it looked like a mileage of 25-30,000 was possible.
Noise was slightly better than the A-008Ps or P600s, ride average
again.

Porsche 944 2.7    1989  205/55 ZR 16 (f) and 225/50 ZR 16 (r)
			   Wheels 7J and 8J, forged "flat" alloys.

1) Dunlop D40-M2s. Good grip in dry, gentle on the limit. Grip
also good in the wet even if a little lower. However these tyres
were skittish in the wet even if they didn't actually misbehave,
i.e. no hairy moments. Robbed me of confidence however. Mileage
was close to 35,000 as a guess as they were part worn when bought.
So so ride and fairly noisy.

2) Pirelli P-Zero Systems. Excellent grip in the wet and dry, too
early to say about on the limit handling. Slightly better than
average noise (so the exhaust note is now clearer!) and slightly
better than average ride. Too early for mileage estimates.
Considering the high UK price neither better or worse than expected.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 11:19:04 EDT
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Aviation Gas

The optimization pf fuels is done to meet operating conditions.  Aviation
gas is optimized so that it won't boil at high altitude.  It works in
a cold engine becuase the dual magneto ignition has a very hot spark
at starting.

Automotive gas contains highly volatile compounds (varied by season)
that help cold starting.  The FAA worries a lot about whether this
might boil at altitude and has generally not allowed it to be used
for aviation even where it has high enough octane.

Yes, higher octane has a slower flame front.  That is basically what
octane does.  This can cause problems if it gets too slow.

Recommendation forget running avgas in your car.  Forget jet fuel as
well unless you have a deisel.

Rick Dill

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 10:38:35 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Tool to adjust Bosch CIS injection.

>Qustion: what type of tool is required to adjust the mixture screw on the
>Bosch CIS System and where could one purchase such an item.

        It's something like a long, long-handled Allen wrench.  Sorta.
Has a T- or loop-shaped handle at the top.  Available at AutoMashin',
for the usual rates, and other places.  Locally, Bugformance in Sunny-
vale has it (for de water-cooled VW's, dontcha see) so I'd guess that
large chain auto-parts stores would as well.

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 11:39:56 -0400

Subject: Re: Seats  for a 914

Sorry for the bandwidth waste, fellow netnicks; but would the USMA Cadet,

responded thusly, please email me at bartonc@infi.net?

is 2690 lbs.

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 08:16:39 PST
From: radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
Subject: The Smoking Method + 914 stub axle

          Regarding the smoking method offered as a way to find vacuum
          leaks:

          I have used the method for several years now and have had
          great success.  I got hooked on the method when a bunch of
          the members of my car club showed me what a cool method it
          was, and hey, I really wanted to fit in with these guys! 
          The only problems I have had are minor:  the engine vacuum
          hoses can get a rather unpleasant smell and a coating of tar
          and nicotine, so I use menthol lights; I also occasionally
          get a slight engine cough, but I'm sure it is related to
          some other fuel injection problem, not the smokes.  I have
          heard from some folks that this smoke method can lead to
          serious problems down the road, but I have a pretty new car
          (so why worry) and also my Grandpa has used this method all
          his life and had no problems... well, except for needing a
          head replacement and a rebuilt carb. 

          BTW, the article didn't discuss how to seal the leaks once
          they are found -- the obvious choice to me is to use a
          nicotine patch.  Seals it right up and even seems to make
          the engine a bit peppier!
          (Sorry gang... someone had to do it....)

          Now, P-phile stuff.  I still can't get the stub axle out. 
          Someone must have a magic method (involving no smoke). 
          Please help!

          -Tim
          '70, '71, '74 and '75 914


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 11:43:15 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: "87" 944 handling & sway bars


My 944 came stock with 21.5 mm bar up front and none in the rear.  I added
a 14mm to the rear.  After playing around with the tire pressures 34psi front
and rear with A008P's it still understeers just a tad but I am satisfied.

My dad and I switched cars this week.  He has an "87" 928.  It really corners
flat and feels like it can generate more grip with Dunlop SP 4000's a Z rated
all season.  Although I've yet to slide the 928 to see exactly where the limit
is, it feels better.  I'm guessing it has to do with stiffer roll bars?
I'm thinking that I might like to go to stiffer bars front and rear on mine
but don't know if it will be a waste of money.  I've always heard "loose is
fast" and I know that the stiffer the rolls bars get, you move further 
away from a true independent supension and you don't do as well around
a bumpy turn.  My car has a lot of body roll compared to the 928.

Has anyone put the 25.4 mm hollow bar up front and 18 in the rear on an 
otherwise stock supension "87" 944?  

What are the trade-offs?

George do you have a set and how much?

Any opinions,criticisms or information is welcome.

Jeff 
jpuzas@astro.ge.com
 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 11:49:48 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: F.A. Porsche-signature Boat

In the June/July, 1989, issue of Boating Product News, there is an article by
Mindy Leaf describing a soon-to-be-introduced Porsche Design speedboat.  It
is a 27-footer, powered by a marine version of the 302 c.i.d 928 S4 engine
with U.S. Marine Jet's Dominator water-jet drive.  Kineo, U.S.A., Ltd.
planned to produce the boat at Tempest Yachts on North Miami Beach's famed
powerboat row.  Testing of the prototype was apparently underway at the time
the article was written, and was being conducted at U.S. Marine Jet's
Dominator plant in Hugo, Oklahoma.

Performance figures included 0-50 in about 10 seconds, planing speed attained
in less than 3 seconds, and a top speed of 60 mph.  The water-jet drive
(unusual on a boat this size) supposedly allowed "sports-car-type handling
ease," while the engine "boasts half the weight and twice the fuel efficiency
of standard cast-iron engines".  The hull was a deep-vee, hand-laid
fiberglass. with a windshield that swept around the cockpit.  Seating was for
four (with flip-up seats for standing).  There was a set-in transom door and
retractable swim platform.  Below decks, a double lounge finished in leather
covered the portable head.  Introduced in silver with bright yellow
upholstery, a variety of colors to match Porsche cars was to follow.

The boat was to be furnished with a "super-sleek Porsche Design trailer
having built-in spare tire and tool box".  The combination - boat and trailer
 - was to be offered only through select Porsche dealers (required to purchase
a minimum of five boats), with special deals to be offered on
car-boat-trailer packages. It was to debut in early fall, 1989.

A photograph accompanied the article.

Anyone ever actually see this interesting new venture by Porsche Design?

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee

1965 356SC
1988 924S

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 16:51:26 +0100
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: 86 991 3.2 Idle Question.


"Hunting" between 800 and 1200 RPM on a 3.2 Carrera
on cold start is normal. There seems to be a direct
relationship between the ambient temp and the period
of hunting. The DME is fiddling with the mixture
but cuts back the full rich in a not very progressive manner
I suppose. The 1500 to 6000 RPM hunting Armand reported is 
grossly abnormal and needs fixing. In fact 6000 RPM on 
a stone cold engine is not a Good Thing at all
and may result in accelerated wear.

Regards

Ben

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 11:22:53 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: PCR's

        Just got the Parade packet yesterday.  Spent most of the evening
reading it (instead of working on my engine--oops!).
        So, is anyone from the Parade Rules Committee (whatever) online
here so's I can bitch and moan about the Parade Competition Rules (PCR's)?
        Three levels of "preparedness": Production, Improved, Modified.
Free in Production are:  Springs/torsion bars, sway bars, spring plates,
exhaust after the head (no open exhaust), any DOT tire, wet-sump oil traps
and deep sumps, oil coolers, etc.  Okay, I figured I wasn't going to be
competitive--my car is box-stock (except that oil trap).  However, a tire
with a circumference of less than 74.25" bumps me up into Improved, where
LSD's, up to 120 cc displacement, flares, extra-wide tires, etc, etc, etc,
are allowed!
        Sanity and Math check, please:
74.25" circumference / pi = 23.635" diameter - 15" rim = 8.635" sidewall
(total) / 2 sidewalls per diameter = 4.317" sidewall * 25.4 mm/in =
109.658 mm sidewall.  110 mm sidewall is a 205/55-15, a 195/60-15, a
175/60-15, a 175/65-15, etc...  Ouch.  You mean I gotta go back to the
60-series?  That's depressing!  Oh well, maybe I'll just be the slowest
car in I1.  Only 1 point in the C column--tires 2" too small.  Sigh.
        Piss and moan, bitch and whine.
        Oh, the tire sizes are pretty similar for most of you pre-SC 911
folks as well!  And maybe even 356'es...
        So, does anyone have a set of four 205/55-15 BFG R1's or 008 RS's
+ rims (4-bolt) they want to lend/rent me for Parade?  Even 195/60's!
        Class, schmass!  I'll just get out there and RUN!

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

> the line to produce the established HP of the model?  Because of this,
> Porsche (and probably BMW & M-B as well) tends to under-rate their engines,
> to account for any manufacturing variations.  Anyone else heard this, or is
> my brain playing tricks on me again?
> 

If there are any tricks being played, they are effecting my brain too...

On my factory tour last March, the tour guide stated that German law
requires each engine to produce at least 99% of the rated HP.

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 11:00:28 PDT
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Re: Re[2]: 914 conversion

Tracy M Nelson says:
> 
> "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu> fired off:
>     Excerpts from mail: 13-Apr-95 Re[2]: 914 conversion by "GFORCE"@cccpp.com 
>     > Not true if you use the aluminum heads.
>     >                     
>     > I've seen a 914 with a all aluminum Buick V8 (318, I think it was), owner 
>     > claimed that the V8 weighted less the then original 4.
>     
> 	I think you're thinking of the 215.... which became a rover engine
>     after a while and continues today in 4.2 liter (I think) trim in the new
>     Range Rover.
> 
> I think G.'s got it right -- it was the 318, which later went on to become a
> rover engine and became the powerplant of the TR-8 (nasty little car).  A
> friend of mine has one (the engine, not a TR-8), it's amazing.  A different
> friend has a TR-8; it's amazing too!
> 
> -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

Think again.  Nate is correct, the engine started in 1962 with the Buick
Wildcat, and continued with GM until 1964 where is was turbocharged in some
models.  GM then sold the design and equipment to Rover Group, who used it 
first in the 3500 sedan (from the displacement of 3.5 litres) then in the
TR-8, and finally in a series of supercar like TVR's and the Range Rover.

Today it is still available in 3.9l, 4.2l and 4.5l versions.

It started out as that all aluminum 215 inch however.  There is a 318 cu in
V8 out there, but it is made by Chrysler, this is the venerable 5.2l iron
block that has been around for almost as long as there have been Dodge
Powerwagons.

OB Porschephiles:

If you are going to the parade this summer, and haven't sent me an RSVP, drop
me a note so you can join the P-phile gathering and meet the other
luminaries.

AL4-55  Intel, 5200 NE Elam Young Parkway, Hillsboro, OR 97124-6497

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 13:49:48 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: What's the best year for a 914?

>I've heard the '73 2.0 was the best and to avoid '75 & '76, though my '75
>doesn't seem to be that much different than my '70 to me.  What was the
>first year of the sideshifter tranny?

        73 was the first year for the sideshifter.  But a number of people
have upgraded earlier cars.  Also for some interior improvements--window
winders, for one.
        73 or 74 2.0 are the "best" ones.  But, of course, everyone knows
that so they're more expensive.  75 and 76 had extra smog crap on them
which reduced power and (possibly) engine life.  They also have the 5 MPH
bumpers which add a pretty fair amount of weight out at the ends of the
car, which is kinda where you don't want it.  It won't turn quite as nice-
ly, but it will tend to be a bit more stable, so....
        A non-California-emissions 73 1.7L could be nice as well.  A little
less power than the 75-76 2.0, but lighter.  Has the side-shifter and the
other interior impovements.  Avoid the CA edition 1.7, low compression
really robs it of power--it's weaker than the 1.8s...
        72 has the adjustable passenger seat (no more footrest!) and some
other interior improvements, with the tail-shifter and 1.7L motor.
        If you can find one with a front through-the-body swaybar, that's
good for handling.  The factory bar usually came with the rear bar and the
forged Fuchs wheels.  Alloy wheels are light and look nice.  Center con-
sole, vynil rollbar trim and chrome bumpers are (mostly) for looks.
        Here in the Bay Area, you can generally find *very* nice early
2.0s for $5K or less.  $3500 is not uncommon for good examples, but you
do have to look pretty hard.  Generally less for other 914s, except of
course for Sixes.  Up to $10K (asking) for total concours queens.

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 11:52:38 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Buicks of many alloys


ALright! Now we have a thread on Pubic Roadbastards. 

FYI, the Buick aluminum V-8 weighs in at 320 pounds, a lot more than a 
type IV 4-cylinder. But almost the same for a 911 6. 

The Buick can be enlarged to 4.5 liters in the aluminum form. In Iron
form, it can be had up to 340 cu in. (5.51l) with 300 inches being the 
most common size. 

Rover bought the Buick variation for use in 1965. The Olds version 
weighs more, but Brabham used a variant to win the first year of the 
3.0l F-1 championship (1966).

Kennedy Engineering makes all the parts for a sano conversion using 
either the alloy Buick V-8 or the devilish V-6 presently still being 
made. Think of a Grand National Buick Turbo V-6 in your 914. 

I prefer the 6 cylinders built at Porsche AG myself. (BIG Grin)

Jim Pasha

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 15:06:47 -0400

Tracy asked if there is a law in Germany that says carmakers have to meet the
advertised power.

Last I heard, that was true. There have been cases where unhappy customers
who couldn't make the advertised autobahn top speed took the cars back to the
dealerships and parked them there pending a refund.

Pete

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 15:06:51 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Early 911 license plates

Fred Hess asked about German license plate dimensions.

There are basically three dimensions: 200 x 340 mm, and 110 x 520 mm,
depending on whether you get two or one line of text. There is also a third
size, made just to fit American cars which are licensed in Germany (GIs
abandoning their Camaros etc.) Motorcycles and such obviously use a different
size standard.

Oval plates are not German license plates. They are export plates, intended
for cars bought for temporary use in Europe only before being exported. Oval
plates cannot legally be used by German nationals living in Germany, as this
is effectively (road) tax evasion. Oval plates are good for one year only, 6
months per country max, and cannot be renewed. Other German plates are good
as long as the car remains in the registration area. If it is sold and
re-registered in another town, it gets new plates. The first two letters
indicate what town. S is Stuttgart, LB is Ludwigsburg, M is Munich, GG is
Gross-Gerau, HB is Heilbronn, BB is Boeblingen, etc.

The new export plates are no longer oval, they are the long single-text-line
rectangular size with a red area on the left side.

Pete

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 15:52:18 EDT
From: RON OLSON  13-Apr-1995 1550 <olson_r@cho000.dnet.ge.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Thermostat tool

  Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com> writes:
  - I'm going to change the 944 thermostat as you all suggest.
  - Does any-one have a part # for the SRPs?   All I have is a 
  - 45deg and about an inch  long.  Is that an inch past the 45deg bend?

Jeff,

 I use Snap-on tool PR5645A ($20).  It's a 9" snap-ring pliers
 with .09" pins at 45deg.  Working from the underside, with the
 snap-ring holes up, the ring comes out easily (i.e. takes about a minute). 

Ron Olson (olson_r@cho.ge.com)

From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: RE Steering Wheel Resto


Steve-

The horn button comes off by turning it about 1/8 of a
turn (can't remember if its CW or CCW, but if it's like a bult it would 
be CCW).  It then pulls away easily.

You restore the worn black paint by applying new paint.

Check  Pano for AGLA's ad to find recovering costs.

 -Bob

> with U.S. Marine Jet's Dominator water-jet drive.  Kineo, U.S.A., Ltd.
> planned to produce the boat at Tempest Yachts on North Miami Beach's famed
> powerboat row.  Testing of the prototype was apparently underway at the time
> the article was written, and was being conducted at U.S. Marine Jet's
> Dominator plant in Hugo, Oklahoma.
> 
> Performance figures included 0-50 in about 10 seconds, planing speed attained
> in less than 3 seconds, and a top speed of 60 mph.  The water-jet drive
> (unusual on a boat this size) supposedly allowed "sports-car-type handling
> ease," while the engine "boasts half the weight and twice the fuel efficiency
> of standard cast-iron engines".  The hull was a deep-vee, hand-laid
> fiberglass. with a windshield that swept around the cockpit.  Seating was for
> four (with flip-up seats for standing).  There was a set-in transom door and
> retractable swim platform.  Below decks, a double lounge finished in leather
> covered the portable head.  Introduced in silver with bright yellow
> upholstery, a variety of colors to match Porsche cars was to follow.
>

> having built-in spare tire and tool box".  The combination - boat and trailer
> - was to be offered only through select Porsche dealers (required to purchase
> a minimum of five boats), with special deals to be offered on

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 16:58:15 -0500 (EST)
From: l anthony eller <leller@indiana.edu>
Subject: Alternative tire choices

Many of us have been caught spending big money for name-brand tires, only 
to find out that they are less than satisfactory.  They may handle like 
rails at first, but after a few hundred miles, they get loose.  Then 
10,000 miles later, they are as bald as Kojak.  Well, here are some tires 
that could change that.  I have no steak in this company, I have just had 
good luck with their tires, and would hope that you would too, if you try 
them.  

	COOPER Tires

1. COOPER Cobra VR50

	-V rated for speeds up to 149 mph.
	-Directional tread expels water effectively for excellent wet traction
	-Black serrated lettering style compliments today's sleek performance
	 cars.

2. COOPER Cobra GTV

	-V speed rated for up to 149 mph.
	-Non-directional tread
	-Designed and built to meet the challenge of performance tire demands.
	 Uniquely constructed to deliver excellent vehicle braking and
	 cornering control.  Strong traction during acceleration.
	-2+2+2 Construction : High-strength nylon overwraps under the tread
	 to provide additional support for the steel belts for excellent
	 tire handling.

3. COOPER Cobra GTH

	-H speed rated for speeds up to 130 mph.
	-Computerized block tread design channels water quickly to help
	 prevent traction loss.
	-Raised black letters enhance the appearance of the stylish
	 black performance sidewall.

4. COOPER Cobra GTS

	-S speed rated for speeds up to 112 mph.
	-Aggressive block tread offers excellent traction and low noise
	 levels for a smooth quiet ride.
	-Raised white-letter sidewalls match today's excitement cars.


I have used the Cobra GTH tires myself, and they beat the hell out of the 
Pirelli P6's I had before.  They handled better in wet and dry, they ran 
quieter, and they lasted longer.


                           
                                       Good Luck!

                                       Anthony Eller







Information courtesy of Cooper Tire & Rubber Co.

		        Findlay, OH 45840


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 17:58:57 EST
From: Neil.NW.Walker@ccmail.ae.ge.com
Subject: Tool to adjust CIS

The tool you require is a 3mm allen wrench. If you are intending to adjust a 911
the long tools seen in the catalogues are probably too long. My T handle wrench 
was too long for both my 930 and an 83 sc as it fouled the bodywork on trying to
insert it but the regular L shape worked fine.

DO NOT FORGET to remove the tool from the CIS before revving the engine as I am 
told that could be quite an expensive mistake!

neil.nw.walker@ccmail.ae.ge.com

Ps off to Mid Ohio tomorrow :-)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 17:16:00 PDT
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: Re: Tool to adjust Bosch CIS injection.


I have an '81 Rabbit and went to Sears and bought a T-handle allen wrench 
set.  It was long enough to do the job (~6 inches).  Its either a 3mm or a 
4mm wrench.

Just remember to take the tool out before you rev the engine to settle the 
mixture.

David B.

'81 Rabbit

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 18:02:53 EDT
From: edjones@tecnet1.jcte.jcs.mil
Subject: 944T Compression?

Hello out there,
 I've been reading the list for a few days now, and REALLY wish I had
discovered it prior to my most recent Porsche purchase. I've learned a
lot and I think my '88 944Turbo has a blown head gasket and I would
like comfermation before undertaking a repair. The symtoms are as
follows.
1. Slow coolant leak, .5 gal/1000 miles
2. Commpression #1-135, #2-113, #3-136, #4-141
3. yellowish gunk on the inside of the oil filler cap

The car is driven daily and gets to full operating temp. It has 56k
miles and has seen some track work.
What is the expected commpression? The #2 appears low.


How do you turn the motor over to TDC, I would like to do a leak down
test. Ever other car I've had you had easy access to the crank pully

bolt, not in this guy.
Speaking of leak down testing, I saw a message that that said his 944
had 6-8%, is this real? I've done a few checks and never seen any this
low, more like 25-35% for street and 10-12% on my ITC care.
TIA,
Ed Jones

'53 MGTD


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 15:18:52 -0700
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: What's the best year for a 914?

>	My brother is in the market for a used car to be driven locally. I 
>think I've talked him into a 914 :^)  What was the best year for them? 
>I've heard the '73 2.0 was the best and to avoid '75 & '76, though my '75 
>doesn't seem to be that much different than my '70 to me.  What was the 
>first year of the sideshifter tranny?   Set me straight so he won't be 
>disappointed.

AVOID the '75 and '76? The common factor I've heard is, when buying a 
Porsche, always buy as new as you can afford.

The obvious differences...
A '70s has a non-movable passenger seat...
Fuel pump right by the motor (hello, vapor lock!)...
IMHO ugly, stubby bumpers.
4.5" wide wheels!

And plenty of other stuff. The later ones are much nicer, have the 
side-shift tranny, better FI (L-jetronic vs D-jetronic), the best-looking 
bumpers (again, IMHO, though it DOES weigh more - but then again, it's 
safer, too), fuel pump in the front trunk, where it belongs... IMHO, nicer 
interior vinyls... And so on.

Oh, BTW, side-shift came in at '73, as I recall - the fuel pump in front 
trunk came into being in '75.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 17:20:41 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Autothority Mass Flow claims


>>Stan Hanks wrote:
>> Porsche in general doesn't give up anything to anyone. Once it is 
established
>> that there is a better way to do something with their cars, it becomes
>> further researched, documented and part of The Way. Typically with more
>> improvements, BTW.

 Taka wrote;
>On a related note, I've noticed that many cars have been losing power
>recently due to the tighter emissions standards, e.g. M-B 500E going from
>322hp to 315hp (I think). Has Porsche had a really clean engine to begin
>with, or have they somehow tweaked their engines to perform cleaner _and_
>better each year? The 911 hp numbers haven't changed from year to year,
>in the 964 and 993 generations.

   I was surprised to find out that the EPA does NOT test wide-open throttle
  operation; this is why even aftermarket Superchargers or Nitrous Oxide
  injection are able to get CARB certification and be fully street legal !

   Restrictions that hurt top horsepower may be in the catalytic converters,
  but most the direction there has been to get quicker operation (eg., by
  pre-heating the cat). Emmissions controls work best now at warm, light
  cruise and idle; cold operation and startup are targets of better control,
  but top end performance isn't restricted by the EPA at all, and the factory
  tunes the system for best reliable performance.

   In thge 70's smog requirements could be blamed for a bunch of ills. But
  because of the EFI technology forced by the smog laws, we've also benefited
  with much better driving, more powerful cars than we ever got from big
  carbs and lots of cubic inches.

          - Lee A.

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 15:28:33 -0700
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: What's the best year for a 914?

>that so they're more expensive.  75 and 76 had extra smog crap on them
>which reduced power and (possibly) engine life.  They also have the 5 MPH

Only the California cars had the smog stuff!!!

The 914s for the rest of the country had a straight pass-through where the 
cat would go, and my 914 carries the '73-'74 style exhaust. (Someone before 
had done it - I ended up replacing my exhaust bit at a time (muffler, THEN 
heat exchangers) so it's still that style. Works fine, though I had to pull 
back the rear valence a tiny bit - it was rubbing against the Bursch 
muffler, which was making a damn annoying squeaking noise.

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 18:55:59 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Curb Weight

Richard:

Sorry, no seats that I can part with.

The Factory Spec Book says that 914's weigh 2139 # (curb), but it doesn't
specify which model.  Early sales brochures rate the car at 1982#, but I
assume that's dry.

Whatever, your car will weigh differently, depending on optional equipment
(air cond?).  It probably has 22 years worth of crud built up on the belly,
plus any rustproofing that may have been applied in the US.

Pat Garvey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 18:58:52 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: Comments-951 cat pipe and steering wheel restoration

951 cat pipe - used ones tend to be rusty, the heat seems to wear them
down; new are < $200; try finding a nickle plated one, they stay nice for a
long time, I just don't know where to get them - cat pipes don't really
make a seat of the pants difference in power; just spools up the turbo a
little faster; neat time to create power-sapping exhaust leaks too; of
course it's good to remove the cat if you are tracking a chipped car and
want to avoid melting down the $1200 original. 
 
Steering wheel restoration - AGLA does crappy work. If you are considering
this route, you are better off ordering the kit and doing the work
yourself; you will do a better job

I have a 951 which isn't exactly the same, but I have the 30(hollow)/24mm

helped, much better than stock, but eventually you'll want a stiffer
suspension to go with the bars. I'm just shopping for a track suspension
now.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 19:29:58 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: 911 Driving (long again)

Thanks for all the positive E-mail on my explanation of driving a 911 at
Sebring.

One question asked was how I could go into a corner while under braking
without the rear spinning around.  Exactamundo!  I went into the corner WHILE
under braking.  Remember that we are working with the laws of physics.  In
the following example I am ignoring the front end of the car, but suffice to
say that it will respond opposite to the rear.

When you step on the brakes, the rear of the car will rise and after one
oscillation (thank G*D for sport shocks) settle at a new level.  It will stay
at this new level until you do something different....like lift off of the
brakes.  While the rear is rising, it will unload the tires, and make the car
very unstable.  If you should turn in while the rear is rising, you will most
assuredly spin.  Once the rear has risen to it's new level, it will once again
 place SOME weight, on the rear tires.  It is at this point that you can
GENTLY turn in to the corner.  The car will be stable, but the limiting
factor to your cornering power in the turn will definately be the grip of the
rear tires.  The more you slow down, the tighter the arc your car can take,
the more you can turn in.  Sounds perfect for that decreasing radius turn,
doesn't it.

Now you can shift to the gas.  As you lift off the brakes, the rear will
drop, increasing the weight on the rear tires, correspondingly increasing
their grip.  If the rear of the car is getting loose at all, once you lift
off the brakes, it will immediately hook up.  Now is the time to get on the
gas and accelerate out of the turn.  Now, even under full throttle, the rear
tires will be heavily loaded and develop all kinds of grip to handle all that
horsepower.  The rear will stay planted, unless you do something to disturb
all that grip, like LIFT, or tighten the steering!  Once again, it will be
spin city.  This is why you want to drive the proper line, so that you can
accelerate all of the way out of the corner.

I have found this technique to work well in large decreasing radius turns,
like turn 17 at Sebring, and Big Bend at Lime Rock.  The line that you
choose, either single apex or double apex, is up to you and your car.  Every
car will be different.  I like to set up mine with some understeer, so that I
can do more trailbraking.  Cars that are setup to oversteer will be much more
sensitive, and difficult, to drive in this fashion.

If any of you out there are finding this helpful, let me know and I will
continue.  See you on the track!

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 19:33:30 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: experimental brakes and ABS

Need some net wisdom;
I am doing some R&D for a brake company that is just getting into racing
brake pads. I used these pads for the first time at Sebring with good but not
great success. They stopped great with poor durability. I just got the pads
back to the engineer in charge of this project and the results are that I was
"frying" the front brakes and getting virtually no wear in the rears. This in
itself is not unusual for my car (an 89 944Turbo). What is unusual is it
seemed to be worse with these pads than any others I had used.
We discussed it for awhile before I mentioned that my rear tires were
different this year, being 275 x 40 x 17's. I have 245 x 45 x 16 in the
front. The rears are now taller than the front so obviously the rears are
doing less revolutions per mile than the fronts.
The engineer thought that I was screwing up the ABS by having this
arrangement since the ABS expects all tires to be going the same RPM's. He
suspects that the ABS was feeding more braking force to the fronts since they
were going faster than the rears.
I am at a loss as to how the ABS would compensate for this and even whether
this is a plausible explanation for the brake wear. BTW at the time of
Sebring the stock proportioning valve was in place.
I would appreciate any input.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:30 pm

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 16:41:42 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: "87" 944 handling & sway bars

I have an '86 944 (non-s, non-turbo) with the bars from the M030 package
on an '89 Turbo, but I also have the sport yellow Koni's and front springs
from the same car.  The set up works well for _very_ aggressive street 
driving (rallies), but I think the rear could be a little better.  I would
either go for larger torsion bars or an adjustable rear bar from a 968 
M030 package.  Other than the tail being just a bit looser than I like,
everything drives just perfectly!  BTW, I haven't lowered the suspension,
so I should even see some reasonable life out of the ball joints.

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com
'72 914 track car
'86 944 rally car (...but setup for the track...)

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 17:04:45 -0700
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re[2]: What's the best year for a 914?

     
Since I have a 75 I can speak with authority.  Don't buy one, especially if you
live in CA.  The smog stuff on a 75 is a real nightmare.  The air-injector 
nozzles strip out, the one-way valve on the air pump manifold goes out and the 
air pumps die from moisture.  The cars won't pass smog tests without a fully
functional air pump system.  I have owned my 75 since 78, and to be honest, its
just my road warrior.  With the exception of an immaculate concours 75/76 or
a special model (1st or last car!) it is best to stick with the 73/74 for best
overall features and value.  The earlier models can be fun, especially if you 
can get a 914/6 (project car).  

Dan

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: What's the best year for a 914?
Author:  jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle) at SMTP
Date:    4/13/95 3:18 PM


>	My brother is in the market for a used car to be driven locally. I 
>think I've talked him into a 914 :^)  What was the best year for them? 
>I've heard the '73 2.0 was the best and to avoid '75 & '76, though my '75 
>doesn't seem to be that much different than my '70 to me.  What was the 
>first year of the sideshifter tranny?   Set me straight so he won't be 
>disappointed.
     
AVOID the '75 and '76? The common factor I've heard is, when buying a 
Porsche, always buy as new as you can afford.
     
The obvious differences...
A '70s has a non-movable passenger seat...
Fuel pump right by the motor (hello, vapor lock!)... 
IMHO ugly, stubby bumpers.
4.5" wide wheels!
     
And plenty of other stuff. The later ones are much nicer, have the 
side-shift tranny, better FI (L-jetronic vs D-jetronic), the best-looking 
bumpers (again, IMHO, though it DOES weigh more - but then again, it's 
safer, too), fuel pump in the front trunk, where it belongs... IMHO, nicer 
interior vinyls... And so on.
     
Oh, BTW, side-shift came in at '73, as I recall - the fuel pump in front 
trunk came into being in '75.

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 19:17:40 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: re: Bargin H4's and Whitney?

Hi Mark,

I've bought H4's from J.C. Whitney and pretty much found that you got 
what you paid for.  The first time I received raydots (French Mfg).  The 
second time it was Carillo's (Italian Mfg)  They were essentially 
replacement shells that held H4 bulbs.  They worked fine.  There has been 
a thread on here about DOT approved H4's.  I think that they were 
approved because the shell was a vacuum sealed unit that held H4 bulbs 
that are replaceable. I personally don't think much of the DOT approval 
because the spec was written in 1939 when some cars still used silver 
plated headlight reflectors.  They needed to be sealed to keep from 
tarnishing and not reflecting the light.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 21:26:44 -0400
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: PCR's

Dave;

    This must be your first Parade, as you seem astonished by the PCR's as it
relates to tire size.  Unfortuneately these circumferance rules were written
back when tires were hard as stones and a lower profile tire gave a
tremendous advantage, nowadays lower profile is not the "big" advantage it
used to be.. To show you how absurd this rule is, at a Parade a number of
years ago, 6 cars were successfully protested for having undersized "front"
tires. If you keep reading the rules you will find some other strange
requirements, but if you are building a car for Parade autocrossing,  working
with the PCR's is the way to go  to gain an advantage.


                         Steve

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 22:13:23 +0500
From: jross@inforamp.net (Jonathan Ross)
Subject: Re: The 215 c.i. Buick Special Engine/914 Conversion

Yes, this is the engine now used in the Range Rover, Morgan, TVR etc. bored
out to 3.9 and 4.2 litres, and now high pressure die cast, not low pressure
as built by GM. Apparently GM has several time tried to re-purchase the
rights to this engine, which has been a great success since 1968 in Britain.
Now that BMW owns it, perhaps we will see a new 215 ci V8 sports car (Z1?)
that might approach the magnificent TR8........

Yes, I'm biased......

Cheers! JR
Jonathan Ross, Toronto Canada.
1981 TR8, 1974 Alfa Romeo 2000 GTV, 1987 Porsche 944 Turbo.

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 00:16:41 -0400 (EDT)
From: Armagan Ozkaya <ozkaya@seas.gwu.edu>
Subject: 944 thermostat, what failure?

Hi,

Sorry to bring up a recent subject again, but I did not quite
understand what failure some of you pphiles were mentioning about.

My 85.5 944 engine runs with the temp gauge in the lower part of the 
scale at highway speeds. In city traffic, temp gauge regularly passes
the line that seperates middle and upper parts of it just a bit. At this
point, the fan comes on which brings the temp back to the middle part.
The owner manual says the middle part of the scale is where the engine
is supposed to run.

I think a few of you mentioned the same behaviour previously.
So, where is the failure or is there any failure?

Thanks.

Armagan.

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 23:24:19 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sanjay Nasta <sanjay@bga.com>
Subject: Dead 944S - More Info

Just thought I'd let everyone know that the mechanic found that the guide
that holds the chain between the two cam's under the valve covers
broke...therefore the chain slipped..therefore the timing belt stripped. 
He's never heard of that happening before.  Has anyone else?  This is not
supposed to be a normal maintenance item.  

Also, it was pointed out to me that I should've attributed where I got the
info I posted in the summary message.  Sorry about that.  Next time I'll do
a bit better job of tracking which people the info came from.

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 00:50:02 -0400
From: HHeath3@aol.com
Subject: What does Porsche *mean*?

LG asks, what does Porsche *mean* to people?  I agree with the meaning of
Corvettes of any vintage.  Based on the reaction of people to my
deceptively-new-looking 1983 944, to most folks it seems to be like this:

"Porsche is God's way of saying you have too much money."

Actually, I have found that owning one helps alleviate any problems of too
much money!

My next question is, what does Camaro mean?

Date: Thu, 13 Apr 95 22:40:08 PDT
From: gschoepp@onramp.net
Subject: Dealership Visit


Lacking any real (billable, that is) work to do late last week, I was in transit to a golf course when I realized that I 
was in the neighborhood of the friendly dealership (Town North Porsche in Dallas; no relation other than 
the one detailed herein) which sold me my 911+17 (my pronunciation <g>).

I stopped in and chatted at length with John, the Assistant Sales Manager. We talked about and he provided me 
with the new little 911 book, which includes specs for the '96 Turbo... For those of you who don't yet have this 
little book, get one... 400hp, 0-60 in 4.4 seconds. Very nice pictures of the whole 928-17 line.

We also discussed, in hushed and reverent tones, the end of 928 production. My dream of someday buying a new 
928 has now ended. In his words, "all the cars that are going to be built, are built". What's on the showroom floor 
is all she wrote. A moment of silence, please. (I apologize if the rest of the list has known this for years now, but I 
just learned it and I'm still not right. Come to think of it, I wasn't right before...).

We also discussed 986's. The dealership is essentially taking $928+$72 deposits to get your name on a list. When 
the final specs and prices are available, you can either put the grand torward the car or take it back. Costs a 
kilobuck to play the Boxter game. He indicated they had not yet thought about ordering one for showroom stock 
so that I could drive it.

Having just recently divested myself of my only weekend warrior car (Shelby GLHS), I told John that I was 
interested in a late 80's 911. He's given me a lead to follow on a trade-in he sold to a gent who has just now 
realized that he has a family and can't fit them in the car he bought. If I don't decide to take this one and it looks 
good, I'll pass the info on to the list.

That's my .02 worth for this week. Have a good one... I do! (My Porsche, you sickos!)

Gene Schoepp
'86 928S Marine Blue Metallic

Porschephiles #1327                         Fri Apr 14 14:06:12 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 23:33:01 -0600
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: Lack of power/1987 944 S

SYMPTOMS:
My 1987 944 S appears to drive better on some days than others.  Overall it 
does not respond as quickly to accelerator input as my 1984 944.  The car 
seems to run out of steam at about 3750-4000 RPM.  The power output after 
this RPM range feels like it is somehow restricted.  This is especially 
noticeable in the lower gears (first & second).  Lots of RPM drama but not 
much corresponding forward motion. My impression, which is subjective at 
best, is that on not so good days there is slightly more vibration at this 
RPM level at the gearshift.  Another subjective impression is that there is 
a lack of air going through the system - I can't tell whether it's at the 
exhaust or somewhere before this point. There is also a slight but 
discernable miss at idle (more so on bad days) which I have been unable to 
cure thus far.
CHECKS & FIXES THUS FAR:
1) Tune-up with new WR7DC plugs (pulled the WR7DP plugs since I was told 
that they are prone to miss at higher RPMs).
2) Checked compression which is 164 lbs with no deviation between cylinders.
3) Replaced all plug wires with OEM Beru set, complete with connectors.
4) Replaced distributor cap and rotor.
5) Replaced cam/timing and balance shaft belts, complete with all rollers 
and tensioner which appeared to have been tampered with by previous 
owner/mechanic.
6) Checked coil according to Haynes-  secondary resistance checks out.
7) Had exhaust system checked out- cats out and muffler's clear, so no 
restrictions.
8) Tried to check the airflow meter but could only measure the resistance 
between the two outer terminals (1500 ohms approx).  The sensor check 
involves measuring the voltage across terminals 7 and ground (should be 
150-250 millivolts) I don't know which is terminal 7 since the connector 
says 4 3 2 1 from front of car to back.  Similarly, I cant tell which is 
terminal 9 (to measure voltage between it and ground with ignition in "on" 
position)  to check operation of sensor. Sensor however does not bind 
anwhere along it's travel from pushing it back and forth through the airbox.
9) My mechanic checked out the injectors and "O" rings, they check out fine. 
(I was told they fire OK) The fuel pressure is also OK. I also used ventil 
sauber over three tanks of gas to help clean out the valves and techron 
between fills to help clean the injectors. 
10) The fuel filter was replaced as well as the air filter.
11) I have not been able to find any leaks in the vacuum system but that 
does not mean I have looked in all the correct places.
12) I have not checked the throttle switch or speed sensor cause I don't 
know how.
DIAGNOSIS
I am no closer to solving this problem now, then when I started, so I am 
willing to listen to any suggestions from the list. (including the obvious)
Thanks.
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 95 05:30:37 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Dead 944S - More Info

> Just thought I'd let everyone know that the mechanic found that the guide
> that holds the chain between the two cam's under the valve covers
> broke...therefore the chain slipped..therefore the timing belt stripped. 
> He's never heard of that happening before.  Has anyone else?  This is not
> supposed to be a normal maintenance item.  
> 
> Also, it was pointed out to me that I should've attributed where I got the
> info I posted in the summary message.  Sorry about that.  Next time I'll do
> a bit better job of tracking which people the info came from.
> 

Hi, Sanjay,

Sorry to say, this is a fairly common problem.

I get a lot of calls from around the country looking for used heads and cams
for 944S cars, due to this very thing happening.

And, no, I don't have anything to help you...

Sorry about your misfortune. Good luck with your mechanic...
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 95 08:15:04 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: PCA Driver Ed - Lime Rock, June 5

On Monday, June 5th, the Hudson Valley Region PCA will host a
Porsche-only Driver Education event at Lime Rock Park in Northwest
Connecticut.  This event is unique in that there is a limit of 60
cars, allowing each driver at least two hours of track time during the
day, and has been a favorite among serious track junkies in the
Northeast.

The fee is $75. Your Porsche, PCA membership, a pre-track tech
inspection, a Snell 85 helmet, and a desire for safe, serious fun are
all that is required.

If you would like an application for the event, please email me your
snail-mail address and I will forward one to you.

George Beuselinck, HVR PCA
georgeb@mhv.net
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 08:47:56 -0400
From: NEIL13@aol.com
Subject: Tires for a 993

Greeting Fellow P-philes,

Apparently, I've gotten "on it" a few times and my rear tires need replacement
 (the fronts look new!).  They're Dunlop SP-8000 255/40ZR17 (Porsche "NO"
spec).  Dunlop says they have none in the US and won't have any for about
another month. This has been going on since late February. Anybody else had
this kind of problem? Anbody got any ideas. I'm down to about an 1/8 of an
inch at 9500 miles...

They're great tires. Superb in both dry AND wet roads. I'd like to stick with
them. Shame you can't buy 'em without a new 993 attached to them <g>.

Thanks for your suggestions

Neil Halvey
1995 993 white coupe
1992 white previa
1988 Scorpio (white)
1-2 SO
3 munchkins
1 lab

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 09:11:10 -0400 (EDT)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Re: Autothority Mass Flow for 3.2 Carrera (fwd)

Stan Hanks wrote:
> 
> > So Stan, how about using the latest Porsche chip and/or engine computer 
> > in your car? Would that make a difference?
> 
> Sure. If you updated the rest of the engine too... It's not like you
> walk into the dealer and see "Turbo 95" software release that's coming Real
> Soon Now.... they work where it does them the most good and that's the
> current platform. On a related note, there *HAVE* been mechanical 
> changes in the 3.2 -> 3.6 -> 3.8 progression that are a direct result
> of things noted in programming the EFI.

I understand, what I meant was would there be an improvement if, say you 
used a 1994 engine computer for a 964 Carrera 2 in a 1990 964 Carrera 2.

> > On a related note, I've noticed that many cars have been losing power 
> > recently due to the tighter emissions standards, e.g. M-B 500E going from 
> > 322hp to 315hp (I think). Has Porsche had a really clean engine to begin 
> > with, or have they somehow tweaked their engines to perform cleaner _and_ 
> > better each year? The 911 hp numbers haven't changed from year to year, 
> > in the 964 and 993 generations.
> 
> Two things there, first, Porsche has done an EXCEPTIONAL job of meeting
> tighter emissions standards *and* getting more HP. Second, note that 
> there is a 0.2 liter increase in the 993 ffrom the 964...

I know about the increase in displacement, but I meant within the generation
from model year to model year, e.g. compare 1990 964 Carrera 2 with 1994 
964 Carrera 2.

> Finally, Porsche claimed HP is usually *WAY* low from actually measured
> if you pop the engine out of a new car and put it on a calibrated dyno.
> Specmanship, most likely. Avoiding liability issues by claiming more
> performance than the engine delivers, also possible.

I see. That's what they did with the 911 Turbo 3.6, I believe. I wonder 
if the upcoming 993 twin turbo actually produces "only" 408 hp. More?


- -- 
Taka Mizutani                                     University of Pennsylvania
takaharu@mail.sas.upenn.edu                            Philadelphia, PA, USA
Land line: (215) 243-1247                             Mobile: (215) 960-0592

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 08:37:39 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re[2]: What's the best year for a 914?

Dan (dswiger@qntm.com) writes:
>Since I have a 75 I can speak with authority.  Don't buy one, especially if
>you live in CA.  The smog stuff on a 75 is a real nightmare.  The air-injector
>nozzles strip out, the one-way valve on the air pump manifold goes out and
>the  air pumps die from moisture.

Just a note that Dan is talking about 2.0L engines here.  The 1.8's do not have
all the air injection stuff.  They do have an EGR valve.  On the negative side,
the 1.8's have about 20 less horsepower than the 2.0's.

Pete
'75 914  1.8L

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 07:56:34 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: JC Whitney H4's

> Just saw in my latest Whitney catalog several headlights labeled "H4" at
> some very reasonable prices. Does anybody know the story on these? Would
> they fit? Are they some off-the-wall brand that I wouldn't want anywhere
> near my porsche?

I've had H-4's that I ordered from Whitney about 5 years ago in my '72 T,
and they work fine.  Some off-brand (Bigie, I think -- cute, huh?).  If
you're hung up on brand names, don't get them.

But don't be put off by Taiwan-bashing.  An H-4 headlight isn't a
technological marvel, so Taiwan's ought to work as well as anyone else's.

- --Walt Thode

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 11:22:37 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Patching track tires

OK
Now you'll hear a horror story. I too tried to patch a track tire. It was a
virtually brand new BFG R1. It also had a screw in the tread, nowhere near
the sidewall. I first plugged it and then filled of the plug flush with the
inside. We then patched the area, obviously from the inside. It was fine for
one run group. The second time out I was doing about 130 at Pocono around one
of the banked corners. The car became suddenly "uncomfortable" and then
downright squirmy. I gently got out of the throttle and started to coast down
when the rear started oscillating all over the place (it was a rear tire). I
limped back to the pits where the tire was just about flat.
The moral is don't do it. You're life and maybe others is at stake. Bite the
bullet and replace the tire. Maybe use it for the street or autoX. If you
sell it you have an obvious moral obligation.
Just say NO to patched tires.
Take it from someone who will NEVER do that again!

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
11:17 am

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 95 08:55:19 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 914/6 Weights


At the various SCCA divisional Autocrosses i ran my 914/6 at, it was
weighed. The car, with all equipment still inside and roof on weighed
2045 pounds, average. This was with a full tank of gas. Dave Colman's
914/6 weighed in at 2072 pounds, same condition. Dave's car has GT
fenders and wider wheels and tires. 
I checked the rule book (SCCA GCRs) and I was allowed to be down to
1945 pounds. David and I won our classes at those events, BTW. (Grin)


Jim Pasha
