------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 11:23:16 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: What's the best year for a 914?

> better FI (L-jetronic vs D-jetronic),

        BZZT!  Thank you for playing.  Only the US-spec 1.8L cars
had the L-jetronic FI.  74 and 75.  Both were low-compression cars,
the 75 had cat and/or EGR, neither one had much power.  And whether
or not the L-jet *on the 914* is better than the D-jet is *entirely*
a matter of personal opinion.  I got tired of not finding the vac-
cuum leak in my 1.8 which is/was making the engine burn itself up.
L-jet is also inferior at high RPMs (above about 4,000) because it
is not designed to effectively measure loads up there.
        I am not sure I believe that 49-state 75 & 76 cars had no
cat, but even if they didn't they still had the more restrictive
exhaust system which robs them of power and heats up the engines
more, this robbing them of lifespan.

> fuel pump in the front trunk, where it belongs...

        My apologies for forgetting the fuel pump.  That really,
*really* is important.  (this is *NOT* sarcasm)  Vapor lock is one
of the more annoying traits the 914s have.
        The wheels were only an issue on the earliest cars, and not
all of them.  I have personally not yet run across a car with the
skinny wheels.  The 73 2.0 came with 5.5" Fuchs alloys, and in 74+
(or earlier?) all the wheels were 5.5", even the steelies.
        All the other stuff is opinion.  And, of course, you can
make any 914 into any other, given money and effort.  You can back-
date/update the exhaust, the seats, the fuel pump...  Of the three,
the exhaust (for a 2.0) is by far the most expensive.  (Does it re-
quire 73-74 heads???  Dunno.)  I hope that Jay's brother can tell
whether or not he likes the chrome/painted bumper or the big plastic
one, whether or not he can live with the non-adjustable seat, and
most of the other "opinion" stuff.

(Oops.  This is more flame-like than I intended.  Sorry.)

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!




------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 12:23:09 -0400
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: Early 911 MFI

I am a big fan of the early 911 MFI.  

If you fancy (or own)  a MFI car, and you do not know the history of the
system, then you had better start to budget for a MFI rebuild ($1,200 US
tops).

If the MFI pump works properly, a 911 will start easily and quickly every
time. The procedure in the owner's mannual should be followed. This ritual
has also been documented in the sports car press (Dennis Jenkins - Motor
Sport Feb,1970 - may have written the best contemporary account of how to
start a MFI 911). If this procedure must be modified, then you can bet the
system has a problem. Most of the time starting is very easy with a tired
unit because the mixture is getting richer and richer.  Foulded plugs that
clean up right way  after a bit of time above 5,000 rpm could be a sign of
trouble in  cars with electronic ignitions systems.

When it works well, the MFI does have all the advantages claimed in the
recent discussion. It is better than carburation. 

This type of unit was once state-of-the-art technology for German racing cars
in the 1960s.  A similar unit is found on the  BMW 2002ti for instance.

When the pumps get old and tired they get impossibly rich. This condition
does not enhance the lubrication of your engine.  

When they are poorly maintained (misadjucted or miscalibrated, worn out or
just broken) they are very unpleasant.

There are skilled technicians (uh... make that skilled mechanics... this is a
1970-72 car after all!!) who can make a MFI 911 run really well. This happens
to be expensive because the the people who really know how to maintain these
fuel systems are worth every penny they charge.

My car starts the same way on a hot August morning as it does on a chilly
November morning. This winter it sat in a dry garage for six weeks and
started right up. The batteries were a tad flat, but it fired right up. 

The accerleration in a MFI car seems to be instantaneous regards less of the
conditions. After about 3500 rpm the engine really takes off with a steady
and strong pull until at least 6,300 rpm. The noise is wonderful (and very
loud!).

I understand the cost of a proper carb set up and a MFI fuel system rebuild
is about the same. Your car's Federal Emission Certification remains intact
if the fuel system is original. While many carb conversions have been done
and done well, I cannot recommend it.

Many P-files have excess to the proper equiptment to mantain these units
themselves. They are very well documented. This is much less expensive and a
great deal of fun for some lucky people. Others, like myself  :<(  , have to
rely on professionals who care about these cars.

Flame away!!! and
Enjoy

Bill Hutton
1971 911E coupe

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 13:12:31 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: Early 911 MFI

Bill,

Well explained and written, Bill.  Like most questions of this nature, these
things come down to ORGINALITY versus COST and in some case PRACTICALLITY.
 If you want to go faster in an older car there are any number of bastardized
things you can do to it-some will actually improve performance, others may or
may not.  

It really is also a matter of values and one's goal.  Being a originality
freak, I wouldn't even consider modifying a street car Porsche while a
dedicated race car is entirely another thing.
If you own an essentially valueless car, it really doesn't matter what you do
to it.  On the other hand the MFI cars, for example, are more collectable and
I, for one, would think really hard before I mucked on up.  Just compare the
actual selling prices of stock S's versus a converted turbo-look S with
webbers and dice hanging from the mirror.

Different strokes.. . . 

 -Allen Henderson, Los Gatos, CA
'72S coupe-very fast
'59A coupe-not so fast but, hey, it's 36 years old!  Maybe I should turbo it?

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 13:38:24 -0500
From: entrada@neosoft.com
Subject: 944 Thermostat & Electrical

		
Re: Thermostat. I am new the "PPhiles" and by no means an expert on the 944 
cooling system but I have just completed reconditioning my 87 944S cooling 
system and am passing along what I have learned. My understanding of how the 
system works is that; as the temp.increases to beyond normal operating temp. 
two things happen 1) the thermostat opens and 2) the cooling fans come on. 
Both of these events work to reduce temp. When the temp. gauge indicator 
registers in the higher range, approaching the "high normal" temp. mark, the 
thermostat will open and the fans will come on and the indicator needle will 
drop to, or close to the "low normal" mark. This cycle will continue until 
something occurs to interupt the cycle. If you do not get "gauge confirmation" 
that the system is cycling then there may be a problem with the gauge.

Re: Electrical. I was going through the electrical system, cleaning 
connections and noticed broken a connection. The connection is located at the 
front of the engine compartment between the power steering reservoir and the 
engine block directly above the heater valve. One wire "appears" to come out 
of the distributer and the connecting wire goes off to god knows where. The 
car is operating fine but I can't figure out what these wires do. Anyone with 
a suggestion?


Mark R. Poritzky
87 944S





------------------------------

Date: 14 Apr 1995 11:59:05 -0800
From: "Tom Biesiada" <Tom.Biesiada@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: 944 - Leak Repairs

Fellow 944ers,
During my mandatory CA smog check yesterday, my mechanic found a number of
leaks/repairs that need to be taken care of.  I would like your help in
determining which of these I can tackle myself and if possible, describe the
procedure or identify a good reference for me to use.  Any general
thoughts/advice on the repairs are welcome.  I normally change my own oil and
have replaced the coolant temp. switch.  BTW, I own a '87 944 with 68K on it.

Here's the list:
Cam housing leak - Apparently the gasket to the cam housing is leaking.  I've
looked at my Haynes manual and it seems like this one is out of my league
because of tools/experience/nerve.  What do you think?

Oil pressure sender leak - I wouldn't think this is a difficult one to handle.
 Any thoughts?

Power steering resevoir leak - The connection to the power steering resevoir
is leaking.  My mechanic suggested that he doesn't normally replace the hose
but cuts off the end and reconnects it to the resevoir.  I recall seeing posts
regarding this problem.  Can anyone direct me to the appropriate archive or
summarize the procedure (if it's more complicated than it appears)?

Cracked exhaust manifold - Apparently the pipes for cyl's 1 & 4 are cracked. 
My mechanic said that they normally remove the manifold and repair by welding
the cracks.  How difficult would it be to remove the manifold myself and take
it to him for the welding?  Does that sound reasonable?  Other solutions?

Balance shaft seals leak - My mechanic suggested that this one could wait
until I have the timing belts done.  Unfortunately, they were just done 5K ago
so I have a while to wait for that one.  I don't know the extent of the leak
but is it reasonable to wait 25K to repair this?  This seems like another
problem that is out of my league?  What do you think?

Sounds like a sieve, doesn't it?  Anyhow, the estimate was $965 to do all but
the balance shaft seals.  Needless to say, I'd love to shave as much from that
as I can by doing the work myself.  I'd also like the satisfaction of learning
more about my car and doing the work myself.  I'd appreciate any help you can
give and as always, direct responses are encouraged.  If anyone else would
like to hear the responses, let me know and I'll either forward them to you or
summarize them and post a message to the list.

TIA,
Tom Biesiada
biesiada1@llnl.gov

87 944 Stone Grey (aka "The Sieve")
FWIW - no cats, one tarantula

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 15:00:44 -0400

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 95 13:03:43 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: MFI... the original "i"


Discussing 911 MFI, "MrBill" wrote:

> 
> This type of unit was once state-of-the-art technology for German racing cars
> in the 1960s.  A similar unit is found on the  BMW 2002ti for instance.
> 

Just one nit to pick, then I'll agree with you.  The injected Other
German Car was the 2002tii ("Touring International Injected").  This nit
is only important 'cause there WAS also a 2002ti, which was also a
factory hot rod but came with big Weber (I think) carbs.   The "tii"
used a Kugelfischer injection system that differs from the Bosch/911
principally in how the engine speed is sensed.

But overall I strongly second your opinion... these MFI units are nifty
little gadgets that work great for hundreds of thousands of miles.  The
technology (kind of a mechanical analog computer with a 3-D space-cam
"PROM") is unlikely to ever re-appear on passenger cars now that the
microprocessor reigns supreme.  Hang on to it, or sell it to someone who
will!

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org

'83 911SC
'72 2002tii ("look Ma - no electrons!)

 

------------------------------

Date:         Fri, 14 Apr 95 15:27:34 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: TR-8s and 944 Thermostats

On 13 Apr 95 15:44:00 EST you said:
>ObPorsche:  All this talk about 944 temperatures going up in traffic, then the
> fan
>come on, the temperature drops, and the fan go off has me confused.  Isn't that
> how
>it's supposed to work?  Mine always has.  Driving at speed, the temp stays in
> the lower
>1/3 of the gauge, but in traffic on a hot day it will climb, and the fan will
> come on.
>That's why it's there.  As long as the fan can bring the temp down, I don't see
>the problem.  Am I missing something here?
>

Yes. You are correct, that's how it's supposed to work, HOWEVER...

On a cool day (high of 65-70F), then temp aint supposed to climb
all the way to the top of the normal range! Once the fans came on,
yes, the temp came down to the bottom of normal range. But what if
the outside temp was 95F? The car would overheat before the fans
could get the engine cool quick enough.

Mine was a combination problem, bad fan switch (fan not coming on
at proper temp), and bad thermostat (not open completely, I suspect).

Since I've replaced both, on 85F days in traffic, the highest my
gauge has been to was slightly above mid normal range.

Darren
'87 944S Indischrot

------------------------------

outside of the frame (ie NO SAGGING).


any opinions from the resident restorers

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 95 17:07:42 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 - Leak Repairs

> Fellow 944ers,
> During my mandatory CA smog check yesterday, my mechanic found a number of
> leaks/repairs that need to be taken care of.  I would like your help in
> determining which of these I can tackle myself and if possible, describe the
> procedure or identify a good reference for me to use.  Any general
> thoughts/advice on the repairs are welcome.  I normally change my own oil and
> have replaced the coolant temp. switch.  BTW, I own a '87 944 with 68K on it.

> 
> Here's the list:
> Cam housing leak - Apparently the gasket to the cam housing is leaking.  I've
> looked at my Haynes manual and it seems like this one is out of my league
> because of tools/experience/nerve.  What do you think?

If you have the tools, you can do it yourself. If not, have your mechanic do
it.  Of course, you have to take the belts loose to do this, so, hmmmm, why
is your mechanic wanting you to wait for the balance shaft seals???

> 
> Oil pressure sender leak - I wouldn't think this is a difficult one to handle
>  Any thoughts?

Do it yourself.

> 
> Power steering resevoir leak - The connection to the power steering resevoir
> is leaking.  My mechanic suggested that he doesn't normally replace the hose
> but cuts off the end and reconnects it to the resevoir.  I recall seeing post
> regarding this problem.  Can anyone direct me to the appropriate archive or
> summarize the procedure (if it's more complicated than it appears)?

Messy job, but you can do it yourself.

> 
> Cracked exhaust manifold - Apparently the pipes for cyl's 1 & 4 are cracked. 
> My mechanic said that they normally remove the manifold and repair by welding
> the cracks.  How difficult would it be to remove the manifold myself and take
> it to him for the welding?  Does that sound reasonable?  Other solutions?

Problem with welding a manifold out of the car is that you may weld it at an
angle that will not fit your head. Does the mechanic have a jig to hold it
properly? If not, you may want to ask him how he is going to ensure that the
manifold mating surfaces (to the head) are going to be in exactly the right
place.

Other than that, the exhaust manifolds can be removed with the engine in the
car, and require a couple of 12 or 13 mm wrenches and sockets. I use 3/8
inch drive sockets to get to the bolts at the downpipe. They can be a
(insert commonly used term for female dog) to get loose.

> 
> Balance shaft seals leak - My mechanic suggested that this one could wait
> until I have the timing belts done.  Unfortunately, they were just done 5K ag
> so I have a while to wait for that one.  I don't know the extent of the leak
> but is it reasonable to wait 25K to repair this?  This seems like another
> problem that is out of my league?  What do you think?

You can wait, but keep an eye on the amount of oil dripping out the front of
the belt covers. If there is too much, you may end up soaking the belts and
spending real money...

> 
> Sounds like a sieve, doesn't it?  Anyhow, the estimate was $965 to do all but
> the balance shaft seals.  Needless to say, I'd love to shave as much from tha
> as I can by doing the work myself.  I'd also like the satisfaction of learnin
> more about my car and doing the work myself.  I'd appreciate any help you can
> give and as always, direct responses are encouraged.  If anyone else would
> like to hear the responses, let me know and I'll either forward them to you o
> summarize them and post a message to the list.
> 
> TIA,
> Tom Biesiada
> biesiada1@llnl.gov
> 
> 87 944 Stone Grey (aka "The Sieve")
> FWIW - no cats, one tarantula
> 
> 
> 

One last comment, what kind of a boat does your mechanic have? Or is he just
planning to go Porsche racing and needs some new go-fast parts. $965 is just
way too much for this kind of work.

Send me a first class airline ticket, put me up at your finest hotel, feed
me till I'm stuffed, and I guarantee I can do all this work and still save
your $300.

:-)

GOOD LUCK!

Date:         Fri, 14 Apr 95 15:45:19 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: 944 Thermostat & Electrical

On Fri, 14 Apr 1995 13:38:24 -0500 you said:
>		
>Re: Thermostat. I am new the "PPhiles" and by no means an expert on the 944
>cooling system but I have just completed reconditioning my 87 944S cooling
>system and am passing along what I have learned. My understanding of how the
>system works is that; as the temp.increases to beyond normal operating temp.
>two things happen 1) the thermostat opens and 2) the cooling fans come on.
>Both of these events work to reduce temp. When the temp. gauge indicator
>registers in the higher range, approaching the "high normal" temp. mark, the
>thermostat will open and the fans will come on and the indicator needle will
>drop to, or close to the "low normal" mark. This cycle will continue until
>something occurs to interupt the cycle. If you do not get "gauge confirmation"
>that the system is cycling then there may be a problem with the gauge.
>

I believe the thermostat opens at 180F and stays open while engine is
running at operating temperature.  The low speed fans come on at 198F
and the high speed fans come on at 216F.  The fan switch is stamped
92C and 102C.  So I assume that's what that means.

>Re: Electrical. I was going through the electrical system, cleaning
>connections and noticed broken a connection. The connection is located at the
>front of the engine compartment between the power steering reservoir and the
>engine block directly above the heater valve. One wire "appears" to come out
>of the distributer and the connecting wire goes off to god knows where. The
>car is operating fine but I can't figure out what these wires do. Anyone with
>a suggestion?
>
>
>Mark R. Poritzky
>87 944S
>

The connector on mine is broken. I've wondered what that wire is too.
The car idles fine with it disconnected. (I forgot to reconnect while
working on the engine one day before I noticed it.)

Darren
'87 944S Indischrot

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 17:16:16 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : Tires for a 993 (Bald) 

Neil Halvey (1995 993) asked :

>Apparently, I've gotten "on it" a few times and my rear tires need 
> replacement (the fronts look new!).  They're Dunlop SP-8000 255/40ZR1
> ... I'm down to about an 1/8 of an inch at 9500 miles...
> They're great tires. Superb in both dry AND wet roads. I'd like to stick
with
> them. Shame you can't buy 'em without a new 993 attached to them <g>.

I guess you have gotten on it more than a few times!

With that kind of wear you should try a set of BFG Comp TA-R1 race
tires. They should last almost the same, and you can go fast on the
track without changing tires! The BFG's are available in 235/40/17
for the front (stock size is wimpy) and 255/40/17 for the rear.
Your car will pull WELL over 1g with these tires.

An added advantage is that the BFG's are WAY CHEAPER than normal street
tires! (about $130). I'll even pay for two of your tires if you would be
interested in a co-driver for an SCCA Pro-Solo or National autocross.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S (really want to drive a 993 to see if
Porsche has finally made a car better than a 2.4S!)

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 14:43:00 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Porsche HP Question (long)

Kim Knapp wrote:

>        I think the 0-60 times are underrated, but I believe that the hp is 
>very accurate. When I toured the factory they were testing engines on the 
>dyno and said that they fail them if they are more than a few % less hp 
>(can't remember how much less now), but let them go if they are over the 
>rated hp. The engine they were testing was only a few hp high.

This is interesting ... I've heard from a BMW dealer that the BMW
Lightweight M3's to be made this summer have engines that have the best hp
rating of those coming off the "standard" M3 line.  This jives with several
people claiming that their M3s have substantially more hp (as tested on
their dynos) than the factory suggests.  The factory spec is 240hp, and
said M3 owners were claiming up to 280 dyno'd hp.  Of course, this is all
second-hand.

Now for some more factual data: When BMW made the M1 all M1 motors (type
M88) were run on a dyno for SEVEN HOURS* (!) to verify that they met the
minimum of 277 hp (DIN).  This, it turned out, was pretty important, as the
early motors (still in development) would self-destruct in short order.
It's also one reason why BMW lost so much money on each M1. In the end, BMW
(through BMW Motorsport) ended up with a pretty good motor, capable of
470hp normally aspirated in Group 4 and around 800hp turbo-charged in Group
5.  This motor and its variants showed up in the M635CSi, the M6 and the
M5, and 4 cylinders of it showed up in the first-generation M3. But the M1
was too heavy to ever have a chance as a serious race car. As a
street/touring car, its handling is quite impressive.

Those of you who can read German may enjoy "Autos die Geschichte machten -
BMW M1", by Lothar Boschen, Motorbuch Verlag, ISBN 3-613-01265-0.

I wrote up a little "M1 Histoy Text" for one of the rec.autos.xxx groups a
while back and will e-mail it to whomever would like a copy.

*Seven hours at high rpm will destroy just about any engine, so obviously
this wasn't at full power.  Unfortunately, I don't know what the M88 "dyno
schedule" was.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  | 
|___________________________________________|
|            Novice Welders Unite!          |
|___________________________________________|         


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 14:43:08 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: MFI... the original "i"

Discussing 911 MFI, "MrBill" wrote:

> 
> This type of unit was once state-of-the-art technology for German racing cars
> in the 1960s.  A similar unit is found on the  BMW 2002ti for instance.
> 

Some additional MFI data points for the history buffs:

All US Alfa-Romeos from 69 to 81 had MFI (mfg by SPICA, main business was
diesel injection pumps). Autodelta (Alfa's quasi-official racing arm)
switched to MFI and a sliding-plate throttle assembly on the early-70's
GTAm to gain an extra 20hp over the Weber 45DCOE-carburated versions of the
famous GTA. The V8 Alfa Montreal used an 8-cylinder SPICA pump in all
markets.

Also, the '77-'80 BMW M1 has a 6-cylinder Kugelfischer pump. When tuned
properly, the throttle response is fast and smooth, and the noise is great!
:)

Lastly, lots and lots of Mercedes gasoline models (starting with the
mid-50's 300SL gullwing, 240hp out of 3.0l, same as the new BMW M3 today)
used Bosch MFI pumps - some 2-piston, some 6-piston.  I don't know if there
were any 4-piston units.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  | 
|___________________________________________|
|            Novice Welders Unite!          |
|___________________________________________|

Subject: 914 what year? $0.02


There was a list printed in the 914 owners association newsletter
a while back, and it ranked the "desireability" of 914's as 
follows:  (and I tend to concurr)

#1	ANY 914-6
#2	1973-74 2.0
#3	1975-76 2.0
#4	1973 1.7
#5	1970-72 1.7
#6	any 1.8
#7	any non-stock engine

This list discounts the California '73-1.7, and the half year of 
1974's with 1.7s.  But heck, it's just one person's opinion!

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 18:54:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: 911 1990: Hot starting problem?

I'm the new owner of a 1990 911 C4 w/ 45k miles.  Everything about the 
car seems to be Ok, except if I drive the car, stop it, and try to 
recrank it - it doesn't start immediately.  It is almost as if the car is 
flooded or something.  I'll try to crank it and it want "catch".  I'll 
try again - keeping the starter engaged longer - still no crank.  Third 
try - cranks up with slight hesitation.  It's Ok after that (unless I 
stop it and try to recrank).

If the car is parked more than - say - 50 minutes - no problem.

I'm new to the car (and to 911s) and would appreciate any advice on what 
the problem could possible be.  Maybe a bad sensor some where?  Maybe a 
clogged fuel filter that needs time to unclog?

Thanks in advance,
Scott
(scokelly@netcom.com)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 22:46:33 -0400
From: WA8MSF@aol.com
Subject: Re: lateral > 1.0g ?

Hi Bill!  Several years ago, I did alot of measuring at Mid-Ohio on various
P-cars of mine and others.  At that time, the old version CompT/A-R1's were
capable of 1.07 to 1.13 g on various 911 and 944T serious setups.  These were
measurements in a slightly banked corner coming on to the start/finish
straight.  These loads were at a speed of 45 - 50 mph, I would guess, with a
certain amount of bumps and control margin left to counteract the slight
banking.

Slicks can give 1.25 to 1.40 if alignment and such are really right on
stiffly sprung cars.

As a slight g-Analyst fun story, at Daytona, Hans Stuck was qualifying the
red #5 Coca-Cola 962 and generated 2.4 g's of braking coming into the infield
turn-off on the front straight.  In the infield u-turn, in second gear, the
962 (I believe in 2.8 liter trim) generated 0.8 g of gas pedal ooomph coming
off the exit of the turn.  Woweeee!


Mike 
Cincinnati

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Apr 1995 23:05:32 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: lateral > 1.0g ?

> Did I hear someone say a 993 will pull WELL over 1g with the proper tires ? I 
> thought an F40 doing 1.1g was outrageous. What will a sc, carrera, and 993 
> pull laterally ?

I have no idea, but I *KNEW* someone was going to give me a chance to say 
this... From "The 356 Porsche: Technical and Restoration Guide" published
by The 356 Registry (obligatory plug: if you have a 356 and you don't belong,
shame on you; if you don't have a 356, and want one, this is the best
place to find one; if you don't care about 356s, read on...)

"...Ludvigsen reports 0.81 and 0.83g skip pad figures for the 356C at
Weissach, depending on the pad diamter. Of the 77 cars listed in the
January Road and Track road test summary, only four cars had better
numbers than the 356: the BMW M1, the Ferrari Berlinetta Boxer, the
Lamborghini Countach, and the Lamborghini Jalpa. The 356 equalled
the 930 Turbo and was better than the 911SC, the 944 and the 928."

So there.

Stan

me specify) could lift it without too much trouble.  We put it on a 
bathroom scale.

Date: Sat, 15 Apr 1995 09:12:22 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: How to get P-car's history?

Scott,

If you can provide to PCNA proof of ownership, and a check for $20, they will
send you information they have on file for the car including where the car
was purchased and the factory options the car was imported with.  I think
this only applies to cars sold in this county through the dealer network.  I
don't know if you can get this service for cars originally sold abroad (i.e.,
so-called grey-market).

 Their mailing address is 100 West Liberty Street, Reno, NV 89501, attn:
Customer Relations Department.   Their telephone number is 1-800-545-8039.  I
believe the lady I spoke with was Teresa.

I don't believe that PCA offers any such service.

JWilli 911  (Jim Williams)

cost.  I, and MotorStadt Region appreciate your expertise.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Apr 1995 10:42:14 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Porsche Turbochargers

> The question of the day is Turbochargers.  Do any of our illustrious few 
> know the entire story about 930 (or any other Porsche) Turbochargers?

Turbocharging per se is old hat, dating to 1905. It's been common in
racing circles for a long time, being just about required on the
Offenhauser powered Indy cars of the 60's. For Porsche, they started
with racing cars and moved it to the street. Naturally, the first Porsche
turbo was on the 917, a car which already had too much of everything
else...

There are a couple of places to start looking.  "Porsche Turbo
Racing Cars" by Ian Bamsey is a nice coffeetable book that claims to be
definitive, but I've noted some holes in. Still, nice pics...

Ludvigsen's "Excellence was Expected" is also full of tasty tidbits on
the turbo program, and something that should be on your bookshelf.

Finally, Bruce Anderson pretty well covers all the 911 variants in "The
911 Performance Handbook", which has a developmental history as well. If
you only care about the 930 family, this is the one you want to have.

> What's the going price for a replacement Turbocharger?

That's like asking "How high is UP?"  Which one, why do you need it, are
you doing any "modifications" to the system, etc. In general figure about
a kilobuck for a replacement unit for what you have, and all the ads
remind you that you can "uprgrade" for "ONLY a few hudred dollars more".

What they don't tell you is that bigger (i.e. pushed more air) is typically
also heavier, which means spins up slower, which means (you guessed it)
more turbo lag... There is no free lunch here. To get significant power
increases, and have the car still be "drivable" on the street, you need
to *re-engineer* the induction, not just bolt crap onto it. You may also
need to re-engineer the rest of the car too, depending on how much more
power you want -- power equals heat, and you gotta do something about that; 
acceleration equals energy and you gotta be able to disapate that when
stopping, etc.

Stan


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Apr 1995 11:41:27 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: MoviePorschesPatriotGamesNote

This thread has been going on since I joined the 'list' - maybe this will be
of interest..
A friend prepared the 3 cars used to portray 1 drab dark green 911 Targa in
Patriot Games.  The color was chosen by Hollywood types so that the car would
NOT divert attention(ie. become the star of the show) from the film itself.
 The 3 cars used were a very low mileage 84 3.2 Targa(about 20k miles), an
average miles 3.2 Carrera Targa, and a high miles SC Targa. If I remember
correctly, none of the cars started life Green, all had to be repainted for
the movie.
The low mileage car is now a Red slant nose turbo look Cab.
The average miles car was wrecked during filming and parted out.
The SC was WRECKED during filming and was parted out... providing, among
other things, an oil cooler system for my 66 911 Vintage racecar(recently
sold, finally!).

Phil VanBuskirk, Porsche Market Letter, PMLetter@aol.com

Date: Sat, 15 Apr 1995 13:43:30 -0400
From: V8350cid@aol.com
Subject: 914 Conversion

I am just getting done w/ my conversion. After starting my swap I found that
to use the stock trans, breaks, and CVs was not the way to go. That cluch on
the 901 is way, way to small. I have ended up welding a lot of tubing, and
sheet metal to reinforce the body and suspension. I boxed every thing. For
the trans I use a "two year" '77 930, the gears are huge. Every thing on this
thing is made for killer duty. The cluch, CVs, and gear ratios for the 930
are more up to the task than that little 901. By the way, converting that
trans and making it shift out the side was quite an interesting and fun
engeneering task. I love this stuff!

Brian Kerns

'75 914 350cidV8  

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Apr 1995 11:51:44 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: lateral >1.0g

Over 1 g?  Heck yeah!

BFG R1's will get you over a G on any well set-up P-Car.  My National 
Championship winning 914 1.7 would pull as much as 1.2 momentary and 1.15 
sustained g's running on BFG stickeys.  The new 944 S2 produced some 
beautiful G-Analayzer traces at the Little Rock Pro Solo with peaks at 
1.16 and sustained at 1.10.  Even my lowly Mazda Miata (last year's 
effort) would go over 1.15 pretty easily.  

These measurements are from Valentine's G-Analyst.  Margin of error, if 
set to the proper roll angles is, they say, less than 1%.  The roll 
angles should be close enough to keep the total error to within about 
2-3%, again according to the company's literature.  Concrete surfaces, 
like Salina or Little Rock routinely produce from .05 - .1 more g's than 
asphault, but a banked track will raise g's considerably.  A bigger 
surprise to me was how LOW my braking G's are in a normal autocross.  
Rarely do I get past .4 braking g's!  

- -- 
                                               Byron D. Short
                                              bshort@AFSinc.com
                                                 (719) 531-9511
                                                    1990 944 S2
                                        1987 944 Turbo (4 Sale)


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Apr 95 14:47:00 EST
From: "Gregory Nyce" <gnyce@nas.edu>
Subject: 914 electrical problem: bad ground?

  my '75 914 (2.0) has some electrical gremlin(s) inside.  Looking for any
  suggestions as to what to look for.  Here are the clues:
  car starts/turns over and catches, and immediately dies/cuts out.  Starts
  if push-started, but no go with the ignition.
  This happened late Friday night.  Got a friend to push-start me and
  parked it in a safe place overnight.  When I turned it off and pulled the
  key, the driver side (front and back) parking lights came on.  Hmm, seems
  electrical (well, duh!).  Put the key in and turn one notch... lights
  off.  Weird.  Not wanting to deal at 1:00 a.m., I pulled the fuse for the
  parking lights and went to bed.
  Now, mechanic sez there was a switch (dunno which) in the steering column
  that needed replacing... ok, so it's ok, but now headlights and
  taillights (according to him) don't work.  Where to look, where to look.
  Winner gets an Aretha Franklin 8-track.

  -Greg
  gnyce@nas.edu
  right now, prob'ly a good thing I bike to work...

Date: Sat, 15 Apr 95 12:56:05 PDT
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: 914 gremlins

>Date: Sat, 15 Apr 95 14:47:00 EST
>From: "Gregory Nyce" <gnyce@nas.edu>
>To: porschephiles@tta.com
>Subject: 914 electrical problem: bad ground?
>
>  my '75 914 (2.0) has some electrical gremlin(s) inside.  Looking for any
>  suggestions as to what to look for.  Here are the clues:
>  car starts/turns over and catches, and immediately dies/cuts out.  Starts
>  if push-started, but no go with the ignition.
>  This happened late Friday night.  Got a friend to push-start me and
>  parked it in a safe place overnight.  When I turned it off and pulled the
>  key, the driver side (front and back) parking lights came on.  Hmm, seems
>  electrical (well, duh!).  Put the key in and turn one notch... lights
>  off.  Weird.  Not wanting to deal at 1:00 a.m., I pulled the fuse for the
>  parking lights and went to bed.
>  Now, mechanic sez there was a switch (dunno which) in the steering column
>  that needed replacing... ok, so it's ok, but now headlights and
>  taillights (according to him) don't work.  Where to look, where to look.
>  Winner gets an Aretha Franklin 8-track.
>
>  -Greg
>  gnyce@nas.edu
>  right now, prob'ly a good thing I bike to work...

Key off, both parking lights on on one side, switch in steering column......

You've left your turn signals on.  To make the French (?) happy, the 914
will turn on its parking lights on one side if you park with the signals
left on.  Seems there's a law that requires "parking" lights to be left
on on the street side.

As for your other gremlin(s).  Make sure that all of your fuses are
pretty and clean, and not corroded and bent like mine were.  Another
excellent cause of electrical distress is the relay panel inside the
engine compartment.

I don't know if it's there on the '75, but the relay group under the
passenger seat (it's there on '74s; help me out here group!) can fill
up with crumbs.  The starter and seatbelt interlock go through there.

I would start my search by looking at the stuff that's "different"
during starting.  Like ignition ballast cut-outs, and the like.

Happy hunting!

Gary.

Date: Sat, 15 Apr 1995 18:01:14 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : lateral > 1.0g & Self-flame

Bill Ataras <Bill_Ataras@ccm.jf.intel.com> asked :

> Did I hear someone say a 993 will pull WELL over 1g with the proper tires ?
> What will a sc, carrera, and 993 pull laterally ?

In about '86 with 195/60/15 Yokohama tires not nearly as sticky as the
current autocross tires, my '72 911S with stock suspension (but lowered)
would pull just over 1g on concrete. I don't know what the new tires
would pull.

Self-Flame : I just read my post about wondering if Porsche has finally
made a BETTER car than a 2.4 S. That was a stupid thing to say!
I meant better for stock class autocrossing. There are plenty of
Porsche models better than a 2.4 S in many ways : today I
took my first drive (with air in the tires!) in my '73 914/2.0. It is
much more fun to blast around in, very light feeling. I had one of these
in college, but forgot how much fun they are. I bought this one to sell
it and make some money for the 911, but now I want to keep it. But no
garage space or time to keep it going...

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S, '73 914/2.0 (?)

Date: Mon, 10 Apr 95 12:11:46 pst
From: Jim_Burke_at_ASTEXEC@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Filling up valve covers with oil in 914's

    Greetings Gang,
    
    I'm not on the mailing list anymore, but I need the collected wisdom of 
    the group. So Jim is posting this message for me...
    
    I club race a 914 2.0 in class J.  In long high G-force corners, the 
    914's tend to load up their valve covers with oil .  The stock set-up 
    sends the oil that doesn't drain back into the crankcase up into the 
    air filter via hoses that come together at a "flashback valve" and then 
    into the air filter.
    
    Since loading up the air filter with oil isn't such a great idea, I 
    thought I'd re-route the single hose coming off the flashback valve up 
    into the oil fill cap.  So now, the cap is tapped and excess oil is 
    routed directly back to the crankcase through the oil fill cap.  To 
    ensure crankcase ventilation, I ran the hose that inputs into the base 
    of the oil filler mouth (it's metal box that mounts to the engine 
    block) to the air filter box.
    
    So now the question...  Is what I've done a good idea?  Typically, I do 
    these things thinking they are a good idea, but sometimes they fall 
    apart after I understand what the engineers were originally trying to 
    do. It seems to me that what I've done is avoid the use of an oil catch 
    bottle, but if it were so easy, why doesn't everyone do it?  
    
    Please respond directly to me at JON.KIES@AST.COM.  As always, your 
    responses are greatly appreciated.
    
    Thanks,
    Jon


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1330                         Mon Apr 17 02:00:08 CDT 1995

Date: Sun, 16 Apr 1995 07:51:26 -0500
From: ricp@ids.net (james stephenson)
Subject: Questions-911S wheel/tire sizes

Situation - I have 1972 911S rebuilt track car with 1989 3.2 Ltr Carerra
engine ( ie 255 hp, maybe 300 ft lbs torque using 50 series tires) ), 901
transmission, and stiff suspension (23 & 29 mm torsion bars). 
Right now I have 7x15 inch front wheels and 8x15 rears, and tires 205x50x15
front and 225x50x15 rear Goodrich R1. 
Two problems: 
(1) rear tries are scrapping outer edge of rear tires, 
(2) the 50 series tires on 15 inch wheels using my 901 transmission are
giving me too much low end torque ( ie, I am in 5th gear when Carreras are
in 4th, and I may run out of top end speed on some race tracks).

Questions-  What should I do about wheel and tires sizes at least cost?
Cheapest alternative may be (a) to buy two 7x15 rear wheels, and sell the
8x15. Then, next tire set I could buy 205x60x15 front and 225x60x15 rear.
Question: would taller 60 series tires fit in 72 911 fenders on 7 inch
wheels?? (Would be somewhat softer ride).
Another, more expensive, alternative (b) is to sell (or trade) 15 inch
wheels and buy four 7x16 inch wheels all around and keep with 50 series
tires I have now. These have wider tread width and different tire pattern
than Goodrich RI 60 series tires. Would the tires w/ 16 " tires fit in a 72
911 fenders with the 1 inch higher wheels?
The last alternative (c) is to spend another $1,000 to flare rear fenders,
but I would still have the problem #2 of tires too small?.
 
Would really appreciate your advice and help.  
  
James Stephenson
Rhode Island Capital Partners
115 Brisas, East Greenwich, RI 02818
Phone 401-885-4357 Fax 401-884-2255
E-Mail address: ricp@ids.net

Date: Sun, 16 Apr 1995 11:40:46 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Questions-911S wheel........

James writes...(some stuff deleted)
>Two problems:
>(1)  rear tires are scraping outer edge of rear tires,

I assume you mean the tires are making contact with the fender opening.  This
does not surprise me.  I have run 7" rear wheels with 205/60-15 A008rs
Yokahama on a 70 911 with the same torsion bars and had rubbing under hard
corning.  (Track conditions)  going from an 8 inch wheel with 225/50-15 to a
7 inch wheel with 225/60-15 will probably not solve your rubbing problem.
 More than likely the only thing you are going to be able to do to get enough
tire under the rear of the car is flare the rear fenders.  (Just what you
wanted to hear, right?)  The early body just wasn,t made for wide wheels.

>(2)  the 50 series tires on 15 inch wheels using my 901 >transmission are
giving me too much low end torque (ie, I am in 5th >gear when Carreras are in
4th, and I may run out of top end speed >on some race tracks).

This is a little confusing as the 72 911 came with a 915  transmission which
with stock gearing  and normal diameter (say about 24"  or so) tires should
be turning about 2600 rpm @ 60 mph in 5th gear.  with a theoritical red line
of 6500 you should be able to pull 150 mph @ redline in 5th gear.  This would
be true even with a late (69-71) 901 gearbox if it has stock gears.  Has your
gearbox been regeared?  It sure sounds like it.  If this is the case, this
may be the foundation of your problem.  Normally rear tire size is selected
for handling balance not gearing, although it will effect gearing to some
degree it may not effect it to the degree you are looking for.  If the car is
oversteering or spinning the rear tires coming off corners and you can't
correct for this with suspension adjustments you may need larger rear tires
and/or a limited slip, but if your only problem is one of top speed vs engine
rpm you are probably going to have to regear the transmission.

Hope this helps

Pat Moyle

Date: Sun, 16 Apr 1995 12:14:11 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: re:re: Autothority Mass Flow for 3.2 Carrera (rambling)

Sorry don't know anything about this and don't even have a Carrera. 
 
However.... 
At the NYC Car Show yesterday, I ran into my mechanic, Tom of AutoSport
Design in Mineola, LI. He was working the Ultrasmith booth. Ultrasmith does
the $$$$$$ chi-chi boy-toy conversions on  MB, Porsche, Ferrari, etc. You
know, ostrich interiors, powered license plate switcher, etc. Being based
in Manhattan, they have the clientele. Apparently, Autosport does much of
the actual work (performance upgrades and ground effects, not audio) for
Ultrasmith. I was surprised, but Tom always surprises me. 
 
Anyway, I asked him why he had the Autothority 330RS #001 (pumped up BMW
325is, reviewed in all the big mags, M3 beater) for sale. It was at the
Ultrasmith booth, Tom has been advertising it in the NY Times lately, and
it seemed to have nothing to do with either. He told me that he built the
car, and that he has does much of the engineering for Autothority. 
 
Autothority..Autosport..Autothority..Autosport..who knows... 
 
He also designed the some of the chips for Autothority, and in fact burns
them at the Autosport shop. 
 
THE POINT: He also told me that the 3.2 Mass Flow was designed by him and
prototyped on his own '87 Carrera. Seems like he might know why and how it
works. Or doesn't. 
 
His '87 car BTW, has received the RUF Yellowbird treatment, albeit, in
white, is turbocharged now and produces 428hp, and performance similar to
that of the two '96 993 turbos PCNA had upstairs. It is a sleeper without
wheel flares. It's also for sale. See it in the Ultrasmith booth too. 
 
Check them out, they advertise in Pano. 
 
The most interesting part of the show for me was not PCNA's announcement
that the 928 and 968 are out of production, that the new '96 993 Turbos
(looks more similar to the normally aspirated versions than in the past)
are only $100,000 (lot of bang for the buck), or the Ultrasmith booth.
Nope, I loved that MBNA (not MB) gave me a 1:24 Revell Cobra for applying
for a credit card and Marlboro gave me a watch (cool watch too!) for
playing their Marlboro Grand Prix video game. 
 
Biggest disappointment: Sitting in a Land Rover Discovery and Defender.
Jeep and even low-buck Suzuki are a lot nicer. 
 
Happy Holiday.

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 09:46:36 +0900
From: Naoki Kumazawa <kumazawa@mosk.semicon.sony.co.jp>
Subject: Re: C2 brake upgrade 

  Sun, 16 Apr 95 Chien Wang wrote;

> Hi everyone, my brother-in-law recently upgraded his 91 C2 rear calipers 
> with the 928(Brembo) units(he also replaced the pads on all four corners).  
> The question is does he need to switch to the 928 proportioning valve 
> too? or anything else he should do? he thinks the rear brake now has too 
> much bias. Thank you all for your help.

  because they are 4 pot calipers (may be the same as 928`s)and perhaps 
  your brother doesn't need to switch parts any more.

Date: Sun, 16 Apr 1995 19:30:00 -0700
From: marcsg@ix.netcom.com (Marc G)
Subject: Sunroof on 944 acting up?

Ok, I know we have been through this but:
  On my 86 944 my roof will only tilt up when it feels like it
ie: I hit the button nothing happins, hit it again a few minutes later 
and it works.
  I put the key in the first position and the roof unlocks fine and can 
be removed, I replace the roof and cant get it to lock again but if I

stupid or what? (dont answer that last one)

Date: Sun, 16 Apr 95 22:42:25 EDT
From: x51903e4@WESTPOINT-EMH2.USMA.ARMY.MIL (Ngo Lan-dinh CDT)
Subject: Factory Alarm

To anyone who can help:

I have an '83 928S and the alarm is very finicky.  I can't find it in the 
manual anywhere but I'm pretty sure it's a factory alarm because when it goes 
off, the horn starts blaring like crazy.  After much trial and error I have 
figured out that (generally) to turn the alarm on all I have to do is lock the 
door (the lock is motorized).  To turn it off, however, is the real trick.  
Usually I just turn the key until the lock raises and hold it in that position 
with the key in the lock for five seconds.  Obviously, lots of trial and error 
to find this little technique.  It usually works but -- not always.  When it 
goes off people from miles around get an earful and I have to wait for it to 
finish blasting (about 30 seconds) and then I try again.

1.  What is the real technique for turning off the alarm?
2.  If I accidentally set if off, is there a way to shut it off quickly or do I
have to wait until it goes off (very loudly) for 30 seconds?

Thanks a lot...


Lan-Dinh Ngo

'83 928S  (Stefan)

Date: Sun, 16 Apr 1995 22:09:01 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Is there a 914 Catalogue available - Body, Trim, Mechanical?

> I am looking for any catalogue information regarding Body, Trim or Mechanical? 

There are *LOTS* of them. See the FAQ for suggestions. 

> Is there any advantage to using carburetors instead of stock injection?

Only to the people that *SELL* carburetors. 

You get generally improved operation for a stock or mostly stock engine
using EFI, and even for race engines, can modify the EFI to provide
better performance than carbs. 

The only applications for which I ever recommend carbs are certain classes
of racing sanctioned by the SCCA which *require* the use of carbs to be
legal.

> I am oubut to replace the clutch due to oil leakage (from the the push rod 
> tubes?)  I would also like to increase the horsepower, but I am new to this, 
> any suggestions?

Oil leaks from the pushrods should not have effected the clutch. Make sure
that you have that leak under control before you replace the clutch, or
you'll either waste money or get to do the work again, or both.

Increasing horsepower is a very different operation. There are no worthwhile
horsepower increases for that engine that do not involve rebuilding at least
part of the engine.

> Mounted on the centre console (armrest) are two rocker style switches that 
> have no apparent purpose - what are they?

They're not factory (unless part of some wierd Canadian option pack).
You'll have to chase down the wiring yourself.

Stan

Date: Sun, 16 Apr 1995 22:28:03 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: MFI vs. Carbs

> > Carbs vs MFI
> 
> Which got me to wonder what the consensus is on this comparison?  What are the
> positives and negatives of each?   

While this was pretty well covered, I figure I'll add my $0.02 here...

All fuel metering devices are approximate. That means all have some deficiency
somewhere, which means for some application, one will be better than another.

Carbs are simple, easy to build, easy to repair completely mechanical devices.
They don't approximate the fuel-air mix very well, as they work on a simple
method of approximating air flow by the suction presented on an orifice.
Many things can hose this up, and there are wide ranges of operating speed
where the air flow is too low or too high for this to be accurate, thus
requiring the addition of additional correction mechanisms. "Really good"
carbs have lots of them; that  means under most conditions they do the
right thing. Problem is that while this works well for certain engine
configurations where a single carb with a common intake plenum can even out
a lot of things, a flat engine with a throat per cylinder magifies the 
problems.

Mechanical Fuel Injection uses a 3-d space cam to approximate the fuel flow 
required for a given engine configuration at a given RPM under a given 
approximate load and delta V. This is a LOT better -- given that all the 
Rube Goldberg assortment of tiny moving parts is actually working right,
the cam isn't worn, the injectors are firing as advertised, and the engine
is not modified.

In general, carbs are easier for Joe Shadetree to get working so that
the car at least runs. I've *NEVER* in 20+ years seen a carb so bad out
of the box that the car bolted underneath didn't run for at least
a while. Carbs are also *CHEAP*. That means that if you're looking at
a $1500 repair on your MFI pump, that Weber conversion for $1000 might look
pretty good. And it will actually run. And the Hawethorne Effect will
*TELL* you that it's "better" even if it's not (look it up  -- it's
good to know about).

I'm a purist.  If I'm racing, I'm in it purely to win and use the very 
best technology I'm allowed to use to win. If I'm restoring  an older
car, I want it to be a nearly perfect (mechanically, anyway) version
of what it was when it was new. There are no MFI Porsches out there
that aren't relics. Hence, for me this is easy: fix the MFI, run the
engine in nearly stock form, and be amazed at how well all this stuff works...

For absolute BEST power, performance, whatever, you'd want a modern
programmable EFI which uses a shit-pile of sensors to allow a software
version of that 3-d space cam to fire the injectors Just So. And it's
still not very good because you have to program it and that's where the
mistakes come from..

Carbs? I use them on 356s, 914/6s, and early 911s. They're too much
trouble on anything I have to deal with regularly.

Stan

Porschephiles #1331                         Mon Apr 17 11:21:37 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 04:16:48 -0500
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: The Natural Life Cycle of Mailing Lists

I pulled this from a list I'm on for people that manage large lists,
where we bitch and moan about how hard it is and how ungrateful all
you subscribers are... 8{) Anyway, this offers a view of the process.
I think Porschephiles sort of transcends this, since we have a high
turn over but a solid, solid core of multi-year subscribers. Anyway,
another "worthless non-Porsche topic" to mull over.

 - --- start forwarded text

Forwarded-by: brent@greatcircle.COM (Brent Chapman)
Forwarded-by: cgw@io.com (Christopher Williams)
Forwarded-by: msbailen@wrdmail.er.usgs.gov (Mark S. Bailen)
Forwarded-by: frie9481@uidaho.edu (Friese Greg)
[author unknown]

THE NATURAL LIFE CYCLE OF MAILING LISTS

Every list seems to go through the same cycle:

1.  Initial enthusiasm (people introduce themselves, and gush alot about
    how wonderful it is to find kindred souls).

2.  Evangelism (people moan about how few folks are posting to the list,
    and brainstorm recruitment strategies).

3.  Growth (more and more people join, more and more lengthy threads
    develop, occasional off-topic threads pop up).

4.  Community (lots of threads, some more relevant than others; lots of
    information and advice is exchanged; experts help other experts as
    well as less experienced colleagues; friendships develop; people tease
    each other; newcomers are welcomed with generosity and patience;
    everyone -- newbie and expert alike -- feels comfortable asking
    questions, suggesting answers, and sharing opinions).

5.  Discomfort with diversity (the number of messages increases
    dramatically; not every thread is fascinating to every reader; people
    start complaining about the signal-to-noise ratio; person 1 threatens
    to quit if *other* people don't limit discussion to person 1's pet
    topic; person 2 agrees with person 1; person 3 tells 1 & 2 to lighten
    up; more bandwidth is wasted complaining about off-topic threads than
    is used for the threads themselves; everyone gets annoyed).

6a. Smug complacency and stagnation (the purists flame everyone who asks
    an 'old' question or responds with humor to a serious post; newbies
    are rebuffed; traffic drops to a doze-producing level of a few minor
    issues; all interesting discussions happen by private email and are
    limited to a few participants; the purists spend lots of time
    self-righteously congratulating each other on keeping off-topic
    threads off the list).
OR

6b. Maturity (a few people quit in a huff; the rest of the participants
    stay near stage 4, with stage 5 popping up briefly every few weeks;
    many people wear out their second or third 'delete' key, but the list
    lives contentedly ever after).

 - --- end forwarded text

Stan

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 07:27:39 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Sunroof on 944 acting up?

> Ok, I know we have been through this but:
>   On my 86 944 my roof will only tilt up when it feels like it
> ie: I hit the button nothing happins, hit it again a few minutes later 
> and it works.
>   I put the key in the first position and the roof unlocks fine and can 
> be removed, I replace the roof and cant get it to lock again but if I 
> leave it unlocked and drive away it will lock itself. Am I totally 
> stupid or what? (dont answer that last one)
> Is is a motor problem?
> Cables?
> Key Position?
> Owner is a twit?
> 
> Thanks all
> Marc
> 
> 86 944 Black
> 88 GTI 16V Black
> 88 S-10 Blazer Black
> 86 Lab/Terrier Mix Black

Sounds like a sticky switch or relay.  The owner is probably not a twit.

You might try swapping the relays at the motor (they are identical) to see
if the symptom changes.

The switch can be checked with an ohmmeter.

There is also a switch at the front of the sunroof, in the center of the
headliner (of the roof itself).

Good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 07:51:05 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: What's it all about, Bartie...?

You 124 payed-up Patrons and Members can delete this...

To you Old and New Porschephile-subscribers (who are wondering
what all this talk of money for a *free* list is all about...)
Greetings!

Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER* 1500 members,
generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per *day*, which is more
traffic than MCI handles!

This volume of traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1
service.  In addition, it now requires that a machine be dedicated to
handle this traffic.  This machine is old, nearing the end of its service
life, and should be replaced.

Not to put too fine a point of this, this eats into the Listmeister's
livelihood, and, amigos, that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable
debt of gratitude for freely providing this service at no cost for the
past 5.5 years.  The very least we can do to show our gratitude is to
take as much of the capital burden upon ourselves as possible.

We have established a Not-for-profit bank account with my bank in
Crofton, Maryland, to accumulate the funds, and are asking that each
member who is concerned for the survival of Porschephiles, to contribute
what they can.  I have suggest appropriate donations would be $15 for
Students, $50 for Employed people, and $100 for those who wish to be
considered Patrons.

*Nobody* has to contribute anything.  We are trying to acquire the funds
to build the infastructure to ensure the survival of Porschephiles
independent of any member.

I don't have firm figures for the costs we are facing, and that doesn't
bother me a bit. I do know that Stan has made the service available to
the group, using the capital resources that he depends upon to earn his
daily bread, and is begining to feel the strain.

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say
"Rectal Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford
$15.  If a poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of
line for a Working person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and
access to the 'net, to be able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more,
then $100 seemed like a nice, tidy round number.

I don't think it's anal-retentive to recognize those who dig deeper.  I
have assured all that no one's name or contribution level will be
published *unless* they instruct me to do so.  NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE
ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  A recent InfoWorld has a
comparison of two package servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  Whatever
organization we form to shelter the funding under, this number will be
your membership number.  You get to be a *charter* member of whatever it
becomes.  Impress your Friends!  Be *attractive* to Members of your
favorite Gender!  Be known as a *True* Porschephile...

And, how about *Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great*
happenings on the 'net?

Finally, the "membership" issue.  We need to decide what kind of an organiztion 
we will be.  Here, again, you can be a PORSCHEPHILE and not join any more
organizations.  Many of us would like to be the Electronic Frontier
Region of PCA, but this is not universal. Most of the Non-US folks are
not interested in affiliating with PCA, and that's no problem either.

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!  Everybody can Join
(whatever orgainzation we decide); again, *NOBODY* has to...there is
enough interest in the EFR business that we *can* go that route if
required to keep my butt out of the [deleted] grasp of the IRS.

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute:  The bank folks would
rather that you send the checks to me, made out to

for deposit to "Porschephiles" Acct #3933150532

My address is:

Custodian "Porschephiles" 
c/o Bart Chambers 
1270 Lavall Drive
Davidsonville, MD  21035 
(410) 721-2989

If you wish to call me, please do so prior 8:30 PM EST.

***Please send me an Email with your address, ck number and amt.*** 
This will be private unless you wish to send it to 'philes yourself:

Here is the name, address and Phone number of the bank officer so anyone 
who whishes, may verify that this is on the up-and-up.

     Cathy Laster,
         re:  Porschephiles acct.# 3933150532
     NationsBank, Crofton Office
     2227 Defense Highway
     Crofton, MD  21114
     (410) 793-0770

We are grateful any and all donations.

Cheers

(yer kindly ol' Unka) Bart

Frau, Feline Varmint, '86 Indischrot Carrera Cabriolet, etc.
Custodian, Porschephiles Phund

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 8:48:45 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Targa top clip screws

Steve,

I think the targa top clip screws are Phillips coutersunk  M4x4's.  Run
down to your friendly neighbourhood hardware store.  I actually could
only find slotted countersunk M4x6's.  So big deal, I don't have the
phillips head.  The extra 2 mm length is not a problem for me.  The
"nuts" are actually a strip of (guess) 3/6" steel about 1" by 5/8".
These are glued in place so you, like me, may not need to replace them
since they still may be there.  If you do need to replace them, just get
a few odds 'n' ends of scrap metal and run a tap through it.

If you don't have any metric taps, and the original nut plates are
still there you'll probably need them to clean the threads out
anyway.  A set of taps and dies is a fantastic tool to have, probably
the best investment in tools I've made barring maybe a torque wrench.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

>Can you give me some info on the car ?

PORCHEV

Body: 1975 Porsche 914

Suspension: Porsche 911 suspension conversion & 911SC brakes,
          heavy duty torsion bars & springs, Koni gas shocks.
        Manny's Porshop, South Holland, IL

Engine: 355 CID - 399 HP Chevrolet small block
          Corvette aluminum heads, 2.02 & 1.6 stainless valves,
          CompetitionCams 280 cam, kit & stainless roller rockers.
          Forged crank, Crower stainless rods, Jackson gear drive.
          Holly 750 on Edelbrock Victor Jr. manifold.
          2 stage electronic fuel pressure regulator.
          MSD multi spark ignition & 2 stage electronic rev control.
        Lingenfelter Racing, Decatur, IN

Drivetrain: 915 transaxle with "Nurburgring" .70 to 1 5th gear,
          Vellios 916 shift kit, and trans-mount/nose-cone,
          Porsche 930 axles and CV joints.
        George Vellios, Manhattan Beach, CA

Conversion Kit: 914/Chevy V8 Engine/Trans adapter, Radiator kit.
        Jaidecar, Long Beach, CA (defunct)

Instrumentation: Porsche/VDO: 911 180 MPH speedometer,
        VDO: Oil Temp, Oil Pressure, Water Temp, Amps, Volts,
        Auto Meter: Remote Fuel Pressure.

Construction: Engine/trans installation, gauges and wiring,
          fuel/oil/radiator plumbing, detail work,
          unfailing enthusiasiam and extraordinary patience.
        Greg Lonberger and Chuck Mill
        Lonberger Restorations,
        9312 Clark Road, Richmond, IL 60071

Performance:
10.80/125 MPH quarter mile & 165 MPH top speed (could probably get into
185-200 range with taller tires).

I have driven the car a total of 13 days since copleation. Less than 1000
miles on engine.

Over $64,000 invested. Asking $25,000.

If you need more detailed info on any point, let me know.

Ken

                    If it doesn't come back - hunt it down and kill it!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 10:24:55 -0400 (EDT)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: Sunroof on 944 acting up?

I had the same problem in my 951. What you do is remove the "trapezoid" 
at the front of the roof, above the interior light. Take the black 
plastic cover off, then check the electrical switch.There's a sponge 
underneath it; chances are this sponge has compressed or worn away, thus 
the roof doesn't work. I recommend using silicone in place of the sponge...


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 07:51:59 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: The Natural Life Cycle of Mailing Lists

You wrote: 
>
>I pulled this from a list I'm on for people that manage large lists,
>where we bitch and moan about how hard it is and how ungrateful all
>you subscribers are... 8{) Anyway, this offers a view of the process.
>I think Porschephiles sort of transcends this, since we have a high
>turn over but a solid, solid core of multi-year subscribers. Anyway,
>another "worthless non-Porsche topic" to mull over.
>
>- --- start forwarded text
>
>Forwarded-by: brent@greatcircle.COM (Brent Chapman)
>Forwarded-by: cgw@io.com (Christopher Williams)
>Forwarded-by: msbailen@wrdmail.er.usgs.gov (Mark S. Bailen)
>Forwarded-by: frie9481@uidaho.edu (Friese Greg)
>[author unknown]
>
>THE NATURAL LIFE CYCLE OF MAILING LISTS
>
>Every list seems to go through the same cycle:
>
>1.  Initial enthusiasm (people introduce themselves, and gush alot 
about how wonderful it is to find kindred souls).
>
>2.  Evangelism (people moan about how few folks are posting to the 
list, and brainstorm recruitment strategies).
>
>3.  Growth (more and more people join, more and more lengthy threads
>    develop, occasional off-topic threads pop up).
>
>4.  Community (lots of threads, some more relevant than others; lots 
of information and advice is exchanged; experts help other experts as
 well as less experienced colleagues; friendships develop; people tease 
each other; newcomers are welcomed with generosity and patience; 
everyone -- newbie and expert alike -- feels comfortable asking 
questions, suggesting answers, and sharing opinions).
>
>5.  Discomfort with diversity (the number of messages increases 
dramatically; not every thread is fascinating to every reader; people 
start complaining about the signal-to-noise ratio; person 1 threatens 
to quit if *other* people don't limit discussion to person 1's pet 
topic; person 2 agrees with person 1; person 3 tells 1 & 2 to lighten
 up; more bandwidth is wasted complaining about off-topic threads than 
is used for the threads themselves; everyone gets annoyed).
>
>6a. Smug complacency and stagnation (the purists flame everyone who 
asks an 'old' question or responds with humor to a serious post; 
newbies are rebuffed; traffic drops to a doze-producing level of a few 
minor issues; all interesting discussions happen by private email and 
are limited to a few participants; the purists spend lots of time 
self-righteously congratulating each other on keeping off-topi  threads 
off the list).
>OR
>
>6b. Maturity (a few people quit in a huff; the rest of the 
participants stay near stage 4, with stage 5 popping up briefly every 
few weeks; many people wear out their second or third 'delete' key, but 
the list lives contentedly ever after).
>
>- --- end forwarded text
>
>Stan
>
Stan & all

How timely for this reminder. I agree with most and need to take a look 
at my responses. One thing the newbies shoud do is read the faq and 
rules stan sends them when they sign up. Anyway more tolerence will 
make our list the best out there. There is so much good information on 
this list that we should always protect and keep what we have with 
encouragement for more participation not less.

Besides without the list will not have the great information that can 
be used in THE DRIFTER. (Sac valley nwsletter)

Mike

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 11:19:31 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Factory Alarm

The alarm on my '84 is turned on by turning the key to the lock position
in either door or the hatch, in theory. It is turned off by turning the
jey to the unlock position in any of those, also in theory - no five-second
delay. In practice, the alarm is not actually turned on or off by the
driver's side door lock - I imagine a switch in there has failed.

In the wiring from the door to the body of the car, the alarm circuit is
a separate three-wire cable, with an easy-to-reach connector. You
could check there to see if reasonable circuits are being made/broken
when you turn the key in the lock.

You should be able to shut the alarm off immediately, if you set it off,
by turning the key to the unlock position in any of the three locks.
If it doesn't shut off, that seems to indicate bad contacts in the
lock you tried.

 -John White-
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 10:20:40 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 944 - Leak Repairs

> 
> Power steering resevoir leak - The connection to the power steering resevoir
> is leaking.  My mechanic suggested that he doesn't normally replace the hose
> but cuts off the end and reconnects it to the resevoir.  I recall seeing post
> regarding this problem.  Can anyone direct me to the appropriate archive or
> summarize the procedure (if it's more complicated than it appears)?

I had this sort of problem when I bought my car.  I didn't even cut
the hoses.  I just went out and but some standard hose clamps at the
local hardware store and replaced the crappy hose clamps that came
on the car.  This took care of my power steering leak until my 
rack went...  Btw, got 1500 miles on my rebuilt rack this weekend.
Everything seems in order.

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 10:37:07 -0500
From: ricp@ids.net (james stephenson)
Subject: 2nd Question- 911 wheels

Question- if you have 1972 911S without flares, with a 7 inch Carrera wheel
(black spokes) and use Goodrich 225x50x15 RI tires,  would the tire rub on
the oil lines on the right inside rear??
I measured a 7 inch wheel with a 205x50x15 tire and it had about 30 to 40 mm
clearance inside between the oil line and tire wall. Assuming that one half
of increased tire width of a 225 is inside, ( ie 10mm) then that would be
about 20mm clearance left inside for the oil lines. Is that  a correct
calculation? Is that enough for high speed track and flexing?

legal in stock class ?

4. Here's what I think I know <g> please correct me:  
 - stiffer sway bars (Not Legal), 
 - adjustable spring plates (N.L.), 
 - slight lowering with rack spacers (Legal?),  
 - racing harness (N.L.), 
 - 7&8 x15 with nonstock profile tires (N.L.)
 - new rubber suspension bushings (L), non-rubber (N.L.)

ride height and alignment done anyway so if I'm going to

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 10:22:20 -0700
From: kwatson@wv.MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Oregon Region Track Day Report (long)

The Oregon Region had a track day at PIR on Friday.  The forecast
was for occasional rain which is just what we got.  I was looking
forward using up a full tank of gas driving in the rain with a
slippery track.  I wanted to practice car control in my 81 911.
Boy, did I get to practice. :-)  I hadn't had the Porsche on the
track in over 2 years.  I have been driving and racing VW's which
are much more forgiving cars and knew I had developed bad habits.
A stock 911 *demands* to be driving smoothly (properly).

The chicane (Festival Curves) was being used.  I would normally say
this is a bad thing for non-race days.  Since racers have problems
with spinning out or getting stuck in the sand trap I would think
club day'ers would have even worse problems with it.  It worked well
though because people already had to pay more attention than usual
since the track was wet.

The Oregon Region chose to run the track day as one long open
session from 2pm to 7pm.  There was a break in the middle of the
session for the SCCA turn workers.  The open session is intended
to allow people to go on and off the track when they would like to.
At the start of the session most of the cars lined up and went out.
I didn't go out right away with the crowd.

Fellow p'philer Miq Millman was out at the track visiting but didn't
bring his Porsche.  I took him for a ride.  (There is a double
meaning there :-).  My lack of track time in the 911 was showing and
it took about half an hour to get used to it again.  The track started
fairly dry then sprinkles began and the track started getting
slippery.  I moved to the rain line.  Crossing over the line,
especially the exit of 1 and the entrance of 9, would always cause
the car to slip sideways a bit.  I only looped the car once while
Miq was a passenger.  It happened exiting 3 which opens up.  I crossed
onto the line with too much power and lost the backend.  Pushed
both feet in and did a lazy 360 off into the grass (and mud).  After
a bit Miq had to get back to work.  I dropped him off and went back
out since there was a little more rain.

I noticed during the day that most people would exit the track when
the rain started and enter again when it stopped.  I was doing the
opposite. :-)  My second time out I stayed out for 45 minutes in the
rain.  I just kept going because I was having so much fun (I was
giggling a couple of times :-) and I was learning so much.  I have
never had the opportunity to be on a racetrack before where the car
would either twitch or slide so much.  Once while braking for the
chicane the car twitched left towards the wall.  Crossing the line
after the apex of 1 the car would slide every time.  Exiting 3 crossing
the line the car would be loose.  At the apex of 5 the car would be
loose.  Once I wasn't paying attention and did my upshift at the apex
of 6 instead of before or after.  Turn 6 (turns right) is innocent
looking but it has a slight dip at the apex.  When it is wet it is
very dangerous and has collected *many* cars.  I found out it makes
the car twitch to the right where the wall is.  I didn't lift so it
was fine.  Later in the day someone hit the same spot and did lift.
His 911 went into the wall on the right and then slid off the track
to the left and hit the guardrail.  He's not the first one and won't
be the last. :-(  Once I had the car twitch to the right towards the
wall in the middle of the back straight.  The back straight is actually
a *long* right sweeper.  The conditions were slippery enough that
I couldn't even take the back straight at full throttle.  Several
times the front wheels locked up while braking for 9 as I would cross
over the line entering 9.  Even exiting 9 onto the front straight
the rear would brake loose a little under hard acceleration.

I thought it was a great track day.  Of course, everyone kept looking
at me funny when I would say I was having so much fun.

Keith Watson
81 Porsche 911 SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 10:24:22 -0600
From: stephenk@synopsys.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: '73 914 2.0L CV Joints

Well folks:

Weather was nice (finally!) this weekend, so I got back to work on the 914
powerplant install.  I was getting ready to button the axles back up to the
transaxle when I decided (because they were 95% out anyway) to drop the
axles and repack the CV joints.  To my dismay, the inner right-hand CV joint
has a broken race.  Assuming the other joints pass inspection, can I replace
just the one broken CV joint on that axle or do I need to do both ends of an
axle at the same time?  Beyond cracks and such, is there anything to check
on a CV to determine its roadworthiness?

Thanks in advance,

Stph

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 13:58:25 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Porsche suing porsche.org owner.


Hello,

Some poeple may find this very interesting.  I hope I don't provoke
another escapade into the old stories we all once followed.

As an intellectual property/patent law student, I was reading one 
of my favorite newsgroups this morning, misc.int-property.  It
turns out I came upon a recent post fro this past Friday (4/14/95) 
and some relies from our old friend T!d M.

Believe it or not, he is being sued by Porsche for trademark 
infringement (probably for the domain name porsche.org), and they 
are also trying to sue his employer becuase Porsche thought he was
running the list from that location.  It turns out that he 
admits in the posting that he was running this from his home via an
internet service provider and had the Porsche.org domainname registered
with the internet domain name service so that the "whois porsche.org"
command on an internet host gave his name and home address.

He is looking for an attorney apparently, and writes that he can't
afford the full cost of a lawsuit, but can afford some up-front adivce.
 
He goes on to say that Porsche has been harassing his employer and
he wishes them to stop doing so.  

Anyways, though this may bring joy to many on this list, I would not
wish it on anyone.  I personally never had a problem with the guy,
and thought the battle on the list was sort of funny.

It also raises an issue that is hot in the legal arena now.  That
issue is the idea of copyright infringment on the internet, and 
trademarking domainnames, etc.  

I would have copied the note he posted, and I am sure he would
want me to, so that he could try and sue me for copyright infringment.
Sorry T, I'm one step ahead of you.  Good luck against Porsche.
Maybe if you just gave them your 911 with 4 different sized wheels
and agreed to be honest about your auto-x times, they would settle out 
of court. :-)

 -Barry Chapin
1981 Euro-911SC Targa
