Date: 17 Apr 95 14:17:06 GMT+05.00
From: Miliano/PAPY_MIS01//US/TELEMAIL/BASF////@basfx400.parsippa.basf-corp.com
Subject: Deals On 968's??????


My two cents on the 968 question.  I talked to Fred Schwab from PCA at the 
NY Auto Show and he said that they are only making two 968 a day.  (NOTE: 
the only 968 at the show was stuck off to the side of the Porsche info booth 
by the Lexus display.) He said, "We'll keep making them as long as people 
want them".  If they're only making two a day, I doubt that there will be 
many around to "blow out."  However, if you find one around on a dealer's 
lot that has the goodies you want, remember not too many shoppers pay retail 
on new Porsches.  I recently heard from a normally reliable source that with 
the air cooled cars, a discount of 8% is not considered unusual (I did the 
math, it's big number in my tax bracket).   So if you know about a good car 
for sale, make an offer and see what happens.

Another idea, you could make friends with the used car or lease manager at a 
dealership and ask him/her to keep an eye out for a good car coming off 
lease.  The discount off new would be substantial.  Anyway, if you really 
like the 968, keep looking, it's a great car to drive.

>From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
>Often when a manufacturer discontinues a car they heavily discount them to
>blow them out...............


Dom Miliano

Date: 17 Apr 1995 13:10:13 PDT
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: 911: SCCA Stock Class


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: 911: SCCA Stock Class
Date: 1995-04-17 15:08
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Chris,
You'll probably get a few responses to your post, here's mine:

>1. Is there an SCCA rulebook for the 911, Porsches, or
>just a big one with everything in it ?  What's it called ?

1995 Solo 1& 2 Rulebook (SCCA).  Call 303-779-6622.  You may have to join to
get a copy and then it's $8 (I think, Sally bought this year's).

>2.  My car has standard seats (non-sport).  What are my options
>for keeping my butt more stationary ?  I figured that aftermarket
>seats would be "non-stock" and also figured that factory "sport
>seats" from the same year might be OK. How about later factory
>sport seats though (like from an RS America) ?

I think you have this one already.  Generally the rule is: if it's a factory
option for your EXACT model that was generally offered through US
dealerships, then you could put that option on.  The catch is, that if it's
one piece of an option set, you have to install the entire option set and
delete anything that optioned model *wouldn't* have had.  Other general rule
is: if the rulebook doesn't say you can do it you CAN'T...

>3. Turbo tie rods - do they make a difference and are they
>legal in stock class ?

Nope and Nope

>4. Here's what I think I know <g> please correct me:
 >- stiffer sway bars (Not Legal),

you can change the front one to whatever you want (including remove it) but
not the rear.

> - adjustable spring plates (N.L.),

Correct, it's not legal.

 - slight lowering with rack spacers (Legal?),

Nope, and not in Street Prepared either.  Superfast BSP driver Eric Messley
got caught at last year's nationals with rack spacers and it cost him the
Solo II and Pro Solo placings (and all his 1994 Pro Solo points). Lowering
by adjustment of factory suspension components is legal

> - racing harness (N.L.),

No, these are ok for the driver's side.  I believe you have to keep the
stock belts as well (this part of the rule is changing for Street Prepared,
though)

> - 7&8 x15 with nonstock profile tires (N.L.)

This is legal as long as the offset of the 7s and 8s are within 1/4" offset
of stock ones (since 7&8x 15s were an option by themselves), tires are free.

> - new rubber suspension bushings (L), non-rubber (N.L.)

Yup.  New OEM is ok, different is not.

>The tie rod question may seem out of place but I'm replacing the
>front shocks [already did the rear while I had the engine out]
>and doing the rack spacer thing. I figured I'll be getting the
>ride height and alignment done anyway so if I'm going to
>do the tie rods someday, now would be a good time.

I took mine *out* and used Carrera tie rods -- at AX speeds you won't tell a
difference, at track speeds you might, but I drove mine both ways before and
after Turbo Tie Rods and it's not a big deal....

> Yes, I feel guilty about asking these questions instead of doing
>all the research you folks already did but take it easy on the
>flames OK ?

Don't feel guilty -- it's far easier to keep on the right side of the rules
by asking questions before you start making wholesale changes.  I had
prepared our car to PCA rules and had to undo scads of stuff when we started
SCCA AXing...

 -Scott Jessen
SCCA ASP 911



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 16:12:35 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Track day at Lime Rock (long)

This is a description of my recent track day at Lime Rock with the
Connecticut Valley Region of the Porsche Club of America.

I recently purchased an 89 944 Turbo, and I was looking forward to a Driver
Ed event so that I could explore the car's (and my) performance in the proper
environment (no police, speed limits, idiots behind the wheel, etc). A
driver's ed event is the perfect place. The CVR had an event, and I was ready
to go.

First of all, getting there was very interesting. I live on Long Island, NY,
and I was meeting one of my friends at his mothers' house, which is only 45
minutes from the track. Since his wife was taking her own car there, my wife
and 8 month old daugher were going with me. My wife would go to the track
with his wife in a separate car. That led to one VERY packed 944. I remember
someone asked it is was possible to fit a baby seat in a 944 - it is. I also
had a stroller, play pen, and my track equipment. There was not room for
anything else. Of course it rained the entire trip to Kingston, but at least
the track day was dry.

This was my first track day of the year, and fourth total. I did three days
last year in an 86 normally aspirated 944, but I was looking for a car with
more performance, so I sold the 86, and bought an 89 turbo. For those of you
who are not aware, the 89 Turbo is the same as the 88 Turbo S, and includes a
247HP engine, really BIG brakes, and a stiffer suspension. 

The day started with a nice drive to the track, with my friend John in his
85.5 944 following me to the track on some nice winding backroads. A very
nice way to warm up your mind and car for the track day. At the track, it was
time to check in, and go through tech inspection.

Since I am still a novice, I had an instructor with me on the track, and we
met before the first run, to find out how much experience I had. When he
found out that I had car for only two weeks, and that I had 3 days track
experience, he got a little nervous, and starting mumbling something about
high performance cars, and the importance of being smooth. After a few laps
where he could see that I knew at least a little about what to do, he
relaxed, and the fun began.

There is only one word to describe the performance of the car - 
AWESOME. 
There is just so much power and brakes available at all times. ABS really
comes in handy. It makes finding the braking limits very easy. I was a little
worried about turbo lag, and the sharp power delivery of a turbocharged
engine, but it turns out there was nothing to worry about. At track speeds,
you are always turning such high RPMs that there is zero lag.

My instructor drives a 911 SC, and he was very impressed with my car. There
were more than a few instances where I made mistakes that he said would have
put his car off the track, but the 944's balance, brakes, and suspension
saved me. Since my instructor didn't know about 944s, I got a ride with
another instructor, who races 944 Turbos in PCA club racing. This way I go to
learn the 944 Turbo line around Lime Rock. I discovered a few turns that I
was taking wrong, and I even changed one shift point. That dropped my lap
times about 2 -3 seconds.

Some other things I noticed: Catching and passing other cars was a breeze. In
my 86 944, I really had to work to catch and then pass other cars. Unless I
was right behind going tinto the straight, the higher performance cars were
able to walk away from me down the straights. Even though I would be faster
in the turns, I could not pass very easily. With the Turbo, I could catch
anyone, and passing was just a matter of waiting for the passing signal, and
putting my foot to the floor. The only cars I could not just fly by were a
new 911 (993), and a 928 S4. The car ran great all day, and I did about 80
miles of track driving.

Now I have one very dirty car and I can't wait until my next track day. Due
to my schedule, that won't be until the end of May. At least my car will be
clean by then.

Later
Barry Lenoble
89 944 Turbo (White, how do I find out if it is Alpine or Grand Pix?)


------------------------------

Date: 17 Apr 1995 13:19:48 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re:  '86 928S Hatchback Rele

                      Subject:                              Time:  1:01 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         RE> '86 928S Hatchback Release        Date:  4/17/95

> When I pull the interior know to release the hatchback,
> I hear motor noises but ...

I've had the same problem with my '84 928S.

The motorized release retracts a little plastic edge
that is wedged over the hatch "catch" and the spring
inside the release mechanism then pushes the hatch
up a little to disengage the catch.

On my car I was able to get it working again by adjusting
the position of the catch on the hatchback.  There are two
allen head bolts holding the catch to the hatch.  Loosen
them slightly and then try different variations -- there is
enough adjustment available that you should be able to 
get it to work.  

I finally took a 2x4 and gently tapped the catch slightly 
on one side (the passenger, I think), tightened the bolts, 
and it worked again.

Before doing all of the above, it's probably a good idea to
see if the motorized release mechanism is really working,
not just making noises.  Take out the tool kit in the rear
of the deck; the release mechanism is visible if you lean
in and look under the rear lip. Get your significant other 
to sit in the car and trigger the release while you observe
the mechanism.  

Good Luck!

John
'84 928S


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 15:28:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: Nathan W Hanson <milhouse@csd.uwm.edu>
Subject: strange people/drivers

Do any of you get strange/aggressive responses from other drivers while 
in your Porsches?  For example, people cutting you off, trying to race in 
front of your, etc.  I decided to compare notes with ya'll on this list 
after 3 occurences of this kind of thing recently.  

Two of such occurences for me were rather harmless, nevertheless stupid.  
On the Milwaukee freeways twice in the past two weeks, I've had people 
pass me on the shoulder in *bumper to bumper, stop and go traffic*.  I'm 
sure they felt better being one car ahead of me for the next 20 minutes.  

Another incident was slightly more disturbing.  A guy in a crappy old 
Chevette came up behind me very close screaming, using various hand 
gestures, etc. 
to display his feelings for my speed of driving (I guess).  The funny 
thing was that I was in the far right lane driving at exactly the 
speed limit.  A similar thing happened to me in Minneapolis a few years 
ago when I had a 924, except this individual wanted me to pull over so he 
could "kick my #$%&*."  His screaming at me for no apparent reason was 
bone chilling (obviously he was a little nuts).  

So, is this type of thing 'par for the course' when one owns a nice car?  
I'm starting to think that a car such as mine attracts extreme 
responses--both postive and negative.
I highly doubt it is something I'm doing wrong, like being some horrible 
misfit driver.  I've never been in an accident and this type of thing has 
never happend to me in any car I've owned except Porsches. 

Nathan Hanson
1987 944S 
1992 Volvo 745


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 16:59:50 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 911 SCCA Stock Class Solo-I

Chris Bennet asked about SCCA Stock Class autocrossing his '86 Carrera :

1. Is there an SCCA rulebook for the 911, Porsches, or
   just a big one with everything in it ?  What's it called ?

There is only one book, and only a few pages are for Stock Class
modifications. There are very few. It is the Solo-II rulebook, $10.

2.  My car has standard seats (non-sport).  What are my options
    for keeping my butt more stationary ?  I figured that aftermarket
    seats would be "non-stock" and also figured that factory "sport
    seats" from the same year might be OK. How about later factory
    sport seats though (like from an RS America) ?

Any seats that were not available from the factory on an '86
are not legal. So get the stock '86 cloth sport seats.

3. Turbo tie rods - do they make a difference and are they
   legal in stock class ?

Not legal in Stock class. If yours are OK they are good enough anyway.

4. Here's what I think I know <g> please correct me:  
    - stiffer sway bars (Not Legal), 

Front bar would be legal, but an '86 uses the underbody style
bar, and the '86 already has the biggest front bar of this type
that Porsche offered. So there is not much you can do with this car.

 - adjustable spring plates (N.L.), 
 - slight lowering with rack spacers (Legal?),  

Yes, Not Legal. But lowering WITHOUT rack spacers is totally legal.

 - racing harness (N.L.), 

These are legal if you keep the original belts in the car.

 - 7&8 x15 with nonstock profile tires (N.L.)

Any size tire is legal on 7 and 8 x 15 rims on an '86 Carrera.
These wheels were a factory option. 225 and 245 50 series BFG tires
are the hot ticket for this car.

 - new rubber suspension bushings (L), non-rubber (N.L.)

Correct. Your '86 bushings are probably OK if your car does not have
very high mileage. My '72 bushings lasted about 100,000 miles, until
about '92. Then they died. An '86 has the best suspension of the
Carreras (same as later ones) so it is pretty good in Stock class.

Good luck!  Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com '72 911S


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 16:57:00 EST
From: "Gregory Nyce" <gnyce@nas.edu>
Subject: What would you do? (my mech. and I)

  I don't do the "outraged consumer" very well, so I'm looking for some
  other opinions.  Here's the situation...

  Dropped my 914 off at my mechanics on Sunday afternoon, March 19 (have
  done this once before).  I was not expected, but had no where else to go.
  Turns out they were in the middle of moving their shop to some other
  locale.  I could've driven it out there, but his wife (he wasn't there)
  assured me that it was no problem, leave the keys and a description of
  the problem, he'd call me.  No sweat.  Felt bad abandoning it there for
  them to deal with, but...

  He called on Tuesday.  Seemed a bit harried, with the move and all.  I
  stressed that I was not in a hurry, I understood the situation he was in,
  and since I commute by bicycle, my need was not great.  After 2 weeks, I
  called to see what was up.  Got a message back (voicemail) the next day
  or so.  Then, on Monday April 10 said he was going to try to have me on
  the road by Tuesday.  Didn't hear from him, so I called on Wednesday.
  Said I needed the car by Friday, was leaving for my folks house for
  Easter.  Later got a message (last Friday) that the part took 1 1/2 weeks
  to get here, and it was the wrong one, so he was driving [somewhere] to
  look for another (a switch in the steering column), would call me later
  on Friday.  He called and left a msg. on Friday at 7:00, was going to get
  the switch in Sat. morning.  Called Saturday at 1:00 pm, said he had the
  switch in but there appeared to be more electrical problems, and he
  wasn't going to be able to get it to me until Monday.

  Today is Monday and I have yet to hear from him.  My options are:  to
  bitch and complain; insist that he get it fixed this week, hell or high
  water; when it is fixed, expect the bill to have some $$ subtracted;
  charge him rent for having my car there for 1 month now; expect to be
  charged for parking; (add your own here).

  I like the guy, I want to appreciate his position and all, it's probably
  not all his fault, but... do I have just cause here?

  -Greg
  gnyce@nas.edu
  PS-I guess this is all justification for learning this stuff and becoming
  your own mechanic.  Easier to complain that way, but probably no better
  results.

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 14:07:34 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: "Standox" paint

All,

        After 9 mos of learning and procrastination, I'm about to have the
356 painted.  It needs a little body work, and repair of some poorly done
previous work.  I'm going to strip all trim and glass and take it to the
shop.  During the car's stay at the shop, I'll be dealing with chrome shops
and rubber suppliers.  The real fun starts in a month when I get to
reassemble everything, and match up the baggies of screws, etc., with the
pieces, and make them fit.

        One question for the painters in the group - The shop I selected
likes Standox Paint.  I've never heard of it.  He says it's German, and used
by Porsche, VW, Audi, etc., and is top quality.  It's a urethane top-coat
system, of course.  (I guess that's the paint of choice when stripping and
starting over.)  So, anyone heard of Standox paint, good or bad?

Bob

Bob Albrecht, San Diego Region
'83 SC Targa, Platinum
'65 SC, Battleship (Dolphin) Grey
Cat named "Mouse"

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 16:52:18 -0500
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re: Air Conditioning In The Porsche

Roger,

So, I got a question.  My '87 911 has a slow A/C leak somewhere.  I've had it
charged and over the course of about 2 months, it eventually stops blowing
cold and manages to produce a mere cool.  I had the UV dye inserted, and so
far (after 2 weeks) we have been unable to spot anything.  So, where might
this leak be occurring.  I mean how is it that I can't find the leak with the
black light.  I've heard that the long rubber hoses leading along the rocker
panels are a trouble spot.  Also, could it be leaking internally to the
compressor?  Will this dye eventually show up?  Should I just wait a
while longer?  What are the most common trouble sources?  Anyway, your wisdom
would be appreciated.

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 15:03:56 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers


- --Boundary-8207168-0-0

Hi Nathan:  So, you've discovered that the juices that flow for you when you 
see a Porsche are different than the juices that flow for others when they see 
the beast. 
 
Grin and bear it and realize that whether it's jealousy, envy, tree hugging 
sympathies or whatever else that incites these folks, the bottom line is that 
you're having fun driving and they are probably driving some average piece of 
s**t and having little fun if any. 
 
I had a red Ferrari 308 GTS and that car caused multitudes of seemingly normal 
people to display a very interesting range of emotions and responses to their 
emotional ebbs and flows. The GT350 Shelby Mustang I drive makes some people 
nuts, especially the younger set with street racing fantasies. 
 
The 930 I used to have was pretty intimidating to lots of folks.  One look at 
the Porsche in their rear view mirror and they either couldn't seem to move 
over fast enough or they'd slow down intentionally and struggled with their 
insecurities by blocking me or tapping their brakes.  I wasn't on their butt 
or going excessively fast, just there, with something they didn't have that 
made them realize how boring and unsuccessful their little lives were. 
 
The 356's seem to inspire different reactions.  Most people smile and seem to 
enjoy them.  I guess they aren't viewed as being as fast for their era as the 
later cars.  
 
So, rejoice in the reality that you're ok but some others should have their 
dosages adjusted. 
 
 
Ted Smith 


- --Boundary-8207168-0-0

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 18:07:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: Don Rubin <rubin@moe.setinc.com>
Subject: 89 951 oil leak

I have scanned the messages for the last few months and haven't found this
problem addressed directly so sorry in advance if this is old news.

My 89 951 has 27K miles, I am not the original owner but I know him and
this car has had a small but annoying oil leak since it was new. When
I bought the car at 20K miles, I had the pan gasket replaced because that
was the most likely (according to my mechanic) source of the leak. No change.
When the clutch went (those pesky little springs on the OE clutch) I had
the dealer replace the rear crank seal while he was doing the clutch. It 
kept leaking perhaps worse. When I brought the car back in and complained 
he had the same mechanic replace the seal assuming it was defective. Well 
within 100 miles it was leaking again. I 
talked to the dealer and PCNA tech and was told "well your problem is the
engine is developing too much crackcase pressure and it is blowing oil
by the seal", they said a leakdown test indicated bad readings on several
cylinders. Time out, I went to my mechanic who in my presence did a leakdown
which was marginal in three cylinders BUT the problem was not the rings
which might have explained the high crankcase pressure but the exhaust 
valves. I assumed that it must have been carbon build up (the car is mostly
driven only to/from/at track events) and had been on short trips and had
been sitting since fall. Last weekend I went to Summit Point for a track
event, on the way home after the 1st day, when I stopped at a light smoke
poured from the hood. As best as I can tell the leak got slightly worse
and the oil burns when it falls on the hot exhaust system. The car uses
very little oil and there is no puddle on the driveway. Anyone have
any ideas? I plan to complain to Porsche because in my opinion there has
always been this problem and they should fix it. I just wish I had the
solution. Also today I talked with someone who said to check the
crankcase breather system, there may be a leak in one of the hoses or the
oil fill system but its hard to get to (you have to remove the maniford).
Sorry for the long saga.

Don Rubin


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 15:04 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Re: What would you do? (my mech. and I)


  Hey Greg,

  If your car was fixed to your satisfaction, you like the
  mechanic and plan to use him again, I would say to
  suck it up and not bitch about it vociferously or expect
  a lot back (i.e. discounts for inconvenience), unless
  you know that he is trying to take advantage of you.
  From your description of the situation, I would guess
  that you will gain much more in future service (again,
  assuming that the mechanic is straight with you) if you
  let him know that you needed it sooner but keep a
  level head about it.

  Also, in the future, whether or not you need it soon, agree
  on a tentative timetable (" I need it no later than X date")
  that you both agree to.

  These are, of course, opinions, so YMMV

  Good luck,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 18:22:51 -0400
From: NEIL13@aol.com
Subject: Re: Tires for a 993/Top speed

Lance, 

I couldn't agree with you more in your assessment of the 993.  I, too,
haven't "topped out" the car. I have seen 175 on the speedo but had to back
off. This was, of course, in a most special location away from innocent
bistanders.  The car was rock steady at that speed (the outside,rearview
mirrors were vibrating a bit, however).  This was with a passenger (she
noticed the mirror vibration).  Here in Florida you have to remember to shut
down the AC somewhere north of 150!

And you talk about addictive, I have put more miles on the 993 in 8 months
than I did my  last car in two years!
Thank God for Mike Valentine!
 
Pleasant motoring

Neil

Some minor modifications to #7, One new Patron, and a +$10 adjustment:

My thanks for the patience and *Generosity* of those of you who sent your
checks, and have been waiting for me to get off my duff and get them in
the bank.  

I made this deposit of $1,155 (less a bounce of $50, plus a make-up Money 
Order of $60 from the bouncer), we now have $6,625 in the Bank (we're getting 
5% interest, so we actually have a few more pennies than that).  Bank was open 
today, Monday after I got home from work.

It gives me great pleasure to join you all in offering our special thanks
to our new Patrons:  Mike Valentine, (Maker of the Famous Valentine One
Radar Detector, widely recognized as the best in the business, who sent
us a *VERY* generous check, and is now *easily* our largest benefactor)
and to our other new Patron, Larry Reynolds, our specialist in Car Care
products!  Also, after preparing this, I got a Patron check from Ken
Roscrow, so I want to recognize him with these other fine folks.

Did I mention that it's easy for anyone to take advantage of our easy
upgrade policy, to join the exhaulted rank of Patron, merely by sending
another check to bring your total up to $100 (or *more*, if the spirit
moves...)

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 15:54:21 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: '73 914 2.0L CV Joints

Hi Steve:

A few years ago I went through the process of replacing the inner CV
joints, then a couple of months later the outer ones for good measure, on
my daily-driver BMW.  It doesn't seem to have suffered. It took me a while
to figure out the CV joint assembly "trick" - now I keep one on my desk as
a brain teaser.

However, when it came time to do my 914 I just bought all-new axles and
replaced the whole lot. Much less aggravating, to be sure. And about the
same price (Lobro does both BMW and Porsche).

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 17:26:32 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: Porsche sightings in movies


What about Doc Holiday?  Did anyone catch it on Sunday night? i

Michael J. Fox's character drove a beautiful red '57 speedster.  After getting
in an accident, he gets stuck in a hick town waiting for the car to be fixed
by some local yocals.  I particularly like the scene when he enters the 
local garage to see his entire engine laid out in pieces on the floor.

I also liked the fact that the mechanic said he needed a new oil pump and 
mentioned he had found a guy in Seattle with one and the guy wanted $300
for it.  I bed many of us have experienced that one before, eh?

To bad it got hit by a semi near the end of the film...

Subject: Those *#$&@ 914 sunvisors!

Has anyone figured out a way to keep the 914 sunvisors tight and well 
in their slots in the retaining clips? What with the constant up and 
down whenever you take the top off/put it on, the pins that come out 
from the sides of the visors always seem to pull in, and then I have to 
unscrew them, pull them out, and screw them tight again... Plus 
sometimes they don't rotate in the retaining clips like they should, 
they just pull themselves loose... It's ARGHHHHH annoying!!!

Not a huge problem, just a bothersome one. :)

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 19:39:32 -0400 (EDT)
From: Adam Wolf Farkas <afarkas@umich.edu>
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers

sigh. porsche prejudice rears its ugly head again.  I really don't know 
what it is about these cars. case in point:  I frequently drive from 
detroit to binghamton NY.. the quickest and most entertaining way to go 
is across canada (no cops, no people, no kidding.)  Unfortunately, this 
necessitates the dreaded "border stop"... These are usually very trivial, 
they ask you where you're from, where you're going, and what you've got 
in the car.  In my subaru, this is no problem. takes 15 seconds & you're 
across. In the 944.. ohboy.  I get these strange looks. "hey boy, how can 
a student afford one of them jobbies"... (i feel like saying "hey buddy, 
that camry you just let fly thru is worth three times as much".. but i 
hold my tongue.)  I've also had to pull over and had my car SEARCHED more 
than once... said they were looking for "drugs and guns" (!) ok, i guess 
my florida plates don't help...
Interestingly, the women at the border have never given me a hard time. 
they are always more curious about the picture of a manatee on the 
plate.  they don't seem to care. 

... the hassle is still more fun than having to drive thru ohio :)

adam
'87 944
 

///--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Adam Farkas
University of Michigan Medical School
Ann Arbor, MI

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 19:50:14 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers

Adam Farkas bent the electrons thusly...

... the hassle is still more fun than having to drive thru ohio :)

- ---

	You just don't know how to drive in Ohio....  Stay off the turnpike,
plot a course along 2-lane roads.  Most are surprisingly well paved and
have passing lanes.  Around where I live (very eastern Ohio/western PA)
I drive around 65-70 on a regular basis and still get passed
occasionally.  Then again, I'm usually driving a VW Golf or an old
pickup (that is really fast, just doesn't look it ;) ) so I probably
don't attract as much attention as you would.

happy speeding,

Nate

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 20:13:06 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: Re: Any deals to be had?

On Mon, 17 Apr 1995 Maestro103@aol.com said: 
 
 
>Excuse, I am what you refer to as a Newbie?  Are you saying that they have
or  
>are about to discontinue the 968?  I am flabbergasted! I am going to
purchase a  
>very clean 944 at the end of June, and I was under the impression that the
968  
>was going to be around for awhile. 
> 
>I am very new, so I don't know if I have to include my address, or if it
will  
>automatically be included with the message.  Well here goes  
- -- 
 
The address is included. Whilst I was scamming a copy of "Are You
Listening" (the 993 sales video) at the NY Auto Show (damn, couldn't get a
press kit),I asked the PCNA rep why there wasn't a 928GTS at the show. She
said that it was discontinued and there were less than 50 new ones left in
the country. Of course, I believe that is about a year's supply at the
typical sales rate for 928's these days. She also said that production had
ended on the 968, and that Boxters (the new entry-level Porsche) would be
available in early '96 as a '97 model. Things could change. I understand
that Porsche's assembly line is very flexible. But for now the supplies of
968's is finite. Since I still see the occasional '93 and '94 leftover
968's sold new, I don't think that you will find it hard to get a new 968
for the next 1-2 years. There was a silver 968 at the show, BTW. 
Triet Le

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 17:31:11 -0700
From: krc@tlg.net (Ron Calef)
Subject: Rough cold start 86 Carrera

Bought an 86 Carrera w/122,000 miles  6 months ago.  It started great until

sputters for a couple of minutes.  The manual says not to let it "warm up"

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 17:42:31 -0700
From: dem@best.com (Dennis Mitsch)
Subject: whee, a 914


Looks like I go both ways now. :) (water cooled and air cooled).

Just picked up a '74 914 2.0.  Not sure if it's the special edition
that went out that year or not?  It has the central console, mahle
rims, etc.  Is there any other identifying marks?

The Stuff:
153K, 60K on bottom end rebuild, less than 1000 miles on top end.
New transmission, clutch, injectors, tires, some interior bits
Compression 140ish on all cylinders.

A bit of rust in the rear trunk where water had settled.  Pretty
much surface rust so hopefully I'll take care of it this weekend with
the ol' wire brush, rust neutralizer and rustoleum paint.

The interior is fairly beat, but I didn't buy this car because it was
beautiful.  No accidents, some minor dents and dings.

Will need brakes and struts some time in the near future.  My mechanic
also mentioned that the rotors have gone "off".  Basicly they're all
black.  He says that turning them wouldn't help, etc.  I've never
heard of this one before.  Can someone explain how rotors go "bad"?

Of course, I spent more than I intended to.  $4500.  I personally
don't think it was a steal, but a fair enough price.

More reports as they develop. :)

Dennis Mitsch
1988 944S
1974 914 2.0 (white)

of charge to the first person to respond.

	They are from a 1/24 scale plastic model kit.

Why do I have them?
	I work for a company that makes graphics products.  The model
	was used for digitizing into a software model.  The wheels and tires
	were left over.  They looked too nice to throw away.

Why would you want them?
	I dunno.  They're free.  They'd make nice decoration or earrings.

I wouldn't be caught dead behind the wheel of a P-car :-)

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 18:02:00 PDT
From: Bill Ataras <Bill_Ataras@ccm.jf.intel.com>
Subject: Re[2]: strange people/drivers


Text item: 

What were your Ferrari experiences like ? I'm half dreaming about getting an

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers
Author:  porschephiles-request@tta.com at SMTPGATE
Date:    4/17/95 3:03 PM


- --Boundary-8207168-0-0

Hi Nathan:  So, you've discovered that the juices that flow for you when you 
see a Porsche are different than the juices that flow for others when they see 
the beast.

Grin and bear it and realize that whether it's jealousy, envy, tree hugging 
sympathies or whatever else that incites these folks, the bottom line is that 
you're having fun driving and they are probably driving some average piece of 
s**t and having little fun if any.

I had a red Ferrari 308 GTS and that car caused multitudes of seemingly normal 
people to display a very interesting range of emotions and responses to their 
emotional ebbs and flows. The GT350 Shelby Mustang I drive makes some people 
nuts, especially the younger set with street racing fantasies.

The 930 I used to have was pretty intimidating to lots of folks.  One look at 
the Porsche in their rear view mirror and they either couldn't seem to move 
over fast enough or they'd slow down intentionally and struggled with their 
insecurities by blocking me or tapping their brakes.  I wasn't on their butt 
or going excessively fast, just there, with something they didn't have that 
made them realize how boring and unsuccessful their little lives were.

The 356's seem to inspire different reactions.  Most people smile and seem to 
enjoy them.  I guess they aren't viewed as being as fast for their era as the 
later cars.

So, rejoice in the reality that you're ok but some others should have their 
dosages adjusted.


Ted Smith


- --Boundary-8207168-0-0
X-Orcl-Content-Type: message/rfc822

Received: 17 Apr 1995 13:39:33                    Sent: 17 Apr 1995 13:39:12 
From:"Nathan W Hanson " <porschephiles-request@tta.com>
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: strange people/drivers
Reply-to: porschephiles-request@tta.com 
X-Orcl-Application: Mime-Version:  1.0
X-Orcl-Application: Content-Type:  TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII


Do any of you get strange/aggressive responses from other drivers while 
in your Porsches?  For example, people cutting you off, trying to race in 
front of your, etc.  I decided to compare notes with ya'll on this list 
after 3 occurences of this kind of thing recently.

Two of such occurences for me were rather harmless, nevertheless stupid. 
On the Milwaukee freeways twice in the past two weeks, I've had people 
pass me on the shoulder in *bumper to bumper, stop and go traffic*.  I'm 
sure they felt better being one car ahead of me for the next 20 minutes.

Another incident was slightly more disturbing.  A guy in a crappy old 
Chevette came up behind me very close screaming, using various hand 
gestures, etc.
to display his feelings for my speed of driving (I guess).  The funny 
thing was that I was in the far right lane driving at exactly the
speed limit.  A similar thing happened to me in Minneapolis a few years 
ago when I had a 924, except this individual wanted me to pull over so he 
could "kick my #$%&*."  His screaming at me for no apparent reason was 
bone chilling (obviously he was a little nuts).

So, is this type of thing 'par for the course' when one owns a nice car? 
I'm starting to think that a car such as mine attracts extreme 
responses--both postive and negative.
I highly doubt it is something I'm doing wrong, like being some horrible 
misfit driver.  I've never been in an accident and this type of thing has 
never happend to me in any car I've owned except Porsches.

Nathan Hanson
1987 944S
1992 Volvo 745



- --Boundary-8207168-0-0--

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 18:06:34 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers

Nathan asked:

>Do any of you get strange/aggressive responses from other drivers while 
>in your Porsches?  For example, people cutting you off, trying to race in 
>front of your, etc.  I decided to compare notes with ya'll on this list 
>after 3 occurences of this kind of thing recently.  

Two weeks ago (SF Bay Area) I was driving my nice-looking '72 Alfa GTV
(Alfa red) coupe in the far right lane, at the speed limit, totally
non-aggressive, and the next thing I knew psycho delivery-van driver from
hell was trying to run me down, honking, gesticulating, getting way too
close, etc. I moved away from him (a couple hundred yards), and took the
next (intended) exit.  As I did I watched him in my rear-view mirror, and I
saw him abort his intended delivery, zoom across traffic to take the exit,
and continue to hound me (I'd change lane, he'd change lane, etc.). This
was getting serious, as it seemed he had every intention of smashing into
me.  So I had to cut left (he followed), and then go way right across three
lanes (it was clear, thankfully - there was some planning involved :) ) to
take the right-turn-on-red. He followed, but I lost him in an area I know
well.  

If it hadn't been for that exit opportunity (the light for all four lanes
was red and traffic was backed up) I'm quite sure he would have either hit
me on purpose or caused an equally unpleasant altercation.  What on earth
was bothering him I'll never know.

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 18:31:25 -0700
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: Re: 951 oil leak


Don & others-

Have your had the gaskets at the rear of the cam tower checked
(by the firewall). I had a leak in a similar fashion to your
long description, eventually got so bad that one morning I couldn't
see anything behind me on the way to the repair shop. It dumps the
oil down the back of the block onto the header near the
wastegate. Mine was misdiagnosed once as a pan gasket (but I really
needed a new pan gasket anyway, FYI- if you have to replace a pan
gasket you might as well do the rod bearings since they are right
there looking at you).

Anyway- check it out.

good luck.

 -jim

for free!!  The guy who developed Cool Carbons works for NASA or the Army
(I forget) here in Huntsville, AL & he *gave* this friend of mine the set.  I
need to work a deal like that...

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 21:35:10 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 911 CIS injector insulators?

Hey,

While rooting around in my engine compartment tonight (I have a bad
habit of just kinda getting in there and looking at stuff), I decided to
pull one of my injectors and see how hard it is to replace the seal.
Unlike every other job I undertake that starts out this way, replacing
the seal was easy.  I even put the injector in a glass and turned on the
ignition and lifted up the sensor beam.  Voila!  Fuel!  The injector itself
seemed to be fine - nice conical spray pattern and it didn't leak when
I let the sensor beam back down (not bad for 19 year old injectors).

Now to the point of this rambling.  Replacing the seal did not reduce the
injector's relative motion in the intake runner.  I think the play is in the
insulator (?).  I heard that these are a b*tch to replace?  I don't have
any evidence of air leaking past the seals/insulators, so this isn't a big
deal, but I'm curious to know what's involved in replacing the insulators.

Thanks,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 22:11:08 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Trail Braking

After my letter on braking and turning in, several people asked me to go
deeper (all puns intended) into the concept of trail braking.  The idea of
trail braking is quite simple, you just continue your braking into the turn,
much as I described in the last letter.  Most people actually do some trail
braking naturally.  Where trail braking becomes complex is in it's
application; i.e. which corners should you trail brake in, and how much?  To
further examine this, we have to explain what car rotation is.

Rotation, for those of you unfamiliar with the term, is where the back of the
car starts to purposefully oversteer at the entrance to a corner, in order to
help the car turn in.  When you turn in on the brakes, the front will turn
immediately because it is heavily weighted.  The rear will start to generate
cornering force, and if those forces are great enough, it will start to slide
(oversteer).  The instant that it starts to slide is when you would get back
on the gas.  This will load the rear, and stop the slide.  You will also have
turned (rotated) the car more than if you just turned the steering wheel.
 This can help if your car does not turn in well (understeer).  That is what
rotation is, and I could write a letter on just that subject as well.

Now let's take the three types of corners separately.  They are the
increasing radius, the constant radius, and the decreasing radius.  I have
listed these in order of growing importance with respect to trail braking.
 Finally I am assuming that your car will be neutral or have understeer.  We
can discuss the merits to oversteer vs. understeer at a later date.

In a typical increasing radius corner, of about 90 to 100 degrees, the need
for trail braking is minor.  If your car turns in to the apex well, you probab
ly will lift off of the brakes as you start to turn into the corner, and you
can pick up the gas rightaway.  If your car has a little understeer, you may
need to hold the brakes until the car starts to rotate, and then make the
transition to the gas.  If the corner is high speed, you probably do not want
any rotation, as this will affect car stability, and reduce the entrance
speed more than it will help you to "get around" the corner.

In a constant radius corner, you will want to trail brake past the turn in
point.  You will need to get some car rotation in order to be pointed at the
apex, so that you can pickup the gas and accelerate across the apex, and out
of the turn.  The reason for this is that the apex is located further around
the turn than in an increasing radius corner, and you have to get more of the
turn accomplished in the beginning.  In order to continue braking past the
turn in point, you must go deeper before you start braking, and therefore
carry more speed into the corner, because you will still be doing some more
braking in the corner.  This is why people who trail brake can "outbrake"
those who don't.  They are giving themselves more room to brake.

In a decreasing radius corner, you must trail brake.  You have to go very far
into the corner before you can even see the apex, so you must carry speed
through the beginning of the corner.  Some fast, long decreasing radius
corners (Big Bend at Lime Rock, Turn 17 at Sebring) give you the room to
double apex, and some people actually make two corners out of one (brake - tur
n in and accelerate past apex #1 - brake again - turn in again - accelerate
past apex #2 and out of the turn).  That is fine, but they still must do some
trail braking at the beginning of the corner.  Tighter turns require
aggressive trail braking where you literally stuff the car into the corner
hard on the brakes, and wait for the rear to "come around".  When it does,
you "catch it" with the gas and accelerate past the apex.  This is the only
way to get the car to point itself towards the apex (other than to go slow!).

So that's the basics of trail braking.  I feel that a car should be set up
for slight understeer, to get a stable platform, and then driven, using
techniques like trail braking, to get through the turns under full power.
 Let me know which topic you want me to cover next.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 22:21:46 -0400
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Re: Fire Extinguishers

Dear Bill:

The best place to mount a 2 1/2 lb fire extinguisher in a 911 is on top of
the transmission hump where it meets the rear seat.  There is an inspection
cover under the carpets.  The bracket will screw into this cover with no
chance of hitting anything (like brake/fuel lines).  Mounting the fire
extinguisher here will allow access with the driver strapped in the seat.

Place the extinguisher and bracket on the hump to position the bracket.
 Remove the extinguisher and mark 3-4 holes using a grease pencil.  Remove
the bracket.  Spread the carpet apart on the marks and put a drop of clear
nail polish on the jute carpet backing.  Allow to dry and then drill through
the nail polish with the proper size drill.  The jute backing will not walk
up the drill bit when you stabilize it with the nail polish.  I recommend
using pan head #8 sheet metal screws 1" to 1 1/8" long.  Remove the
extinguisher from the bracket and screw the bracket down.  Replace the
extinguisher and you are ready to go.  If you remove the bracket, fluff up
the carpet and you won't see the holes.

If possible, I would strongly suggest getting a Halon fire extinguisher with
a double bracket.  Dry chemical extinguishers are a lot cheaper but will ruin
little things like the electrical system, engines and any other aluminum
parts.  If you can't find a Halon extinguisher locally, I stock them and your
cost would be $65.00 less 10% with shipping included.

If you have any other question, please give me a shout.

Thank you,

 Larry Reynolds
 Car Care Specialties, Inc.
 Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
 Post Office Box 535
 Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663-0535
 Phone (201) 796-8300
 Fax (201) 791-9743
 E-mail carcaresp@aol.com
 Old enough to remember when sex was safe and race cars were  dangerous

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 19:32:03 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Targa Top Resto


Steve-

I didn't find getting a tight top a real challenge.  I put
the top on with the frame completely unfolded, starting my
glueing (gluing?) from the center and working towards the
sides.  It had a few 'lumps' when done, but they disappeared
after a day or two in the sun.

I think you have to be careful about getting it too tight.  I
actually recall a posting where someone said they had to do it
twice because the first time was too tight.

Your idea of installing the top with the unit almost,
but not quite unfolded, is a good one, though.  Let us
know how it turns out.

Bob Spindel

P.S.  The bottom line, I think, is that you will have a
brand new top for about $100, instead of $500.  You can spend
the difference on useful stuff like Slick 50, or spitfire plugs...

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 23:05:23 -0400
From: RobVial@aol.com
Subject: Help on buying tires

I posted a note last week about my 944S2 tires and got some good
recommendations from some of you.  Thanks a lot.  I decided to get Dunlop
SP8000's (better wet traction than Yoko's and it rains plenty here in south Lo
uisiana).

Anyhow, I tried to get my tires from the Tire Rack (800-428-8355) and the guy
whom I spoke with was really terrific (John Wompler? x388).  Unfortunately
the Dunlops were out of stock.  I called Dunlop and asked if there were any
dealers in my area.  They asked if I was interested in mail order.  I told
them I had already contacted the Tire Rack but they said there is another
mail order company, Discount Tire Direct (800-831-3456).

I had never heard of them but they had the tires I wanted in stock at about
the same price as the Tire Rack.  They weren't much on the technical support
but they are definately a good second choice to the Tire Rack.

Well, I'm waiting until Friday for my tires.  Then off to Florida for a few
days with the wife.

Rob Vial
1989 944S2 (on crutches)

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 20:08:36 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Trail Braking

Hi Larry:

I'm enjoying reading your posts on getting around the racetrack more
quickly.  I'm just getting into racing, and I have a (perhaps subtle)
question. If it's not too much trouble, can you give me/us your thoughts on
the matter? Thanks.

My question is pretty simple, I hope. When taking corners, is there any
time when it's advantageous to set the car up so that it's stronly
unbalanced? Moreso than the relatively simple case of waiting to get on the
power once the rear comes 'round?

I ask this because I've always driven a line that comes very naturally for
me - one where I'm acutely aware of the car's balance, and where
(correctable) drifts are the obvious and natural way to go faster. I'm
generally a late braker, too. But after reading Vic Elford's book and his
example of the fastest way to get around an icy 180-degree turn (spin the
car till you're going nearly backwards into the turn, then come straight
out) I wonder if there aren't some instances (on a racetrack) where my
approach & attitude prevent me from picking up on some quite radical
manouvers.

Thanks again,

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 21:15:50 -0600
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Update on 912 RTV & Overheat problem

Fellow P-philes,

First let me thank all of you that responded to my plea for help regarding 
two problems (at least) on my 912's engine rebuild: Blue RTV Form-A-Gasket 
in the sump and a serious overheating problem.

The blue junk was traced to the valve covers. Nice huh ?

The overheating was more difficult:

1) I checked the timing. Not too bad but I will need to rebuild my 050  
distributor (or find an original replacement)) as information provided by 
Stan pointed to an irregular/erratic advance curve.

2) I rebuilt the Webers. It took longer than I thought, but I did not want 
to make any mistakes. I may be slow but I'm not good yet |-)

3) Checked the valve clearances. (That's how I found the source of the RTV).

4) Checked the fan impeller (as per Harry's suggestion) and did not find any 
paper towels lodged in there as I had sheepishly hoped.

5) Then I thought. Ahem. I wish there was a way to check if the oil cooler 
was operating without dropping the engine. Hey, why not pull the 
generator/impeller assembly and inspect the cooler through the hole in the 
fan housing ?

Well the final test was the one that revealed an oil cooler absolutely 
encrusted with what I can only describe as tar. I mean this baby could not 
possibly hope to get even a single breath of cool air!

Then I had mixed feelings. I remember pulling the oil cooler out and 
inspecting it maybe less than 8 years ago. It was as clean as a whistle. 
This was before I had the engine rebuilt after finding an exhaust leak and 
burnt valve. 

Has anyone ever encountered a similar situation. Could the exhaust leak have 
resulted in a buildup of oil deposits on the oil cooler ?

I can't understand how the oil cooler became clogged after such a relatively 
short period (few miles and 2 years in cosmetic restoration). 

Well I'm going to inspect the engine further and will keep you posted on 
further developments. Thanks again for your help ! Special thanks to Stan 
and Harry!
Chris Jungmann                                   jungmann@swcp.com
Software Development                             Voice: 505-275-6566
Northern Systems, Inc.                           Fax:   203-373-0880
                                                 BBS:   203-373-0881

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 00:26:21 -0300
From: cbt@eduplus.ca (stephen davies)
Subject: 944 Vibration

Shortly after buying a 1988 944 Turbo S I noticed a disturbing vibration in
the shift lever and to a lesser extent in the clutch pedal between 3000 and
3100 RPM. My local dealer thinks it is either a warped flywheel or bad
clutch. The clutch is shows some sign of wear (engaging near the end of
pedal travel) but engages smoothly most of the time with no slippage. I
have the dealer bought 1 year warranty that covers most repairs but not the
clutch. Before I initiate major repairs I would like to here from others
who may be familiar with the problem. 

Also, since it appears that I might have to drop the transmission for the
above reason or due to another problem (also have a worn second gear
syncro), I am wondering how much the lower ring and pinion (same as 944S)
costs and how much extra labour is involved ?

Stephen Davies
1988 944 TURBO S

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 00:04:47 -0400
From: DougBugs@aol.com
Subject: my 914 sings soprano

My 914 makes a high pitched noise very similar to the noise a teapot makes
when it's boiling. The noise also has a high and low that I believe is
brought about through a rotational movement. I believe the noise is coming
from the drivers side rear but, there is too much engine noise to confirm
this. I have recently changed tires but, the noise was present before the
change. I have also taken it out of gear and cut the engine off at 60 miles
per hr, changed lanes and taken sharp corners in this mode and the sound did
not stop. The sound does not change its tone at all. At all 30 miles per hr
it starts and makes the exact same sound at 80. When I slow down to 25 miles
per hour it disappears. Could someone please list all the possibilities and
remedies to solve this problem. P.S. I have jacked the back wheels up and
spun them by hand and no noise was detected. Thanks, Doug Franks 1974   914
  2.0

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 21:06:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Timothy A. Budd" <budd@rohan.sdsu.edu>
Subject: Strange Drivers

Well, I guess this is as good as any place to tell this little tale:

My friend just bought a 1986 Guards Red 911.  Sufice it to say, he was 
itching to DRIVE it.  He pulled up to a stop light on the outskirts of 
town, when a Highway Patrol officer pulled up next to him.  This road, 
let me tell you, is very seldom traveled and very straight and flat.
Both of them pull off the line together and travel the speed limit for a 
block or two, them come across anohter stoplight.  Both wait..the light 
turns green, once again, both parties travel at the speed limit for a 
couple of blocks, until they reach a third stoplight.   The highway 
patrol office then rolls down his window, motions for my friend to do the 
same, then says "This must really be killing you."  Then he smiles, turns 
onto the freeway, then is gone.

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 23:31:27 -0700 (PDT)
From: Christopher Kirk <kirkch@elwha.evergreen.edu>
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers



On Mon, 17 Apr 1995, Nathan W Hanson wrote:

> Do any of you get strange/aggressive responses from other drivers while 
> in your Porsches?  For example, people cutting you off, trying to race in 
> front of your, etc.  I decided to compare notes with ya'll on this list 
> after 3 occurences of this kind of thing recently.  


Can't say I ever had any troubles while driving, but I used to deliver 
pizza... usually used an old Ford (rather abuse a Ford than a P-car), but 
every now and then I couldn't resist using my 81 924. It has a terrific 
paint job and looks sharp, and it sure was a kick when people noticed 
their pizza boy pulling up to their house in a Porsche!

Once, while sitting outside the restaurant, some redneck drove by in a 
huge jacked-up old Chevy truck (you know the kind) and just yelled out 
the window in amazement: "Godd*mn pizza driver drives a Godd*mn Porsche!" 

Also interesting was pulling up to a shabby house and receiving a 
generous tip from folks who could obviously use an extra couple of bucks 
themselves... they'd notice the car and ask what kind it is, and I'd say, 
"Well, that's a... Porsche, actually... *ahem*..." No one ever asked for 
their tip back, though!  ;-)

Christopher Kirk
Evergreen State College, Olympia WA
81 True Blue 924 (humble but beloved)

    Now that gave me a good laugh... last summer I was the official
delivery beast over at the local Pizza Slut... nobody could deliver a
pizza faster!  Well, I usually drove my mom's old VW Golf (we had an
agreement - my parents didn't want me to have to pay insurance for a car
of my own...) but the clutch went out about halfway through the summer
(NOT MY FAULT!!! I knew it was going bad so I never used the damn thing
except at stoplights) so I was sans wheels for about two weeks.
    Now my Regular Fans (yeah right) may remember my description of my
dad's Tow Pickup From Hell.,.. a '73 Chevy stepside, lowered, forest
green (almost black) blacked out chrome, lowered, 8" rims, headers, dual
pipes, etc....  Anyhoo, you get the idea. Handled like a sports car,
accelerated faster.  Looked evil.  I don't know how many people said
"oh, yeah, I saw you looking for my house, but I didn't think you were
the pizza guy..."  I was, however, very popular with the gearhead set at
the store, especially since nobody could really believe that a skinny,
bespectacled CMU type would have actually done most of the work on such
a badass machine.  Goes to show...
    As for the tips... kinda sad, but the best tippers are the people
who just moved up a rung on the ol' job ladder from pizza dude... but I
digress.

later,

Nate.... who really doesn't want to schlep pies again this summer....

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 12:01:02 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Groaning noise from brakes

	My 911 3.2 Carrera is making a groaning noise from one of the front 
wheels when the car rolls forward after braking (i.e., I brake, take my 
foot off the brake pedal to let the car roll forward a little, and the 
noise occurs).

	On the suggestion of one of the mechanics at the local Porsche 
dealership, I removed the pads on that wheel, cleaned out the caliper with 
brake cleaner and put back the pads (original Porsche items, with plenty of 
meat left on them), using some Coppaslip on the back of the pads.

	But ... it has made absolutely no difference!!

	Any ideas?

Philip Katz	<P.M.Katz@cam3se.boat.bt.com>

quoted here!). If you get a "bounce" message from any mail sent to me, 
**Please** forward it to me at <P.M.Katz@bt-web.bt.co.uk>.

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 07:31:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: M Suzanne Arnold <msarnold@oise.on.ca>
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers

Nathan,

You wrote that you experience testy drivers who "harrass" you when you're 
out in your Porsche.

I don't think that this is an uncommon occurance.  Strangely enough, I 
have the most trouble with people in Minivans (?).  P-cars seem to send a 
signal to people that " Hey, let's see what this rich-guy (gal) can do ! 
".  Although in defense of those people, I will admit that when I'm out 
in my other car and I see a P-car go by, I sub-conciously find myself 
speeding up.  I don't think this is a decidedly aggressive response, but 
rather the brain telling me that I'd rather be driving my P. too.

Unfortunately, this problem gets even worse with the local boys-in-blue 
who see me ( 22 years old ) driving my 911 and naturally assume it's either 
stolen or I sell drugs.  In one month alone I was pulled over six times 
to explain the situation, thankfully Smoky saw my way and thankfully I 
have yet to get ticketed.

The point is that when you have this type of car, others naturally assume 
two things;
		1 : you have lotsa money
		2 : you like to go fast

It can certainly be a pain at times but no matter what happens, you're 
still the one in the Porsche and they're not.

Enough of my drible, 

Work Hard - Play Hard

Jonathan c/o msarnold@oise.on.ca

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 08:51:28 -0400
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: No Subject


Dear Scott,
You wrote,
<OK fellow 914 folks. Here is some intesting news. A 914 rear shift <trans
<can be converted to a side shift by replacing the side shift <mechanism, 2
<studs, rear cover and shift forks.  The final drive casings are <identical.
<The gears are supposedly the same.  Any discussion?  Anyone have <any of
<these parts laying around?  Thanks to Otto for this information.


Conversion of the early model ('70-'72) tail shifting 914 transaxle to the
later (73-76) sideshifting unit is easier than you think. You don't even have
to replace the rear cover if you don't have one. Simply 3 shift forks and the
shift console complete the job.

These days, the parts are readily available and the conversion is very
rewarding. However, with the conversion, the additional shifting and engine
mounting parts must also be used. They are as follows and are all taken from
the 73-76 model 914s:
     Front shifter assembly
     Front tunnel shift rod
     Special large to small shift firewall bushing
     Rear shift rod and coupler with coupler bushings
     Front and rear set screws
     Front rubber shift cover
     Rear crown bushing
     Rear shift cover
     Rear shift boot
     tie
     Rear shift clamp
     Ball cup bushing
     Rear shift head
     Engine mounting bar
     Two rubber engine mounts
     Two outboard solid mounts
     Two engine mounting tabs
     Various hardware

George Hussey


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 08:51:31 -0400
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: what clutch for 914?

<My clutch went out on my 914 and my mechanic is suggesting I <consider a
<heavier duty clutch. I do drive it pretty hard. But I want <something that
is
<comfortable for stop-and-go city driving. (I live in LA. :) ) Any
<suggestions
<or advice?

The factory 4-spring or VW bus 5-spring clutch disc works great for any 4 or
2.0 litre six cylinder 914. As the pressure plate is already the 911 variety,
it obviously works great!

George Hussey

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 06:27:21 -0700
From: "jim gregory" <jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Vibration

On Apr 18, 12:26am, stephen davies wrote:
> Subject: 944 Vibration
{snip}
> Also, since it appears that I might have to drop the transmission for the
> above reason or due to another problem (also have a worn second gear
> syncro), I am wondering how much the lower ring and pinion (same as 944S)
> costs and how much extra labour is involved ?
>
> Stephen Davies
> 1988 944 TURBO S
>
>-- End of excerpt from stephen davies


Steve-

FYI, I believe that to replace a synchro, the entire transaxle needs to be
disassembled. (May want to learn how to double clutch for a while instead). Be
careful about putting the 944S ring & pinion in, Porsche had strongly
recommended NOT doing this since it is not strong enough to handle the power of
the 944 turbo. (had two friends who blew up the ring & pinions this way, I had
mine removed ). The lower gearing is really sweet, but I'm not aware of a lower
gearing that is strong enough to accomodate the 944 turbos. If there is one, I
would *REALLY* like to know about it!

 -jim

Date:          Tue, 18 Apr 1995 08:04:50 +700
From: JBUTLER@park.admin.utah.edu
Subject:       Re: Strange people/drivers

I've never had much excitement while driving a Porsche ... but ... 
was it back in '77? Driving home from Newport Beach, CA about 1AM on 
a Saturday night in an old VW Bus. We had stopped at Charlie's Chile 
for a bowl of his hard stuff (highly reccomended). Proceeding north 
we hit the last stoplight before the 55 freeway. A 930 pulls up 
alongside and the passenger (steroid crazed football player) starts 
yelling ""f" you, pull the "f"ing van over and fight us." Absolute 
silence ensues from the 5 throwbacks in the wayback machine. I notice 
the blood, both fresh and crusty running from his middle finger/knuckles 
all the way down to his elbow and realize we are not his first quarry of 
the evening. I casually lock the drivers side door and look up to see 
the light turn green. Off we go with a sick feeling in my stomach to 
a chorus of " oh wow, man ... what a trip" emanating from the back of 
the wayback machine. The 930 and it's occupants where off in a flash 
in search of more willing prey.

John, U of Utah
jbutler@park.admin.utah.edu
*Fahren in seiner schoensten form*

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 09:12:33 -0500
From: "Richard Hocking" <hocking@cig.mot.com>
Subject: 911: Bad Rear Bearing (novice questions)

In the past few weeks I have occasionally heard a whirring sound coming
from the back of my '87 911.  So I finally got the chance to jack the
car up and spin the wheels.

Findings:  Right Rear wheel spins freely, no brake rubbing or noise.  No play
when I pull/push on top/bottom of wheel.

Left Rear wheel spins, but I hear a clicking sound (not very loud) every
half second or so.  There is no play when I pull/push on the wheel.

So I suspect a bad bearing, although as a novice, I have no idea whether I am
right.  The books I have read indicate that a symptom of a bad bearing is
some play when pulling/pushing on the wheel.

Anyway now to the questions.  (Just FYI the car has just under 50,000 miles).

Does this sound like a bad bearing ?
If not, what ?

Is 50,000 miles usual for a rear bearing to go bad ?

Assuming it is a bad bearing, what is involved in replacing it ?  I am
particulalrly  interested in getting some idea of what is involved and the
cost since I am only a novice and I don't want the dealer to know :-).
I looked in the catalogs and the price for a bearing seems to be around $60.
But some years seemed to need an inner and an outer bearing and for an '87
the catalog did not list inner and outer bearings.  Is there only one, or
two of the same part ?

I tried to figure out what is involved.  After fixing the bearing I assume
an alignment will be in order.  Also, I believe the brakes have to be removed.
Is it worthwhile having the dealer do the brakes at the same time.  This
would hurt because I just bought a new set of pads and was planning on
doing this myself.

I am kind of tight for money right now (dam IRS).  I do want to get it
fixed though.  If only the one side is bad, do I just get the dealer to fix
the one side, or should I do both sides at the same time ?

So, my novice view :-

Parts cost = depends on whether there are 2 bearings and whether I should
do both sides at the same time.
Labor cost = no idea
Brake work = not sure what is needed.  Flush ($60).
Alignment = I am pretty sure I will need this ($150).

As you can see I am just a novice, so your help would be much appreciated.
Richard Hocking.

'87 911 Targa  (Red, what else :-)       |  hocking@cig.mot.com

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 10:33 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Drivers' Ed Advice Needed-Early 911

    Any advice on the best way to mount a fire extinguisher in a pre-74911 would
    be most appreciated.
    
    What size and type unit do yo feel is best?

Get a 2.5lb Halon extinguisher if you can.  I just did (yesterday), they're
more effective than the Purple-K.  I plan to mount mine in my car (87 944S)
with #8 sheet metal screws on the floor in front of the driver's seat.

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 10:44:19 -0400

Weird stuff even happens in 356s. Just last Saturday some punk in a Honda
Civic with the Custom Bad Boy Chrome Stovepipe Exhaust (as if that thing
needs it) wanted to drag me from a light. Walked away from him and when the
road went to one lane he had to fall in behind. There's one thing to be said
for a four-speed: what the 356 gearbox does in one gear, it took him most of
two gears, and once the 356 comes on the cam and I don't have to shift,
they're history. (OK, so I don't pick fights with kids in 5.0 Mustangs. But
Hondas are fair game. Man's gotta know his limitations.)

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 09:09:33 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: 951 Oil Leak

Don Rubin tell us of his 951 mystery oil leak.

I have a guess for you Don.  My 87 951 had a similar mystery leak.  We 
replaced the rear main with the clutch as you did, which mitigated the 
problem to a degree.  But on closer inspection, we found the leak to be 
coming from the rear of the camcover.  My mechanic says this is the most 
common leak he sees on 951s.  It's characterized by the dripping right 
smack onto the exhaust pipe.  Good Luck!

- --

                                              bshort@AFSinc.com

                                                    1990 944 S2
                                        1987 944 Turbo (4 Sale)

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 11:41:28 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 911 Duck Tails

Pat Garvey (PORSCHEFAN@aol.com) asked about the aftermarket vs 
original 911 duck tails.

Last year I put an aftermarket duck tail on my car. It takes a lot
of work not only to get it to fit, but just for drilling and
attaching parts. A plastic grille must be obtained (the early metal
one I had was much too curved to fit). The holes to mount the grille
must be drilled. Also two screw-in rubber stop-bumpers must be
obtained, and holes drilled to screw them into. I also had to
drill a hole for the clasp mechanism (and put a small ding in the
tail by going through and hitting the outer layer of fiberglass).

After all this, the tail fit poorly- the center was curved and stuck
up a bit. But after a few days of engine heat and sun, the tail seemed
to form to the car and now fits OK. 

I weighed the fiberglass tail and my stock engine cover, and the
weight saving is negligible, maybe 4 pounds. But the reduced lift
is well worth the installation, especially on the track.

The factory tail has a metal frame so it will fit much better and
survive more abuse. I think they run about $1500 used.
But the metal frame can rust.

I removed my duck tail to go back to SCCA Solo-II A stock, so if
anyone wants a pre-fit tail ready to bolt on, let me know. Also it's
still unpainted, so you can make it match your car. And the grille
and bumpers are included!

Mike Piera '72 911S, '73 914/2.0 (?)


------------------------------

Date: 18 Apr 1995 08:51:05 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers 

                      Subject:                              Time:  8:30 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Re: strange people/drivers            Date:  4/18/95

The thread about other drivers' responses to P-cars seems
to be mostly stories of encounters of the negative kind, but
my experiences have all been positive (except for last 
weekend's speeding ticket that would have been 
written up at a lower speed if I had been in my Datsun!).

Just as an example ... early in my ownership of my 928
I drove up Malibu Canyon Road here in LA.  For
those who aren't from this area, it's a neat two lane
canyon road that's just fun to drive,  providing you don't
have a slowpoke in front of you (no safe passing areas).  I 
entered the road just behind a slow, fat stakebed truck
and was convinced I'd have a miserable ride.  Then the
truck driver saw me, saw that I'd probably like to drive 
faster than he would be going, and he let me get by.  Now
this took some planning; he had to find a shoulder to 
pull up on, he had to come to almost a complete stop, etc.
This isn't the only time I've had this experience.  If I'm on
the freeway in the left lane and the car in front is not 
going quite as fast as I'd like, most drivers move over as
soon as they see the P-car.  (when I had my Datsun, I 
could sit behind people all day long and they wouldn't 
move over).

I know there's lots of crazies out there, but so far my 
experiences have been pretty good!  I guess there are
also a lot of nice people on the road, we just happen to 
notice the idiots more than the good guys.

John
'84 928S

Fellow fire foes,
 At the last tech session I was at one of the guys had fabricated

went through seat mount and his bracket.  This way he didn't have

it so he could loosen the seat bolts and fold the bracket out of
the way (after removing the the extenguisher).

guys selling strut braces, etc I think.

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 11:25:34 -0500
From: scot@phoenix.phoenix.net (Scot VanAlstine)
Subject: losers at Renegade.

Just got off the phone with a gentleman at Renegade hybrids.  They are real
secretive about their aftermarket gears for 914 transmission.  "Andy" said
that they didn't want their "secret" to get out so therefore they do not
sell the gears seperately.  They will install them with a rebuild.  It has
been my experience that businesses like this probably don't have that
exclusive a product. Sounds like the "secret" that they are trying to
protect is probably that they are installing someone else's gears.

Does anyone know of a "service oriented" business that offers aftermarket
gears and advice?

And by the way if anyone forwards this to renegade more power to them.  I
would like to them to know how they have alienated another prospective
customer with money to spend..

Scot VanAlstine
PCA Lonestar region.

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 09:35:37 -0800

Subject: Wanted: bra for '86 944 turbo



Hello all,

I used to have a bra for the car some years ago but ended up selling it.
Now I just came back from a trip to LA on Hwy 5 and it was bug city.  So,
does anyone out there have a bra that they want to unload?  I don't
particularly care if it's used, but as long as it keeps the bugs from being
splattered on the front of the car.  I'm in the San Francisco Bay Area, so
apologies to those reading this from out of state.  Please reply to

Date: 18 Apr 1995 09:39:09 PDT
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Thread sealant/adhesive that's oil resis


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Thread sealant/adhesive that's oil resistant?
Date: 1995-04-18 11:34
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hi gang,
To those of you with dirty fingernails and wrenches next to your PCs:
While pulling my motor over the weekend I had a problem with the return oil
line that was seized to the fitting going into the oil console (filter
housing).  Bottom line was that I loosened the fitting that goes into the
console and broke it's oil-tight seal.  I need a recommendation for the
sealant/locking adhesive that I need to make the fitting part of the console
again.  To further clarify: the fitting is a male/male threaded nipple that
creates a mechanical seal with the hose on one side and is "glued" in to the
filter housing on the other.  Whatever the sealant ("glue") that was
originally used wasn't up to the torque I had to use to break the hose-end
fitting free...

Oh, and If there is a generic substitute for the original sealant that might
be more available and work as well or better, I'd appreciate that info as
well (e.g.: Locktite 4xx is the right stuff but 3M 323 works fine)

Thanks in advance,

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com



------------------------------

Date:          Tue, 18 Apr 1995 10:52:51 -0700
From: "Don Carlos" <buckland@alinc.com>
Subject:       89 928 S4 for sale

I looked at an 89 928 S4 yesterday, which bears sharing with you guys 
and gals.  I decided not to buy it, as I'm not ready to part with my 
95 BMW M3 just yet, but IF I were to buy a 928, this would be the
one.  It is red/beige,auto,40kmiles,3 piece BBS, new Dunlops, and is
in MINT condition.  The guy wants $25,500, which is a bit below
the going price.  Call him directly for more imfo  (Ron  at 486-3561, 
or 553-8601)
By the way, I am familiar with all the 928 vs 911 arguments, and have
owned everything from a 911s to an SC, to a 930, so please don't de-
luge me with "don't get a 928, it's not a REAL Porsche."  I believe 
that it IS a real Porsche; it  is the most misunderstood, unloved car 
in the world, and will someday be very popular on the collector's 
market.   Drive one sometime, and I think that you will be amazed at 
how much grunt they have, and how well they handle for such a huge 
luxury car.  Whatsmore, an 85 to 89 can be had for peanuts, and can't 
drop too much more in value.  This is the ONLY sports car that I 
would reccomend with an automatic.  Its just too heavy for a clutch, 
and when you punch it down from 4th to 2nd at 80, it will blow you 
into the back seat(such as it is).

On second thought, the 928 vs 911 argument hasn't been had for 
awhile, so maybe we should have it.........

Regards, 

Carl Buckland, Salt Lake City

ps  I LOVE my M3, but will be getting out of it pretty soon to step 
up to a new 993.  Anyone interested?  It's Avus blue/silver, loaded, 
factory wing(very subtle but very sleek), Antera Opus Ones(not subtle 
at all), 7500 miles.   $45,600 new, will consider offers over 
$40,000.

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 13:08:44 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: mounting fire extinguisher in 911


Sorry I deleted the original message in a 
deleting
frenzy after being away for 5 days for Easter.

I mounted a 5 lb halon bottle on the service 
panel
for the shift linkage (centered behind the 
seats) I
figured that the panel is replacable if some 
future
purist doesn't like the holes. You can easily 
reach 
the extinguisher and unclasp it with your right 
hand. I've
also seen them attached to the seat frame under 
the 
driver'slegs. 

Reid (reid_zeigler@merck.com)

track :-)

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 14:15:48 -0400 (EDT)
From: Craig Seko <ak564@freenet.carleton.ca>
Subject: 911 fire extinguisher mounting.

>     Any advice on the best way to mount a fire extinguisher in a pre-74911 would
>     be most appreciated.
>     
>     What size and type unit do yo feel is best?
> 
> Get a 2.5lb Halon extinguisher if you can.  I just did (yesterday), they're
> more effective than the Purple-K.  I plan to mount mine in my car (87 944S)
> with #8 sheet metal screws on the floor in front of the driver's seat.

Hmm. Halon is illegal here... just *murders* the ozone. <shrug>

However, if you don't want to drill in your floor, one can get your
friendly neighbourhood metal-worker to make a bracket that uses the
seat-bolts. It is basically a strip of metal that is bolted to the fire
extinguisher mounting bracket, and then slips in between the seat and the
floor, secured by the seat bolts. Neat and tidy, and easily removed if
necessary...

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 14:16:56 -0500 (EST)
From: "Dave J. Andruczyk" <ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU>
Subject: REG: RE: Groaning brakes...



As per your groaning problem. If it happens when you lighten up on the brakes,
its normal, its called Creep-groan.. (drum  brake cars have this more often) 
If it happens when you let off completely, then it is more likely a sticky
piston in the caliper that isn't letting go completely..

Dave..
'79 924 (in resto...)
