Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 11:24:04 PDT
From: "James Everingham" <JEVERING@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: strange people/drivers


On Mon, 17 Apr 1995, Nathan W Hanson wrote: 
 
> Do any of you get strange/aggressive responses from other drivers while  
> in your Porsches?  For example, people cutting you off, trying to race in  
> front of your, etc.  I decided to compare notes with ya'll on this list  
> after 3 occurences of this kind of thing recently.   
 
I had a humorous experience just this weekend.  I was in San Francisco at 
about midnight on Van Ness - which is a three lane each way road.  I pulled up 
to a light with an SFPD officer in a big white car in the far right lane.  A 
big new Cadillac pulled up between us.  The man in the Caddy looked over at me 
and started reving his engine.  I just looked back at him waiting for him to 
notice the officer to his immediate right.  Well... the light turned green and 
the silly wanker floored his Caddy laying some serious rubber.  I looked over 
at the officer with that "I didn't do anything! My clutch is still depressed!" 
look.  The officer looked at me in disbelief, smiled and shook his head, hit 
the light switch and pulled the guy over.  Oh well, I would like to have heard 
that conversation.

3 more gears.

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 16:37:43 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: 928 and second gear

The conversation so far:
- -----

Carl Buckland from Salt Lake City sez:
>>and when you punch it down from 4th to 2nd at 80, it will blow you 

and Bill Ataras asks:
>Seriously ? a 928 can live at 80 in 2nd ? not topped out ?

Then I answer:
My '83 is topped out in 2nd at ~73mph. So, a 928S4 can probably do this.
After all, top speed is 171 and that speed needs to be distributed among
3 more gears.
Later,
Brian Scudder

- ----
According to the Owners Manual, for the '84 Automatic, 80mph is the
red line for second gear (6000 rpm). And the s4 must have a higher
red line...  So it probably has some left at 80 in 2nd. Scary. Too
bad we can never use it, but that's another thread. I should be
thankful I don't have the 85 mph speedometer.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date:          Tue, 18 Apr 1995 14:01:55 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Hot Running 911

Something ain't right with the car, and my wallet's getting 
frightened:

I have a '75 911S which runs kinda hot.  It's been running about 200
F on the freeway, 190 F around town (on a 65 F day) since I bought it,
but lately things have gotten worse.  At the last autocross, I was
quite unhappy to see temps of about 240 F coming off a two minute run
(great course, lots of full throttle fun).  It's now running about
190-200 F around town, and will go up to 215 with about 20 seconds of
full throttle acceleration.  The temperature seems to have a fairly 
direct relationship to RPMs--200 F while driving, back to 185 at a 
long light, back up after a block, etc.

This is not what I want to be seeing.  What's the collective 
net.wisdom on this?

The engine has the 11 blade fan, '73 exhuast (no thermal rctrs), SC
cams, and is otherwise pretty stock.  I can feel no lack of power;
the engine runs well and revs nicely (other than getting hot).  I
just changed the oil (Kendal 20W/50 GT Turbo, OEM filter), and it
had a tuneup a few months (1500 miles) ago.

Thanks in advance,

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S Brick Shithouse Red

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 14:03:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Insert key.....turn ignition....


POP!

A fuse blows......can't hear the fuel pump.

I knew my long dormant 914-6 project just couldn't fire
up right away.

Out comes the gas tank; look at fuel pump.  Mighty dark
down there.....hey....the damn +12 V line connector is
shorting against the fuel pump body!

Fixed that.....fire up the car again.  Ahhh, yes....there's
the noisy, but powerful, fuel pump....sounds good.

Turn the key a little bit more.....starter engages.....
engine turns over fast and smooth....never fires.

Check for spark....yep....many volts there.

OK, timing must be way out....Stu just eye-balled it
before.  A few adjustments and crank again....

VRRRROOOOOOOMMMMMMM!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

It lives!!!!!

Boy is that sucker LOUD!!!  A 3.0 SC engine
with headers and nothing else fills the neighbourhood
with the pleasant sound of a drag strip.  I guess
I need some mufflers sometime soon....this is
more than noisy....something quite insane.

(No, I didn't drive the car....it's on jackstands.
I still have a few things to do on it before it gets
its wheels put on.)

Only discovered one problem at first, the alternator
light stays on.....it worked a few years ago when the
car was taken off the road.  I must have screwed
something up somewhere.  Oh well......I don't really
care right now.  My baby came to life last night.

Thanks to everyone who helped.....now I know
my troubles are just beginning.  :-)

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
1975 914-6  3.0 SC with no mufflers!!!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 95 14:26:38 pst
From: brian.foster@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Las Vegas International Raceway Driving School

Better late than never...

At our April San Diego BMW CCA chapter meeting, we were discussing ways to fill 
the rest of the slots at our upcoming 2-day driving school. After thinking a 
bit, I thought I would extend an invitation to all my favorite people at 
Porschephiles, so...

 - When and Where:

Saturday and Sunday, April 29th and 30th, at the Las Vegas International 
Speedway.  The track is 1.6 miles long, and is used for SCCA and vintage racing.
BTW, this is the NEW track... :)

 - What:

This is a high-performance driving school, held under close supervision by 
trained instructors (we have Porsche trained instructors, not just 
BMW/Mercedes).  We use a race track to provide a safe, controlled environment, 
but this is NOT a racing school; the emphasis will be on safe, smooth, 
controlled driving.

A first-class weekend includes more than just driving.  We have reserved a block
of rooms at the Imperial Palace Hotel, right on the Strip and home of the famous
automobile museum!  An open house on Friday evening in the museum itself (!) and
a gala buffet dinner are included in your registration.  The entry fee is $225 
per driver.

 - Who can attend:

The school is open to members of the BMW CCA and ACA.  Not a member? No problem 
 - we charge you an additional $35 and you BECOME a CCA member. Non-BMW entries 
will be accepted at the discretion of the committee. (No Formula I cars!)

If you'd like more information, email brian.foster@ast.com with your fax number,
and I'll fax you more information, and a registration form.

See you there! Oops... not me, since my wife is due anyday now with our 
firstborn!
===================================================================== 
Fahr schnell, sei vorsichtig, hab Spass
Brian Foster
88 Land Rover Range Rover
74 BMW 2002Tii
72 BMW 2002
87 BMW 528E
64 Porsche 356SC
Editor, "Fahren Affairs" (newsletter of the San Diego BMW CCA) 
Rancho Santa Margarita, CA
Internet: brian.foster@ast.com
Telephone: 1-500-FOSTER5 (work/home 7AM-11PM PST) (toll call as if calling 714  
                                                   area code)
Nothing I say reflects the views or opinions of anybody else!

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 17:07:49 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Re: strange people/driver

Hi,

I was on my way home from South Miami Beach a couple of months ago and was
stopped at a light. This Bronco pulls up next to me and I notice the
passenger looking at my old Targa. Light turns green, we both go and have to
stop at the next light.  The passenger continues staring at my car and as the
light turns green yells "What's the deal with your Porsche?" Having just
washed and waxed my car the day before I innocently answer " it's clean,"
 and I turn onto the causeway. 

A couple of minutes later, my girlfriend says " You know, I don't think they
realized that you car was so old."  Then it dawned on me, that I probably
sounded like an arrogant a**hole. The guy in the Bronco had no idea that 911
were produced 22+ years ago and except for the bumpers and the stainless
steel Targa bar, the car looks like a newer 911.  Next time I'll say " It's a
'73."

Isn't great when people ask you about your car. I'm always willing to answer
any questions they have. An even greater thrill for me is to encounter other
pre-74 911 owners as well as 356 and 914 owners.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 17:19:39 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Trail Braking OhmyGod

Larry Herman, in a very well written piece on trailbraking, neglected to
throw in one caveat that I feel is very important.
DON'T try Larry's techniques until you are well along in you high speed
driver education training. Trail Braking is an advanced technique that should
not be used in your initial drivers education events. It is very easy to lose
a car when trail braking. It is a delicate balance between steering input,
braking, and throttle transition. If you don't do it exactly right chances
are you are going for a wild ride.
Larry is an excellent driver and instructor and I am sure he is not teaching
his beginners how to trail brake. I am right about that aren't I Larry? 
At your initial drivers ed events you will be taught the basics of car
control and that will normally be limited to straight line braking. After you
have proven your competence in basic and safe high speed maneuvers then you
will be taught more advanced techniques such as trail braking, throttle
steer, and transitioning. 
Please do not expect to go to your first track event and expect to be be
taught the subtleties of high sped line correction techniques. At least not
if I am your instructor!!!
Larry please support me on this! How about all the other instructors?

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
5:04 pm

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 14:28:44 -0700
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: 89 928 S4 for sale

>
>Text item: 
>
>>and when you punch it down from 4th to 2nd at 80, it will blow you 
>
>Seriously ? a 928 can live at 80 in 2nd ? not topped out ?

Absolutely.  I don't know specifically about the 4 speed auto,
but my 3 speed is about 10mph per 1000rpm in 1st gear.  With
the nasty engine I installed (500+ hp), I adjusted it to shift
at about 8500rpm (85mph in 1st gear) when floored.  A stock
engine should be good for 64mph in 1st (redline).  Even the
late 70's, early 80's engines can squeeze the breath out of
you when down-shifting, although they are a little weak off
the line.  Although I love the 911 series, I don't know of
many cars that are better than the 928 for daily commute
comfort, luxury, and fun factor combined.


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 14:37:25 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Groaning Brakes

Philip Katz' brakes are complaining:

> 
> 	My 911 3.2 Carrera is making a groaning noise from one of the front 
> wheels when the car rolls forward after braking (i.e., I brake, take my 
> foot off the brake pedal to let the car roll forward a little, and the 
> noise occurs).
> 
> 	On the suggestion of one of the mechanics at the local Porsche 
> dealership, I removed the pads on that wheel, cleaned out the caliper with 
> brake cleaner and put back the pads (original Porsche items, with plenty of 
> meat left on them), using some Coppaslip on the back of the pads.
> 
> 	But ... it has made absolutely no difference!!
> 
>       Any ideas?


Wotta co-incidence... I just fixed this very problem on my '83SC last
weekend (I think!  You can't see me knocking wood as I type this...)
In my case it was a faint groan at low speed with brakes hot, e.g. after a
long hill.  Overhauling my brakes before an upcoming Laguna Seca
Educational Experience, I found *one* piston in *one* front caliper
rotated away from the specified 20 degree position of the cutout.  In
consequence the pad on that piston was worn *slightly* cupped.  I
cleaned the piston, renewed the rubber seal, re-installed in the correct
position, and put in new pads.  I'm waiting for the new pads to bed on
the new discs before I seriously stomp the brakes, but so far the
"groan" is gone, on hills where I used to have it before.  Knock wood.

Anyway check your pads for flatness with a straightedge and check that
your piston cutout is oriented per the manual (I used Haynes).  I
suppose it's possible the piston seal is a contributor if it's old and
hard, and it's easy to change while you're in there.  (An always-welcome
benefit in my case was a higher, harder pedal after the whole thing was
back together.)  Let me know if it works for you...

Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

p.s.: While on the subject I could use some advice from any of the
gurus who've read this far: I bled the brakes using my "Mityvac" hand
vacuum pump.  As always, it sucked more air around the bleed screw than
it did fluid out of the pipe.  I tried the Vaseline-around-the-threads
bit suggested here without avail (and gosh, I sure hate using Vaseline
near brake rubber!).  I wound up using one of the cone-shaped adapters
supplied with the Mityvac, but I had to remove the bleed screw to make
it work.  All's well that ends well (did I mention my rigid, tumescent
brake pedal yet?), but I'm still mystified by how you pros use the
vacuum bleeders...

 

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 14:38:38 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: My $.02 on Driving War Stories


Some years ago I owned a 914/6 that I autocrossed. I would install the
autocross wheels and tires at home, to save my lady friend the
discomfort of sitting on one of the dirty race wheels/tires.

The 914/6 in this configuration sat very low on the road, in many
instances I could read the casting on truck transfer cases to see if 
it was a Spicer or Eaton. One Sunday morning we were heading from
Danville to Sacramento on I-80 when we happened upon a caravan of
Low-rider Chevies. The 914/6 was so low that all of them had to look
down at us, I doubt if the roof of the 914/6 was higher than the lower
window sill of a '64 Chevy.

Low-riders are a phenom of California, especially the Latino
community. Most are elaborately painted and detailed, the rest aspire
to this. Usually, the seats have been lowered in the car body to let
the occupant to just be able to peer out over the lower window sill. 
All of these cars were so appointed.

Anyway, this guy in one of the '64 Chevies decided he can get lower,
so he raises the car with his hydraulic ride-height adjuster to the
top of the stops, then he slams the thing all the way to the
ground. This is serious, serious enough that he CONTACTS the ground,
making sparks fly out all over. This is at 60 MPH, mind you. The guy
repeats this 4 times, spraying sparks each time. He stops, either
running out of floorboards to spark or battery to run the hydraulics.

Finally, he pulls up along side and gives us a thumbs up for having
such a cool low-rider. We won at the autocross, wondering how a
slammed Chebbie would have done.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 17:34:34 -0400
From: Mike.Worland@DANA.COM
Subject: RE:Hot Running 911



Dirk,

Here is a list of things you might want to check (some may be obvious):

     1. Check the oil level (not enough to cool the engine?)
     2. Check the oil cooler(s) for leaves or other debris
     3. Check the spark advance (too far advanced produces more heat)
     4. Check for a lean condition (pull a plug and look for white
electrode)
     5. Check your fan belt (a loose fan belt can slip and loose cooling
effect)
     6. Check Your Oil Pressure (low oil pressure = less
cooling/lub.=BIGproblem!)
     7. Perhaps you have a kinked oil line (not likely but worth a look)
     8. Check the oil sump for metal particles (maybe you have a bigger
problem)

Given what you said about high rpm's being related (maybe) you might first
suspect the spark advance (higher rpm's means more  spark advance to a
point).
These are only my suggestions don't let them scare you, there may be others.
If I can offer any added assistance please let me know.

GOOD LUCK!
Mike Worland@Dana.Com
'71 911
'88 Mustang GT
'92 Bronco XLT

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 16:41:41 -0500
From: ricp@ids.net (james stephenson)

>
>    Any advice on the best way to mount a fire extinguisher in a pre-74911
would
>    be most appreciated.
>

>
>Get a 2.5lb Halon extinguisher if you can.  I just did (yesterday), they're
>more effective than the Purple-K.  I plan to mount mine in my car (87 944S)
>with #8 sheet metal screws on the floor in front of the driver's seat.
>
>- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)
>
Reply #2 - Yes, I concur with the advice above. Mount extinguisher on floor
just ahead of driver's seat. Put seat all the way forward to find the
correct spot. The extinguisher is easy to get, and I never had a problem
with it getting in my way because it is out of the way where you step into
the car (911). About 7 years ago, I took my street car (924S) on the track,
and mounted the extinguisher on the back floor, but this is not good. Gets
in the way of anybody that may ride there.

unlike BMW, which is a damn good car though it must be the most "hated" car

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 18:50:10 -0400 (EDT)
From: Craig Seko <ak564@freenet.carleton.ca>
Subject: Driving fast in Ontario

> > > detroit to binghamton NY.. the quickest and most entertaining way to go 
> > > is across canada (no cops, no people, no kidding.)  Unfortunately, this 
> > Yeah, but we have photo-radar now. Rumour has it it won't be a problem for
> > you, because pics showing out-of-province plates are tossed... 
> how do the cops treat locals?  I must confess, my only driving 
> experiences in canada have been on routes 401 & 403, and really, they're 
> like a north american autobahn... traffic seems to move @ >80 mph, cops 
> don't bother you if you're acting civilized (turn signals, staying to the 
> right..)  people's road manners seem much more refined.... getting back 
> on to the New York State thruway is like night & day.

The grass is always greener... :-)

Let's put it this way. When they brought photo-radar in, my average speed
(keeping up with the faster traffic) thru Toronto dropped from 140 km/hr (er,
um, 87.5 mph) right down to 100 km/hr (62.5 mph). *Everyone* was going the
same speed. It was like driving on the Ohio turnpike. Last time I was
there, the speed seemed to have creeped back up to 130 (just over 80 mph),
but with wild drops in speed, if someone thought they saw a Chevy Astrovan
(that's what the photo-radar units are in).

There are certain OPP detachments that are well-known for their rigid
enforcement, but I suspect your route may miss these (Milton, just west of
Toronto, for example). The OPP at Dutton (just west of London) were also
known for their annoying enforcement a few years ago, but I don't know
about now.

Don't forget that drivers don't get points on their licence unless their
ticket is for 15km over the limit here (i.e., 115 km/hr - 72 mph). Thus
one has to work *very* hard to get a ticket at those speeds.

Also, with your Florida plates, I suspect many cops just won't bother with
you... <shrug>


- -- 
Craig Seko, Team OS/2 - (613) 951-6960 - sekocet@statcan.ca - <yawn>

The opinions expressed above don't really represent anything at all.

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 16:14:22 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Bill Ataras-308 GT


Bill:  You asked about my experience with the Ferrari 308 as you've been "half 
dreaming about getting one".  Couldn't find your email address in the post so 
I'll do it to the list in case any one else has similar fantasies. 
 
I had a 78, GTS, red, black from 78-81. Also had a moustache and am a white 
guy so people used to shout "Hey Magnum " at me all the time.  The car was fun 
to drive, very neutral, had good power, expensive to tune and service.  It had 
injection which the 77's didn't have so it was better than the carb version.   
 
It used a quart of oil every 200 miles so at 9,000 or so Ferrari put a new 
motor in it.  I broke it in carefully and after 3-4000 miles it used a quart 
every 2-300 miles.  The dealer was only able to mumble something about Ferrari 
owners usually having another car for everyday use like a Mercedes, implying 
that they weren't driven every day and what the hell did I expect for 34K 
anyway.  Message was that it was supposed to be a rich guys weekender car and 
who the hell was I to dare drive it a lot.  So, I started buying Castrol by 
the case. 
 
Put about 30K on the car with no major problems.  Weird electronics at times, 
but it did have a nice exhaust tone. 
 
I did enjoy the car. The best part was that you could take the top off and 
drive 100 mph and not mess up your hair.  It had great aerodynamics.  I think 
the fact is that most people did use them as a weekend car so there are a lot 
of low mileage ones around.  Also they are relatively cheap. I can't think of 
another car that has the same impact as a red 308 for under 30K.    
 
My bet would be that it's a good car for $ appreciation.  Don't let the 
Ferrari puristas discourage you from 308 with the idea that it's a cheap 
Ferrari and therefore not collectable.  Remember the Dino246GT's that everyone 
said were really Fiats.  Try finding a nice one for under 50K today.    So, if 
you're only gonna go around once, do the gusto, go for it, just do it and go 
find one you like.   
 
Ted Smith 
356 B cab 
356 C cpe 
911 SC cab 
66 GT350 Mustang 
one half dead cat

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 19:24:26 -0400
From: jfoster@rohmhaas.com (Jim Foster)
Subject: Re: Fire Extinguishers

Are you sure this installation will pass tech?  Riesentoter region 
requires metal-to-metal mounting for the fire extinguisher.


At 10:21 PM 4/17/95 -0400, CarcareSp@aol.com wrote:
>
>Place the extinguisher and bracket on the hump to position the bracket.
> Remove the extinguisher and mark 3-4 holes using a grease pencil.  Remove
>the bracket.  Spread the carpet apart on the marks and put a drop of clear
>nail polish on the jute carpet backing.  Allow to dry and then drill through
>the nail polish with the proper size drill.  The jute backing will not walk
>up the drill bit when you stabilize it with the nail polish.  I recommend
>using pan head #8 sheet metal screws 1" to 1 1/8" long.  Remove the
>extinguisher from the bracket and screw the bracket down.  Replace the
>extinguisher and you are ready to go.  If you remove the bracket, fluff up
>the carpet and you won't see the holes.
>
- --
Jim Foster - jfoster@rohmhaas.com        (215) 592-2446 (voice) 592-2369 (FAX)
"Being on a Beemer and not having a wave returned by a                   944S2
Sportster is like having a clipper ship's hailing not                  DoD 142
returned by an orphaned New Jersey solid waste barge." -OTL      '91 K100RS16V

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 19:29:25 -0400

Subject: Re: Trail Braking IS OhmyGod!!!!

Dear Jerry:

As a Zone 1 and NNJR Instructor, I must add my total agreement to your
comments.  The last thing I want is a new student trying to trail brake on
Big Bend or Turn 1 at Bridgehampton or Watkins Glenn.  I had a first time
student after his first run,  ask me when I was going to teach him to four
wheel drift in his 944.  I answered with "when you get a new instructor".

Conversely, it is enjoyable to be able to hone the skills of more advanced
driver with goodies such as trail braking, throttle steering, etc.

I had a 78, GTS, red, black from 78-81. Also had a moustache and am a white 
guy so people used to shout "Hey Magnum " at me all the time.  The car was fun 
to drive, very neutral, had good power, expensive to tune and service.  It had 
injection which the 77's didn't have so it was better than the carb version.

It used a quart of oil every 200 miles so at 9,000 or so Ferrari put a new 
motor in it.  I broke it in carefully and after 3-4000 miles it used a quart 
every 2-300 miles.  The dealer was only able to mumble something about Ferrari 
owners usually having another car for everyday use like a Mercedes, implying 
that they weren't driven every day and what the hell did I expect for 34K 
anyway.  Message was that it was supposed to be a rich guys weekender car and 
who the hell was I to dare drive it a lot.  So, I started buying Castrol by the 
case.

Put about 30K on the car with no major problems.  Weird electronics at times, 
but it did have a nice exhaust tone.

I did enjoy the car. The best part was that you could take the top off and 
drive 100 mph and not mess up your hair.  It had great aerodynamics.  I think 
the fact is that most people did use them as a weekend car so there are a lot 
of low mileage ones around.  Also they are relatively cheap. I can't think of

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 20:26:37 -0400
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Re: Fire Extinguishers

Dear Jim:

The "metal to metal fastening" of fire extinguishers requires that a metal
bracket be screwed into a metal part of the car, as opposed to fiberboard or
other materials (the rear seat backs are many times fiberboard).  There may
be carpet between the extinguisher bracket and the anchoring metal as long as
the screws are long enough to provide a secure anchor.  The metal inspection
plate on the 911 is not only acceptable, but the location is also desirable.
 The extinguisher is accessible to the driver belted in the seat.  Some of
the other locations, while acceptable, may not be as desirable, because the
driver may not be able to reach the extinguisher while belted in the seat.
 Seat belt latches have been known to  jam.  That is why all SCCA and
Professional Flaggers carry a large knife.

This location on a 911 is acceptable to NNJR (I am a tech inspector and run te
ch at many events).  It is also acceptable, to the best of my knowlege,  to
CVR, Metro and Zone 1 ( I have done tech for all these).
 
Stable Energies of Garfield, NJ and I have been working on "no drill"
mounting brackets that attach to the passenger seat.  These brackets have
just gone into production and will be available soon.  We do have them
available currently for non-power seats.

If you have any other questions, or I may be of further service, please give
me a shout. 

Thank you,

Larry Reynolds
 Car Care Specialties, Inc.
 Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
 Post Office Box 535
 Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663-0535
 Phone (201) 796-8300
 Fax (201) 791-9743
 E-mail carcaresp@aol.com
 Old enough to remember when sex was safe and race cars were dangerous

Subject: Blaupunkt radio wiring, help

the seller told me he would replace the radio with the original Blaupunkt,
Monterey series (SRQ23).  Which at the time was no problem.  The radio works
fine, but when they installed the other radio & then reinstalled the
Blaupunkt they disconnected the fader switch that is in the center console
by the shifter.  This was done because the other radio had the fader built
into the radio.  I pulled apart the console & found that the female portion
of the connector jack is gone.  Does anyone out in Porschefile land know how
the wiring is suposed to go.  There is 6 wires coming out of the male jack
from the fader switch, red, brown, blue, green, white, and black.  Any help
would be greatly appreciated.  Please e-mail if possible, thanks in advance

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 18:31:07 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Nice Drivers

regarding drivers of Other Cars, Doug Dykaar commented:

> 
> you wanna get a look? let someone else merge in front of you! I get
> unbelievable expressions outta people when the nasty red porsche lets them
> in/out. try it some time.
>

This reminds me of some advice I once heard about how to arrive at
work in a good mood: yield the right of way to someone on your way in.
This does 2 things: 1) lets you do something nice and feel like a good
guy/gal; and 2) puts you in control of the situation... the other person
is virtually compelled to accept your "offer".  Even the baaadest Oakley
Factory Pilot!  It works, and gives Porsche a little good publicity
into the bargain.

And if it doesn't, you can always drop down two gears and listen to that
Porsche song as they shrink in your mirrors...:-)
 
Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 21:56:18 EDT
From: x51903e4@WESTPOINT-EMH2.USMA.ARMY.MIL (Ngo Lan-dinh CDT)
Subject: yielding to traffic

Speaking of letting other cars in front of you, I go to school in New York and 
make the trip to home (MA) regularly.  This past weekend traffic was heavy for 
the Easter holidays and an 18 wheeler was trying to get into the left hand lane
which was not movingfast enough for him.  Of course no one in the left hand 
lane was letting him in.  Who wants to travel behind a truck in bad traffic?  
It was twilight and I had my headlights on so I flashed him my brights to 
signal that I was letting him cross over.  He didn't move for a while because I
think he was in semi-disbelief.  Finally, he saw that I was serious and moved 
ahead of me.
    To make a long story short, as soon as he
cleared a few slow moving vehicles on the right lane, he moved back into it and
gave me a long horn blast -- I think it was a thank you . . .


Lan-Dinh Ngo
'83 928S Red (Stefan)
yet another water-pumped V8

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 21:05:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Hot Running 911

Dear Dick,

Two years ago I replaced the thermostat/oil bypass valve found in the 
right rear wheel well of a 911S the same year as yours.  Diagnosis was 
this: when the oil temp was about 200 degrees the cooling loop in the 
right front fender was the same as the outside air temperature.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 19:09:17 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Trail Braking


> Please do not expect to go to your first track event and expect to be be
> taught the subtleties of high sped line correction techniques. At least not
> if I am your instructor!!!
> Larry please support me on this! How about all the other instructors?
> 
> Regards,
> Jerry

I'm no instructor, but having done 100 fast kilomiles in my 911, I'll speak up
to *strongly agree*.  My reaction on reading Larry's piece was identical to
Jerry's: nice job, good points, but Don't Try This At Home, at least in a  
911.  It doesn't have a friction CIRCLE, it has a friction EGG!

I only trailbrake in SLOW auto-x corners myself.  Never on 
the track.  I've felt OK about this ever since I heard 
an interview with some famous 911 racer (forget
who) and he said "in ze 911 ve must make all za braking before za
koerner, ja?"  Good enuff for him, good enuff for me.  

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 19:17:48 -0700
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: Re: Trail Braking OhmyGod

My kudos to Larry's trailbraking article. Kids, don't try this at home!
Generally speaking as an insrtuctor, if the student is demonstrating
proficiency at smoothness, balance, learning where to be on the track,
braking, cornering, and accelerating ,etc. the instructor will initiate
discussion of trail braking and pick a corner where it can relatively safely be applied, and at a lowered speed.

I will allow the student's ability to learn and develop to set the
pace of teaching various skills. I have had a *few* students (I can count
them on one hand) who were able to discuss trail braking by a late
session on the second day. Typically these students had a related skill
set (motorcycle racers, sprint car drivers, go kart racers, etc) and
were progressing very quickly. 

Then I've also had some students for many schools who were not ready
to learn to trail brake.

There is one skill I advocate learning on the street first, which can
help tremendously on the track: proper heel & toe technique.

Keep the car on the black stuff, the grass is actually faster!

 -jim

87 944 turbo

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 19:31:15 -0700
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: Strange people, driving stories


> If P-cars are supposed to be driven by "bad boys and girls" why is it I am
> almost always allowed to merge, even cut-off other drivers with nary a
> complaint from them?  Has this ever happened to anyone?  I think that
> unlike BMW, which is a damn good car though it must be the most "hated" car
> on the road,

I have noticed this as well, although I'm not big on cutting people off.
I like to drive fast, and my car looks aggressive, but I don't weave
through traffic or drive too close to anyone.  I drive faster than most
others out there.  Then again, this is CA!!  In LA, I was a rolling
chicane until I drove 75mph+.  People don't get offended by pure
speed (within limits), and really seem amazed if you yield right
of way sometimes ;^)

I also own a BMW although it's a plain stock 528e which seems to
attract no abuse.  (except from my "friends" who thought I really sold
out when I bought that car ;^)  My answer is:  I'd rather have an old
BMW as a family car than a new Taurus)

I have driven both cars *with CA plates* up to Seattle and
expected to be run off the road, but simple driving courtesy
seems to go a long way???

OTOH, when I was in NYC once, working in the Mariott Marquis all
day, I stepped out onto Times Square in the evening and the moment
my foot touched the pavement, a street guy was inches from my face
shouting: "You!!  Motherf***er!!  Get your Golden Boy Ass back to Florida!!"
I thanked him and was on my way  (not back to Florida, thank you, I've
never lived there ;^)

Vol

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 19:38:00 -0700
From: johnb@nwlink.com (john burrows)
Subject: Track day at SIR

Porsche Club members have been invited to Seattle International Raceway June 
17, for a non-competitive day on the track hosted by the Northwest Alfa 
Romeo Club.  This is a "playday" and all levels of drivers are invited.  
Cost is $75 for pre-registered NWARC members, $95 at the track, and $95 for 
pre-registered non-NWARC members, and $115 at the track.  Tech. inspection 
is June 10th, at Macaulay Automotive, 1207 Dexter Ave. N. in Seattle form 
10am to 2pm.  E-mail me for further info. and include your snail-mail 
address if you'd like a registration form.

of my (associativly speaking) beloved garage queen...(is that better,
UB?...by the way, kindly 'ol Unka Bart has graciously taken me under his
wing in order to render my radical rantings "porschephilically
correct"...and for that, we all owe UB a debt of gratitude)...anyway, my '88
Carrera (GPW) is garaged and undercover for several reasons I would like to
espouse so others who might wish to cover can cover another with honor...

      ...The thrill of each uncovering is well worth it...and we can all
relate to this principle ( eg., taking the inflatable lady out of the closet
on a regular basis just wouldn't be the same...)...likewise, I believe that
driving my 9car on a daily basis would tragically dilute the euphoric rush...

      ...The cost of maintainance and repairs is prohibitive unless you are
as gifted as many of the list members appear to be...I have neither the
skills, tools, room, nor the desire to become a competent 9car mechanic...

      ...Can't think of any others...

Garage Queen owners of the list unite!...we must go back into the garage
with our beams up high...perhaps (on a really nice sunny day) we could all
have a parade...(oops, sorry UB)...but only if we can stop every couple of
miles to dust...

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 03:16:00 UTC
From: w.oconnell4@genie.geis.com
Subject: Re: Trail Braking OhmyGod

Jerry,
  You are 1000000% right (which we all know is a strange position to find
yourself in). As usual, Larry's article was excellent but trail braking at
your first - or second - or ... event is one of the best ways to a) find out
for sure just how your insurance company feels about track events and b)
just how nice the fellow at the body shop is, especially in a 911.  My novice
students get to practice getting their braking done before the wheel turns.
For your first events you will have far more to learn then that.  We all
like to think we are wonderfull drivers but driving at higher then normal
speeds for a sustained period is a whole different world.  As my first
instructor, Jerry Nelson (who was racing IMSA at the time) said, "Learn to
be smooth, speed will follow".  Spinning off the track is not graceful.  Or
in the words of the famous Silver Streak (aka Mz Jerry), "Don't color
outside the lines children".
 
Bill O'Connell - Riesentoter Region, PCA
 81 SC Pacific Blue - Der Luft-Klub fur Manner
 94 Pontiac Dustbuster
 95 Saab 900SE
 88 Hobbes - aka Retardo Montakitty, with fine Corithian fur

Date: Tue, 18 Apr 1995 23:04:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Strange people, driving stories

As much as I hate to contribute to a thread which bears little to no
technical merit for your average P-car driver, this deserves some
comment.

> People don't get offended by pure
> speed (within limits), and really seem amazed if you yield right
> of way sometimes ;^)

When I last looked at a position in the Bay.Area (the one that made my
wife's first question about any new prospective job "this had better
NOT be in California", btw), we were out for a week or so house
hunting, etc. Texas has a *LARGE* state funded initiative that's run
for close to 25 years around the theme "Drive Friendly". Many of us
who have only been ever driven in this period take it as gospel, including
my wife.  (Other of us believe in the unofficial non-funded traffic
initiative "Why Do You THINK I Have A Gun Rack, Dumbshit", but that's
another story...)

So Day One in NorCal, she's tooling up 880 from San Jose towards Fremont
to see a real estate agent, and this guy wants in her lane. She slows 
down to let him over, and it just about precipitates a multi-car
pileup. Tires squealing, people driving all over the road narrowly missing
each other, etc. He later ran up along side her at her exit, and told her
"I'm sorry about that -- I thought it was some sort of trick."

Sigh. 

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 00:40:55 -0400
From: WRLSAJ@aol.com
Subject: 911 CD unit problem resolved

Well, I could not bring myself to buying another CD unit
without first testing my old one on another 911.  When my unit
checked out OK on the local PCA tech. chairman's  '73 911
my spirits were magically lifted.

I later discovered a short on my spade connector to the
distributor. It was oily and breaking the line from the points.
Thanks to Reid Zeigler who diagnosed this particular gremlin for me
to check.  So there you have it folks, with the factory manuals ($$),
Haynes, and assorted other references, this list alone saved me
$100+ bucks.  My check will be in the mail to Unka Bart.

To those who responded to me or the list, my AOL mailer
literally lost several days mail (this stuff does not happen 
on my work Unix mail system) so I do not have all your
requests for summaries.  There were more requests for summaries
than help though.. 8^)

Bill
back behind the wheel of his  '72 91iT after a too 
long winter hibernation

> Thanks for the clarification on the "metal-to-metal" issue.
> 
> I'm interested in the no-drill bracket.  Will it fit our 944S2 power
> seat?  I currently use three hose clamps to attach it to our harness bar
> (from Stable, of course :-) )  This might even be something that Shannon
> would like to carry for the Goody Store.
> 
> 
Jim, 

Under no circumstances should you use "hose clamps" to mount a
fire extinguisher.  Hose clamps are for hoses.

Just imagine what kind of havoc would happen when you take 3 or 4 pounds of
mass and hurl it at your body at 60 mph.  That's just what will happen 
when you come to a sudden (uncontrolled) stop and those hose clamps 
fail to restrain the extinguisher.

In our region, and at the Zone 1 Track event, your mounting procedure is a
cause for failing tech inspection and eventual disqualification from the 
event.

Mount it properly, so that it contributes to your safety, not detracts from
it.

Good luck,
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 07:50:44 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Trail Braking in a 944

As a PCA Driver Ed instructor, I have to agree that trail braking is an
advanced technique, to be approached gingerly after all the basic skills of
driving have been deeply learned.

The basic driving skills, as I see them, are:

1) Braking in a straight line, at the limit, consistently, and smoothly.

2) Turning properly, at the proper turnin, using the entire track, tracking
   out properly, balancing the car using the throttle, and smoothly.

3) Accelerating properly, at the appropriate moment in the turn, and
   smoothly.

4) Shifting smoothly, choosing the proper gear for the upcoming situation,
   and engaging the clutch, all done smoothly.

5) Proper hand, foot, eye and brain usage, all done smoothly.

Please note that I stress smoothness, that's the key.

Trailbraking can be done with more confidence in a 944 than a 911 by a less
experienced driver, but a well driven 911 will often be able to beat a less
well driven 944 at the track.

It is also my considered opinion that most 944 cars go off the course nose
first, while most 911 cars go off the course tail first. You do the math!


- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: 19 Apr 95 08:25:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: Strange people

Hmmm....

Strange reactions.  

My '84 944 used to have custom plates that read IBEQUIK (previous owner's idea, 
and in California the plates went with the car).  I used to get asked regular 
"How quick are you?"  Usually just grinned.

Or like the time I pulled up in front of a friend's house, and a kid at the curb 
(about 7 or 8 years old) DROPPED his bike and started yelling "WHOA!  WHOA!  WHOA!" 
as if Michael Jordan had just pulled up.  Just a kid, but it felt godd nonetheless.

Or the hotel bellhop, who as he was helping me get my bags out of the back, 
couldn't resist telling me that I had "Excellent taste in cars, sir!"  VBG!

Then there's the people at work who think I must be making lots more than they 
are, since I have a Porsche.  I try to tell them that their Honda is worth three
times what my Porsche is, but they just stare at me like I was an idiot.  "How
can a Honda be worth more than a Porsche?"

Of course, my '84 doesn't look like it's 11 years old.  Sometimes, if I'm feeling
real mean, I'll even tell someone what year it is, just to watch their reaction.

Somebody mentioned minivans.  My daily driver is a minivan, and if you want to
see aggressive driving sometime, try driving one of these.  People come around 
me on the right and try to cut in front of "that slow idiot in the van"  all
the time, only to be surprised that I'm just one in a long line of slow cars 
following some guy in a Ford.  Here's a clue folks - if my van is in the left 
lane going slow, there ain't no open road in front of me or I'd be eatin' it up.

One thing I have noticed though - I have a habit of making eye contact with and
smiling at the ladies (just a smile - I'm happily living in sin with the love of
my life).  In the van, or even my old Datsun (yes - it's that old) beater, I'll
often get a smile back.  In the Porsche, it's strictly the cold shoulder.  Guess
women see a Porsche and automatically assume the guy driving it has gold chains.
(Oops - now where is that Nomex suit of mine?)

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine

Alex Noordergraaf asked :

I already added to it! I have a pretty neat 2 liter that I 
THOUGHT I bought to resell so I can put some $ in my 911S.

But the car is so much fun to drive that I'm trying to find
a way to keep it. Let's see, sell my wife's Sable, and she
can drive my Jeep GC. But when I need the Jeep to trailer my
911, I can let my sister take the 914 (which she loves too)
and my wife can drive my sisters' Grand Cherokee...
Then I need a salt car for the winter...

I will offer it for sale now, and if nobody is interested I will
keep it.

It is pretty clean, needs several small things though.
I don't think it ever had rust repaired- it is 
much cleaner than the '73 that I had in '80 ! It even has a nice 
Momo steering wheel, Bursch muffler, Yoko 008R tires
on the Fuchs forged wheels (5), so its almost ready for 
autocross or track! 

The car has all the good options : sway bars, console, 
appearance group, etc. Interior is brownish, exterior yellow.

Needs some work and a good tune-up (sat for a while in a garage).
Has only about 103,000 miles. It's a late '73 model (June). 
Camshaft was replaced a few years ago, and engine re-assembled.
The car came from Atlanta 5 years ago so is very rust-free, 
no winters while it was in Connecticut.

Needs : Some paint work (previous owner sprayed primer
inside rear trunk and on some paint nicks and scratches).
Radio was removed (stolen?).
Needs a piece of metal welded in the front trunk where the removed
A/C condenser was (easy job, not structural).
Needs a tune up, car has been sitting in a garage for many months.
But engine feels pretty strong, idles fine.
Seems to leak oil a bit.
Needs one rear trunk hinge re-welded (very common).
Needs pedal bushings replaced (I've had to do this on all older Porsches).

I could sell it as it is for $3000 (firm). I also have a complete set of
factory manuals in mint condition that cost $300. This could be
worked into the deal somehow. I also have a nice set of 
styled-steel 5 1/2 x 15 wheels which could be thrown in, and 
maybe with some bald autocross tires.

Mike Piera, dazed and confused (for so long it's not true)

Date: 19 Apr 1995 08:50:45 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: Re: RE: Speed-regulate legislation ?

>Good sci-fi story years ago, set in the near future:  a guy out enjoying his
>well-kept MGB is hunted by vicious drivers of two "safety" cars which are
>governed to 70mph max but whose bumpers, restraints, door beams, etc. allow
>them to survive intentional collisions.
>Only reason to wish success for assault rifle lobby is that the You Should 
>Be Just Like Me Coalition may take the time to finish them off before coming
>after auto hobbyists.
>B.

Yes, I can see it now.  The pseudo news shows (60 Minutes, 20/20, etc)
would show cars clips from Road Warrior while the voiceover says
how many children are killed by cars every year.  When the SCCA
becomes politically involved to save the sports cars they will be branded as
the "killer car nuts" and shills for the "car lobby".  
"These guys want to keep legal the very cars that are killing our kids!."  
"Nobody needs a car that will do double the speed limit."  
"If only one child is saved..."
"Who will stop the massacre ?"
Politicians who ride public transportation will sponsor bills to outlaw the 
"killer cars".  They will be portrayed as the prefered vehicle for
criminals to use as "getaway" cars.  After a while, people will
expect the safer cars to protect them from harm and sue the
auto manufacture when this doesn't happen [I guess that's old news].
Bills will be introduced to levy a %1000 tax on the premium gasoline used
by the "killer cars" to pay for the "carnage they cause".  
The actual definition of "killer car" would be broad enough when
written into law to cover most anything.  Things like overhead cams,
more than two valves per cylinder, tire aspects of less than 50, etc.
would classify the car as a "killer car".

Yes it sounds nuts, but some of us have heard it all before.

Unfortuneately; as we all remember from Driver's Ed, "Driving is a Privilege"

and not protected by that pesky Constitution.

 vrooom,
   Chris

P.S. I prefer the traffic engineer's definition of a good driver: "One
that does not impede the flow of traffic." :-)

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 09:37:44 -0500
From: "Richard Hocking" <hocking@cig.mot.com>
Subject: 911: Help with humming noise from rear

Well after some help from the list on my question about rear
wheel bearings yesterday, and some hints that the clicking emanating
from my left rear wheel might also be a CV joint, I took the car
to the dealer this morning.

It turns out that the clicking is barely audible and the dealer says
both the bearings and the CV joints are fine.

BUT.....

The reason I thought I had a problem is that at any speed over about 45mph
I get a humming from the rear (on the left side).   We took the car for a
drive and the mechanic heard the noise.  He then spent half an hour trying
to figure out what it was.   The noise is kind of a low/quiet hum that sounds
as if something is resonating.  The mechanic tells me that he thinks it is
transmission noise and even if he tears down the transmission he may not be
able to find the problem.  His suggestion is to just monitor the noise
and bring the car back to him if it gets any worse.

With almost a thousand porschephiles out there I was thinking maybe someone
else might have encountered this problem and might be able to give me some
clues.

I am particularly worried as I want to do some auto-xing and track days
this year.  Obviously I don't want to do this if the problem with the
car might be a danger to myself or others.

Anyone got any ideas what this might be.

Thanks,

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 09:55:40 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Hot running '75 911

>From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>

>  I have a '75 911S which runs kinda hot.  It's been running about 200
>F on the freeway, 190 F around town (on a 65 F day) since I bought it,
but lately things have gotten worse.  At the last autocross, I was
>quite unhappy to see temps of about 240 F coming off a two minute run
>(great course, lots of full throttle fun).  It's now running about
>190-200 F around town, and will go up to 215 with about 20 seconds of
>full throttle acceleration.  The temperature seems to have a fairly
>direct relationship to RPMs--200 F while driving, back to 185 at a
>long light, back up after a block, etc.
   (snip)
>Dirk Bergstrom
>'75 911S Brick Shithouse Red

      Dirk, these temps are no problem and are pretty normal. 180-220
   is the correct temp to run at, only worry if you are sustaining over
   230 or 240.

      Two things that will help;
    1. Use straight 40 or 50 weight oil in the summers. I have no idea
       why this works, but temps will slightly drop.
    2. Get a fender mounted oil cooler. I'd personally only bother with
       the factory loop cooler (you won't need any more from what
       you are reporting). Don't even consider rubber lines and cheap
       aftermarket coolers, the "SC" factory setup is good. The lines and
       fittings will depend on whether you have a single inlet or dual
       inlet muffler and heat exchangers, but all this stuff is available.

         - Lee A.




------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 11:02:08 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jan Ringnalda <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: Re: Blaupunkt radio wiring, Help

Howard,
	Your problem is not to do with the Blaupunkt, since the fader switch is 
probably not made by them.  It is not easy to find out what each wire is without 
a fully intact example.
	However, *IF* you can get access to an oscilloscope and/or a voltmeter, 
or even an old speaker you can get the answer you need.
	There wil be three or four wires going from the radio to the fader, 
depending on whether or not the speakers share ground.  Usually the gound is 
common even if there are four wires out of the radio...  I am assuming that you 
have identified the input to the fader.  Hook the radio up to the fader, and 
MAKE SURE NONE OF THE OUTPUT WIRES TOUCH TOGETHER.  (IF THEY DO YOU **WILL** 
BLOW YOUR RADIO UP)  Take the oscilloscope and measure the signal coming out of 
each wire, while you change the balance fully from left to right and fader from 
front to back.  This will get you all the signal wires. (using a bit of 
deduction)  
	You can also find the signal wires by connecting the old speaker to the 
speaker ground (Note: speaker ground, not general ground) on the *input* side of 
the fader, and connecting the other connection of the speaker to each of your 
output wires after setting fader fully one way and the balance over one way, say 
fader full back and balance full left.  As soon as you hear sound from the 
speaker, you have identified the signal wire for the left back speaker. And so 
on.  The ground identification may be more difficult depending on what type of 
crossover the fader has built in, but normally there is a system to the way the 
wires come out of the unit.  If not, measure the resistance between all the non-
signal wires coming out of the fader unit, the two front grounds should have no 
resistance between them, and it doesn't matter which of the two gounds you then 
use with each of the two front signal wires. Same for the rears and extra's (you 
did say 6 in total.)  The extras are normally run from the front speakers, so 
there's a good chance there will be two signal wires for the front settings on 
the fader for each channel, the extras usually fit in there.
	Let me know how you get on, or if it's not clear.  Conversely you can 
send me the fader, I will re-solder DIN plugs back on for your speaker plugs, 
and label the outputs for you.  Have done a few...
	Happy hunting,   Jan

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 10:37:15 -0500 (CDT)

Subject: Re: Speed-regulate legislation ?

Memories.... I remember when I was in high school going to RUSH's Moving
Pictures tour.  When they played "Red Barchetta", they also showed a little
movie that was kind of cool.  It started out as a time vs frequency plot that
went with the music, the plot then flashed and became a red convertible, which
proceeded to rotate and drive on a road.  Lots of driving at high speed
follows, then as the song comes to an end, the view moves from the cockpit of
the car up to the rear view mirror, where a set of flashing  red lights can be
seen....
don't recall all of the lyrics, but some of it includes, i think.:
Wind...in my hair
Shifting and drifting....
Adrenalin surge....

Date: 19 Apr 1995 09:40:30 -0800
From: "Rodger Keesee" <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Speed-regulate legislation

Bill Ataras states:

Disagree. It's the public's business how fast you drive, because they're at 
risk. It's not only *YOUR* life, its *OUR* lives. And there is no fast lane,
so you can't base your assumtions on it.

- --------------------------------
Bill,

Fact 1: Approximately 400 accidents were caused last year in California by
vehicles moving too slow.

Fact 2: 47 accidents were caused last year by vehicles moving to fast.

Conclusion:  Speed, in and of itself, does not increase the likely hood of an
accident.  Speed actually decreases your likely hood of an accident.  (for a
variety of reasons) Speed only determines the severity of an accident if one
occurred.

Yours, is the same logic used by gun control lobbyists to ban assault rifles
when more people are killed by knives and bare hands.

Hypothesis 1:  The perceived danger to the public of *anything* has nothing to
do with the actual threat to public life and property, but with the outrage
associated with that threat.  (Hundreds of examples available on request)

Conclusion 2:  People attempt to ban and/or restrict what outrages them,
regardless of the actual threat to the public.

Porsche content:
I love 'em.
Rodger
911SC shaped space in the garage

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 10:05:13 PDT

Subject: Re: Bill Ataras-308 GT


- --Boundary-8251167-0-0

Bill:  Let's see,  how did I feel driving it?  I guess a bit conspicuous.  The 
car is very visible. In Sillycon Valley, however, they were not so unusual so 
people didn't exactly gawk.  At the time I also had a 58 Vette, red, white 
cove, black, NCRS Top Flight car.  Quite a contrast in reactions from people 
to the Ferrari and Vette. People would pass and smile, wave,thumbs up,"nice 
car", the Vette. On the other hand, folks would sorta look at the Ferrari out 
of the corner of their eyes, not really wanting to acknowledge the car but 
wondering who was driving.  Also, got flipped off and cut off just about 
everytime out in the Fcar.  Best policy seemed to be to stick my nose up int 
air and ignore 'em.  As if they weren't even there or at least weren't worthy 
of acknowledgement.  that seemed to deliver the appropriate message. 
 
Cops weren't a problem.  My 930 drove the cops wild but they didn't seem to 
care about the Fcar.  That really says something for the Porsche, eh?  
Interestingly enough I soldthe Ferrari and got a 930. It's a lot more 
interesting car but the values are higher on Fcars today and I think they'll 
go up while the 930's seem to be dropping.  More of 'em, etc. 
 
I pretty much enjoyed the car so if you've got an itch, scratch it. 
 
Ted

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Bill Ataras-308 GT
Author:  porschephiles-request@tta.com at SMTPGATE
Date:    4/18/95 4:14 PM


Bill:  You asked about my experience with the Ferrari 308 as you've been "half 
dreaming about getting one".  Couldn't find your email address in the post so 
I'll do it to the list in case any one else has similar fantasies.

I had a 78, GTS, red, black from 78-81. Also had a moustache and am a white 
guy so people used to shout "Hey Magnum " at me all the time.  The car was fun 
to drive, very neutral, had good power, expensive to tune and service.  It had 
injection which the 77's didn't have so it was better than the carb version.

It used a quart of oil every 200 miles so at 9,000 or so Ferrari put a new 
motor in it.  I broke it in carefully and after 3-4000 miles it used a quart 
every 2-300 miles.  The dealer was only able to mumble something about Ferrari 
owners usually having another car for everyday use like a Mercedes, implying 
that they weren't driven every day and what the hell did I expect for 34K 
anyway.  Message was that it was supposed to be a rich guys weekender car and 
who the hell was I to dare drive it a lot.  So, I started buying Castrol by the 
case.

Put about 30K on the car with no major problems.  Weird electronics at times, 
but it did have a nice exhaust tone.

I did enjoy the car. The best part was that you could take the top off and 
drive 100 mph and not mess up your hair.  It had great aerodynamics.  I think 
the fact is that most people did use them as a weekend car so there are a lot 
of low mileage ones around.  Also they are relatively cheap. I can't think of 
another car that has the same impact as a red 308 for under 30K.

My bet would be that it's a good car for $ appreciation.  Don't let the 
Ferrari puristas discourage you from 308 with the idea that it's a cheap 
Ferrari and therefore not collectable.  Remember the Dino246GT's that everyone 
said were really Fiats.  Try finding a nice one for under 50K today.    So, if 
you're only gonna go around once, do the gusto, go for it, just do it and go 
find one you like.

Ted Smith
356 B cab
356 C cpe
911 SC cab
66 GT350 Mustang
one half dead cat

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 10:06:52 -0700
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: 500 HP 928?

On 4/18 Sean asked:

WHAT?!?!!  Why haven't you mentioned this before on the list?  What
kind of engine is it?  What year is your 928?  Why automatic?
 - Sean  '80 9

On 4/18 Matt asked:

>What year is your car?  What engine did you install?  How / How
>easy was the transmission mod?


My 928 started as a US '80 with 3 speed automatic.  The original
engine had a "melt down" (overheated in seconds, burst the
coolant tank, siezed a pulley on the front--it was ugly!).  I
replaced that engine with a professionally built racing engine
based upon an '82 Euro 928.  It retains the big valve heads and
the Euro block, but all other components were replaced with high
performance parts.  It was very well balanced, and should be
good for between 9,000 and 10,000 rpm (although wear would be
tremendous).  It has very radical, long duration cams, and
will not idle for more than about 10 seconds in drive (I shift
to neutral at stop lights).  It gets 9 mpg on the highway, and
7 mpg in city driving (tradeoffs).

I had the original transmission rebuilt to help it live peacefully
with the engine, but my mechanic says it probably won't last.
The adjustment I was refering to is simply the shift linkage
tension adjustment on the side of the transmission.  Tighten
the cable for higher shifts and longer duration in low gears.
To get it to shift harder (less slip, to protect the trans.),
turn the set screw on the side of the transmission (I don't
remember which way).

                                                 --Mike

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 10:29:27 -0700
From: "    John Jones" <J.Jones@az05.bull.com>
Subject: Cooling a 2.7 911S

I have 77 911S and have completely rebuilt the engine, so I know it's in
reasonable shape. It's timed correctly and meets emissions.Has an 11 blade fan
(air conditioning but no drive belt). The ambient temp. makes a big, big
difference to its operating temp. This is particularly noticable in as in
Phoenix, mornings can be 35 degF in Winter and 90 degF in Summer. The car had a
fsctory loop cooler but this was not suficeient to keep it cool in the Summer
and certainly not if you work the engine. The best solution is to use a high
efficiency cooler in the fender or front valance. Not wanting to spend $500
just for the cooler I made a cooler from two VW aftermarket coolers in parallel
and mounted it in place of the loop. This arrangement keeps the engine at a
reasonable temp. in Summer but I still would not want to race.

My tame independent Porsche shop tells me this pretty normal for the 2.7
engine.

At one point I did try misting water into the cooling shroud and it works but
don't try it with anything but distilled water.

Any other ideas?

------------------------------

Date: 19 Apr 1995 10:27:31 -0800
From: "Rodger Keesee" <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: re- bad boys, girls, cars

Soren states:

a lot of porsches.  CHP says "no, porsche drivers are pretty good,

- ------------------------------
I buy alot of cars at auctions.  Last month I bought a lowered and
be-spoilered, black '85 318i with gold rims.  Blacked out windows, goofy
windshield wipers - the works.  

There has not been a cop yet that has passed me on the high way without a
thorough check of the plate registration date and a long stare at the driver. 

But even less desirable is the attention the car gets from other vehicles. 
People seem to *hate* this car, and if they like the car, they seem to *hate*
the driver.  
A carfull of teenage boys followed me for miles through town once they saw a
clean cut white boy with wire-rim glasses and a tie behind the wheel.

The got the car for $1500 and will sell it for 4-5k.  I'm beginning to wonder
if it's worth it.

Rodger

cooler(s).

From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Re: Speed-regulate legislation ?

Andrew Kalman responds to an earlier posting, the following wisdom to 
Porschephiles:

> >Only reason to wish success for assault rifle lobby is that the You Should 
> >Be Just Like Me Coalition may take the time to finish them off before coming
> >after auto hobbyists.
 
> May that day never come. My stance is that if you take any (U.S.) freedoms
> seriously it behooves you to oppose the You Should Be Just Like Me
> Coalition every step of the way. Better yet, be proactive instead of
> reactive. It will make for a much better America.

Yer Kindly ol' Unka Bart, throwing his Ruger Mini-14 into the jump seat of his 
911 to provide a bit of List relevance, notes that folks on FIREARMS have heard 
him rant on this very theme.  United we stand, divided they come after us and 
take away *all* our toys, because they do not fit the social "Norm."

When we allow them to get away with denying us *any* of our fundamental 
liberties, we are well on the road (at the *strictly enforced* speed limit, 
at that) to see them deny them all.  Folks, it's never the *Other* guy's 
rights that are being trampled, it *Our* rights.  Every Time.  Stick together,
support the folks trying to roll back gun control, support the folks trying
to roll back the phony *energy* speed limits, support NORML, support your
friendly neighborhood anarchist (Hi Lonn), suppo...

        [whack!] <ouch!  Hey...> [Bop!]  (thud)

This return to sanity is brought to you, courtesy of your friends in the "You 
Should  Be Just Like Me" Coalition.  Please do not adjust your mailers.  Yer 
Kindly ol' Unka Bart will be all right as soon as the doctor finishes checking 
him over and administering his, er... medication.


------------------------------

Date: 19 Apr 1995 10:44:22 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: None

Bill writes:


>I'm throwing out the idea of law governing cars to 70mph just for 
>academic food.  I think its a hard thing to argue against. I'd be 
>curious to see a CNN debate on such a thing. (of course I'd hate 
>it because, well, my name's Bill and uh, I speed... I'm in a 12 
>step program for it...)
>
>In any event, how would you argue against such a thing. Its not 
>a 'You Should Be Just Like Me' thing. How can you argue *for* 
>being allowed to drive over 70mph? Its more dangeous, more gas, 
>wasted police, more $$ etc.

It's pretty easy to argue against.

First, an example:

Around 1973 there was a "well intentioned" law (regulation/decision?)
that all cars should have the seat belt fastened before they could
be started.  How could anyone argue against such a good idea?

The stupidity was appearant to more people after a woman 
was raped because she could not start her car and get away.

Second, why do you feel that this decision should be made for us?
Personally, I'm a big boy and can make my own decisions and be 
responsible for the consequences of these decisions.

Now let's examine your points:

Dangerous to self.  Okay, driving fast is more dangerous.  So what?  
Do we also ban *all* dangerous activities?  Gee, now we're all 
the same...

Dangerous to others.  So is driving a large car.  Passengers in a 
large car are safer partly because of the increased danger to the 
other car in a collision.  Do the momentum calculation before 
replying.  We can all drive Yugos and, yup, all be the same...

More gas.  Yes, it uses more gas.  So what?  Do we ban all 
activities that use unnecessary gas *or* other hydrocarbon 
products?  Gee, now we're all the same... (and bored)

Wasted police.  I always feel good knowing the police have nothing 
better to do with their time than write speeding tickets [he says 
with tounge firmly in cheek].  Besides, they only get wasted if 
they step in front of the fast car.  Most of them know better.  ;-)

More $$.  Get real.  Their *my* dollars.  I buy the car.  I buy 
the gas.  I buy the insurance.  I pay for the roads.  Maybe all my  
money should all be taken away from me because I obviously am not 
capable of using it "correctly."  Then, yup, you guessed it, we 
can all be the same...

Bill, you obviously have pushed some of my buttons.  I realize your 
intentions are good.  However, please remember what road is paved 
with good intentions.


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 10:52:06 PDT
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: radio wiring

>From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
>To: porschephiles <porschephiles@tta.com>
>Subject: RE: Blaupunkt radio wiring, help
>Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 12:19:00 PDT
>
>I tried sending this once but saw no reply.
>I went looking for aftermarket radios (Blaupunkt in particular) and noticed 
>that they have wires hanging out the back of the radio for everything.  All 
>the factory German radios I've seen have common connectors for 
>power/speakers.  Can one purchase an aftermarket radio with these German 
>connectors.  It would be nice to simply swap radios without having a wiring 
>nightmare on my hands.  Any locations or companies that carry these radios 
>would be appreciated.
>
>Thanks,
>David B.
>'89 944

Crutchfield Electronics (Ohio) should be able to sell you an adapter
that will connect your new radio to your old harness.

Aftermarket radios don't have the connectors in them for a couple of
reasons:  They cost money, they take up space inside the radio, and
they're different for every car.

Gary.

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 11:03:24 -0700
From: "    John Jones" <J.Jones@az05.bull.com>
Subject: (Fwd) RE: Cooling a 2.7 911S


- --- Forwarded mail from "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648"
<kennedy@admin.njit.edu>

Does your 2.7 still have its emissions plumbing including thermal reactors?
I'd pull 'em off and use them only at emissions testing time.  Switching to
 ->74 3-into-1 heat exchangers made a big difference in the sound, and a
small difference in the feel, of my 2.7 engine.

The Terbatrol cooler solved my similar problem, but I still hesitate to put
the airconditioning back in.  Since going faster seems to help a good deal,
the next thing I would try in your situation is fan blowing across the oil>
cooler(s).
B.
>-- End of excerpt from William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648

I'm not sure my exhaust is original. I don't have thermal reactors under the
heads. I do have a longitudinal cylinder between the two three branches and the
single input silencer. I belive the two reactor set up was CA only and CA had
an EGR. My 77 only has an air pump, which is disconnected except for emmision
tests.

unny you should mention the fans there are two 12v sitting under my desk at the
moment.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 13:11:23 PDT
From: Robert M Zampardi <us000812@interramp.com>
Subject: Driving Story, HOT 914

To continue the thread:

My first 914 was basically a running parts car, rusted so bad had to jump
over the door to get in..  But it had a great paint job!!
Well one day i am tooling around in my old neighberhood Brooklyn NY
and i smell gas, well i say i will just wait till i get home and take
a good look around see where that gas is leaking from.
At this point i am less then a mile from home..
I turn a corner step on the gas and the car starts to stall.!?
I floor it and suddenly people are all yelling:
YOUR CARS ON FIRE, YOUR CARS ON FIRE, 
I look in the rearview mirror and sure enough flames are shooting up
I look for a place to pull over and i see a big pile of sand from a 
constuction job, i pull over there jump out pull out my small fire
extinguisher (heard this happens) and slap the engine cover to open it.
if finally opens i dump the extinguisher and the fire continues!
Next i grab handfulls of sand and begin dumping it in the engine compartment,
(fuel injected)  eventually the fire goes out.
For my stupidity at not pulling over sooner I pushed her home.
Four hours of vacuuming and rewiring and she was back on the road.
I now keep a big fire extinguisher in any 914 i am driving...
rz

- -------------------------------------

76 Street 914, Lagoon Blue, with Saratoga Top

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 15:13:16 -0400 (EDT)
From: Rick Shimkets <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Backfiring 914

OK guys, I have a problem which seems to be getting worse.  Ever since 
replacing the clutch on my '72 914 I noticed a little engine backfire 
when coming off the throttle.  I also did a little F.I. work then.  I 
removed the exhaust and then replaced it, and PERHAPS I didn't get it on 
perfectly tightly at the exhaust manifold, which was difficult for me to 
see with my primitive lift equipment.  Anyway, I've noticed the car is 
now backfiring loudly when coming off the throttle and appears also to be 
running rich.  I have tried to lean the engine out by adjusting the 
pressure manifold adjusting screw but have exhausted its maximum with no 
effect.  Is the backfiring an exhaust gap or an effect of the rich 
running engine?  HELP!!!!   Thanks!     Rick   quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 11:46:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: sanctus2@annex.com
Subject: Re: Re[4]: Speed-regulate legislation



On Wed, 19 Apr 1995, Bill Ataras wrote:

> 
> Text item: 
> 
> Disagree. It's the public's business how fast you drive, because they're at 
> risk. It's not only *YOUR* life, its *OUR* lives. And there is no fast lane, so 
> you can't base your assumtions on it.
> 

You miss the point completely.  The answer is NOT to regulate speed, but 
rather to provide a place for the public to drive there automobiles at 
the speeds they were designed to be SAFELY driven.  Furthermore, even 
without such a place, I can SAFELY (15 yrs of driving with NO accidents, 
scrapes, etc.  not even a close call) drive my car at speeds far in 
excess of 70MPH (traffic, road, and weather conditions permitting).  And as 
long I'm driving my car SAFELY, it becomes *MY* business and *MY* 
business alone in ANY case.


 '86 928S
 Jack Schwartz
 sanctus2@annex.com

From: cmxi@tiac.net (cmxi)
Subject: Brake Fluid Overflow

Does anyone else have a problem pushing brake fluid out the vent pipe at
track events?  The car is an 86 911 w/ 930 brake calipers & master cylinder
and evidence of the overflow can be seen under the car (wet on left front
suspension pieces and drops by right front wheel at rest). 

I'm not boiling fluid and the fluid/pedal level drops enough in one run
group to trip the brake light. The beginning fluid level has no effect on
the problem and I have tried routing the overflow up above the level of the
resivoir.

Any ideas?
Regards.

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 15:42:40 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: More 914 Flywheel Play

        Okay, I went and got the Feeler-Gauge endplay measurer.  Now
the problem is that the flywheel longitudinal position varies A LOT
depending on where the flywheel ROTATION is!  As it goes past the
TDC mark, it moves OUT about (guess) 1/8"!!!  And at 180 around from
TDC, it moves back in to where it was.
        It was doing this before I took the flywheel off--but I had
hoped/thought it was just my imagination.
        So NOW what?  Am I just hosed anyway?  I'm tempted to throw
the thing back together and just drive it until it explodes....  8(

- --dd  (With mouting frustration levels!)
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Subject: re; fast driving and accidents


    I have to agree largely with Bill--fast driving is a danger to everyone
     within smashing distance. We all have the responsibility to drive
     carefully, its just not our own butts out there.
 
    I also agree that its Reckless driving that usually causes accidents,
     and in my opinion Porsche drivers aren't the worst of the lot--usually
     Porsche drivers are older, more conservative, and less apt to display
     the level of their testosterone thru driving itself than, for instance,
     a 21 year old driving a 5.0 Mustang GT...
                                                    
    Where Porsche owners go wrong is in thinking that the Car itself gives
     them the privilege to drive faster than "less capable cars," or that
     somehow the ability to buy a Porsche makes us inherently smarter.  
     Anybody whos ever pushed their car on the street must have had some  
     experience where they almost bit it or took out someone else in the
     process....

         -Lee A, my $0.02....

Subject: Leaning the backfiring 914

anyway and have chaecked all the FI components, I am wondering if simply 
reducing the fuel pressure from the upper limit to the lower limit will 
help.  If there is an exhaust gap it must have been growing, because the 
problem seems to be worsening.  Any ideas for a way to check for leaks at

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 17:44:45 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: Re: Re[4]: Speed-regulate legislation

I'll throw some fuel on Jack Schwartz' fire by reminding him that this is
a democracy, which means any stupid plurality of the population can have
its way.  So we the people will decide what you can safely do, Jack, and
we will also repeal the bill of rights, outlaw fast cars, condemn your
property and pay you whatever we please, and so forth, unless the inertia
built into representative government slows us down so much that we forget
what we wanted to steal.

Only hope for Porsche-wackos is to seduce more of the population into
Porsche-wackiness, or at least to maintain the Porsche-wackiness of all
those already afflicted.  A great and successful role for porschephiles@
tta.com.

B.
(wondering how much more of this bill of rights thread we get before
Stan gets surly out loud)

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 17:50:15 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@Symtec.com>
Subject: 944T Cooling System Question

I have a question concerning the cooling system of my 1988 944T
with 64K miles. When driven above 40 MPH or so the temperature
gauge stays fast on the lower tic mark (which I assume to be at
the bottom of the operating range). However, when in traffic or
even just stopped at a light for any time at all (like at an
interstate exit) the gauge rises to the upper tic mark. I can
hear the fan relay(s) operate and bring the temperature down to
maybe the middle of the gauge. When the fan(s) stop running the
gauge rises to the upper tic mark. I have never seen it above the
upper tic mark. The water pump and thermostat were replaced about
14 months ago. Like some 928-related posts here, I have noticed
that the temperature gauge will tend to read slightly higher when
there is more drain on the battery. Is the general behaviour of
the temperature gauge typical for this car?

TIA for any posts or replys,

Doug Donsbach
dld@symtec.com
'88 944T
'88 735i
