Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 18:19:54 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Now a word from the Author

To preface, I started my postings on driving when I got caught up in the
thread on 944s vs. 911s and how 911s are such evil handling beasts.  My
response was to illustrate how I can brake and turn-in with my Carrera, a
maneuver that the general public thinks is impossible.  Then I was asked to
explain the technique of trailbraking.  After reading the admonishments from
Jerry, Larry, Jim, and Ed concerning the potential "misuse" of my explanations
 on trailbraking, I have to agree...they are absolutely right.  The
techniques of trailbraking are strictly for expert drivers, people with at
least 30 or 40 track events under their belts.  And even then, most will not
be able to do it well.  It requires consummate car control, and is definitely
a delicate balancing act.  In case there's any ambiguity, I'll state it
again:

==> TRAILBRAKING IS FOR EXPERTS!  <==

If you are a novice...Don't even think about it.  In the future, I will
preface any driving information with the group that it is directed to:

       Novice (drivers with less than 10 events)
       General (drivers with between 10 & 30 events)
       Advanced (drivers with over 30 events)

Like any other sport, driving a car on the track has a long learning curve.
 Just because you can drive on the street, that doesn't make you a race car
driver.  Just like throwing a baseball doesn't make you a major league
pitcher.  As a novice, you have to start with the basics, but the basics will
get you 90% of your speed.  Tricks like trailbraking are for those looking
for that last 10%.  Matter of fact, if you start playing with the last 10%
too soon in your "career", it could mess up your learning curve, and you
might not learn the basic 90% properly.  I have always been amazed by the
number of people with 15 or 20 track events, generally white group drivers,
who have developed major flaws in their styles, and have to be "retrained".
 Because of their flawed style, they cannot continue to improve.  It can be
quite frustrating.

So here's a MAJOR TIP for you novices; learn how to come out of the corner
properly.  Forget everything else for now; brake easily, turn-in gently, find
the apex, and come off the corner like a bat out of hell.  That skill will
get you 90% of your speed, and if mastered, will make you faster than 90% of
the other drivers.  It's that simple.  A renowned tennis player and coach,
Vic Braden, was asked by a novice player how one should structure their game.
Should you scatter your volleys, should you attack the net, should you play
the sideline shots?  His response was a model of simplicity.  He said "hit it
deep". If you can hit the ball deep to the end line on EVERY VOLLEY, you will
be better than 90% of the other players.  When you can do that consistently,
you are ready for the finer points of the game.  When you can turn in to the
corner at a reasonable speed, floor the gas and accelerate PAST the apex and
down the straight consistently, on every turn, then you are ready for the
next step. Remember, know the line, brake at a comfortable rate, turn-in at a
controllable speed, slowly floor it and drive past the apex.  I'll explain
more on how and why to do this with my next post.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 18:25:16 -0400
From: Carrera86@aol.com
Subject: Re: Brake Fluid Overflow

Hi Roger,

Yes, I've had the same problem with my 86 Carrera. In fact I think it's a 911
thing.  
The fix is easy and cheap.

Get a hose about 1' long and run it inbetween the fluid fill container and
the overflow tube.  Clamp it tight at the resivoir. This keeps the fluid from
pushing out all under the car. Filling it to the top will not help.  Believe
it or not, this does work. If you have any questions, feel free to call me.

Christine Ryan
(203)877-0618

Carrera86

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 18:37:06 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: What's a '73.5 911T-is it special?

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	In my brother's quest for a Porsche he recently came across an 
older 911T that his girlfriend's brother owns.  He just got a new Miata 
(what a sellout) and the dealer wouldn't give him but $6000 for such an 
old car.  He'll sell it to my brother for $7200.  Its in nearly perfect 
shaper with three owners, engine never apart (!) except to install 
Carerra tensioners.  The old engine (115K)worries me but all else is OK.  
It was made in July of '73 so he calls it a " '73 and a half".  He says 
they added the funky rubber bumperettes in the '73.5 and thats about the 
only difference.  Is there anything else different or special?
	Some sources say the 911T is the cheap model and isn't worth 
fooling with, is this true?  My brother is in LOVE with this car and its 
all he thinks about, I hate to tell him its a bad car.  I think its a 
great price considering its condition, and my natural instinkt for weird 
cars says GET IT!  What do you think?

Jay Karolyi
'70 rustbucket 914
'75 Corvair/914 now christened "The Bastard"  :^)
'77 924
'80 Toy 'rolla with sticker "My other car is a Porsche" --3 to be exact!

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 17:52:32 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: What's a '73.5 911T-is it special?

> He'll sell it to my brother for $7200.  Its in nearly perfect 
> shaper with three owners, engine never apart (!) except to install 
> Carerra tensioners.  The old engine (115K)worries me but all else is OK.  
> It was made in July of '73 so he calls it a " '73 and a half".  He says 
> they added the funky rubber bumperettes in the '73.5 and thats about the 
> only difference.  Is there anything else different or special?

Ummm. Yes.

The '73 T had MFI. The '73.5 had CIS. There are *LOTS* of one-year only
CIS parts on the '73.5 (the good news is that with some luck and a little
tuning, you can get more power by using the more common 2.7  parts).

115k on that engine doesn't worry me *too* much -- it may need a valve
job and probably does need guides at that milage, but otherwise should
be relatively OK.

> 	Some sources say the 911T is the cheap model and isn't worth 

I like the early Ts. They are much better cars for "normal" foolin' around
driving in traffic stuff. Sure, you'll get *SMOKED* by an S or an E 
or most hybrids, but you'll have a lot of fun. Good "starter car" for
a prospective Porschephile.

Now, the caveats: get the 911 FAQ. You'll need to have a full check-out
done, including compression and leak-down. It would be smart to have
the  CIS checked out pretty hard too. And if it doesn't have CIS, but
has been Weberized, make *DAMN* sure that this is something the emission
guys are happy with... Trying to find the stuff to go BACK to a '73.5 CIS
will be impossible.

Stan

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 18:54:44 -0400 (EDT)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Crash tests and Porsches

Hi,
Did anyone see the offset crash test on Dateline NBC last night? It was 
conducted by an insurance-company sponsored organization.

The test was a 50% offset frontal collision at 38 mph. This sounds 
awfully like the German TUV tests. Are they similar?

Can anyone on the list get access to the TUV tests, which presumably 
cover more cars? I would like to get info on which cars sold in the US 
have good TUV crash tests. 

How did Porsche do in offset collisions?

Also, can a rollcage improve crash results? I assume that a real racing 
seat with a 5-point harness and a full rollcage mounted to the frame of 
the car should make some difference. Personally, I could live with racing 
seats, 5-point harness and full rollcage in a sports car. I just wouldn't 
drive it to work every day. :-)

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 16:48:00 PDT
From: Bill Ataras <Bill_Ataras@ccm.jf.intel.com>
Subject: Re: Speed-regulate legislation


Text item: 

]Fact 1: Approximately 400 accidents were caused last year in California by 
]vehicles moving too slow.
]
]Fact 2: 47 accidents were caused last year by vehicles moving to fast.
]
]Conclusion:  Speed, in and of itself, does not increase the likely hood of an 
]accident.  Speed actually decreases your likely hood of an accident.  (for a 
]variety of reasons) Speed only determines the severity of an accident if one 
]occurred.


I see what you're saying. However, couldn't one argue that the ones going too 
slow were the ones actually doing the speed limit and not 75-80mph ? Meaning in 
reality they were caused by everyone else going to fast. The ones going to slow 
were hit by the ones going faster, yes?  Again, if the government has determined
the speed limit to be 65, shouldn't it back that by limiting vehicles to it ? 
Then people doing the speed limit won't cause accedents.

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 20:02:38 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 Vibration

Stephen Davies said in regard to his 944 Turbo:

> I am wondering how much the lower ring and pinion (same as 944S)
>costs and how much extra labour is involved ?

If you EVER plan to take your car on the track forget the 944S R&P.  It is
MUCH weaker than the stock Turbo unit and has completely ruined at least two
transaxles that I am aware of when it blew up. For the street only, it is
probably ok, but a chip for the Motronic is safer if you want to go faster.

Jon Lowe
'87 944T Escort Series

 already been made that people *can't* drive safely above 60-65 (by virtue of 
 existing laws). Given this assumption, its seems natural MAKE SURE they do it 
 not by throwing cops/courts at em, but by making it so their cars simply can't 
 do it.

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 20:31:34 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Vacuum Brake Bleeder

>Ed Mellinger writes

>p.s.: While on the subject I could use some advice from any of the
>gurus who've read this far: I bled the brakes using my "Mityvac" hand
>vacuum pump.  As always, it sucked more air around the bleed screw than
>it did fluid out of the pipe.  I tried the Vaseline-around-the-threads
>bit suggested here without avail (and gosh, I sure hate using Vaseline
>near brake rubber!).  I wound up using one of the cone-shaped adapters
>supplied with the Mityvac, but I had to remove the bleed screw to make
>it work.  All's well that ends well (did I mention my rigid, tumescent
>brake pedal yet?), but I'm still mystified by how you pros use the
>vacuum bleeders...

Not calling myself a pro, but I made a vacuum bleeder out of an old 30 lb.
freon can.  I use my refrigeration vacuum pump to pull the can down to 25"
vacuum.  Then I attach the hose to the brake nipple.  It really works great,
and only takes a few minutes.  It does suck a little air around the nipple,
but it pulls really hard, and if you look at the design of the nipple, you
will see that the air does not get into the caliper.  It ALWAYS gives a rock
hard pedal.  BTW you could use an old 120v refrigerator compressor to get a
vacuum.  It should pull down to about 20" vacuum.
 

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 19:34:35 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: What's a '73.5 911T-is it special?

> I was under the impression that the early '73T US cars were carburated,
> early '73T ROW cars were MFI and that late '73T cars were all CIS.

Nope. '72 was the magic year. The T kept carbs for Europe, but everything
else had MFI. Transition came in 73.5 for the T moving to CIS, and all other
production modles had CIS in '74. Of course, there are racing engines with
Kuegelfisher MFI, and even the odd unit or so with carbs. But from '72 
on in the US and '73 on in the RoW, if you bought a 911, it had injection.

> ... so I'm probably making a fool of myself 
> (particularly when questioning Stan).

Well, I *DO* make mistakes on this stuff. I've had to promise myself not
to respond to anything between the hours of 3:00 AM and 8:00 AM, which
tends to cut down on the errors, but don't believe it just because it's
*ME*!! Shoot, that would be like, oh, believing something just because
it was printed in Excellence, or European Car, or Pano, or in particularly
nice script in the bathroom at work...

Stan

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 19:24:14 -0500
From: stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda)
Subject: Re: Want a 944, what year?

>I am getting ready to buy a new car (current one is Honda CRX, don't yell).  
>My heart is telling me, 'get a Porsche'.  I've always liked the look of the
944. 
> My budget is about $10,000.  Since I'll finance thru my credit union, the 
>car must still be in the 'Blue Book' (7 years?).  
>
>Can anyone give me some help.  I'm not a race driver.  I want a nice looking 
>auto that is dependable, keeps it's resale value, and will be fun!  
>
>Are there any BAD years for 944s?  For the good years, should I check that 
>certain items have already been repaired?
>
1985 and1/2 or later, because they have the better aluminum A-arms. 1987 or
later, as they have ABS. You should be able to get an 86-88 8 valve 944 in
very good condition for less than $10,000. I'm not sure on pricing on the 16
valve 944's, but they have about 40 more HP.

Scott Sanda
86 944 race car
Scott D Sanda

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 18:37:01 -0700
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: Re:  Trail Braking OhmyGod

ross said:


I've read how to do this and have tried once or twice on the 
street, but I can't reach the throttle while my foot is on 
the brake.  Is there some adjustment that can be made to 
pedal height or am I just doing it wrong?  

Ross Stites


Ross: Try using the ball of your foot on the brake. Slip the ball of
your right foot (the part under your big toe) to the point where it
is placed slightly right of center of the brake pedal. At this point
you should be able to roll your foot over to the right so that the
side of your foot (ideally the part of you foot under your little toe)
can be in a position where you can "blip" the throttle. This allows
you to raise the engine rpms up to the point where they will be matchly
with the rpms of the lower gear, hence a smooooooth downshift. 

also can be used as an alternative approach to left foot braking.

THis is what works for me. Some people actually position their heel
at the base of the accelerator with the ball on the brake. Others
will put their heel on the brake pedal and use the toe on the gas.

Really fancy footwork guys do the braking with the left foot and
leave the right foot on the gas (I can't do this on my car- not
enough room for my legs under the steering wheel.

Give it a shot- practice in areas where if you screw up and your
foot slips off the gas you won't end up running a red light or
anything dangerous. DO NOT TRY TO LEARN THIS AT A RACETRACK!!

Hope it helps.

 -jim

ps. if the above suggestions still don't allow you the ability
to reach both pedals, you can fabricate a lateral extension plate
for the accelerator to make the reach easier. I would save this
as a last resort.


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 19:08:05 -0700
From: Roger52@ix.netcom.com (Roger Eaton)
Subject: Rules for A/C in Porsches

notes  from  the  edge  of  the  world  !

These are observations and rules to live by if you drive a PORSCHE car with an

AIR CONDITIONER  attached to it.   By Roger  Eaton   Roger@ix.netcom.com

1. An a/c system can't be too clean  nor too dry !  Never allow dirt or moisture 
to
get any where near an open a/c line or fitting.  Remember, all the freon in your
a/c must pass thru an opening the size of a pin point each trip around on it's
circuit.  So a single drop of water can freeze and stop everything up, same thing
with dirt.

2. If you have a 911 or 912 or even a 356 with a condenser mounted on the lid
over the engine, you must always be cognizant of the fact that the AIR that is
drawn thru that condenser by the engine fan, keeps that condenser COOL.
So....When ever you are running the AIR COND> you MUST have the LID CLOSED.
Preferably completely.  The pressure inside the a/c system can and will escalate
up to 500 lbs. in about a minute, and if there is a weak fitting or hose you 
could
get a face full of R-12.  Trust me, you wouldn't like it !  Baring a weak hose 
there
is a pressure relief valve located on the rec/drier that is designed to melt and 
let
this pressure out. I can't begin to count all the calls we've gotten from dealers 
over
the years asking what this was when it happened to them, and always they
admit that ,yes the hood was open when they were charging the a/c.  This would
be like taking the fan off a real car and running the engine.

3.The SEAL on the compressor located behind the Clutch NEEDS to be lubricated
regularly that is preferably on a weekly basis. This seal is made of carbon and
when the oil dries out of it, it wants to score the steel plate it rubs against
causing grooves and subsequent leaks.  Leaking seals are easy to spot, just look 
on
the parts on body panels around the comp.,you will see a trail of oil right 
behind
the a/c belt.  It is almost impossible to have a completely dry seal but the best
prevention is once a week use of the a/c, just 5 min. a week that's all we ask !

4.The hoses used on all a/c systems up until the past couple of years, has always
been of the type that was made to leak slowly by putting small pin prick holes
along the length preventing pressure build up in any one spot. Well, now we have
a new kind of hose, mandated by the fed. It is called BARRIER HOSE. It has an
inner liner that prevents this leak thereby extending the life of your FREON.
Why this is important to owners of Porsches is that Porsches are unique in that
they use a LOT of hose because of the way the car is laid out. So making a
change to BARRIER HOSE could be one smart investment !

5. The A/C systems on the Porsche cars have evolved slowly over the past 30 or
33 years. Gosh , I can remember some mighty crude units in the early days, even
tried to make my  own once or twice, but I'm happy now just to make
Improvements to whats out there. Most any 911 or 912 can benifit from more
CONDENSER area , the problem being , there just isn't room for conventional cond.
to be mounted. What I have found is that there is room under the  car for a
single pass heavy duty cond. laid flat to the floor. It adds only ONE inch to the
bottom of the car and is rugged enough to take a lot of abuse. To date (13 years)
we has yet to have one damaged beyond simple repair.  An added benifit of this
cond. is that since this becomes the Primary cond. the cond. over the engine does
less work, thus adding less HEAT to the air coming in to cool the Engine !

6. The Reciever- Drier is a small tank located in the liquid side of most all a/c
systems and it's job is : to store a supply of liquid for the expansion valve to 
use,
to FILTER out any impurities that may have gotten in before they get to the x-
valve  and to act as a drier to remove any moisture in the system.  But the r/d 
is
only built to absorb a minute amount of moisture, measured in drops !  It has a
bag of dessicant much like you would see in a package sent from abroad to
protect electronics from moisture.   If the window on the r/d is cloudy it means
that it is saturated and must be replaced.   If the r/d is cool to the touch when
the system is fully charged it is plugged and must be replaced.  If you get a 
plugged
x-valve the materiel came from the r/d and it must be replaced.  If you have had
your car apart for two years restoring it and the r/d has been open to the
elements... REPLACE IT !  It can absorb enough moisture overnight to ruin it.  If 
you
do take your car apart, seal up the r/d tight and store in a DRY place.  NEVER
use a used r/d it just isn't worth the damage it WILL cause.

7. A FACTORY installed a/c in a 911 with two cond. (one over the eng. & one
under the chin )  will hold three (3) lbs of R-12 when recharged from empty.  All
other (aftermarket and single cond. fact. a/c ) should be satisfied with two (2)
lbs.  Late in 1976 Porsche tried a little scam and left off the FRONT cond on 
their
Factory units.  So all thru '77 and into '78  these cars had the worst a/c's  
that
Porsche ever offered.  Laate in '78 they reverted back to a two row cond. over 
the
eng. and the front cond. with it's fan in front of the spare tire. IF you have 
one of
these bastard units  this explains why you can't get cold. It's time to up date.

Enough for now , more as I think it up.  Questions ???    Roger

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 23:31:30 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: SS Heat Exchangers .........

Mark 

The MFI left heat exchanger has a spigot on the upright portion to which the
heavy rubber hose for thermostat heat is attached.  The carb and CIS heat
exchanger does not have this.  This is the only difference.  You can use a
MFI heat exchanger on a CIS car, but you cannot use a CIS/carb heat exchanger
on a MFI car if you are using the thermostat on the injection pump.

Regards

Pat Moyle

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 23:11:26 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: DP 935's

>      What is so special about the DP cars?  

Well, they're tuned by DP. That means they get some special bodywork,
some special engine stuff, some special suspension stuff, and a
very extra special surprise when you go to pay for it. DP is to Porsche
sort of what AMG is to Mercedes (or TuneupMasters is to Buick, but I
digress)

Which gets us to:

>           is [there]really any difference in value between this one and
>           a 930 say?  Do the DP 935's have any value other than the
>           car itself?  Rarity or otherwise?

My rule of thumb here is simple: if a car is bone stock, I can *KNOW* 
what the value is likely to be today, and probably for some time to
come. I also know exactly what it will cost to run and maintain, as
there is a wealth of such info available.

If a car is "tuned" or "modified", it's a JUMBO crap shoot. Is it *worth*
more? That's up to you. Did it *COST* someone more? You bet. Probably
a lot more. Do they want to get all of their money back when they sell
it? Invariably. "The guy who sold it to me swore that as an investment
it would outperform the S&P 500 index" is something I've heard a lot. *A 
LOT*. Particularly in the sort of Gold Chain Crowd that owns the real
high-dollar "specially tuned" cars whether from DP, Werke I, Kremer,
ANDIAL, or whoever. (As opposed to the kind of guys that own multi-color
BUTT-UGLY '72 911s with enough significant modifications to just about pay
for a new car... Scott? You *are* listening aren't you? 8{) )
Stock street cars you can value accurately, race cars you can at least
establish the market price and price to reproduce, stuff like DPs...

However, a car is more than a collection of parts. It has value to you
based on what it "does for you." If you love it, then it can be a  monumentally
shitty investment and still be a "good deal". 

Simple assessment: the questions you're asking indicate that you are
not totally committed with that "shit I GOTTA have this car" sensation
(that I for instance get everytime I'm within about 20 miles of a
'64-5 Carrera 2 cab...). So it's just about a dead certainty that you
WILL NOT BE HAPPY with this car, particularly when the bills come in.
If you gotta look at it like an investment, you picked the wrong car.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 21:11:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: Want a 944, what year?

On Wed, 19 Apr 1995, scott sanda wrote:

> >Are there any BAD years for 944s?  For the good years, should I check that 
> >certain items have already been repaired?
> >
> 1985 and1/2 or later, because they have the better aluminum A-arms.

The changes were actually more significant than just better control arms. 
Halfway into 1985 (April), Porsche upgraded the following components:
 
 - fuel tank (now plastic) increased to 80 litres!
 - updated oval dash
 - 30 mm lower seat position
 - 18 mm higher steering wheel
 - interior ventilation improved 35%
 - heating system improved
 - battery moves to well behind left rear wheel (not on my '86?!)
 - new crank and balance shaft
 - larger oil pump giving 10% increase in flow
 - front A arms and rear semi-trailing arms all cast in aluminum
 - improved mounting of drivetrain to reduce noise
 - flush bonded windshield
 - others?
 
Source: 'The Porsche 924/944 Book' by Peter Morgan

PS: This book is loaded with layout errors. I wonder if he bothered to 
proof-read it before printing.

implemented it's probably because I lost them.  Please send them along
again and I'll do my best to include them.

Enjoy the FAQ!

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 01:16:56 -0400
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: '73T



Stan writes:
>> The '73 T had MFI. The '73.5 had CIS.

Wade Guthrie writes:
>I was under the impression that the early '73T US cars were carburated,
>early '73T ROW cars were MFI and that late '73T cars were all CIS.

but caveats:
>Now, the books I've read aren't very well organized on this (and I
>I don't have any of them handy)

  Well, Wade, fortunately I DO have Bruce's book here at work :^)  You 
were close.  Porsche needed FI to meet US emissions.  In '72 and early 
'73, they used MFI on US 911T's.  They used carbs on ROW (because carbs
were cheaper than MFI).  Starting in Jan., 1973, they switched to 
CIS for US, because it was cheap and clean.  Bruce's book is ambiguous
as to whether '73.5 ROW T's had carbs or CIS, but I *think* it was carbs.

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa Mocchaschwartz (like the T*dmobile?)

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 23:21:40 -0700 (MDT)
From: Wade Guthrie <wade@realm2.realm.net>
Subject: Compression doesn't match Leakdown: Why?

I'm looking at the records for a car I'm thinking of buying (a '72 911S
Targa -- Hooray!) but one thing doesn't make sense.  Check out these 
numbers:

    Compression:	160  160  170  170  170  170
    Leakdown:		 4%  18%   7%   8%   8%   4%

What's up with cylendar #2?  What would cause a 160 compression with a
whopping 18% leakdown?

Now, of course I'm going to have new numbers run and ask the mechanic about
any anomolous results but I wanted to go in armed with a little 
understanding.

Thanks.

- --

wade@realm.net             |  'em away"            from 'The Hudsucker Proxy'
http://www.realm.net/~wade |

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 95 10:19:46 +0200
From: kevinh@hasler.ascom.ch (Kevin Holden)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1341 Thu Apr 20 02:00:07 CDT 1995


> Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 19:34:35 -0500 (CDT)
> From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
> Subject: Re: What's a '73.5 911T-is it special?
> 
> > I was under the impression that the early '73T US cars were carburated,
> > early '73T ROW cars were MFI and that late '73T cars were all CIS.
> 
> Nope. '72 was the magic year. The T kept carbs for Europe, but everything
> else had MFI. Transition came in 73.5 for the T moving to CIS, and all other
> production modles had CIS in '74. Of course, there are racing engines with
> Kuegelfisher MFI, and even the odd unit or so with carbs. But from '72 
> on in the US and '73 on in the RoW, if you bought a 911, it had injection.

My '73 'T' has Zenith 40 TIN's.. (swiss mkt), they changed in the last x months
production of '73 ROW to injection. It's detailed in Bruce Andersons(?) book
somewhere. 

Kevin.

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 01:49:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: Christopher Kirk <kirkch@elwha.evergreen.edu>
Subject: Re: Re[6]: Speed-regulate legislation



On Wed, 19 Apr 1995, Bill Ataras wrote:

>  I guess I agree *you* can drive safely. I'm working from the assumption that's 
>  already been made that people *can't* drive safely above 60-65 (by virtue of 
>  existing laws). Given this assumption, its seems natural MAKE SURE they do it 
>  not by throwing cops/courts at em, but by making it so their cars simply can't 
>  do it.

Bill, you're absolutely right - you would think that would be a perfectly 
natural, logical thing for the government to do...

Except you're not taking into consideration the amount of money local and 
state governments make from speeding tickets. I don't have any numbers to 
back this up, but I feel safe in supposing it's a substantial amount of
money (at least, my personal contribution has seemed pretty substantial!).

They're not as interested in public safety so much as getting more money 
and spending more money... after all, the local/state governments take in 
money from tickets and at the same time hit up the feds for more money to 
put more police on the streets. The number of traffic violations helps 
demonstrate a need for more police protection, and of course any dollar 
brought home from Washington just enhances a politician's personal 
prestige... and if they don't get money from the feds, hell, they can 
just fall back on local/state money; either way it's a classic plank for 
any campaign platform. Nice system - works for all involved, except us 
poor schmucks who pay the bills. But then, they don't really care about 
us much, do they?

I'd like to think they don't put speed limiters on cars out of fear of a 
public uproar, but I'm afraid I haven't been taking my Pollyanna pills 
(you know, those l'il red, white & blue numbers) like I've been told. I'm 
saving room instead for some of those yellow jobs Unka Bart keeps 
mentioning...

Christopher Kirk
Evergreen State College, Olympia, WA
81 True Blue 924 (humble but beloved)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Apr 95 11:56:38 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Re[2]: Speed-regulate legislation ?

> Text item: 
>In any event,how would you argue against such a thing. Its not a 'You Should Be
>Just Like Me'thing. How can you argue *for* being allowed to drive over 70mph? 
> Its more dangeous, more gas, wasted police, more $$ etc.

More of my own gas, which I paid for. Not a lot more, the car burns
just about the same unless I'm on the race track. There is no more
danger from driving at 100mph safely than there is from driving 20mph
safely. The police are going to waste their time no matter what you
do - have you ever been to a donut shop? The way for the police to
stop wasting their time is for them to actually stop wasting their
time: like, maybe, fire most of them - they have nothing better to do than
hang around at rest stops and highway cutovers. The more $$ thing is of 
personal concern only - I pay my road taxes, I pay for my car maintenance, and
I pay for my gasoline. What's it to you if I want to get somewhere for
it? I drive about 2-1/2 hours a day. If I could drive at a safe faster
speed, I would have 1/2 to 3/4 hours a day that I could do productive labor
in, and make more money as a result. It's a question of being able to
efficiently make use of my own resources as I see fit towards the ends
I am interested in - that includes some fast driving from time to time
(daily would be preferred).


- --

John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

	When I spoke to Peter Morgan about my favourite bug in the book
(the photo of the "944 Turbo" dash, identified by the boost gauge which is
*actually* an MPG gauge from an early 85/2 normally aspirated 944!!), he
gave me the impression that he would add it to the list he already had (this
was one he hadn't already spotted). He also said that he had no current plans
to update the book.

	While it's not in the same league as Bruce Anderson's 911
masterwerk (which *is* being updated), I don't know of a better book dealing
with the 924/944 family.

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 09:56:55 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: re : Compression VS Leakdown

Wade Guthrie <wade@realm2.realm.net> wrote :

>I'm looking at the records for a car I'm thinking of buying (a '72 911S
> Targa -- Hooray!) but one thing doesn't make sense. 
>    Compresn: 160  160  170  170  170  170
>    Leakdown:  4%  18%  7%   8%  8%  4%

>What's up with cylindar #2?  What would cause a 160 compression with a
>whopping 18% leakdown?

First of all, when you do a leakdown test you are supposed to listen to hear
where the leakdown is on any poor cylinder. Listen in the intake for intake
valve,
muffler for exhaust valve, or crankcase for rings. You really can hear it.
So where was it leaking?

Secondly, these compression numbers are too high for a 2.4 S with 8.5 to 1
compression. You should not crank it a dozen times until the pressure
builds real high. If they did this, it may explain why the #2 compression
was OK but leakdown bad. On the Porsche factory compression testers,
it graphs EACH stroke of compression, so you can see the results of even
the first stroke. I think about 3-5 strokes is enough if you just have a
guage.
My first 2.4 engine had about 110 PSI compression, but ran very strong
(strong enough to win the '85 SCCA championship and several pro solos).

So do the tests again, and let us know what you found.

Regards, 

Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com  '72 911S Targa (hooray!)  '73 914/2.0 (?)

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 10:43:29 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: Want a 944, what year?

Hello

I would recommend that you stay away from the 944 Turbo unless you HAVE to
have the extra performance. The Turbo does have a LOT more HP (220 vs. 150)
and better suspension and brakes, but also costs a LOT more for service. A
nice compromise would be to find an S model. These have 16 valve engines with
190HP, and the updated brakes of the Turbo. Service prices for the S models
is not that much higher than for the 8 valve 944 models. Keep in mind that
the regular 944 is not a slow car, it just doesn't accellerate all that fast.


For $10K, you should be able to find a perfect condition 85.5 - 88 944. You
might also be able to find an S model in very good condition. Some other
notes: I would stay away from the regular 89 944. That car has as 2.7L motor,
that was only used that year. Cars before 89 all used 2.5L motors. In 89 the
S2 model came out that used a 3.0L 16 valve engine. Those cars will be out of
your price range. Dual airbags and ABS were an option in 87, and became standa
rd in 88. If you look hard, and get lucky, you might find an 88 944 for 10K.
This might be the best car for someone who wants a very nice, good looking,
reliable, sweet handling, easy to drive, high performance car.

Real expensive items are common to replace are the water pump, and clutch.
Make sure that you have the car checked by a mechanic before you buy it. This
should cost about $100, and can save you bug $$$ later.

All the 944 models are excellent cars that will last a long time if taken
care of. Don't listen to any one who says that water cooled cars can't be
real Porsches!

Let me know it you need any more information.

Barry Lenoble
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 16:51:07 +-200
From: Jeroen Kuenen <j.c.kuenen@et.tudelft.nl>
Subject: RE: re : Compression VS Leakdown


Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com  wrote:
Secondly, these compression numbers are too high for a 2.4 S with 8.5 to 1
compression. You should not crank it a dozen times until the pressure
builds real high. If they did this, it may explain why the #2 compression
was OK but leakdown bad. On the Porsche factory compression testers,
it graphs EACH stroke of compression, so you can see the results of even
the first stroke. I think about 3-5 strokes is enough if you just have a
guage.

To MHO it is not possible to measure too long the compression.
After several stokes the compression tester is filled with compressed air and each additional stroke will not add more air into the tester, because the maximal reached pressure in the cilinder is equal to the pressure in the tester after some strokes.
I assume the compression tester is a pressure gauge with a valve which lets air flow in but not out.

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 11:03:57 -0400
From: PLAlbrecht@aol.com
Subject: Offset crash tests

Taka Mizutani asked if the German TUeV offset crash tests are available to
the public.

The German magazine Auto Motor und Sport (or auto motor und sport if you
adapt their style) cosponsors offset tests with TUeV Bavaria and publishes
these regularly in its biweekly issues. They also have an annual road test
book that I think includes these. ams for Feb. 10 has a cover photo fo an
Opel Corsa (sort of a Golf-class car) crashing against a Mercedes S-Class,
both moving at 50 km/h (about 30 mph) and hitting each other headon with 50%
overlap. Place your bets, gentlemen, place your bets...

Pete

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 08:04:31 PDT
From: mvolp.henr801b@xerox.com
Subject: 911 Transmission Problem.

I own a `77 911S that has a transmission problem.
While I was having the 2.7 RE-rebuilt (under warranty, thank God !), I gave the
transmission to a local PCA`er, who does extensive motor & transmission work,
to repair.  First gear was extremely elusive and 2nd was very notchy and would
grind at higher rpm shifts.  He said he replaced 5 syncro`s, 2nd & 3rd dog
teath, 2nd gear operating sleeve, gaskets and seals.  Parts & Labor $1200.
Now with a totally rebuilt motor and a supposedly rebuilt tranny, I`m ready for
some `next to new` performance.  NO  WAY.  The motor is runs great but the
transmission is EXACTLY the same.  The clutch is new and a new short shifter.
AND, to make a bad situation worse, now I can`t find this guy.
Is there something else in the transmission that could cause the problems or
does it sound like this guy stiffed me and really did nothing but take my money
?

Mike	 `77 911S, Zermat Silver

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 11:09:51 -0400
From: noorder@btg.com
Subject: Re: 914 Hose Help

Well, having gone through mush of the same I can understand the frustration,
but Dave Darling sent this to me a while back...  I think it should
help.

From: Graphics Group <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: 2.0L Hoses

2.0L Hoses
                **** DAVE's 2.0L 914 Hose Arrangement ****

Disclaimer:  This text and cheesy ASCII art contains something approaching
the state of the hoses on my 74 2.0L 914 when I bought it.  Not all of the
lengths are necessarily accurate--the ones that are harder to get to are
estimates; some hoses are listed as (the length of mine + some fudge
factor because I think mine is too short).  I am not even completely certain
that the hoses in my car are connected correctly--but the car seems to run
OK.  No guarantees, allright?  Lengths will probably be updated whenever it
is that I get around to replacing all of my hoses.  If you find that your 
2.0L 914 is different, please do drop me a line.

Items marked with a ***** are swapped on the diagram in the April 93 _Pano_
article on the 73 2.0L hoses.


General Diagrams (or: What Do You Mean By Fitting #2?) :

 Top of the Air Filter Box:         Manifold, under the Air Filter Box:
	
   #1       #2  #3                            #1
  _||_______||_//       Front of Car     _____||_
  |             \           ^           /     o  = #2
  |              = #4       |           |   O   |
  |             /           |       #3 =_______/
  --------------
                                'o' = hose fitting on top of manifold
                                'O' = throttle body


NOTE:  Front, Rear (aft), Left, Right all refer to directions as seen
from the Driver's Seat--e.g., LHS is the driver's side in the US.



    O=    "Flashback Valve" -- lives on LHS of engine, by fan shroud:
    "

13mm * 14"  from top fitting (up, not front)
            to #1 on Air Filter Box
13mm * 36"  from front fitting
            to fitting by RR spark plug
13mm * 18"  from rear fitting
            to fitting by LF spark plug


	Distributor advance and retard:

4mm * 7"    from RF side of throttle body
            to fitting on back of distributor vacc unit         *****
5mm * 36"   from LR side of throttle body
            to fitting on side of distributor vacc unit         *****


    Lines to Charcoal Canister:
    (connect in LF corner of engine compt., under relay box)

14mm * 36"  from upper line below relay box
            to "L" elbow on #3 on Air Filter Box
13mm * 36"  from lower line below relay box
            to fitting on the fan shroud on the LHS of the engine


	Deceleration Valve:
	(silver can near/below battery: one hose each end, one in the side)

5mm * 19"   from fitting on front of Decel Valve
            to "L" elbow on "T" fitting on Manifold fitting #2
10mm * 20"  from fitting on rear of Decel Valve
            to #1 fitting on Manifold
10mm * 20"  from side fitting on Decel Valve
            to #4 fitting on Air Filter Box


    Oil Filler Breather:
	
13mm * 10"  from Oil Filler neck/housing
            to "T" on #2 fitting on Manifold


    Pressure Sensor:
    (RHS, by battery, right by Decel Valve--one hose, one bundle of wires)

8mm * 26"   from Pressure Sensor
            to fitting on top of Manifold


    Aux Air Regulator:
    (Can sitting upright with a "T" coming out of the top, near LHS of
    the manifold)

13mm * 15"  from LHS connection on "T"
            to fitting #3 on Manifold
13mm * 11"  from RHS connection on "T"
            to #2 fitting on Air Filter Box






Alex Noordergraaf [noorder@btg.com]

'73 914 (no engine) [being stripped the old fashioned way - wire wheel :-)]
'73 914 2.0 [lurking under car cover]
[three complete 914s in boxes in the garage (back yard actually :-)]
'88 Honda CRX Si [SCCA DS/S4]
'91 Toyota MR2 [SCCA CS/S3 and SSB (maybe)]

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 95 11:21:04 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 911 Transmission Problem.

> I own a `77 911S that has a transmission problem.
> While I was having the 2.7 RE-rebuilt (under warranty, thank God !), I gave t
> transmission to a local PCA`er, who does extensive motor & transmission work,
> to repair.  First gear was extremely elusive and 2nd was very notchy and woul
> grind at higher rpm shifts.  He said he replaced 5 syncro`s, 2nd & 3rd dog
> teath, 2nd gear operating sleeve, gaskets and seals.  Parts & Labor $1200.
> Now with a totally rebuilt motor and a supposedly rebuilt tranny, I`m ready f
> some `next to new` performance.  NO  WAY.  The motor is runs great but the
> transmission is EXACTLY the same.  The clutch is new and a new short shifter.
> AND, to make a bad situation worse, now I can`t find this guy.
> Is there something else in the transmission that could cause the problems or
> does it sound like this guy stiffed me and really did nothing but take my mon
> 
> Mike	 `77 911S, Zermat Silver

Mi, Mike,

Hmm, did you see the old parts from the tranny, before you paid the bill.

What state was this in...by your domain name, I assume New York... did this
fellow have a DMV license to do auto repair work?  If so, you can contact
the department of consumer affairs and work to find him.

Of course, not everyone in the PCA has a perfect track record.  There are a
lot of people who hold membership cards, advertise that they are "PCA
members since 1977" and we never see them. All it takes to be a PCA'er is 36
bucks per year, with no other obligations...

Did you stop payment on the check yet?  


- --

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 95 11:22:49 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: Valentine / dream detector

I'd be in for a Valentine.

But also, let me take this chance to describe my dream detector:

The detector would consist of TWO units, one to be mounted on each side of the
car - one far left on the driver's visor, one far right on the passenger's
visor.  Each unit would have 4 or 8 horn antennas to receive signals from
any direction.  The units would be connected by a small wire.

The master unit on the driver's side would not have the arrow display, but
a small 1 inch square gas plasma grid for pinpointing the relative location
of any radar sources! 

Using two receiving units and building the the necessary logic, my dream
detector would triangulate on radar sources to tell me position and strength!

Mike, how feasible would this be?


Too bad Ohio's going to laser....


Matt Carpenter
'84 928S
'88 9000t
e-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 11:45:23 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Re: Valentine 1 deals 

Hi Mike, I'm Happy to oblige (must be those little green jobbies of ol' herb's
doin' their job...)

> Hi Bart!  
> 
> I have been reading a thread about discounts for P-filers directed 
> to yours truly.  Maybe you could be my anonymous re-mailer on 
> this very public program about which the group may not know.
> 
> 
> Valentine Research doesn't have any club discount programs
> like CM used to in the old days.  However, all is not lost.
> 
> Occasionally, some customers (not very many) take advantage
> of the 30-day no-questions return policy for various reasons:
> duplicated gifts, financial misfortune, unsympathetic spouse, etc.
> These units are technically "used" merchandise and are not
> re-sold as new.  These units are available at a discount compared
> to new price, but are really the same as new in condition and
> performance.  Every return is inspected for technical performance
> on the same test setup as new production and inspected for
> cosmetic flaws to the same level as new units.  Any deviations
> are corrected before being allowed to be sold again. 
> All refurbished units are the same revision level as new units.
> 
> Valentine One w/laser - refurbished = $359 + shipping
> Valentine One - radar only - refurb. = $296 + shipping
> 
> Quantities are very limited and availability is irregular so
> call ahead to see if any are available if you get the urge.
> 
> 
> Thanx :-)
> Mike

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 09:47:46 -0700
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: 022 or 031, for '69 912?

Folks,

Having heard the talk recently on this list regarding the superior advance
curves of the 022's and 031's over the 009, I've recently dusted off my
022 and 031 distributors (I have an 061, too, and may have it gold-plated).

My 022 and 031 units are both in good shape.  Which should I use?  Is one
better than the other, advance-curve-wise?

My 022 is cast iron; my 031 is aluminum - are they all like that?

Timing question: my specs state 3 degrees AFTER TDC.  But, that's for the
stock 061 distributor (no smog pump - never had it, never will).  Do I
use that timing for an 022/031, or do I go with the earlier 3dBTDC ??

Thanks again,

Peter Gregory

'69 912, polo red, rust-free daily driver in the Pacific Northwest.

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 13:29:55 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: my car

God I love my car
even though it is a victim of entropy
the aroma of warm leather, hot oil
the rolling thunder of a lopey idle trumpeted through the exhaust
the entimacy of the cockpit
the feeling of control as I grasp the wheel
and the tires bite the asphalt
the animal howl as the tach winds up
the visceral tug as I ease down on the throttle
the surge of power as I accerate from the apex (I somtimes hit it !)

sometimes when I park it I have to look over my shoulder as I
walk away, just to confirm that the dream is a reality.

It makes me look forward to going to work in the morning.

I'm soooooo glad I didn't buy the Dodge stealth I was looking at !


Sorry for the aimless ramblings......at least it was on subject !

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 13:38:23 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: lap timer

Hey to all electronic tinkerers out there.

I'm 0.5 heartedly thinking of designing and building an in car lap
timer.  Why build rather than buy......for grins why else ?

I'm thinking of a display which shows two lap times, the just completed
lap and the previous lap, the latter display above the former.  two
push button control - button one resets both displays to zero and
starts the lap timer, the second moves the lower display into the upper
display, displays the just completed lap time in the lower display,
and re-starts the timer from zero.  the timer itself wouldn't
be displayed as it counts up, only after time has been stopped - that way
one can see last lap and previous lap and compare - wouldn't be looking
at a counting timer anyway.

thinking of mounting the two buttons on or near the heater levers.  the
timer either as a seperate box on the dash in the middle or actually
replacing the clock and mounting the timer in a can in the clock hole
(in which case I'd put a clock in it too).

any PCA/SCCA rules I need to know about mounting this kind of gadget ?
anybody out there done this and have advice for me (ie what's a good
chip to use for timer - intersil has a stopwatch chip that some of 
the kitchen timers use, but it has lcd display outputs and I want to
use red 7-segment led displays) ?
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 13:50:26 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: re: Crash tests and Porsches

Taka Mizutani wanted to know where one can get crash test results. 

The German car magazine Auto, motor und Sport regularly has    crash test
results. In the Spetember 9, 1994 issue they had a large report on crash
testing, comparing the differences in US and European crast tests- head on
vs. offset, and air bag differences- US vs. Euro. There was a summary of all
the test results and there was no Porsche included. They were definitely
tested, but Auto, motor und Sport  was obviously not  invited to cover it.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 11:09:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: stevew@tamri.com (Steve Watson)
Subject: Re: Compression doesn't match Leakdown: Why?

Wade

I'm in agreement with Mike Piera on this one.  Your compression numbers are 
way too high for a 2.4S engine.  The compression on my '73S after full rebuild
was 140-145 psi in each cylinder.  Definitely have a mechanic you trust check
the engine over thoroughly before you make the purchase.

Don't know whats up with #2. Again a very good reason to have the car 
thoroughly checked.  

Just curious what the price is on this car and overall condition.  What options
does it have?

BTW, I just located a '72 911S w/ sunroof here in the Bay Area for $6800.00.
I think its already been sold though.  Boy what a deal!!

Steve

> numbers:

some psycho in a Ford Aerostar minivan floored his vehicle so as not to 
let me merge.  He must have been going 75 mph by the time he got 
parrallel with me.  Go figure...

    I would greatly appreciate it if anyone who knows could either

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 18:47:32 -0400
From: cbt@eduplus.ca (Stephen Davies)
Subject: 944 Turbo S

>I am looking at buying a 1989 944 Turbo S that has 134,000 km (80,000 miles).
>It is from a Porsche dealer and it will be brought right up to spec. My
>concern is the high mileage and the fact that it has been winter driven. At
>what mileage can I expect to have to spend serious money on a rebuild? The
>dealer tells me upto 200K miles is normal.

Regards,
Graham Gibson

Graham,

I recently (December) bought a 1988 944 Turbo S in Montreal from a dealer
with 129 K. It was not winter driven but my now sold '86 944 was for 4
winters. It did not suffer except for a little more frequent brake work as
a result of salt. (I live in Halifax, NS). 

Buying from a dealer (ie. 1 yr warranty) really helps, particularly buying
out of town. My local dealer has replaced the Turbo, head gasket, and O2
sensor all at no cost. The dealer had a good look at the engine during the
head gasket job and said that it was in very good shape so 200K miles +
seems reasonable. My '86 944 had 130K miles and was still in good shape and
used next to no oil.

I would not be scared off by the Kms as long as the car is in good shape.
If things do go wrong or turn up to be wrong you have one year of warranty
to help out. Check for little things because they may not be covered by the
warranty. Most major things except the clutch are.

Any more questions, let me know,

Stephen Davies
1988 944 Turbo S

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 13:41:05 -0700
From: "    John Jones" <J.Jones@az05.bull.com>
Subject: Car Theft

I think we all agree that having the car taken from you is potentially the most
dangerous position to be in. So how to protect yourself and get the bad guy.

I noticed a behavior on my car alarm which might be useul.

The other day I reset my alarm and was slow getting the vehicle just as I
inserted the key it beeped indicating it armed itsself. I took no notice turned
on the ignition an drove off. Low and behold 3 minutes later in the middle of
traffic off went the alarm. The alarms in question are those sold by AutoZone
and Checkers ranging from around $50 to $150. Can't think of the make but the
model is TSP500 or AA9447.

If you place an interuption switch in the power sensing line and trip it before
being forced out of the vehicle the alarm will show the above behaviour, don't
have the valet switch and light accessible or the remote on your car keys.

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 23:01:33 GMT
From: spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov (Steve Elkins)
Subject: 944S ignition wire problem


Greetings,

If you have a 944S you may want to check the clearance
between the ignition wires, comming from the distributor
and the hood.  The wires can wear through the insulation
on the hood and short out.  I noticed the Tech Tip in the
Euroselect Catalog and when I looked my wires had worn
through the insulation and I had a couple of nice shinny
bare metal spots on the hood from the wires.  

I changed the wire routing and replaced the insulation.

Steve '87 944S
*****************************************************************************
Steve Elkins
Sterling Software
NASA Ames Research Center
spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov
*****************************************************************************

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 17:38:45 +0800
From: tilden@maunakea.Data-IO.com (John Tilden)
Subject: 911 Oil Return Tubes



	I just recently replaced the oil return tubes on my '87 911
	Carrera, and thought I'd pass along a tip or two.

	The new Porsche factory supplied two piece return tubes have
	"improved" rubber O-rings of higher durometer and are very stiff.
	So stiff that I was unable to extend the tubes without some 
	additional mechanical advantage!

	I cut a pair of 1 inch copper solder sleeves in half, lengthwise.
	Cut the length of one of them down so that they would just fit
	end to end between the retaining ring and the flared end of the 
	inner tube when collapsed to a length that will just allow insertion 
	of one end in the case tube bore.
	Install a hose clamp on each to keep the two split halves together.

	Assemble the two split tubes onto the inner tube, then the snap ring,
	then the two inner O-ring seals, lubricate with motor oil.
	Slip the outer tube over the O-rings until it bottoms out against
	the split tube/retaining ring stackup. Install the two outer O-ring
	seals and lubricate with motor oil. The split tubes must slide freely
	over the inner tube and butt against the retaining ring around it's 
	full circumference.

	Install the large tube end into the Case bore and pivot the tube up
	to align with the bore in the cyl. head, then use your Large External
	Snap Ring Pliers to expand the tube assy until you hear the retaining
	ring snap home. Viola! Undo the hose clamps and remove the split tubes,
	repeat for the balance of tubes.

	Further hints, this job is done with the heat exchangers removed!
	The Left side front tube can be done without removing the Oil line
	from the case, its just a puzzle!

	911s don't have to have wet bottoms! They just take a little 
	maintenance.

John Tilden
tilden@data-io.com
				


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 17:24:54 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Fuel pres. gauge needed

Chris Woodward asked:

>I was hoping somebody might know a direction to go in mail order or 
>otherwise for one.  Nothing fancy, just effective.  

Summit Racing P/N SUM-G3126 ($16.95) is a small (<1.5" face) ,
made-in-Germany (they don't advertise this fact) 0-60psi fp gauge.  You'll
also need a fitting - they have one (SUM G1710, $8.99, currently
backordered, a little big but will fit German fuel line). 216-630-0200.

The trouble with most of these gauges is that they're not damped - as a
result, when your car is running, the needle is bouncing over a 10psi or so
range as the injectors (On L-Jetronic, at least) open and close.  I used to
use a big, fluid-damped guage, but it was really too big for the
application, and so I switched to the abovementioned one. Now the only
accurate way to measure the fp is to have the engine off but the fuel pump
running.

HTH,

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  | 
|___________________________________________|
|            Novice Welders Unite!          |
|___________________________________________|

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 21:21:10 +0000
From: jpalmer@shadow.net (John Andrew Palmer)
Subject: A/C, not low on freon, intermittently blows hot

I have an '88 944s. The A/C will blow nice and cold, and then suddenly begin
blowing hot, as if I had turned the temperature control to full heat. Its
really obnoxiously hot, and even on the coolest day, and the fan turned to
'0', I'll have to open on the windows. Sometimes it will spontaneously
return to blowing cold air, while driving. It seems that it always starts
blowing cold, though. Fiddling with the temperature dial has no effect. Nor
does the A/C switch. I think the temperature dial does work, because when
the A/C is blowing normally cold, the temperature can be adjusted to heat.
Also, when things are running normally, the A/C can be engaged and
disengaged with the dash A/C switch. I haven't been paying much attention to
the problem (been this way for about 6 months) since it hasn't been very
hot, but would like to get it repaired now. 

If you have any ideas as to what might be the problem, I'd appreciate
hearing from you. I'd like to have it serviced, but I'd like to keep the
costs under control. While a completely new A/C condenser, wiring, and dash
controller might fix the problem, I'd rather just replace a failed component. :)

- -- Palmer

        jpalmer@shadow.net

- -- Palmer

   jpalmer@shadow.net

bearing and check it over.  The gears he put in it were either older 911 
gears or some 914 higher ratio racing gears.  But it did not seem that he 
really beefed up the transmission.  He told me that in his own demo car 
that has alot of hp that he always has to rebuild them because he is very 
hard on them and something breaks.

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 22:56:06 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 022 or 031, for '69 912?

Oh boy, hear I go answering questions on 4 hours of sleep in 52 hours of
work...

> My 022 and 031 units are both in good shape.  Which should I use?  Is one
> better than the other, advance-curve-wise?

They're pretty much the same.

> My 022 is cast iron; my 031 is aluminum - are they all like that?

Yes.

> Timing question: my specs state 3 degrees AFTER TDC.  But, that's for the
> stock 061 distributor (no smog pump - never had it, never will).  Do I
> use that timing for an 022/031, or do I go with the earlier 3dBTDC ??

You are correct. Use the 3 BTDC for the 022/031.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 00:12:28 -0400
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: What's a 73.5 (11T

You ask if this the 73.5 T is special. Well, yes it is . Fairly few were made
(834). The 911s from '74 through '77 (2.7 L engines) are generally considered
not to be one of Porsche's best efforts at engine design. So the 73.5 cars
were the last of the early 911s. But a 73.5 T certainly is not rare (i.e.
investment quality). 


This 73.5 911s are considered the most refined early 911s by some. See your
local newstand for the newest "Excellence" magazine for a discussion of the
73 911S. Not to imply  the T is an S (it's not by at least 50 HP - just to
mention one reason). However more than one contemporary writer  considered
the T to a the most desireable 911 for a daily driver.  There is nothing
wrong with a T and they are great cars to own and drive.

Whether or not an early 911 is an appropriate daily driver in 1995.  I'll
leave to others. However if the car is driven daily there will eventually be
many other examples that are much more desireable (unless your brother is
into high maintenance sporst cars). I think a 73.5 911T would be a great
Porsche to own and enjoy as a recreational vehicle. I'm sure there are
excellent early 911s driven on a daily basis but their owners are would not
be in the ranks of the average car owner either.

Of course your brother must get ths car appraised by a knowledgeable Porsche
mechanic. These guys are not cheap until you think how much it can cost to
rebuild major components. Any rust or evidence of recent body/chassis repair
is a tip to insist on impeccible documentation of the repair/restoration or
run away as fast as your feet can carry you. 

Best wishes,

Bill Hutton
1971 911E Coupe 9111200038

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 00:29:29 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jason Caudle <caudlej@cs.unca.edu>
Subject: Re:Not low on freon, intermittently blows hot


	I'm new to the list and this is my first post so hello everyone. 
I am a college student with little $$$ and had a locked ac/compressor. I 
decided to save some money by installing a Nippondenso/Sanden changover 
kit. I installed the kit a couple of months ago and probably didn't save 
any money (After about a month of searching I found a rebuilt unit for 
about $500 and the changover was about $400 for the kit and 
reciever/drier). All worked well for a while and then I began 
experiencing similar problems of intermittent cooling (the comp. clutch 
was engaging only occasionaly). However, the system was cooling quite 
well while it was working which led me to believe there was still freon 
in the system. I reassured my belief when I found the pressure switch 
near the receiver/drier, shorted the leads and the clutch still wouldn't 
engage. I can also hear what I think is the relay for the compressor 
clicking on and off intermittently when the ac button is depressed. I 
don't know much about the electronics in the climate control but it 
works fine for the heater. 
	I may be missing something obvious here so any suggestions would 
be greatly appreciated. 

						Many thanks
							Jason

85 1/2 944
Soon to have Physics degree (May 13)    

------------------------------

Date: 21 Apr 95 00:31:01 EDT
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: Tech Bulletins

>From: Peter Tracy <pgt@novelmail.keps.com>
>Subject: Tech Bulletins (944)


>Last week someone mentioned about having a tech bulletin on adjusting the   
>timing belts on 944s. My nearest dealer seems to be ignorant about any   
>tech bulletins or updates to the factory manuals. I have seen some tech   
>bulletins in the Select catalog, but not this one. Where does one obtain   
>these bulletins?

>Thanks.
>Peter Tracy
>ptracy@keps.com


Peter,

Technical bulletins were issued by PCNA as a way to keep mechanics
informed of changes for a certain model car. At a later time changes
were made to the shop manuals, through supplements. These tech bulletins
are still available, compilied in a softcover book format. Each book contains 
all  the bulletins for a given year. I have found information that you may
be looking for. Techanical Bulletins Jan-Dec '88 # PNA 000 076 Book "E".
These books are available from any Porsche dealer. I used Stoddard's,
because they have most of them in stock(800 342-1414). Prices for these
publications vary ($16.95-$24.95 dealer list)

Good luck Peter!

Following is a complete list:

Technical Bltns 1977-1984     # PNA 000 056
"            "  11/84-12/85   # PNA 000 028   
"            "  1986 Only     # PNA 000 055
"            "  1987 Only     # PNA 000 062
"            "  1988 Only     # PNA 000 076
"            "  1989 Only     # PNA 000 082
"            "  1990 Only     # PNA 000 082A
"            "  1991 Only     # PNA 000 082B
"            "  1992 Only     # PNA 000 082C
"            "  1993 Only     # PNA 000 082D
"            "  1994 Only     # PNA 000 082E



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 23:51:27 -0500 (CDT)

Hello All:

too long, and a few days ago a little lever in the handle
mechanism snapped.  Had to buy a new assembly just to get
the lever, $90.  This would not have happened if I had:

   o  Sprayed some lubricant on the moving
      parts inside

Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 22:50:36 -0400
From: HHeath3@aol.com
Subject: The "right" 944

I can't recall who queried, "Is there a BAD 944?  What should I get?"  My own
experience is limited but I can't resist a comment.  Some have said to get a
post '85.5 944.  I bought a 1983 944 (the puny one!) a couple of years ago
for $10K.  It had 17,000 authenticated miles on it, virgin paint, and an
engine bay that clearly had never known dirt or wet.  The upholstery under
the sheepskins looked "as new."  Now, this car can be outdragged by many a
Japanese sedan these days (witness: Maxima SE), and an S2 almost doubles its
horsepower.  But as a balanced, fun machine, I am getting my money's worth.
 As one advisor told me prepurchase, "Hey, it's cheaper than a used Ford
Escort.  If you don't buy it, I will."

My message is that *all* these Porsches are special, pleasant cars to own and
drive.  I have taken mine to pulse-pounding speeds on twisty, isolated Utah
roads, and find it hard to imagine more fun per dollar spent.

My advice is: driver as many Porsches as you can, study up on them, and shop,
shop, shop, until you find one that makes you say, "I *want* it!"  I enjoyed
a full year of shopping before getting mine, and that was a big part of the
fun.

Hunter Heath

P.S.  I'm shopping again, and still having fun.

P.P.S.  My '83 has been very reliable tho not a daily driver; I can't stand
to get salt on it.  Or even water except from my yard hose.  My wife says,
"get a life."  Me, I think I have one.  And a Porsche for cheap!

Absolutely.  In fact, after simply learning the "line" and using all of
the track, "braking in a straight line" seems to be the thing I have to
watch out for most in my novice and beginner students. Trail braking
seems to be something that new drivers do unconciously -- and most can't
even tell that they're doing something wrong.  At low speed, it's not
dangerous, but as the speed picks up, I get more and more uncomfortable
(I can feel the car lightening in the back...)  I can sense the
student's frustration: I keep complaining "brake in a straight line!" --
they _think_ they are...

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 08:50:08 -0500 (CDT)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: re: speaker ohms

On Fri, 21 Apr 1995 mpl@netcom.com wrote:
> Why does this matter and what happens if you put 4 ohm speakers in there
> or as I have done change the stereo to a cd player etc. and use the front
> speakers which are still 10 ohms while the stereo is listed at 4 ohm output?

Mr, Lommatzsch, 

In this case we are talking about characteristic impedance, not
necessarily resistive impedance.  At any rate, connecting the 10 Ohm
speakers to your 4 Ohm outputs will not break anything.  The load that the
amp outputs will see (the load placed by the speakers) will be higher than
the 4 Ohm matching impedance of the stereo, which will mean that power
output will be less, your speakers will not play as loud.  No harm will be
done though.  On the other hand, connecting a 10 Ohm amp output to 4 Ohm
speakers will most probably cause damage as the load will be less than the
matching impedance.  Most car amps (except for the good ones ie Carver,
Nakamichi, et al) are not all that stable and do not handle such load 
mismatches well, ie it may blow the amp's final output stages. 

On the other hand, it sounds like you will not be using the factory 
stereo so you do not have to worry about that.  Your wiring may say 10 
Ohms but that only refers to the characteristics of the factory stereo, 
there is no magic impedance in the wires.

And to retard all flame ignitions, I have assumed that Mr. Lommatzsch will
be using average stereo equipment, average wires and average speakers, ie
he is not connecting modified Apogees to a modified Krell in his car via
garden hose-thick Audioquest cables. 

I hope I have helped some...
'85 Burgundy Ice Mazda 626LX			mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu
'87 Guard's Red Porsche 944S
'93 Red-White Miyata Five-12
================================================================================
Menelaos Nicholaos Karamichalis, M.S.  |   510 South Kingshighway Boulevard
mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu		       |   Electronic Radiology Laboratory(ERL)
Work # (314)-362-6965		       |   Mallinckrodt Institute Of Radiology
Home # (314)-361-0865		       |   St. Louis, Missouri 63110, USA

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 09:03:13 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: MoTeC  Engine Management Program (EMP) V3.1 V4.1

> This is prob beaten tio death - but what's a reasonable replacement for
> webbers for someone who is computer and mechanically literate but has
> not done this before?
> 
> Integrated dual-plug crankfire with mass flow would be nice, and all
> for a budget price (OK so I'm dreaming) but is there an integrated
> package that you would recommend?

This is always one of those "kids, don't try this at home" kind of deals...

You really have 4 choices:

1) full stock DME setup with some, oh, "tuning". This looks bone stock
   and should pass visual inspection and emissions.

2) Haltech. EFI only, no "engine management" function. Their CPU is about 
   $2k, but you gotta supply the rest of what you need. The new revision 
   system is pretty decent for racing, but doesn't have quite enough range 
   for a daily driven street car. That notwithstanding, I have put a bunch
   of these on the street.

3) Electromotive. Fully integrated engine management, with distributorless
   crankfire, etc. You *CAN NOT* use this setup with high butterflies or
   slide valves, you *GOTTA* use a common plenum. Like the stock DME.
   So one possibility is a semi-stock DME where you make it look like
   factory, but use this stuff as the brains.

4) Motec. OK, I said I don't use it. There's a reason: they like you to be
   a "certified Motec distributor" and I'm not. The feeling is that they
   don't sell it in kit form, that they won't have unhappy customers. They're
   probably right. Current setup is ISO-9000 certified, and has the best
   environmental package of any aftermarket EFI I've seen. They also provide
   all the source code, and to the best of my knowledge, no one else does.

> Any guess on overall systems price?

Figure on about $2k for the brain. You'll have to build or buy everything
else. Good 911 throttle bodies start at about $3k and go from there.
Then you need the fuel rails, the injectors, the rest of the plumbing and
the wiring. And a bunch of dyno and programming hours.

I usually send people to Sam Shalala at ProTechnik in Houston for Motec.
His whole system, installed and tuned, is about $10k. The last one he did
was for Alex Jobbe (which he used to take the win at Sebring, in fact).

> Are there any out there that are self tuning (via emissions sensing)?

No. Not that I'm aware of. There are several that use O2 and EGT sensors
but you have to integrate that stuff...

> I do not feel like the biuiannual motor swap for DMV inspection and now
> that the body's done need to turn my attentions back to the motor (3.4
> max moritz/carrera crank)

Sounds like a nice engine. What are your inspection requirements? That
could well dictate your choice...

Stan

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 17:27:01 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: concours score sheets

Wayne:

Concours score sheets vary widely from region to region/zone to zone.  The
ONLY one you should use to prepare for this variance is the official Porsche
Parade Concours score sheets.  Minor differences occur from year to year, but
they are just that - minor.  If you prepare your Porsche to Parade specs,
you're ready for anything.  Most regionals are easier than the Parade, but
its better to be prepared for the worst case.

I was the chairman for the '93 Parade Concours, in Cincinnati, and I'd be
happy to send you a copy of the score sheets from that year.  Send your
address & I'll mail.  If you prefer, I'll have them scanned and e-mai; you.
 Let me know - and good luck, it's a lot of work, even for a street prep.

Pat Garvey

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 19:04:01 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jan Ringnalda <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: RE:Speaker Ohms

Mike,
	DO NOT MIX & MATCH Speakers, as you will cause an impedance mismatch and 
you risk damaging your amplifier in you radio.  Essentially, if you put two 8 ohm 
speakers in series, the resulting impedance is NOT 16 ohm, but 4.  Putting an 8 
ohm speaker on a 4 ohm amp will essentially reduce the efficiency of the amp, but 
should not blow the system, however it will not be as loud.  If you put a 4 ohm 
speaker on an 8 ohm amp, the sound will be louder, you will be over-exerting your 
amplifier and you risk blowing something.  If you want to put in extra speakers, 
you have to add a cross-over system specially made for this purpose.  That's why 
the little tune-up speakers for the dash are always high impedance, since they go 
in series with the front speakers.
	Speak to your local in-car entertainment buff about adding speakers.
Cheers,  Jan
