Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 19:03:23 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: re: speaker ohms

At 7:52 pm 4/20/95, Mike Lommatzsch wrote:
>Why does this matter and what happens if you put 4 ohm speakers in there
>or as I have done change the stereo to a cd player etc. and use the front
>speakers which are still 10 ohms while the stereo is listed at 4 ohm output?
>
>Please explain the difference and what would happen either way.

Mike,

The impedance rating of a speaker in ohms will effect how the output of the
amplifier is loaded. What does this mean? Typically, a 4 ohm speaker will
put out twice the volume (3dB) than an 8 ohm speaker at the same volume
setting. A two ohm speaker will be twice as loud as the 4 ohm, and so on.
The output of an amplifier basically tells you what impedance the amp wants
to see from the speakers. If you connect 8 ohm speakers to an amp that is
rated for 4 ohms, the amp will have to work harder to achieve the same
given volume it would with the ideal (4 ohm) speakers. On the other hand,
if you connected a bunch of speakers to the amp (which is rated at 4 ohms),
and the total impedance of the chain of speakers is, say, less than 1 ohm,
the amp will become unstable and probably blow up (don't forget, less than
2 ohms is getting mighty close to a short circuit, and typically amplifiers
don't like to see shorts across their outputs). In any case, you want to
try to stay as close to the rated impedance on the output of the amp as
possible. ON the other hand, if you hook everthing up and it sounds ok to
you, then I wouldn't worry. Amplifiers generally don't mind seeing more
than their rated impedance at their outputs, just less.

I would suggest getting a new pair of front speakers (even cheap ones) that
are rated at 4 ohms. You don't have to spend very much on aftermarket
speakers to surpass the quality of oem speakers (except in some cases) ...

Hope this helps ...

trev.


===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

While surfing, stop at:
http://www.io.org/~cme/MIC/mic.html
and you will find a listing on trev ...



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 21:13:28 +0600
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Stereo Problems--(was: speaker ohms)

Maybe I can help eliminate some of the recent stereo confusion.

First of all, for those who don't know, stock stereo systems very often 
differ greatly in their design and layout as compared to the more usual and 
"standard" aftermarket systems.  The most commonly used aftermarket auto 
speakers are of the 4-ohm variety (with some 8-ohm also), but OEM units 
don't necessarily conform to the same "rules".  Thus, it is not usually a 
good idea to mix various stock stereos/speakers with other aftermarket 
stereos/speakers unless you are sure of proper load matching.

Speakers do not act as resistors (they are reactive loads), but it is 
possible to think of them as such for use in determining the overall nominal 
load.  Simply stated, when speakers are wired in SERIES, the total impedence 
will be the sum of the parts (i.e. two 4-ohm speakers in SERIES will have a 
total load of 8-ohms).  In a case where TWO speakers of the SAME impedence 
rating are wired in PARALLEL, the total impedence will be HALF of the rating 
of ONE OF THE SPEAKERS (i.e. if two 4-ohm speakers are wired in PARALLEL the 
total load will equal 2-ohms).  

The lower the load, the less resistance there is to the flow of power, and 
the harder the amp must work.  Only specially designed amps ($$$) are 
capable of driving a load as low as 2-ohms or less while maintaining 
stability.  With the average head-unit powering two or four speakers it is 
best to use speakers of the proper impedence load stated on the head-unit by 
the (aftermarket) manufacturer.  It is important to avoid dropping the load 
below that rating on the head because damage will most likely result.  Using 
a load greater than that recommended will not cause damage, but will only 
result in a decrease in efficiency, and less overall sound output.

This is an oversimplified explanation, but I hope it helped.

Now, in reference to Dan Starkey's question...
For all of you out there with the stiffly sprung 911's, there is little you 
can do (cheaply) to eliminate skipping.  The skip-resistance of any 
particular CD player is quite simply a function of the design of its built 
in "suspension" system.  Some of the better (read: more $$$) brands have 
better shock resistance than the cheaper models, but every in-dash CD player 
has a limit to its internal suspension.  The easiest cure is probably to opt 
for or add a CD changer.  Due to their larger size the changers are able to 
incorporate much beefier shock absorbers, but even they are not 
"shock-proof".  Rest assurred, however, that many more models will become 
available in the (sometime) near future (I only know of one now) that 
incorporate a large "buffer-memory" of a few megs (like the Sony MD) to 
store data as it is read from the transport.  This CD players will be nearly 
shock-proof.

I hope all this stuff helped someone!

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 19:32:20 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: RE:Speaker Ohms

At 7:04 pm 4/21/95, Jan Ringnalda wrote:
>Mike,
>        DO NOT MIX & MATCH Speakers, as you will cause an impedance
>mismatch and
>you risk damaging your amplifier in you radio.  Essentially, if you put
>two 8 ohm
>speakers in series, the resulting impedance is NOT 16 ohm, but 4

I'm sorry Jan, but you are **very** wrong on this. If you connect two 8 ohm
speakers in series, you do in fact get 16 ohms. If you connect two 8 ohm
speakers in parallel, you get 4 ohms.

Series = amp. positive to speaker #1 positive
              speaker #1 negative to speaker #2 positive
              speaker #2 negative to amp negative

Parallel = amp. positive to speaker #1&2 positive.
                amp. negative to speaker #1&2 negative.

In any case, this effect is known as ohm's law. You are correct in that if
an 8 ohm amplifier sees less than 8 ohms that can lead to damage, but only
if the load were to go below 4 ohms (please, do not flame me on this
because after doing live sound and studio recording for 8 years i know what
amplifiers do in the real world). If the amp were to see, say, less than 2
ohms then you would run into problems.

On the same token, if an amp see a lot more than it's rated impedance (say
an amp rated at a 4 ohm output has four eight ohm speakers hooked up to it
in series and therefore is seeing 32 ohms) the amp would sound badly
distorted and it could cause damage. So, deviation from the specified
impedance of the amp in either direction too far can be bad.

As a side note, it should be known that speaker impedance is a general
spec. and a speaker's actual impedance varies across the frequency spectrum
(ie. - a speaker rated at 8 ohms might only have a 3 ohm impedance at
300Hz). Most impedance measurements are rated at 1kHz (a somewhat standard
freq. to measure things at). In any case, my point is that a speaker's
impedance is not an exact measurement, only a general one. One reason why
the expensive amps sound so good is that they can deal with varying
impedance loads that a speaker will present to the outputs of the
amplifier. (ie - a "good" amp will be stable to a lower impedance than a
crappy one).

In any case, I just wanted to clarify this little situation. I think as a
general note, if you don't really know what you're doing, then just connect
together what you're supposed to connect together (ie - 8 ohm speakers to
the outputs of an amp rated for 8 ohms).

regards,
trev.


===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

While surfing, stop at:
http://www.io.org/~cme/MIC/mic.html
and you will find a listing on trev ...



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Apr 1995 21:46:02 -0400
From: mdunston@vt.edu (Michael Dunston)
Subject: RE:Speaker Ohms

>Mike,
>        DO NOT MIX & MATCH Speakers, as you will cause an impedance
>mismatch and
>you risk damaging your amplifier in you radio.  Essentially, if you put
>two 8 ohm
>speakers in series, the resulting impedance is NOT 16 ohm, but 4.
>...Cheers,  Jan

Actually, two 8-ohm drivers wired in series  * WILL *  result in a total
load impedance of 16 ohms.  However, if the two 8 ohm drivers are wired in
parallel then the total load inpedance would then be 4 ohms.  Mixing
components with different impedances does no harm to the amplifier.  This
is done quite often within many professional sound cabinets and
reinforcement systems.  The problem arises when the impedance begins to
become less than 2 ohms or so.  As the load impedance drops towards zero
(and remember that a speaker's impedance rating is a nominal rating- the
actual value changes significantly with the load and frequency of the
speaker's output *IMPORTANT*) the amp ATTEMPTS to increase its output
exponentially.  This is what destroys the amplifier.  As long as you wire
the speakers so the total load impedance is greater than 2 ohms per amp
channel (preferably 4 or 8 ohms- it would be safer) mix and match away.
Just remember for speakers wired in SERIES you just add the rated
impedances together. [per above: 8+8 = 16 ohm load]   For speakers wired in
PARALLEL, you add the inverse of each load together and then take the
inverse of that sum. [ 1/(1/8+1/8) = 4 ohm load ]  There are pros and cons
with each method of wiring, but parallel wiring is generaly preferred.  If
you would like to discuss this in more depth, we should probably move it to
private email.
Hope this helps.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Michael Dunston
Audio Enginneer
VT Dept. of Music




------------------------------

solving the problem but knowing more about my car.  Maybe we can work this
one with the help of the list.

identical vacum switch located besides the heater unit without success ....
therefore confirming that the switches were operating properly.

the vacuum switch for an unknown reason.

they are within specs (based on the workshop manual data) but I wasn't able
to checked the mixing chamber temp sensor because I have to remove a piece of
the dash that I have great *fear* to break ( the portion covering the middle
section where the heater control is located) in order to have access to the
connector.

Porschephiles #1347                         Sun Apr 23 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 22 Apr 1995 10:39:50 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re:944 a good deal?

Kevin,
You wrote (among other things),

> Price? $4500.  

We list more than 100 944's each issue of PML and 83/84 cars seem to always
be between $3500 and $5500 unless they are very low mileage or have some
other notable positive factors involved (like new engine/trans/water
pump/timing belts/competition setup/etc). So this is probably a good starting
price on the car - I assume you'll try to negotiate the price down a be as
well.

I'll leave it to Pfiles 944 experts to tell you about what to look for in,
and expect from, an early 944.

Good Luck,

Phil VanBuskirk, PMLetter@aol.com

Date: Sat, 22 Apr 1995 21:08:28 -0400
From: RonS993@aol.com
Subject: Re: bras & stereos

Dan,

You might consider one of the newer Sony CD player/changers.  They
incorporate a 3 second RAM buffer to allow the laser pickup to find it's
place when it gets bumped out of position.  Or consider going over to Mini
Disc.  The Sony units have 10 seconds of buffer, so it's almost impossible to
get them to skip.  I have a Sony MDX-400, which is an in-dash 4 disk minidisc
player.  I think it sounds as good as any CD, and definitely much better than
any cassette.   Good luck.

Ron S.


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Apr 1995 21:43:46 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Coming out of the Corner

Coming out of the Corner (Rated N for novice)

In my last posting, I made the statement that learning to come out of the
corner would provide you with 90% of your speed.  I'd like to prove the
validity of that statement, and explain the driving techniques require to do
this proficiently.  I am assuming that everyone knows what the terms turn-in
point, apex, and trackout mean.

The goal in driving on a race track is to get around the track as quickly as
possible.  Other factors, such as safety, car control, consistency, and
smoothness are all necessary ingredients, but the main goal is speed.  If you
consider the average race track, you will find that most of the time you are
accelerating.  On most tracks that I have run, about 60% of my time is spent
accelerating, 30% of my time is spent cornering AND accelerating, and 10% is
spent braking.  For ANY driver, I teach that the logical starting point would
be to work on the 90%, and forget about the 10% (for now).  Matter of fact,
as an "expert", when I learn a new track, the way I find out the line is to
figure out how to come out of the corners.  Only after I am satisfied with
that will I start to work on carrying more speed into the corner.

Those of you reading more carefully will notice that I mentioned the "L"
word; that right, the LINE.  I know, I know...it's the fastest way around the
track, it's the safest way, it's the only way, etc.  Like that (great?) rock
group Chicago once sang "Does anybody really know what line it is?" 8{).
ANYWAY, I feel that the line is comprised of two elements, the path that 
you drive into the corner, and the path that you drive out of the corner.
And as stated above, the path that you drive out of the corner is 9 times 
(90% vs. 10%) more important.  Simply stated, the line coming out of the
corner is the path that will let you accelerate as soon as possible, at full
throttle, around as much of the corner as possible, and down the following
straight.

The technique that I teach to do this is as follows:

1) Know where you want to turn-in at and apex the corner.

2) Brake moderately up to the corner.  Remember, it's only 10% of your speed,
so if you are slow here it's no big deal.  Besides, if you are too fast it
will screw up your entry to the corner.

3) Turn-in under full control, in an arc that will take you past the apex.

4) Pick up the throttle and SLOWLY floor it.  It should take about 3 seconds
from the time you touch the gas until it's floored.  Don't jam it down (not
yet anyway).

5) Drive past the apex, and slowly unwind the wheel as your speed increases.
You should get to the trackout point under control and be headed down the
straight.

If you have done this right, you will fly past the apex, and the car will
automatically drive out to the edge of the track, and down the straight.  If
you find that you have to tighten the steering (wrong thing to do) to avoid
running off of the track, your apex point is too early in the turn.  Go a
little deeper into the turn, turn-in a little harder, and apex a little
later.  Work up to this slowly.  Once you have found that you can drive past
the apex floored, try getting on the gas sooner after your turn-in.  The path
that you can take through the corner under full throttle, *that is the line
coming out of the corner*.

The point at which you pick up the gas and accelerate is called the
transition point.  Remember that for future discussions; I will refer to it
often.  This transition point is the part of the turn, in the beginning,
where you get off the brakes and get onto the gas.  The car will gain
stability, the rear will be "hooked up" and you can accelerate  through the
turn.  Knowing this point, and being able to find it consistently every lap,
is the key to the next step.


Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 95 08:55:32 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 good deal?

> I am considering buying a 944 heres what I found out about it:
> 
> 
> 1984 944. Burgundy in color with tan interior.
>  Power everything
> including a power moonroof. Cruise control and working air
> conditioning.  It has the black 5-spoke wheels with pirelli tires and
> a descent sounding stereo. Price? $4500.  
> 
(additional description deleted)

Yep, pretty good starting point.

What to do:

1) Have a reliable Porsche mechanic check out the car. You should spend
about $100 for his time to give you a reasoned evaluation of the car. You
can locate a pretty good mechanic through the officers of your local PCA
region. 

2) The items on a 1984 944 that will cost you big money to fix are:

Power steering leaks (rack, pump, hoses)
Timing belt failures
Water pump failures
Clutch disk 

The rest of the stuff is relatively cheap.

Assuming that the car passes a mechanic's scrutiny, and that you really want
it, you should offer something less than the asking price...Then work your
way up, if necessary.

With proper maintenance, the car will give another 100K miles of reasonably
reliable service.

Without proper maintenance, that car will give you about 20K miles of
headaches.

Also, if you do buy this car, join the PCA, and learn as much as you can
about your car from local, regional and national gurus on the subject...
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 09:15:18 -0400
From: Cutterrig@aol.com
Subject: 84 911 Brake Light warning

In my 79 911 I had the same thing happen.  turns out all I had to do was
disconnect the Pos. (+) lead from the batt. and turn the key on for about 30
seconds, (I think it was 30 seconds), turn the key back off then reconnect
the batt. and all was ok. Give it a try. let me know if this helps


Cutter Rig

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 95 10:51:56 PDT
From: gschoepp@onramp.net
Subject: Ted*osterone


Well folks, here's a sheepish story. This maneuver taught me that my 928 is 
capable of doing ungraceful things...

Been raining here in north Texas, and I had been out early in the day to visit the 
bank, Home Depot, typical Saturday stuff. Came home, did a couple of 
honey-do's, noted that my wife was still at work (the joy of a two-career 
household).

It got to be around 6pm and I decided to "make a run for the border" to grab 
some tacos for dinner. Got in the 928, backed out the long drive, pulled up to 
the corner which allows access to our development. This is a documented and 
signed "Dangerous Intersection" as it is at the top of a hill and almost blind from 
both sides. I looked left, looked right, and then the Tedosterone(tm) kicked in.

Glanced at my temp gauge, thought "It's warm, what the hell". No one coming 
either way. Started my left turn, then kicked it - hard. 288hp came screaming to 
life. Tires break loose. Rear end fishtails nicely. Let off the gas. Tires continue 
spinning. Totally off the gas now. Car is still fishtailing. Adrenaline rush kicks in. 
Car now out of my control. Car continues around in a wide 360 with me 
countersteering against the skid.

Car ends up on the same side of the road it started on, facing the way I didn't 
want to go. Five feet from the ditch and in light grass. Embarassed and shocked 
driver drives off in the wrong direction, hoping no one from the homeowner's 
association saw this little display.

** BE CAREFUL ** THIS COULD HAPPEN TO YOU ** 
** TEDOSTERONE IS DANGEROUS AND SHOULD BE IGNORED! **

I can see my driving a little slower, a little more careful, a little more 
conservatively, and a little less in a juvenile manner. Had there been a curb on 
this road or the ditch a little closer, my little macho maneuver might have caused 
serious damage to me, or god forbid, my car :-).

Hanging my head in shame, and asking humbly for the T*d of the Month 
award...

Gene Schoepp
gschoepp@onramp.net
'86 928S, Marine Blue Metallic (with a little grass in the tires)



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 13:49:57 -0500
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re: 84 911 Questions ?


Mark,

> I recently bought an '84 911 Targa Carrera (yeah!)...only 45,000 miles, 

Congradulations!

> 1. The brake pad warning light was on during my test drive, and sure enough, 
> during inspection, it required new rear pads.  However, the mechanic 
> neglected to hit the warning light reset.  Is there a reset button or is 
> there some auto-sensing mechanism?  If there's a reset button, where is it?

The brake wear sensor is a continuous loop wire that is seated in a recess in
one of the brake pads of each wheel.  When the pad has worn sufficiently, the
brake disc will wear thru the wire.  When the wire is completely severed, the
connection is broken, and the brake pad sensor light will be illuminated. 
So...either your mechanic did not replace the wear sensor wires, or the front
pads need replacing also.  If you don't care about having the sensor light
operational, you can simply cut the sensor wires at each wheel and solder the
ends together, permanently shorting the circuits.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  Wayne D. Michelsen                | W_Michelsen@hso.link.com
  '87 911 Targa [Guards-Red/Black]  | RedAcorn@aol.com

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 15:10:29 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Re: RE:Speaker Ohms

Trevor,
	Thanks for the note, you are absolutely right.  I should have sat down and 
written that reply after a little more thought; as it was I had to go to a meeting 
which is why I hurried it.  Not many people connect speakers in series, I think, 
so hopefully the gist of the message will be as you stated.  Get your local radio 
buff to do it.  As it stands Mike's stereo is a replacement so will therefore 
probably be a 4 watt.  So if he uses the factory connections, even though the 
cables are marked 10 Ohms; he should use 4 Ohm speakers.
	Thanks for the correction...
Cheers,  Jan

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 16:27:30 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: Coming out of the Corner

Larry,

I enjoyed your thoughts on learning to drive fast! The way you analyze a
track is about the same as I do. One thought I would add to the 10% that you
assign to braking.... since you do this (braking) at the time you are going
the fastest (at least on longer straights) it may, in fact, end up with
greater than a 10% effect on your lap times. However, I still agree that,
when you are learning a track, braking early and arriving at the corner
slower than you will later on, is the best way to start.

Phil VanBuskirk, PMLetter@aol.com

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 18:05:47 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: 944 stuff

 
>I have an '88 944S manual, and an '88 944 automatic. I'm moving, and
Disney  
>will only pay for 1 auto relo. So I'm going to sell the '88 944 automatic
here  
>in Miami. 58k miles, looks nice, lady driven ....... $13,000  
> 
$13K for that car is a lot. I think that as a sports car, 944's go down in
value with a automatic, unlike other types of cars. You would eliminate a
substantial number of potential customers up front. That said, most
customers want to know if you are the first owner, reasons for bodywork or
paint, any new or upgraded parts, and want to see all service records. Get
the car detailed, make sure any dents are knocked out, that the hood shocks
work, and those types of little things. $13K should mean that the car is
indistinguishable from new. Take them on a test drive and tell them about
Porsche's racing heritage. Then hit them with how much a new clutch costs:)

 
You probably would get more for the 5-spd. Also, it may not cost that much
to trailer your car to the new job. For instance, it would cost about $350
to trailer my car 120 miles from Bridgehampton to NYC, but only about $850
to trailer 2000 miles to Florida. Could be very realistic, if the car
doesn't move at your price. 
 
************NON-PORSCHE ISSUE************** 
What is the typical recourse if one gets ripped-off using the Internet as a
the transport? And if the source lives on AOL? No, this is not a test.
Please e-mail. 
********END OF NON-PORSCHE ISSUE**********

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 18:14:30 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 73/1.7/mfi

> I would like to replace the 1.7 fuel injectors with 2.0 litre injectors and 
> no other changes, would performance improve?  

No. You must change the rest of the engine before changing the EFI
makes any sense at all.

> Also, any tips on how to tune 
> an MFI?

It's a simple system, really... You can change fuel pressure and/or
the injectors to get more gas, change the manifold sensor and temperature
sensors to modify when the brain seeks to enrich the mix, etc. Try
to understand what it's really doing first, then the modifications make
more sense.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 20:11:45 -0400
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Vacuum Brake Bleeder


>Larry,
>
>Please send me details on how to do this home made vacum puller
>
>Omar Sidak

The vacuum brake bleeder that I made was out of a 30 lb freon can, but a
large steel can, the size of a 20 lb propane bottle will work just as well.
 I have a vacuum gauge, 1/4" tube, and a shutoff valve attached to the tank.
 I use a refrigeration vacuum pump to pull a 25" vacuum, but any small pump
that can pull to 25" will work.  They are available for less than $130.  I
use a 1/4" schrader flare fitting to attach my vacuum pump, and I remove it
once I have pulled a vacuum.  If I were to use a dedicated pump, I would
probably attach it permanently, and valve it off, or use a check valve.  I
hook the tube to the brake nipple, and pull about a reservoir full of fluid
through each caliper.  You will also pull some air around the nipple threads,
but the air will not get into the caliper.  Remember that by decreasing the
pressure on the fluid, any entrapped air bubbles will expand, and become
easier to suck out.  It works very well.  After my tank gets alot of fluid in
it, I pressurize it slightly, and blow the old fluid out.  Let me know how
you make out.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 21:57:45 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Marc and Oil Pressure answers 

 Hey Marc and other Porschephiliacs,
 	Before fearing the worst suspect the least.  The oil pressure guage 
 on my 924 did the same thing.  Since the guage and light run off the same 
 sender, try replacing the sender.  VDO oil pressure guages are known to 
 give inaccurate readings when they get on in age.  I replaced 
 mine--problem solved :^)  Now my pressure reads normal and the light 
 NEVER comes on.  Hope this helps...
 	I saw you had a VW GTI; do you know of a listserv for watercooled
 Veedubs?  I've asked and searched and can find nothing. If you know of 
 one I would be greatly appreciative.  Thanx!
 
 Jay Karolyi
 '70 914 Rustbucket
 '75 Corvair/914
 '77 928 4-cyl a.k.a. 924
 '80 Toy 'rolla

Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 21:41:47 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: re: a/c receiver/drier

Bob -

Glad all is well with your a/c unit.  Yes, can do what you did but 
typically a customer isn't going to pay to have someone dry out their 
original receiver/drier and not get a guarantee with it (plus it would 
probably cost more and the car would be down longer!).  If I was to use 
a receiver/drier on my own car or home a/c system that was dried by me 
that's fine, but I wouldn't want to do it for a customer where I have to 
warranty the thing and the labor to replace it if it isn't completely 
dried and cleaned of any contaminents.  Besides, if I get a call back on 
a job it hurts my reputation for doing th job right the first time around.


Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 01:17:53 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 944 Electrical Problem, Maybe?

Perci Hala (@@cadvision.com) asked:

>On a 1984 [944], if I have the ignition turned off and the signal 
>light lever down, my side marker and parking lights come on, but don't 
>blink. Is this right? .... Does the same on both sides.

    Yeah, it's right... At least, that's how it works on 911s and 914s. 
    It has something to do with traffic laws in one of those backward   
    European countries -- France, I think.

>When the signals, and key, are on they seem to flash quicker than 
>normal. Hazards flash fast too.

    This is usually the (engineered-in) symptom of a burned-out         
    turn-signal bulb.

    -Andy

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 95 07:23:18 PDT
From: thatguy@uplex.net (Tim Heikell)
Subject: Fuel sending unit

I have a '69 911S with the optional 100 liter fuel tank. Recently the fuel 
sending unit decided to convert itself into a birds nest. The slide wire 
resister broke in a place that it is now to short to be re-soldered. These 
sending units are no longer available to purchase new.

My chices I've decided on so far are:

1) Find someone that happens to have one of these units (part# 901 741 801 0)

2) Put in a unit from a 62 liter tank and live with it reading empty sooner 
(but even with the correct unit the tank still had 10 gallons left when the 
guage hit R.

3) Repair the unit I have. To do this I have found that I need wire called 
Manginine (which I have so far had no luck in finding) and then it needs to 
be silver soldered (do you think I'll be able to talk a jeweler into 
soldering my gas sender?)

In summary, HELP!

Tim


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 10:34:10 -0500 (EST)
From: Jan Ringnalda <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: Re: Ted*osterone

Just having read the story about gene doing a 360 in his 928.  I was driving my 
928S in the UK near Liverpool, where there is a huge roundabout -uh- (traffic 
island) on the way to Southport.  Anyway there's me cruisin' along minding my 
own business when an XR2 Fiesta (yes these things are called "hot hatches" and 
very popular with the kiddies in the UK, although not so popular with the 
insurance companies) overtakes me on the inside on a left turn (yes on a 
roundabout)  I cannot believe this audacity, and start to ease the power on as 
we are exiting the bend.  Then I noticed the wet patch...  A full spin later and 
still going into the same direction only two lanes over, I manage to catch the 
wheels spinning in the way they were intended to, so I slow down and park the 
expensive toy in a conveniently located (i.e. close) lay-by for a quick change 
of undergarments.
	Yes Gene, these puppies will really spin, and looking at it it's 
understandable; the wheelbase is nearly square, and you sit nearly on the back 
wheels.  I treated this car with mucho respect in the wet after this.  The 944 
is much more driveable, although I haven't done any serious wet work yet.
Cheers,  Jan

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 10:44:15 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Hey Peter, 924 vibrations,etc.

Hey Peter and other Porschephiles,
	Wow, an '85 924.  I read in a Porsche book of mine that they 
continued to make a 924 from '82 to '86 for Europe only, with the 
'86.5-'88 924S following, but I've never had a chance to hear of an 
example.  About your shaking nose (might want to see a doctor :^), this 
is a common problem for early 944s and is probably the case with an '85 
924.  It has to do with the steering/suspension assembly, but this is the 
extent of my knowledge.  Write George B. at george@mhv.net and ask him 
how to fix an early 944 shimmy, it should apply to your car too.
	About the '85 924, Your address seems to come from Europe, where 
are you?  Also, is there much difference in your 924 from earlier models?
Does it have a rear spoiler and four wheel disk brakes?  Did they 
continue the 924 Turbo as well for Europe from '83-'86?  Please reply, 
I'm *dying* to know more about the Euro models! 

Thanks
	Jay Karolyi        '77 924, etc.

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 11:21:19 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@use.usit.net>
Subject: 951 Cooling Problems

I recently posted here about the apparent large swings in
the coolant temperature (as indicated by the temperature
gauge) of my '88 951 (64K miles). I decided to bleed air
from the cooling system by opening the bleed bolt and adding
coolant until coolant began to run out of the bleed fitting.
Closed the bleed bolt and noted that the coolant level in
the tank was about 3/4" above the "maximum" rectangle on
the tank. Several test drives, extended traffic stops, etc.
later the temperature gauge now indicates much smaller swings
in coolant temperature. I think the thing to be learned from
this is that opening the bleed and filling to the "maximum"
point is probably not going to force air out of the system -
you have to see coolant at the bleed point before you can be
reasonably sure that you have done the job. Others may know
this but from the number of posts in the archives it appears
that many don't.

Doug Donsbach
'88 951
'88 735i

Date: 24 Apr 1995 10:07:34 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: Bras and CDs

                      Subject:                              Time:  9:46 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Bras and CDs                          Date:  4/24/95


Re recent bra and CD questions...
The Colgan bra for my 84 cab constantly trapped debris in the hood
pocket, leaving sand and dried leaves to vibrate around.  Had to remove
the bra every few days to prevent abrasions.  The bra also has to be
removed after any rain and before washing.  Just isn't worth it, IMO,
unless you want to hide damage.

A nice stereo solution for those 84-89 Carrera owners who want to
keep the car stock but are interested in playing CD's is the Pioneer
10 disk changer with wireless remote (about $490). Run it off any
FM radio.  Sound quality was great with my Blaupunkt Reno and some
decent replacement speakers and a 4 channel amp.  The LED receiving
unit fits *perfectly* over the cubby hole below the A/C controls and
matches the interior look.  No wires show.  Velcro the remote to the
seatback rake handle for a good aim and to keep it out of the way.
This unit almost never skipped in my stock 88 turbo look targa (i.e.,
firm ride).  Don't know if it fits other Porsches as well.  Maybe the
SC?  Is the console the same?

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
95 993 coupe, guards red
85 535i, everyday grey

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 12:49:22 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: How to sell a 944?

Palmer, contemplating finding a new home for his 944...

>have any tips on selling? My plan was just to advertise in the paper,
>probably at $13,000 -- list specs, highlighting the automatic, and the lady
>driven features. Do you think that that would be too much? Should I also put
>in a "must sell, moving"? I keep the car covered, which makes for a nice
>dramatic unveiling. I suppose I should somehow convey to the prospective
>buyer, the pleasure I've gotten from these cars, and relate some of the
>anecdotes about how long-lived these Porsches are. I'd be especially
>appreciative to hear about your successful sales, and how you structured
>your presentation.
>
Palmer,
  You know what they say about what something is worth, "it's worth exactly 
what a non-distressed seller that has a willing purchasers commitment (and 
check!)". FYI a 1988 944 has a NADA book of $10900 (Retail) and a loan value
of $7800. Add 1200 for the miles, all the other options are a wash (not 
considered inthe book). The reason I mention this is that many sales are
directly controled by the bank. This is what the bank uses to establish
value on the vehicle. Not that it's correct all the time, but that is how 
they do it. I usualy tell prospective buyers that I am asking X and I am
negotiable, motivated but not distressed seller. I usualy keeps the jerkoffs
out of the game. As far as negotiations are concerned, I only negotiate with
a qualified, commited buyer. IE "Mr. Buyer, if the terms and price are to 
your satisfication, will you pay and own NOW?" Then I get into negotiations.
No reason to drop your drawers for a "shopper". And to the shoppers I let 
them know there are realy 2 things to shop for. #1 is the vehicle, #2 is the
price on the qualifing vehicle. This breaks it down to a simple task. IE when
you are done "shopping for vehicles" and have decided that you would would 
own this one, that part of the sale is compleat (the vehicle sale) the 2nd 
part of the sale is to show better value in the product than one has in 
their $$$. See Sales 101 :-}  That's how I do it, it keeps people from being 
offended by pricing and makes it easy to consumate a transaction when
booth parties are satisfied.



Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)

Hi Asad,

Well, here's the easy one.  No, not all 911s leak oil.  My '86 doesn't (yet).

As to the other stuff, there's only one way to determine which model is
right for you.  Drive a few examples of each.  High performance has both
a subjective as well as an objective component; another way of saying that
the numbers alone, do not tell the entire story.

Personally, I'd be happy with a prime example of either, then again, some
have accused me of being, ummmmmm, shall we say, not completely representative
of rational thinking (on this or any other subject)...

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 95 14:55:00 CDT
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.ks.symbios.com>
Subject: MIG welder maladies.


Greetings all you hands-on types!

  <kyle sez:>
  I'm one of those guilty of using an el-cheapo MIG welder and
now that mine has 3+ years of heavy use, it is showing its age.
  It starts with poor wire feed, like intermittent.  I surmise the cause
is the pinch roller and/or feed hoze wearout.  Another problem
is the size of the roll of wire you use.  I really like the 9 pound
spool, but these are so heavy and the darn machine is poorly
setup for this type of load -it too can cause poor wire feed.
  This can really screwup your welds, so beware.

  Another cause of crummy welds is slag buildup in the nozzle.
    -particularly when doing inverted position welding. . .
Sometimes causing a short to the schnoz, causing the thing to
become 'hot'.  If you weld anything like I do, you occasionally
dip the nozzle into the work, causing a temporary short circuit.
  All this robs your weld of heating current or at least disrupts the
gas envelope, and can screwup your welds. . .beware.

  So the moral of the story is:  keep your schoz clean; use a nozzle
protectant such as spatter-pruf (avoid silicone gunks and sprays).
  Do prepare weld site and vicinity as bare metal clean as possible.
  Do keep on hand spare parts such as nozzles, tips, rollers, and
maybe a hoze.
  Do add to your machine a ball bearing setup such as a 'lazy susan'
to aid the spool in moving freely (in horizontal orientation), (cook up
your own solution for vertical) as the plastic arrangment will wear out,
causing delays in your work.    (AAaarrgghhh!!)

  For those doing inverted position welding:
  Do use your leathers, gloves, skull cap and chaps, or at least cotton
jeans and . . .socks.  Even then droplets may 'tan' your hide.
  Do use a protective shield over your hood's viewscreen.
  Do keep a fire extinguisher within reach.
  Do avoid inhaling welding fumes, thus 'fume fever'.
  Do avoid welding in drafty locations (gas mig).
  <do penetrate deeply>  =:)

  Do *NOT* use a 'weld thru' zinc coating in vicinity of welds. -it wont 
work.

    ( pearls of techno-wisdom)
   <kyle.ehler@symbios.com>  *** offline to p-philes ***   Wichita, Kansas
      Regards to OKC    . . . _ _ _ . . .

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 15:56:22 -0400
From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
Subject: Re: Chips for Porsches

The day I went on vacation Stan wrote some fairly discouraging things about
chips, and even though it was 2 weeks ago, I would like to put the other
side of the story. 

Firstly, I get the impression that Stan is a Porsche man! By that I mean
that if it is not approved by Porsche, it's usually  not worth bothering
with. This impression has been made over several weeks of reading his very
knowledgeable replies to all sorts of questions.

I am happy (very happy in fact) to accept that the Autothority mass flow
system does not get his approval :)

Let me address the question of chips alone for Porsche cars, and start off
by stating that the last 25 944 normally aspirated cars sold in England were
sold with a Superchip fitted to get another claimed 25 HP. This was a
marketing ploy designed to move the cars along while everyone was waiting
for the much acclaimed 968s. That is only a small part of our pedigree in
association with the importers (not Porsche)

The Bosch systems are comparatively easy to reprogram and we can get more
power out of the engines by doing it. We get 25 HP from the 993 engines and
it has been done without putting a car on the dyno. Yes we do have a dyno
here, a very expensive one in fact, but the problem with reprogramming the
993 was not in getting more power out of it but in defeating the built in
protection system. 

Once that had been done, the reprogramming follows simple guidelines. After
all when you have reprogrammed over 300 different types of  Bosch computers,
you tend to find the common denominators which control the way power can be
increased. So yes, given a chip, I can whip up an improved program for it.
It won't be the very best program because I would need to put that car on
the dyno and make a chip for only that car, but it will be better than stock
and nearly perfect for any car with that engine in it. The 25 HP figure came
later when a customer brought his car in and we finally got it on the dyno.
The changes we made to the chip we had been selling  were
very small and concerned only the fuelling at one point on WOT which was 1%
richer than we prefer.

When Stan said he spent 65 hours on the dynbo programming a chip, I can
sympathise with him. It's hard work. However, that is because the  whole
character of the engine is being changed for racing. With a road car, it,s
not being changed just honed to perfection, and that is a lot easier because
Bosch got it most of the way there in the first place, just leaving us with
a little more fine tuning. Always the same amount in the  same places!

The second part of Stans posting was about reverse engineering the chip.
Well, it simply doesn't happen! Unless I need to change how the software
works, I don't need to reverse engineer it. All I want to do is advance the
ignition and tune the fuelling and to do this you need to know which are
timing maps and which are fuelling maps and when you have done 300 of them,
you can do it while scrolling through a hex dump of the code. As it happens,
Bosch engineers are so predictable that we have written a program to
identify which is map and which is code. 

I dont know why Porsche leave this power increase for us to find. I am
grateful that they do and when I sell a chip for a Porsche I rarely get it
back as not doing what I claimed it would do. So ease off Stan, and accept
that even a Porsche can be improved, and it can be done in America too.
Peter Wales
Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 95 14:38:42 -0700
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: purchasing a 911vs 928

...
>I know the 928 is more luxurious, especially for everyday driving.  What 
>is the reliablity and performance like vs a 911?  I have in mind a 1984 
>928 that is being sold by a dealer.  
>
...

I won't attempt to compare the 911 to the 928.  They are very
different.  My recommendation is to drive them both.  I will
say some things from my experience as someone who is owned by
a 928.

I am very happy with my choice (928).  I think it is the best
all around choice for me, since I do a so much driving, from
stop and go to wide open highway.  The feel of luxury, stability,
and power is a plus that is hard to quantify--test drive one.
An acqaintance of mine has repeatedly made trade offers to me--
his 911 plus cash for my 928.  His wife wishes for a 928, also.

However, I am a power freak.  Enough is never enough.  The 928
is probably much more expensive to build for power.  Parts are
more expensive, and most of what you do will need to do for
that power involves custom engine building and fabrication of
one-of-a-kind parts.

Aside from that, repairs can be more expensive.  New parts are
astronomical in price, if purchased from Porsche.  Take for
example, $2000 to $3000 for a radiator, or several thousand
dollars for one body panel, or $600 for a glove box door.
Luckily, used parts can be had for a lot less.  However,
expect to have to set aside two or three hundred a month to
cover unexpected repair costs (less, if you buy a well kept
late model, or drive it less).

You just need to drive one, and decide if what it feels like
outweighs the costs.

One more thing:  Buy as new a 928 as you can afford.  '89 or
'90 is a good candidate.  The reason is that, if you consider
purchase price AND the first few years of repairs and
refurbishing, you will probably spend more on the '84.

                                                 --Mike

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 17:08:15 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: 66 912 Fuel Smell


I would start looking for the source of the fuel "smell" by:

1.  Remove the metal plate which covers the access to the M.Cyl
	and gas tank underneath the car.   Carefull, these may
	be rusty and you may need some penetrant to get these
	loose without breaking the bolts/nuts off!

	Inspect the connection of a short (maybe 8") length of rubber
	fuel line which connects the gas tank to the one-piece gas line
	which runs the length of the shift tunnel and exits near the
	transmission.  The fitting on the gas tank may be loose or
	the rubber fuel line may need to be changed.

	There is another gas tank fitting/plug if you need to
	drain the gas tank right next to it.

2.  Open the rear inspection plate on the tunnel by the rear seats
	and stick your nose in there and check for fumes.

	If its there, then the metal line has been rusted and is leaking
	in the tunnel.  That could be tricky to replace (I replaced
	mine while replacing the floor pan(s)).


3.  Jack up the rear and check where the one-piece metal gas line
	exits the "tunnel" and connects to another rubber line.
	This is also a short rubber line and connects up to another
	metal gas line that goes over the wheel well and up into
	the engine compartment.

4.  Look in the engine compartment:

	- Inspect where the metal gas line enters the engine compartment
	and connects to another rubber line that goes to the fuel
	pump on the engine.

	- Inspect the rubber fuel lines that feed the carbs (note,
	you'll need to check the rubber/metal lines that run between
	carbs behind the engine fan shroud.
	

Good Luck!  I think I remembered all the metal/rubber places to look.
if I missed any - let me know and I'll look at my '66 912 or
someone else on the net can lend his/her expertise.

Ron D.

rondl@uscbu.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 95 15:12:34 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Repairing Gas Gauge (Spelled Right!) Sender


Tim-

I just replaced the wire in my sending unit with some 'standard' 
resistance wire and it seems to work OK.  No need to silver solder. I 
don't think it's as strong as Manginine, and probably won't last as 
long, but the wire in the sender is pretty well protected so who 
knows?

Reid Zeigler gave me a five foot piece of wire and has graciously
agreed to provide pieces to those who really need it.  I repeat his 
message to me here:

"Go ahead and post your repair procedure and you can list me as
a source for the wire. The wire will be free, although I'd like
to reserve it for those who really need it. They can send a stamped,
self addressed envelope to:

     Reid Zeigler
     19 Ravine Drive
     Matawan, NJ 07747"

For those who are interested, here are the details.  The wire is thin, so 
be careful. The original sender wire is very light, about 0.004" in 
diameter.  Reid's wire is a bit less than this once the insulation is 
removed, maybe 0.003".  It's not easy working with stuff that fine.

First, you have to strip off the lacquer insulation from the wire.  I 
stretched the wire between two nails in a long board, and put a few 
drops of paint remover on a small piece of fine sandpaper (600 or so) 
folded, and sort of carefully rubbed up and down the wire a few 
times to get the lacquer off.  You can see when it's off; the wire looks 
silver instead of black.  I also slid an ohmeter along it to make sure 
there were no missed spots.

Someone (I can't remember who) recently provided an excellent, 
detailed account of what the sender looks like.  In brief, the sender is 
wired with a single strand, about 24" long, although you need more 
like 36" to work with.  The strand forms a long U, about 10" on each 
leg, and about 1" across the bottom.It's soldered at the top of each end 
of the U to a bracket at the top of the tank that consitutes the top of 
the sender, and loops over a 1" plastic (hence insulated) bracket at the 
bottom of the sender, which is near the bottom of the tank.  A float 
rides up and down the U, making contact with the wires on each leg, 
and shorting them.  Thus,  when full, with the float at the top, 
resistance across the U is zero.  At the bottom, when empty, the 
resistance is about 60-70 ohms (for a standard tank, a bit more for the 
oversized tank).  The original wire is about 36 ohms/foot.  

The thinner wire might not be as sturdy as the original, but the 
sender is very well protected and there really are no forces acting on 
the wire other than the float slowly going up or down.  The thing is
constructed so the entire U is housed in an aluminum cylinder with a
small hole in it to allow gas to flow in or out.  This damps out 
sloshing in the gas  tank.


 -Bob Spindel

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 16:17:21 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: 75 911 S: repair or sell?

To repair or to sell, IMHO, would depend on the condition of the body.
If it were my own car, which I've owned since new and still has
original paint, I'd repair it.  But you could learn from my own
experience.  My engine self-destructed at about 66K, but I have had no
trouble since, other than an oil leak which it has had since new.  I
have 50K on the rebuild, with a new case and pistons.

BUT, if I had it to do over again (and I hope I don't), I'd put in an
SC or later engine, which would have a greater life expectancy than
the ill-fated 2.7.

Good luck.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

If you hooked up the ignition kill to your fuel gauge as well, this *should*
help.  Then the situation would be very similar to having a near-empty
tank at the time of the heist.  Don't forget to hook up the low fuel idiot
light as well.  No form of "fuel level" deception would be involved, which
may get you sued.  If the thief actually looked at the fuel gauge, he'd see
an empty tank which is what he'd experience after a minute of driving.

No, I'm not a lawyer, and I used, what appears to me, common
sense - and yes, I know that doesn't often apply to the law.  :-)

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 95 19:12:49 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: missing air pump - what, me worry?


I've been prepping my recently purchased '84 928S (62k mi) for the 
driving season.  I believe the car has had some accident damage, but
I'm not sure how much.  Anyways, I have discovered that there's an 
empty pully where my air pump should be!  Should I worry?

I checked the emissions equipment diagram in the owner's manual and
it shows the output of the air pump to go to three places:
1. Catalytic converter
2. throttle assembly
3. air cleaner (behind the filter)

Before I bought the car, the catalytic converter had been replaced.
It is most likely not a Porsche part.  The dealer had this installed 
and paid $175 for the part - Stoddard wants $3000 (yes, $3k) for the 
Porsche part.  After inspecting it, I found no port for an air hose to 
attach -but- the Euroselect catalog doesn't see the connection for the 
air pump.  What's happening here?

Sometimes when the car is running I'll get white smoke - usually
after starting, which has been once a week, and sometimes during
extended idle.  I don't *think* there's a coolant leak.

I know the air pump is there for a reason, but what's the impact of
not having one?  Surely, I need to cap the air pump's port on the air
cleaner assembly, but why is air fed into the throttle assembly?
Why the cat conv, and air cleaner for that matter?

Can I run without the air pump?

Finally, if this is something I need to install, since this is emissions
emissions equipment is there any legal recourse against the dealer even 
though the car was bought as used ('as-is')?

Gee, other than that, the car performs well and looks even better!

Any comments greatly appreciated!

Matt Carpenter
'84 928S   62K

compression so it works right when installed, etc. Pete? Any

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 17:20:55 GMT
From: Colin Barratt <Colin@cbarratt.demon.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Hey Peter, 924 vibrations,etc.

Dear Jay,
(In reply to your message dated Monday 24, April 1995)
I am a new reader of the Porschephiles pages and was interested to read your piece about 944 'shimmy'. Now I didn't see the original mention of 944 shimmy
but thought you might like to hear a story which is true - I know it happened.  I was there!
I live in England (precisely where I'll not tell you in case my local dealer reads these pages!)
In 1984 a friend of mine took his new 944 back to the main dealer for it's first sevice and was greeted enthusiastically by the salesman. Presumbaly because
he had just spent a lot of money!
 The salesman asked if he was happy with his 944 and if he had encountered any problems. My friend replied that he was 95% 
happy with the car but was a little concerned that the car was pulling to the left quite noticeably. (We drive on the left here remember!) The salesman
replied with sickening sincerity that this was part of the car's design. The 944 had, he wanted us to accept, been built to pull to the left to avoid drifting
into oncoming traffic in the event of the driver losing concentration or falling asleep! 
It was, he pointed out, true therefore that left hand drive cars (U.S. and mainland Europe etc.) were designed to pull to the right for the same reason.
I know it sounds an unlikely story but I swear it's true. As a footnote, my friend traded his 944 shortly afterwards for a Jaguar - which didn't have the same
features!


- -- 
Colin Barratt


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1351                         Tue Apr 25 12:52:27 CDT 1995
Date:          Tue, 25 Apr 1995 08:39:25 +0000
From: "Peter Remeijer" <peter@qv3pluto.LeidenUniv.nl>
Subject:       Re: Hey Peter, 924 vibrations,etc.

Hi Jay,

I'm afraid i'll have to disappoint you :-( They didn't change the 
basic design of the 924 after '82. So I don't have four disk brakes 
and the supension is the same as the 82 model. The good news is that  
a turbo style rear spoiler became standard in '83 and all the 944 
luxury goodies, like the electric sunroof etc,  were also an option 
for  the 924. Furthermore, we have the advantage of the 125 hp 
engine, but this is true for all european models.  In Europe , the 924
turbo also didn't make it past '82. It was succeeded by the 944, the
177 hp model being the last one.

I bought my car in Germany (I live in the Netherlands which is next 
to it) because the cars seem to be quite a lot cheaper than here and they 
always seem to be equiped with all possible options. And last but not 
least, driving on German autobahns is great !

Hope this satisfied your information need a bit :-) ,

Peter Remeijer
'85 924

PS if you have a www browser, you can hav a look at it at
http://qv3pluto.leidenuniv.nl/peter.htm

Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 18:11:28 -0500
From: stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda)
Subject: Re: Wanted: PCA Racing Stuff

>I am setting up a 1974 911 for PCA Racing. I'm only looking to buy safety
>equipment, not performance equipment, at this time. 
>
From a safety standpoint, 2 or 3 layer nomex is the best bet.

As for a roll bar: Put in a cage. From a safety standpoint, the cage is the
best possible bet. make sure that it does not mount to the floor pan, but tp
the frame rail wherever possible.

Mount your net to the cage. Mounting it to the door is useless. in a hard
rollover situation, the door could pop open, and now your net is outside of
the car.

Hope this helps

Scott Sanda
86 944 race car
>
Scott D Sanda

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 09:36:54 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: re: speaker ohms

On Thu, 20 Apr 1995, Mike Lommatzsch wrote:

> 
> When I purchased a new non-p-car recently, the rear area had no speakers 
> installed but the wiring was there.  The tag on the wiring said "10 ohm" 
> speakers only.
> 

You get maximum power transfer when the resistance/impedance is "matched" 
to the driver circuit.

The fact that the speakers are mis- matched means that power gets 
disippated in the power amp and wiring rather than the speakers the 
amount of power that gets delivered to the speakers is 4X4/10X10 of the 
available power ie you can only get about 1/6 of the max power ie around 
8dB down - this equates to winding the vol knob back from full to 3/4

Most well designed amps have built in self limiting to stop you blowing 
up the output stage - distortion is an audible sign that the 
self limiting is working.

If you are a member of the human race ( rather than an 18 year old mutant 
), then you probably drive round with the vol at < 1/2 max and will not 
notice any difference. 

If you do find the noise is bad - use the following steps
	make the partner(PC auto insertion) walk home
	turn of the radio and listen to that fantastic exhaust roar

Pete 




+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 10:57:44 +0100
From: P.M.KATZ@CAM3SE.boat.bt.com
Subject: RE: 84 911 Questions ?

> 1. The brake pad warning light was on during my test drive, and sure enough,
> during inspection, it required new rear pads.  However, the mechanic
> neglected to hit the warning light reset.  Is there a reset button or is
> there some auto-sensing mechanism?  If there's a reset button, where is it?

	The light is activated by a "sensor" which clips onto the brake pad. This
is just a plastic covered piece of wire (the 944 uses a similar 
system), and when
the pad wears down the plastic wears through, earthing the wire against 
the disk
("grounding the wire against the rotor" in US-speak) and turning on the light.

	The sensors are quite expensive (of the same order of cost as a pad, I
think) and the answer is usually to change your pads *before* the light 
goes on.

> 2. Being a newbie to 911s, I've found that going throught the gearbox is
> much like reading a map in the dark.  It's often tough to get into 2nd gear,
> requiring double clutching.  Is this normal or is the new clutch still out
> of adjustment?

	I've found the gear change on my '89 911 Carrera 3.2 (with the G50
gearbox / hydraulic clutch) to be a bit difficult, specifically when 
going into a
gear (*any* gear!) ... there seems to be a slight resistance when going from
neutral *into* the gear. Double declutching overcomes this, but I don't always
want to do this, especially in a heavy traffic commute. Some people have told
me that all 911s do this, others that I'm try to change gear too quickly, and
others that I may have a problem with my gear linkage.

> 3. The original clock does not work.  Anyone have any simple suggestions on
> how to test if it's the clock or a wiring problem?

	One of the advantages of the 911 is that the gauges are all separate and
and quite easy to remove. On the RHD car the clock s on the right hand side and
I can get to the back of it through the luggage compartment without popping
anything. Put a voltmeter across the terminals and see if there is 12V 
there. Also
check the fuse.

regards,
Philip Katz                                         <KatzPM@boat.bt.com>

1989 911 Carrera 3.2 Sport Coupe (Taubenblau/Baltic Blue Metallic)
Zero cats (but we're thinking of getting 2 kittens ...)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 08:33:01 -0400
From: MitchSF@aol.com
Subject: Re: purchasing a 911vs 928

Asad:
I was faced with the same decision in 1986, and I made it wrong (for me, that
is).  I chose the 928.  All performance statistics aside, is it a third car,
or a daily driver? Is comfort important?  Certainly the answer is different
for everyone, but if you are going to commute to downtown Baltimore in the
car every day, you should try to spend some time in stop and go traffic with
each car, especially the 911.  After a year, I gave the 928 to my wife, and
got a 911 - then we traded both on a Carrera 2.  I'd recommend a 1987 or
later 911 if you're commuting because of the improved clutch and
transmission.
Good Luck
Mitch Feig

Recently I decided to buy two sets (driver + passenger/instructor) of
6-point Simpson harnesses with the Weltmeister harness bar for my 944.  On
recommendation from friends I called Northstar Motorsports, in Wauconda IL
(708-487-2877 and orders at 800-356-2080).  Neither my friends nor I have
any financial interest in this company but.... I called on Tuesday morning
April 11 and had the whole order by late on the 12th.  I wasn't even ready
to install them!  Got around to that this past weekend and found I had
neglected to ask for clip ends to the crotch belts.  I called Brian Allman
at Northstar at 400PM his time yesterday and he sent the ends out then - no
charge, saying he should have asked about the clips!

I'm impressed with the service.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 09:27:27 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: RE: Chips for Porsches


I haven't seen what Stan wrote, but from the response by pjwales@magicnet. etc.
I know I agree with Stan.  My admittedly naive understanding is that the only
thing you can control is the injection pulse width and the ignition timing.
Put the engine on a dyno, modify these variables for max torque at a given
load and you've maximized engine output. 

I think it is smoke and mirrors.
These guys start raising the redline and changing timing for better fuel.
Try playing the same game, i.e., same redline and required octane rating
and I think you will not do better than Porsche.  Sure, you may add a little,
but at what expense.  Being an engineer, I am cognizant of the compromises
that must be made to generate the best *OVERALL* design in response to a 
given set of requirements.  All you guys are doing is changing the 
requirements, i.e., tuning the engine for more expensive gas. 

I have installed an Autothority chip in my "87" 944.  In 3rd gear from 1000
rpm to 6000 rpm the performance improved by 0.25 seconds over a 16 second
period, about what you would expect in going from 87 to 94 octane.  But you
have now increased the operating costs by $0.25/gal and decreased engine
life by some undeterminable amount.  You have not increased the *OVERALL*
performance with this kind of modification.  I have since sent the chip
back and reinstalled the original.

Why do you think my "87" 944 didn't 
come with a rear roll bar?  Porsche came up with a very good ride handling 
compromise.  As soon as I added the rear bar, the ride changed dramatically.
On uneven pavement, I get tossed around in the car where before I didn't even
notice the uneven pavement.  This may not make sense to the individual who 
autocrosses and to whom ride quality means nothing, but as a daily driver
I consider it a challenge to get the most out of the car as is and am con-
sidering removing the rear bar.  It also understeers just a tad now, but 
that can be controlled with tire pressure and throttle.  The car is a tad
more confident feeling through a corner now - but at what expense?  The same 
arguement applies to the chip.  

"You are not improving the car- you are changing
the car based on a different set of requirements."

jpuzas@astro.ge.com

Jeff

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 10:17:22 -0400 (EDT)

Subject: 911 SC Pistons and Cylinders



>Do any of you have any 3.2 "SC" style Max Moritz P&C's
>hanging around?  Or any other 3.0 SC P&C's which would
>allow running "S" or greater cams?

Boy, I wish I did. I need some too. You should look into the new 
replacement pistons produced by Shasta Design. They fit your existing 
cylinders, increase your compression ratio, and allow more 
aggressive cams. All this without producing flutter in the air flow 
baffle. And they cost $995 at the intro price.  If you buy them, 
keep me posted; I want some myself.  BTW Shasta has a great 
reputation among the 356 performance crowd for a quiet, light and 
durable replacement piston.

>I discovered that my engine likes to leak oil from a few
>places and cylinder #2 has an oil leak somewhere since
>it burns blue on that side and the heat exchanger gasket
>has oil on it.  So if I'm going to rebuild this thing "While I'm
>in there...." 275 or more HP sounds nice.  :-)

Yeah, it sounds nice, but sounds unrealistic to me (IMHO). 240 hp 
sounds obtainable without turning the car into snarling beast. 
Snarling beasts are good, if that is what you seek, but there are 
probably better recipes for  275 hp street engines than one based on 
normal aspiration and CIS injection.  Let me know if you are 
successful, I would like to know how.

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 10:22:41 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 F.I. Question??

>  Apparently an injector
>is leaking, but I seem to remember that there is a cold start injector
>that acts like a choke.

        The Cold Start injector is on the intake air distributor (the
plenum that the four intake runners come out of and the throttle goes
into).  On the 2.0 it is in the left-rear corner--not sure about the
1.7's.  It is most likely held on by two screws or bolts.  If you take
it out, get a new gasket for it.
        The "regular" injectors are held in by one 10mm nut each.  No
gaskets required, just a pair of rubber "donuts" each.  The nut goes
on a metal bit shaped something like:
                   _
                  /o\           o   = where the stud from the intake goes
                 / _ \          _
                ( (_) )        (_)  = where the injector goes
                 `---'

        To check them out, pressurize the system (e.g., start the car,
then shut it down) and take out one injector at a time.  If one or more
is leaking *at all* it should be thoroughly cleaned or replaced.  It is
safest to just replace it.  Oh, and watch out for dripping gasoline on
hot engine parts...  Engine fires really, really suck.
        Hmm--you should also check the Thermo-Time switch which controls
the Cold Start Valve.  It should have a specific resistance (I think)
when cold and one when hot.  I beleive that the correct procedure is in
Haynes.  (Don't have my manuals with me at work today  8)

- --DD

Dave Darling, 914 re-mantler
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

------------------------------

Date: 25 Apr 1995 08:49:55 -0800
From: Steve Poole <stevep@wrq.com>
Subject: Re(2): Chips for Porsches

>"You are not improving the car- you are changing
>the car based on a different set of requirements."

While I don't really have an opinion on the issue being debated,
I do have to observe that this is specious reasoning. As it happened, your
set of requirements turned out to be closer to Porsche's than to those
of the aftermarket chip and roll bar makers. That does not imply that
the car is not improved for someone whose requirements ARE better 
served by the changes provided by those components. 

As you say, part of engineering is determining the tradeoffs that best meet
the requirements. However, as engineers I think we can also say that we place
those requirements in the middle of our target audience bell curve. There are
always users whose requirements we have not matched completely, and their
equally legitimate requirements can be served by third parties.

Steve Poole
'79 911SC, coppery color 453-9-3

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 09:42:14 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: 916 -> 5 lug conversions

In response to text from thak chaloemtiarana:

>I am looking for steel flares for my 914 (cover wider tires for Solo II).

Speaking of flares, I've heard various opinions on the merits and headaches
of a 5-lug conversion on a 914.  Some say that not only do the hubs need to
be drilled at the rear, but also the entire front suspension needs to be 
replaced(upgraded).  I had thought that only all four hubs needed to be
modified.

When you put flares on a 914 one naturally wants to go with 8-inch rear wheels
and 7-inch front wheels to fill out the flared fenders.  Personally, I like
the look of "stuffed" wheel wells.  

Without the modifications, one could get 6-inch front, 7-inch rear, 4-lug 
wheels.  I'd like to hear what others who may have experience with flaring
914s have to say about the decisions they made.

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 09:56:28 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 FI Part #

In response to text from Andrew Kalman:

>My notes indicate that the '017 is the correct head temp resistor.  But I
>don't know about the in-line resistor - I hope someone can answer that ...

I received some advice regarding head temp sensors and idle mixture that I'll
pass on:

A head temperature sensor varies resistance with temperature which in turn
causes the "brain" to alter the mixture appropriately.  People speak of the
270-ohm resistor trick, but with a little time and effort you can get much
better results when it comes to calibrating the head temp sensor.

Needed:		a) variable resister ("pot") from radio shack
		b) means of measuring for stoich(lamba, Gastester, etc.)
		c) multimeter

Throw the potentiometer in series with your head temperature sensor and 
start the engine cold.  Vary the resistance with the pot until the best
cold idle mixture is obtained.  Remove pot and measure resistance across 
it, run out to radio shack get the appropriate resistor and install it
where the pot was.

This technique is handy when major engine modifications have been done(like
my little '70 1.7, 96mm NPR, FAT FI cam, 2.0 injector, beast).
	
Regards,
- -- 
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady               vox:313 996 9900   internet: jrb@one.com     -
 - Open Networks Engineering    fax:313 996 9908             abaris@msen.com -
 -                                                                           -   
 - [ '70 914 1.9 (96mm NPR, canary yellow 916 conversion) ]                  -
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: 25 Apr 1995 09:28:31 -0700
From: "Randal Jacoby" <Randal_Jacoby@chdqm.sps.mot.com>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1350 Ingn

        Reply to:   RE>Porschephiles #1350 Ingnition Kill

I, too, inquired about delayed ignition kill switches, and was told that they
were unavailable because of the liability questions if the car were to, say,
die in the middle of an intersection, or during a lane change on the freeway. 
I think that problem is solvable by programing the system to kill the ignition
after three minutes, but then only when the car comes to a stop.  This could
safely happen at the next red light, in heavy traffic, school crossings  etc. 
This would be OK I think for general security, plus I like the idea of really
inconveniencing the thief.
  
I was also interested in an anti-car-jacking measure.  The real problem I see
with this system or any other is in how to design it so that you can easily
and discretely trigger the sequence without being noticed by the car-jacker,
and at the same time make it difficult for the owner to accidentally trigger
the sequence.  Certainly a car is not worth dying over, but if there were a
safe way of triggering a system it might be worth having.  Maybe a pressure
(or lack of pressure) sensor in the seat AND a discrete switch, both of which
must be triggered within 30 seconds of each other with the engine idling to
activate the system?  More importantly, could I retire on the royalty income
from this?




------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 11:25:56 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: Chips for Porsches

Just a note on Superchips.  About a year ago I sent a message off
asking to receive info, including dyno charts, from Superchips.
All I received was the standard sales BS and a list of installers
for Superchips.  I refuse to believe anyones claims for power
gains without seeing dyno results.  Superchips claims to have
a dyno but is apparently unwilling to let you see the truth 
about what their chips actually do...  

Oh, even if you can get significant gains from chipping the question
remains - how much extra wear and tear are you putting on your 
engine.  There is no free lunch (one of my engineering professors
favorite lines) - added power means more heat which wears parts faster.

Ross Stites
'87 951

     I think it is smoke and mirrors. These guys start raising the redline
and changing      timing for better fuel. Try playing the same game, i.e.,
same redline and required      octane rating and I think you will not do
better than Porsche.  Sure, you may add      a little, but at what expense.
 Being an engineer, I am cognizant of the      compromises that must be made
to generate the best *OVERALL* design in      response to a given set of
requirements.  All you guys are doing is changing the 
     requirements, i.e., tuning the engine for more expensive gas. 

I would bet that most Porsche owners already use premium fuel. Why not take

     I have installed an Autothority chip in my "87" 944.  [deleted for
bevity] You have      not increased the *OVERALL* performance with this kind
of modification.  I have      since sent the chip back and reinstalled the
original.

What is OVERALL performance? I (and most others) are interested in having the
highest amount of HP at all points in the RPM range. Most other parameters
(mileage, emissions, etc.) are secondary. I can always drive my Ford Temp
when I need an efficient car.

     Why do you think my "87" 944 didn't come with a rear roll bar?  Porsche
came       up with a very good ride handling compromise.  As soon as I added
the rear bar,      the ride changed dramatically.[deleted for brevity] The
car is a tad more                  confident feeling through a corner now -
but at what expense?  The same                arguement applies to the chip.
 

Many 944's come with rear antiroll bars. I believe it was part of the sport
suspension package. I guess Porsche did find it necessary.

     "You are not improving the car- you are changing the car based on a
different      set of requirements."

I consider that an improvement.

Barry Lenoble
Blenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 13:12:59 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: RE(2): Chips for Porsches


Steve writes in response to:
> From stevep@wrq.com  Tue Apr 25 11:56:20 1995
> >"You are not improving the car- you are changing
> >the car based on a different set of requirements."
> 
> While I don't really have an opinion on the issue being debated,
> I do have to observe that this is specious reasoning. As it happened, your
> set of requirements turned out to be closer to Porsche's than to those
> of the aftermarket chip and roll bar makers. That does not imply that
> the car is not improved for someone whose requirements ARE better 
> served by the changes provided by those components. 
> 
> As you say, part of engineering is determining the tradeoffs that best meet
> the requirements. However, as engineers I think we can also say that we place
> those requirements in the middle of our target audience bell curve. There are
> always users whose requirements we have not matched completely, and their
> equally legitimate requirements can be served by third parties.
 
It seems we agree almost perfectly.  But my point is also that the chips
do not do what they claim to do which is increase torque by as much as
10 - 15%.  Most of the claims lead one to believe that the factory has
somehow not extracted everything that can be extracted from an engine
which they designed and built; and that they know some secret place
to get 10% that the factory does not know is there.

jpuzas@astro.ge.com
