Date: Tue, 25 Apr 95 09:50:07 pst
From: "GFORCE" <GFORCE@cccpp.com>
Subject: Re[2]: Car Theft Idea

What about the anti theft devices available today... the "Lojack system"?

        As far as I know, the Lojack system is localize and is available 
currently only in LA, San Diego and New York.  The use proprietary/private 
tracking systems installed only in the aforemention cities.

        There is another system call "Satrac" (I think that's the name) that is 
a combo GPS/cellular and has national coverage (As long as it's in cellular 
coverage, it'll work).  When your car is stolen/jacked, you call your car to 
have it transmit it's GPS location via cellular to a monitoring station, the 
monitor station then tramits the car's location to local authorties.

        On a side note, anyone know why GPS and Cell phone development kits are 
so damm expensive (complete GPS units are < $400, cell phones are < $100, kits 
range from $4600 !! to $500 !!)

G


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 95 10:46:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: 916 -> 5 lug conversions


>In response to text from thak chaloemtiarana:
>
>>I am looking for steel flares for my 914 (cover wider tires for Solo II).

Steel is good.......fiberglass will give you headaches!!!

>Speaking of flares, I've heard various opinions on the merits and headaches
>of a 5-lug conversion on a 914.  Some say that not only do the hubs need to
>be drilled at the rear, but also the entire front suspension needs to be
>replaced(upgraded).  I had thought that only all four hubs needed to be
>modified.

>I'd like to hear what others who may have experience with flaring
>914s have to say about the decisions they made.

I always hesitate at the thought of drilling more holes in the hubs in
order to change the bolt pattern.  It doesn't seem terribly safe to me.
Perhaps I'm paranoid....I just think of all the extreme cornering forces
exerted on the wheels and suspension and don't like the thought
of "swiss-cheese" hubs holding on my wheels.

I have 911 'S' front struts on my 914.  They just bolted right in place.
Along with the 5-bolt upgrade, I now have EXCELLENT brakes on
my car.  The difference is amazing.  I also had the extra expense
of 8x15 wheels and tires too, though.  Don't forget this when pricing
out your new flaring/wheel package.

The rear of my car was done by bolting in 911 hubs and stub axles.
VW Bus CV joints were used since they have 914 style splines
(well....close enough!) and the 6-bolt 911-style mounting method.
I am using 914-6 rear rotors and my 914-4 calipers required a
slight "trim" on the inside with a die grinder since the 914-6 rotors
are slightly larger in diameter than the 914-4 ones.

If all you want is to "fill the fenders", I believe a few weeks ago Stan
mentioned a company that makes wide 914-4 wheels.  This might
be the cheapest option.  If you want a decent brake upgrade, you
might consider what I did, or use the wide 914-4 wheels combined
with aftermarket Brembos or Bremteks, etc which are made for
the 914-4 strut to improve your brakes.  I have no idea what those
cost, but that is another option and would keep you from drilling
out your hubs.

Good luck!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
'75 914-6  3.0 SC

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 11:15:39 -0800
From: mkoto@rain.org (Michael F. Kotowski)
Subject: Re: Chips for Porsches

Peter Wales wrote:

>The day I went on vacation Stan wrote some fairly discouraging things about
>chips, and even though it was 2 weeks ago, I would like to put the other
>side of the story.
>
>Firstly, I get the impression that Stan is a Porsche man! By that I mean
>that if it is not approved by Porsche, it's usually  not worth bothering
>with. This impression has been made over several weeks of reading his very
>knowledgeable replies to all sorts of questions.
>
>I am happy (very happy in fact) to accept that the Autothority mass flow
>system does not get his approval.

Regarding chips and mass flow sensors, I'd like to post my original
question: Has anyone had a positive experience with an aftermarket chip
and/or mass flow sensor? After sending my Authority chip and sensor back to
the factory twice, I gave up and got my money back.

I made a dozen or so timed runs from 50 mph to 100 mph in third gear (same
road) and found my "before and after" times to be identical. Worse still,
the chip would occasionally cause the engine to run full rich and stall
out. After two or three of these episodes, I had the car towed back to the
shop and the original chip and sensor reinstalled.

Stan's comment regarding my experience was something to the effect that
there are no "magic bullets" out there. As much as I'd like to believe in
(chip) magic, I have to conclude that Stan's right.

Michael F. Kotowski   (mkoto@rain.org)   Santa Barbara, CA



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 13:25:26 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: RE: 916 -> 5 lug conversions

>I always hesitate at the thought of drilling more holes in the hubs in
>order to change the bolt pattern.  It doesn't seem terribly safe to me.

        *Supposedly* this was what the factory did on 70-71 cars.  I have
heard that the early hubs have reinforced areas that can be drilled for
either the four- or the five-bolt pattern.  I have no experience with
this, though--and I agree, it doesn't sound too safe somehow.

- --DD



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 11:39:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: KN@sundog.caltech.edu
Subject: 914 5 lug conversion

Just to add to the thread on 5 lug conversions.  I am in the middle
of doing the suspension/brake/wheel conversion for my 73 914-6
project. The reason for using a 911 strut and hub in the front is
I believe that the front hubs for 914s were not designed (ie
reinforced to be drilled for 5 lugs). The rears however were made
this way ( at least in 1970). Here's what I'm doing to my non-flared
car -
Front: Swapping to 1973 T front suspension - Rebuilt with all new parts
including new factory torsion bars, Bilstein shocks. Adding 19mm
adjustable sway bar.
Rear: Using proper 1970 drilled hubs and the stock 914 drive shafts
(my engine will be a 73 T motor w/ 150 ft-lbs), 911 vented rotors
and 911 "M" calipers with and adjustable "Tilton" style proportioning
valve.
Wheels - 6*16 911 Fuchs with 205/55 - 16 street tires, possibly
Comp TAs.
Brake pads - Ferodo AF
Misc: New OEM rubber brake lines, 19mm master cylinder
This should provide a nice balance package for my needs (one of 
which is to keep down costs).
If anyone wants more details, ie prices, reasonable vendors, etc,
contact me directly - Kjell  kn@sundog.caltech.edu

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 11:49:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: 916 -> 5 lug conversions

Hi all -

> >I always hesitate at the thought of drilling more holes in the hubs in
> >order to change the bolt pattern.  It doesn't seem terribly safe to me.

I agree, but for model years 70-71 the factory did make hubs with 
"beefed" up areas for either a four or five bolt pattern as Dave Darling 
has suggested below.

> *Supposedly* this was what the factory did on 70-71 cars.  I have
> heard that the early hubs have reinforced areas that can be drilled for
> either the four- or the five-bolt pattern.  I have no experience with
> this, though--and I agree, it doesn't sound too safe somehow.

I did this when we constructed our 914 race car and found some earlier 
hubs with the four/five bolt pattern and re-drilled them for five bolts. 
The hubs are getting hard to find and demand a premium when you do find 
them.  We have now used them for over five years and have yet to have a 
problem (knock on wood now that I have made this statement :-).).  We run 
wide race tires on the rear and the only problem with anything coming 
loose is the cv joints at the tranny.  Seems that no matter how tight you 
tighten the cv joints the gaskets continue to slip out with all the 
centrifical force.  Have recently gone without gaskets after "stoning" 
the surfaces of the cv joints and the problem seems to have gone away 
including the mess of leaking grease.  Without the gaskets seems 
definitely better.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 14:50:35 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Re: Chips for Porsches


>      .. My admittedly naive understanding is that the only thing you can
> control is the         injection pulse width and the ignition timing. Put the
> engine on a dyno, modify         these variables for max torque at a given
> load and you've maximized engine            output.... 
> 
> Correct - and that might be higher than from the factory - Wouldn't  this be
> considered higher performance?

My point here is that it is not any better than from the factory.  This is not
rocket science.  If it was in there Porsche would find it.  These aftermarket
chip makers are simply retuning the engine for higher octane gas.

> 
>      I think it is smoke and mirrors. These guys start raising the redline
> and changing      timing for better fuel. Try playing the same game, i.e.,
> same redline and required      octane rating and I think you will not do
> better than Porsche.  Sure, you may add      a little, but at what expense.
>  Being an engineer, I am cognizant of the      compromises that must be made
> to generate the best *OVERALL* design in      response to a given set of
> requirements.  All you guys are doing is changing the 
>      requirements, i.e., tuning the engine for more expensive gas. 
> 
> I would bet that most Porsche owners already use premium fuel. Why not take
> full advantage of it?

If your car is not tuned for higher octane you are *WASTING* your money.
> 
>      I have installed an Autothority chip in my "87" 944.  [deleted for
> bevity] You have      not increased the *OVERALL* performance with this kind
> of modification.  I have      since sent the chip back and reinstalled the
> original.
> 
> What is OVERALL performance? I (and most others) are interested in having the
> highest amount of HP at all points in the RPM range. Most other parameters
> (mileage, emissions, etc.) are secondary. I can always drive my Ford Temp
> when I need an efficient car.

Your response is based on the chip living up to its claims.  My point here
is that you have increased your operating costs by 25% for an almost 
imperceptable performance increase.  

And you would be driving a Ford Tempo, not a Porsche.
> 
>      Why do you think my "87" 944 didn't come with a rear roll bar?  Porsche
> came       up with a very good ride handling compromise.  As soon as I added
> the rear bar,      the ride changed dramatically.[deleted for brevity] The
> car is a tad more                  confident feeling through a corner now -
> but at what expense?  The same                arguement applies to the chip.
>  
> 
> Many 944's come with rear antiroll bars. I believe it was part of the sport
> suspension package. I guess Porsche did find it necessary.

They found it neccesary to satisfy a select few buyers by offering it as an
option at the expense of ride quality.  Different - not better.  Better would
be to keep ride quality the same and improve handling.

> 
>      "You are not improving the car- you are changing the car based on a
> different      set of requirements."
> 
> I consider that an improvement.

I can not argue with your reality, that is why Porsche offers options to 
satisfy those who would compromise ride quality for handling.
> 
> Barry Lenoble
> Blenoble@aol.com
> 89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

If it's chipped, you'll be replacing a head gasket guaranteed; and you'll also
experience premature wear of all drive train components such as, clutch, CV
joints, transaxel, main bearings etc., which were sized for a given design
life based on 247hp.
 
By the way I've driven a chipped 89 Turbo and man does 
that thing get the adrenaline going.  I understand why you guys
chip the Turbos.  There are tremendous performance gains that are
a hell of a lot of fun if you're willing to live with the reliability
issues.  However, the normally aspirated engines do not respond any
where near like the turbos.  It is an imperceptable difference.  

>

Well, I survived the trip to Myrtle Beach and back in "Katarina".  Only 
problem was the loss of a little over a quart of oil at the 1600 mile 
mark.  Is this normal usage or should I be looking for a leak?  The spec 
book appears to say oil consumption is "approx. 1.5 liters per 1000/kms." 
(p. 123). 

The only noteworthy event (for this list) on the trip was the significant 
absence of fellow Porsches on the roads.  I saw one 911SC Targa (black) 
parked at Joey's Ribs in Charleston, WV 4/18 then saw a white 944 being 
visited by the state policia in Ohio and a red 944 going the other 
direction in Ohio, both on 4/23.  That was it.  I was very surprised.  

Well, Katarina needs a good bath after her 2100+ mile odyssey.  C-ya!

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 95 13:41:06 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Antitheft Switches

Regarding dashboard engine kill/fuel cutoff switches, Wayne wrote:

> Does anyone know of a small
> Porsche rocker type switch that is a toggle mechanism, or has anyone modified
> one of the existing switches to be a toggle?
>

Don't know your model 911 but on my SC the electric mirror left/right
select switch fits the hdlt. washer switch cutout and has the sustained
action (ie not momentary).  Go to your dealer parts counter and explain
what you're after.  Only problem is it's a power switch and as such not
suitable for logic level switching, but it should work OK for the fuel
pump relay.

Can any of you legal types comment further on the liability issue here?
It sounds crazy enough to be true, but on the other hand the joint
probability of (carjack * out-of-gas-accident * lawsuit) seems pretty
low... but what do I know?  Is this the whiplash of the 90s?

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 95 13:41:44 PDT
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: 911: engine backfires - HELP


P-Netters,
	On my newly rebuilt 2.2l w/Zenith carbs, I am experiencing
an engine backfire.  This occures pretty much all the time,
however, it is worse on severe deceleration, or going downhill
in a lower gear.  I have tried to tune the engine to get rid
of this with no luck.  
	I have gotten two completely different answers from a couple
of non-porsche owning friends.  Both are sudo-mechanics, but I would
hesitate to take thier advice without hearing from an expert.
	One says the carbs are not delivering enough fuel, hense the
backfire. (trying to have it smogged, high hc's, smog shop, says running
too lean).  The other says its my valve seats not seating properly.
	If it matters, I am running a Bursch Turbo muffler.  Other
than the backfires the engine runs very strong, best from 3000 to ~4200.

	Any help or advice appreciated.

Tom 1970 911T 

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 13:53:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: Re: Ignition Kill etc..

Hi all,

	With all this talk of sophisticated kill systems and time delay cut
 -off switches, I'd just like to relate my little tale of inconvinience and
how it could be used as a kill switch.

	This last winter was the big engine refit for my 914 2.0. All new
fuel system, temp sensors, hoses etc... and one of those frustrating little
black double-spade connectors had broken internally and I didn't catch it.
This connector was for the head-temp sensor. So as a result, the car was
fine when cold, but as the engine heated up, the mixture stayed rich.
Making for really bad running at low RPM. The warmer the engine got, the
worse it would idle. And when the engine got to normal temp it -would-
stall unless the rpms were kept high. The engine would then be flooded at
that point and wouldn't re-start unless the fuel pump was turned off, the engine
restarted, run untill it starves, reconect the pump, start and go. I always
thought this would be quite a handy little device for anti car-jacking.
However, I'm not sure that a 914 really is high on the list of a car-jacker
. And I doubt this would work for a more modern car that uses O2 sensors
and the like. And naturally, carbed cars are different creature too. So,
for all of you out there with older bosch FI, this might be an interesting
alternative to time delay switches etc... 

 -Josh



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 15:59:26 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: racing & porsche infoP

>I want to know about auto-crossing in the NJ and eastern PA region.  Are there
>any in this area and if so what are the costs associated with it.
>What about Porsche clubs?  How much $$$?  What are the events?

        For Porsche Club info, see the information you got in your Porsche-
philes sign-up packet.  ($36/year, must have VIN...)  Northern NJ is one of
the largest and most active regions in the PCA.

>The racing plans for now are for my '79 Scirocco, but when the 914 is done
>it will be time to play with it too.

        The PCA folks will (probably) insist on you racing your Porsche.
That's OK, because it's a *really* fun autoX car.  Not the most competi-
tive car when stock, but lots of fun.  For your Scirocco, you can talk
to the SCCA (probably some info in that first big message you got).  There
are also other clubs around, but I'm not sure which ones operate in that
area.  Marque clubs (like BMWCCA, the Alfa club, the 510/Datsun club, etc)
are often willing to let "ousiders" run.  Check around at specialty repair
shops and/or racing shops in your area.
        Good luck--the 914 is a very rewarding car when driven properly,
and isn't as unforgiving as some when driven improperly.

- --DD

Dave Darling, 914 re-mantler
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 14:25:26 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Some (advanced?) Brake Caliper Questions

Hi All:

I just finished rebuilding yet another set of Ate brake calipers, and my
curiosity has led to a few questions - perhaps someone knows the answer.

1) What type of rubber are caliper O-ring seals (the ones between the
caliper halves) made of? Butyl? Buna-N?

2) If the rubber is special / not commonly available, does anyone know of a
good source?  The only place I've ever seen them made available is through
BMP design, a BMW parts house in Texas. And they're quite expensive.

3) Some Ate two-piston calipers (e.g. 911T non-vented) have a sort of guide
pin that goes into a hole (that is free to move laterally a bit) in the
piston. Others (e.g. BMW and Alfa rears, BMW 320i front (?)) do not have
this guide pin arrangement, and neither do the 4-piston (BMW 2002tii,
530i/528i) Ate units I've done.  Why is this arrangement used on some
calipers and not others? Is a guide pin required above a certain piston
diameter?

4) The pistons on calipers that don't use the guide pin arrangement
mentioned above often have their "bottom" (as in the bottom of a cup) as
far from the pad as possible (leaving a big hollow space that rusts between
the pad and the back wall of the piston), whereas those with the guide pin
arrangement have their "bottom" up close near the pad. This affects the
volume of fluid that's in each caliper cylinder -- those with no guide pin
contain much less fluid. Isn't less fluid behind the piston always better?

5) I've noticed that high-performance calipers (e.g. Brembo and Wilwood)
have "differential piston sizes for reduced pad taper." Am I right in
assuming that the smaller piston is the on at the leading edge of the pad
for the same reason(s) that one rotates Ate single-piston-caliper pistons
with their cutout at 20degrees?

I have HPBooks' Brake Handbook but it doesn't cover brake caliper design
very well.

Thanks for your input,

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  | 
|___________________________________________|
|            Novice Welders Unite!          |
|___________________________________________|         


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 14:25:19 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: MOMO Steering Wheel Horn Buttons - Closure

I'd like to thank everyone for responding to my query about the current
availability of marque-specific horn buttons for MOMO steering wheels.

The Net Wisdom is that Porsche and BMW, in an ongoing effort to protect
their copyrighted material, sued MOMO and forced them to stop making said
buttons. 

This happened a couple of years ago, and in the meantime many people
(including me) have found existing or leftover buttons at a variety of
suppliers.  

I confirmed via telephone with MOMO in Miami that marque-specific buttons
are NLA.

The supply of these buttons is now dwindling or gone completely, so don't
throw away your MOMO horn button - it's probably worth something!

Again, thanks for responding.



 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  | 
|___________________________________________|
|            Novice Welders Unite!          |
|___________________________________________|         


------------------------------

Date: 25 Apr 1995 17:19:04 -0500
From: "Elliot Entin" <elliot.entin@alphatech.com>
Subject: Anti-Theft

                       Subject:                               Time:4:58 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          Anti-Theft                             Date:4/25/95

Back in the misspent days of my youth when I work-on and drag-raced flathead
Fords, I wired up a '48 with five double-pole double-throw toggle switches as
a lark.  All the toggle switches had to be in the right position for the car
to start.  Of course there were no marks on the switches and they were
randomized as to position.  I would randomly changes the setting of three
switch when I left the car.  Its a hard problem to solve if you are in a hurry
(as a thief would be).  
The down side was ocassionly I forgot the right position, and had to
experiment a bit.  But it worked - I never used a key, and my '48 rag top was
never taken for a joy ride (favorite past time of some).

Elliot
'83 911 SC   


------------------------------

Date: 25 Apr 1995 14:47:06 -0800
From: "Rodger Keesee" <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re: Antitheft Switches

Ed writes: (referring to kill switches) 

Can any of you legal types comment further on the liability issue here?
It sounds crazy enough to be true, but on the other hand the joint
probability of (carjack * out-of-gas-accident * lawsuit) seems pretty
low... but what do I know?  Is this the whiplash of the 90s?

Reply:
I am only a "legal type" to the extent that I aspire to become an attorney.
(Currently pre-law) 
But, personal injury attorneys have definitely made an example of this kind of
thing.  I know of some really appalling cases where crime did pay (millions)
because of a personal injury incurred during the committal of the crime.  It's
blatantly illegal to plan on any theft deterrent to injure the potential
thief.  (i.e. rig a gun to your front door)  Along the same vein, if someone
(even the thief) is injured because of your theft deterrent, (whether you
planned on it or not) constitutes negligence on your part. Cases have been
lost concerning the very scenario I described in an earlier post, which is why
delayed kill switches made today don't kill the engine until the door is
opened or the car is shut off by the driver.  

Rodger
911SC shaped space in the parking lot

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 18:55:00 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: distributor for 914

I followed with interest the 912/356 distributor debate and although much of 
the information applies to distributors holistically, I have a specific 
enquiry re: a 914. 

I am putting together an engine with 104mm Wiseco pistons, stroker Skat 
crank & Skat rods and massively reworked heads (total displ. 2.65 l). The 
engine is intended for autocross and some PCA track stuff but street driving 
as well.

My concern lies with distributor choice. I would like to use a distributor 
that has some vacuum advance to keep the car streetable (I think that I can 
gang together enough vacuum inputs from the manifolds to keep the pulsation 
effect to a dull roar), but not necessarily the stock unit with the FI 
points in it.

Has anybody had any experience with the 050 distributor in this sort of 
application (ie. can it still be run well on the street w/ centrifugal 
advance) or perhaps the MSD distributor made for Type I engines? Any 
comments would be appreciated. I also have an MSD 6 unit w/ the crankfire 
trigger, but I'm not sure that that would impact my advance problem.
Christopher Paine                         "Technology is like a steamroller,
Metropolis Pictures, Director              if you're not on it, you become
Editor,Der Auspuff,Rennsport Region PCA    part of the road"

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 17:36:11 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: non-competitive 914s

>What did you mean by 'not the most competitive car'?  Are you referring to
>PCA rules?  I believe the 914 can sometimes be competitive in SCCA autox
>classes.

        What I meant was that a stock 914 was no TToD threat.  Few stock
cars are, but the stock 914s are more likely to be toward the bottom than
the stock 911s.  Unfortunately, HP *does* count.  (It couldn't *all* be
my driving, *could* it?)
        Then again, I know of one or two 914s that, when they show up, are
pretty much guaranteed TToD.  8)   One is a 3.2L six-cylinder monster, and
the others are 2.4L (?  2.7???) four-banger OUTRAGEOUS monsters!
        As to rules, PCA does not have one unified rule-set.  The closest
thing seems to be the PCRs, which almost everyone agrees is kinda screwed
up.  914s can be competitive in their classes, depending on the ruleset--
in the PCA Zone 7 rules, 2.0L 914s are in their own classes, so of course
they're competitive...  ;)

- --DD

Dave Darling, 914 re-mantler
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 17:55:47 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Chips for Porsches

> Stan's comment regarding my experience was something to the effect that
> there are no "magic bullets" out there. As much as I'd like to believe in
> (chip) magic, I have to conclude that Stan's right.

As a designer of whole EFI systems, a programmer of other people's systems,
and a consumer of high-end racing stuff, I've spent a *PILE* of time
thrashing this stuff out on the dyno.

* chips in and of themselves are not magic. They got the "awesome" rep
  from Motronic turbo cars where you can control the wastegate by
  software, which really lets you get a lot more power even though it
  may come a some expense (see also "951 head gasket, blown" and "heat
  of combustion")

* programmable EFI lets you adjust the fuel characteristics to the specifics
  of *YOUR* engine and operating environment. For instance, it's a lot
  easier to compensate for being at 5000 ft. above sea level or having
  to run on 102 octane instead of 110 or whatever.

* better programming -- these days -- very, very seldom makes more power.
  Where you make more power is in CHANGING OTHER STUFF and then changing
  the programming to match.

BTW, anyone want to buy a couple of cases of 64KB and 128KB EPROMs? No
car-related stuff on them, sorry....

Stan

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1353                         Wed Apr 26 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 17:57:14 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 916 -> 5 lug conversions

>         *Supposedly* this was what the factory did on 70-71 cars.  I have
> heard that the early hubs have reinforced areas that can be drilled for
> either the four- or the five-bolt pattern.  I have no experience with
> this, though--and I agree, it doesn't sound too safe somehow.

This is correct. There are extra reinforced lands on the '70 hubs to
accommodate drilling for five-lug. Unfortunately, once you drill for
four-lug, you've already weakened the structure a bunch....

Drilling is not a good idea, except for "show only" cars. If you've going
to drive it hard, you create these *unbelievable* stress risers...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 25 Apr 1995 15:58:15 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Auto A/C Leak & Repair

                      Subject:                              Time:  3:46 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         Auto A/C Leak & Repair                Date:  4/25/95

A recent thread on auto a/c indicated that there are
some P-philers out there who understand a lot more about
air conditioners that I do and I'm hoping that your
collective wisdom can help me out of a jam.

My '84 928S sprang a leak in the a/c recently and the Porsche
dealer (after an hour and a half of diagnostics) found 
a pinhole leak in an alloy pipe running from the compressor
hose to the firewall area.  My first thought was that it 
would be an easy fix ... well, they want a fairly hefty 
price when you add up labor, parts (pipe, gaskets, freon,
etc) and sales tax.  Being a cheapskate (squeezing the 
nickel until the buffalo farts), I've been thinking about
doing the pipe replacement myself.

Here are my questions.  First, the pipe is on the high 
pressure side of the compressor.  Can I either solder the
pinhole or have a shop weld it closed such that it will
hold up under pressure?  Would a radiator shop do that
kind of work or would I take the pipe to an a/c shop?  A
machine shop?   Do I need a pipe, or could I just
make a custom hose using the same type of a/c hose and 
fittings that are coming from the compressor?

Second, would it be worth risking buying a salvaged pipe
if I can find one?  How would I test it before installing?  How
many PSI should it be able to take?

Third, if I do the removal and replacement work myself, what
do I need to do to avoid damaging my system?  For example, 
I seem to recall a statement in one of the threads that if
the system is exposed to outside air, the drier (?) will be
contaminated/ruined.  When I take the pipe out, of course
the system will be exposed to the air, so should I just plug
the compressor hose and the expansion valve opening?  With
what should I plug them (a baggie wrapped around the hose 
and secured with electrical tape?)??

Fourth, have any of you had this type of problem?  The 
mechanic said he had never seen one of these pipes leak before.

Any and all suggestions would help me greatly as all I know
about a/c is where the button is to turn it on!  FWIW, I do
most of my own maintenance and am somewhat mechanically 
inclined.

TIA for all your help!

John
'84 928S (nice and toasty in the sun!)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 95 16:59:18 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Antitheft Switches

} From: "Rodger Keesee"  <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
}
} I am only a "legal type" to the extent that I aspire to become an attorney.
} (Currently pre-law)
} But, personal injury attorneys have definitely made an example of 
this kind of
} thing.  I know of some really appalling cases where crime did pay (millions)
} because of a personal injury incurred during the committal of the 
crime.  It's
} blatantly illegal to plan on any theft deterrent to injure the potential
} thief.  (i.e. rig a gun to your front door)  Along the same vein, if someone
} (even the thief) is injured because of your theft deterrent, (whether you
} planned on it or not) constitutes negligence on your part. Cases have been
} lost concerning the very scenario I described in an earlier post, 
which is why
} delayed kill switches made today don't kill the engine until the door is
} opened or the car is shut off by the driver.

Hmmm, so the rule "you must have clean hands to come into equity" only
applies if the crime deterent methodologies cannot be construed as
neglegent? (gee, that sounded good! maybe I should go to law school! :-)
Thus, if a thief falls and breaks a leg inside your dark house, he cannot
sue because of the clean hands rule, but if you had a trap door that
caused the thief to fall and be hurt, then he could sue? It appears that
the burglary victim does not have the same rights as the burglar, but
in fact he/she does. The victim could certainly sue the burglar for a
variety of things, but the burglar probably doesn't have any assets.
The victim does have assets, so the burglar's suit has a good chance
of resulting in collecting an award. It just boils down to the old deep
pockets chase: the legal eagles go after those who have the assets
to pay damages.

Getting back to the p-car related content::

So, instead of a kill switch, how about a time delay tripping of the alarm;
the alarm horn sounds and the lights start flashing but the car doesn't
die (perhaps until the car comes to a stop)? In fact, my alarm system
(a Code alarm) remote control has a "panic" button that sets the alarm
off immediately. Someone recommended carrying the alarm remote
separately from your keys. If you had the remote in your pocket when
the carjacker forced you out of the car, you could set the alarm off as
he drove off. A delay might be in order if you didn't want to be too
close when the alarm goes off.

Are carjackings really all that common an occurance? Has anyone
on the list been carjacked? If so, what city and what kind of area did
it occur?

    Eric

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 20:14:31 -0400
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: 911 Voltage & Cellular Phone

P-filers,

The cellular phone in my '87 Carrera keeps switching on and off erratically.
After testing the entire system, the installers concluded that I had a
problem with my battery: voltage reading was only 10-11 V with the car shut
off and 16 V when running. They explained that I had an "open cel" in the
battery and that the high voltage during running means that the battery
doesn't provide enough "load" for the alternator. To me it sounded more like
a voltage regulator going bad and possibly the battery with it. The '84-'89
factory manuals don't even mention the voltage regulator and I don't have the
manuals for earlier series cars. 
Can anyone give me the right voltage readings and testing procedure for the
'87 Carrera ?

Thanks,

Bart

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 22:02:39 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: Salvaged 1991 911 Turbo

Terry asked about what a stipped 1991 911 might be worth missing most all the
easily removable parts save the engine and tranny.

Terry,

Given all the stuff your salvaged 1991 turbo is missing: perhaps a good way
to see how good a deal the left-overs are (i.e., body shell, engine and
tranny), would be to call a salvage dealer and give them a list of what you
need to make the car whole again.  Then add a whole bunch of hours for
reconnecting things such as wiring harnesses for the doors, "stuff from under
the dash", etc., at what ever price you value your time, add about 50% to
that for time you didn't anticpate, for things you didn't anticpate doing,
subtract all this from the *wholesale* price of the car, and you might get
close to what you should expect to pay for the car.

If you use the retail price of the car to subtract everything from, I think
you will only be kidding yourself about what the car will bring when your
buyer finds out the car was pieced back together from a bunch of other cars,
even if you do a creditable job of putting all the requred pieces back
together.

I hate to sound pessimistic, but in my view you should do somthing like this
in order not to sink in more $ than you could ever hope to get out.
 .....Just a suggestion, FWIW.

Jim Williams
JWilli 911@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 21:17:10 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 suspension

> Does anyone have or know were I can get a pair of adjustable or lower 
> rear shock perches.  I need to find a pair so I can lower the rear end of 
> the car without cutting the springs.  

Paragon Products in Corpus Christi TX. Get Koni shocks with their adjustable
spring perch kit. Yes, you gotta get the shocks if you want the kit unless
you already have Konis. They also sell the springs you need in a variety
of different stiffnesses.

> Also is there any trick stiffneres 
> for the front of a 914, it seems loss when you turn the wheel quick left 
> then right as if the whole front is twisting.  

Stiffer torsion bars. Possibly stiffer sway bar. Possibly new bearings, or
A-arm bushings, or balljoints.

Or there is a very remote chance that you really have overexceeded the 
design limits of the tub.

Stan

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 02:12:48 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Naresh H. Singh" <nhs1681@is2.NYU.EDU>
Subject: Security: Anti-Carjack Protection


Hi Porschephiles,

With all the recent talk of Porsche security I couldn't resist being a 
electronics and security buff!

As for the "kill switches," they are a great idea but if the fuel cuts 
off while the thief is on the highway, your Porsche is liable to be 
totalled! Now, as it has been suggested if there was a way to rig the 
system so that it would only activate while the car was stopped, that 
would be great. However, there is an easier alternative...

Crimestopper Alarms offer a "Carjack feature" that once the door is 
opened for a pre-determined length of time while the engine is running it 
will go into Carjack mode. Two minutes after it is triggered, your alarm 
siren goes off and parking lights flash (at this point the thief should 
be a safe distance away). Eight seconds later the starter disable circuit 
engages which will prevent the thief from re-starting the car. Doesn't 
sound too impressive yet... here is where it can get interesting...        

You can add to this system a "Interior Pain Generator Siren" which is a 
125db (I think) siren. This way, when Carjack mode has been activated the 
thief will be treated to the sweet sounds of 125db going through the 
interior of the car.. needless to say, he (she) is sure to get the heck 
out of there. To make things more interesting you could possibly add more 
than one "Pain Generator" <bg>

This way you don't run the risk of your car getting injured in the incident
by having the gas cut-off. Nor do you run the risk of being sued by the 
thief. Unless, of course, for deafness <vbg>

Obviously the system is more complex than this, I've outlined the features 
for you. The "Carjack" Feature is currently available on the Crimestopper 
CS-9605Pi and CS-9206CR3 priced at $159 and $199 respectively. You can 
get more info by calling Crutchfield at 1-800-955-3000. They are a great 
source of Home and Auto audio equipment.

If you have any questions run it by them or Email and I'll try to answer 
you as best as I can.


Naresh H. Singh
'85 and '86 not likely Carjack targets!

 -Pre-law and still no Porsche! (still looking for a 944)


BTW, I have no link with Crimestopper or Crutchfield (satisfied customer) 
and have provided this information as a service to fellow Porschephiles

Hi

I have the bear tracker II and it works as adv. the warning sound only 
works when they use their radio. No talking then you won't know where 
they are. The thing works great for finding the airplane type speed 
traps. You can hear the pilot talking with the patrol cars miles away.

You can't totally rely on this as mentioned before. I have had crusiers 
on the back bumper and not a sound from the beartracker. Thats where 
the rear view mirrow comes in. Also watch the traffice around and in 
front of you if all of a sudden you find yourself in a pack there is 
usually a reason for it. IE patrol car leading or in the middle of the 
pack.

Don't know about any jammers they are avail.

There are hidden radar detectors and there are even some which are 
stealth as won't be picked up by a dectector detector.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 95 14:39:27 -0700
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: 928 and power

In response to a message from Matt, which said:

...
>I have an '84 928S.  With the 16 valve engine, 234HP is definitely
>not enough.  What year is your 928 and have you made any mods
>to increase performance?
...

I posted a message to the list last week in response to some
inquiries about my engine, but I think there was a problem
with delivery to part of the list.  Part of the following is
that message.

My 928 started as a US '80 with 3 speed automatic.  The original
engine had a "melt down" (overheated in seconds, burst the
coolant tank, siezed a pulley on the front--it was ugly!).  I
replaced that engine with a professionally built racing engine
based upon an '82 Euro 928.  It retains the big valve heads and
the Euro block, but all other components were replaced with high
performance parts.  It was very well balanced, and should be
good for between 9,000 and 10,000 rpm (although wear would be
tremendous).  It has very radical, long duration cams, and
will not idle for more than about 10 seconds in drive (I shift
to neutral at stop lights).  It gets 9 mpg on the highway, and
7 mpg in city driving (tradeoffs).

I had the original transmission rebuilt to help it live
peacefully with the engine, but my mechanic says it probably
won't last.  The adjustment I was refering to is simply the shift
linkage tension adjustment on the side of the transmission.
Tighten the cable for higher shifts and longer duration in low
gears.  To get it to shift harder (less slip, to protect the
trans.), turn the set screw on the side of the transmission (I
don't remember which way).

I can't list all that was done to my engine, because I bought
it from a racer who had it made by a professional racing engine
builder.  However, the key points to emphasize are:

  Hone and polish the intake system (all of it, including a bigger
  throttle and less restrictive air flow meter).

  Use big valve heads (or make/modify your own, if none are
  available).

  Increase the compression ratio (different pistons or mill heads).

  Port/polish the heads.

  Use VERY radical long duration cams.

  Use racing headers with low restriction exhaust (Borla is good).

  Use a late model crank shaft (has bigger/better oil porting).

  Have the engine meticulously balanced (because the horse power
  will be at very high revs--I typically shift at 8500rpm, and
  it pulls harder at even higher).

  Replace the computer with one that can be "tuned."

  Have the car dyno tuned.

I am currently installing a supercharger to give moderate low
RPM boost to improve low RPM torque, and to compensate for high
altitude mountain driving (this should work without decreasing
the compression ratio because the long duration cams result in
low effective compression at low RPMs).  A new fuel computer is
in the works;  I designed it based upon a Microchip PIC 16C74
CPU.  600 HP is my goal.  I'll let everyone know how it goes.


                                                 --Mike

Date: Tue, 25 Apr 1995 23:14:00 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: EFI/Electromotive TEC

First, I would like to let people know that I am now employed at 
Electromotive, and can be reached there at 703-378-2444 or by e-mail. 

Last week Stan made the comment that the Electromotive TEC engine 
management system "*CAN NOT*" be used with anything but a common plenum 
intake. That is no longer true. At long last, the issue of running a TEC 
on an engine without a super stable manifold pressure signal has been 
addressed.

We now offer a new software package, Super*Blend, which provides a 
sixteen position map that allows the use of some or all of the throttle 
position sensor voltage to control fuel at low throttle openings. This 
signal is "blended" with the manifold pressure signal in zero to sixteen 
steps to provide the benefits of throttle/RPM mapping at low throttle 
openings and speed density (manifold pressure/temperature/RPM) tuning at 
higher load settings.

ECU with crank triggered twin-plug ignition system and calibration 
software (includes data logging and graphics package) is $2050. Single 
plug systems are much ($400) cheaper.

To offer some idea of the true capability of the TEC system, consider 
that it is the only aftermarket EFI system to pass California Air 
Resources Board testing for an aftermarket bolt-on kit. This was for a 
Jeep, admittedly, but one look at that 1940's era intake manifold should 
give you some idea of what we were up against.

I have worked with Electromotive products since 1988, when the TEC was 
introduced. I feel they offer the best value in aftermarket EFI's, and 
this new software is exactly what has been needed for years. I will also 
say that they have never been known for great information and product 
support, and that is a big part of what I hope to improve.

Call write or e-mail if you would like more information.

Larry Bershtein

of course!).

out for in car of this mileage? and (2) what (if any) special precautions 
should I take to ensure that it keeps going for another 94,000 miles?

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 08:32:02 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1350 Ingn

On 25 Apr 1995, Randal Jacoby wrote:

> I was also interested in an anti-car-jacking measure.  The real problem I see
> with this system or any other is in how to design it so that you can easily
> and discretely trigger the sequence without being noticed by the car-jacker,
> and at the same time make it difficult for the owner to accidentally trigger
> the sequence.  Certainly a car is not worth dying over, but if there were a
> safe way of triggering a system it might be worth having.  Maybe a pressure
> (or lack of pressure) sensor in the seat AND a discrete switch, both of which
> must be triggered within 30 seconds of each other with the engine idling to
> activate the system?  More importantly, could I retire on the royalty income
> from this?
I kinda like the idea in Naked Gun 33 1/3 (if you don't know what I'm 
talking about, rent it, watch it)... VERY unnoticeable, VERY painful... 
oh, but if you do design a system, how about something like a keychain 
(that you don't put in the car, but simply carry on you, like a beeper, 
for instance) so that after being a safe distance, but still within 
viewing range of the car, you could kill it yourself? A safer idea, 
though requiring more engineering skills (and electroncs skills in todays 
world) would be a transmission disengager... Simply set the thing to, in 
say 3 minutes, go only in neutral (so as to not piss them off and break 
your park pins)... Or even better, sense when the car has come to a 
grinding halt, then let at it... They'd be sitting there revving the 
engine and not getting anywhere... of course, an officer will come over 
and "problem son?" and then you could reclaim your car...
 -Derek Cahill

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 06:09:23 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Re: 944 with 94,000 miles

Gary,

I had a 1985.5 (tear drop dash) that ran strong until I sold it with 
186,000 miles on the odometer.  I think it should go another 75k given 
the same care I gave it.

I bought the car with 50k miles on it in 1988 and sold it in 1995.  The 
key to it doing so well?  Maybe I just got a good one - but here is what 
I did to maintain it:
  - Used Mobil One since I bought it.
  - Changed oil/filter every 3k-4k miles.
  - Replaced timing belts every 15k miles.
  - Bought shop manuals, educated myself, and if something didn't seem
    right about the car - I fixed it - immediately.
Replacing the timing belts isn't cheap - but I think it added a lot 
to the life of my engine. Besides replacing clutch, brake pads, wiper 
blades, etc .- I fixed major items as needed.  In fact - I have a detailed 
list of what I replaced and when that I will post.  It may give some 
idea of what may be next to go on your car.  (The list is at work).

The only major engine problem I had was right when I bought the car.  The 
water pump went out and I didn't stop the car quick enough.  The head 
warped and required resurfacing.  Other than that, the other major 
component replacements were: oil cooler, timing belts & clutch.

Good luck with your car!
Scott
(scokelly@netcom.com)
90 911 C4

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 10:04:42 -0400 (EDT)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: Thanks Auto Atlanta

Hi all,

I wanted to thank Auto Atlanta in public for some help and money savings 
this week.

Our 914 with Bursch Muffler got very loud at the track, and when it was
home I discovered that a vertical bracket on the muffler (for stiffness)
between muffler parts one on top of the other had lost its weld and there
was a nice square 1 inch hole in the muffler. The hole had the vertical
piece sitting on top of it, but lots of air was seeping through.Given that
my usual muffler experience in life was that once you start to get holes
you change mufflers, I called A.A. for advice on getting a new muffler.

They told me that Bursch's last a long time. I told them that mine had 
this problem. They refused to sell me a new one: "Get it welded locally; 
if you cannot find someone to weld it for cheap, mail it to us, we'll do 
it free.Do not buy a new one" is what they said.

I had it welded at my local friendly auto place..$25. Guy there told me 
that the muffler itself was in fine shape. No air is now leaking. Car is 
as quiet (or more) than since we've owned it.

thanks Auto Atlanta! My next purchase is from you!

Mark

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 95 08:43:23 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; antitheft devices and carjacking

>>Regarding dashboard engine kill/fuel cutoff switches, Wayne wrote:

>> Does anyone know of a small
>> Porsche rocker type switch that is a toggle mechanism, or has anyone
>> modified one of the existing switches to be a toggle?
  (snip)

>Can any of you legal types comment further on the liability issue here?
>It sounds crazy enough to be true, but on the other hand the joint
>probability of (carjack * out-of-gas-accident * lawsuit) seems pretty
>low... but what do I know?  Is this the whiplash of the 90s?

>-Ed Mellinger

    The earlier statement that the car is going to still work for 2-3 minutes
  after the fuel pump is cutoff is silly; the car will die immediately if the
  fuel pump is cut off (okay, for fuel injected cars only...or any Porsche
  since '73...).  As far as any other liability issue when a thief
  takes your car....neither Juries nor Judges have a lot of patience with 
  thieves. But everyone has sympathy with a true victim.

     As far as getting sued if your car stalls and you impede traffic...I'd be
  in debtors prison if that was ever worthy of a suit...

     As far as kill switches that prevent the car from being started...someone
  a few months ago nixed the idea of wiring the fuel pump, etc, in favor of
  interrupting the wire to the solenoid. Sure, someone might push start the
  car if they were guessing well but the advantage is that you don't have
  sustained amounts of current to maintain. Also, it can't break down in the  
  middle of a corner or as you are driving; the worst that can happen is you
  can't start the car.

      I think imagining hidden switches that we'd somehow have the presence
  of mind to trigger when a gun is popped in our face is stretching the
  coolness of our nerve....if someone tries to hijack my car, my "plan" is to
  let them in, buckle them up, give them gas money and push the car off....

         -Lee A. (take my wife...Please !)

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 95 18:24:00 PDT
From: "Thiger Jonas, Netsupport" <jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se>
Subject: Re: Chips for Porsches

Have followed the discussions about chips with interest, since I'm in need 
for more power in my '87 944 (VW's and other bug's getting closer...).
My question to anyone with experience is:

What about the third-party headers and camshafts? Will these make an 
improvement, what manufacturer is the best, and what about
combinations of headers, cams and chips, has anyone tried that?

The std 944 has a very flat torque curve, to me it looks like it should be 
possible to rise mid/hi-end torque quite easily by changing the cam, and 
that would be better use of money than chip-only tuning.

The moderate 163hp from 2,5 ltr (Swedish specs) indicates a few 
sleeping stallions. In fact it's exactly the same hp/vol ratio as my Audi
80 GTE (U.S 4000 series) with 112hp K-jetronic engine, which is easily
tuned to 130-150 hp.

Jonas Thiger (jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se)
Sweden

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 95 09:30:44 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Swap Meet and 914 5-bolt conversions


1st Item:

For those of you in the San francisco area, Automotion is having their
annual Swap-Meet on Sunday, April 30. 

Event opens at about 6:30 am for those wishing to have a stall. Lots
of goodies and Automotion will have quite a few items on sale, both 
regular and close-outs.

This is the first Porsche-only swap-meet of the year.

2nd item:

Five bolt conversions are safe and reliable. The rear flanges are of 
very high quality steel, forged. Even the later flanges can be drilled
and are reliable. BUT, only have a machinst with the proper equipment
do the job. The 914/4 rotors can also be re-drilled and used, to save
other hassles.

The fronts. I recommend going to the 914/6-911 setup. The biggest reason
isn't brakes, as the 914 2.0 and 914/6 have the same size pads. The
biggest reason is the increase of static front track, over 1 inch. This 
improves turn-in and improves front-end geometry. The all-alloy front
brace and complete suspension off an '89 and earlier 911 bolts right in.

Jim Pasha

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 95 09:40:30 pst
From: "GFORCE" <GFORCE@cccpp.com>
Subject: Re[2]: Antitheft Switches



Getting back to the p-car related content::

So, instead of a kill switch, how about a time delay tripping of the alarm; 
the alarm horn sounds and the lights start flashing but the car doesn't
    die (perhaps until the car comes to a stop)? In fact, my alarm system (a 
    Code alarm) remote control has a "panic" button that sets the alarm off 
    immediately. 
    
This is exactly what my alarm does, I have a Clifford 800 with Blackjax, the 
anti car jacking system is activated everytime you start the car and works as 
follows; 

1) Everytime you start the car, you have to enter a secret code using the "Plain
view" alarm switch.  Otherwise the alarm trips in about 30 secs and as soon as 
your car is going slower then 5 mph, the alarm kills the car.

2) If you open either door while the car is running, the alarm is resets and you
have enter your code again, otherwise the alarm trips as describe above.

Great system, since it's always on, you won't have to think about flicking any 
hidden switches while there's a gun pointed at your head....also, finding the 
code switch (hence plain view) won't do anything since they need your secret 
code.

Took me about a week to get used to entering the code when I start the car, 
twice I forgot and had the stero turned up loud so I didn't hear the warning 
beeps from the alarm and my car died, pretty embarassing in the middle of the 
street, now it's second nature.

Another cool thing with this system is that even if someone were to steal my car
keys with the alarm remote, they couldn't drive away with my car (at least not 
very far).

G.E.

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 12:59:24 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: 89 951 Oil change story

Hi John,

Thanks for your response (on 4/5), sorry its taken me so long to get back to
you. Your were dead on with the water pump - 8 hours, and I did change the
belts. 

I just finished changing the oil (Mobil 1 Synthetic) on the car, and boy, did
I make a mess! After putting the car on jackstands, I saw that there is a
shield that covers almost the entire bottom of the car. I saw that I could
use a wrench, and take out the drain plug without removing the shield. Then I
realized that oil would pour onto the shield, and leak out without ending up
in my drain pan. I was going to remove the shield, when one of my friends
decided that he could make a little plastic piece that would make the oil
drain down, into the pan, instead of gushing over the cover. While he was maki
ng the guard (out of an orange juice bottle) I loosened the drain plug, and
then got out from under the car to get my filter wrench. When  I came back,
he was under the car, yelling for help. He had touched the drain plug, and it
fell out, and went some where. Oil is not pouring everywhere, and his
plactive guard is not working. Oil is going on top of the shield, gushing
onto my driveway, and making a very big mess. I go running into the garage
and grab as many pieces of cardboard that I can find. By this time almost all
of the oil is out of the car, and there is not too much else to do but watch
the oil run down my driveway. After removing the filter, finding and
installing the drain plug, adding the oil, and moving the car (being very
careful not to get oil onto the rear wheels, I get to spend the next hour
putting kitty litter on the oil spots, grinding it into the oil spots, and
then sweeping it up. The driveway still looks like sh*t. Does anyone know
what I can use to remove oil spots (slicks) from the driveway?

The moral of the story is to remove the shield next time (or have Jiffy Lube
do it) the next time I change the oil.

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 13:03:04 +0600
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: 89 951 Oil change story

>The driveway still looks like sh*t. Does anyone know what I can use to 
remove oil >spots (slicks) from the driveway?
>
>Barry Lenoble
>BLenoble@aol.com
>89 944 Turbo, Alpine White


They have specialized cleaners for removing oil stains from concrete 
available at the local auto parts store.  Fine saw-dust left on the spot 
will absorb much of the stain, but I doubt it will do much more than the 
kitty-litter you used.  I have also used heavy DAWN dish soap with lots of 
scrubbing and high pressure water to lighten small spots.  It doesn't get it 
all, but a few passes should get most of it.  Good Luck.

Andy


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 10:24:44 -0600
From: stephenk@synopsys.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: 914 suspension

Stan wrote:

>Or there is a very remote chance that you really have overexceeded the 
>design limits of the tub.

This is somewhat less than a "remote" possibility.  My 914 has a largish,
rather ugly, hole torn in the left front inner fender where the sway bar
used to be mounted.  Apparently, some previous owner had installed a very
stiff sway bar and then took the car racing.  Our guess is that under severe
cornering stress or perhaps a hard bump, the sheet metal around the sway bar
just gave way.  It's tough to say actually happened and the PO is long since
lost to us.  Suffice it to say that cornering forces have to be absorbed
somewhere in the rolling chassis or the chassis will fail.  Which leads to
an interesting question.  What are the rules of thumb that suspension
designers use when considering modifications to an existing design?

Stph
- --------------------------------
Stephen Keller
'73 914 2.0L
stephenk@synopsys.com

You don't have to remove the entire shield.  The shield is two

takes 6 bolts.  Btw, the mechanic at our local dealership told
me to just leave off the back part of the shield.  I'd love to 
hear other opinions on this.

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 14:44:12 -0500
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re: antitheft devices and carjacking

I've noticed part of one of my messages included in this thread recently, but
the reference has been taken somewhat out of context.

> Regarding dashboard engine kill/fuel cutoff switches, Wayne wrote:

>> Does anyone know of a small
>> Porsche rocker type switch that is a toggle mechanism, or has anyone
>> modified one of the existing switches to be a toggle?

This has been referenced as part of the anti-carjacking thread .....

Anyway, I don't pretend to have enough cool to flick a switch during a
carjacking no matter how accessable it is.  I intend to let them have the
car and simply rely on the statistics that carjackings are less common than
the old fashioned parking lot thefts. ...  My original purpose was using a
stock / dash mounted switch as a cleverly "hidden" kill switch for
"anti-theft" purposes (i.e. evening parking downtown, or long term parking at
the airport).  It seems that most car thiefs know the standard wiring of most
common "advanced" car alarm systems, but may be stumped (just long enough) by
the low-tech but "non-standard" home brews.

87 944, many new parts, runs excellent, $8000
84 944 black, runs / looks great - $5600

It must be a good week for Porsche sales!

From these, and other prices I have seen, 12.5 for a 100K car is too high. Do
you have the maintenance history? When was the last timing belt, clutch,
water pump, head gasket, motor mount, etc. done? If all of these items have
been replaced recently, then the price is OK. Otherwise, be prepared for a
few $1000 in service.

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 14:30:41 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Main Bearings

        So, does anyone want to buy a reeeealy expensive piece of
scrap metal?
        The flywheel endplay was a tad excessive.  In fact, it moved
enough that I thought there weren't any shims in.  Well, there were.
All three.  And it still had 0.065" of endplay (we *like* the dial
indicator!!!).  So Mr. Ellsworth (aka Mr. Machinist) popped off the
seal, took the shims out, and looked at the thrust bearing.  There
more or less wasn't one.  That is, there *was* one, but the shoulder
part of it was just about worn away.  He tells me (and I believe him)
that 1) it won't run for very long in this condition--as Stan says,
"see 'Welding, Friction'".  2) It requires taking the crankcase apart,
and 3) something has to be done with/to the bearing.
        Several questions arise :
        Does anyone make "oversize" bearings (Mr. Machinist's words)
so that we can get one that will fit?
        Does anyone have a 2.0L 914 motor (I have the "externals",
like induction, shrouding, etc.) that they'll loan me through Parade?
I still want to drive up to Portland and drive *IN* Portland.
        Does anyone know if Parade will give me my money back if my
car ist Ja Todt?
        Does anyone have a 2.0L long/short block for sale?
        Or, alternately, does anyone wanna buy a 914 collection and
then shoot me?     8P

        Well, I guess it's time for a loan from the Bank of Mom and
(Step-) Dad.  I wonder if they'll want me to put a sponsor decal on
the car?   ;)

        BTW, donations, advice, and sympathy will *all* be gratefully
accepted.  (Who needs a savings account, anyway!)

- --DD

Dave Darling, owner of two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Barry,
	One thing to try is to squirt Gunk or Jizer or such like on the 
driveway, and let it soak or brush in with a stiff broom.  Then hose residue 
away.  One other method is to actually light the spill using gasoline, however 
this activity is not without risk...
	I'd say Gunk it and then get the Chlorox out and wash the whole thing 
down.  If you spend some time doing it now, even though it'll look like shit for 
a while, it should improve with time.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 15:39:01 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sanjay Nasta <sanjay@bga.com>
Subject: 944S Cam Chain Tensioner Failure:  Discussion

Hi,
   As some of you may know the Cam Chain Tensioner on my '87 944S failed. 
This is not a normal maintenance part, in fact it isn't even on Porsche's
checklist.  The cost of this failure is approximately $3000 (donations
welcome <grin>).  John Dwyer at Balcones European Motors (did I do good on
the credit there) is basically going to start checking the tensioner for
cracking every 30,000 miles (when he recommends that the timing belt be
changed).  To check it you have to basically pop open the valve cover...its
basically the part that is tensioning the chain that drives the two cams. 
His advice is basically check the plastic (yes plastic) part of it for
cracking.  What happens is that the plastic part breaks off...jams the
chain...strips the timing belt...bends lotsa valves.  The tensioner costs
$300 to replace...heck of a lot cheaper to replace than all the valves. 
Anyway, if anyone else has any experience with this (George @ 944 Ecology
says he's seen this happening more and more....so..)  drop me a note.  

Also, got kinda ticked at some sloppy repair work done by a previous shop. 
When they took the water pump off...there was one stud missing...someone had
broken off a hardened drill bit in there..and not bothered to get it out
(cost me damn near $150 to get it out).  John said if you are going to work
on the silly thing yourself (as I usually do), be extremely careful removing
the bolts/studs on the bottom half of the water pump since they get corroded
because any coolant that leaks ends up pooling @ the bottom bolts.  Obvious
little hint but it might save someone some $$$.  BTW this might not be
politically correct but the last shop that touched the water pump was DC
Racing in Irving, TX....the name on the invoice was Donnie....not saying it
was there fault....but......Guess I better get back to work and sell some
training so I can afford this...

Sanjay@bga.com

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 14:10:24 -0700
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: RE: 70-71T's that Backfire

> Tom, I have a 1971 911T with the same problem. Same Zenith Carbs.
> Mine has been backfiring since I bought it 2 years ago. I took it into my
>mechanic and he was able to reduce the backfiring. Now it sounds mostly like
>farts with a few loud pops every once in a while.
> It runs stongly but is kind of embarassing. Other than replacing the
> Zeniths with Webers($$$$$$) I don't know what to do. Does anyone else
> have any ideas??
>
>      Please help us not look so bad.

My 71T (with Zeniths) tended to backfire when decelerating last year.
The fix did not involve the carbs.  It was ignition related and I
believe it to have been valve adjustment related.  The Zeniths were
rebuilt by the previous owner and were/are in good shape.

After a complete tune and valve adjustment my problem went away.

Incidently, FWIW, now that it's been awhile and I'm not so steamed
about it, my valves were WAY too tight on at least 3 cylinders.
The last place the valves had been touched was the first place I took
it after I bought it, namely HIGH PERFORMANCE HOUSE in Redwood City.

1 year later I took it to Tony Heyer who told me how seriously out
of adjustment it was and there was a strong possibility of burned valves.
(erratic compression, etc.)  Over the last year I had Tony do repeated
valve adjustments to allow carbon to burn off.  1 year later, the compression
has stablized and all is well.  Whew!!

I would have been significantly out of luck if the valves had
burned.  HP HOUSE told me at the time they worked on it that the valves
had been very loose.  I joked and said, "Better than too tight, eh?"
and forgot about it until the next year.

Needless to say I have not been back to HP HOUSE and had grown weary of
them for other reasons before this happened.

This is not a Public Service Announcement or specific FLAME against those
guys as I know a lot of people like them (especially the 914 community).
It's just an experience I had that has made me ever-so-cautious.  YMMV.

Vol

- --

Subject: Re: 914's

>Hi Christopher,
>
>I noticed your questions about a distributor for your car and see that you 
are going for the big displacement 4 in your car. I have the same intentions 
for my car ('76 2.0L) but have not decided on the specifics, stroke, bore, 
etc. Are you having one of these VW shops or possibly FAT Performance do 
your work or are you doing it yourself?
>
>Also, I've tried to find someone that's done this before and can give me 
some performance numbers, i.e., 2.6L = ~160hp = 0-60/6.5 sec.... I'm looking 
for 0-60 times in the 6 sec range (911 numbers) and don't know what size 
engine to shoot for with an otherwise stock car; I don't want to spend a lot 
of money and find out that I should have got the 6 anyway. If you have some 
experience in this area I'd sure like to know.
>
>Thanks and keep me informed of your results,
>Craig
>'76 914 restoration project (anxious to put gas in it instead of money)
>
>
This is extremely vague territory. I decided to go the way I went after 
looking at 1) Stock rebuild 2) Stock rebuild w/euro p&c 3) big bore rebuild 
w/carbs 4) big bore rebuild w/programmable fuel injection.

Each version has it pros and cons, and only you know what you're willing to 
sacrifice (and you *will* sacrifice things) and what you want to gain.

I decided that I was willing to sacrifice money, gas mileage, durability and 
some streetability in exchange for power. That said, my engine has extra 
head studs, tons of oil cooling, dowels in the flywheel and the best parts I 
could find in an effort to have the thing stay together long enough for me 
to have some fun with it. I am also building a back-up 2.0 injected engine 
to have when the 2.7 blows up.

So, if you're still thinking about it, send me some more specifics (ie, what 
are you considering) and I tell you what I found out. I am doing most of the 
work myself, though, at this stage that consists mainly of exercising my 
credit card and driving parts to various machine shops.

As far as performance goes, you never really know till you do it, so I'll 
tell you when mine's done. I gather that you should get a respectable 160 hp 
or so from a reasonably well done 2.6. That, incidentally, puts you in the 
same weight/hp range as a 951. Intriuging, yes?

Talk to you later.

__________________________________________________________________________
Christopher Paine                         "Technology is like a steamroller,
Metropolis Pictures, Director              if you're not on it, you become
Editor,Der Auspuff,Rennsport Region PCA    part of the road"

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 15:42:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: 914 Suspension bushings and other assorted questions...

Hi All,

	Well, now that I have -almost- fully replaced the suspension on my
914, the more subtle problems are making themselves more noticable. I'm
getting a very distinct -click- from my left rear quater during load
transitions. I have traced this to a toasted inner trailing arm bushing.
So, I have a question to all those who have attempted such a replacement.
Seeing as how the Haynes manual recomends replacing the entire trailing arm
, I plan on replacing only the bushings. What are the best ways to go about
extracting the old bushings and installing the poly bushings. I thought I'd
try soaking the bushings in something like gasoline for a day or so to
loosen up the rubber, and then use whatever tools I have at my disposal to
extract it. Installing the new ones are what I'm most curious about. Any
suggestions? I've been told that there's alot of shaving and shaping to get
them to fit right. Is it usefull to have the engine out of the way to do
the whole job? I plan on getting a new high volume oil pump at the
automotion swap meet this weekend along with a list of other oil system
related goodies to go with my new suspension bushings. And as long as the
engine is coming out at some point, I might as well do it all at the same
time. Heh! That's what I said last winter and the engine stayed on my
garage floor for a month and a half!

	Second question, I plan on buying a 2.0L in the future and
gradually rebuild it over the course of many months. Are there any special
tools that I need? And having never done a rebuild before, what kind of
parts list am I looking at for the bottom end (the heads'll be given to
someone else). And what can a competent shade tree mechanic accomplish, and
 -not- accomplish. I know this is vague. Assume this is for a stock motor.
Actually, it's for an SCCA CSP autoxer. So any goody ideas would be welcome
too, not that I can use them, but I'd like know what -could- be done if I
were building this for a different class.

Many Thanks,
	Josh

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 17:57:28 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914's

>I decided that I was willing to sacrifice money, gas mileage, durability and
>some streetability in exchange for power. That said, my engine has extra
>head studs, tons of oil cooling, dowels in the flywheel and the best parts I
>could find in an effort to have the thing stay together long enough for me
>to have some fun with it. I am also building a back-up 2.0 injected engine
>to have when the 2.7 blows up.

        I talked to a gentleman at the last (and first!) LPR autocross who
had at one point put a 2.4 in his car.  It didn't last very long (10k mi?
20k?) he told me because the case flexed (!) enough for the distributor
drive shaft to bind, which ate the distributor drive gears, which spewed
metal shavings into the case, which...  He thought that it probably would
have been OK if he'd had it "shuffle pinned".
        I have also heard that fans are a weak point in high-power high-
RPM engines.  If you're building one of these, you might talk to people
about somehow beefing up the way the fan (fan hub) is held onto the crank.
        Just things to think about when you build the high-$$$, high-dis-
placement, high-power engine.

- --DD

Dave Darling, owner of two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Yet another possibility......

The hole that was cut for the radiator (bottom of front trunk) was cut
too big, or wrong.

I learned a long time ago that the Germans never put any *extra* metal
in their cars, so any modification that involves cutting or removing
chassis panels is a "bad idea".

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 21:01:38 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: RE: '86 944T price and hot 928's

'86 944T w/ 100k miles for $12.5k 
 
Too much-Most similar cars in typical condition (worn seats, incomplete
history, not all power accessories working, lots of stone chips, bent phone
dial wheels, scraped chin spoiler) sell for less than $10K at the dealer.
$12.5K could buy a low mile (under 20k), or an accident-free concours
winner, or a car with very, very desirable options or upgrades (sport
seats, ltd slip, magnesium wheels, sunroof and pwr window delete, etc.) A
friend was offered $6.5k and $8.5k from dealers for his like-new 62k mile
'86 944T. It is stock, has a history since 20k miles, new clutch, water
pump, motor mounts, all 16 water hoses, belts and a rebuilt tranny in the
last 6 months. The tranny was done due to a slow 1-2 synchro. The rest was
preventative maintenance based on turning 60k miles or having the tranny
out.. All work done at the dealer or at Porsche-only independants. Phone
dials and tires are perfect. No dings. Manifold doesn't leak. Air filter
and cassette box aren't cracked. Sunroof works. Engine strong. Drivers seat
looks like it has 5k miles of wear. Garaged and covered. On the downside,
it has no sport options and a trained eye can spot minor bodywork (new
paint, but the panel wasn't replaced). The nose has been sprayed twice for
stone chips. Never broken down, never towed. Muffler not scratched or
rusted. Fog lights not cracked. He accepted the $8.5k. Figured he might get
$10k from a private buyer, but didn't want the hassle. 
 
Hot 928's-Anyone remember the RST ads in Excellence which promised a 1000hp
928. I think that they sold a video. Always wondered if the car existed.
Any Porschephiles buy it? It looks like the one in the new ad for 928
International. 
- -- 
Triet Le

switch at the radiator with a multimeter and found that the contacts are 
stuck closed even when cool, indicating the switch is faulty.

The switch I picked up from my parts guy says, 85 deg (term 1), 93 deg (t 2)

for the Turbo. My '86 944 is not a Turbo, so should I be using the cooler 
one instead? The dealer (as always) is ignorant and seems only to carry 
the 92/102 version.
 
I'd prefer the cooler one, but I don't want to mess with the wrong one if 
that's not what the Porsche engineers had intended.

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 22:20:46 -0400
From: Jrhetten@aol.com
Subject: '91 911 C-2 oil leak repair

During the 30,000 mile service at Paramount Motors, Hickory, NC in November a
"crankshaft seal leak' was found.  Paramount performed the $700 repair of the
seal about 500 miles and several weeks later.  All but $50 was covered by the
extended warranty by Quaker.....but the oil smell remained.   

During the last service, 4 months and 1200 miles later, Hendricks Porsche,
Charlotte, NC states the crankshaft seal is still leaking PLUS two cylinder
seals.    Gasket and seals  are covered by  Quaker.  They are balking at the
estimated $7,800 repair cost..(Not a surprise).   The proposed solution is to
remove the manifold, send to Porsche, (Nevada)  to be retooled, crosshatched
for better sealing, install new pistons etc.

The cranshaft seal is dripping, the cylinders are just "weeping" and weeping
is not covered per Quaker, and if it were, the cost of the upgraded parts
would not be covered, only the original parts (which are not available from
Porsche since they have been upgraded.)

Any facts to help build the case for a total rebuild? other alternatives?

Thanks much,

Jim Hettenhaus
Charlotte, NC

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 23:15:14 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: interior lights

Hi Dave.

I'm reading mail from yesterday and someone may have already answered your
question.  Dave wrote:
>I have a '77 911S. According to the owner's manual, the interior lights 
>have a three positon switch: off, on with door open, and on. 2 of the 3 
>positions work but I cannot switch on the light in the 3rd position when 
>the door is closed. I looked at the switch/light and cannot see how it 
>could work. There appears to be only one switch position where power gets to

>the light bulb. Am I missing something?

Power (+12 volts) is on the light switch at all times on one side of the
bulb.  The other end picks up a ground (earth) to turn the light on.  In one
position it never picks up ground (off all the time), in the second it picks
up a ground from the door switch when the door is open, and in the third , it
picks up a ground from the frame of the switch (on all the time).  Most
likely if the light doesn't come on when the door is opened, the fault lies
with the switch in the door jamb having some corrosion on the contacts.  I
believe the switch unscrews and can be easily removed to clean the contacts.

Hope this helps. (How are you Dave? Are you the same Dave from last
September's 911 engine rebuild class at Jerry Wood's shop?)

Jim Williams (JWilli 911@aol.com)
