------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 95 23:57:04 -0700
From: Bittmans <bittman@fct.com>
Subject: '85 924 wheel vibration

Peter,

Since your 924 has the early steel front a-arms one thing you might  
check is the condition of the bushing.  I had the rear rubber
bushing on the right side fail due to heat problems caused by it's  
proximity to the exhaust system.  Mine actually detached from the
a-arm and was gone by the time I noticed it (it didn't take long :-)  
).  These need to be pressed on so they should be replaced by a
mechanic.

Also, you should check for the following:  a-arm ball-joint play,
wheel balance and trueness and front wheel bearing play.  A quick
check would be to jack up both sides of the front of your car and
try to shake the wheel in all directions, then spin the wheel to see  
if it is dented.

Veel geluk toegewenst met uw porsche en met de snelheidslimiet in
holland.  ok tot ziens.

Chuck Bittman
'80 924 (135K+ mile) for track and autocross.

P.S. I've converted my brakes to pre-85.5 944 vented discs, if you  
have any interest drop me a line.

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 01:18:41 -0400
From: FURNANS7@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911: engine backfires - HELP

Tom

If the engine is stock and carb jetting is stock, try the original muffler
and you will probably eliminate the backfire.  The Bursch may be scavenging
the exhaust before it can all be burned.  The engine needs the backpressure
the stock muffler provides.  Also, if you have a flat spot in the
acceleration, that may be cured as well.  This worked for me years ago with a
67 911s that had the same symptoms.

Good luck
Bob
Furnans7@aol.com

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 23:36:58 -0700
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: 944 fan thermostat

>My cooling fan does not always start at the same temperature.
>Sometimes the temp gauge gets up to and beyond the last tick
>mark before the fan kicks in (that is, the last tick mark before the
>solid region; this is on an '84). Other times it starts at just beyond
>the middle tick mark. Is this normal or do I have a flakey fan
>thermostat?

The one experience I had with the failure of a fan switch was not
gradual.  One day it worked, the next day it closed forever, draining
my battery.

I think (or very much hope) that the dash gauge indicates cylinder
head water temperature.  Since the fan switch is mounted in the
radiator, it is measuring the coolant temperature there.  It is
therefore easy to imagine scenarios in which the gauge readings and
fan operation might not be well correlated.  I would check the
thermostat (the one in the water pump, not the *switch* that runs the
fans) and bleed the system well before buying any new parts.

 -Milo
'86 951




------------------------------


Porschephiles #1357                         Thu Apr 27 11:15:32 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 00:36:35 -0700
From: paulm@kestrel.engr.sgi.com (Paul Mielke)
Subject: question on lug nuts

I'm having the Fuchs wheels on my 911SC refinished to the
stock black center paint scheme.  The original owner had
them polished out, but the look is just too pimped out
for my tastes.  I need to replace the wheel nuts with black
ones to complete the job.  My mechanic recommends sticking
with the factory nuts at $5.80 a pop.  I called Robert
Woods in LA (the folks with the showy full page ads about
wheels in Pano and Excellence).  They recommend an aftermarket
wheel nut that they sell for $3.50, claiming that it is better
finished than the factory nuts and fits just as well.

My mechanic showed me some used sample wheel nuts that he
had lying around and it was quite clear from inspecting them
that the particular aftermarket samples he had did not fit
as well as the factory ones.  You could clearly see from the
pattern of wear in the anodization that the aftermarket nuts
were making contact with the wheel in only a narrow band.
The used factory samples showed wear in a much wider area
all over the rounded end of the nut.  Given the comments
in the article in Pano this month about wheels, this argues
strongly in favor of sticking with the factory stuff.

But the question is whether all aftermarket wheel nuts
are necessarily ill fitting.  One would think that reproducing
the exact shape of the factory nut should be a relatively
straightforward engineering question.

So I guess it comes down to a question of whether I am
to trust the word of Robert Woods, Inc that there wheel
nuts are high quality and fit as well as the OEM versions.

Have any of you had experience with Robert Woods in general
or their aftermarket wheel nuts in particular and care to
share your comments?

Please reply directly to me rather than the list as a whole.
If anyone else is interested in the answer, drop me a line and
I'll send you the digest of the responses I get.

Thanks!


Paul Mielke (paulm@sgi.com)
Silicon Graphics, Inc.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 03:52:33 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 with worn thrust bearing

Re: Worn Thrust Bearing in 914
    Yes, you WILL have to take the engine apart! The usual reason for a badly
worn thrust surface on the #1 Flywheel Main Bearing is a worn case, causing
 the bearing to lose its "crush".  Like virginity, once lost, the crush will
not return unless you Align Bore the case. If you're very lucky and have led
a good life, only the bearing  will be damaged. If you have sinned too much,
the thrust surface of the CASE will be worn too, in which situation you have
a more serious problem. Then, you must find a 914 Flywheel Main Bearing with
an "oversize" thrust, cut the case to clean it, and cut the oversize thrust
bearing to fit. OR you can custom-machine a piece of aluminum to fit the case
to take up the slop so that a new bearing (without an oversize thrust) will
work.
     We';ve done both of these fixes. The better  solution is the oversize
thrust Main Bearing, if available.
    You'd better check the other bearing webs of the case to see if the
 unrestrained crank had hit them too! (Though usually an align bore takes
care of those problems  too.) In a 356/912 when this happens, the "tangs" of
the Middle Main Bearings of the S-90/356C/SC/912 55mm crank will break out
part of the case.

Good Luck.
KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 09:37:57 +0100

| some of the seams an are pretty trashed.  I'd like to keep the original 
| pattern, cost permitting.  Will I have to go to Porsche for the material

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 08:29:19 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: fuel injection v. carbs - tuned intakes


Attempting to become my own car expert, I'm reading Probst's
book on Bosch fuel injection systems.  I was surprised to learn that
my former 1985 Tempo with Ford's EEC-IV was more sophisticated than 
my 1984 928S (L-Jetronic).

The book asserts that as an advantage over carbeurators, fuel 
injection allows the use of tuned intake runners.  I don't understand 
why they can't be used on carbeurated engines.  Any thoughts?

Also, just how are tuned intake and exhaust manifolds designed?  I
understand that the operation of the pistons and valves creates
pressure waves, but what is the design goal when engineering manifolds?

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 08:44:03 EDT
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: 944S Cam Chain Tensioner Failure:  Discussion

>
>Hi,
>   As some of you may know the Cam Chain Tensioner on my '87 944S failed. 
>This is not a normal maintenance part, in fact it isn't even on Porsche's
>checklist.  The cost of this failure is approximately $3000 (donations
>welcome <grin>).  John Dwyer at Balcones European Motors (did I do good on
>the credit there) is basically going to start checking the tensioner for
>cracking every 30,000 miles (when he recommends that the timing belt be
>changed).  To check it you have to basically pop open the valve cover...its
>basically the part that is tensioning the chain that drives the two cams. 
>His advice is basically check the plastic (yes plastic) part of it for
>cracking.  What happens is that the plastic part breaks off...jams the
>chain...strips the timing belt...bends lotsa valves.  The tensioner costs
>$300 to replace...heck of a lot cheaper to replace than all the valves. 
>Anyway, if anyone else has any experience with this (George @ 944 Ecology
>says he's seen this happening more and more....so..)  drop me a note.  

Since I have an 87 944S, and I don't want to spend $3000, I am quite
interested in this. Is the message to inspect the plastic part of the
"between the cams" tensioner regularly (how regularly? is that what he
recommends every 30K miles?), or to simply replace the whole tensioner
regularly? If I want to go in and browse, do I need to use a new cam cover
gasket each time (I assume)?  What does that mean it costs for each look?
I'm a bit concerned that looking every 30,000 miles might be too infrequent
to catch a developing crack before it breaks off. BTW, will the crack that
represents impending doom be obvious, or where do I look? Depending on how
complicated the plastic part is, it might be interesting to see if making
a metal replacement is possible. Has Porsche fixed this on the 968 series,
with a part which might be backward retrofittable?

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 08:39:50 -0700
From: Bittmans <bittman@fct.com>
Subject: Re: Hey Chuck! How do you swap brakes?

Hi Jay,

Nice to hear from follow 924 drivers.

Ths brake swaps really is not too hard.  I did it myself part time  
in just a few days.  The parts are available from most of the auto  
dismantlers for about $500-$750.  But then you need to buy 5 bolt  
wheels.  The nice thing is that any 6 inch wide early 911 wheel will  
fit.  I used 6 & 7 x 16s's from a '85 Carrera and only had to make  
minor mods. in the rear. I'm at work now so I don't have my notes  
with me, but if your really interested I can give you all the part  
numbers you will need.  You should replace your master and booster  
to be complete.

As for other mods. I've put on MSDS tubular headers, a euro.  
primary muffler (though I still use the factory secondary), 210 lbs.  
springs in front, 25mm torsion bars in back, sport Koni's all  
around, 22mm/19mm sway bars, 6 point harness, harness bar and  
Performance Friction pads.

I've not put in a roll bar so I'm not Club Racing (yet) but I do  
participate in about 6-8 driver's ed. events a year.

Let me know if you a serious about doing the swap (because it's  
alot of typing) and I'll send you all the info.

Talk to you later...

Chuck Bittman '80 924

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 9:53:21 EDT
From: Paul Moruzzi <pmoruzzi@hpwarhw.an.hp.com>
Subject: 951 hard to shift when warm

Looking for list experience on this one,

the car; 1986 951 with about 84k mi clutch update at about 45k.

The simptoms;  Trans wont go into first and hard to get in the other
gears.  This first happened yesterday and when I got the car home I
jacked it up and checked the travel of the slave cylinder.  As near as I
could tell it had about .59" travel (I couldn't measure accuratly so it
may be off a bit).  This morning with the car cold I can shift with no
problem into any gear.  After about 3 mi (with a 10 min stop at daycare
engine off) I get gas and the simptom reappears.  After my 55mi commute
its clearly there lots of resistance to first gear (I never forced it
in) and significant bur managable resistance to second gear.

No sighns of external leakage anywhere (master cylinder or slave
cylinder) no signs of any leakage at the transmission, and after 55 mi
of highway driving the trans case is not hot.  Original slave and master
cylinders.

My guess is internal leakage in the slave cylinder when warm.  Anybody
confirm or deny this?  All help greatly appreciated.

TIA
PVM

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 09:19:33 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: 911: engine backfires - HELP

Bob Furans, discussing backfiring on carburated P-cars

>If the engine is stock and carb jetting is stock, try the original muffler
>and you will probably eliminate the backfire.  The Bursch may be scavenging
>the exhaust before it can all be burned.  The engine needs the backpressure
>the stock muffler provides.  Also, if you have a flat spot in the
>acceleration, that may be cured as well.  This worked for me years ago with a
>67 911s that had the same symptoms.
>
 My rebuild on my 66 is now 1100 miles old. I have done the second valve
adjustment on it and have noticed the same backfiring under deceleration.
I have taken 1 of the Webbers apart to clean and adjust, everything looked
good. I havent gotten the time to do the other one yet and I plan on 
recalibrating booth when done. Good advice on the muffler replacement. That 
is basicaly the only part that I haven't renewed on my car. I have noticed
that after recalibration, the backfiring does stop. I guess to to it
correctly I will need to go to my friends shop and use his gas analyzer.
Comments please!!!!

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org

Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 09:28:15 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Misc. 924 questions

> Also, does anyone know ways to modify the CIS system on an '80 924  
> to change the fuel mixture while retaining the CIS.  

Once you've done something to incrase the airflow, you *may* need to
do something to incrase the gasflow. Of course, you'll need some
chassis dyno time to see how this looks under load *FIRST*. Then
once you start making mods, you'll need more chassis dyno time...

There are two simple tricks: 1) larger injectors/higher base fuel
pressure, 2) rising rate regulator.

Larger injectors have an obvious advantage: they're larger, so flow more
gas. There may be special application injectors (I'd guess off-hand
the 931s, maybe the 924 Euro version, certainly the factory racing 
version) that you can use, or you can get them "adjusted" by Kinsler
or Marren Motorsport. Higher base fuel pressure accomplishes the same
thing without changing hardware. These modifications, while increasing
richness when you want it, also run richer *ALL* the time, which is
a huge problem on the street. 

Rising rate regulators are simply put the most effective modification 
you can make to L-jet or CIS motors to get more gas in cheapest. They
change the fuel presssure when you "get on it", which increases gas
flow through the injector. This also makes a better spray pattern
which may also improve combustion. I don't have the manufacturer info
of the top of my head for where you can get these, but they've been
discussed at length many times. See the archives.

Finally, you can use a secondary injection system, with a simgle pulsed
injector blowing gas into the main intake plenum under control of a
secondary controller that's looking at things like RPM, manifold pressure,
etc. This is also a fine solution but takes a bit of fabrication to make
it work.

Anyway, at some point you get into the problem of how stock does
it have to LOOK Like it is, but that's another set of engineering....

Stan


------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 09:36:34 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: fuel injection v. carbs - tuned intakes

> The book asserts that as an advantage over carbeurators, fuel 
> injection allows the use of tuned intake runners.  I don't understand 
> why they can't be used on carbeurated engines.  Any thoughts?

It's not that it can't be done (look at any early Ferrari, or the
higher performance versions of the 356 family, or early 911s), it's
that it can't be done *CHEAPLY*. Mass production requirements mean that
things have to be simple and cheap. One carb on a big cast iron manifold
is both. One EFI control setup on a nice tuned aluminium intake is not
much more complex, and "cheap" is relative when you consider the impact
of EPA and CAFE requirements. However, multithroat carbs with tuned 
air horns are *NOT* cheap under any possible interpretation.

> Also, just how are tuned intake and exhaust manifolds designed?  I
> understand that the operation of the pistons and valves creates
> pressure waves, but what is the design goal when engineering manifolds?

Colin Campbell, "The Scientific Design of Intake and Exhaust Systems"
is your friend. About 1971, its currently carried under the Robert Bentley
press, and I *think* you can get it from United German Precision in scenic
Pittstown NJ.

Stan

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 10:43:09 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: 944 Master Cylinder Leak


To the list:

The 951 hard to shift post reminded me of a problem a friend had and I wanted
to warn the list.  "87" 944S brake warning light was coming on to
warn of low fluid 
level.  Addition of fluid turned t he light off but only to light again in 
a couple of days.  No signs of leakage, but the clutch pedal height was 
erratic. 

The master cylinder was leaking inside the car and ruined the carpeting
before he identified the problem.

Subject: hydraulic clutch problems

I went to pick up my 944 from storage Saturday. Pushed in the clutch and it
went to the floor.  Master cylinder or slave cylinder right. Called our local
Motorstadt guru who is probably reading this suggested slave cylinder and had
an old one that might work, Rebuilt it(kit $36) put it in, bled it( pumped pedal
at least 15 times) still no pressure. Lots of air came out, but very little
fluid. Am I missing something or do I need a master cylinder? This thing is
awful to get out and the car is 43 miles from my house and even more from my
mechanic. A minimum of $125 flatbed costs. I would at least like to get it
home. The old slave cylinder looks and feels ok, but the fluid was very black.
Mechanic thinks it still has air. Sitting my help release some of that air or
it may need to be pressure bled.

Your advice will be appreciated.

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 10:54:19 -0500 (CDT)
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: C-88?

Derek wrote:
> mjt@adc.com wrote:
> > What split-up?  What old system?  Porsche is, and has always been, an
> > independent company.  The only association with VW-Audi (other than
> > design/engineering work which they also do for many other companies)
> > was the marketing agreement for a shared Porsche+Audi dealer network
> > here in the U.S.
> Actually, Porsche, Volkswagen, and Audi were all-in-one up until the
> mid-70s. Porsche, until they had a significant volume, was simply a subset
> of VW.
> 

Porsche was *never* a subset of VW.  Porsche is still a family owned
enterprise (the family owns *ALL* the voting shares of stock - the
other half of the stock is publicly traded, but non-voting).


History of Porsche - The Company

Source:
  "Ferry Porsche: Cars Are My Life", Ferry Porsche and Gunther Molter.


1931  Porsche GmbH, Stuttgart
      owners: Ferdinand Porsche
      purpose: design office for engines and motor vehicles

1932  Hochleistungs-Fahrzeug-Bau GmbH
      owners: Ferdinand Porsche
      purpose: construction and sale of racing and sports cars
               (Auto Union P-car until 1938, Mercedes W154 from 1938-194x)

1947  Porsche Konstruktionen GmbH, Gmund Austria
      owners: Ferry Porsche and Louise Piech
      purpose: technical design and consultation

1949  Porsche Salzburg
      owners: Anton Piech, Louise Piech, Ferry Porsche
      purpose: import, distribution, and customer service for VW Beetle
               in Austria

1950  Porsche KG, Stuttgart
      owners: Ferry Porsche
      purpose: design office and construction of sports cars (356, etc)
               (replaces Porsche GmbH which had legal/war related problems)

1964  Porsche KG takes over Reutter's coachbuilding activities.
      The remainder of Reutter becomes Recaro.

1969  VW-Porsche VG is created
      owners: 50% VW, 50% Porsche KG
      purpose: sales of VW, Audi, and Porsche automobiles.  914 to
               be sold as VW-Porsche in RoW, Porsche in USA.  Porsche+Audi
               dealer network created.
               Ferry Porsche writes, "Rumors had been spreading in connection
                 with the founding of the joint distribution company, to the
                 effect that VW and Porsche were about to merge.  That was
                 rubbish of course."

1972  Porsche AG
      owners: Ferry Porsche, Louise Piech, and their eight children each
              own 10% of the stock in the company
      purpose: holding company for Porsche KG, Porsche Salzburg, and
               VW-Porsche VG

1974  Porsche AG acquires VW's stake in VW-Porsche VG

1984  Porsche AG
      owners: one-third of the company's capital stock is made public in the
              form of non-voting shares.  another one-sixth of the stock is
              also converted to non-voting shares but made available only to
              the family members.

- -- 
mike
mjt@adc.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 11:00:17 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Misc. 924 questions

> Stan mentions a secondary injection system to inject into the main intake
> plenum, which sounds a lot like what the cold start injector already is.

But....

1) the cold start injector is designed for a different job, mainly being
   closed almost all the time and being able to just "hang out" without
   doing anything for extended periods. It is *NOT* designed as a duty-
   cycle injector


2) you'd needs speciaized electronics, or a very fast wrist, to switcht it
   on and off enough to keep it at the right rate for the enrichment
   you need.

3) you'll have a hard time quessing what that rate is without access to
   more control info.

But the kit.

Stan

------------------------------

      purpose: sales of VW, Audi, and Porsche automobiles.  914 to
               be sold as VW-Porsche in RoW, Porsche in USA.  Porsche+Audi
               dealer network created.
               Ferry Porsche writes, "Rumors had been spreading in connection
                 with the founding of the joint distribution company, to the
                 effect that VW and Porsche were about to merge.  That was
                 rubbish of course."

1972  Porsche AG
      owners: Ferry Porsche, Louise Piech, and their eight children each
              own 10% of the stock in the company
      purpose: holding company for Porsche KG, Porsche Salzburg, and
               VW-Porsche VG

      owners: one-third of the company's capital stock is made public in the
              form of non-voting shares.  another one-sixth of the stock is

Porschephiles #1358                         Thu Apr 27 14:39:00 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 09:00:17 PDT
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Misc. 924 questions

> Stan mentions a secondary injection system to inject into the main intake
> plenum, which sounds a lot like what the cold start injector already is.

But....

1) the cold start injector is designed for a different job, mainly being
   closed almost all the time and being able to just "hang out" without
   doing anything for extended periods. It is *NOT* designed as a duty-
   cycle injector


2) you'd needs speciaized electronics, or a very fast wrist, to switcht it
   on and off enough to keep it at the right rate for the enrichment
   you need.

3) you'll have a hard time quessing what that rate is without access to
   more control info.

But the kit.

Stan

I went to pick up my 944 from storage Saturday. Pushed in the clutch and it
went to the floor.  Master cylinder or slave cylinder right. Called our local

an old one that might work, Rebuilt it(kit $36) put it in, bled it( pumped pedal
at least 15 times) still no pressure. Lots of air came out, but very little
fluid. Am I missing something or do I need a master cylinder? This thing is
awful to get out and the car is 43 miles from my house and even more from my
mechanic. A minimum of $125 flatbed costs. I would at least like to get it
home. The old slave cylinder looks and feels ok, but the fluid was very black.

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 09:38:41 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: Oil Change Mess


I've had pretty fair success using Gunk engine cleaner to clean
driveway oil spills.  My theory is that the stuff is made to
dissolve oil and grease on engines, so why not on driveways?

They actually make driveway cleaner version.  Comes in a
non-aerosol can.  

Spray or pour it on.  Scrub with a brush.  Let stand for
5 minutes. Hose off.  Repeat about 50 times, or until
you can live with what's left.  (It'll still look bad,
but not like sh*t.)

Then wait a year for rain and sun to finish the job.  Since
rain is the controlling element, here in Seattle you only have
to wait 6 months.

 -Bob Spindel

P.S. Great story.  All of us have more than one just like it.  My last was removing the front cover from a 911 engine
to re-do the gasket.  I couldn't imagine that the natural
oil level in the crankcase was that high up.  It is...

Date:         Thu, 27 Apr 95 12:08:43 EDT
From: Archie <SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU>
Subject:      Double Vac Distributor

Fellow P-car aficionados, I am looking for some general information.
Last evening, I was looking at the vacuum hoses on my 1972 914-4 1.7 and
was surprised to discover that one of the vacuum ports on my distributor
was connected to the back of the air intake at the same location as the
oil breather hose.  The other vacuum port was attached to the front of the
air intake near the throttle body.  There is a second vacuum port on the
side of the air intake at the throttle body that had a hose attached
running to the distributor but not connected at the distributor.

The car ran fairly well with this configuration but I had a problem with
the idle.  Sometimes too high, 1200-1400 rpm, frequently 800-900rpm, and
when the car is at normal operating temperature, 250-300rpm.  The 250-300
rpm occurred when at normal operating temperature and driving in city
traffic.  That is, when going from traffic light to traffic light, the
rpm would drop very low or when starting the car when the engine is hot.

Questions:  1.  What effect would the vacuum conections to the distrubutor
  have with one to the throttle body intake per the manual and the other to
  the air intake with the oil breather hose?
            2.  Would the vacuum hoses so connected affect the rpm as in
  very low idle rpm at normal operating temperature?
            3.  What is the normal rpm when the engine is cold?
Many thanks.

Archie T. Smith
East Carolina University
Department of Sociology, Brewster A-412
Greenville, NC 27858 (919) 328-6147
Bitnet: SOASMITH@ECUVM1 Internet: SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 08:54:19 PDT
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: C-88?

Derek wrote:
> mjt@adc.com wrote:
> > What split-up?  What old system?  Porsche is, and has always been, an
> > independent company.  The only association with VW-Audi (other than
> > design/engineering work which they also do for many other companies)
> > was the marketing agreement for a shared Porsche+Audi dealer network
> > here in the U.S.
> Actually, Porsche, Volkswagen, and Audi were all-in-one up until the
> mid-70s. Porsche, until they had a significant volume, was simply a subset
> of VW.
> 

Porsche was *never* a subset of VW.  Porsche is still a family owned
enterprise (the family owns *ALL* the voting shares of stock - the
other half of the stock is publicly traded, but non-voting).


History of Porsche - The Company

Source:
  "Ferry Porsche: Cars Are My Life", Ferry Porsche and Gunther Molter.


1931  Porsche GmbH, Stuttgart
      owners: Ferdinand Porsche
      purpose: design office for engines and motor vehicles

1932  Hochleistungs-Fahrzeug-Bau GmbH
      owners: Ferdinand Porsche
      purpose: construction and sale of racing and sports cars
               (Auto Union P-car until 1938, Mercedes W154 from 1938-194x)

1947  Porsche Konstruktionen GmbH, Gmund Austria
      owners: Ferry Porsche and Louise Piech
      purpose: technical design and consultation

1949  Porsche Salzburg
      owners: Anton Piech, Louise Piech, Ferry Porsche
      purpose: import, distribution, and customer service for VW Beetle
               in Austria

1950  Porsche KG, Stuttgart
      owners: Ferry Porsche
      purpose: design office and construction of sports cars (356, etc)
               (replaces Porsche GmbH which had legal/war related problems)

1964  Porsche KG takes over Reutter's coachbuilding activities.
      The remainder of Reutter becomes Recaro.

1969  VW-Porsche VG is created
      owners: 50% VW, 50% Porsche KG
      purpose: sales of VW, Audi, and Porsche automobiles.  914 to
               be sold as VW-Porsche in RoW, Porsche in USA.  Porsche+Audi
               dealer network created.
               Ferry Porsche writes, "Rumors had been spreading in connection
                 with the founding of the joint distribution company, to the
                 effect that VW and Porsche were about to merge.  That was
                 rubbish of course."

1972  Porsche AG
      owners: Ferry Porsche, Louise Piech, and their eight children each
              own 10% of the stock in the company
      purpose: holding company for Porsche KG, Porsche Salzburg, and
               VW-Porsche VG

1974  Porsche AG acquires VW's stake in VW-Porsche VG

1984  Porsche AG
      owners: one-third of the company's capital stock is made public in the
              form of non-voting shares.  another one-sixth of the stock is
              also converted to non-voting shares but made available only to
              the family members.

- -- 
mike
mjt@adc.com

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 11:48:09 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: AutoMashin Endplay Tool

        After careful consideration, and attempting to use this
particular item, I would have to recommend against it.
        The problem was that the shank was not large enough to
allow me to pull the flywheel all the way out.  With the adjust-
ment screw on the "business" end backed all the way out, my fly-
wheel would hit the tool when I pulled on it.  The tool also
measured on the teeth of the flywheel, which does not sound like
the best way to go to me--since the teeth can be machined and
(if I remember the bit from the manual) are supposed to be
slightly beveled.
        Live and learn.

- --DD

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 12:25:03 EDT
From: dit@bach.jhuapl.edu (Daryl I. Tewell)
Subject: Re: Roof drain clogged!  Help!

 > Subject: Roof drain clogged!  Help!
 > 
 > Hi all
 >    I have an 86 944 and my drivers side sunroof drain that runs down the 
 > A piller seems to have something clogged in it, I hit it with compressed 
 > air and this did nothing. I tryed to snake it out but only got about 3 
 > inches down and hit something hard that seems to be lodged in it.
 > Any ideas?
 > Thanks in advance for any help
 > Regards 
 > Marc
 > 86 944
 > 88 GTI 16v 
 > 88 S-10 Blazer


I recently had the following symptoms in a 1986 928:

******** BEGIN IMPORTANT PART *********
 - water accumulation on floors (front and back) of left (driver's) side
  of car.  NOTE: In the front, the water was not as noticeable,
  because the foam padding beneath the carpet has an impermeable
  rubber backing that prevents any water below it from wetting the
  carpet.
******** END IMPORTANT PART *********

 - moisture on floor of passenger side and in rear compartment.  This
  may have been a result of condensation of water already in the car.

 - condensation on INSIDE of windows.  This is what really tipped
  me off to the leak.

 - water in the vent duct (yes, really!) of the driver's side door.


Finding the problem:

 - Using a garden hose with low water pressure, and parking the
  car at different slopes, I proceeded to find the leak.
  I first started low on the car, eliminating leaks from those places
  first.

 - With the car parked front-end lower than back, water flowing onto
  the CLOSED sunroof leaked to the floor via the left windshield
  pillar.  I saw the leak by opening the driver's side door and
  observing water drops from the juncture of the pillar molding and
  the dash pad.

******** BEGIN IMPORTANT PART *********
 - Repeating the test with the sunroof opened revealed that the left
  front sunroof drain hose was clogged.
******** END IMPORTANT PART *********


Fixing the problem:

 - Blowing compressed air through the hose did not free the blockage.

 - Stuffing various wires down the hose could not dislodge whatever
  was blocking it.

******** BEGIN IMPORTANT PART *********
 - Removing the left front wheel and plastic inner wheel well allowed me
  to see the hose where it came down from the inside of the windshield
  pillar.  The hose is white, about three-eighths of an inch in diameter.
  I followed it with my hand and found that the end was pinched against
  the inner fender by the vacuum (weird-looking) canister for the cruise
  control.
******** END IMPORTANT PART *********

 - I loosened the bolt holding the canister to the inner fender, freeing
  the drain hose.

 - As the hose is hard plastic, I could not reshape the pinched end, so
  I cut off about 1.5 inches.  I tested the hose for proper operation,
  then tightened the canister bolt, making sure that the drain hose was
  not pinched.


Final thoughts/Lessons learned:

 - This problem could have been caused by a careless mechanic, but I'll
  bet it existed since the car's date of production.

 - Given that the car was delivered some eight years before with this
  problem, it's amazing that this was not corrected earlier.

 - Although the gasket around the sunroof appears to fit snuggly, I
  realize now that it is not intended to prevent ALL water from
  leaking through. (Anyone disagree?) Some water WILL leak through, and
  should then be drained by the drain hoses at each corner of the
  sunroof opening.

 - In hindsight, the water path can be traced from the front left area
  of the sunroof opening, overflowing into the interior, flowing
  behind the windshield pillar molding, continuing to both the floor
  and the vent duct of the door.  From the floor at the driver's feet,
  the water flowed to the floor of the passenger behind the driver.
  Once inside the car, the water evaporated and condensed on other
  interior parts throughout the car.

 - Drying the wet interior was a problem in itself.  I just aired
  everything out for several weeks.  Anybody have experience with
  using desiccants for this?


Daryl Tewell
daryl_tewell@aplmail.jhuapl.edu

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 13:13:19 EDT

My 87 944 did not have the rear shield when I bought it.  Apparently 
a previous mechanic agreed with your dealership.

I don't think it would be a real problem to leave it off, as it
only covers the oil pan area.  The front shield, however, appears to
prevent rocks, gravel, etc. from getting on the Alt/AC and PS Pump belts.
That one should stay on.

the roads about once a year (S.Florida)  I usually keep the car 
in the garage when that happens, but we do get suprised...

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 13:26:43 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Re: hydraulic clutch problems

> Help philers!
> 
> I went to pick up my 944 from storage Saturday. Pushed in the clutch and it
> went to the floor.  Master cylinder or slave cylinder right. Called our local
> Motorstadt guru who is probably reading this suggested slave cylinder and had
> an old one that might work, Rebuilt it(kit $36) put it in, bled it( pumped pedal
> at least 15 times) still no pressure. Lots of air came out, but very little
> fluid. Am I missing something or do I need a master cylinder? This thing is
> awful to get out and the car is 43 miles from my house and even more from my
> mechanic. A minimum of $125 flatbed costs. I would at least like to get it
> home. The old slave cylinder looks and feels ok, but the fluid was very black.
> Mechanic thinks it still has air. Sitting my help release some of that air or
> it may need to be pressure bled.
> 
> Your advice will be appreciated.
> 
> David I. Johnson
> 
> 
Try elevating the rear of the car.  The problem is the position of the feed
line to the master cylinder.  It is at the front and top of the brake fluid 
resevoir and is easily uncovered to allow more air in the system.  If it is not
convenient to raise the rear of the car, try running some clear plastic 
tubing from the slave cylinder bleed petcock back up into the brake fluid
resevoir to make a loop and maintain a contstant fluid level.  I've done the
latter and it worked well.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 12:32:39 CDT
From: gregg@cyrix.com (Greg Grohoski)
Subject: 951 hard to shift when warm

I had a similar problem with my '88 951 last summer.
Occasionally at stop lights the car would not
go into 1st gear. The only way I could get it to 
move was to put it in 3rd or 5th, let the clutch out
slightly with a bit of gas to get the car
to move, then put it in 1st.

My mechanic diagnosed it as a bad clutch
slave cylinder and hydraulic hose.  He
replaced them and since then I haven't
had the problem.  (Hopefully it won't
recur). 

At least check the clutch hydraulics
(especially the hose) before ripping
into the clutch.  I'm assuming you
know how big of a job the clutch is.

greg

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 12:55:06 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 vacc lines/idle

>Last evening, I was looking at the vacuum hoses on my 1972 914-4 1.7 and
>was surprised to discover that one of the vacuum ports on my distributor
>was connected to the back of the air intake at the same location as the
>oil breather hose.  The other vacuum port was attached to the front of the
>air intake near the throttle body.  There is a second vacuum port on the
>side of the air intake at the throttle body that had a hose attached
>running to the distributor but not connected at the distributor.

        The two vaccuum lines are for the vaccuum advance and retard (for
the timing).  One of the ports expects to see pre-throttle vaccuum, the
other expects post-throttle vaccuum.  I am not sure that it matters a
*whole* lot which pre-throttle vacc you get, but I could be wrong.
        The proper setup for these lines (if the 72 1.7 follows the 74
2.0, which it sounds like it does) is for the two vacc lines coming from
the throttle body to go to the two ports on the distributor.  If you get
them on there swapped, you'll probably know when you try to drive it  ;)
The small line from the 'T' (actally kind of an 'L' + on mine) goes to the
deceleration valve which is down by the manifold pressure sensor below and
behind the battery on the RHS of the engine compartment.
        Vaccuum leaks can cause odd things to happen to your idle--but the
"typical" symptom for D-jet cars is a high idle.  Warm idle should be
somewhere around 1000 RPM (800-1000), with cold idle higher due to the aux
air regulator.
        If your car idles too low when warm (250 RPM?  Does it stall?) it
could be anything from just not being adjusted correctly (the idle screw
is on the throttle body) to a more serious problem, like funky old injec-
tors, to fuel starvation due to vapor-lock (or near-lock).  Also check the
head-temp sensor resistance.  It should vary from about 3 Kohms cold to
about 0-50 ohms hot.  ("Hot" being about 210 F or 100 C.)  The head temp
sensor is on the RHS in between the spark plugs in the head.
        Good luck!

- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 14:03:36 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@Symtec.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Curise Control Problems

In response to posts regarding erratic operation of the cruise
control on 944's of various vintage someone suggested lubrication
of the cable connected to the cruise control motor. One should
be careful about what is used to lubricate the cable because on
my '88 951 the cable part is covered in some kind of plastic. Use
of an oil-based lubricant will probably turn that into a sticky
mess pronto.

Doug Donsbach
dld@symtec.com
'88 951
'88 735i

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 13:18:10 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; fuel injection vs. carbs--tuned intakes

>Attempting to become my own car expert, I'm reading Probst's
>book on Bosch fuel injection systems...
  (snip)
>The book asserts that as an advantage over carbeurators, fuel
>injection allows the use of tuned intake runners.  I don't understand
>why they can't be used on carbeurated engines.  Any thoughts?
 (snip)
>Matt Carpenter

      Part of the distinction is between "wet" and "dry" manifolds.
You can get away with more on a fuel-injected (port injected, not
throttle body injected) motor since you don't care about the dynamics
of how the fuel goes thru the runner. Tuned-port runners can bend and
twist, an air-fuel mixture cannot; given a bend, the air will turn
left and the fuel go straight, ending up sticking on the wall. This causes
"sheeting" effects where blobs of fuel come off, not exactly an even,
 atomized mixture.

      Port fuel injection (like CIS) just squirts over the top of the hot
 intake valve, neatly creating a cloud that gets sucked in but doesn't have 
 to travel down an intake. That let designers "tune"  for the air only and
 don't have the same tradeoffs a carbureted manifold has...(i.e., conceivably
 you could stick a Holley 2bbl in place of the throttle body on a 911 CIS 
 intake, but it would run -baaaaddddlllyy-...kinda like those 914 Weber 
 conversions...)

      Probst also wrote a book for Ford fuel injections (same publisher)
  that is very good.  Pretty fascinating stuff...

          -Lee A.


------------------------------

Date: 27 Apr 1995 11:09:37 -0800
From: "Rodger Keesee" <Rodger.Keesee@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: RE-tuned intakes

I reply:
I hope you don't mind that I've copied to the list Andres, but the digest
seems moldy lately and I would hate to see all the interesting conversations 
take place off-line.  Besides, what's the use of getting flamed if it's not by
your friends?
Matt Carpenter says:

> Also, just how are tuned intake and exhaust manifolds designed?  I
> understand that the operation of the pistons and valves creates
> pressure waves, but what is the design goal when engineering manifolds?

Almost this exact same question was asked on the BMW list yesterday, my reply
was based on info gleened from various articles, but I will surely get the
book suggested by Stan. My original reply follows:

First a little primer: 
An engine is basically an air pump. The more air through it, the more power.
Air has mass. Air (like anything else) when in motion tends to stay in motion.
 

OK...When an intake valve opens it is true that the downstroke of the piston
draws the air into the cylinder, also, once the air begins moving into the
cylinder the air still in the intake runner pushes even more air into the
cylinder, because of the air's mass etc. This creates a kind of supercharging
effect and increases the efficiency of an engine. The ZR-1 Corvette and many
other highly efficient autos actually change the length of the intake runners
to maximize this effect.
Well, the opposite occurs at the exhaust.  The air traveling down the exhaust
actually has a suction effect on the cylinder and creates a kind of vacuum in
the cylinder.  This is the kind of technology referred to when a manufacturer
calls something "tuned intake runners" or "tuned exhaust". Thus there is a
fine line between too much restriction and not enough of this sucking effect.

Of course timing plays a large part in this discussion, which is why we have
VANOS and VTEC and VARIOCAM and all the other "V" stuff. It also explains why
what works good at one rpm is not so good at another. (i.e. a muffler)

Rodger

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 14:37:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Double Vac Distributor

> Questions:  1.  What effect would the vacuum conections to the distrubutor
>   have with one to the throttle body intake per the manual and the other to
>   the air intake with the oil breather hose?

It's a push-pull vaccuum advance. One uses the manifold pressure difference
to artificially retard the advance by 5 degrees, the other is used to 
automaticly advance the timing by 5 degrees under accelleration. That, plus
the static advance and mechanical advance, means that yoy can have both
a decent idle and good acceleration. If everything is working right, you 
should show 27 degrees advance at the crank at 3500 RPM.

>             2.  Would the vacuum hoses so connected affect the rpm as in
>   very low idle rpm at normal operating temperature?

Yes. See above. It probably means the one that is holding back the advance
is broken.

>             3.  What is the normal rpm when the engine is cold?

By the book, it's 800-900 RPM.

Stan

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 12:27:30 TZ
From: Marc Olson <marco@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Oil Change Mess

I had a similar problem last night changing the oil in my LandCruiser.  
The filter is mounted vertically, and after unscrewing it the contents 
of the filter goes into the engine compartment.  I'd anticipated this 
with a strategically placed drain pan, but the oil hit various and 
sundry suspension components and spattered everywhere but into the drain pan.

I used full strength Simple Green and a brush to clean it off of a very 
porous driveway.  By the time I finished it was dark, but this morning 
you couldn't tell that I'd spilled any oil, except for the very clean 
patch of driveway.

Marc
'78 911 SC Targa
'92 Landcruiser

Porschephiles #1359                         Thu Apr 27 23:58:53 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 12:45:00 -0800 (PDT)
From: John Wright <jpw@reebok.sr.hp.com>
Subject: ECU EPROM Chips

Regarding this post:

>Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 15:56:22 -0400
>From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
>Subject: Re: Chips for Porsches

>The day I went on vacation Stan wrote some fairly discouraging things about
chips, and even though it was 2 weeks ago, I would like to put the other
>side of the story. 

<stuff deleted>

>The Bosch systems are comparatively easy to reprogram and we can get more
>power out of the engines by doing it. We get 25 HP from the 993 engines and
>it has been done without putting a car on the dyno. Yes we do have a dyno
>here, a very expensive one in fact, but the problem with reprogramming the
>993 was not in getting more power out of it but in defeating the built in
>protection system. 

<stuff deleted>

>I dont know why Porsche leave this power increase for us to find. I am
>grateful that they do and when I sell a chip for a Porsche I rarely get it
>back as not doing what I claimed it would do. So ease off Stan, and accept
>that even a Porsche can be improved, and it can be done in America too.
>Peter Wales
>Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"


From this posting, it appears the Porsche hardware people design in
performance only to have the Porsche firmware developers consistently
write code that utilizes the hardware suboptimally.

I'd guess this would cause some hard feelings at the Porsche factory, since
the engine hardware people design the engine to be high performance, only to 
have the Porsche firmware developers squander some of the performance with poor
firmware.

This could lead to some "heated discussions" in the factory parking lot.

Furthermore, to judge from some magazine "Chip" advertisements, suboptimal 
ECU code is present in cars from different manufacturers.   

After all, with improved firmware, the factories might meet the same 
performance goals at a lower cost.  Possibly a less expensive intake 
manifold could be substituted, possibly the exhaust system could be made 
less expensive.  Maybe a less expensive head assembly could be substituted.  
Possibly the cam lobe grind tolerances could be relaxed to make the cams less
costly to make.  The car could even tolerate more weight if it would 
lower costs.

So suboptimal ECU firmware could be costing Porsche and other manufacturers
real MONEY, year after year.

And Porsche has been struggling to lower costs/increase profits.

One might think the factory would difference the aftermarket EPROM vs the 
factory EPROM to determine where the factory firmware developers overlooked
something, and then incorporate the differences. 

Maybe the Porsche factory does do this, but is always one step behind, even 
though they have a large R&D facility, a large R&D expenditure and considerable
performance tuning experience from racing.

I know I can't explain this surprising phenomenon.

John Wright

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 15:51:52 -0400
From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
Subject: Re: ECU EPROM Chips

At 12:45 PM 4/27/95 -0800, John Wright wrote:

>>From this posting, it appears the Porsche hardware people design in
>performance only to have the Porsche firmware developers consistently
>write code that utilizes the hardware suboptimally.
>(snip)

I guess the word for today is suboptimal


>
>I know I can't explain this surprising phenomenon.
>
>John Wright


Try, production tolerancing!

When anyone makes  mechanical components, no two of them are going to be
exactly the same. So, Bosch (they write the software I believe) creates
software which will run the optimal engine perfectly, and run a suboptimal
engine equally as well. This is why chips work well in some cars, less well
in more, and not too well in a few. Simply a question of how close is the
engine to the tolerance limits and in which way.

For example, a high compression engine will be closer to activating the
knock sensor than a low compression engine. Consequently adding 3 degrees
ignition to the high compression engine will probably result in the knock
sensor coming on and retarding the engine. Result - less power than before.
Conversely, a low compression engine will not activate the knock sensor and
the extra advance will pay off in performance terms. A simplistic but
illustrative answer I hope, and not even Porsche can make every engine the same.

 It is also a way of meeting German Law demanding all engines come within a
tolerance of the claimed power output. Detune them all to the same easy to
achieve level, but I have no idea whether it figures in their programming,
certainly, the ability to get more from most engines has been around for a
lot longer than that law.
Peter Wales
Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 07:43:09 PDT

Subject: 944 Master Cylinder Leak


To the list:

The 951 hard to shift post reminded me of a problem a friend had and I wanted
to warn the list.  "87" 944S brake warning light was coming on to
warn of low fluid 
level.  Addition of fluid turned t he light off but only to light again in 
a couple of days.  No signs of leakage, but the clutch pedal height was 
erratic. 

The master cylinder was leaking inside the car and ruined the carpeting
before he identified the problem.

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 07:36:34 PDT
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: fuel injection v. carbs - tuned intakes

> The book asserts that as an advantage over carbeurators, fuel 
> injection allows the use of tuned intake runners.  I don't understand 
> why they can't be used on carbeurated engines.  Any thoughts?

It's not that it can't be done (look at any early Ferrari, or the
higher performance versions of the 356 family, or early 911s), it's
that it can't be done *CHEAPLY*. Mass production requirements mean that
things have to be simple and cheap. One carb on a big cast iron manifold
is both. One EFI control setup on a nice tuned aluminium intake is not
much more complex, and "cheap" is relative when you consider the impact
of EPA and CAFE requirements. However, multithroat carbs with tuned 
air horns are *NOT* cheap under any possible interpretation.

> Also, just how are tuned intake and exhaust manifolds designed?  I
> understand that the operation of the pistons and valves creates
> pressure waves, but what is the design goal when engineering manifolds?

Colin Campbell, "The Scientific Design of Intake and Exhaust Systems"
is your friend. About 1971, its currently carried under the Robert Bentley
press, and I *think* you can get it from United German Precision in scenic
Pittstown NJ.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 07:28:15 PDT
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Misc. 924 questions

> Also, does anyone know ways to modify the CIS system on an '80 924  
> to change the fuel mixture while retaining the CIS.  

Once you've done something to incrase the airflow, you *may* need to
do something to incrase the gasflow. Of course, you'll need some
chassis dyno time to see how this looks under load *FIRST*. Then
once you start making mods, you'll need more chassis dyno time...

There are two simple tricks: 1) larger injectors/higher base fuel
pressure, 2) rising rate regulator.

Larger injectors have an obvious advantage: they're larger, so flow more
gas. There may be special application injectors (I'd guess off-hand
the 931s, maybe the 924 Euro version, certainly the factory racing 
version) that you can use, or you can get them "adjusted" by Kinsler
or Marren Motorsport. Higher base fuel pressure accomplishes the same
thing without changing hardware. These modifications, while increasing
richness when you want it, also run richer *ALL* the time, which is
a huge problem on the street. 

Rising rate regulators are simply put the most effective modification 
you can make to L-jet or CIS motors to get more gas in cheapest. They
change the fuel presssure when you "get on it", which increases gas
flow through the injector. This also makes a better spray pattern
which may also improve combustion. I don't have the manufacturer info
of the top of my head for where you can get these, but they've been
discussed at length many times. See the archives.

Finally, you can use a secondary injection system, with a simgle pulsed
injector blowing gas into the main intake plenum under control of a
secondary controller that's looking at things like RPM, manifold pressure,
etc. This is also a fine solution but takes a bit of fabrication to make
it work.

Anyway, at some point you get into the problem of how stock does
it have to LOOK Like it is, but that's another set of engineering....

Stan


------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 95 20:26:27 PDT
From: tom@craney.demon.co.uk
Subject: Chips-by Bruce Anderson

Bruce Anderson wrote an excellent 6 page article on Chips and the 
911 in Excellence October 1991.  Using a borrowed 3.2 motronic 
he tested all the available chips on the market(Authority, 
Hypertech, Z Industries, Keeno and Knightech) at the time as 
well as a variety of exhaust systems including SSI and Ruf.
All of the analysis was done on Dynamometer.  His conclusion,
was "the best of 5 performance chips produced a 9hp improvement
while the best exhaust change produced a 13hp improvement leading
us to conclude that the best performance chip to install was 
actually an exhaust system".




Tom Craney



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 19:11:44 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: 914 Shuffle Pins

After I discribed the engine I am building, I got a response from Mr. 
Darling suggesting that "shuffle pinning" may be a good thing. 

I have been to several machinists up here in the Great White North and none 
of them really know what I'm talking about (not that I do, so that's part of 
it). I assume that shuffle pinning refers to installing dowels above and 
below the bearing saddles. Is this correct? Do you do all three of the 
saddles or is just the central one necessary? Do they in fact help? It seems 
to me that all the shuffle pins in the world won't help if your engine is 
gonna twist enough to toast the *distributor shaft*. My impression is that 
they just prevent the bearing saddles from twisting, and thus, the bearings 
from melting.

Any comments? Thanks, Chris

__________________________________________________________________________
Christopher Paine                         "Technology is like a steamroller,
Metropolis Pictures, Director              if you're not on it, you become
Editor,Der Auspuff,Rennsport Region PCA    part of the road"

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 18:30:25 -0500
From: dgcole@sam.neosoft.com (David G. Cole)
Subject: Re: Misc. 924 questions

>Hello p-philes:
>
>I was interested in finding information about part numbers on  
>924GT(euro. only of course :-( ).  I've heard that they had 930  
...
..
.
>Chuck BIttman '80 924 (135K+)  for track and autocross.


Chuck,

        I am currently a attempting a Carrera GT conversion to an '80 924 
turbo. Finally tracked down and received the parts fiche for car (GT), but 
have not had a chance to look at it yet in detail. Yes the GT had 930 
brakes, but not 917 brakes, those was reserved for the GTS/GTR cars. I will 
look those part #'s up for you if you wish. Personal opinion is instead of 
putting on 930 brakes, is to take '86 951 brakes and bolt them on. You will 
need the front struts and the complete rear suspension, but it is a somewhat 
straight forward bolt on process and not "all" that expensive. (Thank you to 
Jim Pasha for that bit of wisdom) Used parts places, *when available* are 
asking about $750 for the stuff.

        I will email you the part # on the brakes/suspension if you still 
wish them, let me know.

        As for the CIS modification, I can not be of much help there at the 
moment. I am currently trying to track down a company to do the recurving of 
the 924 fuel distributor to match the GT. Price on the GT distributor (when 
found) is absolutely unreal. Will keep you posted on this if you wish.

        I was told that in a mag called "Turbo" or some such name, some 
companies are marketing an additional injection port for added mass flow 
under higher rpm/boast conditions. But as stan already pointed out, how much 
flow, how and where do you curve it to your specific engine?

Good luck

David G. Cole
wife, cat, toys, windmills...

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 19:47:15 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 911 Brake/CV Joint Noises

Hey,

The last few days I have a noticed a faint "squeaking" coming from
the left rear axle area.  Today, as I pulled into my driveway, it became
more of a rythmic scaping (kinda like when brake pads get really thin).
Thinking it was my brakes I pulled the pads out but the noise didn't
go away (the pads/rotor were fine).  I did find some small pebbles stuck 
down in a little cavity between the caliper and the rotor.  Spinning the 
axle with the pads out produced a faint sound real similar to the sound 
of brake pads dragging on a rotor.

I put everything back together and went out for a test drive.  No discernable
noises.  Should I be concerned about the faint sound coming from the 
CV joint bearing-in-the-hub area?  FWIW, both sides made the same noise.

TIA,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911
mlbdayton@aol.com

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 19:01:32 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: ECU EPROM Chips

> >>From this posting, it appears the Porsche hardware people design in
> >performance only to have the Porsche firmware developers consistently
> >write code that utilizes the hardware suboptimally.
> 
> I guess the word for today is suboptimal

Could be worse, like "pessimal" (one of my favorites).

> >I know I can't explain this surprising phenomenon.
>
> Try, production tolerancing!

There are other, less flattering words which might be equally applicable.
Since we live in a litigous society, I won't say them. I will stand behind
my basic position that almost all aftermarket chips are either snake
oil or give performance increases at some great expense to engine longevity.

I think John hit on the core issue. In a bottom-line oriented market
where Porsche is routinely taking it in the shorts, the idea that they
are not optimizing the firmware within an angstrom of the last bit
is laughable. I know that I insist on my people getting the architecture
absolutely right, the hardware implementations correct but flexible and
then spend *ALL* of the time tuning software from then on. 

Stan

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 21:52:43 -0400
From: Jrhetten@aol.com
Subject: '91 911 C2 oil leak clarified

After personally seeing the leaks today, the CAMSHAFT SEAL,  not the
crankshaft seal is dripping.   This had been previously repaired by Paramount
11/15/94 at 30,085 miles.  Two cylinders HAVE leaked as evidenced by small
stains on the pan under the chassis, but the surface is dry (today).  

Heritage Warranty, a Quaker State Company, paid for the Paramount repair,
$873.48, less $50 deductible .  They will not pay Hendricks for redoing the
job.  Also, they are balking at paying for correcting cylinder "weeps."  They
want to see LIQUID oil dripping.  

Porsche has authorized Hendricks to  re-repair of the troublesome camshaft
seal and save me the time of returning to Paramount.  The other old leak,
"weep" remains unresolved.  If the leak resumes the warranty company agrees
to cover the repair, BUT apparrently will not follow the Porsche tech
bulletin and carry out the repair properly.

Other than that no problems.  Except this is springtime in the south and my
CAB is in the shop while adjustors, service managers and others argue back
and forth.

Any facts, suggestions will be appreciated.

Thanks much.

Jim Hettenhaus
Charlotte, NC.........

>pattern of wear in the anodization that the aftermarket nuts
>were making contact with the wheel in only a narrow band.
>The used factory samples showed wear in a much wider area
>all over the rounded end of the nut.  Given the comments

You could always do what tool manufacturers do: buy one, paint
the nose with dykem, a bluing agent for inspecting surface
correlations, and inspect whether/not it has an acceptable
purchase on YOUR wheels.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 19:20:04 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: General car question (Why parking lights ?)

They're for idiots who think they're saving money on their utility
bills.  In California it's illegal to drive with them on by
themselves, but I see people doing it all the time, and have yet to
see anyone being cited.  I can see their usefulness, literally, while
the car is parked, for a limited period of time.  VW, Porsche and Audi
(maybe others) always had the feature that headlights left on would
revert to parking lights when the engine was turned off.

Just my two cents.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Porschephiles #1361                         Fri Apr 28 09:38:26 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 03:04:51 -0400
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: Re: Chips

I think that I must agree with the Superchips guy. Of course there is more
performance in the car, although the additional cost of maintenance
intervals and warranty claims negate the benefit. In the case of the Escort
944 Turbos, didn't Porsche come up with the infamous first "head gasket"
chip which optimized the car for racing gas with the idea that each engine
only had to last one race. Blew up head gaskets fast with street gas. If I
am wrong, please be kind...... 
 
On another vein, I sort of recall a Compuserve thread in which a fellow
decided to modify a Superchip EPROM for his car (Eagle Talon Turbo?) He
dumped the Superchip-labelled EPROM, compared it to the stock EPROM, and
ha-ha-ha, found them identical. Superchips response was that they sold a
kit for the car which included a chip and a wastegate spring. This kit
improved hp. So what if it was only the spring that was important. As long
as you got the hp, you had nothing to complain about. Guess they thought
that someone might try to engineer the spring for less than the $200-300
that the kit went for, if they left out the chip. This is by no means an
attack on Superchips. I think that it's a neat way to make money and wish
that I could do something equally clever actually. I'd be very interested
in comments, Peter. 
- -- 
Triet Le 

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 02:45:26 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Shuffle Pins

> I assume that shuffle pinning refers to installing dowels above and 
> below the bearing saddles. Is this correct? 

More or less. Done well, there are several other locations around the
rim of the case that pins are also inserted.

> Do you do all three of the 
> saddles or is just the central one necessary? 

You do much more than the three saddles. You do two pins on each saddle,
plus a total of about 6 other locations.

> Do they in fact help? 

Well, it depends. If you do it right -- meaning start with a new case --
*AND* you're talking about racing only, then yes, it helps. But you'll
still only get a fairly short life from a full race engine. For street
engines, dunno --haven't had to tear down any that have been shuffle
pinned. Maybe that says something, maybe not.

> It seems 
> to me that all the shuffle pins in the world won't help if your engine is 
> gonna twist enough to toast the *distributor shaft*. My impression is that 
> they just prevent the bearing saddles from twisting, and thus, the bearings 
> from melting.
> 
> Any comments? Thanks, Chris

Well, it's *REALLY* supposed to keep the case edges from fretting. Once
a case starts doing that, it's time to call the nice Alcoa people about
just recycling it for the $0.36 a pound.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 02:47:53 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Why Are Used 911 Coupes Wor

> Why is it that used Targas list for less than Coupes?  

Well, you actually hit on it later in the note...

> According to the dealer
> I spoke to yesterday, the major reason is body stiffness.  According to him,
> the Targa's frame is identical to the Coupe's, and it does NOT have reinforced
> floor of the Cabriolet. True?  

False. The Cab and Targa have the same identical body and there is a
significant amount of reinforecment that goes into them. That is not
to say that they don't flex however.

> I would have thought the resale differential
> was more a matter of styling preference, and maybe hassles with and
> deterioration of the Targa roofs.

Yup. That's most likely it. All Targas leak. Period.

> Would a Targa or Cabriolet be OK for hard driving, say, maybe a driver's
> school a couple of times a year?  

You bet! Even for *REAL* serious driving like a nationsl
points chase in autox...

> Does the roof when put in place on the Targa add any rigidity to the car?

No.

Stan

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 11:28:57 +0100

In relation to a leaking 91 C2, the following was said:

| Slick 50 would be a good problem sovler if you lose a lot of oil.  It binds
| to the inside of the walls.  It is really good stuff.  Ask your local parts
| store.

Sorry, this is Snake Oil and is not a Good Thing. There is no evidence
to suggest that the claims of the manufacturer are true. This is a
cash flow device. You have been sucessfully brainwashed by men-in-suits
marketing execs, who seem to have got your wavelength very effectively indeed.

| Slick 50 would be a good problem sovler if you lose a lot of oil.

No. This is a seriously weird view of solving the known oil leak problem
in early 3.6 boxers. If I had a leaker I would go berserk if I took it
in to have it fixed by Porsche and they put Slick 50 in it. The very idea
is utterly absurd.

| It is really good stuff

No. It is worthless at best.

| Ask your local parts store

No. Don't ask at your local parts store for anything to do
with your Porsche. Bubba might have a clue about prehistoric
cast-iron V8 truck engines, but he has no idea about ass-engine
nazi slot cars, trust me on this one. Ask a Porsche expert, Stan or 
any of the other People-Who-Know will confirm the facts and evidence
of the crap nature of Slick and similar products.

I would never pollute the engine in my 911 with this stuff, neither 
would 99.99% of the 911 people on the list. Neither would Dr Porsche,
if it was any good the damn things would roll out of the 
factory with Slick 50 in the sump. 

Regards

Ben "Just say No" Evans

Date:          Fri, 28 Apr 1995 12:14:26 +0000
From: "Peter Remeijer" <peter@qv3pluto.LeidenUniv.nl>
Subject:       924 vibrations

Hi there,

Thanks to all of you who have responded to my question on 924 
vibrations. There are a few things not clear to me though. 
Is the 924 suspension the same as the early 944 type (except for the 
brakes) and does it have the same "shimmy" problem as described by 
George Beuselinck ? Would this  also cause the large vibrations 
during braking, or is that something that should be contributed to 
bearing play etc. ?

Thanks,

 Peter Remeijer
'85 924

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 95 07:30:39 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re:       924 vibrations

> Hi there,
> 
> Thanks to all of you who have responded to my question on 924 
> vibrations. There are a few things not clear to me though. 
> Is the 924 suspension the same as the early 944 type (except for the 
> brakes) and does it have the same "shimmy" problem as described by 
> George Beuselinck ? Would this  also cause the large vibrations 
> during braking, or is that something that should be contributed to 
> bearing play etc. ?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
>  Peter Remeijer
> '85 924

If you're having large vibrations during braking, very likely you have
warped brake rotors, or less likely, bent wheels or out of round tires.

The 924 suspension in the 197x-1982 US model 924 cars did have the steel
control arms, and probably does in your 1985 model. They probably had less
of a shimmy problem due to smaller wheels and tires.

My guess is that the larger tires reached the design limits of the
suspension and made the adjustments more critical.

Of course all bets are off if the car has ever been in the slightest
accident...
- --
Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net, 1983 944 Track Car
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

	44,000 Miles.
	Jerry is the second owner and has had the car
	for the past 11 years.
	A/C, power windows, radio, built in CB.
	Jerry has a complete service record for the car.
        Jerry is asking $24,900 for the car.

	Call:  608-273-1383 between 9:00 AM and 9:00 PM CDT.

Harvey Hensley
University of Wisconsin-Platteville
E-MAIL:	hensley@uwplatt.edu
PHONE:	608-342-1657

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 07:34:49 -0400
From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
Subject: Re: ECU EPROM Chips

At 07:01 PM 4/27/95 -0500, Stan Hanks wrote:
 In a bottom-line oriented market
>where Porsche is routinely taking it in the shorts, the idea that they
>are not optimizing the firmware within an angstrom of the last bit
>is laughable. I know that I insist on my people getting the architecture
>absolutely right, the hardware implementations correct but flexible and
>then spend *ALL* of the time tuning software from then on. 

You are entitled to your opinion on whether chips are snake oil or not but......

I am afraid I find the concept of any motor manufacturer tuning his product
to "the last angstrom" somewhat ludicrous. If he did, one engine would be
perfectly in tune and so would every other engine *exactly* the same. Not
even a die hard Porscheophile like Stan could possibly believe that Porsche
can produce a few thousand engines all *exactly* the same. Therefore, all of
the others would be off tune.

Unless of course, Stan thinks that each one is programmed on the dyno
individually. Join the real world on this one Stan.
Peter Wales
Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 09:58:32 -0300
From: rosvall@itchy.mi.net (Peter & Julie Rosvall)
Subject: 911L Production (LONG)

To all:

I just thought that I would post this to the list for discussion, as a owner
of a 911L I'm curious to hear peoples opinions.

LETTER TO EUROPEAN CAR SEPTEMBER 1993

911L Production

	I really enjoyed the 911 anniversary issue, I thought, however, that you
might like some
additional information concerning the production figures that you have
provided on page 61. My
comments focus specifically on the 1968 model year, since I have just
finished a complete mechanical
restoration of a 1968 911L Coupe.The priminary research for this project
uncovered some fascinating
facts about this vehicle. First, production run of this model was very low.
According to sources at PCNA,
720 of the L were built. This was because the S would not pass Federal
emission standards for 1968. As
a result, Porsche took the light S European bodyshell with the Koni racing
suspension, vented brake
discs, etc. and installed the standard 911 "plain" 2000 series engine in it.
A trim package unique to the
L was then offered. Almost all these cars were special ordered, and few were
equipped the same.
Although only a "fill" model for 1968 (the S returned for 1969), many were
taken direct from delivery to
the shop where they were stripped and more powerful engines installed,
taking advantages of the high-
performance chassis.
	My research shows that many experts feel that there are less than 100
unaltered L models left. I
tend to agree, as I have been approached by two different customers in the
last three months claiming
that they would like to restore their 911Ls. Neither car was an L. The owner
of the car I had just finished
had been told over a dozen times during our search for parts that there is
no such animal as a 911L.
Needless to say, this model of 911 is going to appreciate rapidly as the
last remaining examples are
located and restored. The attraction of this model is not performance but
rather very low production
numbers and a unique options packages. Thanks again for the outstanding issue.

Randy Bush
Durango, Colorado

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 09:49:29 -0500 (CDT)
From: babak marefat <bmarefat@tigr1.fhsu.edu>
Subject: Speed Limit Legistlation

*scratches head*
Umm, Hi gang:
Several asked for the bill #'s with regard to the legislation
slated toward revoking the national speed limit.  I posted it on
the list but didnt see it on my digests.
1-either I am blind
2-I forgot how to read english or
3-it didn't get posted
well here they are:
H.R. 607 and H.R. 427 if passed will revoke the national max speed
limit
H.R. 1007 will increase the speed limit on non interstate highways
to 65 from 55 (thus making for a smaller fine when clocked at 80
in them there back roads)
A bill authored (but without a number yet) by Sen. Nickles and
Sen. Nighthorse Campbell will do pretty much the same thing as
H.R. 607 and 427
Babak

 911 used to be quite popular police cars for high speed pursuits and motorway
(freeway) duties in Europe although now that the 911 has become more expensive
police forces are tending to use 968 club sports with the nessecary extras.

The theroy being you where able to sit on the role bar with a speed gun and thendrop straight into the seat when you needed to!!!!
