Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 12:40:46 -0500 (CDT)
From: Geert Pallemans <pallemag@daisy.ac.siue.edu>
Subject: Re: 911 Police car



On Wed, 26 Apr 1995, Jim Bauman jbauman@btr.com wrote:

> I was on the freeway (ooops...Autobahn I mean) somewhere east
> of Amsterdam back in 1976, and saw a neat 911 Targa (white with
> orange stripes) with two cops with Bell Star helmets and orange
> jumpsuits. They had a big Mercedes with German plates pulled over.
> I don't think they were discussing improved foreign relations!
> 
> Jim Bauman
> '86 Carrera Cab
> GETA911
> 
Growing up in Belgium the white 911 with orange stripe running over the 
hood and trunk was a somewhat regular image. Why these "pursuit 
vehicles" were invariably Targas, I don't know. I seem to remember that the
police light was attached on the driver's side of the Targa bar and the siren 
mounted on the wing-less trunk. Cool job indeed. I am not sure what the 
Belgian State Patrol members in those cars wore, but it could have been 
either the regular blue military uniforms (B.S.P. is a division of the 
Belgian Military), or the motorcycle version: black leather 
outfits with high black leather boots...very Mad Max like! At any 
rate, I am pretty sure they didn't have to wear any helmets in Belgium.
Today the B.S.P. (Rijkswacht) is equiped with Volkswagen GTI's, the VW 
little busses (to pull you in/check papers/question you/and haul you 
off with). The fast car in the lineup to date is the BMW 325i. Yep, 
another poignant illustration of a global recession!


Geert Pallemans
84 911 Carrera Targa (Platinum)
IL.Lic.plate: PORCHE 1


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 1995 19:09:27 -0500
From: stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda)
Subject: setting up a 944 for racing


>
>Hello, My name is Scott Sanda, and I have a 1986 normally aspirated 944 
>that I race, both in SCCA and in Porsche Club Racing. This article will 
>primarily apply to PCA racing but is applicable to everything, even 
>drivers ed.
>
>So that you know that I'm not just full of hot air, here is the history 
>of the car so far this season. I run it stock, in class I. The car 
>weighs 2840 lbs with a quarter tank of gas, and it is completely legal. 
>So far, I have ran in 4 PCA races, and have 3 first place finishes and 
>one mechanical DNF. In 1995 I have won races at Sebring, and Road Atlanta,  
>At Sebring my fast time was 2:47.4, and at Road Atlanta it was 1:47.5. 
>These may not seem all that fast, but in class, they really are. I also 
>have 2 years of SCCA experiance, none of which is on my new suspension.
>
>The reason I am putting my setup information and advice (2 years of 
>research and testing) out on this conference is that I want to see more 
>cars run in the "lower" stock race groups. There are literally hundreds 
>of 911's and turbo 944's running, but very few normally aspirated 944's. 
>This is really a shame, because the 944 is the best handling car Porsche 
>ever produced. Given the proper suspension, it will totally crush any 
>other stock class car out there. Just ask all the 911's that couldn't 
>keep up with me in the turns at Sebring and Atlanta. (of course, they 
>all dusted me in the straights, horsepower makes up for a whole lot of 
>things!)
>
>Here are the 4 area's to look at in setting up a 944: 
>Safety, engine/drive train,  suspension, and brakes.
>
>I'll tackle safety first, as it is what will keep you out of the 
>hospital.
>     1. Put in a good roll cage, not a bar. A roll bar will not help you 
>if you flip, and a good cage will. A cage also adds some chassis 
>stiffness, which is a good thing. Don't skimp here, get a cage that 
>bolts to the FRAME RAILS, not the floor pan. Floor pans mounts will poke 
>through in the event of a hard enough rollover, and don't do a thing for 
>stiffness.
>
>     2. Connect your window net to the cage, not the door. The door 
>mounted nets make it really easy to get in and out, but what happens to 
>your net if the door pops open?
>
>     3. Put in a seat back brace, to help prevent the seat from 
>collapsing backwards. All the pro's have them.
>
>The PCA rulebook covers belts, fire extinguishers and the like, and is 
>very complete.
>
>Engine:
>
>The sad fact is, an 8 valve, normally aspirated 944 is under powered. On 
>a good day you'll get about 160 hp out of it. Don't waste your money 
>with super fancy 20 minute valve jobs, high compression heads, special 
>pistons, cams, etc. They may add power, but they don't comply to the 
>spirit or the letter of the rules. If you want horsepower, race a turbo.
>If you happen to race SCCA as well, be prepared to be out horsepowed by 
>everything else in your class. (You can beat them in the corners and on
>the brakes.)
>
>All that being said, here are the things I think you should do to take 
>maximum advantage of your engine/drive train, and to ensure long life 
>and reliability.
>
>     1. Put in a good header, throw out the cat, and put in a good low 
>back pressure muffler. I ran a straight pipe last year, and really 
>assaulted the ears of those around me, but this year, with a flow master 
>muffler instead, I'm getting a lot more torque (and fewer noise 
>complaints)
>
>     2. K&N air filter is a must.
>
>     3. Put in an external oil cooler. You can replace the factory 
>internal cooler with the 944 turbo oil bypass. It is a factory part, 
>eliminates the possibility of coolant/oil mixture, allows you to hook up 
>any external oil cooler, and is relatively inexpensive. You can buy them 
>used.
>
>     4. 944's can have an oiling problem under high G cornering loads. 
>Don't run a thin, lightweight oil. Red line or mobile 1 work fine. I 
>have an accusump, which feeds a sandwich plate under the oil filter. It 
>provides pressurized oil to the system in case the pick-up tube becomes 
>momentarily uncovered. Porsche also makes a factory baffle for the oil 
>pan, that help prevent sloshing. You don't necessarily have to have 
>either the accusump or baffle, but please don't run any thin "high 
>horsepower" racing oils, I ran royal purple once, and it thinned out due 
>to heat, sloshed away from the pickup in hard cornering, burnt a 
>bearing, and hand-grenaded my number 2 connecting rod at about 6000 rpm. 
>Believe me, it was not any fun. Newer engines, I.E. 88 and up, seem to 
>have some improvements here, but I have no actual proof.
>
>    THIS IS NOT A CHRONIC PROBLEM IF YOU APPROACH IT CORRECTLY!!!
>
>     5. Have you engine rebuilt, balanced and blueprinted. This simply 
>means making everything like new, and as harmonious as possible. You'll 
>see a small power gain, but your reliability will skyrocket. Get a good, 
>durable valve job. It should last all season.
>
>     6. Have your transmission rebuilt. Put in a limited slip 
>differential. (believe me, you'll notice the difference over an open 
>dif) Try to go with a factory differential, as this won't move you up a 
>class in PCAR. My friends a Kelly-Moss have done extensive testing and 
>have found no real difference in performance between the factory and the 
>quaiff differential. They happen to like the factory better. However, 
>the factory diff generates more heat, and needs to be "tightened" 
>occasionally. (every couple of years)
>
>I'm sure there are other things that can be done legally, but most of 
>them move you up a class. Chips, quaiff differentials, etc. will not 
>make you competitive with a 944S or S2 on a straight horsepower basis.
>
>SUSPENSION:
>
>Here is where a 944 shines. With the right suspension, no 911 will ever 
>hang with you in a corner. (provided, of course, that you take the 
>corner correctly, don't scrub, have as high as possible an entrance 
>speed, and proper apex and track out, and get on the power the instant 
>you turn in. remember, in a 944, momentum is everything. We don't have 
>the raw power to go slowly in a turn!)
>
>There are a lot of correct way to do this, a lot of correct spring 
>weights, camber and castor settings, shock absorbers(koni or bilstien), 
>etc. I'll tell you what I have done, and you can experiment from there.
>
>     1. Double adjustable Koni's.
>
>     2. 400 pound springs up front, 30mm torsion bar in the rear.
>
>     3. Solid suspension bushings wherever possible.
>
>     4. Threaded, adjustable spring plates up front(to help properly 
>balance and set ride height)
>
>     5. Weltmeister front and rear swaybars as large as you can get 
>them, with adjustable drop links.
>
>     6. A good front shock tower brace
>
>     7. DO NOT radically lower your suspension, this could cause 
>catastrophic ball joint failure by limiting travel! (If this worries 
>you, Fabcar Engineering in Indiana makes Steel A-arms for racing, and 
>PCA/SCCA/IMSA endorse them.)
>
>Doesn't seem like much, does it? Well, once you get it balanced, adjust 
>out the oversteer and understeer, and get used to the rougher ride, 
>you'll find that your in a completely different car than you started 
>with. You'll be able to corner harder, pull over 1 G, and generally 
>carry a lot more speed.
>
>Brakes:
>
>You don't have to change a thing, just make some improvements: steel 
>braided brake lines, a good brake cooling kit(I use a cool brake kit 
>from OG racing), a good high temperature brake fluid (I use AP800, but 
>ATE blue is just fine) and performance friction carbon metallic brake 
>pads.
>
>Don't cross drill your rotors, you'll only weaken them and decrease the 
>effective pad contact area.
>
>944 brakes are great. After you learn how to modulate your foot on the 
>brake, you'll out brake almost everything. (This isn't necessarily a 
>good thing, the harder you brake, the more you slow down and the more 
>your lack of horsepower shows.) As in anything, there is a learning 
>curve.
>
>I forgot to mention tires. Who makes the best tires? Who knows? I run 
>Hoosiers and BFG's, other people swear by Goodyear GSCS(expensive). My 
>best advice on this: put on the BFG's as they are easy to set the 
>suspension for, and have fun. I personally prefer the Hoosiers, but the 
>suspension setup is difficult, because they are Bias Ply, not radial.
>Experiment as you are able.
>
>There are a lot of good books out there to help you out. Find them and 
>read them. They will make you think, help you learn and help you drive 
>better(or understand driving better).
>
>This information should apply to all 944's, not just the 8 valves.
>
>Some people to talk to, who have good information, sell new/used parts, 
>and/or work on race cars are:
>
>Dave and Jeff Stone at Kelly Moss Motorsports - 608-274-5054
>Joe Cogbill at PAP - 404-449-3146
>George Beusilink at 944 ecology - 914-658-9593
>Jeff Chandler at JCM Motorsports - 303-444-2585
>Bob Long at truechoice(Koni rep) - 800-388-8783
>George or Brian Weathered at Midwest Eurosport - 708-595-5577
>
>These people have all helped me, but if your going to take up a lot of 
>their time, you should buy something from them to show your 
>appreciation.
>
>As a disclaimer: I race at an amateur level, and am by no means a 
>subject matter expert. If you take this advice and something doesn't 
>work or go wrong, that's racing, and I am in no way responsible.
>
>With that legal bullshit out of the way, set up your 944's and come out 
>and race!
>
>Scott Sanda
>
Scott D Sanda



------------------------------

Date: 27 Apr 1995 09:10:32 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: 911: Motronic advice needed

Phellow Philers,

The car: 
 '86 Carrera, totally stock

The symptoms:
 - At idle, revs bounce between 800 and 1000 RPM immediately after 
   coming down from normal engine speed abruptly. It does this irregularly
   but most often when the engine is fully warm and the outside temp is
   cool (say 40 degrees). Sounds like: "Rump Rump Rump Rump..."
 - When engine is warm, taking off smoothly from a stop is difficult. It
   seems to lose a little power right after I engage the clutch. Basically,
   I get one jerk as I take off.  
 - When the engine is cold  this doesn't happen i.e. takeoffs are smooth.
 - It didn't do this before I removed the engine and put it back.

The question:
 - Is this something I can expect to fix or diagnose if I buy the Bosch
  fuel injection book or do I need specialized tools (like an oscilloscope
  or exhaust gas analyzer) ?

 thanks in advance,
   Chris

cbennet@lmcorp.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 10:28:17 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: '95 911 Carrera 993

Hi,

I posted this on the autocross list (team.net) today and thought
some of you would like to see it. The 993 is now in SCCA 
A-Stock with all the old 911's, and is considering moving 
it to Super Stock with the RX-7 twin turbo and late
model Corvettes (where it seems to fit better).

"Burns, James B." <BurnsJB1@central.ssd.jhuapl.edu> asked :

>I'm not familiar with the new 993.  What engine does it have?  Is it AWD? 
>How does it compare to the Carrera 2 or Carrera 4, and what's its price?

The new 993s are the newest and only 911s now available (the 400HP twin
turbo all wheel drive version will be out soon). The 993 is the first
911 to have a modified body shape - the front end is sleeker and the
rear modified. The engine is an improved version of the Carrera-2 3.6
liter twin-plug engine, tuned to 270 HP and 243 ft/lbs of torque.

The 993 Carrera is standard with 2 wheel drive. The main advantage over
the old C2 (along with the power) is the totally redesigned rear suspension.
Rather than the antique trailing arms used since '65 (and in my '72S)
they have a rear subframe with a multi-link rear suspension. This allowed
Porsche to tune the suspension MUCH more neutrally than any 911 since
the early '70s. Recent 911s have plowed at the limit (!) so that Porsche
could avoid lawsuits from poor drivers going off the road backwards.
The new 993 allows lifting in the turns (some!) without biting you.
The 993 comes with 7 and 9 by 17" rims, which are perfect for the BFG
autocross tires now available (235/45 and 255/40). This larger-than-stock
front tire (stock is only 205) will allow tuning a 993 to be totally
neutral in slow autocross-speed turns.

The price is actually a bit lower (I think) than the C2 that it
replaces. I believe it is a real value at about $60,000. (I drove Tony
Platano's new '95 Camaro 1LE yesterday and can't believe I just said that.
Tony's car is pretty awesome for a GM product - lots of torque and feels
smaller than it looks! And not a flimsy rattle trap like his '86 Vette.) 

The 993 Carrera-4 with the same specs but all-wheel-drive is 
also available now. It uses an improved, simplified AWD 
system that is more effective and cheaper than the one 
it replaced. It is light weight and makes the new Carrera-4 cheaper 
than ANY previous C4 (even less than the '89 model!).
The new 993 C4 does not plow as bad as the original, but I think the
2WD 993 would be better for autocrossing unless there is rain.

Here is the info from my spreadsheet, mostly taken from Autoweek.
The '72 911 price is from the '95 Porsche 968 (the 944 replacement, 
which is the current model A-Stock Porsche. Or is it the amount I 
have spent on my car since 1984?) :-( 

Some of these numbers may be slightly out of date, but they
are quite close. You can see that the 993 is a real rocket ship.
Autoweek recorded the fastest ever slalom speed in it (beating the
RX-7) and said only the ZR-1 was faster in acceleration of any
cars they have tested. If you plot the 0-60, 1/4 mile, Lbs/HP,
or Lbs/Torque, you will see two distinct groups, with the 993
right in the middle of the Super Stock group.

    Car Type      0-60 1/4 m HP   Torque Weight Lbs/HP Lbs/Tor Price
1  92 MR-2 T      6.3  14.9  200    200   2760  13.80  13.80  30000
2  95 BMW M3      6.2  14.6  240    225   3175  13.23  14.11  36000
3  72 911S        6.0  14.4  190    159   2455  12.92  15.44  40000 (968)

4  92 Corvette    5.7  14.1  300    330   3270  10.90   9.91  37000
5  94 Supra T     5.5  13.9  320    315   3350  10.47  10.63  42000
6  93 RX-7        5.3  14.1  255    217   2815  11.04  12.97  37000
7  95 Carrera     5.3  13.8  270    243   3064  11.35  12.61  60000
8  92 Acura NSX   5.3  13.7  270    210   3010  11.15  14.33  75000
9  94 ZR-1        5.2  13.4  405    385   3503   8.65   9.10  66000

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S (wish I had a spare $60K)

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 09:35:06 -0500 (CDT)
From: Alex Rozenberg <alx@csd.uwm.edu>
Subject: Re: General car question (Why parking lights ?)

Mercedes Benz has the feature of leaving one side of parking lights on.  
If you park on the right side of the steet...you can leave the left front 
and rear parking light on.  These are very low energy lights and could be 
left on for 3-5 days w/o discharging the battery.

Considering the small European streets....not a terribly bad Idea.

Now, running lights are a totaly different idea.  In the US we use 
"parking" lights as "running" lights.  I agree that the US version is 
totaly useless, but here in the US....where we have a million laws to ensure 
user safety.....things are done to "look cool" rather than for logical 
resons.

I personally think that daytime running lights are a good safety 
measure....and, I think that they do "look cool."  I think that it GEO 
that is adverting in the US that they are first to have daytime lights as 
standard equipment....yeah, right....and the internal cumbustion engine 
was invented by Edison.



Alex

Porschephiles #1362                         Fri Apr 28 16:02:22 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 10:53:35 -0400 (EDT)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Weird '85 944-what is M030 pack?

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	My brother and I are still looking for a good P-car in the 5-6K 
range, He decided that the '73.5 911T was too expensive since he couldn't 
get a home equity loan (we seem to have BAD luck with finances :^)  We're 
still looking at 914s but haven't found any good 2.0s.  He's beginning to 
get interested in early 944s, and I'm not going to stop him!
	Anyway, we've found two 944s, an '83 and early '85.  The '83 is a 
one owner w/135K on it that runs good but has a few minor electric 
problems (wipers always on, headlight switch) and needs paint-$3100.  For 
that price we could do many updates or...
	We spotted an '85 (early, unfortunately) w/83K, which is not 
remarkable, other than it has Fuchs forged wheels and a FULL leather 
interior, not the half vinyl like another '85 I saw.  It was in a 
mechanics lot and he said the owner wanted to fix some electrical 
problems (oh boy :^) and sell it, but he doesn't know how much $.  Do the 
Fuchs alloys (and perhaps the uplevel interior) indicate a special 
package, assuming it came from the factory?  What about the "M030" 
package, did this usually come with Fuchs along with the upgraded 
suspension?  What about limited slip?  This car is in decent shape and 
I would'nt ask about it except I feel its a unique model.  Maybe I've got 
my hopes up for what amounts to be an "appearance package".  Let me know 
any and all ideas...
Thanx!
		Jay Karolyi
	"Before fearing the worst, suspect the least"
X '70 914 (hauled away yesterday, totally stripped)
'75 Corvair/914 "THe Bastard"
'77 924
'80 Toy 'rolla

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 10:17:12 -0500
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: All Targas Leak! Cabrios?


I've heard many times that all Targas leak.  I believe this is mostly true. 
It seems that new seals last about 5 years then the drips start coming in.

But do Cabrios leak also?  The Targas tend to leak in the front corners above
the triangular deflector windows.  However, I thought the windshield and Targa
top side seals were the same part numbers for both Targas and Cabrios.  This
would imply very similar sealing weaknesses.

So, do Cabrios leak the same as Targas?  Or, doesn't anyone drive his/her
Cabrio in the rain.  Or, is the mention of a Cabrio flaw taboo?

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 11:34:50 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Re: Setting up a 944 for racing


Scott,
Your just the man I needed to talk to.  I have some limited supension design
experience from my mechanical engineering senior project:  A formula SAE
car designed, fabricated and raced by our own 10 hands of a team of 5.  It
was powered by a Yamaha FZ 600 motor that we turbo charged, haltech fuel
injected and ran M85(85% methanol) in.  It produced 100 hp and 95ft-lbf
of torque with a 28mm restrictor upwind of the turbo.  The car weighed
550 lbs and "ran like a scalded dog" to quote the engineer from West
Virginia.  Enough introduction.
Carrol Smiths book on supension design talks a lot about containing the 
roll center and suspension geometry etc., but I've never really gotten a good
feel for how to design roll bars.  My question is not a design question but
an experience question.  I once read a quote from a suspension designer
that read "There are three important things to consider when designing 
a suspension:  One is front and rear roll stiffness and I forget what the
other two are".  I would like to improve my "87" 944 handling but don't want
to live with a real stiff suspension.  Is thicker sway bars the way to go
or do I have to go to stiffer springs and torsion bars.  What are the trade-
offs?

.]

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 09:12:37 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Parking and running lights

Porsche and BMW have the same feature (left or right side lights).  GM
is advertising running lights for its new cars, which are already
required in Canada.  Arguably they add safety, but they also
constitute just one more little decision that is taken out of your
hands.  A disadvantage I can see is that if your alternator goes out
they inhibit your ability to drive on the battery to a repair site.  I
would like to see a manual override available for such contingencies
(although I guess you could pull a fuse--if indeed *that* decision is
even possible).

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 95 09:24:01 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Opinion's Please: '72 911T


I'm looking for another project, after having just restored a '72 911E 
Targa.  My preference is another early '70s, but a coupe.  I saw one 
today and am curious to have another opinion or two.  It's not my 
ideal car, but...

1) 1972 911T, 2.4, very little if any rust, numbers match, no signs of 
accident damage.

2) It has a front air dam which looks like the 'S' dam for that year, but 
there is no rubber bumper guard, so I suspect it's an aftermarket unit.  
Wheels are aftermarket BBS's with 205/60's, that look OK, but not 
like a rel Porsche.   Everything else looks stock.

3) Being a T, there are no front or rear sway bars, and minimal 
gauges--like only fuel level, but no oil level; oil temp, but not oil 
pressure. 

4) Transmission seems to be jammed in 2nd gear.  Cannot get it
to shift.  

5) It turned over nicely but wouldn't start when I looked at it.  Owner 
said he's had trouble starting it, but did manage to get it running last 
week.  This doesn't bother me.  I'd rebuild the engine anyway.

Owner said he'd be ecstatic to get $1500.  I'm pretty sure he'll take 
less, say $1000.  Since it is a project, I don't mind redoing the 
transmission, rebuilding the engine, etc.  That's the fun of it.

My concern is:

Even for $1000, is it worth it for a T.  I've heard people say the T's are 
great for around town, but is that really true or are they just saying 
that because they have a T and not an S?

Please e-mail me direct.  I get the digest, which comes late in the day, 
and have to get back to the owner this afternoon.

Many thanks.

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 12:26:00 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: 928 and power

Jerome (Porsche928@Delphi.com) gave me some info
about 600HP+ 928 engines.

Thanks for the non Flame. 

I've been waiting for the sound of a V-8 grenading at 9000
RPM before I replied to the 928 owner (Mike Selfridge)
flame, but it may take a few months.   ;-) 

I agree that the 928 is an AWESOME car, but I'm realistic.
I'm sure that the engine can put out this kind of power.
But at 9000 RPM and 600HP, how many hours will
it run? Drag cars with huge HP are considered successful
if they can run for a few MINUTES!

Bruce Anderson replied to me that :

>The reason that we don't see the high horsepower 928 engines is that the
>bottom end is not strong enough and they couldn't figure out how to beef it
>up. 

If Porsche and big $ race teams can't figure it out, I doubt 
these tuner$ can do it. (I hope I'm wrong, I hate seeing
people lose big $$ making their cars 'faster'.)

But at 300-400 HP, these should last forever and be one of the
best street cars ever. We'll see how long the 600HP ones
last. 

Regards, Mike  P.S. The earth is neither round nor flat.

lights are exactly. I've seen them in Japan- the headlights appear to be 
running on a very low wattage lamp, just enough to illuminate the 
headlamp to other drivers and not enough to illuminate the road.

Is it a regulation that people dim their headlights to these "city" 
lights when they are in a town with street lighting? Does anyone think that
this is a good idea?

a bit, which means I get to drive a lot of different rental cars, and
company Taurus's.  Although new cars have a smooth ride and good
handling, I never can wait to get home and take a spin in my 25 year
old bucket, even with all its quirks.

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 12:20:29 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: '91 911 C-2 oil leak repair

>Slick 50 would be a good problem sovler if you lose a lot of oil.  It binds
>to the inside of the walls.  It is really good stuff.  Ask your local parts
>store.

        Actually, a better solution is cyanoacrylate, also known as "Crazy
Glue".  Get a 1-qt bottle at an industrial supply place, and pour it in
your oil.  Oh--you 911 guys need the 1-gallon size, since you have so
much more oil than "normal" cars.
        If the oil leak doesn't clear up in short order (say, 100 miles)
then put 4-5 grams of iron filings into the oil.  This will bind with the
crazy glue and keep oil from seeping through the little gaps between the
cylinders and the heads.
        If the leak still hasn't cleared up 1K miles after this second
treatment, stronger medicine is in order.  Sprinkle aluminum and iron
filings all around the car's interior and (especially!) engine compart-
ment.  Douse thoroughly with gasoline, then sit in the drivers' seat and
light a road flare.  This should solve the oil leak completely, for all
time.  If you do this in your garage at home, it will also kill any pests
(rats, roaches, unwanted house guests) that are in your house at the time.
        As you can see, all of these approaches do what Slick-50 does,
but do it much better!

- --DD

Dave Darling   + Two dead 914s
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 95 10:23:33 -0700
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: 928 and power--flame

In response to the message from AnalogMike@aol.com regarding
flames and 928 engines going boom:

My apologies for the flame, but it was my first time flaming.
I thoroughly enjoyed doing it, though.

I agree, running high RPM's and high HP is risky.  The higher
you go with either or both, the more stress the engine is
subjected to.  A friend of mine races 928's, with engines in
the 400 to 500 HP range (naturally aspirated).  He revs to
10,000 RPM as a matter of course, and he usually rebuilds
every 3rd to 4th race for safety.

High RPM horse power can be great fun, when used in moderation.
To this end, I take the hot rodder's oath:

   "I swear that I will use the power sparingly.
   I promise to slow down at cross walks, and to keep at
   least two wheels on the ground at all times.
   I will use the power only for good, never for evil.
   So help my wallet."


                                                 --Mike

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 95 14:02:50 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: chips

>I am afraid I find the concept of any motor manufacturer tuning his product
>to "the last angstrom" somewhat ludicrous. If he did, one engine would be
>perfectly in tune and so would every other engine *exactly* the same. Not
>even a die hard Porscheophile like Stan could possibly believe that Porsche
>can produce a few thousand engines all *exactly* the same. Therefore, all of
>the others would be off tune.

So, how could you mass produce replacement chips to improve performance on
a certain model car without putting each particular car on the dyno?

How many cars / engines are used when developing a chip replacement to
conclude that a particular chip does in fact increase performance?  Also,
(assuming that multiple cars are tested with a proposed chip replacement)
how much does the performance improvement (if any) vary?  On one car the
chip produces x+5 HP, another x-3 HP...?


Matt Carpenter
'84 928S 62K
'88 9000t 169K
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 14:43:08 -0400

- ---------- Forwarded message ----------
The following are a sampling of REAL answers received on exams given
by the California Department of Transportation's driving school (read
Saturday Traffic School for moving violation offenders.)

Q: Do you yield when a blind pedestrian is crossing the road?
A: What for? He can't see my license plate.

Q: Who has the right of way when four cars approach a four-way stop at the
same time?
A: The pick up truck with the gun rack and the bumper sticker saying, "Guns
don't kill people. I do."

Q: What are the important safety tips to remember when backing your car?
A: Always wear a condom.

Q: When driving through fog, what should you use?
A: Your car.

Q: How can you reduce the possibility of having an accident?
A: Be too shit- faced to find your keys.

Q: What problems would you face if you were arrested for drunk driving?
A: I'd probably lose my buzz a lot faster.

Q: What changes would occur in your lifestyle if you could no longer
drive lawfully?
A: I would be forced to drive unlawfully.

Q: What are some points to remember when passing or being passed?
A: Make eye contact and wave "hello" if he/she is cute.

Q: What is the difference between a flashing red traffic light and a
flashing yellow traffic light?
A: The color.

Q: How do you deal with heavy traffic?
A: Heavy psychedelics.

Q: What can you do to help ease a heavy traffic problem?
A: Carry loaded weapons.

Q: Why would it be difficult to be a police officer?
A: It would be tough to be a dickhead all day long.



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 14:52:15 -0400
From: Jeffrey Puzas <jpuzas@astro.ge.com>
Subject: Avoiding water spots in S. CA


Are you sure your not seeing acid rain damage.  Can you wash away these
water spots or do they seem permanent?  Try washing the car early in the
morning when the air is moist and the water isn't evaporating so 
quickly.  Wash the car in the shade otherwise and keep the whole car
wet when you are washing it ,e.g., don't let the roof dry when you are
scrubbing the tires.  If this doesn't work then I suspect you have acid 
rain damage in which case they have to be wet sanded out and buffed -
lotsa work!

> We have very hard water in Southern CA.  Even though I use a
> chamois to dry my car after washing, it seems as though I always
> wind up with water spots.  Any suggestions?
> 
 ~e
~p


jpuzas@astro.ge.com

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 16:26:41 -0400 (EDT)
From: gp310ad@prism.gatech.edu (ROBERT DUCKWORTH)
Subject: Re: chips

I've not played with chips for 'P' cars but the ones I have played with 
are basically a lookup table. Based upon measured parameters the ignition
and injector timeing is adjusted. 

If the parameters in the factory chip are a compromise between performance
and other goals, i.e. emissions, economy/mileage then I would expect 
there to be some room for optimization. 

There may not be much room with the 'P' cars though :-)

 -bob

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 95 13:32:37 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: Why all this valve adjusting?


- --Boundary-8458585-0-0

Your car is almost 30 years old.. It's from the dinosaur age of automotive 
development.  Porsche recommended adjusting valves every 4-5000 miles. Normal 
maintenance on these buggies dictated that your 3-4Kmile service consisted of 
change oil and filter, adjust valves, reset points, and adjust carbs.  Cars of 
this vintage often had to have brakes adjusted as well(drum brakes).  Big 
changes have taken place over the last 30 years in metallurgy, materials, 
electronics, oils, etc. that have minimized maintenance.   Also, the racing 
set is much tougher on engine parts so valve stem, seat and adjuster wear and 
movement is greater. As a rule, the newer the car the less often one needs 
adjust. 
 
Ted Smith 
 
tres dinosaurus 
63 B Cab 
64 C Cpe 
68 912 Softback Targa 
 



- --Boundary-8458585-0-0
X-Orcl-Content-Type: message/rfc822

Reply-to: porschephiles-request@tta.com

It seems like I've read a recent thread of people adjusting the valves
to rid themselves of various problems.  So, a naive question from
a '66 912 owner is "why all this adjusting?"  Why do they keep
getting out of adjustment - is it age/wear?

It seems like distributers and valve adjustment are much
more common problems than I originally thought.

Ron  rondl@uscbu.att.com

Subject: GENERAL CARS--->Your opinions on safety


In my very biased opinion the safest car I have ever driven is my 911.
However, what is the net wisdom on anti lock brakes, crumple zones,
seat belts etc?

Anti lock: I can control much better the regular brakes on my 87 911 
and 87 Jetta, have very little feel with the anti lock brakes on 
our 94 GMC van. I was able to lock the wheels and brake in a straight line 
with the Jetta when a pedestrian stepped in front of me, and due to 
the extra scrub I stopped in time. With anti lock they would have played
the on-off brake game, and I would have hit him. 

Crumple zones. I know very little, but someone stated some tests 
on a German magazine (Mercedes versus Opel, and others). Could you 
please FAX me a copy of the test results (Prof. Korakianitis
at FAx 314-935-4014).

Seat belts. All I know is that mine are tightened up every time I drive,
and that if ever I'm in an accident I have to replace them.
What's the hoopla with Honda seat belts, anyway?

Any other topics?

Please reply direct to ---> tk@zeus.wustl.edu

I will compile the results and comments next Monday evening.

T. Korakianitis

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 15:39:58 -0400
From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
Subject: Re: chips

At 02:02 PM 4/28/95 PDT, mwc@lubrizol.com wrote:

>So, how could you mass produce replacement chips to improve performance on
>a certain model car without putting each particular car on the dyno?

I am always amazed by the lack of understanding people seem to have about
manufacturing. As a matter of interest, is statistics taught in High School
in the US? (I'm English and we get a smattering of it in school). I keep on
bumping into people who have the impression that the world is a perfect
place and while I can understand a lack of experience I am amazed at people
who think that you can make something which works on one car  and then they
think it will work on every other car. Perhaps I'm just getting old.

If you manufacture a quantity of anything, then the results will conform to
the well known bell shaped curve. Whether the criteria is power, weight or
even sensitivity to tuning, there will always be this curve indicating that
some are more and some are less, and the further away you get from the
standard, the fewer deviants there will be. If you set the ignition timing
at the top of the curve, 50% of the engines will ping! So it is set back so
that 90% or 95% or even 99.999% won't ping with that timing figure.( I don't
know what percentage Bosch uses) This means that 40% or 45% or 49.999%,as
the case may be, of these engines won't ping if the ignition is advanced.

We move the baseline up a little so that we optimise say 80% of the engines.
The more performance you go for, the fewer respond and yes, the best way is
to tune each one on the dyno individually. As manufacturers we have to
tolerance the chips we make, to balance the performance gains with the
number of returns we get from customers who, at one end of the scale say the
increase is not enough because the timing was not aggressive enough, and at
the other end, from customers who say the car pings because the timing was
too aggressive.

This is why we offer a custom programmming service, so that we can get
closer to the optimum by getting performance feedback from the customers and
altering the settings accordingly. It also explains why we get variable
results from reprogramming chips. Some work, some don't and of those that do
work, the results can vary tremendously.

I am quite happy that there are sceptics amongst you, and there are people
who have tried a chip in their car and it was less than they hoped and so
they sent it back. There are also a lot of very happy customers out there
who have tried a chip in their car and enjoyed the results. I have worldwide
sales (and I mean worldwide) of about $10,000,000 each year and I am not
nearly the biggest player in the US so we must be doing something right.

Now, you guys aren't going to like this bit, but, the latest GM system
presents a bigger challenge than Bosch because it is more advanced. They
have an excellent knock detection system and the engine rides on it nearly
all of the time, running just below detonation. Hence, when we advance the
ignition to get more power, we get zilch. The best I have seen on an LT1 is
13HP and on my Impala SS I got 3HP! The Bosch system is not as nasty as
this....yet. That is an example of the electronics reducing the deviation
from standard which works really well.

Finally, in case you think I am trying use the list as a sales media, I have
been on the net for about 1 year, and in all that time, I have given away
about 10 chips and sold 2 or 3, so I'm not about to waste too much time
trying hard to get a marketing spiel across, just don't discount the product
(mine or anyone elses) because one or two people have found that it was not
succesful in their case. They are the ones at the left hand end of the bell
shaped curve:)
Peter Wales
Superchips Inc                          "Timing is everything"


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1363                         Sat Apr 29 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 16:22:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Why all this valve adjusting?

> It seems like I've read a recent thread of people adjusting the valves
> to rid themselves of various problems.  So, a naive question from
> a '66 912 owner is "why all this adjusting?"  Why do they keep
> getting out of adjustment - is it age/wear?

Ahh... Well, Ron, you've just either told us how old you are, or that
you never worked on cars Back When.

It's an "age" problem, all right, but not the way you're thinking. It
is that these parts come from an Age when things were done differently.
Great pains were taken to design things to close tolerances, and for high
performance applications, you had to adjust all sorts of things to keep them 
in their optimal range. Everything was mechanical, there were few power
assist items and the dash board clock was as close to "sophisticated
electronics" as most cars came.

Look at the Driver's Manual for your car sometime -- every 3,000 miles 
you had to adjust valves, change oil, lube and adjust the front end
(well, if you have a 356 - 912s went a bit longer and there was no 
"adjust"), check ignition timing, and check the points.  What happened?
Well, people decided that doing all that was a load of shit and devised
ways around it. Hydraulic valve followers. Breakerless ignition. Capacitive
discharge. Sealed ball joints. Fuel injection. That sort of thing.

It's called Progress, and means that if you think that how any car built
in the last 5-10 years is "normal", then you'll be *REALLY* surprised when
you start driving a high precision sports car from the 50s through mid-70s.

Stan

>to tune each one on the dyno individually. As manufacturers we have to

>This is why we offer a custom programmming service, so that we can get

This makes sense.  Now it is occurring to me that the holy grail of engine
management would be to calculate engine variables based on closed-loop
operation.  It seems that a highly optimized engine map is only a snapshot
of optimal performance based on engine condition at that time.  The
latest ECUs can adapt, but can they adapt enough?  Or, would it be better
to have another "snapshot" taken?

What's the price of a custom tune?

>Now, you guys aren't going to like this bit, but, the latest GM system
>presents a bigger challenge than Bosch because it is more advanced. They

I already found out earlier this week that my '84 928S (L-Jetronic) and

Ford Tempo (EEC-IV).

>Finally, in case you think I am trying use the list as a sales media, I have

Not at all.  Personally, I'm happy to be able to actually converse with
someone who knows what they're talking about.  Unless you do this for a
living, it's not often you can get past the marketing hype and understand
the engineering / design principles that can allow you to decide for yourself
whether this would work and if the tradeoffs are acceptable.

Again, I've never seen a chip ad say "engine longevity and drivability may
be negatively impacted."  Again, I haven't read Superchips' brochures.

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 95 15:12:12 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924 CIS


I've been following the thread about the cold start injector and some of the less expensive cures for the problem. The cold start injector can 
stay on for extended periods without damage to the injector. You will 
experience a significant DECREASE in mileage. 

Other than the warmup regulator failing, the other cause of failure is 
broken wires right at the injector, under the rubber boot. Easiest way 
to check is when the engine is cold. Unplug the connector, then test 
to see if 12 volts is present on one of the pins. If it isn't, and the 
warm up regulator is switching correctly, the wire is broken. To test 
the solenoid, just measure across the two pins on its connector, there 
should be less than 10 ohms present.

If you are seeking to enrich a 1980 - 82 924 Turbo or 80.5 - 82 924, 
there is a device called a frequency valve located just under the 
throttle plate on the manifold. It works in the same manner as a DME 
injector, only it bleeds off excess pressure to the return line to the 
gas tank.  This may be altered to increase the enrichment on a 924 Turbo
(all models that use this system) to avoid changing of the fuel 
distributor. The 924 Carrera does have a different fuel distributor, 
which is a recalibrated 928 unit. The GTS also uses this system. The 
GTR uses a long stack mechanical system. The GTS uses a completely 
different intake and intercooler than the Carrera 924.

If you are driving a normally asirated 924 on the street, the best thing
is to use a bypass for the catalyst and a good header with the stock 
rear exhaust section. There is a 11 HP gain this way with no fooling 
with the CIS. I did some serious dyno tests for a well-known aftermarket
supplier. This was the best. We also found that the 80.5 - 82 924 
delivers 14 more real HP at the rear wheels than the earlier cars. They
have the best CIS, exhaust and head of all the 2.0 924s.

Jim Pasha

Date: 28 Apr 1995 15:14:50 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: A/C Leak/Repair Question

                      Subject:                              Time:  2:55 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         A/C Leak/Repair Question              Date:  4/28/95

Let me apologize in advance ....
Our e-mail system went toes-up for several days just after I submitted the
following question and I've missed about 6 digests, so I've probably missed
any/all replies.

Would anyone who replied to this message (or someone who would like to) give
it a try, once again?  I sure could use some expert advice!

- ------------  Original message with latest info follows  ---------

A recent thread on auto a/c indicated that there are
some P-philers out there who understand more about
air conditioners that I do and I'm hoping that your
collective wisdom can help me out of a jam.

My '84 928S sprang a leak in the a/c recently and the 
dealer (after an hour and a half of diagnostics) found 
a pinhole leak in an alloy pipe running from the
compressor hose to the firewall area. (I think it goes to a
fuel cooler, then to a short pipe which in turn goes 
through the firewall to the expansion valve.   My first
 thought was that it would be an easy fix ... well, they
 want a fairly hefty price when you add up labor, parts 
(pipe, gaskets, freon, etc) and sales tax.  Being a 
cheapskate (squeezing the nickel until the buffalo farts), 
I've been thinking about doing the pipe replacement 
myself.

Here are my questions.  First, I've been told that  the pipe is on the high
pressure side of the compressor.  Can I 
either solder the pinhole or have a shop weld it closed 
such that it will hold up under pressure?  Would a radiator 
shop do that kind of work or would I take the pipe to
an a/c shop?  A machine shop?   Do I need a pipe, or 
could I just make a custom hose using the same type 
of a/c hose and fittings that are coming from the 
compressor?

Second, would it be worth risking buying a salvaged pipe
if I can find one?  How would I test it before installing? 
How many PSI should it be able to take?

Third, if I do the removal and replacement work myself, 
what do I need to do to avoid damaging my system?  For
 example, I seem to recall a statement in one of the 
threads that if the system is exposed to outside air, 
the drier (?) will be contaminated/ruined.  When I take 
the pipe out, of course the system will be exposed to the
air, so should I just plug the compressor hose and the 
fuel cooler opening?  With what should I plug them (a 
baggie wrapped around the hose and secured with 
electrical tape?)??

Fourth, have any of you had this type of problem?  The 
mechanic said he had never seen one of these pipes leak before.

Any and all suggestions would help me greatly as all I
know about a/c is where the button is to turn it on! 
FWIW, I do most of my own maintenance and am
somewhat mechanically inclined.

TIA for all your help!

John
'84 928S (nice and toasty in the sun!)

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 95 16:03:21 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: muffler

Speaking of his '84 911, Geert Pallemans wrote:

> Does anyone have any first-hand info on 
> after market mufflers for my type of car? Which one sounds great for 
> the road? Hate to say it, but my wife's 95 Miata has a more glorious 
> exhaust note than my 911!  

I have an Ansa on my '83 with SSI headers and the sound is nicely
businesslike, with a complex resonance around 2200 rpm that I find
pleasing and unique to the 911.  Unfortunately the Ansa build quality is
less than pleasing!  Also I've no idea how this setup would perform on 
your '84 which has very different induction plumbing.  I hope some 
P-phile has access to some dyno data.

BTW I'm sure everyone's heard this, but the Miata sounds the way it
does (nice, I've got to admit) because the designers spent hours with a
spectrum analyzer and a fleet of vintage British sports cars.  In Japan
this is considered Good... and they're good at it.  I find it
merely Telling...

Ed Mellinger

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 16:39:37 -0700
From: Bill@bpetersen.com (Bill Petersen)
Subject: Re: GENERAL CARS--->Your opinions on safety

When I attended a Derek Bell driving school some years ago I had my first
look at Porsches with ABS. We used our own cars, mine was an '85 cpe. Part
of the school was practicing stopping without lock-up. Hitting the breaks
hard up front, then letting up a bit allowing the rear to work as well. (a
great way to demonstrate the value of refreshing the break fluid now and
then) Well, there were a couple of early C2s in attendance. The
instructions to these drivers was to more or less just stand to the breaks
(this was all straight line stopping from around 60 or so). Damn
impressive. None of the non-ABS cars pulled up as short as the ABS cars.
Not once. I now have a C2 and while I liked the feel (mechanical) of the
breaks on my '85 much better, I think the C2 will stop quicker for me on
wet or dry pavement. Not so sure on sandy/gravel surfaces.

...Bill

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 17:20:32 -0700
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Test Pipe and Catalytic Converter

>Apologies if this has come up before, as I am a new member of the list.  
>My catalytic converter is about to give up the ghost - it has about 
>70,000 miles on it - and I would like to replace it with a "test pipe," 
>both because is cheaper and because it should give me a little more 
>power.  Does anybody have any experience with this?  Also, any hints 

You don't say where you live, but by your address I'd have to guess Hawaii 
(boy I'm smart. :)

Anyways, you'd have to check your local laws, but I know here in New York, 
and I'm 95% sure that everywhere else in the USA, there's three words you 
should remember: "ILLEGAL ILLEGAL ILLEGAL". Don't get me wrong, I have no 
problem with, say, non-DOT-approved bright headlights, but cats are a 
totally different thing. I believe that you aren't supposed to pass 
inspection with a test pipe, it's illegal for parts places to sell them 
(unless the car is "off-road"), and some places have exhaust sniffing as 
part of the inspection - obviously, they'll really hound you there.

Of course, they are incredibly expensive, but...

If you can do it and get away with it, go for it, but be aware that the 
government looks very unkindly to such things. Them's the breaks...

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 17:21:47 -0700
From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
Subject: Re: Test Pipe and Catalytic Converter


Here is what I did, it may be of help to you :
I tried to remove the bolts on my 84 911 exhaust system but they were
welded on from age and rust, so I took the easy route and spent $25 and
saved my fingers and a lot of bad language!
I went to my local muffler guy who I trusted from previos work, and had him
burn off/melt off the nuts and bolts on my exh system. I asked him to do
ALL the bolts from the headers back to the banana muffler. I then replaced
all the nuts and bolts with fresh ones and used anti seize stuff. I then
went home and installed a test pipe and a Bursche muffler(new gaskets
installed of course) I used a metal brush to clean the pipe surfaces. I
felt a little increase in the performance of the car, but it may have been
psychalogical (spelled right?). The sound of the Bursche is music to my
ears and it is not loud at all IMHO. When the windows are closed, I can
still hear the Boxer singing as usual.
Now I can change mufflers in about an hour. (used anti seize on the O2
sensor too).


        Hope this helps.

Ehab.


>Apologies if this has come up before, as I am a new member of the list.
>My catalytic converter is about to give up the ghost - it has about
>70,000 miles on it - and I would like to replace it with a "test pipe,"
>both because is cheaper and because it should give me a little more
>power.  Does anybody have any experience with this?  Also, any hints
>about taking off the converter without have to grind off the nuts and
>bolts?  I will, of course, flood them with a good rust solvent before
>taking the socket wrench to them, but is there any other helpful hint
>that you can provide?
>
>Rick Castberg
>1982 911SC
>1987 M-B 300E

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 17:56:44 -0700
From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
Subject: Re: Test Pipe and Catalytic Converter

        You are right Jeff, it is illegal to run w/o a Cat in most of the
USA. That is why the pipe is called a test pipe and can be sold thru mail
order. I am not sure of the laws in Hawaii thu.
 I run with a stock muffler and a cat or a Bursche muffler and a cat. My
car passed California smog with both mufflers no problems (had to lean out
the mixture to compensate for an old O2).


        Ehab.

>should remember: "ILLEGAL ILLEGAL ILLEGAL". Don't get me wrong, I have no
>problem with, say, non-DOT-approved bright headlights, but cats are a
>totally different thing. I believe that you aren't supposed to pass
>inspection with a test pipe, it's illegal for parts places to sell them

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 18:15:44 -0800 (PDT)

Subject: 928 Clutch Job: DIY?


Hi all,

I'm gearing up to research the possiblity of doing the 928 clutch 
replacement by myself. I've gone through the Workshop manual 
couple times already. I seems not impossible to do it myself.

(1) Do I need to drop the transmission to replace the clutch? 

    The manual says no. My boss, who is driving a 944 Turbo Cup Sport
    says maybe. If yes, I guess I'll need the transmission stand
    and some alignment tools, which would be discourage enough for
    me to take it to the $hop.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 19:39:38 -0500
From: stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda)
Subject: Re: Setting up a 944 for racing

>
.  I would like to improve my "87" 944 handling but don't want
>to live with a real stiff suspension.  Is thicker sway bars the way to go
>or do I have to go to stiffer springs and torsion bars.  What are the trade-
>offs?
>
>.]
>
What do you currently have as far as sway bars? The factory front and rear
are pretty god, but don't give you any adjustability. I'm not a expert, but
for street and occasion "spirited" driving I would go up to a heavier
spring, mabye 220 lbs, slightly larger tortion bars, mabye 26mm, and some
adjustable swaybars. Weltmeister sells both, and they work well. If you have
factory bars, try the spring and tortion bar increase first. You can do it
all yourself, but the T-bars are tough. It's worth your cost to have a shop
put them in for you. Remember, this will make your ride harder, but it
shoulden't rattle your kidneys. I liked the feel when I had this setup in
mine. A lot of the local fast 944 drivers-education types(some of who are
very fast) have the same basic setup in their street cars.

Hope this helps.

Scott
Scott D Sanda

Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 22:10:03 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Several 911 questions

> I have a couple of questions as a new Porsche owner.

Hey! Welcome aboard!!!

> First, and this crossed my mind because of the stuck cold start injector
> thread, what kind of mileage should I expect from my 1979 911SC? 

It varies. Remember this is a 3 liter engine, and high performance
at that. I used to get about 420 km to a fillup, which is what? About
21 km/gallon, times .62 is... 13 mpg. So I guess you're about right
on...

> Second, when I turn the ignition to the On position, something electrical
> begins humming fairly loudly. I believe it persists after the engine has
> started, but it's a little hard to tell because of the engine noise. What is
> this sound?

Fuel pump. If it's making a lot of noise, then it's getting old and tired
and you need to get ready to replace it.

> Third, the driver side window sticks at about the midpoint on its way down.
> Sometimes it will go all the way down, sometimes it won't. What can I do to
> remedy this?

Something is wonky in the regulator. Or it could be the motor on the window
on that side. In any event, a competent body shop can fix it for you.

Stan

group coached me through the R&R.  I still have the posts
if you're interested in any hints regarding how to replace
it.  Rebuilt units go for about $250. The other option
would be to find an alternator/generator repair shop to
rebuild it for you.

Porschephiles #1364                         Sun Apr 30 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 29 Apr 95 03:32:12 EDT
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: Re: GENERAL CARS--->Your opinions on safety


> I was able to lock the wheels and brake in a straight line 
> with the Jetta when a pedestrian stepped in front of me, and due to 
> the extra scrub I stopped in time. With anti lock they would have played
> the on-off brake game, and I would have hit him. 

The "on-off brake game" usually occurs at over 10Hz (10x per second).

The primary advantage of anti-lock brakes is that you
can steer while under heavy braking, even on slick surfaces.  
Straight-line braking performance in most car mag. tests does 
not seem to improve much with ABS, as you suggest, but that's with
a skilled driver on a dry surface.  Try stopping in a straight
line by locking your wheels on a wet road covered with fallen 
leaves.

It's interesting to note a recent concern that ABS has not
made cars safer, but may have actually contributed to some
accidents.  This is allegedly because people think they will stop 
faster, and they forget to steer around the obstacle/person/etc.

 -Scott Humphreys
scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com
87 944

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 01:57:08 -0600
From: Steve "THRUD" Cook <steve@prism.nmt.edu>
Subject: Re: 89 951 Oil change story

Regarding driving through water with a 944....

  The biggest thing you should worry about is getting water in the
air intake (front driverside fender).  It is rather low and can suck water r
right into your cylinders...  Not Good....  I was just looking through
some of the p-phile archives, and in the 90 archive there is a 
pretty good discussion of driving through water with a 944.  I suggest checkin'
it out (but it does take a while to sort through..)

 -steve

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 04:48:03 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: alternator woes...

Buzz,

The fact that your alternator light doesn't always come on when you turn on
the key indicates worn brushes in the voltage regulator.  If one of the
brushes isn't making contact with the commutator you lose the continuity
required to light the light.  This is not an unusual problem on 911s with
internal voltage regulators.  It can possibly be cured by replacing the
voltage regulator but the big question will be, "how much wear is there on
the commutator itself.  If it's minimal,  you can probably replace the
regulator without any further alternator work.  If the grooves where the
brushes make contact are deep I would have an electrical specialist take a
look at it and see if it can be turned.  If they are really deep, (2-3mm)
 you will probably have to replace the alternator as the brushes in the new
regulator will wear out very quickly.

Hope this helps

Pat Moyle

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 08:16:36 -0400

more time than you thought.  It is just one of the laws of nature.  I
have the luxury of letting something sit in the garage for a couple of
weeks while I order more parts or go get more tools.  I would not look
forward to undertaking such a task as a 928 clutch replacement in a
garage I rented for the weekend.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 95 10:07:24 EDT
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: Re: Several 911 questions

> > Second, when I turn the ignition to the On position, something electrical
> > begins humming fairly loudly. I believe it persists after the engine has
> > started, but it's a little hard to tell because of the engine noise. What is
> > this sound?
> 
> Fuel pump. If it's making a lot of noise, then it's getting old and tired
> and you need to get ready to replace it.

If the noise is high-pitched and coming from the engine compartment, it's
the Bosch capacitor-discharge (CD) ignition unit, and electronic thingy
that generates high voltage spark. It's supposed to whine like that.

Stefan

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 09:32:57 -0500 (CDT)
From: blackfoot.austin.ibm.com!alanr@ibmpa
Subject: pre-purchase woes.

Dear Porschephiles, 

I am in the process of buying my first Porsche and have run across what 
I thought to be an excellent 87 944S for 9950.00.  It has low miles (76K), 
nice paint, and nice uncracked interior.  However, after a prepurchase 
inspection was done the following items were found:
  
1.  Cam belt shows signs of edge shaving.  They speculate that the 
    pulley was incorrectly installed.  Front seals leaking also.
    To Fix:  Replace front seal and fix pulley (p&l)........    507
    To Replace cam and roller belt (parts)..................     77
    To Replace ALL rollers at same time.(p&l)...............    350

2.  Starter needs to be replaced.  Current starter (non-bosch unit)
    has cracked housing, cracked solenoid, and cracked mountings.
    To Fix:  Replace with rebuilt Bosch unit.(p&l)..........    412

3.  Alternator cooling hose missing.
    To Fix:  Replace hose..(p&l)............................     50

4.  Power Steering cooler hose leak..(p&l)..................     65

5.  Lower balance shaft housing leaking oil.
    To Fix:  Replace seals  .(p&l)..............................540
   
6.  Motor mount passenger side sagging. 
    To Fix:  When replacing 5. above..(p&l).................    330

7.  Sway Bar bushing swollen from oil spillage.
    To Fix:  Replace bushing. .(p&l)..........................   40

8.  Some body damage to front headlight area.  Inspection shows
    that body work was done correctly. .....................    n/a
    All fixes recommended: 1 - 7          2326.00
    Less 350 for all rollers being good   1976.00

The seller is very reluctant to lower the price of the car any to 
compensate for any of these repairs.  His attitude is that this is just
the way it is with Porsches (he has a 928 too).  I don't expect a 
full 2k off the price, but at least halfway would be fair in my opinion.
Am I way off base?  Should I just walk away and find another?  That's
what my wife thinks.  I'm a little fuzzy right now.  It could be Porsche
pheremones.  ;-)

 - Alan Reynolds				( alanr@austin.ibm.com )

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 11:38:19 -0400 (EDT)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: Parking and running lights

I believe the feature you're referring to on Porsches,BMWs, and on M-Bs 
is a parking light, which is either the left or the right one. This is 
useful mainly in Europe, where the roads are narrow, and when a little 
light on a dark may go a long way to prevent an accident. These aren't 
running lamps, but parking lamps. 

As an aside, if you've ever seen a Saab or Volvo (in Euro-spec), there'll 
be a "white" light below the front turn signal indicator--this is a 
running light, and they've had 'em in Sweden for well over a decade. 


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 11:40:34 -0400 (EDT)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: City lights?

"City lights", or running lights aren't the headlight bulb operating at a 
dimmer wattage. Rather, they are usually the same type of bulb one finds 
light dashboards. I use to replace the ones on my M-B at least once a 
year. Overall, they give the viewer a larger "footprint" than a small 
"parking lamp."


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 12:18:59 -0700
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: 914 left (!) suspension problems!

Well, I almost feel like crying - just got the official word on my 
rubbing left rear tire. A little background:

Last weekend, was taking a right-hand turn off an expressway, hit a 
bump, and the 914 oversteered. Not badly, but I didn't think it would 
at all - I wasn't going that fast. The car stunk of rubber smoke for a 
couple minutes. I glanced, looked like all was in order, and forgot 
about it.

Later in the week, noticed funny noises from the left rear - felt like 
a flat front left tire, or no spring in the left rear. Noticed a rub 
line on the inside of the left tire - it had rubbed the inner fender by 
the top of the tire. (195/50 tires probably didn't help. :) It hadn't 
rubbed bad, but it had definetely hit. Do a little observation, notice 
the car sitting a little lower on that side. I knew the springs were 
really worn out, so I thought perhaps I broke a spring - though it was 
quiet, and I couldn't see how that'd make the tire rub. So I've got my 
Eiback 100lb (110lb?) springs on their way from California (to New 
York.)

So today I'm out with my restoration friend who does the work on the 
car, and the whole thing sounds a little fishy. We jack up the corner, 
and notice a bolt ALMOST all the way out of the CV joint by the tranny. 
OK, we replace that - the others seemed OK. Sounds a little strange, 
but not like something that'd make the wheel move. (Did I mention the 
entire wheel could be moved around a little when it was jacked up?) 
While moving it, I notice... The suspension was broken off from the 
body ahead of the tire. Damn rust! So anyways, it looks like I need to 
find a nice bit patch piece to repair it, however, everyone has the 
right one (from the usual battery-tray rust), and noone has the left 
one! Plus, it looks like we'll have to cut away the quarter panel to 
get access to weld in the new piece... And since it's stronger metal 
(probably 16 guage?), it's not something that he can fabricate.

Anyone else had this experience, or have any advice? (OK, so I don't 
feel like crying, but it is a bit of a bummer. *Sigh* Especially when 
it's my daily driver - gonna have to borrow a car to get me to work 
while it gets repaired.) Am I the only one with a 914 that's relatively 
solid on the passenger side, and all rotted on the driver's side?

"A boy with a 914 and his money are soon parted..."  :)

- -- 
| Jeff Kyle                                    "Memo to myself:           |
| jeffk914@ix.netcom.com                        Do the dumb things        |
| Scottsville, NY, USA                                  I gotta do."      |
| "Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914                       -They Might Be Giants |

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 16:45:12 -0700
From: dem@best.com (Dennis Mitsch)
Subject: 914 rear trunk height adjustment?


The rust repair is coming along fine.  I (and the current rain storm :)
did a little experimenting to attempt to find out where the water
is getting in.

The main culprit appears to be the passenger side height adjustment.
The weather stripping just isn't making contact with the lid.  The
water runs down the edge of the trunk, onto the interior bottom portion,
and then drips inside.

The height is incorrect (about 1/8") right above the hinge and
progresses all the way down the entire side.  If it was just the
far edge, I'd bend the lid a bit.  But since it's off by the hinge,
it seems like there should be some other sort of adjustment.

Sooo, how is this adjustment made?  The trunk hinge has 3 or 4
bolts to fiddle with.  The Haynes manual is totally useless (suprise).

To me, it looks like I will need to disconnect the torsion spring.  To
remove that, Haynes says I have to take off the trunk lid.  This
would make it rather difficult to adjust the height of the lid. :)

Anyone done this before?

Dennis Mitsch
1988 944S (dry)
1974 914 2.0 (wet)

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 19:05:10 -0700
From: cjrebbe@rain.org (Chris and Jessica)
Subject: ongoing capacitive discharge dilema

Hello to one of the better subsets of society, Porsche lovers.
  I'm Chris. Been reading porschephiles for about 3 weeks now. Really
enjoying the comradarie, razzing, and sharing of expert and not so expert
information. I'm hoping some of you patient and wise guru's can help me in a
search for some answers to my questions. (BTW I don't know a hellava lot
compaired to you guys) Here's the deal:  
   1970 911T. Rebuilt/restored/redone by a guy who use to race and set track
records at Riverside.(So I'm told by my father who bought the car then sold
it to me). So now it has a '76 911 2.7L flat six, Webber six pac, zero emission
controls, and lots of things I am ignorant of that I'm told if I did ever
take it to the racecource of my local PCA region (Santa Barbara) someone
would want to take it off my hands.(super tricked-out suspension etc.)
Anyway, my problems lies in the ignitoin system. A few years ago the car
wouldn't start after it had been running for a long time.(1hr or longer
trips) I was told that sometimes when starters get hot that they don't
function properly. This was only a minor inconveniece because I didn't go
that far usually. But then the car began a halfway cutting out or a lurching
effect while driving. This went on sporatically for a day or two then the
car would start dying while I was driving it. (I think this is getting to
long winded so I'll start abbreviating). Pull to side of road and car won't
fire, starter ok though. It seemed that if I had someone crank it over while
I banged on the coil or cds unit then it would start again. Anyway, cds unit
finally goes out (no whistling sound, no voltage to coil). Purchase junkyard
Permatune for $100 as well put in new points, rotor, and dist. cap.  Used
cds lasts 2 days.  Coil and rpm sensor both ohm out ok. Call all parts
houses around country from the back of Panorama magazine. Can't afford $1300
Bosche cds so purchase NEW Permatune cds for $190. It lasts 1 week. Decide
to take it to the specialists(local P dealer) They tell me I've got a bad
cds unit(no kidding). $250 for a new "Permatune" cds plus labor. I tried to
tell them that it seemed something was blowing out the cds unit but to no
avail. Of course car runs fine then but unit goes out after a year. Is there
any way to figure out why I'm having this problem??  Ground is good and cds
gets 12v.  I've now purchased a used Bosche for $100 and car runs but still
lurches. Sometimes won't start and seems to want to fire when ignition is
being turned off.( coil is not backwards). Thanks for listening and allowing
a hack like me to partake of the porschephiles.                              
                                               Chris

convertable 356 (dad's)
'84 944 (mom's) almost crashed it in high school.
'70 911T(dad's then mine)

the sidewalk and half on the road.  Leaving the turn signal down leaves a 
warning light for night traffic.  On my '84 it also runs down the battery -
 more than once.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 21:01:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Auto A/C Leak & Repair

John -

Let me reply to your recent request:

> Here are my questions.  First, the pipe is on the high 
> pressure side of the compressor.  Can I either solder the
> pinhole or have a shop weld it closed such that it will
> hold up under pressure?  Would a radiator shop do that
> kind of work or would I take the pipe to an a/c shop?  A
> machine shop?   Do I need a pipe, or could I just
> make a custom hose using the same type of a/c hose and 
> fittings that are coming from the compressor?

You can have it welded, but since I don't know what kind of material the 
pipe is made out of it may be tough to weld.  The high side of the 
compressor usually sees pressures of around 275-300 PSI but during a very 
hot day it may see pressures around 350PSI.  Making a custom out of a 
rubber type material will only leak more.  Freon has a way of finding its 
way out of any porous material.

> Second, would it be worth risking buying a salvaged pipe
> if I can find one?  How would I test it before installing?  How
> many PSI should it be able to take?

A used one would be fine if it hold pressure.  To test is going to be 
tough with out special fittings and a high pressure compressor.

> Third, if I do the removal and replacement work myself, what 
> do I need to do to avoid damaging my system?  For example, 
> I seem to recall a statement in one of the threads that if
> the system is exposed to outside air, the drier (?) will be
> contaminated/ruined.  When I take the pipe out, of course
> the system will be exposed to the air, so should I just plug
> the compressor hose and the expansion valve opening?  With
> what should I plug them (a baggie wrapped around the hose 
> and secured with electrical tape?)??

Anything to plug the hole is fine.  Just don't let it sit around with air 
getting into it along with the water vapor that's in the air.  Next, you 
should try and get the system evacuated after fixing the hose.  That is 
removing all air and moisture that has gotten in with a vacuum pump.

> Fourth, have any of you had this type of problem?  The 
> mechanic said he had never seen one of these pipes leak before.

Usually the pipes don't have a problem unless there has been a lot of 
vibration that has caused a flare joint to fail at a fitting from being 
stressed back and forth at a small distance; tough to imagine but I just 
had it happen on a two month old power steering high pressure line at the 
fitting.  Nice stress fracture at the flare joint.

If you can't get access to the freon to refill, the shop you take it to 
should be able to evacuate the system for you.


Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1365                         Sun Apr 30 21:57:25 CDT 1995
Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 03:18:52 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 left (!) suspension problems!

> I notice... The suspension was broken off from the 
> body ahead of the tire. 

That's called the "suspension console", for what it's worth.

> Anyone else had this experience, or have any advice? (OK, so I don't 
> feel like crying, but it is a bit of a bummer. *Sigh* Especially when 
> it's my daily driver - gonna have to borrow a car to get me to work 
> while it gets repaired.) Am I the only one with a 914 that's relatively 
> solid on the passenger side, and all rotted on the driver's side?

Ummm. I'll guess "yes". Just about all the 914s that have broken
suspension consoles that I've ever seen had bad units on the
passenger side, *NOT* the driver's side. In fact, I know that you can
trivally get replacement weld-in units for the passenger side (BTDT)
but I'm not even sure that part is listed for the driver side!

Your absolute best bet is to find a good body shop with a good fabricator
and see if he can make enough parts to fix it. You'll need a factory
shop manual for the dimensions and offset for the pickups, etc.

Good luck!! Let us know how it comes out.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 03:19:58 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)

> The rust repair is coming along fine.  I (and the current rain storm :)
> did a little experimenting to attempt to find out where the water
> is getting in.

Ummmm. Before you get carried away with all this, in my long years of
experience, the water leak is *ALWAYS* around the tail lights. Always.

Stan

Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 11:38:31 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re:914 Suspension.......

Jeff,

Since the suspension console problem on the left side is relatively unusual,
perhaps finding a dismantler who would be willing to cut that area out of a
previously discarded chassis would be a possibility.

When I was building my SCCA IT car I acquired miscellaneous body and chassis
parts from Tom Conway at Carquip in Boulder Colorado.
His phone # is 303-443-1343.  Colorado is not salt country so chassis parts
are generally in good condition plus Tom is knowledgeable in the body/chassis
repair techniques required to fix this problem.  If you describe to him how
much of this area you need I'm sure he can help you out.  (You might discuss
this with your body man first to make sure you get what he feels he needs to
make the repair).

We see this problem more on cars with stiff suspension and sticky tires which
are used in track events.  This is why the use of chassis reinforcing in this
area is a good idea as most 914's will start coming apart under these
conditions.  So far my 914-6 has escaped any chassis problems, but since it
is used exclusively for Club Racing and Drivers Ed, I check it thoroughly
after every event. 

Since this will probably be a fairly expensive repair, and it sounds like you
have other rust problems, you might have to evaluate your commitment to this
particular car and weigh the cost of repair against the cost of replacement.

Good Luck

Pat Moyle

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 13:40:33 -0400
From: Jrhetten@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Apr 95 12:18:15 PDT
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE:  914 trunk leaks

>From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
>Subject: Re: 914 rear trunk height adjustment?
>
>> The rust repair is coming along fine.  I (and the current rain storm :)
>> did a little experimenting to attempt to find out where the water
>> is getting in.
>
>Ummmm. Before you get carried away with all this, in my long years of
>experience, the water leak is *ALWAYS* around the tail lights. Always.
>
>Stan

Good rule to always follow:  Never say always.

The rear trunk in my 914 fills up with water when it rains.  So I
followed the sage advice and hermetically sealed the tail lights.
(New gaskets/lenses, RTV, enough gunk to keep a diaper pail from
smelling on a hot day!)  Trunk still filled with water.  After
a really good rain, the pockets for the top latches would have
water in them.

I have found the path of the water.  It's some weird capillary action
around the inside of the trunk lid.  So the weatherstripping around
the trunk is important.

Gary.

A cheaper solution would be to get the jack pad sold by Automotion,
maybe others.  It fits into the jack port and should give you the
extra clearance you need.  It does in mine (whereas my mechanic needs
me to lift the car up a bit so he can get *his* jack underneath!).
