Date: Sun, 30 Apr 95 19:52:29 EDT
From: weltyc@cs.vassar.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: May Porsching Column


Permission is given to use this material in any publication as long
as my name and affiliation are left intact.  If you can, send me the
issue.  Previous Porsching columns are available at
http://www.cs.vassar.edu/faculty/welty/porsching

PORSCHING  by Chris Welty
Hudson-Champlain Region

When You Wish Upon A Star - Part V


We soon left the mall to the mallians, and proceeded to an appointment
with destiny.  John, who was more attuned to mystic forces than Frank
or I was since donning the Madam Zelda hat, clearly felt it first. 

"Chris, this is the car you will buy," he said as we arrived.

I didn't believe him at all, but the accuracy of his prediction is
still further proof that we were merely following a predetermined
course. 

We had developed during our feast at the mall a new strategy for
impressing the owners of cars we visited.  This strategy employed a
tool we had yet to use in our mind games with those we dealt with -
Karl was actually German.  We decided to pose as a team of German
Porsche specialists, John and Karl would perform their usual
inspection of the car,  except that when they found anything they
would say something in German.   The plan called for me to stand with
a clipboard, like some obergruppenfuhrer, pretending to understand
them and jotting down notes.  Karl fed John some German phrases about
torsion bars and rust, and after several failed rehersals I settled on
some canned responses such as, "Ja," "Ja?" and of course, "Gut." 

We assaulted the car in Blitzkreig-like fashion, while I, employing a
heavy German accent, explained to the owner what they were doing.
Karl spewed forth a steady stream of observations, which he later told
us was the words to a song he learned in elementary school.   The car
was a metallic blue 1971 911T.  The original color had been burgundy,
but it had been repainted as the result of an accident suffered in
1973.  The paint actually looked very good for fifteen years old, and
luckily all the rubber had been well preserved since it was under the
paint. 

It was difficult to tell how much of an effect our act had on this
guy, because we soon revealed what turned out to be our most
impressive tool.  There are only a few things that I can whip out of
my "tool belt" the sight of which will fill people with awe - jaws
drop open, and the faint-hearted swoon.  I am talking, of course,
about the stethescope.  It is a simple device, really, and none of the
three of use could ever have predicted its universal and undeniably
profound effect.  Bringing forth the stethescope was like injecting a
truth serum into the sellers we met.  Suddenly, "perfect" cars became
cars that "dropped a valve a few years ago," or "ran for a few minutes
without oil."  I'm not counting in this assessment the time I tried to
listen to the spark plug wires (the resulting jolt of electricity
perhaps explains a lot about these articles), other than that one time
we had people so impressed we were considering wearing it whenever any
of the aforementioned scantily clad women came into view.  

In this case the stethescope immediately brought forth the confession,
"My mechanic says the carbs need to be rebuilt."  Actually one of the
milder revelations we heard.   Karl noted a few oil leaks, but found
the car to be basically solid.  John, in his examinations of the front
end, did find something disturbing. 

"Karl, kommen hier, bitte," he said.  Karl crawled out from inside one
of the cylinders and joined John in the trunk.  After conferring a
moment, Karl spewed forth some more gibberish in German and motioned
for the owner and me to take a look. 

"Zis car has been hit," said John.  "Look at zis."  He pointed at a
region of the trunk behind the passenger side fender.  "Look at all
zis velding."   

Of course the standard response to such an accusation is, "That
happened before I got the car."    One day I'm going to meet the guy
who gets into all these accidents...  

The repair seemed good enough, however, and the rest of the car and
interior was immaculate, so the next step was to test drive the car.
This was actually my first test drive of the trip, so I tried to keep
calm.  I attempted to explain away my nervous shaking as the result of
a wound suffered when my family was fleeing the Nazis.  In response to
the owners voiced skepticism that I was old enough to have lived in
Nazi Germany, I said,  "Ahhhh, yes, vell, I grew up in Illinois, you
see."  This seemed enough for him and we took off.  I was pretty
impressed, actually, that the guy had even heard of Illinois, most of
the mall children we'd met seemed to think the United States was made
up of California, Mexico, and the "East." 

The car started easily and drove well.  I was still pretty tentative,
and was only foiled twice by the 901 gearbox; luckily there was no one
behind us either time I inadvertanly shifted into reverse.  It was a
little embarrassing, though, since one of those times we were sitting
at a red light revving engines with a Camaro.  When the light changed
to green, the chevy spun its tires in place for about five minutes
while I backed up to the previous intersection.  By the time I made it
back to the intersection, he had worn through to the belts and I
sailed right by.  The really funny part is that as I passed him, I
noted the expression on his face and it was clear he felt he'd "won."
After all, I hadn't spun my tires at all. 

While driving, I noticed something didn't seem quite right: the car
seemed a little "loose" in the front steering, but after Karl test
drove it he seemed to believe that it was just my lack of experience
with driving cars that don't have an engine over the front wheels.
Although in the end it turned out I was right, and there had been
something wrong, Karl's explanation quieted my fears.  After a short
conference with my collaborators, I approached our host. 

"Vell, as ve have pointed out, zere are several prRRr...excuse me, let
me just vipe zat off your face...ahh, zere ve go.  As I vas saying,
zere are several prrRRrroblems vis ze car, and I sink zat ze prRRrice
of seben sousand is too high.  I am villing to offer you six." 

The guy considered for a moment and shook his head.  "No, I'd like to
get a little more than that," he said. 

I nodded.  "Vell, I have your telephone number.  Ve vill look at some
more cars and perhaps I vill call you back.  Sank you."   

Back in our car, I was barely able to contain my excitement as I said
to John, "Did you see his expression? I think he will take 6500.  I
think the car is worth 6500, don't you?"  John and Karl both seemd to
agree.  I made a little note of that in my list.  Things were starting
to look up. 

We visited several more locations that afternoon, and most were
promising, though by and large we were hoping for much better deals. 

Our final appointment took us way off the beaten track.   It was
getting late, around 8PM, which for us was 11, so we were starting to
tire and hunger a bit.  While it was still fairly bright out, the lack
of direct sunlight seemed to cast the world in vague shadows.  We
weren't exactly lost, but Karl had already stopped at four or five
payphones to call for directions.   Somehow our mood had begun to
shift imperceptably, and these factors served to exaggerate our
response when we finally arrived at our destination. 

To begin with, the problem had been that Karl was not a native speaker
of English, the person giving directions likewise, and the breakdown
in communications occured in the one trying to convey to the other
that he was located in the back of a large construction site.  We did
finally figure this out, and as our car bounced slowly along the
truck-compressed gravel road, John and I began to feel a little
nervous.   

I should be clear that John and I had both grown up in New York City,
and were naturally extremely suspicious people.  We were not normally
prone to over-react, however, nor were we ever particularly impressed
or frightened by much.  Still, growing up in such an environment does
breed a certain wariness, a certain ability to detect and avoid
situations that are not quite as they should be.  Driving to the back
of a deserted construction site always sets off all the alarms. 

We approached one of the few completed buildings in sight, and I made
a visual reconnaisance of the area, planning an escape route.   Karl
parked next to what was clearly the car we had come to see, and we
extracted ourselves from our own vehicle.  John and I exchanged
nervous glances.  My ninja-type sixth sense was now fully activated.

One of the doors in the completed building opened, and I swung my gaze
slowly around to regard the person coming out.  My reaction was quick,
despite the fear which consumed my entire being instantly.  Supressing
the urge to panic, I screamed and dived headlong into our car,
reaching for the Uzi I kept stashed under the seat.  

Now you, reading this from the quiet comfort of your home, or office,
or walking down the driveway to throw this magazine in the garbage,
may think that I not only failed to supress the urge to panic, but
that my reaction was a little drastic.  Let me assure you, however,
that first of all if I had panicked I would not have had the presence
of mind to actually open the car door before executing the dive
maneuver, and second of all it is likely you have never come face to
face with Carlos, "the Jackal," famed international assassin and
terrorist.  Carlos is believed to be responsible for the death of
several hundred people, and as my hand groped desperately for the
soothing metal of the machine gun, I realized we were going to be
next.   

Was this, in fact, the destiny I had been so relentlessly driven to
for the past few days? 




=====

Christopher Welty                        Vassar College Computer Science Dept
SIGART Information Director                            Poughkeepsie, NY 12601
weltyc@sigart.acm.org                                    weltyc@cs.vassar.edu

Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 20:36:18 -0400
From: hqb@netcom.com (Henry Bibb)
Subject: 914 trunk hinge adjustments

Dennis Mitsch wrote:


>The main culprit appears to be the passenger side height adjustment.
>The weather stripping just isn't making contact with the lid.  The
>water runs down the edge of the trunk, onto the interior bottom portion,
>and then drips inside.
>
>The height is incorrect (about 1/8") right above the hinge and
>progresses all the way down the entire side.  If it was just the
>far edge, I'd bend the lid a bit.  But since it's off by the hinge,
>it seems like there should be some other sort of adjustment.
>
>Sooo, how is this adjustment made?  The trunk hinge has 3 or 4
>bolts to fiddle with.  The Haynes manual is totally useless (suprise).
>
>To me, it looks like I will need to disconnect the torsion spring.  To
>remove that, Haynes says I have to take off the trunk lid.  This
>would make it rather difficult to adjust the height of the lid. :)
>
>Anyone done this before?

I think you may find the vertical adjustment at that point is profoundly
influenced by the location of that hinge-bolt pivot, and that yours may
have been replaced at some time in the past.  I had one go on mine (the
shouldered bolt siezes, and rips the attachment point off the body), but
I was lucky & found someone who fixed it well.

Be careful if you have to take that torsion spring off - that thing is
under unbelievable tension (at least, I didn't believe it until i took
one off :) ).  The factory books, and maybe the Haynes manuals show a
locally-fabricated tool to get it off.  I remember it was a real bear.

Good luck with it,
Henry Bibb
'74 914 undergoing fix-ups

Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 18:26:24 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: 1973 - Transmission help

It is a lot easier in the long run to take the eng an trans out 
together. It will take less time to take them both out.

Be sure to tag all wires and hoses as you disconnect. It is not 
necessary to disconnect the fuel inujection just take the brain and lay 
it on the eng.

mike

Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 19:49:08 -0700
From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
Subject: RE: Motronic problem

Written 4/27/95......................

Subject: Motronic advice needed
The symptoms:
 - At idle, revs bounce between 800 and 1000 RPM immediately after 
   coming down from normal engine speed abruptly. It does this          
   irregularly
   but most often when the engine is fully warm and the outside temp is
   cool (say 40 degrees). Sounds like: "Rump Rump Rump Rump..."
 - When engine is warm, taking off smoothly from a stop is difficult.   
   It seems to lose a little power right after I engage the clutch.     
   Basically, I get one jerk as I take off.  
 - When the engine is cold  this doesn't happen i.e. takeoffs are       
smooth.
 - It didn't do this before I removed the engine and put it back.
The question:
 - Is this something I can expect to fix or diagnose if I buy the Bosch
   fuel injection book or do I need specialized tools (like an
   oscilloscope  or exhaust gas analyzer) ?
thanks in advance,
   Chris
.......................................

Chris,

Buy the Bosch book, by Probst, it's well worth the $30 (Bently
published). Finished reading the motronics section today.  You don't 
need an exhaust analyzer etc. it just makes things easier.  The must 
haves are a multimeter and potentially a fuel pressure gauge.

Your symptom sounds like a vacuum leak.  I eliminated the same sysmptom 
on a motronic by properly torqueing an intake gasket (+-15 lbs).  The 
cause for occilation at idle is likely the system trying to overcome
an imbalance in the mixture (ie air/fuel).  Recommended to me was 
dropping water in all likely areas and listening for retarded engine 
operation.  Probst recomends propane gas at the hoses/fittings.  
That'll increase RPM if a leak is found.  Hope this helps.

Can I follow with a question for myself?

I recently tormented the list with a "944S idle problem".  The 
suggestions were great, thanks.  The problem is still there, however.

Symptom:
	-occasional stumble while warm.  Goes 950RPM-450RPM-1200RPM and 
	 back to 950 over .5 to 1.0 seconds.  Sometimes 950-stallout.
	 symptom seems to occur out of nowhere.
	-guilty of going 27000mi on one fuel filter.
Done:	-new fuel filter (four tanks ago), clean/test idle stabilizer, 
	 two bottles cheap injector cleanor(techron on the way           
        from NAPA), fuel delivery @1150cc per 30sec, injector wires     
        pulled while running, test was successful, fuel gauge on way.
Anyone seen this one?  Other likely areas ahead of fuel filter where 
crud could have gotten?  Neat injector tests/mode of servicing?  Other 
suggestions appreciated.

Thanks
Chris Woodward
944S

Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 22:56:52 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Matthew A. Dilligan" <diligan@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Re: 89 951 Oil change story

On Sat, 29 Apr 1995, Dave Hagood wrote:

>         Another thing that you might try is muratic acid, which is
> evidently used
> to clean stains from swimming pools.
> 

Careful with this one. This works by physically eating away the concrete 
(or masonry or marble, or whetever). The oil would probably end up 
protectiong the concrete so you would just end up etching away the 
non-stained part. Then you would have contoured as well as colored oil 
marks. This stuff (muriatic acid = hydrochloric acid) will also eat the hell 
out of aluminum, FWIW.

Matt

Porschephiles #1366                         Mon May 1 02:00:10 CDT 1995
Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 23:32:03 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: Salvaged 1991 911 Turbo

Terry wrote, (among other things),

>Another words, the strippers were for some reason very 
>careful in removing the parts so as to not damage the car???

I didn't get to follow this thread in detail because I was out of town
delivering my recently sold (finally) vintage race car. But, I recently heard
an interesting story about 'stripped' stolen/salvaged cars that might shed
light on why the car was so carefully stripped and the engine and trans left
intact by the thiefs... It seems that cars are stolen (not necessarily Pcars)
and stripped of ALL non-serial numbered parts (ie. engine/trans etc are left
in the car).  When the car is recovered, the owners insurance company figures
out that age old fact, the parts cost more than the car... so, they pay off
the owner and sell the car at a salvage auction. The enterprising thiefs then
buy it back at the auction and, having saved ALL the parts, put it back
together and sell it. As usual, all I can think off is, if people would put
this kind of effort and ingenuity into productive/legal activities the
results would be amazing... and, our insurance would cost a lot less!
 Apologies if I'm repeating something that was already posted to Pfiles.
 And, Terry... I hope you get the car and have some fun with it!

Phil VanBuskirk, PMLetter@aol.com

Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 20:34:09 -0700
From: paulm@kestrel.engr.sgi.com (Paul Mielke)
Subject: Re: Several 911 questions

| Date: 28 Apr 1995 16:07:34 -0800
| From: Steve Poole <stevep@wrq.com>
| Subject: Several 911 questions
| 
| I have a couple of questions as a new Porsche owner.
| 
| First, and this crossed my mind because of the stuck cold start injector
| thread, what kind of mileage should I expect from my 1979 911SC? I've only
| gone through one tank of gas and drove moderately aggressively over a mix of
| highway and city miles. I think I got about 14 mpg. Is this reasonable?
| What's the best I can expect if I drive a little more sedately?

Hi, Steve.  I've got an 80 SC that I've had for about a year.  When I
first got the car, I had problems with cold starting.  The engine would
cough and spit and have a hard time catching when cold.  The mechanic
"fixed" this by what I later learned was what we'd call a "cheap hack"
in computer lingo:  he just richened up the mixture a bunch.  This caused
the car to start with no trouble, but caused me to get 15 MPG in pretty
much all driving conditions.  I subsequently got myself a new mechanic
who was able to readjust the fuel injection system so that the car starts
easily and I now get better than 20 MPG in highway driving with no
detectable decrease in performance.  I guess my throttle foot's a bit
lighter than Stan's ;^).

| 
| Second, when I turn the ignition to the On position, something electrical
| begins humming fairly loudly. I believe it persists after the engine has
| started, but it's a little hard to tell because of the engine noise. What is
| this sound?

Other folks have covered the sophisticated stuff.  Another possibility
is your electic antenna motor.  When I first got my car, the antenna was stuck.
You could hear the motor whirring for 30 seconds or so when you first turned
on the radio.  This sound is easy to distinguish:  it comes from the
direction of the antenna and it stops after a fixed period of time, even
if the antenna doesn't actually extend.

Cheers,



Paul Mielke (paulm@sgi.com)
Silicon Graphics, Inc.

Date: Mon, 1 May 1995 01:04:32 -0400
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Re: Applying Carnuba Wax

Scott Kelly asked the proper way to apply carnauba wax.

One of the keys to applying carnauba waxes is to apply it sparingly.
 Assuming that the finish has just been washed and dried and is free of grit
and does not need glazing,  then apply the wax with a small piece of 100%
cotton terry cloth or a terry cloth covered sponge applicator pad.  An even
better method of application is to use your fingers.  Hold your fingers
together to form an "applicator".  Rub the wax thoroughly into the surface.
 Your fingers will give you the tactile feedback to let you know when the wax
has been worked into the surface.  This is NOT a situation where a little is
good, so a lot must be better.  Your paint will only accept X amount of wax.
 If you apply 100 times X then you will have to remove 99X in the form of
dried powder.  It will make waxing more difficult, require more buffing and
create clouds of white dust.  

Make sure the paint surface is cool.  Rule of thumb, if you can hold your
hand comfortably on the paint, then it is cool enough to wax.  Work in the
shade, preferably in a garage.  To apply the wax, choose an area about 12" x
12".  Open your can of wax, get a small amount on your fingers (or cloth/pad)
and recover the can (this keeps dirt out of the can).  Apply to the paint
surface, rubbing in a linear motion.  Work into the paint in a front-to-back,
back-to-front motion (the way the air flows over the car).  Don't go around in
 circles the way dear old dad taught you.  If you are using a pad and
airborne grit gets under the pad, you have made sandpaper. If you are working
in a circle, you have made a 360 degree scratch (or swirl mark).  Since a scra
tch or swirl mark is most visible from a 90 degree viewing angle, a circular
scratch is visible anywhere.  If you work in a linear motion, and scratch the
surface, the line scratch is only visible from a small viewing angle.  Using
only your fingers to apply wax will give you the tactile feedback to know
when surface grit is about to scratch your paint.  

Work the small amount of wax into the surface until all that remains is
slight haze.  Use of your fingers will also tell you when the wax has been
thoroughly worked into the paint and will help prevent you from using too
much wax.  Most waxes work best when this slight haze is allowed to dry.
 There are some waxes that require you to buff immediately after applying.
 Zymol is a classic example of this type of wax.  If you allow Zymol to dry
before buffing, you will need a belt sander to remove it.   Read the
directions on the can to determine the proper method.  Buff out the slight
haze with a soft 100% cotton towel.  Buff this small section, shake out the
towel to remove any grit and rebuff with a new section of towel.  Keep using
new sections of towel and change towels frequently.   I use my wife's old
flannel sheets.  They are super soft and produce a brilliant shine.  Move
onto another 12" x 12" section of the car.  Repeat the application and
buffing procedures.  When the car had been completed, return to the first
section completed and rebuff with
another clean towel, continue to rebuff the entire car.  The wax has had time
to harden off and this extra buffing will bring out a deep shine.  If there
are areas that are hazy or cloudy, and you are using a carnuaba based wax,
the wax has become hydroscopic and has absorbed a little water.  Mist the
cloudy areas with a small amount of water (a plant mister works well) and
rebuff.  This should remove the clouding. 

If you are using a polymer based wax on a German paint and have hazy or
clouding of the wax, about the only thing that will work is to strip  the
polymer wax and rewax with a carnauba based wax.  German paints hate polymer
based waxes.  I have spoken to paint chemists, the Glazurit people, Porsche,
BMW and M/B people and to date have not gotten a viable reason for this.  I
have gotten a lot of mumbling and shuffling of feet, but no hard and fast
answers.  The Amercian and Japanese paints LOVE polymer waxes.  The German
paints just don't react well with most of these products.

Another trick to buff out any cloudy areas is to mist the area with Meguiar
#34 Final Inspection and buff out.  This will usually remove all traces of
trapped water.

All towels you use on your Porsche should be 100% cotton and should be washed
in the washing machine using only detergent.  Do not add any fabric softner
to the water.  Dry them in the dryer and DO NOT use a dryer anti-static towel
(I think that's what they are called). These dryer towels contain coatings tha
t are transferred to your car towels and may cause streaks.  If you have ever
had your wax streak and you could not figure out why, your dryer towel was
probably the culprit.  You will remove a giant ball of towel and static
electricity from your dryer, but will not have mysterious streaks.

Some people use a power buffer on their paint.  I personally think that your
Porsche deserves to be caressed by hand.  Save the machine for your SO or Yugo
.   Use of a machine is a learned art and not a science.  It is very easy to
"burn" an edge or create swirl marks.  There is nothing that a person with
the proper chemicals and elbow grease can not do better than a machine.  The
only advantage of a machine is speed and the risks in my humble opinion far
outweigh any time advantage.     

If anyone has any further questions on types of waxes, glazes, polishes or
application, please feel free to contact me.  

Thank you,
